DOC.HEADLINE: QIAN QICHEN DUBIOUS OF NEW US-JAPAN DEFENSE GUIDELINES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Lai Sheng-chuan & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen was highly skeptical of Tokyo's explanations of the content of the newly published US-Japan guidelines for defense cooperation when he met Monday in Beijing with representatives of Japan's press.
Qian also said the time is not ripe yet for a trilateral official dialogue among Washington, Beijing and Tokyo on defense, adding that "scholarly discussion" would be appropriate at the present.

Qian's remarks indicate that despite explanations of the new guidelines by Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi, Beijing is still very worried about whether Taiwan falls within the sphere of the bilateral defense agreement.
According to reports in the Japanese media, among Qian's concerns are:
-- If the defense pact is a matter between Washington and Tokyo, it should be unnecessary to renew it, hence putting its content into doubt.
-- Although the new guidelines do not specifically mention geographic criteria, there is still speculation that they cover Taiwan.
-- Some have argued for raising the transparency of the bilateral agreement, while others advocate keeping it ambiguous and opaque.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM CALLS FOR EARLY CONCLUSION OF ROC-US WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei on Wednesday appealed for an early conclusion of trade consultations between the United States and the Republic of China on terms for Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

AmCham President Jeffrey R. Williams told a news conference that all AmCham members hope bilateral ROC-US WTO talks will be concluded as soon as possible to facilitate Taiwan's entry to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

According to Williams, most American business people with interests in Taiwan are convinced that they will benefit from Taiwan's WTO accession because Taiwan would be required to further open its market and better protect intellectual property rights.

Williams, who just returned from a "doorknocking" visit to Washington, D.C. at the head of a 12-member AmCham delegation, said the US executive branch agreed with AmCham that Taiwan's WTO accession should not be linked to mainland China's membership application.

"We agree that Taiwan's WTO entry should be considered completely on the basis of its own economic conditions," Williams said, adding that Taiwan is likely to conclude WTO-related trade consultations with the United States before the end of bilateral WTO talks between Washington and Beijing.

During its stay in the United States, the AmCham delegation met with many Clinton administration officials and Congress members to exchange views on ways to help American corporations upgrade their overseas competitiveness.

Williams said the AmCham mission had urged various US federal agencies to allow their senior officials to make frequent visits to Taiwan to help boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation for mutual benefits.

Even though the Clinton administration was busy preparing for mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's planned visit to the United States late this month, Williams said, many federal government officials still showed keen interest in listening to AmCham's suggestions and opinions about reinforcing Taipei-Washington trade and economic ties.

As to the AmCham 1997-98 Taiwan White Paper, which he formally unveiled at a news conference held in Washington, D.C. last Thursday, Williams said the annual report mainly analyzed Taiwan's current economic and investment climate as a reference for American companies intending to invest in Taiwan, adding that the White Paper was not aimed at criticizing any party.

The White Paper said Taiwan's restrictions on trade and investment across the Taiwan Strait have not only hindered the development of its own industries but have also discouraged multinational business groups from setting up a foothold on the island. It further claimed that the ROC government's master plan to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific operations center would remain a pipe dream if Taiwan companies are not allowed to enter the vast mainland market directly and obtain access to its resources.

Williams said AmCham's analysis was made purely from a commercial viewpoint, adding that AmCham members believe Taiwan must establish direct communications and transport links with mainland China so that Taiwan-based companies can make successful inroads into the world's largest market.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN TO BUILD WORLD'S 3RD LARGEST CONTAINER PORT IN ITALY
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By H.T. Chung & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Evergreen's green-colored ships and green matchbox-like containers are the hope of the port of Gioia Tauro in southern Italy.

Taiwan-based Evergreen Marine Corp., which operates one of the largest container fleets in the world, is wagering on Gioia Tauro, a newly-developed and non-urban port area, attempting to build it into the third largest container port in the world.
Evergreen is also targeting Gioia Tauro as a gateway to all Mediterranean-rim states and the Black Sea to the north, said a company spokesman.

The Italian government has put up nearly US$180 million since 1975 to develop the quiet backwater fishing port into a commercial harbor. With most parts of the development already finished, the harbor accommodated some 1,270 ships in the first six months of this year. The harbor bureau there estimated that its transshipment capacity may reach 1.4 million TEUs this year.

Although the port is fully operational, its peripheral facilities are still in dire need of help, Aldo Alessio, mayor of Gioia Tauro, lamented. He noted that many support works have been left unfinished due to budget constraints, with highways in the vicinity only four meters wide and the nearby hinterland remaining undeveloped and blanketed by weeds.

Taipei's representative office in Rome, which has generally been reluctant to beckon Taiwan investors to Italy for fear that the European country's labor union clout and chronically inefficient bureaucracy may hinder their development, has championed Evergreen's container port project in Gioia Tauro.

Joe Hung, Taipei representative in Italy, said Evergreen made the right decision by choosing Gioia Tauro. As long as there is no major strike problem, chances for the project's success are great, he said, noting that the port of Gioia Tauro is strategically positioned and has the full support of the Italian government.

While Evergreen's arrival in Gioia Tauro brings hope to people in southern Italy, the move also stimulates Taiwan investors to look toward Italy, enabling them to have other choices beyond mainland China, Southeast Asia and Latin America, Hung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENTITLED TO EQUAL APEC REPRESENTATION: P.K. CHIANG

TEXT.P: Taiwan should be treated the same as all 17 other members in meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum even if the gatherings are held in Beijing, Taipei's arch rival, said P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), on Wednesday.

Chiang made the remarks in an interpellation session before the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs Committee, during which Legislator Yen Chin-fu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party asked him what Taiwan would do if Beijing sponsors the 2001 APEC meeting and demands that Taiwan take part in the gathering as a local economic entity of the People's Republic of China.
Chiang said it is still too early to speculate on who will host the 2001 APEC meeting.

Taiwan, a full APEC member, has taken part in all eight APEC ministerial-level meetings in the past as a sovereign economic entity with a status equal to that of every other APEC member, Chiang said. "Things didn't change in the past and they won't change in the future," he said.
No matter who sponsors the 2001 gathering, no APEC member should violate the principles of the organization's establishment, which champion equality and cooperation, Chiang noted.

Chiang, who led the Chinese Taipei delegation to the 1996 APEC annual meeting held in the Philippines, recalled that mainland Chinese Vice Premier and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen spoke at a joint press conference then to downgrade Taiwan's legitimate status at the organization.
Chiang said he rebuked Qian for the remarks and reiterated that Taiwan's APEC status is both legitimate and unchangeable.
Chiang said his speech received wide support from many other member countries.

APEC groups 18 economies: Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, mainland China, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6.7 PERCENT GROWTH IN 1997 FEASIBLE, SAYS TOP PLANNER

TEXT.P: With this being a year of economic recovery, 6.7 percent annual economic growth in 1997 is feasible, Taiwan's top economic planner said on Wednesday.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that with growth in the second half of the year forecast to reach 6.56 percent, annual growth should top 6.58 percent in 1997, which would be the seventh highest in the world and a five-year high in Taiwan.
Chiang gave the figures in a report on national economic prospects before the Legislative Economic Affairs Committee.
To accelerate the pace of the recovery, he said, the government will continue promoting public construction projects as well as stimulating private investment.

In addition, Chiang underlined several other factors fueling the domestic economy, including the commencement of private-run power plants and intelligent industrial parks islandwide, the level of private investment in high-tech industries remaining high, and export businesses continuing to pick up steam.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTIMATED 200,000 TAIWAN RESIDENTS TAKING ILLEGAL DRUGS

TEXT.P: At least 5,000 people are arrested every month islandwide for taking illegal drugs, according to the Department of Health (DOH).

Li Chih-heng, head of the DOH's Narcotics Bureau, warned on Tuesday that half of those arrested are repeat offenders, indicating that current anti-drug efforts haven't been able to reduce the number of drug users in Taiwan.

Based on the previous figures, the DOH estimates that Taiwan has over 200,000 residents who take illegal drugs, or about 1 percent of the island's population, Li said at an anti-drug conference in Taipei.
Noting that smoking cigarettes and chewing betel nuts often precedes illegal drug use, Li said that an important step to keep away from drugs is to "say no to smoking."
Betel nuts, or "Chinese chewing gum" as they are sometimes called in Taiwan, are chewed for their stimulant effect and are addictive. Chewing betel nuts can lead to oral cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT SPRING IS GOOD TIME FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: KOO

TEXT.P: Next spring would be a good time for the resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait which was suspended by Beijing following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995, Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said on Wednesday.

The time for the resumption of cross-strait negotiation is "almost near, while the two sides are patiently creating a favorable climate" for dialogue to take place, Koo told reporters, revealing that mainland China has shown willingness to talk.

He also said that he believes there is no need for Taiwan and mainland China to set up a new channel for future negotiations, stressing that they should still be conducted by the two existing intermediary bodies -- the SEF and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- both semi-official organizations set up to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official relations.

Questioned on possible topics for future talks, Koo said that at the moment, there should be no problem for the two sides to hold talks on practical and economic issues. However, engagement in political negotiations will require the support of public opinion, he added.
Mainland Vice Premier and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen recently has commented that the two sides should open political dialogue as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, Koo revealed that a key meeting of the National Unification Council is expected to be held following a US visit by mainland President Jiang Zemin later this month. He said President Lee is expected to deliver an important speech to the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOSPITAL PERFORMS 100TH HEART TRANSPLANT

TEXT.P: A medical team at the Chenghsin Medical Center (CMC) in suburban Taipei successfully performed its 100th heart transplant operation on Wednesday, nine years after the hospital pioneered this type of surgery in Taiwan.

A hospital spokesman said the patient, identified only by his surname of Pai, had suffered from an enlarged heart for five years. He was transferred to Chenghsin from another local hospital in August to receive a transplant. The medical center obtained a donated heart on Tuesday and completed the transplant operation early Wednesday morning.
"The patient is now recuperating in an intensive care ward, where his condition is stable," CMC President Wei Cheng said.

According to Wei, 85 of the 100 people who have received new hearts at the CMC over the past nine years are still alive, while the center has a one-year survival rate of 94 percent and a three-year survival rate of 84 percent, the highest in Asia and even higher than the world average one-year survival rate of 82 percent, Wei added.
The oldest recipient was 75 at the time of his operation and the youngest was only 15, Wei said, adding that the oldest surviving patient is now 67 years old.

The CMC is also the only local hospital which has used an artificial heart to help a patient survive the waiting time for a donor heart for permanent transplant, Wei said, pointing out that some patients died die before a suitable donor organ became available.
The CMC held a cocktail reception on Wednesday to celebrate its 100th heart transplant, which was attended by many of the surviving transplant recipients.
Addressing the occasion, Wei called on local residents to support the organ donation drive to give new leases of life to people with serious illnesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA SAID TO MAINTAIN DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Panama's foreign minister said here Tuesday that as his country is assuming control of the Panama Canal, it would try to maintain close relations with all users of the canal, including mainland China, but "that should not, in any way, affect or would affect the good friendship and diplomatic relationship we maintain with the Republic of China on Taiwan."
Ricardo Alberto Arias made the remarks to reporters after paying a call on Jason Hu, Taipei's representative to the United States.

Arias failed to speak in support of Taipei's membership in the United Nations when he addressed the UN General Assembly last Friday. The ROC now maintains diplomatic ties with only 30 countries, and whether a country is willing to speak on behalf of its UN bid is frequently taken as an indication of how solid the relationship is.

Arias' failure to voice public support for Taipei's UN membership struck an especially sensitive cord in Taiwan because his speech came on the heels of a meeting with Beijing's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. Taipei, still basking in the afterglow of President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Panama earlier this month for an international meeting on the canal, was caught off guard.

Arias said he did not discuss Taiwan with Qian, adding that they talked only about the canal's reversion to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999, the need for establishing and maintaining lines of communication between their two governments given the importance of the canal issue to both, and Panama's commercial office in Hong Kong, which had been a consulate but shed its official status following the former British colony's reversion to Beijing's rule on July 1.
The foreign minister also denied knowledge of any plan for Qian to visit Panama later this year as reported in the press, saying that Qian did not mention anything about a visit to Panama.

Asked why he decided not to mention Taiwan in his speech, Arias said that Panama is assuming control of the canal and, therefore, must refrain from taking positions on issues of international conflicts in accordance with a 1978 treaty with the United States that guarantees the neutrality of the canal after its transfer.

In addition, he said, a major debate at the current UN General Assembly session is about amendments to the UN Charter that would limit the availability of assistance to developing countries, and it was important for Panama, which will host the next secretariat of the Rio Group, a Latin American grouping, to address that issue.

He said that his speech was devoted mostly to the amendments issue with a brief mention of the canal at the end. The Taiwan issue would not fit into the speech as it did not address any other international matters that are being considered by the world body, such as the issue of land mines or Cyprus, he argued.
He said that Panama has always spoken at the United Nations and different forums in support of universal UN participation, and this position remains unchanged.

Arias, a former ambassador to the United States, first met Hu when they served together in Washington last year. Coincidentally, Hu has also been appointed foreign minister and is expected to assume his new duties in Taipei next month.
The outgoing Taipei representative said he appreciates the goodwill and sincerity shown by the Panamanian foreign minister but that he cannot fully agree with Arias' course of action.

Hu said he is neither optimistic nor pessimistic about the future of diplomatic ties between their two countries. "What is important," he added, "is to do all we can to further promote the bilateral relationship."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices ended lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 13.81 points to finish at 8,695.02.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,737.08 and experienced a low of 8,625.84.
Losers outnumbered gainers 304 to 113, with 45 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.97 billion (US$3.29 billion).

Paper and pulp shares dropped the most at 2.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.9 percent, construction stocks at 1.6 percent, plastic and chemical issues at 1.4 percent, and financial and cement textile stocks at 1.1 percent, respectively.
Electrical engineering stocks rose 1.7 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronic International, ACER, Liton Electronic, A.S.E., Winbond Electronics, Microtek International, and Mitac International.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE ADDRESSES OVERSEAS CHINESE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: October 10, the National Day of the Republic of China, otherwise known as "double-ten day" is fast-approaching.

In a written speech released by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle prior to the ROC double-ten national holiday, President Lee Teng-hui addressed all overseas Chinese, saying that "it is our persistent goal to pursue the unification of China under the system of freedom, democracy and prosperity; and that the ROC's survival and development is the only way to implement this historic mission."

"On that premise, we will encourage interaction and cooperation between the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait in order to open up a new era of co-existence and prosperity for the benefit of both sides," Lee said in his address.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC MINISTER UNVEILS SIX MAJOR POLICY DIRECTIONS

TEXT.P: ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Tuesday unveiled six major policy directions to allow Taiwan's economy to achieve better performance.
Wang outlined the new policies at a morning presentation delivered to the ruling Kuomintang's policy-making Central Standing Committee meeting in Taipei.
His report, entitled "Building A Competitive Advantage: Heading towards Development of An Economic Peak," listed six major goals of the government.

These goals include creating a favorable investment environment, improving basic infrastructure, developing technology-oriented industries, strengthening and expanding the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), strengthening the competitiveness of exports and expanding international cooperation.

Wang said measures to achieve the goals were urgently needed to ensure that the country can retain its economic clout and that the island's enterprises maintain their competitiveness amid growing global competition.

In the same report, Wang said that over the past few years, Taiwan's economy has clearly emerged from the doldrums of recession to take the lead among the four "Asian Dragon" countries in terms of economic growth.
Confidence among Taiwan's industrial executives has largely been restored and private investment has vastly increased, providing a driving force behind Taiwan's future economic growth, Wang added.

He predicted that the country's annual economic growth rate will exceed 6.58 percent by the end of the year, based on stable growth, increased private investment and more active commercial and industrial sectors.
If such growth can be achieved, Taiwan will rank seventh in the world in terms of economic growth, its highest position since 1992, Wang said.

However, despite his optimistic forecast, the minister warned domestic industries that they will need to overcome many internal and external environmental challenges in order to achieve a metamorphosis that will enable them to face up to global competition.
A highly efficient investment mechanism, a better investment environment and a high level of investment standards will have to be provided as part of this process.

Wang described the achieving of an overall boost in production competitiveness as an "important mission" in reforming the country's economic system, adding that significant results will still depend upon an increase in corporate investment, economic growth and technological progress.

He gave an assurance that his ministry will also work to help industries create breakthroughs in production, innovations, actively counsel SMEs to help them upgrade their production bases, encourage firms to actively jump into international markets and capitalize on Taiwan's economic strength to revitalize the global market.
Wang said the new policy directions have been designed to meet current domestic and international economic trends so that Taiwan's economy can reach a new peak in performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISES

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.005 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$28.602.
The greenback opened at the day's high of 28.602 and had a low of 28.595, Interbank US dollar trading reached US$186 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL GIVEN ULTIMATUM TO PAY HIGHER INTEREST RATE FOR LEASED PLANES

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsay Jaw-yang delivered an ultimatum to China Airlines (CAL) on Wednesday that if it refuses to pay new interest rates for planes leased by the company, the government will terminate its contract with the former national carrier.
Tsay's ultimatum came during a report to the Legislative Yuan.

In order to address a trade imbalance with the United States ten years ago, the government purchased 10 long-haul planes, including five 747-400s, one 747-200 and four MD-11s, subsequently leasing them to CAL.

CAL later bought three of the planes from the government, but continues to rent the remaining seven, which are registered by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) as being worth a total of NT$21.45 billion (US$747.38 million). The interest rate was listed at 3 percent, subject to review every three years during the 19-and-a-half year lease.

The current rate was supposed to be 5.4375 percent until its expiration on Oct. 22, 1998, but legislators in a previous session of the legislature earlier this year decided to adjust the rate upwards to 7.2 percent, starting from Oct. 4.

The CAA is now asking CAL to pay the new rate or risk termination of the lease contract. Sources said that if CAL contests the new rate, the CAA will turn the issue over to arbitration or solve it through legal means.

CAL said that the old rate should remain until the 1998 expiration date, adding that the government should not adjust the rate unilaterally. CAL also cited its good credit record, which should entitle it to a low interest rate, so that it need not pay the full 7.2 percent.
Moreover, CAL complained that the only reason it leased the planes in the first place was because it was following government policy at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN POLITICAL SCENE ENTERS PERIOD OF TURBULENCE

TEXT.P: The Australian political scene is entering a period of turbulence as the ruling coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard is taking a tit-for-tat approach to the opposition, which has so far brought down three ministers and three prime ministerial office staff over a travel expenses scandal, analysts said.

Opposition Labor Party leader Kim Beazley, who was one of the politicians who disclosed the scandal last week, will be drawn into a travel expense scandal of his own on Wednesday over the involvement of one of his personal staffers in a rental car scandal.

Analysts said this is the beginning of a tit-for-tat battle being waged by the Howard government to get even with the opposition, which has successfully forced Howard to sack three ministers and three of his personal staff.
But they said Beazley will also have new ammunition to fire at Veterans Affairs Minister Bruce Scott over his use of a taxpayer-funded plane to visit friends four times in a single year.
The two new issues guarantee that the so-called "travelgate" scandal will continue to dominate the Australian parliament.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock, who disclosed the false car rental claims of Beazley's staffer, forced all MPs to stop and think about where they are heading on the expenses scandal.
Their actions are only serving to increase the already considerable cynicism in the electorate towards all politicians in Australia, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OFFERS SECURITY AID FOR CAMBODIAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Australia is offering to provide security personnel to monitor Cambodia's national elections next May in the wake of the country's coup and subsequent political unrest.
The Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday reported Foreign Minister Alexander Downer's plans to raise the security issue at a meeting in New York with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.

Because neither the Cambodian government nor the United Nations is keen on the type of major UN operation conducted in the lead-up to Cambodia's elections in 1993, Australia has floated an alternative.

The daily said it would be a far more modest exercise, bringing together a coalition of countries which could include representatives from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations as well as Australia, Japan and the United States.
The Cambodian government is highly sensitive to any foreign involvement that could be seen as interference in its internal affairs, the daily reported.

The paper quoted sources as saying that the possibility of coaxing Hun Sen into accepting an outside security role in the elections was discussed the previous day at a meeting in New York convened by the foreign ministers of Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia.
"My concern is that all those who wish to participate in the elections can participate in a fair, appropriate and democratic way...," Downer said.
The paper said Australia is also offering to provide various logistical equipment and personnel, including ballot boxes and officials to help prepare electoral rolls.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING TYCOON PUBLISHES MEMOIRS TO MARK 70TH BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: The memoirs of Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa hit bookstores on Wednesday to mark the shipping tycoon's 70th birthday on Oct. 6.

In a preface to his autobiography, Chang mentions that many people tend to describe him as a "mysterious" person. "In fact, I'm not a bit mysterious, although I do adopt a low-profile way of life and seldom provide my personal data to the outside world," the self-made shipping baron noted.
Chang said he has spent nearly 10 years preparing for the publication of his memoirs because he wants to give the reading public an honest, unexaggerated account of his life's journey.

His memoirs recount his family background, school years, the start of his career and the establishment of Evergreen Marine Corp., which currently operates the world's largest container shipping fleet.

Chang said he hopes the story of his struggle from scratch to achieve fame in the shipping world will provide some inspiration to today's youth who are striving to build up their own careers or business ventures.

Chang's first venture -- Evergreen Marine Corp. -- was launched in 1968 and has since managed to expand into a number of lines of business. Today, the Evergreen Group has emerged as a multinational business conglomerate with interests in many different areas.

In addition to shipping services, the group also controls EVA Airways, the first completely private Taiwan airline to operate international flights, and a variety of companies in manufacturing, construction, financial services and other industries.

"Although some people describe Evergreen's development from an obscure firm to one of the world's largest shipping corporations in a rather short period of time as a `miracle,' I fully understand that there is not a bit of `luck' in its success," Chang wrote. "Evergreen's success lies in the wholehearted devotion of me and my colleagues. Other people can never understand how much time, sweat, blood and money we have contributed to our ventures."

Chang recounted the way other shipping companies had tried to boycott Evergreen when it opened its new shipping routes, as well as the many stumbling blocks which he had to overcome in his struggle to establish EVA Airways.

Chang depicts himself as a "son of the sea." Born and raised in Suao, a small fishing port on Taiwan's northeastern coast, he then lived in the northern Taiwan port city of Keelung for 40 years. His father and elder brothers were all engaged in the marine transport business and he himself started work in a shipping company while still in high school. He later qualified as a navigation technician and began his own shipping company after serving as a sailor for 15 years.

Chang said he has always maintained his belief in the goodness of humanity, adding that a thankful heart and a willingness to repay dues are the most important assets to allow one to lead a happy and meaningful life.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRESSION MAY CONTRIBUTE TO NICOTINE WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS

TEXT.P: Though it generally is true that giving up smoking is more difficult for those who smoke more cigarettes or have smoked longer, investigators at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis have found that psychiatric illnesses also may contribute to severe withdrawal symptoms, making it even harder for those smokers to stop.
The investigators questioned more than 550 women to learn their smoking histories, determine their history of nicotine dependence and catalogue their nicotine withdrawal symptoms.
This study was reported in a recent issue of the journal Addition.

"I was interested in whether there were different profiles of nicotine withdrawal symptoms, and if so, whether certain combinations of symptoms might be more likely to occur in smokers with a history of psychiatric disorder," said Pamela Madden, Ph.D., research instructor of psychiatry at Washington University, who co-headed the study. "The literature suggests an association between nicotine dependence, nicotine withdrawal and a history of major depression -- a psychiatric disorder that is more prevalent in women."

Madden found that most women in the study experienced one of three levels of nicotine withdrawal: mild, moderate or severe. About 41 percent of smokers suffered mild withdrawal from nicotine, with most experiencing only a few symptoms. Another 36 percent were rated as having moderate withdrawal symptoms. The severe group included about 18 percent of smokers in the study.

Madden plans further analysis of this data to look more closely at genetic and personality factor involved in nicotine withdrawal. All women surveyed in the study were twins, so she hopes to look at whether symptoms of nicotine withdrawal and other indicators of nicotine dependence run in families. Ultimately, she'd like to use data from the women in her studies and compare them to men to learn about gender differences and their impact on nicotine dependence and withdrawal.

DOC.HEADLINE: SILICON VALLEY BECOMES NO. 1 US EXPORTER

TEXT.P: High-tech products again showed their increasing strength in the US economy, as San Jose, the capital of Silicon Valley, became the top exporter of US products in 1996.

According to a Commerce Department study, San Jose exported US$29.3 billion worth of goods in 1996, overcoming New York's US$28 billion and Detroit's US$27.5 billion. Detroit enjoyed the top spot in 1994 and 1995.

The figures underscore Silicon Valley's crucial role in vast global trading networks. Many local companies, including giants such as Hewlett-Packard and Intel, record more than half their sales overseas.

The Commerce Department statistics include only manufactured goods. They don't include products such as software, which is still classified as service. If included, software exports would undoubtedly add billions more to the region's export totals.
San Jose, with a population of only 875,000 and the third largest city in California, has steadily increased its dominance of US exports. In 1994, San Jose ranked fifth in exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY 1998 ELECTIONS MAY MARK END OF 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' FOR HK

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Times said Tuesday that Beijing continues to make good on its promise to eliminate democratic measures that the British instituted in Hong Kong in 1995, and that the May 1998 election of the Hong Kong legislature may mark the end of the touted "one country, two systems" policy.

In an editorial on Tuesday, the daily noted, "Members of Hong Kong's new provisional legislature, all appointed with Beijing's blessing, have approved plans to sharply cut back the number of eligible voters in the first election under Chinese rule, set for next May."
It called the rollback "expected but nevertheless disappointing."

"In the 1995 election, under British rule, 2.7 million residents were able to vote. According to the new rules, Hong Kong will use a complex proportional representation system to prevent any one party from dominating the 60-seat legislature. Under Beijing's scheme, 20 seats will be filled at large by all voters and 30 seats will go to business representatives elected by a smaller number, 180,000 people. The remaining 10 seats will be filled by an 800-member electoral committee of pro-Beijing and business interests," the daily noted.

"The new electoral rules make clear that Beijing intends to make its influence felt in the legislature, both in numbers and policies. None of the changes offer fresh air for democracy. The May elections will be watched closely, for they may mark the end of the touted 'one China, two system' policy," the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INITIAL INVESTIGATION SHOWS HUMAN ERROR TO BLAME FOR F-5 CRASH

TEXT.P: A high-ranking air force official said on Wednesday that a preliminary investigation showed that human error might to be blame for the crash of two F-5 series jet fighters on Tuesday.

"The pilots are believed to have misjudged the altitude at which they were flying before their jets crashed into a mountainside in the eastern county of Hualien," Hsu Chai-chung, chief-of-staff of the Air Force Headquarters, said at the Legislative Yuan while answering questions from lawmakers.

His statement excluded the possibility that the F-5E and the twin-seater F-5F might have collided with each other during a flight back to their air base in Hualien following a routine training mission.

Hsu said the investigation has found that the two military fighters maintained the required distance while flying side-by-side and that judging from the way the treetops had been sheared off at the crash site, the pilots might have made deadly errors in judging altitude in conditions of poor visibility.

Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said that earlier remarks made by him on Tuesday that the two jets had collided was based on initial investigation results, adding that "the real cause of the accident is still under investigation."

Legislator Wang Tien-ching of ruling Kuomintang commented that the air force has a rather high accident rate, proven by the fact that eight military planes have crashed since November 1995, claiming the lives of 13 air force personnel.
Chiang demurred, however, indicating that the ROC air force accident rate of 2,8 cases per 100,000 flying hours compared favorably with the US's 6.5 cases and France's 6.2 cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEINBERGER URGES WASHINGTON TO REJECT "ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS"
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Jane-jane Huang and Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger has urged Washington to reject Beijing's proposal to apply its "one country, two systems" unification model toward Taiwan.

Weinberger, whose views were published in an opinion column appearing in the latest edition of Forbes magazine, said Washington should not fall into what he called a Communist Chinese trap by sanctioning Beijing's plans to engineer Taiwan's unification with the mainland under the "one country, two systems" formula.
The scheme was devised by former mainland Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping and provided the framework for Hong Kong's transition after the former British colony's July 1997 handover to Beijing.

Under the policy, Hong Kong is allowed to retain its free-market economy and capitalist lifestyle for 50 years and is promised a "high degree of autonomy" with minimum interference from the socialist mainland.
Since the handover, Beijing has launched a propaganda campaign aimed at seeking Taiwan's consent to unify with the mainland under the same system.
However, in his commentary, Weinberger said Taiwan's situation was completely different from that of Hong Kong.

He said the 21 million people on Taiwan not only had selected their head of state in direct, democratic elections, but also had complete freedom of choice in their form of government and had long enjoyed freedoms of speech and religion.
As a fully democratic country, Taiwan has absolutely nothing in common with the communist regime, he said.

Weinberger noted that Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive of the newly established "Special Administrative Region" of Hong Kong, had repeatedly asserted during his recent visit to the United States that Hong Kong's economy has continued to grow since the handover and that he had painted a rosy picture of the territory under Communist Chinese rule.

Tung also said that as long as the American government is confident in the success of the "one country, two systems" framework in Hong Kong, Taiwan would have no reason to continue resisting unification under the same formula.

Weinberger, who oversaw US defense policy in the administration of former President Ronald Reagan, said Beijing's unrelenting pressure on the issue had clearly won a degree of support within President Bill Clinton's administration.

He expressed concern that Clinton might be swayed by these opinions in the hope of improving relations with Beijing or for similar reasons, warning that this could result in a major mistake that would be hard to reverse.

Weinberger said Washington's relations with Taipei are defined by the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, under which the United States is committed to provide Taiwan with adequate defensive weapons and services needed to maintain the island's self-defense capability.
It also seeks to ensure that only peaceful means will be used in deciding Taiwan's future.
Weinberger said the United States must be highly concerned over any potential threats to the stability of the Western Pacific region.

Weinberger, who has visited Taiwan several times since stepping down as defense secretary, also discussed Washington's dispatch of two aircraft carrier groups to the Taiwan area in March 1996, when Beijing conducted a series of menacing military exercises and missile tests in waters off the island's coast.
He said that if America had failed to take such action, Communist China would have interpreted it as a sign that Washington had conceded to Beijing's effective sovereignty over Taiwan.
This in turn could have prompted a bloody war between America and Communist China, he said.

He said that World War II had erupted primarily because Nazi Germany's dictator Adolf Hitler thought no country would stand up to his aggression. And the Korean War had broken out in part because then US Secretary of State Dean Acheson had stated in a policy speech that the Korean Peninsula was outside the American defense perimeter, which indirectly encouraged North Korea to launch an attack on the South. Weinberger warned Americans not to tolerate aggressive actions against Taiwan by simply thinking that "Taiwan is just another Hong Kong."
If Communist China is made aware of America's resolve to prevent threats to Taiwan's security, the island will be less likely to fall victim to a military attack from the mainland, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE PANEL FAVORS THEATER MISSLE DEFENSE SYSTEM FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives approved on Tuesday a bill that would require the secretary of defense to report to Congress on how the United States would help Taiwan develop a theater ballistic missile defense system against missile attacks from mainland China.

The bill, approved by a voice vote, says that no later than July 1, 1998, the secretary of defense shall submit a report to Congress to describe how the United States would provide Taiwan with an advanced missile defense system.

The bill also expresses the sense of Congress that the US president, if requested by the Taipei government, should transfer appropriate defense articles to Taiwan for the purpose of establishing a local-area ballistic missile defense system to protect Taiwan, the Penghu Islands, and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

"The Congress declares that it is in the national interest of the United States that Taiwan be included in any effort at ballistic missile defense cooperation, networking, or interoperability with friendly and allied nations in the Asia-Pacific region," it says.

Prior to passing the measure, the committee adopted an amendment introduced by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), adding a new provision in the bill. The provision expresses the sense of Congress that the president should state openly that the American people have a "firm commitment" to the security and democracy of the people of Taiwan. He should also reiterate that issues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be resolved by peaceful means.

The committee also adopted a motion by Rep. Donald Manzullo (R-Ill.) to delete a provision that would amend the Taiwan Relations Act. The provision called for a new subsection in Section 3 of the Taiwan Relations Act, stating that the subsections (a) and (b) regarding US arms sales to Taiwan "supersede" any contrary provision of the Aug. 17, 1982, joint communique between Washington and Beijing.

Testifying at the markup meeting, Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, insisted that the Taiwan Relations Act and the three joint communiques between the United States and mainland China are consistent.

While acknowledging that the Taiwan Relations Act, a US law, takes precedence over any policy statements such as the communiques, Shirk said these documents together have formed the foundation of US policy toward mainland China and Taiwan and have helped to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait area for a long time.

Shirk warned that the provision could disrupt the foundation of the US relationship with Beijing. She also said the Clinton administration opposed the "United States-Taiwan Anti-Ballistic Missile Defense Cooperation Act" because Beijing might view it as the United States viewing mainland China as an enemy.
In her view, the effect of this legislation could cause disruption in the administration's plans for the forthcoming summit between President Bill Clinton and Communist Chinese leader Jiang Zemin.

However, Rep. Rohrabacher disagreed, saying that as Jiang is coming to the United States for his first official visit, it is important for the United States to restate clearly the prerequisites for the US relationship with mainland China, so that Beijing will not have a false impression of the US positions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES MOVES FOR ASIA-PACIFIC PEACE: CHANG

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes any move that will contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang said on Wednesday.

Chang was responding to the passage of a bill by the International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives calling for US-Taiwan cooperation in establishing a theater ballistic missile defense system.

Chang said the bill mainly reflects congressional views and will not necessarily form a part of US policy, adding that the attitude of the US executive branch is critical to determining whether or not Taiwan will be included within the US-proposed Asia-Pacific regional anti-ballistic missile defense system.
Chang said the proposal to include Taiwan within such a system, also known as a theater missile defense system (TMD), has been brought up by many American lawmakers and academics.

In fact, Vice President Lien Chan said earlier this year that mainland China's missile tests and war games in waters near Taiwan between mid-1995 and March 1996 have prompted the United States and the international community to pay much more attention to Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability. Against this backdrop, the proposal to develop a costly TMD system is once again under serious consideration.

Chang said he cannot comment on the newly passed US congressional bill before he has fully analyzed its content. "But we welcome any proposal or action that will contribute to Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability."

According to reports from Washington, the International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives approved a bill by a voice vote on Tuesday that would require the secretary of defense to report to Congress on how the United States would help Taiwan develop a theater ballistic missile defense system against missile attacks from mainland China.
The bill says that no later than July 1, 1998, the defense secretary shall submit a report to Congress to describe how the US would provide Taiwan with an advanced missile defense system.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC SAYS IT CAN BUILD SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: The state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said Wednesday that it has beefed up its ability to build and maintain ships, and is confident that it is capable of building submarines.
The CSBC was responding to earlier reports that the Navy is planning to work with the CSBC to build submarines.

The CSBC said however that the Navy has not contacted it over the matter. But, should the navy decide to build submarines after repeated setbacks in attempts to purchase them from major arms-supplying countries, the CSBC said it has sufficient experience in shipbuilding and maintenance to construct the underwater vessels, so long as it can obtain design blueprints and related technology.

In the 1980s, Taiwan successfully developed the Indigenous Defense Fighter aircraft with the help of some foreign components, and the Navy is reportedly considering the same approach to produce submarines.

Taiwan currently operates two Dutch-built Swordfish submarines, and the CSBC has actively sought assistance for their upkeep, hoping to gain some know-how for building and maintaining its own submarines.
The CSBC has close links with the Navy, which has already commissioned the CSBC to build seven Cheng Kung-class frigates patterned after the US-developed Perry-class frigates.
The CSBC also assists in the maintenance and repair of the Navy's Knox-class frigates leased from the United States and the Lafayette-class missile frigates purchased from France.

The CSBC said the basic principles behind the construction of all warships are essentially the same and, although submarines are more sophisticated than surface vessels, it should be able to overcome most of the difficulties in building an indigenous submarine so long as the necessary design blueprints and technical assistance can be obtained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MARK ELDERS DAY (I)

TEXT.P: In slightly over a week's time, the Republic of China on Taiwan will celebrate Elders Day, an occasion set aside by the nation to pay homage to its senior citizens.

For ancestor-worshipping Chinese, the day which falls on the ninth day of the ninth month on the lunar calendar is a time for people to display their filial piety and to educate the youth to respect their seniors. Elders Day this year comes on Oct. 10, the ROC National Day.

To mark the special day, a series of activities, including parties, ball games, and seminars on welfare for the aged will be held in counties and cities throughout the Taiwan area. People over 70 years of age will also be given red envelops containing cash and other gifts to observe the occasion.

In Taipei City, two centenarians have been invited to join in some celebratory programs where they will receive special citations and gifts. The two, Ms. Huang Lien-mei, 114, and Ms. Hsi Shenholien, 113, are the oldest citizens in Taipei and probably in all Taiwan.

Ms. Huang has two sons, one daughter, 12 grandchildren and more than a dozen great-grandchildren. She lives with one of her grandchildren and enjoys chatting with people. Ms. Hsi has stayed in a home for the elderly following the death of her son three years ago. She is shy with reporters but not with people who come bearing gifts. She likes to eat the coconut candies brought by her daughter-in-law on frequent visits.

With the improvement of living standards and better health care, the life span for people in Taiwan has been steadily increasing during the past decades. Recently released statistics show that the life span in Taiwan stands at 74.5 years, 71.81 years for men and 77.76 for women. The figure, although lower compared with the 79 years for the Japanese, is among the highest in Asia. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MARK ELDERS DAY (II)

TEXT.P: A nation is considered an aged society when more than 7 percent of its people are 65 years old or over, according to the criteria set by the United Nations. Taiwan became an aged society in 1993 when official statistics indicated that 7.1 percent of its population was over 65.

Researchers at the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that the aging of the population in Taiwan has occurred faster than in many other countries due to a drastic fall in birth rates following the post-World War II baby boom. Persons born in 1945 will turn 65 in the year 2010. By 2050, senior citizens will make up 16.5 percent of Taiwan's population, they predicted.

At present, one in every nine persons in Taiwan is over 65, but by 2025, the ratio will be one in every five persons. The increased percentage of elderly people will undoubtedly present burdens on those members of society who support them. This means that while each citizen over 65 is currently being supported by eight younger persons, in 30 years' time, only four persons will be supporting the seniors. Therefore, younger people in the 21st century will face heavier financial burdens, the researchers pointed out.

As the nation's average life span steadily increases, the number of centenarians in Taiwan also grows. In 1992, there were only 291 persons aged 100 years or older, but the figure rose to 497 in 1994, and 583 in 1996. The CEPD estimates that the number of centenarians islandwide will reach 818 by the turn of the century, 2,911 by the year 2020 and 5,335 by 2030.

The rapid increase in the number of senior citizens has already posed serious problems for both the government and the public. As people grow older, they need more financial assistance from the government and also require more and often costly medical services for longer periods of time. To meet these costs, the government has to raise tax revenues from younger people in the workforce.

Experts in social welfare and family planning programs have called on the government and the public to work together in finding ways to resolve the problems caused by the graying society. Their suggestions include the establishment of a compulsory savings system for working people when they are young, improvement of medical insurance programs for the elderly, and an efficient pension system.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER WELCOMES US PROPOSAL FOR TAIWAN'S INCLUSION IN TMD

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said Wednesday that Taiwan welcomes a proposal by a committee of US House of Representatives that Taiwan be included in a theater missile defense (TMD) system.

Chiang was responding to the passage of a bill Tuesday by the Committee on International Relations, which called for the United States to help Taiwan establish a local-area ballistic missile defense system to protect the island from missile attacks.
Chiang said that Taiwan appreciates the US congressmen's good intentions, but whether it will take part in the missile defense system needs further study.

Chiang said that the research and development of the US-initiated TMD system is still at the initial stages, adding that the huge cost of the missile defense system will be shared by the countries covered.

The Defense Ministry will assess whether the TMD system can effectively protect the countries involved from outside missile attacks and determine whether the national defense budget can support Taiwan's participation in the system, Chiang said at the Legislative Yuan while answering questions from lawmakers.

The defense officials said that the TMD system is derived from the "Star Wars" defense initiative by the US Reagan administration in the 1980s, with its magnitude reduced to a regional scope. The initial research fund is estimated at US$9 billion, currently shared by the US and Japan.
The officials said that the TMD system is expected to reach the first-stage completion by the year 2003, with the total research and development fund amounting to over US$20 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SIGNS MOU ON ECONOMIC AND TECHNICAL COOPERATION WITH AUSTRIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Austria on Wednesday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on economic and technical cooperation.
ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu and his Austrian counterpart Josef Mayer, signed the MOU on behalf of their respective governments.

Mayer earlier called on ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and was briefed by economics officials on Taiwan's trade and economic situation. The two ministers also discussed the development of bilateral ties.

Wang indicated that Austria is keen to participate in Taiwan's environmental protection efforts, including the development of incinerators, as well as large-scale petrochemical and aviation industry projects. He said the signing of the MOU will help establish a pattern for technological cooperation and will promote trade and information exchanges.
Austria's economics minister, Hannes Farleiter, is scheduled to visit Taiwan soon, following the steps of German Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt, who arrived here last week.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Austria totaled US$540 million last year, with Taiwan exporting US$310 million in goods and services to Austria, while importing US$230 million of products from Austria.
Taiwan is Austria's third largest trading partner in Asia. Taiwan business activities in Austria are mostly concentrated in the areas of computer and telecommunications equipment.

Economic officials said Austria, located in a strategic position in central Europe, has close relations with both Eastern and Western Europe. Taiwan's increased trade relations with Austria is expected to help it promote trade with those areas as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN IN MID OCTOBER

TEXT.P: President of the Republic of Chad Idriss Deby will pay a visit to Taiwan from Oct. 15 to 19, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Wednesday.

The African country resumed the diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on August 12 after a 25-year hiatus. Deby, who won Chad's first post-independence presidential election in July 1996 and formed a government in May 1997, will visit Taiwan for the first time at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui.

President Lee will welcome Deby with a military ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei. Lee and Deby will then hold talks on issues of mutual concern between their countries.

In addition, Deby will visit Economics Ministry and the cabinet-level the Council of Agriculture, meet with local business leaders and visit the World Trade Center to gain a better understanding of the economic and cultural development of Taiwan.

Located in central Africa, Chad has a population of about seven million on a land area of 1.28 million square kilometers. Taiwan was Chad's fifth largest importer in 1996, with the import value worth over US$4 million. The leading import item into Taiwan from Chad was cotton.

The ROC established diplomatic ties with Chad in January 1962, but severed those links on Dec. 27 1972, one month after Chad signed a communique recognizing the government in Beijing. The two countries restored diplomatic relations when Chad Foreign Minister Mahamat Saleh Annadif visited Taipei in August and signed a communique of mutual recognition with ROC Foreign Minister John Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RELEASE DISSIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: It is ironic that millions of refugees who fled to Hong Kong to escape Communist Chinese rule are now seeing the mainland's five-star flag hoisted everywhere in celebration of national day, observed an editorial in Hong Kong's Oriental Daily News on Wednesday.

The editorial pointed out that many people in Hong Kong have little confidence in the People's Republic of China (PRC) due to Beijing's steadfast adherence to communism. It said that the red flag is a totem of all the hardships and bitterness suffered by the Chinese people in recent decades.

After adopting free-market reforms and an open door policy in 1979, Beijing has made genuine progress in upgrading people's material living standards as well as their spiritual lives. But the most important thing for the leadership in Beijing, said the editorial, is to learn the lessons of the past and never repeat those mistakes.

While wishing Beijing well in its efforts to firmly establish the rule of law and to crack down on corruption, the Oriental Daily urged the communist authorities to be more "open-minded" and to release imprisoned pro-democracy dissidents at an early date.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE APPEALS FOR ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The vice premier of Belize, Dean O. Barrow, on Wednesday criticized the United Nations for excluding the Republic of China, saying the policy is irrational and unenlightened.

Barrow, who concurrently serves as the Central American country's minister of foreign affairs, took advantage during his address at the UN General Assembly debate to lend support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the world body.
Living in a successful, robust and prosperous democracy, Barrow said, the 21 million people of Taiwan should be entitled at the very least to a discussion of their circumstances.

"The blanket `no,' the annual ritual that continues to slam the door shut on even the possibility of debating their aspirations, is irrational and unenlightened," Barrow asserted, adding that a way must be found to review the situation in a manner consistent with the rights of the parties and the spirit of the UN Charter.
The foreign ministers of two other ROC diplomatic allies -- Malawi and Haiti -- also spoke on the same occasion, but neither touched on the issue of the ROC's UN membership.

Although the prepared text of Malawi Foreign Minister Mapopa Chipeta contained a paragraph supporting the ROC's bid to join international organizations and activities, Chipeta skipped the paragraph while addressing the General Assembly debate session.
The ROC lost its seat in the United Nations in 1971 when the world body accepted the communist government in Beijing as the sole representative of the Chinese people.

The UN General Assembly's steering committee on Sept. 17 rejected for a fifth straight year a request to consider the question of ROC representation. This year's petition, signed by 14 of Taipei's diplomatic allies, called for the re-examination of Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC in 1971 to make way for mainland China.

In addition to Belize, nine other UN members -- Nicaragua, Fiji, Paraguay, El Salvador, Honduras, the Dominican Republic, Saint Christopher and Nevis, Swaziland and Burkina Faso --have also voiced support for the ROC's UN bid since the current General Assembly debate session started on Sept. 22.
