DOC.HEADLINE: COMPULSORY SAVINGS MAY HELP PREVENT ABSCONDING: HSU

TEXT.P: Compulsory savings can be an effective measure to prevent irregularities such as absconding on the part of foreign laborers working in Taiwan, Taiwan's top labor affairs official said on Thursday.

Hsu Chieh-kwei, chairman of the cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said he reached a consensus with labor affairs ministers from Thailand and the Philippines during a recent APEC meeting in Seoul on a plan to require Filipino and Thai workers in Taiwan to put part of their earnings in savings as part of a scheme to dissuade them from fleeing their jobs.

According to a preliminary CLA plan, Thai and Filipino workers will be asked to deposit one-third of their monthly salaries in time savings accounts which cannot be drawn upon during their stay in Taiwan. The savings will be mailed overseas to the workers' hometowns only after they legally terminate their Taiwan employment, he noted.
Thailand and the Philippines are the main sources of foreign laborers in Taiwan, most of whom work in labor-intensive sectors, such as manufacturing and construction, and as household helpers.
The measure, which must be drafted and then passed by the legislature, will be the first of its kind in the world if put into force, Hsu noted.

Actually, several Taiwan manufacturing companies already require their foreign laborers to save part of their monthly earnings as a "safety measure" to not only help the workers save money for their own benefit but also to prevent them from easily absconding, Hsu pointed out.

He said that any company which adopts the practice should open the time savings accounts under the alien workers' individual names rather than under the company's name. Troubles may arise if a manufacturing company closes down and its alien workers' savings accounts are held in the company's name, Hsu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 190.36 points to finish at 8,504.66.
The bourse opened at 8,698.67 and experienced a high of 8,733.61 and a low of 8,502.94.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 385 to 44, with 38 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.79 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.74 billion (US$3.8 billion).

Paper and pulp shares declined the most at 4.5 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues at 4.4 percent, construction issues at 3.8 percent, textile stocks at 3.7 percent, foodstuff shares at 3.5 percent, cement issues at 3 percent, financial stocks at 2.3 percent, and electrical engineering issues at 0.6 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, China Steel, A.S.E., Macronic International, ACER, Mitac International, Liton Electronic, Winbond Electronics, and Orient Semiconductor Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE BUSINESSES REAP HARVEST AT MILAN TRADE FAIR
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan textile businesses have hauled in new orders valued at US$6.2 million, with US$25 million worth of follow-up orders, at a trade fair sponsored by the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF) in Milan, Italy.

A TTF spokesman said here on Wednesday that the harvest broke the previous record of US$6 million in new orders set in March at a similar TTF trade fair in Paris. He said the impressive figures indicate that Taiwan-made fabrics are compatible with current market demands in Europe.

A total of 21 Taiwanese textile manufacturers displayed their products in three categories -- synthetic fibers, woven and silk materials -- at the Milan trade fair between Sept. 28 and Sept. 30. More than 400 buyers showed up in search of their favorite fabrics.
Italy was Taiwan's fourth largest source of textile products last year, supplying 7 percent of the total value of the island's imports in this sector, according to TTF statistics.

Over the past few years, the major items of Taiwan's textile exports have shifted from garments to cloth materials, which accounted for 59 percent of Taiwan's entire textile exports in 1996, with an accumulated export value of US$9.1 billion, the TTF spokesman indicated.

He said Taiwan's textile industry has been facing strong competition from mainland China, which enjoys cheap labor and low-cost resources. As a result, most textile enterprises on the island have been forced to upgrade or shift their current development strategies from making low-cost garments to producing high-quality, diverse and delicate items.

The spokesman said that with his federation's assistance and the efforts of local textile-makers in upgrading the industry, which includes forging overseas alliances, Taiwan's textile sector is enjoying success in opening new markets, especially those in Europe where several international fashion centers are located.

Last year, Taiwan's textile exports were valued at US$15.5 billion, which accounted for 14 percent of the total export volume, the TTF statistics showed. That performance placed the textile industry as the second largest in Taiwan, following the information sector.
The TTF is a key organization in Taiwan for the regulation of textile quotas, promotion of textile exports, marketing research and providing relevant information.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLORIDA GOVERNOR VISITING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Florida Governor Lawton Chiles led a 14-member delegation that arrived here Thursday.
During his stay in Taiwan, Chiles will call on President Lee Teng-hui and other government officials.

On Friday, Kao Yi-hsin, secretary-general of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), and John Anderson, a member of Chiles' delegation and president and CEO of Enterprise Florida Inc., will sign an agreement on mutual assistance.
Chiles and CETRA Chairman Lin Cheng-kuo will witness the signing ceremony.

CETRA officials said that Florida is a leader in the aviation industry in the United States, with its production value second only to that of California. They noted that major companies such as Grumman and McDonnell Douglas Corp. have set up production facilities in Florida. The state also has booming electronics, film and videotape and laser equipment industries, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS WITHOUT CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday once again welcomed mainland Chinese leaders' recent calls for opening of political negotiations across the Taiwan Strait as "positive" responses to Taiwan's overtures.

Siew, however, reiterated Taipei's hope that the two sides unconditionally resume the high-level talks initiated in 1993, better known as the "Koo-Wang talks" in reference to the officials from the two sides who chaired those discussions.

It was the second time in three days that Siew had made similar statements, following calls by mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng and by Vice Premier and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen on Sept. 29 for Taipei to consult with Beijing on procedural arrangements for cross-strait political negotiations.
Siew reiterated Taipei's position that the two sides can begin preparatory discussions on cross-strait political issues by resuming the Koo-Wang talks.

Taipei has repeatedly called for the resumption of cross-strait talks during the past two years after Beijing unilaterally suspended bilateral dialogue in June 1995 in the wake of President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States, Siew noted.
Siew again stressed that the unification of China under the principles of democracy, freedom and the equitable distribution of wealth is the ultimate goal of the ROC's mainland policy.

He said the ROC government not only undertakes to protect the security and well-being of the 21.6 million people living in Taiwan, but also wants to help raise the standards of living of the 1.2 billion fellow countrymen on the mainland.

To reach that goal, he said, Taipei has long promoted cross-strait exchanges and sought pragmatic means of dialogue, in the hope that "sincerity" and "goodwill" will help accelerate the improvement of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTCH BANK TO ISSUE CREDIT CARDS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Dutch ABN AMRO Bank will begin issuing credit cards in Taiwan in mid-October, hoping to take the advantage of the booming domestic plastic-money market.

According to Maarten Reuchlin, senior executive vice president of ABN AMRO Bank's global consumer banking business, ABN AMRO chose Taiwan over Singapore and Hong Kong for the maiden issuance of credit cards in Asia because of Taiwan's larger population and less-competitive market.

Although fast-growing, Taiwan's credit card market still offers room for ABN AMRO's presence, Reuchlin noted. By comparison, Singapore and Hong Kong, both saturated and fiercely competitive, offer little chances for newcomers, he added.

Beginning on Oct. 15, said Paul Scholten, general manager of ABN AMRO Bank in Taiwan, the bank will make available ABN AMRO Cards for ordinary consumers, "Tulip Cards" for women clients, and "Business Cards" for businessmen who frequently travel overseas.
Using Taiwan as a testing gateway, ABN AMRO will aim at making inroads into other Asian markets, including Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, India, Hong Kong and the Philippines, Scholten said.

ABN AMRO Bank is the largest bank in the Netherlands and the eighth largest in the world in terms of capitalization. The bank, which has had a presence in Taiwan for 25 years, maintains branch offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG TALKS ABOUT QIAO SHI'S RETIREMENT

TEXT.P: It seems that mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is quite sensitive to the opinions of the outside world concerning Qiao Shi's retirement.

As chairman of the Standing Committee of the 8th National People's Congress, Qiao's removal from the Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), aroused much speculation. Qiao has long been seen as Jiang's political enemy.
During a meeting with former Japanese Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita in Beijing on Wednesday, Jiang explained that Qiao's stepping down was due solely to his advanced age.

Those accompanying Takeshita in the meeting disclosed to the Japanese media that, according to Jiang's explanation, under new stipulation regarding the counting of age, persons born after the month of June can be counted as being born in the following year.

Thus, born in August 1926, Jiang was considered to be 70 years old rather than 71 when the 15th National Congress of the CCP convened this September. Hence, he was not deemed to have exceeded the 70-year-old age limitation for the forced retirement of officials, a rule adopted by the CCP.

While Qiao Shi, born in December 1924, could also take advantage of being considered one year younger, he had clearly surpassed the retirement age, and thus there was no question regarding his stepping down.
According to the Japanese media reports, Jiang emphasized that although Qiao's retirement had given rise to much criticism, the move was part of a natural process of rejuvenation.
Under this process, Jiang added, the 15th Party Congress had replaced one-half of its Central Committee members and one-third of its Politburo members.

Qiao Shi will hand over his post as chairman of the standing committee of the National People's Congress next March, which will be filled by Premier Li Peng. Current Vice Premier Zhu Rongji is expected to succeed Li in the premiership.
Takeshita is attending activities marking the 25th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between Tokyo and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED REACTION TO PROPOSED INCLUSION OF TAIWAN IN TMD SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The passage of a bill by a committee of the US House of Representatives calling for Taiwan to be included in a theater missile defense (TMD) system received a mixed reaction from legislators Thursday.

Some legislators believed that if Taiwan agrees to such a proposal, it will burden itself with enormous costs and might trigger an arms race between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Others said Taiwan should accept the offer in order to better ensure its safety.

Legislator Parris Chang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that he welcomed the US proposal, although he believed that the proposal will be hard to implement. He added that the proposal indicates that the United States is genuinely concerned about the security of Taiwan.
Chang said that even if the US Defense Department opposes the plan, Taiwan should not abandon the idea of a theater missile defense (TMD) system.
Tsaur Eel-jong of the ruling Kuomintang recalled the words of Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling in describing the plan as a "money pit."

Tsaur also said that if Taiwan joins the TMD system, it will only increase misgivings across the Taiwan Strait and possible trigger an arms race which would hurt efforts to improve cross-strait relations.
Lee Ching-hua of the opposition New Party also said that if Taiwan agrees to cooperate with the United States, it will sour cross-strait relations.

Another New Party legislator, Lin Yu-fang, said that the TMD system is still at the research and development stage, and that Taiwan would have to shoulder astronomical costs if it wishes to be included in the project.
As the national defense budget is already enormous, Lin said, he opposed accepting the proposal.
Lin echoed Tsaur's opinion that Taiwan's participation will trigger an arms race and destabilize relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to reports from Washington, the International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives approved a bill by voice vote on Tuesday that would require the secretary of defense to report to Congress on how the United States would help Taiwan develop a theater ballistic missile defense system against missile attacks from mainland China.

The bill says that the secretary of defense shall submit a report to Congress no later than July 1, 1998, describing how the United States would provide Taiwan with an advanced missile defense system.

US defense officials said that the TMD system is derived from the "Star Wars" defense initiative of the Reagan administration in the 1980s, with its magnitude reduced to a regional scope. The initial research fund is estimated at US$9 billion, currently shared by the United States and Japan.
The officials said that the TMD system is expected to reach the first-stage completion by the year 2002, with the total research and development fund amounting to over US$20 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S CENTRAL BANK RATE UP

TEXT.P: The Bank of Canada raised its benchmark Bank Rate and operating band for the overnight rate by one quarter of a percentage point Wednesday. The new Bank Rate is 3.75 percent and the operating band is 3.25 percent to 3.75 percent.

Announcing the increases, the bank said that in recent months there has been growing evidence that the Canadian economy is expanding rapidly and absorbing unused capacity. Indicators of aggregate demand, output and money supply growth have all been strong.

The gathering momentum now evident in the economy has occurred largely as a result of the substantial monetary support that has been provided to offset the effects associated with private and public sector restructuring.

Given the lags between monetary policy actions and their effect on the economy, timely action to moderate the extent of monetary stimulus will contribute to making the economic expansion long-lasting, the bank said.

Canadian interest rates remain below those in the United States, and monetary conditions continue to support economic growth with low inflation. The Canadian prime rate stood at 4.75 percent on Wednesday, while that of the United States was 8.50 percent on the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADER TO VISIT GERMANY

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taiwan, and Dr. Parris Chang, another high-ranking DPP member, are scheduled to arrive in Berlin on Oct. 9 for a three-day visit.

During their stay, they will call on Herbert Knoblich, speaker of the Brandenburg State Parliament, and attend a worldwide summit meeting of free parties on Oct. 10 sponsored by Germany's Freie Demokratische Partei (Free Democratic Party).
Chang, an incumbent legislator, will also deliver a speech on "relations between Taiwan's democracy and the world" at Berlin's Free University on the day of their arrival.

The two DPP heavyweights will fly to Bonn Oct. 13, where they will join with other DPP members to meet with representatives of Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party for talks on party cooperation.
The DPP delegation will leave for Paris on Oct. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA HEAD EXPECTS SOLUTION TO INTEREST RATE DEADLOCK WITH CAL

TEXT.P: Tsai Tuei, director general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), said Thursday that he believes the dispute over an interest rate hike related to planes China Airlines (CAL) leases from the government can be resolved.
Tsai said that the CAA would terminate the lease with the flag carrier and recover the planes only as the last resort.
In order to address a trade imbalance with the United States a decade ago, the government purchased 10 US-made planes, including five 747-400s, one 747-200 and four MD-11s.

CAL bought three of the planes and has been renting the remaining seven from the CAA. The contract stated that CAL would pay an initial interest rate of 3 percent, subject to review every three years during the 10-and-a-half-year lease.

The current interest rate of 5.44 percent was scheduled to last until Oct. 22, 1999. But the previous session of the Legislative Yuan asked that it be adjusted upward to 7.2 percent starting Oct. 4, 1997.

CAL strongly protested the decision, saying the contract rate should be honored until the 1999 expiration date. The airline also pointed out that as it has a good credit rating, it would normally be entitled to an interest rate lower than 7.2 percent.
Tsai said that he believes a solution can be found that will be satisfactory to the CAA and CAL as well as the Legislative Yuan.

Tsay Jaw-yang, the minister of Transportation of Communications, delivered an ultimatum to CAL Wednesday that if the airline did not agree to pay the higher rate by Oct. 4, the ministry would terminate the contract.
Officials said if CAL does not comply, the ministry would repossess all seven planes within two years and invite bidding to buy or rent the aircraft.

They noted, however, that the recall of the planes would have no short-term tangible benefits since the government would have to spend an estimated NT$913 million (US$32 million) on maintenance to keep the planes airworthy.

DOC.HEADLINE: USTR SAYS TAIPEI UNFAIRLY BLOCKING US PHARMACEUTICAL PRODUCTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: US trade officials have urged Taiwan's National Health Insurance Bureau not to impede the competitiveness of US-made pharmaceuticals in the Taiwan market by setting recommended price listings.

The US Trade Representative's Office (USTR) said the bureau has legitimate authority to control the costs of health care, but it warned against practices such as price listing that could present unfair barriers to US-manufactured pharmaceutical products.
The warning was issued in a report prepared by the USTR office together with its annual "Super 301" list of countries accused of unfairly creating obstacles to US exports.

The list and the accompanying report were drafted in accordance with US law, which requires the USTR office to undertake retaliatory measures against foreign countries that are deemed to engage in unfair trade practices.
While Taipei was not cited for retaliation, mention was made of the ROC government-sponsored National Health Insurance program in the report's "Other Bilateral Issues" section.
The report referred to what it called barriers against sales of US-made products in Taiwan's pharmaceutical market.
US pharmaceutical manufacturers are concerned about measures within Taiwan's system of recommended prices, the reports said.
An American official told the Central News Agency that Washington hopes to find a "reasonable solution" to the issue in the upcoming round of bilateral consultations, scheduled for later this month.
Meanwhile, a US association of pharmaceutical manufacturers, PhRMA, released its own statement on the issue after the Super 301 list was announced.

The statement complained against what it described as a bias against American-made pharmaceuticals and newly developed medicinal products in the Taiwan market. It also called on Taipei to recognize "contributions made to Taiwan's new health care system" by American pharmaceutical manufacturers, whose efforts were said to be focused primarily on researching and developing original products.

American manufacturers have said their main complaint is Taipei's alleged practice of fixing low prices that favor domestic manufacturers of generic pharmaceutical products over foreign manufacturers that had originally researched and developed the products.
Such manufacturing, which saves Taiwan manufacturers the enormous expense of developing new medicines, is legally permissible after the original manufacturer's patent expires, they said.
They asserted that the practice is not only creating obstacles to imports, but also having negative effects on the quality of health care in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL SEES NOTHING TO HAPPEN ON TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: Retired Gen. Colin Powell said in Singapore Wednesday that Taiwan is the likeliest flash point for a conflict involving mainland China.

The former chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff pointed out "that is the one area where something could go wrong if we do not handle the situation and watch it carefully," alluding to tensions which have arisen from time to time across the Taiwan Strait.
He said, however, that he does not expect anything to happen because "the Chinese realize that it is in their interest not to have anything happen."
Powell also called on the international community to engage rather than isolate mainland China.
Beijing recognizes that the key to becoming a more successful and wealthy nation is for it to participate in the world economic order, he said.

Powell, who served as chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff from 1989 to 1993, made these points at a lunch talk organized by Citibank as part of its Asian Leadership series, and at a subsequent press conference. He left for home Wednesday night after a two-day visit here.

In his address, Powell noted that intellectuals and journals in the United States have continued to ask whether there should be engagement with or containment of Beijing and whether an economically powerful mainland China would be a threat to the region.
While he said his answer to the first issue was clear -- "We engage" -- he chose to hedge on the second, saying that although the situation needs watching, it is "too early to worry."
Touching on the development and dynamism of the Asian region, Powell pointed to mainland China as a "growing power."

"They are becoming a power not because they have a superior ideology or because the People's Liberation Army is superior. They are becoming a power because they are participating in the globalization of the world economic system," he said.

"We should welcome that, encourage that, because the more they come out, they will also feel that it is to their advantage to slowly join the world system ... because over time, they will discover the advantages of being part of that system."
Powell said he believes Beijing has come to the conclusion that the way to become more successful and prosperous is "not to threaten its neighbors."

"There are problems in places like the Spratlys, but I do not think China is going to ruin its trading relationship over this rock," he said in reference to the chain of islands in the South China Sea that a number of countries have claimed as their territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES NEW REGULATIONS UNDER FUTURES TRADING LAW

TEXT.P: A package of detailed regulations drafted in conformity with the recently passed Futures Trading Law was approved at Thursday's Cabinet meeting.
The measures, drafted by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) in the wake of the Legislative Yuan's passage of a law legalizing the trading of futures in Taiwan, were approved and put into effect.
MOF officials said they had drafted a series of detailed measures in compliance with Article 124 of the Futures Trading Law, which went into effect June 1.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) and Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX) both welcomed the measures.
The CME and SIMEX both launched Taiwan stock index futures trading on Jan. 9. Their positive performance has won the approval of financial scholars and the financial community.
The local futures exchange market has also been awaiting the approval of the futures exchange drafts since the Legislative Yuan passed the law June 1.

According to the MOF officials, the new measures are the product of intensive consultations between a variety of government ministries and agencies, including the MOF's Securities and Futures Exchange Commission and Monetary Affairs Bureau, the Ministries of Justice and Economic Affairs, the Central Bank of China, and the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE ACCOMPANIES GOODALL ON TRIP TO KENTING PARK

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday accompanied Dr. Jane Goodall, commonly known as the "Mother of Chimpanzees," on an inspection tour of the Kenting National Park at the southernmost tip of Taiwan.

They arrived at the Kenting park at 10 a.m.. During their brief stopover at the Kenting resources exhibition hall, Goodall presented President Lee with a citation in appreciation of his donation of NT$1 million (US$34,965) to the Jane Goodall Institute on Wednesday to help the wildlife conservation institute set up a branch in Taiwan.

For his part, Lee expressed the hope that the respected British primatologist would take time out of her busy schedule to give lectures at the "Lee Teng-hui Chair," a special teaching program at Lee's alma mater, Cornell University in New York State.

Before starting their tour of the scenic and ecologically rich Kenting park, Lee and Goodall were briefed on the park's geological, climatic, maritime and ecological conditions as well as its special species of flora and fauna.
Lee and Goodall, one of the world's three leading primatologists, then toured a forestry recreational area, which is also a main habitat of indigenous Formosan macaques.
Standing atop a sea-observation tower, Goodall said she was impressed by the Kenting park's natural scenery.
In the afternoon, Goodall toured the park's Sheting area to see for herself Taiwan conservationists' success in breeding the rare Siko, also known as the Formosan spotted deer.

The special indigenous animal had been extinct in Taiwan's wilderness areas since 1969. The ROC government launched a rehabilitation program in 1984, and, through long years of strenuous efforts, specialists at Kenting have managed to increase the herd of Siko deer to 200, some 80 of which have been released into the wild.
Goodall said she was moved when she saw the rare deer species roaming the woods freely. She was also excited when she unexpectedly spotted a large flock of migrant birds resting on the Kenting beach.

Goodall arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day visit. This is her second trip to this island. President Lee honored his promise to accompany her on a Kenting trip to get a glimpse of Taiwan's wildlife conservation programs and natural scenery.

The 63-year-old primatologist, who has been studying chimpanzees in Africa since 1957, has traveled around the world in recent years to promote her "Roots and Shoots" campaign, a conservation program for children.

On Wednesday evening, Goodall attended a bazaar in Taipei, which was organized by local environmentalists and industrialists to raise funds for the planned Taiwan branch of the Jane Goodall Institute. About NT$5 million in cash was raised during the bazaar.

Earlier that day, Goodall addressed a group of young local students, reminding them of the importance of protecting the natural environment, conserving wildlife, and respecting and caring for human beings and animals.

On Wednesday, Goodall also met with Premier Vincent Siew. During the meeting, Goodall suggested that the ROC government ban circuses from performing in Taiwan, calling the process of training animals for performances "very cruel."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN SCIENTISTS NEAR VACCINE FOR VD

TEXT.P: Canadian researchers are closing in on a vaccine against the parasite that infects up to 250 million women in the world each year, a major Canadian newspaper reported Wednesday.
The Toronto Star noted that the vaccine would protect women from the world's most common -- but least easily recognized -- venereal disease.

Trichomonas vaginalis is a tiny one-celled parasite that infects millions of women annually, including hundreds of thousands in Canada alone. Most men, and many women, who are infected show no symptoms although they can spread the bug.

Women who display symptoms commonly experience a vaginal discharge that is easily confused with a yeast infection. In pregnant women, however, the parasite increases risk of a premature delivery by 30 to 40 percent, the daily quoted Dr. James McGregor of the University of Colorado as telling a Toronto medical conference.
And the condition may cause miscarriages during the early stages of pregnancy, he added.

Canadian scientists have been successful in infecting laboratory mice with the parasite, and tests have produced a vaccine that reduces the disease in these animals by 80 percent, said Dr. Gary Garber, head of the division of infectious disease at the University of Ottawa.
A vaccination would be particularly useful for populations at high risk of this parasite, he said. "In Canada, in the northern regions of our country, trichomonas is endemic."
In contrast to the relative neglect of this disease in humans, McGregor said a vaccine already exists for a similar parasite that attacks cattle, since farmers are concerned about losing calves.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER HK RESIDENTS EXPECTED TO ATTEND DOUBLE TEN CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: About 1,000 to 1,300 Hong Kong residents are expected to come to Taipei next week to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations, a senior official said on Thursday.
The number is far lower than the 6,500 recorded last year, according to government tallies.

"The trend is understandable," Chu Chi-ying, minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said, adding that Hong Kong's reversion to mainland Chinese rule on July 1 has caused "some inconveniences" for its residents to take part in this kind of activities in Taiwan.
Chu said his commission has not yet received complaints from ROC expatriates in Hong Kong about restrictions on celebrating the ROC's National Day, which falls on Oct. 10.

Nevertheless, Chu said, he hopes ROC expatriates there will take into consideration their personal safety and the security of their jobs in Hong Kong when they organize any ROC National Day celebration activities.

Overseas Chinese began to return to Taipei on Thursday in preparation for attending the National Day celebrations. Chu said more than 7,000 overseas Chinese from around the world are expected to come to Taipei for various celebration programs this year.
Moreover, Chu said, over 660 overseas Chinese organizations in countries around the globe are actively preparing for Double Ten festivities.

Chu further said an estimated 250,000 overseas Chinese are expected to attend diverse ROC National Day celebrations in worldwide Chinese communities this year, far more than the 40,000 ethnic Chinese who showed up at various festive programs marking communist China's Oct. 1 National Day on Wednesday.

Noting that the majority of overseas Chinese remain loyal to the Republic of China, Chu said many up-and-coming industrialists, including those in high-technology industries, have voluntarily taken time out of their busy schedules to organize Double Ten celebration activities in their resident countries. Many of them have sent invitations to the elite members of mainstream social and political groups in those countries, Chu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO BOOST DEFENSE SPENDING TO COPE WITH MILITARY BUILDUPS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia plans to increase defense spending and extend its military firepower to cope with rising military buildups in the Asian region.

Defense Minister Ian McLachlan on Tuesday released a progress report on the implementation of defense management reforms under which Australia will commit to increasing its military strength "to keep abreast of the unprecedented growth and sophistication of military capabilities within the region."

The plan calls for the government to organize the Australian Defense Force and the Department of Defense to find annual savings of at least A$770 million to redirect to combat capability, according to The Australian.

The report from the review team says: "Finding and redistributing savings to war-fighting capability will be a major step forward. However, it is likely that more overall resources -- i.e. a high proportion of gross domestic product -- will need to be allocated to defense in future."
McLachlan said the recommendation will be addressed in the strategic review and taken into account "in the defense long-term planning process."

He said priorities for how the savings will be spent are to be outlined in the strategic review. The capability priorities include airborne early warning and control aircraft, expanding the capabilities of the submarine fleet, modernizing combat aircraft and increasing weapons and sensors on surface ships.
Defense analysts said the plan to increase defense spending is designed to cope with rising military buildups in mainland China, Japan, Taiwan, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam and Thailand.

They believe military buildups in the Asian Pacific area could increase tension throughout the region and the only way to safeguard Australia's interests accordingly is to increase its defense spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIFT TO COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: In recognition of a landmark $25 million donation from the Fu Foundation, Columbia University will rename its renowned School of Engineering and Applied Science.

The donation will be used to recruit and retain world-class faculty members and the most promising students in four fields at the newly renamed Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science: computer sciences, biomedical engineering, applied mathematics, and electrical engineering, according to an announcement by Columbia University President George Rupp.

"This is a transforming gift," said Rupp, "that will focus support on Columbia's greatest asset--our outstanding faculty and the students who will succeed them as international leaders in the most dynamic fields of engineering and applied science."

"These resources will enable talented engineers and scientists to produce great discoveries and inventions that will improve human welfare even as they expand our intellectual world and stimulate global economic growth," he added.

Z.Y. Fu, 77, is an international entrepreneur active in the import-export business, investments and securities trading. Born in Shanghai to a family of 13 children, he was educated in China and Japan, where in 1951 he founded the Tokyo-based Sansiao Trading Corporation. Sansiao now operates branches in Kobe and New York in addition to a Hong Kong subsidiary, San Tsin Trading Corporation. Fu divides his time among homes in Hong Kong, Tokyo and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSSIBLE LANDMARK DISCOVERY ON DIABETES, SCLEROSIS ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: A recent discovery by scientists here could be a major landmark in the research on diabetes and sclerosis.

Until now, no one understood what generated both illnesses, rendering research for a treatment extremely difficult. But scientists Bernard Mach and Bernard Conrad may have found the answer: a retrovirus coded into our genetic pattern.

Hundreds of such "sleeping viruses" are known to exist, their origins dating back to the faraway past of human evolution, Mach pointed out. Usually ineffectual, they can be "woken up" for reasons yet to be understood. Once they are activated they attack certain pancreatic cells and impair the production of insulin, resulting in diabetes, he said.
For sclerosis, he said, the mechanism is similar, except that tissues are destroyed.
The model remains to be confirmed by testing, but it has already attracted international attention and could pave the way for a new treatment of both illnesses, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA WELCOMES MIDDLE EAST PEACE MOVES

TEXT.P: South Africa has welcomed the resumption of negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians after a six-month impasse.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that the end of the stalemate was a step in the right direction.
Israel and Palestine on Monday agreed to resume talks in the region next week. The talks will be shifted to Washington later in October.
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright called the decision a reverse in a "downward spiral" in the Middle East.
The months since the last talks were broken off have been marked by violence and recrimination.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.001 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Thursday, finishing at NT$28.601.
The greenback opened at the day's low of NT$28.600 and had a high of NT$28.602. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$390 million. (by Bear lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIKE MAY SERIOUSLY DISRUPT AUSTRALIA'S COAL EXPORTS (I)

TEXT.P: Australia's coal exports, the No. 1 export earner here, are facing major disruption because almost half of the nation's coal industry has been paralyzed by the three-day strike of 8,000 workers that began Wednesday.

The strikes, affecting 52 mines, are in protest of the government's crackdown on unions after mining giant Rio Tinto unveiled plans to seek court injunctions against union officials and some workers over picket lines at its strike-bound Hunter Valley No. 1 mine in New South Wales (NSW).
The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the biggest union in this country, warned of a national strike and its president Jennie Gorge declared that "bad laws were meant to be broken."
The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canberra is keeping a close watch on the dispute with an eye toward its possible impact on Taiwan, TECO's economic section director Henry Yang said.

"If the dispute can be solved shortly, then the production stoppage caused by the three-day strike will have little effect on our economy," he said in an interview. "However, we would be worried if the strike were to be prolonged."
Australia supplies about one third of Taiwan's coal. The United States, South Africa, Canada, Indonesia and mainland China also export coal to the island.
Rio Tinto's management rejected NSW Premier Bob Carr's call Wednesday night to accept arbitration by the government's Industrial Relations Commission (IRC).

Mine manager Allan Davies told Carr the arbitration would not deliver the changes the company needs to improve the mine's productivity but would only create further disputes over interpretations of rulings.
The IRC told coal companies Wednesday it would furnish injunctions Thursday ordering miners back to work.
Federal Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith said Carr should back Rio Tinto's attempts to reform the coal industry.

The strike against Rio Tinto is the second in about three months over disputes related to the hiring of workers. Rio Tinto wants to employ workers through individual contracts, but the union -- the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU) -- wants the company to hire workers through union contracts.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIKE MAY SERIOUSLY DISRUPT AUSTRALIA'S COAL EXPORTS (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of coal workers at Rio Tinto's Hunter Valley mines recently ended a six week strike. But plans by Rio Tinto to seek court injunctions to sue union members over their picket lines last month angered the CFMEU, which launched the larger strike in retaliation.
The Australian government is sympathetic with Rio Tinto as Reith is trying to reform industrial productivity to make Australia more competitive in the world market.
But the government's support for the company is facing ever-increasing opposition from the ACTU and CFMEU, both powerful unions.
The unions intend to expand the stoppage district-by-district, closing mines from Wollongong, New South Wales, to Queensland.
Australia's ports are also expected to face the threat of industrial action with the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) pledging Wednesday to join the strike if the CFMEU asks it to.
"If we get call from that union for assistance, we will be honoring our obligations of mutual support," MUA assistant national secretary Vic Slater told reporters.

Exports from the nation's biggest coal port, Newcastle, are now facing major disruption as more than 20 ships are anchored nearby, waiting to load coal for export to Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and other locations, company sources said.
Many believe it will very difficult for miners and mine owners to reach a compromise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKISH TROOPS KILL 342 SEPARATISTS IN NORTHERN IRAQ

TEXT.P: A total of 342 separatists belonging to the Turkish Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) have been killed so far in the ongoing Turkish government's cross-border operation against PKK strongholds in northern Iraq since last week, a Turkish military official said, adding that Turkish jets bombed fleeing separatists near Iraq's mountainous border with Iran on Thursday.

The official said warplanes bombed the separatists as Turkish troops pursued them eastwards after capturing the PKK's main base at Zap in northern Iraq a day earlier. Turkish forces, backed by air support, attacked three other camps near the Turkish border in an effort to dislodge the PKK, who had regrouped there.

About 15,000 Turkish troops and more than 100 tanks entered Iraq last week in a push that has angered Baghdad, which lost control of northern Iraq to Iraqi Kurdish groups after the 1991 Gulf War. The PKK uses bases in northern Iraq to launch attacks into Turkey. More than 26,000 people have been killed during the PKK's 13-year campaign for independence in Turkey's southeast.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH COMPANIES EARN RESPECT FROM GENERAL PUBLIC

TEXT.P: Silicon Valley's high-technology companies not only make good money for investors but earn great respect from Californians, who, according to a newly released public poll, have more confidence in high-tech companies than in any other institutions, such as the police, the medical profession or the US Supreme Court.

Moreover, the level of confidence in high-tech companies is higher now than in 1984 -- the last time such a poll was conducted -- bucking a general decline in public confidence in most of the 34 other institutions measured, Mark DiCamillo of the Field Poll told the San Jose Mercury News on Thursday.
"I think the public is equating high-tech companies with the good economy," DiCamillo was quoted as saying.
Overall, 45 percent of people surveyed said they had "a lot" of confidence in high-tech companies. In the 1984 survey, high-tech companies ranked third, behind universities and research scientists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS NEW ZEALAND'S SEVENTH-LARGEST TRADING PARTNER

TEXT.P: Taiwan is New Zealand's seventh-largest trading partner, with imports from New Zealand into Taiwan reaching NT$10.18 billion (US$356 million) for the first half of this year, an official from the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei said on Thursday.

Anthony Aucutt, deputy trade chief of the New Zealand Office, said that major import items from New Zealand into Taiwan are dairy products, meat, seafood, vegetables and fruits, accounting for 58 percent of the total.
Imports of dairy products alone were worth NT$2.94 billion (US$103 million) for the six-month period, constituting 30 percent of total imports, Aucutt said.

The official said two-way trade volume between Taiwan and New Zealand has been increasing over the past few years, adding that Wellington attaches great importance to the Taiwan market and will continue to make efforts to expand trade with the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WARNED AGAINST VISITING SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The ROC Foreign Ministry on Thursday warned its people to avoid traveling to Southeast Asian countries because of the choking smog caused by numerous forest fires in Indonesia which continues to envelop much of the region.
The Foreign Ministry statement said that the smog in Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei and Singapore causes respiratory problems and might lead to other infections.

Many schools, businesses and nonessential government offices in the area have been closed to try to protect people from the haze, while many flights are being canceled or delayed because of poor visibility, the statement said.

The ministry said that it has ordered his representative offices in the affected countries to closely monitor air pollution levels and send regular reports back to Taipei. Air quality in the major Southeast Asian cities and resorts will be passed on to the Department of Health and made public via the Internet.
The ministry also asked its representative offices to show concern over the smog and to ask the governments concerned what Taiwan can do to help control the catastrophe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE PRODUCTS EXPECTED TO BE MORE COMPETITIVE

TEXT.P: The domestic textile industry is expected to overcome recent difficulties and upgrade its global competitiveness, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Friday.

The BOFT noted that major international textile manufacturers have faced dramatic changes since the 1990s, including stiff competition from low-cost producers in Eastern Europe and mainland China. They also have seen the emergence of regional economic blocs, which hinder exports to the countries in those groupings.

In Taiwan, the textile industry has encountered the appreciation of the New Taiwan Dollar, a shortage of labor, rising wages for workers, as well as difficulty in acquiring land for factories and protests from environmental activists, BOFT officials said.

The government's liberalization policy also means more competition from foreign products due to reduced import tariffs, they said. Consequently, the contribution of the textile sector as a share of the total production value in the manufacturing industry has steadily declined in recent years. It is estimated that by the year 2002, the number of textile plants in Taiwan will fall to 5,800, with 290,000 persons employed and an annual production value of NT$900 billion (US$31.35 billion).

But the textile industry has played a major role in contributing to Taiwan's huge trade surpluses in the past. BOFT officials said that textile exports in 1996 totaled US$15.5 billion, while imports amounted to only US$3.62 billion in 1996, creating a US$11.88 billion trade surplus.

The officials said that as Taiwan's textile industry has established sound marketing and production networks, actively researched the development of new materials and upgraded its design capability, it should be able to successfully overcome recent challenges and upgrade its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID TO ABOLISH ONE-CHILD POLICY

TEXT.P: Beijing plans to abolish the one-child policy it has implemented since the late 1970s, reported a Japanese economic daily on Thursday.
In mainland China's 640 cities where the one-child policy has been enforced, bearing a second child will soon be permitted once again.

The Japanese newspaper indicated in its report from Beijing that the mainland's central government does not oppose the new practice, primarily because China's population is gradually aging. In addition, the one-child policy has been the target of severe criticism by Westerners from a human rights standpoint.

According to the report, among a total population of 1.2 billion, only 360 million people reside in the 640 cities which promote the one-child limit. Authorities in Beijing have confirmed that the restriction in those cities will henceforth be "limited to one generation," while other areas will "have the right to stipulate their own rules in accordance with respective local conditions."

The eldest members of the generation born after the one-child policy was implemented in 1979 are now 18 years of age. It is expected that the relaxed regulations will not become applicable before they reach marriageable age in their early 20s.

Some of the domestic factors prompting the change include the fact that the ratio of the mainland population over 60 years of age now accounts for 10 percent of the total. An aging society will adversely affect the welfare of the younger generation. Also, with the cost of living in urban areas steadily rising, it is expected that population levels in major cities will not increase dramatically even if the one-child restriction is lifted, the report added.
