DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY SEEKING ROC AID FOR AIRPORT RENOVATION
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Stephen Shen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government of Paraguay will ask the Republic of China to assist in renovating its major international airport in suburban Asuncion, a senior official said on Thursday.

Paraguayan Defense Minister Hugo Estigarribia Elizeche told the local press that Paraguay will seek Taiwan's technical and financial assistance for repairing and refurbishing the facility, located some 16 kilometers from Asuncion's downtown area.
The airport renovation project, including renewal of its runways and radar systems, will call for an estimated outlay of US$35 million to US$40 million, according to Estigarribia.

The minister said Paraguay has yet to decide which form of assistance it will request from the ROC, but stressed that the aid will greatly contribute to one of his country's most important infrastructure development projects.

ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Liu Ting-tsu said Paraguayan Minister of Foreign Affairs Ruben Melgarejo Lanzoni mentioned the airport renovation during their meeting on Wednesday. "But we didn't discuss any details concerning the program," Liu said.
Sources said the ROC Embassy here will refer the issue back to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for study.

The Asuncion international airport has been in poor condition due to many years of use, with its runways dilapidated and radar systems malfunctioning. The international flight safety organization has warned the Paraguayan government if it fails to take contingent measures to improve the airport's equipment, the organization will ban international airlines from landing at the airport.

The EVA Air Boeing 747 plane which took ROC President Lee Teng-hui and his entourage to Paraguay for a four-day state visit in mid-September was the first such aircraft in many years to land and take off at the Asuncion airport.

Paraguay is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in South America. The two countries signed an aviation agreement during Lee's visit, paving the way for the inauguration of direct flight services between the two countries in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ASKS MAINLAND TO OPEN MORE MAJOR SEAPORTS

TEXT.P: Unless mainland China opens more major seaports to cross-strait shipping operations, Taipei will not consider implementing a plan to grant customs clearance services and allow landing privileges for mainland seamen, officials in charge of shipping affairs said on Friday.
Beijing authorities currently allow only the mainland ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen to handle the long-negotiated cross-strait shipping trade.

By comparison, the officials from the ROC's Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said that since April this year Taipei has liberalized a great number of related policy regulations to help accelerate cross-strait shipping operations.

They pointed out that Taipei has opened direct shipping between Taiwan and the mainland for cargo which is transported through a third place, usually Hong Kong. It also allows mainland Chinese-owned foreign-registered vessels to anchor at Taiwan ports and has lowered port charges.

In addition, Taipei is now prepared to allow big ships, regardless of their country of registration, to sail between Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor and any mainland port under an offshore transshipment program. In the future, all of Taiwan's export processing zones and special economic zones will also be included in the program, the officials noted.
On the contrary, they said, Beijing has done nothing to promote cross-strait shipping links other than to open Fuzhou and Xiamen, two minor seaports in southern province of Fujian.

Fuzhou and Xiamen have a combined cargo capacity of 450,000 TEUs (twenty-foot-equivalent units). Since the cross-strait transshipment trade with Kaohsiung Harbor began in April, the two ports have handled only 150,000 TEUs of cargo, statistics show.

Kaohsiung Harbor, on the other hand, has a capacity of 1.5 million TEUs, and other Taiwan ports, including Keeling, Hualien and Taichung, have also been designated to join the offshore transshipment program.

Shipping operators from both Taiwan and mainland China have urged that other major mainland Chinese seaports, such as Guangzhou, Shanghai, Qingdao, Tienjin and Dalien, be allowed to join the offshore transshipment links. The officials noted that this will not only promote Taiwan's and mainland China's shipping sectors, but will also benefit foreign carriers as well.
(By Debbie Kuo)
ENDITEM ZCZC CEP006 10-03-97 NO HURRY FOR NEW TAIPEI-PRETORIA CONSULTATION: MOFA

Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) A new round of high-level negotiations between the Republic of China and South Africa originally slated for Oct. 5 in Pretoria will be postponed indefinitely, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

ROC Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen and his South African counterpart Aziz Pahad had been set to discuss a new framework for future bilateral exchanges after the two countries suspend diplomatic ties at the end of this year. It will be postponed to an unspecified later date because of Pahad's tight schedule, said Timothy Yang, director of the MOFA's African Affairs Department.

Yang said that in fact Taipei feels no urgency to hold such a meeting since the two governments have already reached consensus on major issues related to the conduct of future relations during a visit by Pahad to Taipei in June.
Deputy foreign ministers from Taipei and Pretoria may well meet again after lower-ranking officials complete one or two more rounds of working-level talks, Yang added.
South African President Nelson Mandela announced in November 1996 that Pretoria will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing at the end of 1997.

The ROC's foreign affairs minister at that time, John Chang, traveled to Pretoria on in early December of 1996, in an unsuccessful last-ditch effort to salvage the bilateral ties. He announced on Dec. 5 the recall of Taipei's ambassador to South Africa and the suspension of all aid projects to that country after fruitless meetings with Mandela and Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo.

The two governments have held several rounds of working-level negotiations on future bilateral relations during the past eight months. Issues surrounding the fate of the ROC's three consulates general in South Africa, nevertheless, remain unresolved.

Taipei has expressed that it would like to maintain its consulates general, located in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban, after the two countries sever diplomatic ties on Dec. 31. Pretoria has yet to make a decision on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY SENATOR SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S IMF MEMBERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Debbie Kuo) (By Bill Wang)

TEXT.P: Sen. Tom Daschel (D-SD) and Sen. Connie Mack (R-FL) signed on Wednesday to the resolution submitted on May 23 by Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Their moves brought to 20 the number of co-sponsors.

The resolution, which is pending in Sen. Helms' committee, notes that the membership of Taiwan in the IMF would benefit the world economy, especially those developing countries in need of capital. It would also contribute to the IMF's purposes as the island has the world's 14th largest economy, seventh largest amount of foreign investment, and one of the largest foreign exchange reserves.

The resolution notes that the IMF, which aims to advance worldwide economic relationships, is not a political entity, as evidenced by the fact that Taiwan remained a member of that body until 1980, eight years after it was forced to give up its membership in the United Nations.

As IMF membership is a prerequisite for accession to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and regional banks in which the membership of Taiwan would be beneficial and fully justified, it goes on, it is the sense of Congress that US policy should support Taiwan's admission to the IMF, the IBRD and all appropriate regional multilateral economic institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREECE, GREEK CYPRIOTS DEFEND MISSILE PURCHASE AT UN

TEXT.P: Greece and the Greek Cypriots have sent letters to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan defending the purchase and future deployment of Russian-made S-300 missiles on Cypress, the Turkish semi-official Anatolia news agency reported Thursday.

Under a US$250 million agreement signed with Russia earlier this year, the Greek Cypriots have purchased at least 150 S-300 missiles, whose 150-kilometer range can reach Turkey's Mediterranean military bases. The Greek Cypriots plan to deploy these missiles on the island next year, in a move that has angered Turkey.

In their letters, Greece and the Greek Cypriots said that Greek Cyprus is an independent state and it has the right to take the measures necessary to ensure its defense, Anatolia reported. The letters also claimed that Turkey is occupying a part of Cyprus in contravention of UN Security Council resolutions.

Greece's letter pointed out that as a guarantor of Cyprus, it feels responsible for helping the Greek Cypriots with their defense needs. Meanwhile, the Russian ambassador to Nicosia, Gorgie Muradov, said that Greek Cyprus is an independent state and the arms it procured are intended to strengthen its defense capability, Anatolia reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOU CAN'T SEE THE FORESTS FOR THE FIRES

TEXT.P: The stories about forest fires that blanketed much of Southeast Asia seems to have dropped from the world's attention. This is most unfortunate, a Canadian columnist said Tuesday.
Eric Margolis of the Sun newspapers said Indonesia and other Asian nations that tolerate the wholesale rapine of their forests deserve international condemnation.

According to UN studies, as much as one-third of Southeast Asia's old-growth forests have been destroyed. While ecological groups have long protested this atrocity, it was not until last week's run-amok incineration that the full scale of the environmental disaster created by rapacious businessmen and greedy politicians became terrifyingly apparent, he said.
He noted that each year, Indonesian forestry firms set vast fires on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo to burn off undergrowth in order to get at virgin stands of valuable hardwood timber.
Monsoon rains usually extinguish the fires. But this year, the El Nino meteorological phenomena is causing intense drought in Southeast Asia and Australia, he pointed out.

Smoke and haze from Indonesia's manmade fires quickly combined with Southeast Asia's filthy, polluted urban air, producing a life-threatening brew that contributed to a major air crash in Sumatra and a ship sinking, Margolis added.

The noxious haze reached as far away as Malaysia, Burma, southern Thailand, Singapore, and the Philippines, causing an epidemic of respiratory ailments. "This totally avoidable disaster should be a final warning to Asian nations to start respecting norms of environmental decency and basic common sense," he claimed.

Much of the region is an eco-disaster area, he said. Each major Asian city has different colored air. Beijing's is brown, Tokyo's gray, Manila's yellow. Bangkok, which has the most nightmarish traffic jams on earth, has green air. Dust, automotive exhaust, burning garbage, and belching smokestacks give Asian cities the world's worst air, except for their sisters in soot -- Athens, Mexico City, Sao Paulo and Cairo, according to Margolis.

He said Japanese industry bears a heavy responsibility for this disaster. Japan's Shinto faith teaches reverence for nature and trees. Yet Japan is the main customer for Southeast Asia's strip-mined forests, which it consumes with thoughtless and relentless prodigality, he wrote.
For Japanese, "shibui" -- love of nature -- stops at home, he observed.

It's easy, of course, to criticize Asians or Brazilians. North Americans long ago felled their magnificent virgin forests. Even today, "our few remaining stands of ancient woods are being razed by forestry firms that share the same brutish mentality as hunters who slaughter terrified, helpless animals and call it sport," he pointed out.

Indonesia's incredibly irresponsible actions also remind us that a major international issue in coming years will be ecological aggression. Nations like China, Taiwan, Mexico, Thailand, Japan and India that pump uncontrolled pollutants into the air may one day be branded international outlaws, he predicted.
Cross-border contamination could become as much a "causus belli" as armed invasion, he noted.
The catastrophe in Indonesia warns that urgent action is required by civilized nations to save remaining forests from commercial vandalism, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LAUNCHES REWARD PROGRAM FOR SHOPPERS WHO BUY AUSSIE PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Australian government has launched a A$50 million shopper-reward loyalty program to encourage Australians to buy products made in Australia.
Trade Minister Tim Fischer launched the program in Sydney on Wednesday.
Under the scheme, shoppers will collect special stamps from businesses selling Australian-made goods, including gas stations.
The stamps are used to fill the Advantage Australia Passbooks, which can be redeemed for special offers such as discounts and rewards. Details of the rewards have yet to be released.
Two million passbooks will be distributed in Sunday newspapers and magazines from this weekend and an estimated 800 million stamps will go into circulation in the coming year.
Participants are instructed to fill out their names and addresses in the form at the back of the Point Passbook in order to claim their reward.
A regular lottery will also offer more than A$50,000 worth of prizes.
This is the second "buy Australian" campaign launched by the government. The previous drive failed in part because there was no reward incentive for consumers.
Consumer associations have said they expect the innovative new program to be more successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU TIGHTENS RULES ON GENETIC FOOD

TEXT.P: Food produced from genetically modified soybeans or maize will have to carry special labels under regulations adopted by the European Commission, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Thursday.
The decision, to be implemented on Nov. 1, is a victory for consumer groups but could cause friction with trading partners and European importers.
More than half of processed foods contain soybeans or derivatives. Many importers mix genetically modified soy with ordinary soy.
Under EC regulations, food wrappers will have to indicate the presence of genetically modified soy or maize.
If there is uncertainty about whether the contents of a particular product are modified, the label must state this as well, the WTO report said.

The decision, made in agreement with all 15 European Union member-states, put soybeans and maize into a category with other "novelty foods" which have been subject to similar requirements since May 1.
The novelty food regulation requires that the end consumer be informed of the presence of any food properties that render a food or food ingredient "no longer equivalent" to an existing product.
It is intended to cover a range of biosynthetic and other technological processes.
Genetically modified soybeans and maize had previously escaped the novelty food regulations because they were approved for use before the directive came into force.

That approval has caused widespread controversy. Luxembourg and Austria are resisting attempts by the Commission to force them into lifting import bans on genetically modified maize. Both countries have said they are prepared to take the issue to court.

The controversy is likely to be heightened over the next few months as the EU attempts to clarify exactly what the food labels covered by the novelty foods and modified soybeans and maize should say and whether they should carry symbols.

Genetically modified maize has been developed by Novartis, the Swiss biotechnology company, to resist the corn borer pest. Genetically modified soybeans have been developed by Monsanto, the US chemical giant.
The EU licensed both products for sale after they were declared safe by scientific advisers, who also unanimously backed the EC's decision to label those items.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TRADE WITH M'LAND CHINA STILL UNDER ASSESSMENT, SAYS PM

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no "concrete plans" yet to conduct direct trade with arch rival mainland China as related government agencies are still assessing its feasibility, Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.

Siew stressed that the government will make a comprehensive assessment on issues surrounding the "three direct links" -- post, trade and shipping -- with mainland China as part of an effort to improve cross-strait relations.
Maintaining national security and dignity must be prerequisites for considering the three direct links projects, which involve a wide range of issues, Siew noted.

He made the remarks during a plenary session at the Legislative Yuan in response to a question by Kuomintang Legislator Wang Tien-ching on whether the direct-trade issue would be on agenda if Taipei indeed resumes dialogue with Beijing in the near future.

Meanwhile, Chen Jui-lung, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said plans on direct trade with mainland China hinge on the National Reunification Guidelines and changing of the nation's mainland China policies.
Although the BOFT has continuously carried out research on trade relations across the Taiwan Strait, no concrete policies have been made yet on this matter, he added.

Speaking at a press conference, Chen said that since Taiwan opened indirect trade across the Taiwan Strait in 1989, Taipei has granted permission for 5,318 categories of industrial and agricultural products to be imported to Taiwan from mainland China via a third place.
In an effort to widen Taiwan manufacturers' access to more low-cost materials and semi-finished products, Taiwan further liberalized restrictions on mainland imports in 1996, Chen said.

Before July 1, 1996, all products not listed as approved for import were forbidden. On that date, however, the government reversed this by publishing a list of categories of products forbidden to enter Taiwan, allowing all others to be imported.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR PILLARS OWNER INDICATED FOR THEFT OF TRADE SECRETS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct.2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The owner of Taiwan-based Four Pillars Enterprise and his daughter will go to trial in the United States following a federal grand jury indictment on 21 charges related to the theft of commercial secrets announced by the US Justice Department on Wednesday.

Businessman Yang Pin-yen and his daughter Yang Hwei-chen were arrested by US investigators Sept. 4 on charges of conspiracy, mail and wire fraud, money laundering, possession of stolen goods and theft of technological know-how from the Avery Dennison Corporation of Pasadena, California. They were freed on bail 13 days later and been subject to electronic monitoring since that time.

With no significant deviations from the original charges, the indictment alleges that Yang, 70, and his 39-year-old daughter, the manager for research and development at Four Pillars, carried out the scheme over nearly a decade, spanning from 1989 to 1997, with the assistance of Lee Ten-hong, a Dennison employee.

The Yangs' alleged theft of trade secrets would violate the 1996 Economic Espionage Act, the department said. Any violation of the law carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison, along with a US$500,000 fine.

Yang Ping-yen's Cleveland-based lawyer Patrick McLaughlin told CNA that the Yangs will plead not guilty to the charges against them at their arraignment by the state of Ohio's North District Court next week.

According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Lee confessed to his involvement in the crime last March, revealing that he received between US$140,000 and US$150,000 from Four Pillars over the eight-year period for providing the company with valuable technical know-how owned by Dennison.

In early June, Lee bargained with the FBI and prosecutors to face a less severe charge of wire fraud in exchange for his full cooperation in building a case against the Yangs and Four Pillars, which produces and markets adhesive products in the US, Taiwan, mainland China and Malaysia.
Avery Dennison is listed as one of the largest manufacturers in the US of self-adhesive products like postage stamps and tape for disposable diapers, employing over 16,000 personnel worldwide.
An estimate by the US Justice Department indicated that the value of the trade secrets allegedly stolen by Four Pillars amounted to between US$50 million and US$60 million.
Meanwhile, Dennison has filed a separate civil lawsuit against the Yangs and their company in order to seek compensation for the losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN LAWMAKERS PROMOTE LEGISLATION ON TAIWAN TIES

TEXT.P: A group of Russian parliamentarians are promoting legislation on relations with Taiwan to facilitate bilateral exchanges, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said on Friday.

Wang Wei-chieh, director of the ministry's West Asian Affairs department, told a routine news conference that Alexei Mitrofonov, chairman of the Geographical Policy Committee of the State Duma, the lower house of the Russian parliament, has introduced a bill on better regulating substantive Moscow-Taipei ties.
The bill was patterned after the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), a US law regulating relations between Taiwan and the United States in the absence of official ties.

Wang said the Mitrofonov-drafted bill provides for Taiwan-Russian civilian and commercial exchanges. Though the bill does not mention security commitments and arms sales to Taiwan like the US act, its content is very agreeable for Taiwan.
According to the Russian parliamentary rules, the bill must be approved by the Foreign Affairs Committee before it is referred to the plenary session for a second reading.

Wang said Mitrofonov called a public hearing on the bill in July, during which Russian Foreign Ministry officials voiced strong opposition to the bill. They said there was no need for new legislation since Russian President Boris Yeltsin had already issued an administrative decree to regulate unofficial Taipei-Moscow ties, adding the bill violated Russia's "one China" policy.
The bill has also drawn a strong backlash from the mainalnd Chinese embassy in Moscow, Wang noted.
As Russia has maintained far closer ties with Beijing than Taipei, Wang said, the bill is not expected to clear the Duma easily.

"Still, the bill marks a good beginning for our relations with Moscow," Wang said, adding that the bill still stands a chance to pass the Russian legislature through intense discussion and deliberation.

Touching on the privileges for ROC officials stationed in Moscow, Wang said a major breakthrough was achieved in this regard in September. Russian authorities have agreed to draft a bill providing for diplomatic immunities and other privileges to ROC officials.
The Russian parliament is expected to pass the bill before the end of this year, Wang said, adding, "By then, our representative office in Moscow will enjoy more freedoms to complete its work."
Wang said ROC-Russian relations have taken a big step forward since the inauguration of the Russian representative office in Taipei last December.
Meanwhile, Wang said direct flight services between the two countries are expected to start next spring to further boost bilateral tourist, cultural and commercial exchanges.
After more than three years of negotiations, Taiwan and Russia formally signed an agreement on the establishment of direct airlinks earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS CROSS-STRAIT HOSTILITY TERMINATED IN 1991

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Friday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not been in a state of hostility since May 1991.
Siew made the remarks when responding to questions by Legislator Kao Yu-jen. Kao asked if the two both sides of the Taiwan Strait have terminated their state of hostility by law.

Siew said that when the ROC constitutionally terminated the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of National Mobilization in May 1991, it substantially acknowledged the termination of hostility and the fact of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The ROC has taken the initiative to unilaterally renounce the use of force, and will instead employ only peaceful and democratic means to pursue national unification, Siew said.

Siew said that since the termination of the temporary provisions, Taipei has regarded Beijing as a political entity that has jurisdiction over mainland China. He pointed out that the ROC has also abolished the Statutes for the Purging of Communist Agents, as well as the Statutes for the Punishment of Insurrection.

Siew expressed the hope that Beijing would acknowledge Taiwan's sincerity and efforts in promoting cross-strait relations by making its own reciprocal announcement indicating the cessation of hostilities.

Kao also asked if Siew would stand by statements he had made as a legislator, urging the two sides to engage in talks regarding what is known as the "three links" -- direct postal, trade and transportation contacts -- and to set up offices of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in each other's capital. The two intermediary bodies were set up to handle civilian exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal ties.
Siew said that his stance has not changed but the premise of those suggestions will be that both sides deal with each other with respect and recognize the fact of separate rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE IN RELATIONS WITH BEIJING: MARTIN LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Democratic Party Chairman Martin Lee observed Thursday that his presence at celebrations organized by the government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) to mark mainland China's national day does not mean that relations between his party and the Chinese Communist Party have made great advances.

Lee came to the fore in 1989 by leading the people of Hong Kong in support for mainland students' protests for democratic reforms. Beijing crushed the protests in the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 4 that year.

Beijing has criticized the Hong Kong Democratic Party in recent years as an "anti-China" organization aimed at stirring up trouble and has prohibited its members, including Lee, from entering mainland China.

During its years as a British colony, Hong Kong held no celebrations of mainland China's national day. The Hong Kong bureau of the Xinhua news agency, then the de facto mainland embassy, sponsored some activities but never invited members of the Democratic Party to these.

When, three months after Hong Kong's handover to mainland control, Lee and other core members of the Democratic Party attended the HKSAR government's banquet for mainland China's national day, much speculation arose that the party had changed its attitude toward Beijing.
Lee said at the banquet that he is confident he will be permitted later to visit his homeland.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rebounded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 32.52 points to finish at 8,537.18.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,395.88 and experienced a high of 8,537.18.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 209 to 206, with 45 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.1 billion (US$3.12 billion).
Among the eight stock categories, electrical engineering shares rose 2.7 percent, while foodstuff issues and plastic and chemical issues surged 0.3 percent, respectively.
Paper and pulp stocks plunged 2.1 percent, ahead of a 1.9-percent drop by financial stocks, 0.9 percent by textile shares, 0.3 percent by cement issues, and 0.2 percent by construction stocks.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Macronic International, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, ACER, A.S.E., Orient Semiconductor Electronic, Mitac International, First International Computer, Kinpo Electronics, and Liton Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN TO GROW VIGOROUSLY: KAHT

TEXT.P: The head of the German Trade Office in Taipei said on Friday that he expects German investment in Taiwan will grow considerably as a result of the steps toward liberalization that the government of the Republic of China has taken in pursuit of its project to develop the island into an Asia-Pacific operations hub and in preparation for its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Hilmar Kaht, director-general of the office, made the remarks at a reception marking the seventh anniversary of Germany's reunification. Several ROC officials, including Fredrick Chien, speaker of the National Assembly, and Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, were present.

Kaht said that Taiwan and Germany have many characteristics in common, noting that both are highly industrialized and export-oriented, and depend to a significant extent on trade and investment abroad.

"With regard to this, Germany and Taiwan have reason to be well satisfied with each other," he said, noting that Taiwan is his country's fourth largest trade partner in the Asia-Pacific area, with an overall bilateral trade volume of US$9 billion in 1996.
Germany is Taiwan's largest trade partner in Europe, he added.

The representative also said that Taiwan-German trade and economic relations have been further enhanced by meetings and an exchange of delegations. He cited the visit of ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang to Bonn in June and the recent Taipei visit of German Minister of Economic Affairs Guenter Rexrodt as especially significant.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN DELEGATIONS TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Two separate delegations from Russia will visit Taiwan for celebrations of the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day, comprising one of the largest Russian contingents here in recent years, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
James Wang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, said that a six-member delegation led by former Russian Vice Premier Oleg Lobov will visit Taiwan Oct. 5-12.

Wang noted that Lobov had served as the chairman of the Moscow-Taipei Economic & Cultural Coordination Commission and as Russia's Economics minister. Lobov and John Chang, then ROC minister of Foreign Affairs, signed a protocol in Paris in 1992 that established the framework of bilateral relations. Moscow-Taipei and Taipei-Moscow Economic & Cultural Coordination Commissions were later set up under the protocol.
A four-member Russian parliamentarian delegation led by I.D. Grachev, deputy chairman of the committee on property, privatization and economic activity, will also visit here Oct. 8-16, Wang said.
Meanwhile, a delegation of journalists from Belarus will make its first visit to Taiwan for the National Day celebrations, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MORE COUNTRIES APPEAL FOR ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Four more countries appealed for the Republic of China's bid to rejoin the United Nations at the UN General Assembly debate on Friday.
The four ROC diplomatic allies -- the Commonwealth of Dominica, Senegal, Liberia and Chad -- cited a variety of reasons to back the ROC's UN bid.

Edison James, prime minister of the Commonwealth of Dominica, said in his address to the General Assembly debate session that the ROC was a UN founding member and once played an important role in the world body. Moreover, James said, the ROC is a robust, prosperous democracy, with its government and parliament elected through universal suffrage.
Against this backdrop, James said, all UN member states should not continue to ignore or block the ROC's efforts to rejoin the world body.

Speaking on the same occasion, Senegal's minister of foreign affairs, Moustapha Niasse, said readmission of the ROC will not only reinforce the UN's principle of membership universality but will also bring justice to the people of that country.

Niasse stressed that the ROC's economic, social and political developments all follow the directions set in the UN Charter and its contributions to the international community have proved that it is capable of fulfilling its obligations as a UN member.

Liberian Minister of Foreign Affairs Monie Captan said Liberia is also a UN founding member and has consistently backed the inclusion of all countries into the UN system. "Our policy is that any country which intends to join the UN should be given the right to realize its goal."

Captan said the UN General Assembly's 1971 Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC to make way for communist China, was inappropriate, adding the UN should re-examine the resolution and let the ROC have a voice in the world body.

He went on to say that the parallel participation in the UN by the ROC and mainland China will not hinder China's eventual peaceful reunification. "Such an arrangement will also contribute to regional security and world peace."

Mahamat Saleh Annadif, Chad's minister of foreign affairs, said the Chad government and people support the ROC's reentry into the world body based on the UN's own principle of membership universality.
Chad resumed diplomatic ties with the ROC in August 1997 after a 25-year hiatus. Its president, Colonel Idriss Deby, will make a state visit to Taiwan on Oct. 15-19.
The ROC lost its seat in the UN in 1971 when the world body accepted the communist government in Beijing as the sole representative of the Chinese people.

The UN General Assembly's steering committee on Sept. 17 rejected for a fifth straight year a request to consider the question of ROC representation. This year's petition, signed by 14 of Taipei's diplomatic allies, called for the re-examination of Resolution No. 2758.

A total of 15 countries -- Nicaragua, Fiji, Paraguay, El Salvador, Honduras, the Dominican Republic, Saint Christopher and Nevis, Swaziland, Burkina Faso, Belize, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Senegal, Chad and Liberia -- have so far spoken for the ROC's UN bid since the current General Assembly debate session started on Sept. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA SEEKS 'SAFER SEX' EDUCATION PROGRAM FROM AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China has asked Australia to provide a "safer sex" education program for its nearly 300 million adolescents so that it can reduce abortions and slow population growth.
Mainland China already has 1.2 billion inhabitants.

Under a A$500,000 (US$362,000) four-year pilot program, Australian experts will help mainland China map out plans to reduce abortions, slow population growth and provide information about the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV-AIDS.

Professor Roger Short, a reproductive physiologist with the Royal Women's Hospital and the University of Melbourne, told a meeting of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science in Adelaide on Thursday that Beijing has no national strategy for reaching the nation's youth, who increasingly are breaking with tradition and becoming sexually active.

Traditionally, mainland China's family planning efforts have relied upon social sanctions against premarital sex, a minimum legal marriage age of 24 years and the use of contraceptives after the birth of the first child, Short said.
He estimated contraceptive failures led to eight million abortions in mainland China last year.

He said reports that girl babies were selectively aborted in mainland China were incorrect. In fact, he said, new research shows that girls are "under-reported" at birth so couples can try again for a boy without officially violating Beijing's one-child policy.
"They turn up later in the statistics," Short claimed.
Short said Beijing was impressed with a video-based adolescent sex education program used in Australia and asked Australian experts to provide advice on sex education programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGRANTS TO SET UP TAIWAN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE IN SYDNEY

TEXT.P: Taiwanese business migrants residing and doing business in Sydney will set up the first Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Australia on October 25.

A 10-member ad hoc committee has been set up to organize the chamber, which will aim to help boost Taiwanese investment in Australia; upgrade the image of Taiwanese businessmen; promote understanding among members, the Australian government and Australian businessmen; and seek cooperation among members, Australian businessmen and overseas Chinese businessmen.
The organizing committee will hold a meeting on October 25 to elect the first chairman of the chamber and members of its board of directors.

"We believe our chamber will not only help members to promote their investment in Australia but also serve as a bridge in promoting trade between Taiwan and Australia," one committee member told CNA Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASSURED CLINTON-JIANG TALKS WON'T AFFECT ITS INTERESTS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Friday that the United States has assured Taiwan that the summit talks between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Oct. 28 will not damage Taiwan's interests.

Siew said that Taiwan will closely monitor the Washington-Beijing summit talks. The ROC representative to the United States, Jason Hu, has expressed Taiwan's concern over the summit to the US government and has obtained assurances that the talks will not affect Taiwan's interests, he added.

Answering questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, the premier said that his remark earlier this week that "the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could hold talks next spring" was "speculation" based on the international situation and Beijing's recent remarks on cross-strait ties.

The bottom line for cross-strait negotiations lies in the National Unification Guidelines, he said, noting that they specify "freedom, democracy and an equitable distribution of wealth" as the principles governing the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Siew stressed that he has ordered relevant government agencies to prepare for cross-strait talks. If mainland China maintains a friendly attitude toward Taiwan, next spring would be appropriate for talks between Taipei and Beijing, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S YOUNGER LEADERS SET NEW TONE (I)

TEXT.P: The close of the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) saw the retirement from the party's Central Committee of virtually all party veterans whose political careers began before 1949, The Straits Times pointed out in a commentary Friday.
For the first time in the history of the CCP, the decision-making body is composed of members who began their political careers shortly before 1949.
Such a development has great implications for mainland China, the article said.

The year 1949, when the Communists took control over mainland China, is used as a benchmark to demarcate generations. Revolutionaries like Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping are considered the first generation. People like Jiang Zemin and Li Peng who joined the party and public service around 1949 are the second generation, while those born after 1949 are the third generation.
Studies have found that those belonging to the second generation shared common characteristics.
They lacked the legendary revolutionary experiences and monumental achievements of the first generation to back up their claim to power.
They also lacked both the charisma and force of character characterizing the first generation.
This group was, therefore, more inclined toward a power-sharing arrangement within the ruling caucus.

Although collective leadership was an ideal for first generation leaders, it was never actually put into practice because of the strong character of its members. With the second generation, it stood a better chance of success.
Working under the shadow of the first generation leaders meant that second generation members had less room to innovate.
It was not until after the collapse of the Soviet Union that they were forced to take a more reformist line.
Having had a university education, the second generation leaders were also good technocrats.
They were more rational, willing to listen to different points of view and prepared to make greater use of think tanks in running the economy.
The results of the 15th party congress seem to confirm these observations, The Straits Times said.
The party congress showed an element of power-sharing, though not at the highest level, it noted.
The first sign of power-sharing was in 1995 when Jiang promoted 1,000 military officers to the rank of major-general and above in exchange for their loyalty, the article said.

At the 15th congress, the same strategy was adopted, though on a smaller scale, it added, noting that the Central Committee (comprising both full and alternate members) grew from 319 to 344 members, an increase of 7 percent.
The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection also expanded from 108 to 115 members, or 6 percent.
At the next tier up, the number of Politburo members (including alternate members) increased from 22 to 24, while the membership of the Central Secretariat rose from five to seven.
The two most powerful bodies -- the Standing Committee of the Politburo and the Central Military Commission -- were untouched. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S YOUNGER LEADERS SET NEW TONE (II)

TEXT.P: The daily said that the characteristics of the second generation -- power sharing, adherence to the teachings handed down from their party elders and a more technocratic approach to running state affairs -- might be just what mainland China needs to meet the challenges posed by the demise of strong-man politics there.

The retirement of party veterans from the Central Committee also brought about the obliteration of the "princelings" -- the sons and daughters of mainland China's rulers -- as a class, it said, noting that in the mid-1980s, they were considered one of the main sources of future leaders.
Another development worth noting is the ascendancy of regional forces, the article said.
The phenomenal growth in influence of the "regional" seats in the Central Committee is the direct result of the decentralization of power that was part of Deng's reform program, it said.
This increase in regional clout might pose problems for Beijing's ruling elite, for there are signs that the regional bosses are increasingly unwilling to toe Beijing's line, the daily noted.

Another hypothesis that could explain the big increase in seats for regional forces is again the power-sharing concept, it said, noting that Jiang might want to broaden his power base by allotting each province extra seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED DESPITE HOT TRADING

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Friday experienced rare hot trading of the US dollar on its foreign exchange market, with transactions hitting US$1,539 million.
Despite this, the value of the greenback remained unchanged at NT$28.601, opening at the day's high of NT$28.602 and closing at NT$28.601, also the day's low.

Dealers attributed the increased transactions to several factors, including remittances by the Foreign Affairs Ministry of US$100 million in aid and loans to friendly countries in Central and South America, and payment of an undisclosed sum by the Defense Ministry for foreign arms purchases, as well as the withdrawal of foreign capital from the local stock market, which has lost its steam recently.

Economics officials said that the hot trading also signaled a greenback-buying spree on the part of the private sector, taking advantage of the fact that the US dollar is gaining strength in the wake of the currency turmoil in several Southeast Asian countries.

But they said that the booming US dollar trading is still considered by the Central Bank of China (CBC) as being within "tolerable" limits. One of the principal priorities of the CBC is to maintain stable NT dollar and local commodity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGHER SUICIDE RATE AMONG TAIWAN'S ELDERLY

TEXT.P: Suicides among Taiwan residents aged over 65 posted an average rate of 30.33 per 100,000 people in 1996, much higher than the overall average rate of 8.61 per 100,000, according to statistics made public by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Thursday.
A total of 1,847 people committed suicide in Taiwan last year, of whom 1,250 were male and 597 were female.

The rate of suicide among the elderly was 2.5-fold that of the average and the increase in the number of suicides in this age group was also the highest, prompting one commentator to say that the government and society should provide more care to the elderly, especially since Taiwan officially became a "gray society" in 1993.

The statistics show that at the end of 1996, Taiwan had a total population of 21.47 million people, with the birth rate dropping to 7.9 per 1,000. Elderly people over 65 accounted for 7.9 percent of the total population.
Every nine people aged between 15 and 64 in Taiwan now have to support someone over 65, a heavier burden than ten years ago, when every 12 young people had to support one senior citizen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA RETURNS CHINESE BOAT PEOPLE TO OPEN SEA

TEXT.P: A total of 39 Chinese boat people who were found on the Indonesian island of Java were sent back to the open sea on Thursday afternoon, escorted by an Indonesian naval vessel.
Local authorities decided that the boat people, who included seven women, be returned to the high seas, Antara news agency said.
An inspection of the boat showed that none of the 39 passengers had any navigational instruments with them, except for a compass, and no other equipment apart from cooking utensils and a fishing net.

They told police that their destination was either Australia or New Zealand, where they hoped to find a better life and that they had been sailing for 40 days before being spotted and apprehended by an Indonesian patrol boat.
Before being sent on their way, the boat people were provided with enough food and fuel to allow them to reach their destination, probably Australia. (Wu Pin-chiang)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR PILLARS OWNER INDICTED FOR THEFT OF TRADE SECRETS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct.2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The owner of Taiwan-based Four Pillars Enterprise and his daughter will go to trial in the United States following a federal grand jury indictment on 21 charges related to the theft of commercial secrets announced by the US Justice Department on Wednesday.

Businessman Yang Pin-yen and his daughter Yang Hwei-chen were arrested by US investigators Sept. 4 on charges of conspiracy, mail and wire fraud, money laundering, possession of stolen goods and theft of technological know-how from the Avery Dennison Corporation of Pasadena, California. They were freed on bail 13 days later and been subject to electronic monitoring since that time.

With no significant deviations from the original charges, the indictment alleges that Yang, 70, and his 39-year-old daughter, the manager for research and development at Four Pillars, carried out the scheme over nearly a decade, spanning from 1989 to 1997, with the assistance of Lee Ten-hong, a Dennison employee.

The Yangs' alleged theft of trade secrets would violate the 1996 Economic Espionage Act, the department said. Any violation of the law carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison, along with a US$500,000 fine.

Yang Ping-yen's Cleveland-based lawyer Patrick McLaughlin told CNA that the Yangs will plead not guilty to the charges against them at their arraignment by the state of Ohio's North District Court next week.

According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Lee confessed to his involvement in the crime last March, revealing that he received between US$140,000 and US$150,000 from Four Pillars over the eight-year period for providing the company with valuable technical know-how owned by Dennison.

In early June, Lee bargained with the FBI and prosecutors to face a less severe charge of wire fraud in exchange for his full cooperation in building a case against the Yangs and Four Pillars, which produces and markets adhesive products in the US, Taiwan, mainland China and Malaysia.
Avery Dennison is listed as one of the largest manufacturers in the US of self-adhesive products like postage stamps and tape for disposable diapers, employing over 16,000 personnel worldwide.
An estimate by the US Justice Department indicated that the value of the trade secrets allegedly stolen by Four Pillars amounted to between US$50 million and US$60 million.
Meanwhile, Dennison has filed a separate civil lawsuit against the Yangs and their company in order to seek compensation for the losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN ENVOY NOT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT

TEXT.P: Russian envoy to Taiwan Victor Trifonov said on Friday that he is pessimistic about the Russian parliament's passage of a law regulating his country's relations with Taiwan.

Trifonov, chief of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission's Taipei office, was commenting on the "Taiwan Relations Bill" recently initiated by a group of Russian parliamentarians friendly to Taiwan.

In an interview with the CNA, Trifonov would not speculate on how many of Russia's more-than 400 parliamentarians would throw their support behind the bill, but he said he personally considered it "very difficult" for the Russian parliament, or Dumas, to pass the law, modeled after the one passed by the US Congress following Washington's switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.
The Taiwan Relations Act has formed the basis for Taipei-Washington exchanges in the absence of formal ties since then.

He said the reason for his pessimism is that Russian President Boris Yeltsin issued a decree in September, 1992, providing a framework for exchanges between Moscow and Taipei and thus there is no need for his country to enact a law to serve the same purpose.
But he said chances would be much higher for the parliament to enact laws and regulations on "substantial issues," such as the promotion of investment and the avoidance of double taxation.

Questioned about the presence of mainland Chinese embassy officials at a Russian public hearing on the new law, where they voiced their opposition, Trifonov said that whether Moscow needs such a law is an internal issue and has nothing to do with its relations with the mainland.
With regard to exchanges of high-level visits between Taiwan and Russia, Trifonov said that he believes exchanges of this nature will gradually increase in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW'S PERFORMANCE GETS THUMBS-UP

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew has achieved a nearly 70 percent approval rating for his performance since assuming the position one month ago, according to the result of a survey made public by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Friday.

The survey found that 15.65 percent of those interviewed think Siew's performance has been "quite satisfactory" and 53.85 percent described it as "satisfactory," while only 16.19 percent said that they are dissatisfied with his performance.

Some 24.06 percent of those polled chose "Siew's smile and his friendly character" as the thing that has most impressed them since Siew took office on Sept. 1. His decision to cancel preferential traffic control for the premier's limousine during rush hours won approval from 14.85 percent of the polled, followed by his "action cabinet" slogan with 14.04 percent, the importance he attaches to public opinion at 11.81 percent and his attempts to relax the tensions between the central government and the provincial government at 10.29 percent.

Asked about the priorities of the tasks facing Siew, improving social order was cited as the first priority by 58.68 percent of the respondents, while expanding diplomatic frontiers only garnered 5.37 percent and improving cross-strait relations was considered a priority by a tiny 1.88 percent.

Strengthening trade and economic development came as the second priority at 11 percent, followed by improving social welfare at 9.03 percent, promoting education quality and cultural activities at 5.46 percent, pushing for environmental protection at 3.76 percent and upgrading the island's defense capability at 1.97 percent.
The KMT's Central Policy Committee conducted the telephone survey of 1,118 adults around the island between Sept. 30 and Oct. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG CHING-KUO WAS GIMO'S NATURAL SON: MAINLAND BOOK

TEXT.P: A report that the late President Chiang Ching-kuo of the Republic of China was not the natural son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has come as a shock to the people of Taiwan and has become the hottest topic of the day.

The Taipei-based Business Weekly magazine said in its current issue that the report was based on information from Chiang Kai-shek's second son, the late General Chiang Wego, who died last month aged 81. Wego, who was actually Chiang's adopted son, said before his death that his brother Ching-kuo was also adopted.

Both Chiang Kai-shek (1887-1975) and Chiang Ching-kuo served as president of the Republic of China. A very important figure in modern China, Chiang Kai-shek served as president from 1948 to 1949 and after a brief retirement, from 1950 until his death in 1975. Chiang Ching-kuo (1910-1988) was president from 1978 to 1988.

The Business Weekly said that it got its information from Professor Fan Kuang-ling who teaches at Taiwan's Chung Hsing University. A good friend of Wego, Fan conducted a series of interviews with him over the past few years. At one of these interviews in 1994, Wego told Fan that his brother Ching-kuo, like him, was not the natural son of the generalissimo.

In an accompanying article in the magazine, Fan said he believes Wego was telling the truth because he talked with great calm and sincerity. He also said that all the interviews were recorded on tape.
However, a book entitled "Chiang Kai-shek's Family, published in mainland China, said Chiang Ching-kuo was indeed the natural child of Chiang Kai-shek and his first wife Mao Fu-mei.

The book's author reportedly consulted many documents and books in mainland China, Taiwan, Japan and the United States and the book was approved by the United Front Department of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee before its publication.

Meanwhile, another mainland book, "Mao Fu-mei, Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo," said Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo are natural father and son. It said that during the summer of 1909, Chiang came back for summer vacation from Japan, where he was attending a military academy. He and his wife spent a couple of months together in Shanghai before he returned to Japan.
It was during this period that Fu-mei became pregnant and their son Ching-kuo was born the following year.

The new report has caused great concern among the people of Taiwan. Some say the truth should come out, but most doubt the authenticity of the report. Many say that the Chiangs made such great contributions to the development of the Republic of China that reports such as this should be treated with care. "We will not believe it until there is enough evidence to prove it," one historian stressed, adding that as all three Chiangs are now dead, it will be almost impossible to confirm the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Saturday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 156.35 points to finish at 8,380.83.
The bourse opened at 8,402.22, and experienced a high of 8,429.64 and a low of 8,315.67.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 334 to 91, with 138 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.47 billion (US$3.27 billion).

Plastic and chemical shares declined the most at 3.7 percent, followed by financial issues at 2.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.6 percent, textile stocks at 2.3 percent, cement shares at 1.4 percent, electrical engineering issues at 1.2 percent, construction stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were Macronic International, United Micro Electronics, Winbond Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, China Steel, ACER, A.S.E., Kinpo Electronics, Orient Semiconductor Electronic and Mitac International.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LISTED AS FIFTH-LARGEST BUYER FOR US AGRICULTURAL GOODS

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked the United States' fifth-largest buyer of agricultural products in the first seven months of this year, ahead of mainland China, which dropped to eighth in the ranking from fifth in 1996, according to statistics released on Friday by the US Department of Agriculture.

The figures show that the 10 largest overseas agricultural markets for the US in the period were Japan, Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Taiwan, the Netherlands, Hong Kong, mainland China, Germany and Britain, in that order.
The US exported US$32.08 billion-worth of agricultural goods during the January-July period of this year, down 8.6 percent from the same period of last year, the statistics show.
Around 19.6 percent of this total was shipped to Japan, while Taiwan bought approximately US$1.504 billion-worth of US agricultural products.

Including products from the fishery and forestry sectors, the tallies indicate that Taiwan still ranks as the fifth-largest foreign buyer from the US, with total purchases valued at US$1.602 billion in the seven-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 17TH-LARGEST INVESTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's 1996 direct outbound investment hit US$3.096 billion, making it the 17th-largest investor in the world, according to the latest United Nations report on world investment.
The report indicates that Taiwan's 1996 net capital outflow reached US$1.694 billion to rank the nation fourth among the world's developing countries, trailing Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.

The world's top 13 outbound investors, according to the report, are the United States, Britain, Germany, France, Japan, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Belgium, Canada, Italy, Norway, Sweden and Spain, in that order.
Taiwan's direct outbound investment has grown steadily over the past five years, with 1996 seeing a growth of 22.9 percent, or US$840 million, over 1995.
The report also said that Taiwan attracted direct inbound investment of US$1.42 billion in 1996, a decrease of about 10 percent from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD WTO TALKS WITH SINGAPORE, UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore will hold a new round of World Trade Organization (WTO) talks on Taiwan's terms for entry into the world trade regulatory body, Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said on Saturday.

Chen said that the talks will be held when representatives from both nations attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's Special Senior Official Meeting in Singapore, scheduled for Oct. 27-28.
Chen said Singapore is expected to present a list of 40 industrial items, including petrochemical, electric and electronics products upon which the city-state hopes that Taiwan will cut tariffs.

High on the agenda of the talks will be Singapore's request for Taiwan to open maritime auxiliary services, including maritime cargo handling services, storage and warehousing services in ports, maritime agency services, maritime freight forwarding services and container station and depot services.

Chen said that during ministerial-level WTO talks last year, Taiwan and Singapore reached a preliminary agreement to complete the maritime services talks before 2000. But as a global framework has yet to be completed, it is doubtful that Taiwan will make any promises in this regard in the absence of such a framework, he added.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's latest week-long round of WTO talks with the United States will be held in Taipei from Oct. 16, when both sides are expected to discuss questions outstanding in the agricultural, industrial, service and government procurement fields.
The opening of US markets for pork bellies, offal, beef and other agricultural products are expected to be the main focus of these talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOOK PUBLISHED ON LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: A new book, "Lee Kuan Yew, The Man and His Ideas," which chronicles the development of Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's key political ideas was officially launched on Friday.
During the launch ceremony, Lee personally presented some 150 copies of a hardcover, gilt-edged signed edition of the book to people who donated S$10,000 to charity.
The book, written by three Straits Times journalists, recounts Lee's accomplishments and the reasons behind them, but draws no conclusions, leaving that up to the reader.
Orders for the book have been streaming in and booksellers believe that all 25,000 copies of the first print run are likely to be snapped up soon.
In will also be available in Malaysia, Indonesia, Australia and Japan. Orders by mail have been coming in "fast and furious" since last Saturday, said a leading local bookseller.
