DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK-WHITE IQ GAP

TEXT.P: White students tend to outscore black students by as many as 15 IQ points during their senior years in high school, but blacks effectively cut their IQ gap with whites in half by graduation from college.

This is one of the key findings of a new study from Washington University in St. Louis that holds important implications for the current debate over federal and state attempts to rollback affirmative action programs.

"Our study shows that differences in IQ test scores among blacks and whites may have little to do with genetics and much to do with the relative quality of the educational opportunities afforded to blacks and whites," said Mark R. Rank, an associate professor at the university's George Warren Brown School of Social Work.

The study also blasts holes in several controversial theories put forth by The Bell Curve, a 1994 book by conservative social theorists Charles Murray and the late Richard Herrnstein. The book and its theories on race-based intelligence are credited by some with fueling the attack on affirmative action.

"The message for the affirmative action debate is that black students who finish college appear to make dramatic gains in cognitive abilities," said Joel Myerson, research instructor in the School of Medicine's Health Administration Program and a member of the Washington University research team. "White students also improve during college, but to a lesser extent."

"The more important point," Myerson added," is that the level of ability black students exhibit at the end of college would have been greatly underestimated based on how they tested when they took college entrance exams in high school. For at least some black high school students, the SAT and other common college entrance exams may not provide an accurate picture of their potential."

The findings have implications for debates now raging over the use of racial preferences in affirmative action programs, including California's controversial Proposition 209. Effective last September, Prop. 209 makes it illegal to use race as a factor in awarding government contracts, scholarships and other perquisites commonly included in affirmative action programs.

The Washington University study provides ammunition for those seeking to maintain some form of racial preferences by offering evidence that some blacks are indeed more qualified than their test scores indicate. The test scores of some whites also may not reflect their true potential, but this research suggests that scores that underestimate future performance may be more common among blacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND KING HONORED WITH MILITARY SALUTE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday presided over an official welcoming ceremony for King Mswati III of Swaziland, who arrived in Taipei on Friday for a six-day state visit.
Mswati was honored with a 21-gun salute during an official welcoming ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.
The king was then joined by President Lee to review an honor guard in front of the hall.
Lee extended a hearty welcome to Mswati, saying his visit symbolizes the closeness of relations between the Republic of China and Swaziland.
Swaziland has been a staunch supporter and close ally of the ROC since 1968, when the southern African nation won independence from its British colonial rulers, Lee noted.
Mswati's visit, his third since ascending the throne in 1986, heralded a new era in friendship between the two countries, Lee said.

Replying to Lee's welcoming address, the Swazi king said his visit is aimed at seeking ways to strengthen economic cooperation and other exchanges, both official and private, between the two countries under the principles of mutual trust, understanding and respect.
While here, Mswati and his entourage will meet with Premier Vincent Siew, Vice Premier and Foreign Affairs Minister John Chang and Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.

The king will also join President Lee in signing a joint communique to further accelerate bilateral ties, as well as meeting with representatives from Taiwan's industrial and maritime transport sectors for business talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUGUST WORLDWIDE CHIP SALES HIT US$11.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Asia-Pacific semiconductor market, excluding Japan, recorded August sales of US$2.576 billion, an 18.5 percent sales increase compared to the same period of last year, said the Semiconductor Industry Association's (SIA) monthly Global Sales Report released on Friday.

On the other hand, the American market is still dominant and the fastest-growing in the world, with total sales of US$3.858 billion, which helped push global semiconductor sales in August 1997 to US$11.6 billion, a 15.3 percent increase over sales recorded in August 1996.

"This marks the fourth straight month of strong year-to-year growth for the semiconductor industry," said SIA President George Scalise. "Despite some seasonal sluggishness in the European and Japanese markets, all indicators suggest the global industry is growing as we start the fourth quarter."

The global sales data, compiled by the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics Organization, shows that August's sales were nearly identical to July 1997 sales in all four major chip markets, the Americas, Europe, Japan and the Asia-Pacific. "This is particularly good news because sales stayed strong during the peak summer vacation season," Scalise said.

On a month-to-month basis, the Asia-Pacific region had the best performance in August, with a 1.8 percent growth from the previous month, while the Americas market rose 0.4 percent. In Europe and Japan, where August sales traditionally decrease, sales declined by 1 percent and 1.3 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKERS MORE COMPETITIVE: CLA

TEXT.P: Workers in Taiwan's manufacturing sector are more competitive than their counterparts from other major APEC economies in terms of wages and pay increase rates, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported on Saturday.

In a recent survey of nominal wages and pay increase rates among manufacturing workers in Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and the United States, the council found that among laborers in Taiwan's manufacturing sector, monthly nominal wages, averaging US$1,225 in 1995, were the second-lowest among the six major APEC economies, ahead only of Hong Kong's US$1,090.
By comparison, average monthly nominal wages in South Korea were US$1,457, US$1,522 in Singapore, US$4,153 in Japan and US$2,230 in the United States.
In terms of pay increase rates, Taiwan posted the lowest among four "Asian Dragons" during the period of 1991-1995, the officials said.
Average salaries increased 8.35 percent during the five-year period, as compared with 9.29 percent in Hong Kong, 11.79 percent in South Korea and 14.61 percent in Singapore.

CLA officials pointed out that Taiwan's relatively low nominal wages and slower pay increase rates were key factors in making the island's manufacturing sector more competitive than those of other major APEC economies.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's average annual working hours totaled 2,418 in 1995, down five hours from 1991's 2,423 hours. The 1995 figure was lower than those posted in Singapore and South Korea, but much higher than those in Hong Kong, Japan and the United States, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORBES PUBLISHES SUPPLEMENT ON ROC

TEXT.P: US business magazine Forbes will publish a special supplement on the Republic of China in its Oct. 13 edition, in celebration of the ROC's Double-Tenth National Day, which falls on Oct. 10, hence the name.
The nine-page supplement will introduce the latest political and economic developments in the ROC in recent years.

In a preface to the supplement, ROC President Lee Teng-hui writes that the ROC remains dedicated to building upon Taiwan's economic and political achievements of recent decades to assure its survival and sustainable growth well into the 21st century.

As the new millennium approaches, exciting changes in the economic and political landscape of Taiwan hold the promise of even more astonishing successes in the years to come, Lee said, pointing out that the government and private sectors are increasingly working hand-in-hand to turn Taiwan into a hub of activity for the Asia-Pacific region, with the intention of attracting more foreign investment.

Noting that sustainable economic development over the long term will require a healthy democratic political climate, Lee said the recent round of constitutional revisions has provided the proper system of checks and balances to ensure that the executive and legislative branches of government can work productively to forge the national policies needed for the new century.
The supplement, headlined "Taiwan: on the Global Fast Track," tells of the booming ROC economy, describing it as the world's 19th-largest economy and the 14th-largest trading nation.
The article said that in just a few years, the island has boldly transformed itself from a society ruled by martial law into a near-full-fledged democracy.

The article cited the words of David Tawei Lee, director general of the ROC Government Information Office, who said: "The blossoming of democracy in Taiwan represents a political miracle rivaling the success of Taiwan's economic development."

Lee also noted the advantages of investing in Taiwan and urged US hi-tech and aviation companies to invest in his country. The article also explains in detail Taiwan-US trade relations, US investment in Taiwan and the nation's flagship Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
Forbes, a bi-weekly magazine, has a circulation of 760,000 and is one of the most influential business magazines in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC UN BID GETS MORE SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Two more nations expressed their support for the Republic of China's efforts to rejoin the United Nations, calling Friday for the UN to abide by the principles and purposes of its charter.

Foreign Minister of the Solomon Islands Pattefon Oti said in his speech to the 52nd UN General Assembly that the Republic of China, which is fully committed to the purposes and principles of the UN charter, has the means to be an active contributor to the organization's work.

Later that day, Foreign Minister Fayez Zawarneh of Jordan called for UN membership for all peace-loving states in accordance with Article IV (1) of the charter, in order to achieve the universality of the charter.
Oti also mentioned the peaceful reunification of China, affirming that the participation of the ROC in the UN would greatly assist in successful negotiations on the matter.
Bringing about and successfully completing these negotiations will be a long and difficult process that would be greatly helped by the participation of the ROC in the UN, he claimed.
He also condemned Beijing for threatening his country and other states that have spoken on behalf of the ROC.

"Regrettably, threats have been made and actions taken against Solomon Islands and other member-states that have spoken on behalf of the Republic of China. Even the use of force against us has been threatened, in violation of the charter's principles and the letter and spirit of numerous General Assembly resolutions," he said.
"Threats have no place at the United Nations," he emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SUFFERS DROP IN TOURISTS FROM TAIWAN (I)

TEXT.P: Hit hard by racial debates, increasing competition and strict entry requirements, Australia has suffered its first setback in luring more tourists from Taiwan since Canberra opened air links with Taipei in 1991, travel agents and officials said.
Between July 1, 1996 and June 30, 1997, the number of Taiwanese tourists to Australia dropped 3.6 percent to 152,366 from the previous year, according to the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC).

"This is the first drop Australia has ever experienced since it opened air links with Taiwan to lure Taiwanese tourists to the Down Under," Joseph Hunghai Ru, director of the Sydney office of the Taiwan Visitors Association, said in an interview with CNA.

He said Australia failed to attract tourists from Taiwan because of a number of factors, including the need for a visa, keener competition from the United States and Europe, more expensive travel packages and, above all, the racial debate triggered by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson.
The previous Labor Party government decided to waive visa requirements for Taiwanese tourists this year, but the change of the government in March 1996 has delayed the process.
The government of the Republic of China, however, waived visa requirements for Australian citizens several years ago.

This lack of reciprocity has annoyed many Taiwanese tourists. Many countries, including the United States and some in Europe, have eased travel restrictions for Taiwanese visitors, travel agents said.
They said the visa requirement causes delays and inconvenience for organizing group tours from Taiwan to Australia.

Traveling to Australia is more expensive than to other countries a similar distance away, and the United States is trying very hard to lower air fares and accommodation rates to attract more tourists from Taiwan and other Asian countries, the agents said.

A new survey, commissioned by the Tourism Council of Australia (TCA) and conducted by the University of Western Sydney and Anderson Consulting, found that Australia is one of the most expensive tourist destinations.

The racial debate here since late 1996 has also made things worse for Australia as more and more tourists from Taiwan and other Asian countries believe going to the Down Under might no longer be safe or enjoyable.

Ru said Taiwan is a leading tourist market for many countries because at least five million Taiwanese travel abroad every year. And Taiwanese visitors are known as big spenders in many countries. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SUFFERS DROP IN TOURISTS FROM TAIWAN (II)

TEXT.P: Travel agents blamed the decline of Taiwanese visitors on unfavorable conditions in Australia and they warned Australia could lose still more Asian visitors.
Tourism contributes more than a million jobs and earns more than 10 percent of Australia's gross domestic product, according to the two surveys by the Bureau of Tourism in Australia.

TCA managing director Bruce Baird, who opened the Australian Tourism Conference in Sydney on Friday, said Australian tourism accounted for one in nine jobs and had a turnover of more than US$36 billion.

Federal Tourism Minister John Moore told the Sydney conference: "In many of our markets, Australia is constantly nominated as the preferred destination, but only a small percentage of these potential tourists actually visit here. The challenge which clearly confronts us is to convert these preferences into actual visits."

Soon after Australia opened air links with Taiwan in late 1991 with the aim of boosting tourism and bilateral trade, the number of Taiwanese visitors surged from about 35,000 a year to 63,500 in 1992. Tourism from Taiwan became Australia's fastest growing tourist market.
But the situation has changed.

Between July 1996 and June 1997, the only negative growth in tourism Australia suffered came from Taiwan. But Australia also had markedly reduced growth in the number of tourists from major markets such as Korea, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand, travel agents said.
"This is an alarm bell for Australia because the tourism industry is one of the top foreign exchange earners for this country," one agent commented.
Overall, between July 1996 and June 1997, Australia attracted more than 4.25 million foreign tourists, up 7.2 percent from the previous year.
This increase, however, is less than agents have hoped for in advance of the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, one agent noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE INAUGURATES 1ST F-16 SQUADRON

TEXT.P: The ROC's first squadron of F-16 fighter jets was inaugurated on Saturday at an air force base in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, at a ceremony presided over by Air Force commander-in-chief Gen. Huang Hsien-jung and several other top-ranking military commanders.
The inauguration ceremony capped five months of intensive training and preparation by air force personnel to fly and maintain the advanced US-built fighter jets.

The squadron is comprised of 18 Lockheed-Martin made F-16 A/B (MLU) aircraft, Former US President George Bush agreed in 1992 to Taipei's request to purchase 150 of the planes as part of an ongoing plan to upgrade the island's defensive capabilities.
The planes have gradually been delivered to Taiwan over the past year.
At the ceremony, Gen. Huang inspected the new squadron and presented awards to flight officers and ground crews for successfully completing the transfer to the new aircraft.
He said the squadron's ability to adapt to the new aircraft in such a short period demonstrated the flexibility and capability of the revamped and modernized air force.

Describing flight safety as one of the air force's top priorities, Huang had particular praise for the ground crews, which have had to be completely re-trained to handle the new aircraft, which are designed for "next generation" warfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARDS IN CIRCULATION IN TAIWAN UP 52.9 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Saturday that as of July, there are 6.91 million credit cards in circulation in Taiwan, up 52.9 percent from the same period of last year.
Among the cards issued, international credit cards account for 94.5 percent of the total, a 6.4 percent increase from last July.
The DGBAS estimated that there are now 32 credit cards for every 100 people in Taiwan, up 50 percent from the same period of last year.

Taiwan cardholder transactions were worth a total of NT$210 billion (US$7.31 billion) between January and July, up 43.1 percent from the same seven-month period of last year, with NT$179.5 billion-worth of transactions taking place in Taiwan and NT$30.5 billion-worth of credit slips being signed overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGTEL TAKES FCC TO COURT OVER RATE-CUT MOVE

TEXT.P: Singapore Telecommunications Corporation (SingTel) has taken court action to overturn the United States Federal Communications Commission (FCC)'s one-sided decision to cut international settlement rates on overseas calls.

SingTel said on Saturday it filed a lawsuit two days ago at the US Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia, claiming the FCC order was "outside its lawful jurisdiction and that it was arbitrary due to the unilateral setting of benchmark levels, in spite of a lack of cost data."
The corporation said it hoped the FCC's order to slash rates could be "invalidated" so that all carriers could work jointly to achieve an amicable solution towards global reform of accounting rates.

Settlement rates are the amounts phone companies charge each other to complete the connection of international calls and SingTel's petition followed similar action by other regional telecommunications operators.

On August 28, the FCC said it would proceed with plans to cut the rates by up to 70 percent from January next year, setting new, lower benchmarks for international settlement rates in an effort to reduce a US$5.4 billion payment deficit by US telephone companies to foreign carriers.
The move places a ceiling on the settlement rates US-based carriers have to pay their foreign counterparts.

The FCC has categorized Singapore and other developed countries and areas like Japan and Hong Kong as high-income nations -- a decision which would reduce drastically the settlement fees paid to their phone companies, cutting the 42 US cents per minute SingTel currently receives for completing calls to just 15 US cents.

SingTel said it does not agree with such unilateral action and believes that global reform of settlement rates should be carried out on a multilateral basis, in an international forum such as the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).
The ITU, a Geneva-based arm of the United Nations, regulates the worldwide telecommunications market.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.052 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Saturday, finishing at NT$28.549.
The greenback opened at NT$28.6 and was traded between NT$28.602 and NT$28.45.
Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$528 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF ANNOUNCES 7 PERCENT BOURSE LIMIT TO REMAIN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Saturday announced that the current 7 percent daily rise-fall cap on individual stocks' values on the Taiwan Stock Exchange will remain in order to help keep trading stable.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's top economic planning agency, proposed in July to remove the eight-year-old limitation in line with the island's financial liberalization.
After the MOF questioned the proposal, however, the Executive Yuan asked the ministry to investigate its feasibility and to report the results of the study in three weeks.

At an unscheduled press conference Saturday, MOF Vice Minister Yen Ching-chang officially announced the ministry's decision to preserve the rule, stressing that a stably developing stock market is more important at the present than dropping the cap.

Currently, over 90 percent of total turnover in the local bourse comes from individual investors. Because of this, Yen said, trading on the market is easily swayed by rumors and the speculation of investors.

The weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange has experienced several significant drops over the past few weeks as the result of weak confidence in the market in the wake of financial crises in Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELGIAN PRIEST ATTRACTED BY MOUNTAINOUS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: He likes to ride his 150cc motorcycle on deserted roads deep into the mountains of Hsinchu County to visit his aboriginal friends and share Maiyouji (chicken stewed in rice wine and sesame oil) with them.

People might guess that Olivier Lardinois, a handsome, 183cm-tall young Belgian, who also enjoys stopping off at roadside foodstands in downtown Hsinchu to eat fried "stinky" tofu, is a traveler rather than a Catholic curate.

Lardinois was ordained into the priesthood on Saturday during an ordination ceremony presided over by Most Reverend Luke Liu, DD, of the Bishop's Office of Hsinchu Diocese, officially kicking off his career as a father in Taiwan.

The 33-year-old, with a masters degree in history from Belgium's University of Louvain, first came to Taiwan seven years ago to study Mandarin Chinese and work at the Catholic Huakuang Development Center in Hsinchu City.

After five years of clergy work in Hsinchu's mountainous areas of Wufeng, Chienshih and Chutung, inhabited mainly by aboriginal Atayal tribespeople, Lardinois decided to devote the rest of his life to the Catholic church in Taiwan.

Asked once whether he doesn't think it a waste of time for him to spend so much of his life in the backwater mountain districts, he replied that not only does he enjoy being a "mountain man," he also considers his having the opportunity to preach in the mountains as "blessed."

Like most ordinary men, Lardinois has dreamed of having his own family and raising several children. But that dream is now definitely gone because of his choice to enter the priesthood. Lardinois said he has no regrets about this, saying that he will have thousands of brothers, sisters, mothers and children now that he has become a father.

Lardinois, who also enjoys strolling through night markets to see the many and varied faces of the local people, said he has found the people of Taiwan to be energetic and full of passion, although he lamented that they don't seem to pay much attention to their environment. He expressed the hope that the people of Taiwan will learn to love mother nature more so that Taiwan will remain "Ilha Formosa" -- the beautiful island -- forever.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HISTORY MATERIAL ACCESSED THROUGH INTERNET

TEXT.P: At a ceremony in Taipei on Friday, National Taiwan University (NTU) unveiled a new collection of materials related to the history of Taiwan, including the island's indigenous tribes.
The new materials, both pictures and text, have been digitized and are accessible on the World Wide Web.

At the ceremony, Kao Cheng-shang, head of the Taipei City Government's Aboriginal Affairs Office, told participants the new collection would help dispel the long-standing myth that Taiwan's history only began some 400 years ago when Han Chinese began to settle on the island.
The materials contain a great deal of valuable information on Taiwan's aboriginal tribes, who had been living on the island long before the Han arrived, he said.

Professor Wu Mi-tsung of NTU's department of history said the recorded historical materials gathered under the project had provided little information about Taiwan before settlers started arriving 400 years ago.
But information obtained through archaeological studies and ethnologists have shed light on the island's aboriginal history, he said.

Discussing the progress that had been made by anthropologists and archaeologists in recent years. Hsieh Hsu-chang,chair of the university's anthropology department, said preliminary research on some 1,500 graves recently discovered in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County indicates they may date back 5,500 years.
Many other sites being examined around the island appear to be around 2,500 years old, he added.

Based on scientific research, he said, aboriginal culture probably didn't appear on Taiwan earlier than the New Stone Age. But he added that the existence of an earlier culture still could not be ruled out.
The collecting and digitizing of historical materials on Taiwan is the first stage of the university's efforts to build a large electronic database, NTU President Chen Wei-chao said.
The database project calls for materials to be collected covering such disciplines as history, library science, anthropology, computer science and electrical engineering.
Chen said scanning and electronically storing the historical materials would preserve them for future generations.
Information on the history of the aborigines that inhabited Taiwan's plains regions is already available on the Internet, he said.
The information can be found on the World Wide Web at http://ntudlm.csie.ntu.edu.tw/. The website is currently only in Chinese.
The university is hoping that the database will provide everyone interested with an unparalleled learning environment for the study of Taiwan's history.
University officials also said that the database is being constructed in full conformity with the standards of international museums and research institutions.
The project is the only one of its kind in Asia to form cooperative links with the Museum Information Exchange Association, a worldwide organization, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREX RESERVES EXPECTED TO DROP BELOW US$85 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves are expected to drop below US$85 billion in the wake of the Central Bank of China (CBC) injecting some of the island's official reserves into the local foreign exchange market to stop the New Taiwan dollar from depreciating, local market sources said on Saturday.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves dropped to around US$82.55 billion last March from US$90.08 billion because of nervousness related to mainland China's missile tests near the island, but later increased to around US$90 billion by May this year following a thaw in Taipei-Beijing relations.
However, the impact of the financial crises in Southeast Asia in July reversed the upward trend, with Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves falling to US$87.79 billion in August.
With the CBC injecting capital into the foreign exchange market to maintain the stability of the local currency, the amount is expected to decrease further.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG HOPES US MEET WILL OPEN NEW ERA IN BILATERAL RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's first state visit to Washington will take place in late October and Jiang hopes the trip will open a new era in bilateral relations.

The visit will take place against the background of improved relations between Beijing and Washington and Jiang's confirmation as leader at the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC), of which Jiang is also general secretary.
Jiang assumed the post of CPC General Secretary after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, which means he well-knows the pressure of public opinion from the international community.

After assuming the presidency of mainland China in 1993, Jiang was active in foreign affairs, particularly with Washington, and was heavily influenced by Deng Xiaoping, the old guard of the second generation mainland leadership, who also had a keen interest in US relations, realizing as he did that reform in mainland China would depend on the country's integration into the world community.

When Jiang met with US President Bill Clinton for the second time in Seattle in 1994, he made it clear that Beijing's standpoint toward Washington is "increasing confidence, decreasing trouble, developing cooperation and having no confrontation." It is Jiang's hope that he will be able to confirm the following five principles of their bilateral relationship:
-- Handle relations between Beijing and Washington with an eye to world trends and the 21st century;
-- Get rid of the differences in social systems and ideologies between the two sides and tackle all the problems with goodwill;
-- Take advantage of one another's characteristics and promote all-round economic cooperation based on equality and mutual benefit;
-- Cooperate in preventing arms proliferation, promoting environmental conservation, cracking down on drugs and terrorism;
-- Enhance mutual visits and high-level contacts.

Last March, with relations between Beijing and Washington thawing gradually, Jiang told Al Gore, US vice president and highest-ranking US leader to visit Beijing after Deng's death and the Tiananmen massacre, that in order to enter into the next century with a sound and stable peace, there are three principles which should be adhered to firmly -- consistently adhering to the principle of mutual interests, standing higher and viewing farther, and acting in accordance with the three joint communiques in handling the Taiwan problem properly.

Jiang's interpretation of the above principles is worthy of much attention. For the first principle, Jiang this time stressed "mutual interests" instead of "common enemy," as he has done in the past. The second principle sounds rather empty, but what it really means is that Beijing must stick to its policy of reform and opening-up. The third principle is of most significance to Taipei as it emphasizes not letting the Taiwan problem affect the progress of Sino-US bilateral relations.

It seems that Jiang's three principles have received a positive response from Washington, which is probably why Jiang used the Chinese idiom "the sky clears up after long rain" to depict bilateral relations when he met with House Speaker Newt Gingrich two days after the meeting with Gore.

Viewed with hindsight, Deng's five principles of 1994 can be seen as a fledgling form of Jiang's pattern, while the present three principles represent the complete emergence of Jiang's own philosophy.

Jiang is talking about the three principles prior to the meeting with US President Bill Clinton, indicating that he is hoping they will be accepted by Washington and merged into the bilateral relationship.

According to informed sources, although a fourth communique is not likely to be signed during Jiang's visit, it is still Beijing's yearning that Clinton and Jiang will present a common stance to the world, which will lead to a new era with mutual interests as the basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: SE ASIA'S HAZE MAY NOT DISSIPATE UNTIL NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The haze that has lingered for months over the area around Indonesia will probably not dissipate fully until sometime between the first and third week of November, when the northeast monsoon sets in and the increasing showers help put out the forest fires in Indonesia, said an official with Singapore's Ministry of the Environment.

In the next six weeks, there is a "slim chance" -- less than 10 percent -- that the daily PSI (Pollutants Standard Index) readings in Singapore will go into the "very unhealthy range" of over 200, he predicted.

Since the Environment Ministry started providing daily PSI readings in August, haze levels over Singapore have hovered in the moderate to unhealthy range below 200. The highest 24-hour reading so far is 138.
The official said that the severity of the haze here depends mainly on the direction of the wind and how close the fires are to Singapore.
The haze, an annual phenomenon, is particularly bad this year because more land in neighboring Indonesia is on fire and the very dry weather has exacerbated the conditions, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MALAYSIA UNAFFECTED BY FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Despite the slip in the Malaysian ringgit against the US dollar, Taiwan's investment and trade relations with Malaysia have not been affected, a Taipei official stationed here said Saturday.

Paul Tso, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia, said that Taiwan businessmen had launched 31 investment projects worth some US$91.35 million in Malaysia during the first seventh months of the year.

"In terms of accumulated investment value in Malaysia, Taiwan is the second-largest foreign investor, second only to Japan," Tso said while attending the opening ceremony of the annual meeting of the Taiwan Businessmen Association in Malaysia.

In his first public speech since assuming the position on Sept. 17, Tso expressed optimism over the Malaysian economy, saying that Malaysia's economic structure is quite stable and that the government has the ability to take effective remedial measures. Malaysia can soon overcome the financial crisis which has plagued the countries of Southeast Asia for months, he added.

"Trade ties between Taiwan and Malaysia are progressing," Tso said, adding that the two-way trade volume reached US$3.25 billion between January and July, up 11.72 percent from the same period of last year. Malaysia exported goods worth US$1.59 billion to Taiwan, and imported goods valued at US$1.66 billion from Taiwan, Tso said.

Taiwan remains Malaysia's fourth-largest trading partner, while Malaysia is Taiwan's seventh-largest trading partner. The current financial crisis does not affect Taiwan's trade and investment relations with Malaysia, Tso said.

The Malaysian ringgit has eroded more than 30 percent against the US dollar since July, while the stock market has lost about one-third in capitalization, amid a spate of turmoil involving regional currencies set off by the devaluation of the Thai baht. The Malaysian ringgit closed at a rate of 3.3825 to one US dollar on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS MAY RESUME BY YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait may resume consultations by the end of this year, a local mainland China affairs expert said on Sunday.
Pan Hsi-tang, a Tamkang University professor, made the forecast at a seminar on prospects for cross-strait political talks.
Pan said Taipei and Beijing have offered olive branches to each other in recent days in an attempt to create a friendly atmosphere in preparation for resumption of stalled bilateral talks.
Those moves are also intended to feel out each other's terms for the resumption of dialogue, Pan noted.

Although many observers have predicted that cross-strait talks will not resume until next spring, Pan said he does not rule out the possibility that the two sides could return to the negotiation table late this year.

Pan said if the outcome of the upcoming summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland President Jiang Zemin meet Beijing's expectations and if the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party wins in Taiwan's year-end mayoral and county magistrate elections, the mainland leadership is very likely to reopen talks with Taiwan before year's end with a view to "stemming the island's independence movement and promoting China's reunification."

Pan further predicted that future cross-strait talks will focus on political issues instead of nonpolitical technical issues and that the level of participating officials will be higher than in the past.
Professor Hsu Yu of the military-run Fuhsingkang College, however, disagreed with Pan's viewpoints, saying that next spring is the earliest possible juncture for the resumption of cross-strait talks.

Hsu said ROC President Lee Teng-hui is expected to speak on cross-strait issues in his New Year's message while mainland President Jiang will also air his views on the same topic in his message to be released on the eve of Chinese lunar new year.
"Only after the top leaders of the two sides have expressed their opinions about the agenda can cross-strait consultations resume," Hsu asserted.
Speaking on the same occasion, Ma Chi-hua, a National Chengchi University professor, said that for both Taipei and Beijing, negotiation is not a choice, but a necessity.

"Beijing would like to maintain a comparative state of peace in the Taiwan Strait because it is afraid that a cross-strait military confrontation would affect its economic development and the implementation of its `one country, two systems' formula in Hong Kong and Macau," Ma analyzed.

Against this background, Ma said, Beijing would desire a resumption of talks with Taiwan to reach an agreement on certain controversial issues. "Mainland China's stance is to prepare for war while seeking peace. As for Taiwan, its stance is the avoidance of war through negotiation," Ma said.

Touching on possible developments in future cross-strait political talks, Professor Liang Chung-ming of Nan Hua Management College, said Taipei and Beijing will continue to express their own opinions in the short term.

They are expected to remove any preconditions for talks in the medium term, Liang said, adding that over the long run, discussion will focus on constitutional amendments on each side and that both sides will mull the possibility of legislating a "China Basic Law" to regulate relations among the Chinese mainland, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

Some scholars also suggested at the seminar that academics from both sides of the strait meet to discuss some controversial issues, such as the "one China" police, before cross-strait dialogue is formally resumed. Academic discussion on those issues will certainly helpful to future cross-strait talks, they claimed.

Beijing unilaterally suspended semi-official cross-strait dialogue after President Lee made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995, which Beijing interpreted as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN REFUSES TO CONFIRM EUROPEAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Sunday refused to confirm that he will make a visit to several European countries this month, saying that, "I will let my countrymen know if such a trip is forthcoming."

Premier Vincent Siew was quoted as saying that Lien will make an overseas journey in the near future although the itinerary has not yet been decided. "In the face of Beijing's diplomatic blockade, it's not wise to make public Lien's travel plans before his departure," Siew added.

Vice Premier and Foreign Minister John Chang said that Lien will visit several unidentified European countries at an undetermined time. But once the itinerary is confirmed, Lien will depart shortly thereafter, he added.
The trip would be Lien's second overseas journey this year following visits to Ireland and the Vatican in January. He secretly traveled to Ukraine in August of last year.
Chang also stressed that if the itinerary for the upcoming trip is revealed too early, it might create trouble for the countries concerned and affect the preparations already under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAKE COIN PRODUCTION FACILITY BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police raided a New Taiwan Dollar coin counterfeiting facility in Taichung, central Taiwan, on Sunday and arrested two suspects in the case.
Also confiscated in the sweep were nearly 30,000 bogus NT$10 and NT$50 coins as well as a batch of tools and machinery used for producing fake coins.
Police officers had arrested Chu Chi-chin, 47, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung late Saturday and seized 6,796 counterfeit NT$50 coins, with a face value of NT$339,800, at Chu's home.
Chu told police that the fake coins were purchased from a woman living in Taichung.
Acting on tips provided by Chu, police managed to arrest the woman, identified as Huang Chen-tsai, in a pre-dawn raid on her home.

In the basement of Huang's residence, officers uncovered 906 counterfeit new-version NT$50 coins and 22,000 bogus NT$10 coins, in addition to some semifinished counterfeit products, raw materials and machinery.
Huang, 50, told police that her son, Huang Li-wei, began to counterfeit NT$10 and NT$50 coins in late August as he had lost a large sum of money in a failed investment project.
Huang Li-wei, 23, managed to flee before police arrived at his home and remains at large.
Initial investigations show that a large number of bogus NT$10 and NT$50 coins, with a face value of about NT$4 million, has already flowed into the domestic market.
Huang said the fake coins were sold to unknown persons, including street vendors and vegetable retailers.

Police said the counterfeit coins were thinner and darker in color than the genuine versions. However, they said, the bogus coins appear very similar to the authentic ones, adding that local residents should pay close attention to the quality of coins they receive.

DOC.HEADLINE: THRONGS OF BUDDHIST FOLLOWERS RALLY FOR SPIRITUAL RENEWAL

TEXT.P: About 80,000 people, including Buddhist followers, senior government officials and foreign dignitaries, joined in a giant rally in downtown Taipei on Sunday dedicated to spiritual renewal.

The introspective rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex was part of a program organized by the Republic of China chapter of the International Buddha Light Association founded by Buddhist Master Hsin Yun.
The program, launched in May, is aimed at stemming moral decline and promoting compassion and love.

Addressing the rally, Master Hsin Yun, who is also founder of the Fokuangshan Buddhist Temple in southern Taiwan, said the rally marked the beginning of a nationwide program for spiritual revitalization.
"The soul-searching exercise requires the participation of all of our people, not just Buddhist followers," Hsin Yun said, adding that he hopes the program will even be promoted overseas.

Hsin Yun further explained that the program is aimed mainly at reminding individuals to cultivate compassion and love. "What Taiwan badly needs today is not money or skyscrapers, but compassion and a loving heart."

Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew also spoke on the occasion, encouraging every local resident to be a benevolent, loving person. "Let us try our best to give others confidence, convenience and happiness," Lien urged in his speech.

Foreign ambassadors and unofficial envoys stationed in Taipei, including those from Panama, Spain, Turkey, India, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, also joined in the rally to throw their support behind the spiritual renewal program.
Addressing the crowd, Panamanian Ambassador Carlos A. Mendoza said he hopes the program will be continued in Taiwan and perhaps even eventually spread to his homeland.
During the rally, Master Hsin Yun presented a US$20,000 check to the Papua New Guinea trade representative in Taiwan to help relieve flood victims in the South Pacific island nation.
Meanwhile, Hsin Yun is scheduled to visit India next February to preach his faith.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN LEAVES FOR EUROPE SUNDAY NIGHT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan and his wife Lien Fang-yu will embark on an overseas journey to Europe Sunday night.

Lien will depart at 10:20 p.m. on China Airlines (CAL) flight number CI065 bound for Amsterdam, Netherlands via Bangkok, Thailand. He will then proceed to several unidentified European countries for a series of private visits.

The government has not made public Lien's itinerary to avoid creating trouble beforehand for the countries concerned arising from objections by Beijing. With the exception of the Vatican, Taiwan has no formal diplomatic allies in Europe.
Diplomatic sources said that Lien's visits, described as fulfilling "academic" objectives, are aimed at establishing cooperative programs between universities in Taiwan and Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG SCOFFS AT RUMORS REGARDING FAMILY HISTORY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Foreign Minister John Chang on Sunday broke days of silence when he commented on recent reports that late President Chiang Ching-kuo was not the natural son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, saying that he "laughed away" such rumors.

"A learned man should be thoughtful of others. What he said or what he did should not hurt the deceased or the living," said Chang, who along with his deceased twin brother Winston Chang is an illegitimate son of Chiang Ching-kuo. He was referring to comments made by a professor regarding the Chiang family history which have sparked heated discussion around Taiwan.

Based on information provided by Professor Fan Kuang-ling, the Taipei-based Business Weekly magazine reported in its latest issue that Chiang Kai-shek had been deprived of the ability to produce offspring because of an accident in his early childhood. The professor also said that Chiang Ching-kuo was not the natural son of Chiang Kai-shek and his first wife Mao Fu-mei.

The magazine said that Fan Kuang-ling was a good friend of Wego Chiang, Chiang Kai-shek's adopted son who passed away recently, and that Fan had conducted a series of taped interviews with Wego over the past few years. At one of these sessions in 1994, Wego told him that his brother Ching-kuo, like himself, was not the natural son of the generalissimo, Fan was quoted as saying in the magazine.

But in a press conference held Saturday by the publisher of the Business Weekly, Chin Wei-chun, among the eight interview tapes made public by Fan, the part regarding Chiang Kai-shek's childhood accident was related by Fan himself instead of Wego Chiang.
Fan claimed that he had redubbed that portion of the interview, which Wego had written down on paper, at Wego's request. But he insisted that Wego had related the story to him personally.
However, rather than clarify the matter, Fan's remarks served to cast more doubt on the authenticity of his story.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE STAR PITCHER TO RETIRE FROM JAPANESE PRO-BASEBALL

TEXT.P: Taiwanese star pitcher Kuo Tai-yuan will retire from Japan's Seibu Lions professional baseball team at the end of this baseball season.

Kuo, who used to be nicknamed "Eastern Express" for his speed, gave his farewell pitching Sunday in a match with the Daiei team. An emotional Kuo, accompanined by his wife Chang Chun-chih, a former television actress, and their daughter, bade farewell to tens of thousands of his fans at the end of the game.

Though Seibu lost to Daiei in the Sunday match, the team was already certain to win this year's championship in the Pacific League on Friday. It will vie for the national title with the Central League champion team Yakult starting on Oct. 18.

Kuo, 36, joined Seibu in 1985 after representing the Republic of China on Taiwan in many regional and international baseball contests. He played a leading role in helping the ROC team win a bronze medal in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games.
During his nearly 13 years with Seibu, Kuo recorded 117 wins, 68 losses and 18 reliefs. During the period, Seibu won eight Pacific League championships.
Kuo has set many outstanding records over the past 13 years, including pitching a no-hit, no-run perfect match in 1985. He has also won many awards, including a Pacific League MVP award in 1991.
Kuo decided to retire because of his age and an old wound to his right hand, which has affected his performance in the past two seasons.
Kuo earned more than 1 billion Japanese yen (about NT$260.3 million) during his stint with Seibu.
Kuo and his wife are scheduled to return to Taiwan in mid-November. He is expected to continue his baseball career after return to his homeland.

The Taiwan Major League, one of Taiwan's two professional baseball leagues, reportedly intends to hire Kuo by offering an annual income of NT$10 million. The income will include a monthly salary of NT$500,000 plus advertisement revenues and prize money.
However, Kuo said he has yet to make a final decision on whether to join the Taiwan Major League.

Another Taiwanese star pitcher Kuo Yuan-chih, who returned to Taiwan last year after pitching for Japan's Central League Chunichi Dragons team for more than 20 years, has decided to go back to Japan to serve as a coach next year.

Kuo Yuan-chih, who plays for Taiwan's President Lions team during the current baseball season, was disappointed by Taiwan's pro-baseball climate. Taiwan's seven-year pro-baseball community has been troubled by a marred image resulting from alleged involvement of some of its players in gambling and game fixing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S OFFICE RENTS MAY SOFTEN FURTHER

TEXT.P: Singapore's office rents remained in seventh spot in a recently conducted global survey by property consultancy Knight Frank.
However, average rents have softened by between 5 percent and 10 percent so far in 1997 and could fall by another 5 percent before the office rental market starts to consolidate next year.
The total average annual cost of occupying an office in Singapore was US$83 per square foot, about 57 percent lower than top-ranked Seoul at US$130 psf a year, according to the survey.
Seoul displaced other high-flying cities such as Bombay and Tokyo to top the list. Hong Kong, with US$111 psf, took the second spot in the global survey.

The third through tenth ranked areas in descending order were London-West End (US$99 psf); London-City (US$95 psf); Bombay, (US$93 psf); Moscow (US$85 psf); Singapore (US$83 psf); Beijing (US$78 psf); New Delhi (US$70 psf); and Tokyo (US$62 psf).
The survey said the outlook for office rents in Asia was bleak and rents have come under pressure in most countries because of rising supply.
In addition, rent-free periods, incentives and flexible lease terms have become more common.
It said the supply of offices will increase in Singapore, China, Malaysia and Thailand and predicted falling rents in Singapore.
However, rents could start rising again late next year or early in 1999 when the bulk of the supply has been absorbed by steady demand.

Meanwhile, Hong Kong's office rents -- the world's second highest -- have held up well because of the renewed confidence after the July 1 handover to Beijing's rule, but the market could be heading for oversupply next year, said a Knight Frank research director.
He also noted that office rents in emerging markets like India's Bombay and China's Beijing and Shanghai had been volatile.
This is due to the sudden influx of foreign companies colliding with a limited supply of existing offices, which drives rents up, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIPO CUTS INTERNATIONAL PATENT FEES

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World International Property Organization (WIPO), the United Nations agency that administers global treaties on patents, copyrights and trademarks, is cutting international patent fees by an average of 15 percent.
The move comes in response to criticism it is pilling up huge surpluses from its patent activities, a spokesman of the WIPO said Saturday.

A record 47,291 applications were filed in 1996, a rise of more than 20 percent from the previous year, and the increase in the first six months of 1997 was an additional 12.6 percent. The number of WIPO staff, now 650, is rising at a similar rate.

The spokesman said the cut in patent fees, from about US$524 to US$448, would not reduce total patent income, given the increasing volume of applications. Further fee reductions may be considered in due course.

Under WIPO's Patent Cooperation Treaty, inventors can make a single patent application to cover a large number of countries, though they may need to go through procedures within individual nations at a later date in order to receive more comprehensive protection.
WIPO's profitable patent business has made the UN agency virtually self-supporting. Nine-tenths of its US$100 million a year budget is financed from patent fees and other revenue-raising activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CUSTOMS ORGANIZATION OPENS SAUDI OFFICE

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia has approved the establishment of a regional office for the World Customs Organization in the country.
The kingdom's Ministry of Finance and National Economy will plan the organizational structure of the office.

The director-general of the ministry's Monitoring Devices Department, Abdullah bin Saleh Al-Ghamdi, said the idea of establishing the office for exchange of information has been initiated by the member-states of the organization.

Al-Ghamdi said this office will be concerned with the collection, analysis and publication of information related to drug trafficking and money laundering, and will exchange this information with the organization's headquarters in Brussels and its other regional offices.

Al-Ghamdi said the Mideast region has recently become a transit point for drugs coming from adjacent Asian countries and there are indicators showing a link between the Mideast, Africa and Latin America.

Al-Ghamdi said in view of the geographical location of the region and statistics showing ever-increasing drug trafficking activities, the member-states were urged to support the new office to help create a reliable regional information network.
He said the government has already approved the establishment of the office, which will be based in Riyadh and will operate under supervision of the Saudi Customs Authority. (BY Yang I-feng)

DOC.HEADLINE: US DAILY ANALYZES ROC-PANAMA RELATIONS

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles Times said in a datelined report from Colon, Panama, on Saturday that "beneath a larger-than-life poster proclaiming the friendship between their lands, Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladares and Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui last month inaugurated a keystone of this country's (Panama's) economic future."

"They cut the ribbon for Davis industrial park, the biggest industrial investment so far on the former US military bases being returned to Panama under the terms of a 1977 canal treaty. Eight Taiwanese companies have set up export factories here in a crucial vote of confidence for Panama's efforts to turn the old bases into thriving, job-producing manufacturing centers. The $25-million investment is expected to grow to $90-million in five years.

"Still, even that project is overshadowed by the $150 million or more that Panamanian authorities said Hutchison Whampoa plans to invest during the same period in Panama's two most important ports. The Hong Kong conglomerate also will pay Panama $22.2 million a year for 25 years for the concession to run the ports, turned over to Panama under the same treaty as the bases."

The Times said, "apparently, the Hong Kong and Taiwan investments are complementary parts of building Panama's future after the United States completes its gradual pullout from the canal in 1999. But they represent conflicting interests: The former British colony of Hong Kong on July 1 was returned to (Communist) China, which regards Taiwan as a renegade province. And the importance of that change half a world away from Panama became clear last month when (Communist) China, for the first time, used Hong Kong's economic clout to punish a nation for its ties to Taiwan.

"Lee told Panama's Congress that, `if the Panama Canal or the economy of the nation is affected for having taken this fair and courageous position, I believe the nations of the world, especially (Taiwan), should cooperate as much as possible with Panama,'" the Times reported.

"Economic cooperation has been key to Taiwan's ability to keep its allies, mainly small, poor Latin American and African nations. Taiwan recently has funded a trade office in its capital, Taipei, for Panama's neighbors and pledged $200 million to create an `economic cooperation' fund to strengthen bilateral ties and increase trade with the five Central American nations, which now totals about $260 million a year," the report continued.

It pointed out that until taking over Hong Kong, Communist China was hard-pressed to respond to Taiwan's economic overtures to its allies. Panamanian Vice President Tomas Altamirano Duque recently dismissed Communist China's threats, saying Beijing "has not given us much help."

"As (Communist) China's pressure and Taiwan's defiance both rise, Panama may be forced to choose between the two. And the factors that affect that choice could influence whether this country's (Panama's) neighbors in Central America -- one of the few regions where Taiwan holds diplomatic sway -- ultimately switch alliances," the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN NICKEL FIRM EYES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: PT International Nickel Indonesia (Inco) plans to expand its operations overseas to gain access to the dynamic Asian economies such as Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and China.
"The rapid economic growth of those countries prompts higher demands for nickel," the state-run Antara news agency quoted Inco Chairman Rumengan Musu as saying in Jakarta recently.
He reiterated the company's commitment to Indonesia, however, saying that although Inco's entire nickel production is exported to Japan, it will always give priority to the needs of the home country.
Musu said that Inco at present is carrying out expansion of its annual production capacity--from 100 million pounds to 150 million pounds by the year 2000.
Nickel currently sells at between US$ 2.87 and 3.50 per pound in the international market.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SCREENS ANTI-DOMESTIC VIOLENCE BILL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's judicial, interior and education affairs committees called a joint meeting on Monday to screen an anti-domestic violence bill.
The bill, introduced by Legislator Pan Wei-kang (KMT-Taipei City) and endorsed by 36 other lawmakers of different political stripes, marks Taiwan's first legislation against domestic violence.

Addressing the meeting, Pan, who also chairs the nonprofit Modern Women Foundation, said domestic violence has worsened in Taiwan and has in many cases seriously affected the family's social functions.

Worse yet, Pan said, conservative concepts which hold that the law should not concern itself with domestic issues and that officials should not become involved in family disputes have served to deny many victims of domestic violence access to proper governmental and public assistance.
Pan, who has long been outspoken on domestic violence-related issues, said the most effective way to protect the members of society is to enact an anti-domestic violence law.

The legislation will provide for the establishment of a comprehensive system to offer timely and attentive protection for domestic violence victims by pooling resources of judicial, police, medical, educational, social counseling and welfare service organizations, Pan said.

In addition, Pan said, educational institutes and social groups should work hand in hand to instill in the public consciousness the concept of gender equality and the importance of using nonviolent means to resolve family disputes.

The 60-article bill sets forth legal definitions of "domestic violence," contains regulations designed to protect victims of domestic violence and establishes guidelines for handling child custody and other related issues.

According to the draft bill, domestic violence victims can apply for court protection, and police officers are authorized to act on their own discretion in dealing with domestic violence cases. The bill also requires the government to set up a domestic violence prevention commission and a treatment center to offer rescue, counseling and treatment services.

A number of legislators present at the meeting urged the executive branch to present its own version of an anti-domestic violence bill to the Legislature to facilitate the deliberation of related measures.

Relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, the National Police Administration and judicial organs, have met five times to discuss an anti-domestic violence bill which corresponds to the one introduced by Pan. However, a final draft has yet to be completed.
