DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY SEEKS US APPROVAL FOR JET FIGHTER DONATION
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Stephen Sheng & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Paraguayan government is seeking approval from the United States for free transfer of 12 jet fighters from the Republic of China to Paraguay as the aircraft were originally built in America, the ABC Daily reported on Sunday.

The ROC decided last month to donate 10 F-5E single-seat jet fighters and two F-5F double-seat trainers to Paraguay, Taiwan's sole diplomatic ally in South America, as a token of friendship, the ABC said.

The daily quoted ROC Vice Premier John Chang as saying that the transfer of 12 combat planes to the Paraguayan Air Force is a donation aimed at strengthening bilateral relations, rather than a sale. However, the gesture is subject to approval from Washington because the original purchase agreement between the ROC and the United States prohibits the transfer of the planes to a third country without permission.

Chang said in late September that the donation of the US-made fighters will not affect the ROC Air Force's combat preparedness. He added that the timetable for delivery will hinge on the arrival in Taiwan of second-generation warplanes.
The ABC said the ROC Air Force will also provide 70 percent of the related components and parts, as well as assist in training 21 Paraguayan pilots.
A spokesman for Paraguayan Air Force Command said the 12 fighters will help boost Paraguay's air defensive capabilities without posing a security threat to neighboring countries.

The ROC currently has 250 F-5Es as the backbone of its air defense. But, as its second-generation buildup plan is proceeding smoothly with the delivery of 150 F-16 and 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters ordered from the United States and France, respectively, the military plans to retire some the aging F-5Es.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI UP 1.66 PERCENT IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer prices rose slightly in September over August's figures, with educational fees and fruit and vegetable prices registering the most significant hikes, the government reported on Monday.

The consumer price index (CPI), which measures price changes from 1991 when the index stood at 100, rose 0.62 percent from the year-earlier level to 122.46 in September, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said.

Compared with August, the CPI edged up 0.64 percent mainly because of an increase in registration fees at colleges and universities, the celebration of the Mid-Autumn Festival, one of the three major holidays in Taiwan, and seasonal changes in the cost of fruits and vegetables which resulted in volatile price levels, DGBAS officials noted.
Nevertheless, falling prices for other commodities, including those for pork, poultry and betel nuts, has helped to curb inflationary pressures, they said.
As a result, the wholesale price index dropped 0.68 percent in September from the previous month, posting negative growth for the 18th consecutive month, according to the officials.
Both the export and import price indexes also dropped in September, down 0.75 percent and 0.64 percent, respectively, as compared with August, the DGBAS tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 INFLATION RATE EXPECTED TO BE AT LOW OF 1.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The annual growth rate of the domestic consumer price index (CPI) is expected to be kept to a low of 1.5 percent for 1997 if inflation in the last quarter of this year does not exceed third-quarter levels, the government reported on Monday.

A precondition of this forecast, however, is the absence of major factors which could fuel inflationary pressure in the next three months, officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said.

The CPI, which measures domestic consumer price changes from the year 1991 when the index was set at 100, rose a mere 1.09 percent in the third quarter of this year over the same period a year ago. This created an increase in the inflation rate that was much lower than the DGBAS had previously estimated, DGBAS officials noted.

As the impact of weather and climatic factors upon the economy diminishes with the end of the June-September typhoon season, the DGBAS expects that inflationary pressure in the last quarter of this year will be reduced accordingly.
The recent rise in oil prices on international markets, however, could be instrumental in driving up the CPI, a situation which is worthy of notice, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES RECORD MODEST GAIN

TEXT.P: Share prices registered a modest gain on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rose 11.76 points to finish at 8,392.59.
The bourse opened at 8,405.3 and experienced a high of 8,498.74 and a low of 8,384.35.
Gainers outnumbered losers 301 to 122, with 46 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.63 billion shares changes hands on a market turnover of NT$106.362 billion (US$3.7 billion).

Plastics and chemical issues rose the most at 2.0 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.0 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent and financial stocks at 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA-TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT TO BE COMPLETED IN 6 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Former Russian First Vice Premier Oleg Lobov said Sunday that Russia's parliament is working on an act to govern its relations with Taiwan, and that he is optimistic the legislation can be completed within six months.
Lobov made the remarks as he arrived at the head of a six-member delegation, in Taipei to celebrate the Republic of China's National Day, which falls on Oct. 10.

Noting that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia, which was nonexistent in 1992, has grown to US$2 billion in value so far in 1997, Lobov said that both sides should increase exchanges in the areas of economics, culture and sports.
He also expressed the hope that the two nations could cooperate in the aviation industry.

Lobov and then ROC Foreign Minister John Chang signed a protocol in Paris in 1992 that established the framework for bilateral relations. The Moscow-Taipei and the Taipei-Moscow economic and cultural coordination commissions were later set up under the protocol.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO TAKE `BALANCED' APPROACH TO ASIA-PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Canada must continue to take a "balanced" approach with its allies in the Asian Pacific region, without focusing exclusively upon either business and trade relations or upon issues such as human rights, the country's top diplomat said Saturday.
"Human rights are a threshold issue in all our bilateral relations and international standard-setting is a priority for us multilaterally," Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said.

"In both these arenas, our basic policy is one of effective influence. That means supporting change from within by building domestic grassroots capacity," he told the National Foreign Policy Conference in Regina, Saskatchewan.

Axworthy cited Indonesia as an example, saying Canada's good relationship with Jakarta allows for an open dialogue on human rights that might otherwise not exist. He did not mention mainland China, whose human rights record is equally poor, if not worse, for fear of upsetting the Communist leaders of Canada's largest wheat market.

He noted that along with its business ties, Canada has been expanding its goodwill role in the Asian Pacific region. It has done so through projects to fight child exploitation, battle drug trafficking, raise awareness of human rights and ease poverty.
Canada is well positioned to become a major player in the Asian Pacific region, which he said will likely be "home to seven of the top 10 economies in the world" in 25 years.

"Surely no country is better suited than Canada to deal with the subtleties and complexities in Asia-Pacific," he claimed, noting that since 1979, Canada has had more immigrants from across the Pacific than from across the Atlantic.
That helps create and strengthen ties and puts Canada in a strong position to increase its presence in the region, he suggested.
But more must be done and, "as we approach the new millennia, I believe it is time to build a more formal policy framework," he told the delegates to the policy input conference.

Axworthy said that the framework includes: -- a continued active commitment to multilateral issues; -- advancing human security as the "ultimate" goal; -- extension of Canadian networks and knowledge of the region; and -- an active bilateral program of engagement. ENDITEM ZCZC CEP009 10-06-97 PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT LEADS NATIONAL PRAYER MEETING

Manila, Oct. 5 (CNA) Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Sunday led a national prayer at Manila's Luneta Park, asking God "to break all the curses" that have divided the country "so that freedom, peace, prosperity and unity will prevail."

The nation's chief executive was the main speaker at a gathering sponsored by the Jesus is Lord Church, a born-again movement which celebrated its 19th anniversary that day. Police estimated the crowd at about 100,000 people.

In his address to the rally, Ramos said that no interest group, no matter how powerful, can set the agenda on the issue of constitutional change, which he said he is compelled to leave to his successor in 1998.
"This power belongs to the people" he said.
He said future changes in the national charter should remove impediments to economic efficiency, strengthen the institution of democracy and allow all citizens to share the fruits of progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY TO BENEFIT SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia's membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) will have a positive impact on Saudi businessmen and manufacturers, according to Abdul Rahman Al-Jeraisy , chairman of the Council of Saudi Chambers of Commerce and Industry and head of the Riyadh chamber.
"There will be many benefits once Saudi Arabia becomes a WTO member," Al-Jeraisy said recently, adding that Saudi negotiators were working to secure maximum advantages for the country.

Al-Jeraisy said there are a number of government establishments that must be privatized as a condition for membership, including Saudi Arabian Airlines, the Saudi Railroad Organization, the telecommunications sector, and the water and sewage departments.
He said that the privatization work would be carried out through political processes.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN BUSINESS TYCOON DECORATED

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Wang Yung-ching on Monday in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's industrial development.
President Lee personally decorated Wang with the Order and praised him for his down-to-earth working style and contributions to society and the nation.
For his part, Wang said he felt honored to receive the decoration. "It's the most glorious day in my life."
The 80-year-old tycoon went on to say that he owes much to the country, crediting his business success to Taiwan's phenomenal economic development over the past four decades.
"Taiwan has managed to develop from scratch to prosperity in a relative short period of time mainly because of the government's wise leadership plus the diligence of our people," Wang noted.

Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan's industry is now at a critical juncture of transformation and requires the government's assistance to upgrade its technological level. "Only high technology will help sustain growth and enable us to survive the ever-increasing global competition."
Wang concluded his speech by once again expressing his thanks for the decoration and pledging to redouble his efforts to repay his debt of gratitude to the country and society.
Scores of senior government officials and business leaders were invited to witness the decoration ceremony at the Presidential Office.

Wang is the third local business magnate to receive the decoration. The first two were Chinatrust Group Chairman C.F. Koo, who is also Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, and Wang Yu-yun, a former Kaohsiung mayor now with the private Chung Hsing Commercial Bank.

Some observers said the award is part of the government's efforts to persuade large domestic enterprises to slow or suspend their investment activities in mainland China in line with the government's "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland-bound investment.

The Formosa Group drew the government's ire earlier this year when it announced plans to invest in a multibillion dollar power plant project in mainland China's Fujian province. The company later denied that it was proceeding with work on the plant in Zhangzhou in defiance of the government's regulations.

Wang was reluctant to comment on the government's mainland investment policy at a news conference given after the decoration, but noted that the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei had recently issued a white paper on Taiwan's investment and economic policy.

The white paper criticized Taiwan's "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy, saying it will not only hinder Taiwan's economic development but would also discourage multinational conglomerates from setting up their Asia-Pacific regional headquarters on the island.
The outspoken tycoon further said Taiwan's current economic problems do not lie with its workers, but with the leadership or managerial-level positions.

Wang said the people of Taiwan are smart and diligent. "The greatest bottleneck faced by many local enterprises is that their management staff lacks vision and a down-to-earth working style," he observed.

Wang went on to say that Taiwan has talent, technology, experience and capital and that the priority task for the government is to create an investment climate suitable for the island's technological development.

Wang lamented that local society, particularly the business community, has become increasingly extravagant and vainglorious. "We should not forget that diligence is the driving force behind Taiwan's economic growth and must continue to uphold this spirit."

In addition to developing high-tech industries, Wang said the government should not ignore the upgrading of conventional steel, shipbuilding, machinery and other related industries. "My observation is that both high-tech and traditional industries should brace up for increased competition and liberalization pressure following Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization."

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDER ACCOUNTS FOR 10 PERCENT OF TAIWAN FISHERMEN'S DEATHS

TEXT.P: About 10 percent of work-related fatalities among Taiwan's fishermen result from acts of murder, with 58 percent of those crimes being perpetrated by mainland Chinese, an analysis by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) revealed Monday.

The analysis, conducted by the CLA's National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, also found that local and foreign fishermen were each responsible for 16 percent of the murder cases, while pirates of unidentified nationality committed the remaining 10 percent of such crimes.
In terms of rank, captains and chief engineers aboard Taiwan's fishing vessels are most likely to be killed, accounting for one-half of the high-seas murder victims.

As the number of local deep-sea fishermen declines, shipping companies have been forced to employ more crewmen from the Chinese mainland. As misunderstandings and disputes are more likely to arise due to cultural differences between Taiwan and mainland crew members, the institute urged shipping companies and their officers to pay more attention to mainland Chinese crewmen's emotion and behavior in order to prevent mutinies from occurring.
The institute recently conducted a survey of occupational hazards faced by local fishermen and made reference to the cases in creating a relief fund for the families of murdered or disabled seamen.
The institute found that the fatality rate of 5.5 per 10,000 workers in the fishing industry was twice as high as that of 2.7 per 10,000 in the construction sector.

In analyzing the causes of death, the institute found that one-third of the fatalities were attributed to crew members falling overboard at sea. Twenty percent of the deaths were caused by the capsizing of fishing vessels, with sudden illnesses making up another 20 percent of high-seas fatalities. Accidents in fishing operations accounted for 16 percent, while murder at the hands of other crewmen accounted for 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NII SEEN AS IMPORTANT INDICATOR OF NATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: The development of a National Information Infrastructure (NII), which will eventually link networks from around the world, will be an important indicator of a nation's international competitiveness, said Dr. Yuan T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, on Monday.

The NII, better-known as the "information superhighway," which will eventually combine existing cable TV and public telecommunications networks such the Internet, is also expected to bring about global interaction on an unprecedented scale, he noted.

Addressing a seminar on NII development and promotion, Lee described a future without geographical territories, as a result of NII development. The NII will also help globalize the small- and medium-sized enterprises sector, improve management quality in state-owned organizations and increase participation by the private sector in public affairs, thus contributing to democratization, he said.
Taiwan cannot afford to be a late entry in NII development if it wants to realize its goal of turning itself into a "high-tech" island, Lee stressed.

The NII, originally used only by the academic sector and the military, has become the principal platform for global information exchange and high-tech cooperation. A "living environment" of the future, NII services will include academic instruction, video conferencing, multimedia databases, cable TV services and on-line medical diagnosis.

However, Lee, a Nobel Prize winner, reminded his audience that the ultimate goal of NII development is not just for economic prosperity. Instead, it should be aimed at seeking sustainable development throughout the world.
While developing cutting-edge innovations in the field of science, he said, the human race should also address other issues which are equally vital to the successful future of the species.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU JINTAO'S PROSPECTS AS HEIR-APPARENT OF CPC 4TH GENERATION

TEXT.P: Hu Jintao, previously the seventh and most junior standing member of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China (CPC), was promoted to fifth position at the just-concluded 15th National Congress of CPC. The sheer fact that Hu is only 55 years of age is worthy of special attention.

CPC General Secretary Jiang Zemin mentioned Hu's new role at meetings with several foreign visitors recently, underlining Hu's prominence as a rising star and heir-apparent of the CPC's fourth-generation leadership.

But whether Hu's fortunes will follow those of his predecessors Liu Shaoqi, Lin Biao, Hua Guofeng, Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang, all of whom were eventually ousted, or whether he will come to the fore as Jiang Zemin did, all depends on his political wisdom and the prevailing conditions.
Hu has already broken several records on mainland China's political stage:
-- He became the youngest member of the CPC Central Committee at the 12th National Congress in 1982;
-- He became the youngest secretary of the CPC Provincial Committee in 1985;
-- He became the youngest member of the cross-century fourth generation leadership at the 14th party congress in 1992 when he was promoted to standing member of the CPC Politburo.

With his wealth of political experience, Hu's future is considered very bright by many political observers. After having been one of the seven standing members of the CPC Politburo and having administered the personnel and organizational sections for five years, Hu's political assets are both broad and deep. He is also the principal of the Central Party School.
If we analyze the failures of his predecessors, Hu will have to be especially wary to avoid these potential pitfalls:
-- Do not defy the leaders of former generations as did Liu Shaoqi and Lin Biao toward Mao Zedong, or as did Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang toward the CPC old guard.

-- Do not act contrary to the will of the people and be wary of one's international image. Although designated heir-apparent by Mao himself, Hua Guofeng was replaced by Deng Xiaoping as paramount leader of mainland China because the people were disappointed with Hua's adherence to Mao's line after the end of the 10-year Cultural Revolution. In later years, Premier Li Peng's notorious international image as "the butcher of Tiananmen" resulted in his being ranked second to Jiang Zemin, although Jiang is actually junior to Li in the mainland political hierarchy.

-- Do not lend your support to the wrong side. The decline in the power structure of Politburo member Tian Jiyun and Central Committee member Hu Qili were due to their siding with the ousted Zhao Ziyang, while Central Committee member Wang Zhaoguo's downfall was due to his having sided with Hu Yaobang. Wang, who was secretary of the CPC Secretariat in 1985, has never been restored to his former level.

-- Do not set yourself up as heir-apparent prematurely. The fall of Liu Shaoqi, Lin Biao, Hua Guofeng, Hu Yaobang, Zhao Ziyang and the frustrations of Li Peng and Hu Qili were all the result of posing as heir-apparent prematurely.
Taking into account all these factors, it is evident that Hu is facing a long and hard climb if he is to successfully achieve the top post in Beijing at the 16th Party Congress five years from now.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE PRICES IN TAIWAN SHOW SMALLEST RISE IN DECADE

TEXT.P: Prices for services in Taiwan between January and September rose by the smallest percentage in a decade, according to statistics released on Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

In its report on consumer prices for September, the DGBAS said prices in the service category rose by 2.34 percent between January and September over the same period of 1996, the smallest increase in this category since 1987.

A DGBAS spokesman told reporters the low increase was the result of smaller salary increases for military, education and government personnel, although efforts aimed at improving production costs had not been as successful as in the past.

The spokesman said that during the nine-month period, salaries for military, education and government personnel were only raised by 3 percent, while workers in the manufacturing sector saw their paychecks rise 3.1 percent, both rather small increases.

He pointed out that in terms of costs, a comparison of ten-year periods shows that Taiwan's Wholesale Price Index (WPI) from 1977 to 1986 increased by an average of 4.2 percent, while the figure only rose by 0.2 percent in the decade between 1987 and 1996.

Comparing Taiwan's situation to those of neighboring countries, WPI increases in Japan during the same two ten-year periods amounted to 1.5 percent and -0.7 percent, respectively, while for South Korea, the figures were 10.1 percent and 2.0 percent.

The spokesman also said that minimal pay increases and free interaction within the labor market were additional reasons for stable service sector prices. Traditional manufacturing industries and service industries both have a high degree of labor substitution and salary levels in both sectors tend to have a restraining effect on each other, he pointed out.

Even though salaries in new service industries have increased by 14.7 percent, much higher than the 3.1 percent rise in the manufacturing sector, the overall service price index was still affected by the mutually restraining effect between manufacturing and service sector salaries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DREYER'S TAIWAN BRANCH RECALLS PRODUCTS FOR EXAMINATION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan branch of US-based Dreyer's Ice Cream Co. announced on Monday it is recalling all of its Cookies 'N Cream bars from local stores for inspection because of fears the product may be contaminated by a potentially dangerous bacteria.

The product will not be distributed again in Taiwan until the ROC's Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine confirms that it is not contaminated by the bacteria "listeria monocytogenes," a Dreyer's spokesman said.
The company made the announcement after foreign wire service reports said over the weekend that the bacteria had been found in Dreyer's Cookies 'N Cream bars being sold in Hong Kong.

The spokesman said Taiwan has imported 8,600 of the candy bars, 2,300 of which have already entered the local market. "Even though the product imported into Taiwan does not belong to the same batch that was shipped to Hong Kong, we still decided to recall the product for inspection to ensure safety," the spokesman said.

Local health officials said the bacteria can exist in a wide variety of living environments and can infect both humans and animals. The bacteria can, in severe cases, cause infection of the brain and potentially lethal meningitis. The bacteria is killed in foodstuffs which have undergone high-temperature treatment or which have been stored at a temperature of minus 8 degrees Celsius, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRAQ, IRAN TO RESIST US MEASURES

TEXT.P: "No one can expect us to keep silent about this conspiracy concerning our territories, and Baghdad has the right to defend itself," a senior Iraqi diplomat said Sunday.
He was commenting upon the recent decision by Washington to send an aircraft carrier to enforce the no-fly zone in southern Iraq, beginning at the 33rd parallel.
"We will fight this decision, even it will lead others to attack us," the Iraqi diplomat continued.

The United States, reacting to Iranian air attacks on Teheran's main opposition group, the People's Mujaheddin, in southern Iraq last week, announced that the aircraft carrier, the USS Nimitz, would skip a port call in Singapore and head to the Persian Gulf.

A large number of Shiite Arabs, which are the dominant group in Iran but a minority in Iraq, inhabit the southern part of Iraq, while the United Nations-imposed no-fly zone in northern Iraq is occupied by another large opposition group, the ethnic Kurds.

Meanwhile, Iran's Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi also said that Teheran had the right to attack Iranian "terrorist" groups in Iraq, according to remarks published by Saudi-owned newspaper al-Hatat on Sunday.
Iran has protested to the United Nations over what it said were cross-border attacks from Iraq and said the incursions prompted its air raids on Iranian Mujaheddin rebel bases inside Iraq last week.
In response, Washington ordered the USS Nimitz to deploy in the Gulf and warned Iran that its aircraft could be shot down if they violate the flight ban in southern Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STUDY PROVES CANCER-HORMONE LINK

TEXT.P: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), the "youth drug" being used by millions of women, has been indisputably linked to breast cancer in the biggest study to date of its long-term risks, according to mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Monday.
The study shows that among some groups of women taking HRT, the risk of developing breast cancer was 2.3 times higher than that of non-users.
It shows the overall risk of breast cancer is 35 percent higher if women take HRT on average for 11 years, according to a draft of a report on the study.

The research, which pooled data from more than 40 previous projects involving more than 60,000 women, was designed to resolve the controversy over whether HRT causes breast cancer, the daily reported.

The Australian quoted health officials as estimating that about one million Australian women who have passed menopause, take a daily pill which replaces estrogen, the hormone produced naturally by the body during fertile years.
The aim is to reduce the risk of dementia, osteoporosis and heart disease, all of which have been linked to declining hormonal levels.
But results of the overall study are still being disputed by authors of some of the individual sections, who argue that the publication of the report will cause unnecessary panic among HRT users.
Researchers said the link between HRT and developing breast cancer is clear, but added that there is no evidence that HRT affected death rates from the disease.
The daily reported the manufacturers of HRT declined to make any comment on the study.

Breast cancer surgeon and lecturer Vernon Marshall of the Monash University in Melbourne told the daily that the report's findings were not unexpected, but said that they must also be weighed against HRT's benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SINGAPOREANS FALLING SICK FROM HAZE

TEXT.P: The haze caused by wildfires on the Indonesian island of Sumatra that has engulfed a large portion of Southeast Asia is taking its toll on the health of Singaporeans.
Singapore's Health Ministry said that the number of haze-related cases, such as sore throats and asthma, seen at local clinics increased during the last week of September.
Acute respiratory-tract infections, which include sore throats, leapt by nearly 1,200 cases over the previous week, a 13-percent jump from 9,197 to 10,378 cases, it reported.
Fewer patients complained of acute bronchitis and skin allergies but more patients complained of conjunctivitis, asthma and runny noses or allergic rhinitis.
In the same week, asthma cases shot up by more than 200 to a total of 1,228, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-BEIJING TIES SEEN IMPROVING

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and mainland China are expected to improve as bilateral ties between Washington and Beijing head towards new balance with the first official visit of President Jiang Zemin to America later this month, a leading Australian strategic expert said on Monday.

In an interview with the CNA, Gary Klintworth, a visiting fellow at the Department of International Relations of the Australian National University, said he believes the 1996 tension between Taiwan and mainland China to be over and that ties across the Taiwan Strait will improve.

"This can be justified by studying the history between Taiwan and China. Since 1949, when ties between the US and China were bad, Beijing would become angry with Taiwan. But when relations between Washington and Beijing get better, ties between China and Taiwan also improve," he said.

He described the 1995 tension between Taiwan and the mainland following Beijing's missile-firing exercises off the island as the result of worsening ties between Washington and Beijing because the US government granted Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui a visa to visit Cornell University, his alma mater.
Klintworth last month went to Beijing and Shanghai, where he engaged in extensive discussions on the triangular ties between the US, Taiwan and the mainland with strategists there.

Klintworth said that from the discussions he concluded that "a new balance has been struck between China and the US. Both sides accept that their interests outweigh the sum of their differences and that conflict resolution and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region are contingent on a cooperative Sino-US relationship."

"The Clinton administration has reaffirmed its commitment to a one-China policy, including no US support for Taiwan's UN membership bid and a warning to Taipei that the US is not prepared to support Taiwan's independence. The US also reaffirmed its commitment to a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue," he said.

"Jiang Zemin's China can live with that. Beijing reaffirmed that while it will not renounce the use of force, its priority is peaceful reunification with Taiwan and the avoidance of conflict with the US," he said.
"Besides, China is in no doubt about the technological superiority enjoyed by the US armed forces," he said.
He mentioned that China's defense minister, Chi Haotian, was shown some of America's most modern and formidable military hardware during his visit to the US last December.

"According to Chinese security advisers that I interviewed last month in China's leading strategic studies institutes... China is now happier with the US In the Chinese view, America has adjusted its China policy after being jolted by the Taiwan Strait crisis of 1995-96," Klintworth said.

"According to these strategists, most US policymakers believe that confrontation with China is not in the best interests of either the US or China and that as the Asia-Pacific region's two most important powers, China and the US share too many strategic interests. Sensationalist predictions about a coming war between China and the US were dismissed as a minority viewpoint," he said.
Klintworth said the present US government understands that a policy of containment towards mainland China is likely to leave the US as the state that is isolated.
"The aftermath of the Tiananmen affair in 1989 and the Taiwan Strait crisis in 1995-96 suggests that most countries in the region prefer to accommodate, not confront, China's rise," he said.

"For its part, Chinese policymakers realize, belatedly, that US foreign policy is not just made by the Administration, but includes Congress, the media, think-tanks and corporate America. The US Congress, meanwhile, better understands China's sensitivity on the Taiwan issue.

"The revised US strategy for engaging China is practical, strategically sound and potentially very profitable for both sides and for the Asia-Pacific region, with enormous commercial opportunities for both China and the US and the wider Asia-Pacific community," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE DOCTORS USE FINE NEEDLES TO CHECK CANCEROUS LUMPS

TEXT.P: More doctors in Singapore are turning to the use of a fine needle to find out whether tumors are cancerous or not.
Called Fine Needle Aspiration (FNA) biopsy, the technique uses a very fine needle to obtain a tiny part of the lump tissue which is then mounted on a glass slide for evaluation under the microscope.
Results are usually obtained within hours.
Conventional biopsy, on the other hand, involves the surgical removal of the lump, which usually requires general anesthesia and hospitalization. Results usually take a few days to obtain.

Not surprisingly, the number of FNA biopsies in Singapore have been increasing steadily by about 10 percent annually since the technique was first introduced in the late 1980s, said Dr. Angela Chong, a spokeswoman for a three-day FNA workshop, which ended here on Sunday.
The workshop, attended by more than 60 pathologists from around the region, was organized by the Chapter of Pathologists, the Academy of Medicine and the Singapore Society of Pathologists.
Last year, about 4,000 FNA biopsies were done in government and private hospitals in Singapore, many of which were biopsies for thyroid and breast growths, she said.

The Singapore National University Hospital has one of the largest published series of fine-needle biopsies of the liver in the world -- 92 liver cancers were diagnosed using the method between 1985 and 1992.
Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is widely used in most developed countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI POLICE TO PROTECT YOUTH FROM DANGEROUS INFLUENCES

TEXT.P: Taipei's police force will work even harder to protect the city's youth from dangerous influences ranging from pornography to drugs, Mayor Chen Shui-ban said on Monday.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony honoring police officers who played key roles in the recent apprehension of suspects involved in selling pornographic CD-ROMs and illegal drugs to youths.

The arrests took place in busts which included the break-up of gang-controlled rings that had been selling pirated pornographic CD-ROMs at the Kuang-hua Market, a popular major retail center for computers and software, and raids on pubs, dance-halls and clubs known to be popular places for the sale and use of illegal drugs like ecstasy and amphetamines.
The raids were conducted by city police with tips from the Municipal Bureau of Information and the Bureau of Health.
In his remarks to the police officers at the ceremony, Chen said his first priority was crime prevention, especially with regard to the new types of crime that have surfaced in recent years.

He described this policy as being in line with the desire to solve criminal cases, as well as being the best way to keep problems from rapidly worsening and creating a further burden on police resources.
The mayor pointed out that sales of so-called "Big Tonic" or "DBT" pornographic CD-ROMs and illegal drugs are not only harming the city's youth, but also severely worsening social order in the city.
For the sake of the country's future development, the authorities cannot tolerate the sale of illegal drugs, he said.
He also commended the bureaus of health and information for their cooperation with the police.
Mayor Chen also inspected the city's Criminal Investigation Corps and presented citations to some 30 officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT EUROPE TO STUDY COALITION CABINET OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will leave Taipei on Wednesday for a 10-day European tour which will take him to Germany and France.

Hsu's first stop will be the biennial Berlin Meeting, which is organized by the Fredrick Neumann Foundation under Germany's Free Democratic Party. The chairmen of major political parties dedicated to freedom and democracy from 20 countries around the world are expected to attend the meeting.
Hsu will then travel to France, where he will deliver a keynote speech on relations across the Taiwan Strait at a seminar sponsored by France's Socialist Party.
Hsu said on Monday his French host will also arrange for him to look into the way France's current coalition cabinet functions.
Hsu said he is interested in studying the transformation of major foreign political parties, as well as the operations of coalition cabinets in other countries.

The leader of Taiwan's largest opposition party said he will not touch on the coalition cabinet issue in his campaign activities for the year-end mayoral and county magistrate elections, although he did say the issue will be a major topic for the DPP's campaign literature for next year's Legislative Yuan election.
Hsu has advocated the formation of a coalition cabinet comprising officials from both the ruling Kuomintang and the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN TRADE PERFORMS WELL: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade performed vigorously in the third quarter of this year, with growth in both exports and imports in September, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Monday.

According to statistics the MOF is to release on Tuesday, Taiwan's exports amounted to over US$10.3 billion in September, up 8 percent from the previous month, while imports reached about US$9.6 billion, up more than 20 percent.

Most export items were from the information and electrical sectors, the MOF said, adding that Taiwan imported numerous military goods, as well as lots of components for automatic data processors and integrated circuit boards in September.

Although the island's imports grew more than its exports did last month, resulting in a declining trade surplus, Taiwan's performance in foreign trade is still "healthy" because most of the additional imports will be used for production here, the MOF said.

The ministry predicted exports in the fourth quarter will perform well, based on increasing orders and an average 7 percent rise in exports in the third quarter of 1997 in comparison with the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: GCC TO ADOPT UNIFIED CUSTOMS PROCEDURES

TEXT.P: The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states have agreed to adopt new unified customs procedures beginning February next year, according to a spokesman for the General Secretariat here.
The spokesman said the agreement was reached during a one-day meeting of directors general of customs departments from the six-nation regional grouping.

Two separate procedures were drawn up, one for export and the other for re-export. Following a wide-ranging exchange of views, the meeting of customs chiefs decided to combine the two regulations and treat them as one, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLORFUL ACTIVITIES TO MARK ROC NATIONAL DAY IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: "Double Tenth" celebrations will be held in all major Australian cities between Oct. 7 and 10 to mark the 86th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, organizers said on Monday.

Celebration parties will be held in large hotels in Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide to mark the occasion, with overseas Chinese leaders and Australian government officials taking part.

Related events will feature badminton competitions, golf tournaments, the distribution of gifts to elder overseas Chinese in Sydney, lion dances and performances of traditional Chinese music, the organizers said, adding that thousands of overseas Chinese are expected to take part.
There are currently about 400,000 overseas Chinese living in Australia with between 20,000 and 30,000 from Taiwan.

The events are being organized by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne, the offices of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and the ROC Nationalist Party, or Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HONG YANG CONSTRUCTION BOOSTS INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Hong Yang Construction Co., one of the largest residential developers in Taiwan, is negotiating to buy the Nowra Fair Shopping Center on the south coast of New South Wales, property sources said.
Shin Yen International, a subsidiary of Hong Yang in Australia, is expected to pay about US$29 million for the 16,039 square-meter shopping center, which houses major department stores.

Shin Yen made its investment debut in Australia when it spent almost US$24 million to buy a shopping center in Sydney early this year. It recently paid US$30 million to buy another shopping center in Gold Coast, Queensland.
The sources said they expect Shin Yen to seal a contract for the new shopping center in Nowra. In addition, they said, Shin Yen is eyeing two more shopping centers worth about US$72 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.037 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Monday, finishing at NT$28.586.
The greenback opened at NT$28.58 and was traded between NT$28.512 and NT$28.6. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$337 million.

Meanwhile, the US dollar averaged NT$27.82 during the first nine months of this year, up 1.2 percent from the same period of last year, according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The figures also indicate that the Japanese yen averaged NT$0.2358 during the nine month period, down 9.3 percent from the year-earlier level, while the deutsche mark was worth NT$16.29, depreciating 13.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON SPECULATIVE ATTACKS ON TAIWAN CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Monday's edition of local English-language daily The China Post.
The CBC Must Firmly Curb Speculation
During the last two business days, the Taipei foreign exchange market saw a massive sell-off of the New Taiwan dollar.

The large sales of the NT dollar last week came mainly as a result of widespread market expectations for the depreciation of the local currency. Many traders and investors expected a lower NT dollar for a number of reasons. First, they believed that the lingering Southeast Asian currency crises would sooner or later impact other regional markets, such as Taiwan.

Second, Taiwan's domestic unfavorable economic changes of late could build downward pressure on the NT dollar. One such change was a slowdown in export growth. Another adverse development was a continuous falling stock market, which could cause more foreign institutional investors to pull their funds out of Taiwan. But a closer look at these local economic conditions will find the market's speculation for the NT dollar to undergo major depreciation lacks solid foundation. Although Taiwan's exports have slowed somewhat this year, the island still enjoyed a surplus of more than US$4 billion thus far...

Although some foreign institutional investors seem to have continued to remit more funds out of Taiwan than they sent in lately because of a continued decline of the stock market, yet since foreign equity investments account for only a small 4 percent of the local bourse's capitalization, such a trend is unlikely to cause a major destabilizing effect on the local forex market.

In regard to speculation that the NT dollar could come under potential wild speculative attack simply because of a possible fallout from Southeast Asian markets, that is not well-based. Countries like Thailand and Malaysia, which are currently faced with currency crises, are suffering such problems because their economic fundamentals have gone wrong.

That is not the situation with Taiwan. Unlike those economies, Taiwan's financial markets are generally healthy. Its balance of international payments has always remained favorable. And it has the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves of some US$90 billion...

So the market expectations for the NT dollar to depreciate were unreasonable and it was right for the CBC to intervene under current circumstances, prevent speculative attacks and maintain orderly transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATIZATION OF CHINA PETROLEUM CORP. AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The state-run China Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will be privatized by fiscal 2001 as scheduled, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said Monday.
Wang said that despite strong voices of opposition from the CPC employees, the Ministry of Economics will start the process of the firm's privatization in fiscal 1998 and complete it by fiscal 2001.

In line with the privatization plan, 15 percent of CPC shares will be released in fiscal 1998, and additional 37 percent will be released in Taiwan and abroad over the following three fiscal years, Wang said while answering questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang said he believes that the new CPC chairman, Chen Chou-wei, who was former executive director of the Commission of National Corporations and once headed the Taiwan Salt Corp. and BES Engineering Corp., has the ability to lead the CPC against the competition it will face when the oil products market is totally liberalized in less than 5 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA MAY HAVE 59,000 HIV-POSITIVE INHABITANTS

TEXT.P: The number of people in Indonesia who have tested positive for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, rose 2 percent to 590 last month, an official said.
The real number of those infected with HIV could be 100 times higher, the Antara news agency quoted Dr. Hadi M. Abednego as saying on Saturday.

Hadi, who is the director general of the department for the prevention of communicable diseases of the Indonesian Ministry of Health, noted that in 90 percent of the cases the virus was transmitted by sexual contact.
There have been 81 AIDS-related deaths in Indonesia, Hadi said, adding that 308 -- or more than half -- of HIV cases have been concentrated in the remote areas of Maluku and Irian Jaya.
The two provinces harbor bases for large fishing operations that employ foreigners, mostly Taiwanese and Thais.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA TO TIGHTEN REQUIREMENTS TO PROTECT ITS WORKERS ABROAD

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Manpower Ministry will apply stricter requirements to sending workers abroad in order to help protect their rights, the Indonesia Times reported Monday.

Jacky Iskandarsyah, director of manpower placement at the ministry, was quoted by the daily as saying that the requirements would apply to workers, local agencies, foreign agencies and overseas employers.
Around two million Indonesians work abroad and earn billions of dollars for the country, Iskandarsyah said.
The new requirements will go into effect in the 1998/1999 fiscal year, which starts in April 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY ATTRACTS US SUPPORT: BELLOCCHI

TEXT.P: The development of democracy in Taiwan will remain the key factor in US support for the island, a former high ranking US official on Taiwan affairs said on Monday.

Nat Bellocchi, former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said in a speech here that while emphasizing the significance of its first popular presidential election held last year, Taiwan also needs to introduce the international community to more of its achievements in democratization in order to promote its international profile.

Taiwan should let the world gain a better understanding of the island's current social, political, and economic situations via a variety of channels and means, Bellocchi suggested, adding that Taiwan need not keep mentioning that it has made a lot of progress compared with 20 or 30 years ago.

On cross-strait relations, Bellocchi said that the US government has never pressured Taiwan to hold negotiations with mainland China. Washington simply hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can have more contacts, he added.

Bellocchi said that when he served as AIT chairman between August 1990 and December 1995, he often told the US State Department that Washington should attach more importance to Taiwan. He also denied that the State Department is unfriendly to Taiwan, citing the department's unprecedented announcement that whether or not Taiwan will be reunified with mainland China should be decided by the people of Taiwan.

Bellocchi delivered his speech at a luncheon meeting sponsored by the Kaohsiung-based Asian Pacific Public Affairs Forum (APPAF). He praised the forum and other such private organizations, saying that they can help Taiwan increase its international profile by conducting academic and cultural exchanges with private organizations in the United States and other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SPAIN TIES IMPROVING

TEXT.P: ROC-Spanish relations have been improving for the last year or two, along with the improvement in ties between other West European countries and the Republic of China, said a senior Foreign Ministry official Monday, one day after Vice President Lien Chan left for Iceland on a private visit.
Lien will reportedly stop over in the Iberian state on his way back home.
Chen Chien-jen, vice foreign minister, told CNA that the friendship Taiwan and Spain once shared sank to a nadir after 1973, when Madrid broke its ties with Taipei.

Thanks to a recent increase in exchanges between Taiwan and West European states, Madrid and Taipei have been improving their ties with each other along with gaining an increasing understanding of each other's economic development and democratization, and both have expressed an interest in beefing up trade and commercial ties, said Chen.

Trade and economic ties -- which have helped Taiwan forge non-official relations with many countries in the absence of diplomatic ties -- are a vital part of modern diplomacy, Chen said, adding that Beijing's attempts to isolate Taipei on the international stage have been the major obstacle to the island's efforts to expand its international role.
However, the vice minister said that more and more countries have realized recently that they could choose their own friends on the diplomatic stage without taking into account Beijing's desires.
Chen, who visited Spain in May, denied that his trip was aimed at laying the groundwork for Lien's visit to Madrid.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE AND VISITING SWAZI KING VOW TO FURTHER DEEPEN TIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui and visiting Swazi King Mswati III vowed Monday evening to further deepen cooperation between their two countries and upgrade the welfare of the peoples of both lands.
In a state banquet hosted by Lee for Mswati, Lee thanked Swaziland for its firm support for the Republic of China's bid to rejoin the United Nations.

The southern African state is one of 30 countries that maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC, and one of 15 states that spoke out at the ongoing UN General Assembly session for Taipei's bid to occupy a UN seat, just as Beijing does.
Mswati thanked Lee at the banquet for the warm reception he has been given here.

As an ally of the ROC, Swaziland will continue its support for Taipei on the international stage, Mswati said, adding that he looks forward to closer cooperation with Taipei for the benefit of both countries.
Also at Monday's banquet were foreign envoys to Taipei and senior ROC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT VISITING ICELAND

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan and his wife arrived in Iceland Monday for an unofficial visit, the Presidential Office said in a brief press release.

"The Icelandic government has extended its welcome to Lien's visit and will arrange meetings between Lien and Icelandic political and business leaders in a bid to help promote mutual understanding between the two counties," it said, adding that Lien will also visit cultural and economic establishments there.
Iceland, an island nation in the north Atlantic, occupies an important strategic position. With sound infrastructure facilities and a high quality of life, Iceland is now a highly developed country.
Having adopted a parliamentary system about 1,000 years ago, Iceland is one of the earliest European democracies.
Currently, Taipei neither maintains diplomatic relations with nor operates a representative office in Iceland.
The Presidential Office termed Lien's visit to Iceland "the beginning of pragmatic diplomacy between the ROC and northern European countries."
Lien, accompanied by his wife and Hsu Li-teh, a presidential senior advisor, left here for Iceland via Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PEOPLE BECOME USED TO POST-HANDOVER STATE: MAC

TEXT.P: The people of Hong Kong appear used to the post-handover government there, while its new leader Tung Chee-hwa is enjoying increasing popularity, an official report here noted.
William Li, director of the Hong Kong and Macau affairs of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Monday released a report on Hong Kong's post-handover status.
The MAC has asked relevant agencies to regularly submit reports on the current situations in Hong Kong and Macau, as well as on Taiwan-Hong Kong ties.

According to survey results, the report said, Hong Kong residents are growing accustomed to their new government and see little change in the economy since the former British colony reverted to Beijing's rule.

Meanwhile, the report also noted that although more and more Hong Kong emigrants have returned for visits since the July 1 handover, the number of foreign visitors has declined, with a 35 percent drop in July in comparison with the year-earlier level and a 25 percent decrease in August.
An MAC official told CNA Monday that his council hopes links between Taiwan and Hong Kong will be further enhanced, especially in the field of official visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL WELL PREPARED FOR CROSS-STRAIT AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) has made all necessary preparations for the opening of air links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, CAL Chairman Chiang Hung-yi said here Monday.

Chiang predicted that CAL will not begin flight services to mainland China within the coming year, but he was optimistic about the long-term prospects for cross-strait air links as the atmosphere between the two sides has become more relaxed in recent months.
Chiang traveled to Thailand to preside over a celebration marking the 30th anniversary of CAL's Bangkok branch office.

To prepare for the inauguration of cross-strait air links, CAL has established CAL-Asia Investment Inc. in the Virgin Islands and set up an office in Beijing, Chiang said. CAL has also reached agreement with some mainland airlines, including China Southern Airline and China Northern Airline, to provide transit passengers with inter-airline boarding passes and to check luggage directly through to their final destinations, he added.

In an interview with CNA, Chiang also said that CAL attaches great importance to its flight routes in Southeast Asia. Recently it has opened a charter service between Taipei and Rangoon, Burma. Due to high demand, the airline plans to increase its twice-weekly flights to three flights a week.
The CAL also hopes to open routes to South Asian countries such as India, Chiang said.

Chiang said CAL is currently working to train its own corps of pilots. It has so far sent nine groups of personnel for training in the United States. In addition, the airline also sent two groups of trainees to Germany.
In order to operate the fleet of 67 planes it expects to field by the year 2003, CAL will also invite retired foreign pilots or discharged air force pilots to serve the former national flag carrier.

Chiang said CAL presently has crew members from Japan, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore. If there are needs to increase the number of flights to Europe, he added, the company will consider recruiting personnel from countries on that continent. (By F. C. Kuo and Lilian Wu) ENDITEM ZCZC CEP002 10-07-97 ROC JOINS CONFERENCE ON FREE-TRADE ZONES

Ankara, Oct. 6 (CNA) The World Export Processing Zones Association (WEPZA) opened its 17th conference in Istanbul on Monday, in which participants from 40 countries, including the Republic of China, called for greater cooperation among free-trade zones around the world.

According to conference organizers, some 150 delegates from 40 countries are participating in the Oct. 6-8 meeting. The them of discussion is "The Role of Free Zones in the Emerging World Trade System." The gathering will also discuss subjects such as technology transfers, sharing of statistical information and documentation, and closer international trade cooperation between the zones.

WEPZA, based in Flagstaff, Arizona, in the United States, is the only organization that brings together 46 private and government-owned free industrial and trade zones and ports in 38 countries. Founded in Manila in 1978 under the auspices of the United Nations Industrial Development Organizations, WEPZA is the only UN-sponsored organization of which the Republic of China is a member.
Countries and areas represented at the Istanbul meeting include the ROC, mainland China, Hong Kong, the United States, Canada, Germany, Russia, Australia, Brazil, South Korea and the Philippines.
