DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE GAP WITH JAPAN WIDENS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chronic trade imbalance with Japan has worsened this year because of dwindling exports to that country, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Tuesday.

Although Taiwan managed to post a 4.9 percent gain in overall outbound shipments for the first three quarters of this year, its monthly sales to Japan have continued to suffer double-digit declines for several months.
According to MOF tallies, Taiwan exports to Japan registered a 13 percent year-on-year drop in August and the annual rate of decrease expanded to an alarming 15.5 percent in September.

Taiwan exported only US$900 million worth of goods to Japan in September, while importing US$2.57 billion worth of Japanese products. As a result, Taiwan registered a trade deficit of US$1.69 billion in that month alone.

Taiwan's accumulated trade deficit with Japan for the first nine months of this year has already topped US$15 billion, far higher than the US$10.23 billion recorded for the same period of last year and larger even than the US$13.83 billion registered for all of 1996.

MOF officials attributed the serious drop in Japan-bound shipments mainly to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at local hog farms in March that prompted the Japanese government to ban pork imports from Taiwan.

Prior to implementation of the ban, Japan had been Taiwan's largest pork export market, absorbing more than 90 percent of the island's annual exports of pork products. At the same time, imports from Japan have continued to climb due to the increasing demand for Japanese electronics parts and components, which has served to further widen Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE NATIONS SUPPORT ROC'S UN BID

TEXT.P: The foreign ministers of the Gambia, Guinea-Bissau and Grenada on Monday expressed their support for the Republic of China's efforts to join the United Nations and participate in international activities.

"My delegation strongly supports the aspirations of the 21.3 million people of the Republic of China on Taiwan to exercise their rights to share and participate in the activities of intergovernmental organizations on international cooperation by joining this community of nations," Foreign Minister Omar Y. Njie of the Gambia said in a speech to the UN General Assembly.

The legitimacy of their aspirations, both legal and national, has been reinforced by similar actions and measures taken by the United Nations on the issue of parallel representation and which now serve as useful reminders and examples, he stressed.

The Taiwan question is also a test of the international community's interpretation of "democracy," and the participation of the ROC on Taiwan in the United Nations can only enrich the organization, Njie continued.

The ROC has existed physically, legally and politically since the creation of the world body, he pointed out, adding that "my government therefore believes that our organization will do itself a great service by admitting Taiwan among our midst, in the true spirit of the application of democratic principles."

Foreign Minister Fernando D. da Silva of Guinea-Bissau said that, based on the principles of universality and equal sovereignty of states, the government of Guinea-Bissau reiterated its conviction that the ROC deserves to regain a place in the United Nations.

He also praised Taiwan for its achievements in economic and social developments and respect for fundamental human rights. The participation of the ROC in the United Nations and its agencies would be an important factor for the preservation of international peace, stability and cooperation, the minister stated.
On his part, Foreign Minister Raphael Fletcher of Grenada stressed that the ROC's membership in the world body is a matter of "justice."

"To all who subscribe to the principle of the right of a people to self-determination, the case for membership of the United Nations organization on behalf of the Republic of China on Taiwan is a compelling one," he indicated.
Some 50 years ago, the minister explained, this people chose self-determination. "They voted with their feet," as they moved from their home in mainland China to Taiwan.

And today, he continued, 21.3 million people practice democracy in Taiwan. Their economic achievements are widely known, as is their willingness to participate in the international community as a member of the United Nations.
"What more is required for the Republic of China to be admitted to UN membership, one may well ask," Fletcher emphasized. "My answer is `justice,'" he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND BECOME ILLEGAL IVORY PROCESSING CENTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China have become major illegal ivory processing centers in the Asia-Pacific region, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Tuesday.

Despite a global ban on ivory trade, illegal smuggling rings still manage to smuggle large quantities of elephant tusks from Africa to mainland China and Taiwan via Southeast Asia or Hong Kong for processing, the council said, adding that the processed ivories are then smuggled abroad, with ethnic Chinese as the main customers.
According to the council, ivory products processed in mainland China are usually smuggled to Hong Kong, while those processed in Taiwan are mostly shipped to the United States.
COA officials said Chinese-style ivory carvings and sculptures, particularly those in dragon or phoenix motif, have consistently enjoyed brisk sales in overseas Chinese communities.

The officials said the hobby of collecting ivory products has declined in Taiwan since government authorities intensified efforts to crackdown on illegal trade in ivory a few years ago. However, they said, illicit ivory processing has continued to exist in Taiwan.
COA figures show that ivory has often topped the list of contraband wildlife products confiscated by local law-enforcement authorities.
A total of 173 violations of the wildlife conservation law were reported between June and September this year, with ivory-related cases forming the largest portion, the officials said.

Meanwhile, nearly all of the contraband goods seized by customs offices in recent months were made of ivory, including necklaces, folding fans, Buddhist figurines, floral vases, walking cane heads, ink holders and chopsticks.
The officials said some souvenir shops at local tourist hotels and jewelry trading centers in downtown Taipei had been found to illegally display ivory products.
The officials said the COA will intensify its crackdown on illegal ivory trade in addition to launching a publicity campaign to remind local people not to purchase or own ivory items.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE 171.24 POINTS ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 171.24 points to finish at 8221.35.
The bourse opened at 8285.28 and experienced a high of 8368.29 and a low of 8177.54.
Losers outnumbered gainers 386 to 54, with 29 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.91 billion (US$3.43 billion).

Electrical engineering issues and plastic and chemical shares fell the most at 2.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks at 2.6 percent and textile shares at 1.9 percent. Cement, conctruction and foodstuff shares dropped at 1.5 percent, while finance shares fell 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCP CONGRESS REPORT NEGLECTED POLITICAL REFORM: XU JIATUN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Xu Jiatun, former Hong Kong Bureau chief of Xinhua News Agency, criticized the report by Chinese Communist Party (CCP) General Secretary Jiang Zemin to the party's 15th National Congress, saying it focused upon economic development while neglecting political reforms.

Jiang has inherited the "monistic" system of leadership from late Communist patriarch Deng Xiaoping, and its disastrous effects will soon emerge, Xu observed in an article published Sunday in the Hong Kong Economic Journal.

Xu pointed out in the article that Jiang's report on economic reform brings the reform of state-run enterprises going parallel with all the other forms ownership. It is based on the premise that "socialist public ownership is dominant, while diverse forms of ownership develop side by side," thus providing the principle of public ownership as the mainstay of economic development with a new interpretation.
The report acknowledged the spirit of Deng Xiaoping Theory in the sphere of economic reform, and a new wave of economic development can be expected, Xu added.
But he criticized Jiang's report as being too conservative on the question of political reform. It asserts only that "progress is continuing" without mentioning specific details, Xu said.

In the Chinese mainland, the Communists claim to be representing the people, while in fact they are replacing the people; and the so called government "of the people" is in fact the rule "of the party," he added.

Jiang's interpretation of political reform, said Xu, is impressive in appearance but not in substance, and except there is an innovative attempt to introduce "administration according to law," basically any initiatives in this regard are tantamount to treading water.

In order to promote the overall development of mainland China, Beijing should abandon its conservative line toward political reform in the process of implementing the policies outlined at the recently concluded 15th congress, Xu recommended.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRONG DATA ON HEIGHT OF MOUNTAIN MIGHT CAUSE F-5 CRASH

TEXT.P: Wrong Data on the height of a mountain may be behind the crash of two F-5E jet fighters on Sept. 30 in eastern Taiwan, a preliminary investigation has shown.

Huang Hsien-jung, commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Air Force, said Tuesday that when the accident at Mount Hotien happened, the jet fighters were flying at 1,002 feet, much higher than the previous estimate of 650 feet.

Mount Hotien, in the eastern county of Hualien, is listed as being 850 feet high in the military's data. A survey following the crash, however, showed that the mountain actually has a height of 1,200 feet.

An F-5E and a twin-seater F-5F crashed into Mount Hotien on Sept. 30, claiming the lives of three pilots. Air Force Headquarters ruled out the possibility that the two fighters collided with each other, saying that with weather conditions causing poor visibility, the pilots might have fatally misjudged the mountain's height.

The new information reveals that the wrong data on the height of the mountain may have led to the three deaths. Because of poor visibility at that time, the pilots were flying by instruments at 1,002 feet and never suspected they could crash into a mountain listed as 850 feet high.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN LONDON CELEBRATES DOUBLE TENTH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative in the United Kingdom Eugene Chien and former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Monday jointly cut a cake to kick off a party celebrating the National Day of the Republic of China.

More than 400 guests, including ROC officials, Taiwan businessmen, British legislators and officials, and foreign envoys stationed in London, took part in the party held at Grosvenor House Hotel on Monday night.

Chien noted that Taiwan has made great strides in political democratization and economic liberalization since the lifting of martial law in 1987. ROC-British relations have been growing closer since then, he said, citing the increasing number of Taiwan students pursuing higher education in Britain and the rise in investment projects there made by Taiwan businessmen.

Chien told the guests that he will soon step down from his current position and return to Taipei to serve as an advisor to the National Security Council, but that he will also continue his efforts to promote ROC-British ties while in Taipei.

In addition to expressing her congratulations to the ROC on its National Day, which is commonly called "Double Tenth Day" since it falls on October 10, Thatcher praised Chien's significant contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties between the ROC and Britain during his four-year tenure.

Tom Cox, chief of the British-Taiwan Parliamentary Group, said that the parliament will make more efforts to help improve the ROC's diplomatic status in Britain and in the international community, while another member of parliament, Martin O'Neil, said that the parliament will continue its support for the ROC and promote the bilateral ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports set a new single-month high of US$10.87 billion in September, marking a 10.7 percent year-on-year rise, while imports soared 26.3 percent to US$9.75 billion, the Ministry of Finance reported on Tuesday.

As a result, Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$1.12 billion, down 46.5 percent from that recorded in September 1996. Nevertheless, it was the third time that the monthly trade surplus managed to exceed the US$1 billion mark.
Both the export and import growth rates for September were the highest so far this year, according to ministry tallies.
Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the ministry's Statistics Department, attributed the significant export growth rate partly to the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar in recent months.
Hsu optimistically predicted that the current export boom will go on in the months ahead as the NT dollar's devaluation will continue to benefit local export industries.

Generally speaking, Hsu pointed out, Taiwan will also benefit from the recent currency crises in major Southeast Asian countries. The expected economic slowdown in those countries due to their currency crises is not expected to seriously affect Taiwan's export trade because the region does not account for a large portion of the island's total overseas sales. On the other hand, the depreciation of Southeast Asian currencies will help reduce import costs for local manaufacturers who have relied on the region for the supply of raw materials.

Judging from recent trade records, Hsu said Taiwan's annual export growth rate will exceed 5 percent this year, while its import growth rate will be 11 to 12 percent. With imports growing faster than exports, Hsu said, Taiwan's trade surplus will shrink to between US$7 billion and US$8 billion.
According to ministry statistics, exports posted a 4.9 percent gain in the first three quarters of this year, while imports surged 19.2 percent during the same nine-month period.

"The sharp rise in imports mainly reflects brisk domestic demand and robust production activities," Hsu noted, adding that raw materials and production equipment continued to form the bulk of imports and both registered double-digit growth during the January-September period. "All these figures indicate that our economy will continue to pick up steam."
On the export front, electronics, information technology and communications remained the best-selling items in September and all chalked up a 20 percent year-on-year gain.
Exports to such major markets as the United States, Hong Kong, Europe and Southeast Asia all posted gains in September, but sales to Japan declined as compared with the eyar-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.091 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taiwan foreign exchange market on Tuesday, finishing at the day's low of NT$28.495.
The greenback opened at NT$28.587, and had a high of NT$28.6.
Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$440 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EXPAND ECONOMIC LINKS WITH ICELAND
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: Authorities in Iceland hope to expand their island nation's economic relations with Taiwan by boosting trade and tourism exchanges, an official at Taipei's representative office in Denmark said.

Chuo Chung-cheng, economic section director at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Copenhagen, said two-way trade between Iceland and Taiwan totaled only US$21.37 million in 1996, leaving what he called ample room for economic cooperation and development between the two countries.
Chou's responsibilities include overseeing Taiwan's economic links with the Scandinavian nation as Taipei has not established a representative office in Iceland.

Chou also said Iceland imported some US$7.15 million worth of goods from Taiwan last year, including bicycles, fishing nets, automobile parts, computer components and automatic data processing equipment.
The country's major export items to Taiwan were seafood products, including frozen fish, nonedible fish meat, shellfish, crustaceans and caviar, he said.
Although Iceland's population and trade are relatively small, there is ample room for economic cooperation between the ROC and Iceland, especially in the industrial and fishery sectors, he said.
Chou cited the aluminum casting industry as an example for potential bilateral cooperation.

Iceland generates far more energy than it consumes and is begining to produce aluminum, accordingly, Taiwan's aluminum casting industries would be wise to seek cooperation opportunities in Iceland, Chou said.

The fishing industry of Iceland, which generates about 10 percent of gross national product, is another ideal field for joint ventures. Taiwan fishermen would benefit from cooperation with partners in Iceland, he added.

Iceland's technological know-how in harnessing geothermal energy is so advanced that the United Nations has established a special university to train students from developing nations on methods of harnessing the natural resources, he pointed out.
Taiwan could benefit from such technology as the island is also rich in geothermal resources, Chou said.
He also cited government statistics from Iceland which indicate that 6,000 tourists from Taiwan have visited there since the beginning of this year.
The statistics shows that Taiwan tourists are being drawn to Iceland in increasing numbers by the island's unique geographic features, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT VISITS ICELAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan of the Republic of China arrived in the Icelandic capital of Reykjavik late Monday afternoon together with his wife and a small entourage.
Lien is expected to meet with Iceland's Prime Minister David Oddson on Wednesday, the highlight of Lien's five-day stay in the Scandinavian island nation.
A group of Taiwan reporters greeted Lien outside his hotel.
Interest in Lien's visit has also been high among the Icelandic media.
According to Chen Yu-chu, the ROC's chief representative to Denmark, Lien did not have any major activity in his first evening in Iceland.
Lien is scheduled to visit economic facilities Tuesday morning, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN WALL STREET JOURNAL TO BE PRINTED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Asian Wall Street Journal (AWSJ) has announced that it will print its newspaper in Taipei by the end of this year.
Copies of the business daily are currently flown into Taiwan from Hong Kong. The new plan will make the newspaper available in Taiwan in the morning instead of mid-afternoon.

William Adamopoulos, AWSJ managing director, said Monday the paper has an audited daily circulation of 2,581 in Taiwan and that he hopes its circulation here will soon increase to 5,000 or even 6,000 copies.
The price of the daily will remain much the same as the current NT$80 (US$2.80), he said. In the future, however, the paper will increase its reporting on Taiwan news, he added.
Adamopoulos said that Taipei will be the seventh printing site for the paper in the Asian region, where it enjoys a circulation of over 56,000 copies.
The China Post, an English-language newspaper based in Taipei, will be responsible for the printing and distribution of the Asian Wall Street Journal in Taiwan.
The AWSJ made its debut in Hong Kong in 1976.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY IMPORTS BETEL NUTS FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By L.K. Sheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Though there are fewer than 10,000 overseas Chinese in Paraguay, the fact that many of them are in the import-export business has made Taiwan betel nuts easily available here.
The "Chinese chewing gum" was first brought from Taiwan to the South American country about 12 years ago. It is said that chewing the nuts can help relieve the homesickness of Chinese immigrants.
Paraguay's monthly imports of the Taiwan product grew to a peak of 60,000 nuts before gradually declining to around 35,000.

Betel nut chewers are not limited to Taiwanese; they include people from mainland China and Hong Kong. Even some Koreans and Arabs who have dealings with Taiwanese have gotten hooked on the natural stimulant.
Overseas Chinese in Brazil and Argentina, who have had difficulty in importing betel nuts, have had to rely on the resale of betel nuts from Paraguay.
Sources said that since betel nuts are not easy to keep fresh, a shipment could go rotten if there is any delay in delivery or customs clearance.

With the high costs involved in importing betel nuts, their price is also high. A box of 12 betel nuts can go for up to US$10, double the market price in Taiwan. But in La Ciudad del Este, where Taiwan businessmen converge, over 300 packs are sold some nights.

Eyeing the possibility of high returns, overseas Chinese have tried to grow betel palms in Paraguay. The nuts from these trees have a taste similar to those from palms in Taiwan, according to some who have tried both.

The limited number of betel palms in Paraguay is insufficient to meet the demand here. If the number of betel nut consumers grows, however, the trees could become part of the diversification of Paraguay's agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY FACILITIES MOVED UNDERGROUND TO AVOID MAINLAND ATTACK

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan's military facilities and weapons depots have been moved underground to avoid a possible mainland Chinese attack, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) reported on Tuesday.
The ministry was commenting on foreign wire service reports that eight of mainland China's missile bases currently target Taiwan and its major offshore islands.

Military spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding told a news conference that the eight missile bases are only part of mainland China's overall missile deployment and that although its missiles are usually deployed against specific neighboring countries, they can be easily adjusted to aim at new targets. Kung also pointed out that Taiwan is within range of all types of strategic and tactical missiles deployed by mainland China.
In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, Kung said the ROC military has moved most of its installations and arsenals underground to minimize any possible war damage.
The military is also using separation and camouflage strategies to hide or disguise its facilities and installations, the general added.
He said the MND has no knowledge about a US defense report which predicts that mainland China will have the capacity to produce 1,000 ballistic missiles in 10 years' time.
"We will keep a close watch on these developments," Kung said, adding that a country's missile production capabilities hinge on its technological level, economic strength and budget distribution.

Commenting on a US naval report that mainland China is currently upgrading six types of its warplanes and expects to achieve air supremacy over Taiwan in eight years, Kung said airborne combat capabilities rely not only on the performance of the planes themselves but also on the weaponry and radar systems installed on the aircraft, as well as on the command, control, communications and intelligence-gathering abilities of all those involved in operating the planes. "A country's airborne combat capabilities are not weighed solely by the number of warplanes it can deploy."
Kung stressed that Taiwan has no intention of engaging in an arms race with mainland China. "The ultimate goal of our military build-up plan is to construct an elite deterrent force," he emphasized.

Meanwhile, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling told lawmakers on Tuesday that the air force is studying a request by the state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. to postpone the delivery of the country's locally manufactured Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters for one year.

Chiang further said the government's plan to trim the country's armed forces to 400,000 is an appropriate goal. Under this plan, the number of people in uniform will form only 1.82 percent of Taiwan's total population, lower, for example, than Israel's 3.058 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC TO BE WORLD'S 2ND LARGEST IT MARKET

TEXT.P: By the year 2000, the Asia-Pacific region is expected to overtake Europe as the world's second largest information technology (IT) market after the United States, a high-ranking Singapore official said Tuesday.
Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Lee Yock Suan made the assertion in his keynote address at the opening ceremony of the mammoth Comdex Asia '97 exhibition here.

He said the Asia-Pacific IT market is growing at 35 percent per annum. Last year, the Asia-Pacific region accounted for 24 percent of the world's US$610 billion IT market, behind Western Europe at 27 percent and the United States at 42 percent, he added.
"By the Year 2000," he predicted, "the Asia-Pacific is expected to overtake Europe as the world's second largest IT market after the USA."
Governments and businesses in the region are eager to harness IT to boost their economic competitiveness, he said.
The Asia-Pacific region is fast emerging as an IT powerhouse. In 1995, six of the top 10 IT exporters were from this region. Together, they produced 58 percent of global IT products, he said.
With the tremendous growth potential of IT, Lee said, many Asia-Pacific countries have ambitious plans to develop their IT industries and infrastructure.
Singapore has materialized some of its plans to transform Singapore into an "Intelligent Island," he said, adding, "We aim to develop Singapore as the IT Hub of this region."

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCKBROKERS REAP WINDFALL FROM SE ASIAN CURRENCY CRISIS

TEXT.P: Stockbrokers in Singapore enjoyed windfall takings in the third quarter, benefiting from the currency crisis that had gripped the region.
Turnover on the Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) in the July-September quarter soared 126 percent year-on-year to 14.2 billion shares from 6.3 billion shares.
Trading value almost doubled to S$33.4 billion (US$21.7 billion) from S$17.1 billion (US$11.1 billion) previously. Brokers are paid commissions based on the value of shares dealt.
Turnover in volume and value in September alone was a hefty 172 percent and 106 percent higher than the corresponding month last year.

Trading in non-Singapore dollar stocks last month saw a significant rise with turnover hitting 798.4 million units worth S$1.6 billion -- a huge jump from a meager 182.6 million units worth S$491.3 million in September 1996.
These figures comprise all trades on the main board, including non-Singapore dollar shares, Clob International and Sesdaq, according to the SES.
Since July 2, when the Thai baht was effectively devalued, trading volume on the SES has witnessed a resurgence.

Before that, the local bourse had languished, its lack of direction reflected in the paltry 8.7 billion shares worth S$23.1 billion transacted in the second quarter, The Straits Times said in a report Tuesday.
But the hefty increase in trading came at the expense of share values, which shrank S$21.5 billion or 8.5 percent in the third quarter.
However, the blue-chip Straits Times Industrials Index shed only 1.7 percent to 1,954.68 during this period.

Dealers said the benchmark index had outperformed the broader market due to a strong showing from four index heavyweights: Singapore Bus Service, ST Aerospace and the local branches of Singapore Airlines and Singapore Press Holdings.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA THREATENS TO WALK AWAY FROM GLOBAL WARMING SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Australia has threatened to walk away from an international summit meeting on global warming in Kyoto, Japan in December and refuse to sign any related treaty that would cost jobs in the Down Under.

In his strongest message on the subject to date, Prime Minister John Howard said Monday that Australia is prepared to walk away from the Kyoto climate-change summit on December 1 because of tough proposals by the United States, European Union (EU) and Japan.

The Japanese proposal demands that Australia cut greenhouse gas emissions by 1.8 percent by the year 2012, based on 1990 levels, which is considerably less onerous than the EU target of a 15 percent reduction by all industrialized countries.
"There is a call that Australia's growing economy be burdened with a new, unrealistic and unfair speed limit upon growth," Howard told the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers in Melbourne on Monday.

"The government is not prepared to sign on to any agreement at Kyoto unless it is fair and unless we are confident the Australian community can achieve any commitments we undertake. Australia cannot sign up to proposals that would lead to the export of jobs and our energy efficient minerals and metals processing industries," Howard said.
Australia wants each country to negotiate its own greenhouse gas emission target based on national circumstances, including its level of fossil-fuel dependence.
Howard said meeting the EU or Japanese targets is "simply not achievable without enormous economic costs for Australia."
But greenhouse groups and foreign economists claim Australia could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 20 percent without causing significant economic hardship.
The United States, considered to be the key player, is finalizing its climate-change target.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WELCOMES FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN ITS FINANCIAL MARKETS

TEXT.P: Australia's Federal Treasurer Peter Costello has encouraged foreign individuals and institutions to invest in the country's financial markets, brushing aside the current chaos of financial markets in Thailand, Malaysia and other Asian countries.

In response to a comment by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir that currency speculation should be banned, Costello has moved to isolate the Australian financial markets from the chaos in Asian markets.
He assured potential investors that Australia is very different from its Asian counterparts.
Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia have all suffered substantial falls in their share and currency markets during the last six months.

"We in Australia think that financial markets work best when they are open. We have a freely traded currency, we do not impose capital controls, we have a financial environment which encourages investment and we think that's important for our economic growth," he said.
"We will be working very hard to take ... measures which will encourage people to use Australia as a financial base," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIALS TO VISIT GERMANY AND FRANCE

TEXT.P: Leaders from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Taiwan's major opposition party, are leaving for Europe later this week to "continue on the party's diplomacy track" laid down earlier this year, DPP sources said on Tuesday.

DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, who is scheduled to leave for Germany on Wednesday, will attend the "Berlin Meeting" on Thursday, along with leaders of political parties from over 20 countries. The meeting is being organized by the Friedrich-Naumann Foundation under Germany's opposition Free Democratic Party (FDP).

Hsu will then be joined by DPP Department of Information Director Sissy Chen in Bonn, where they will meet with officials from the FDP and another opposition party, the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD).

In addition to further enhancing exchanges with Germany's opposition parties, the DPP delegation will meet representatives from Germany's private sector to gain an understanding of German enterprises' experience in domestic policy, the sources said.

They will also meet with the German Federal Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth, for an overview of the German welfare system, particularly as it relates to child care and welfare.

After spending six days in Germany, Hsu and Chen will proceed to Paris for a four-day visit, when they will meet with French government officials and party and business leaders to discuss political issues such as child care and nuclear waste management technology.

Hsu said he is interested in studying the transformation of major foreign political parties, as well as the operations of coalition cabinets in other countries. He has previously advocated the formation of a coalition cabinet in the ROC, comprising officials from both the ruling Kuomintang and the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SEEKS TAIWAN'S SUPPORT IN ELECTRONIC TRADE LIBERALIZATION

TEXT.P: Donald Phillips, assistant to the United States Trade Representative, on Tuesday urged Taiwan to support the liberalization of the electronic business and agricultural biotechnology industries.

Phillips made the request while calling on ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu. He arrived here on Monday for a one-day visit seeking ROC support at a ministerial meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which will take place in November.

The US official said that with the expanding development of the Internet, a worldwide information and telecommunications network, trade and commercial activities on the Internet -- commonly defined as electronic business -- are expected to play a key role in the world's economic development during the 21st century.
Accordingly, Phillips voiced the US hope that a comprehensive package aimed at promoting tariff-free global electronic trade can be raised at the upcoming APEC conference.

He also conveyed Washington's hope that Taiwan, one of the 18 APEC member-countries, will raise the issue of the importance of biotechnology in the agricultural industry at the APEC meeting, which will be held in Tokyo.

According to Phillips, the US also hopes that Taiwan will lend its support to the liberalization of the chemistry, medical equipment and service sectors, the automobile industry, the communication and information technology industry, the energy industry, the environmental protection industry and the timber industry.

Sources at the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that Taiwan has agreed to support the issue of electronic trade, as well as reaching a consensus with the US on the liberalization of the environmental protection sector.
Phillips will leave Taiwan on Tuesday for a tour of seven other Asian APEC economies, including Singapore, Thailand, Macau and Japan, to seek their support.

The 18 APEC members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MISSING AFTER OIL TANKER BLAST

TEXT.P: Two maintenance workers have been reported missing following an explosion on the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) oil tanker Chang Yun at around 9:30 a.m. Tuesday just outside the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung.

The explosion ignited a blaze which took nearly five hours to bring under control and caused extensive damage to the tanker. None of the 22 crew and 11 other maintenance workers aboard were injured, according to a CPC spokesman.

The cause of the blast was not immediately known and an investigation is under way, said CPC Deputy General Manager Chiu Chi-hsiung, who added that the accident is unlikely to affect CPC's crude oil imports or its domestic supplies of oil products.

Although the Chang Yun's cargo of crude oil had been unloaded days before the vessel underwent routine checks and maintenance, the explosion is causing a certain degree of environmental damage, as residual crude can be seen leaking into the surrounding water.
The 220,000-ton tanker, operated by Yangming Marine Transport, was launched in 1981 and the CPC may now decide to retire the 16-year old carrier, according to Chiu.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON GOVERNMENT'S DEFENSE OF CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Tuesday's edition of local English-language daily the China News.
Market Forces Cannot be Denied
The government has made an honorable... gesture by offering its help to Southeast Asian economies beset by currency crises and general economic problems.

But... Taiwan's government should refrain from adopting the kind of rhetoric that Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has brought into vogue. Speculators are not the prime cause of Southeast Asia's economic woes at present and neither are they the main forces applying pressure on the NT dollar.
The first myth that needs clearing up is one which holds that huge foreign currency reserves are all that is needed to prop up a currency.

A week of attacks like the one experienced last Friday -- when US$1.2 billion was spent in one day by the (Central Bank of China) -- and (Taiwan's US$85 billion) foreign exchange reserves start to look less than impregnable.

This bleak scenario worsens when it is considered that no one... will come to Taiwan's aid if those reserves eventually dry up. The International Monetary Fund (of which Taiwan is not a member), will certainly not throw the island a lifeline the way it did with Thailand.
The second misconception needing to be addressed is that a devalued currency is a sign of weakness in an economy and should be avoided at all costs.
Chained to a currency that is so much more expensive to buy than its Southeast Asian export-oriented rivals, prices for Taiwan products in the world's major consumer markets will be unattractive.

...they (Southeast Asian states) were wrapped up in the belief that a greenback-linked currency is a good currency. As a result, many were caught off-guard by changing market forces, having grown comfortable with the assurance of stable exchange rates. Taiwan needs to realize... that it cannot insulate itself forever from world currency trends through a de facto link to the US dollar.
To be sure, the people likely to be worst affected by the devaluation are those who have been lulled into a false sense of security and have not bothered to plan strategically.
As long as the basics are sound, then Taiwan has nothing to worry about.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MALAYSIA DISCUSS `OPEN SKY' PACT

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and Malaysia met Tuesday in Taipei for talks on easing aviation restrictions and gradually liberalizing mutual controls based on existing frameworks in order to reach an "open sky" goal.

After a fruitful one-day discussion, the two sides reached consensus on completely liberalizing flight frameworks in both countries, agreeing to allow Taiwan airline companies to fly to any destination in Malaysia from any Taiwan airport, and vice versa.

The two sides also agreed that the number of flights between Taiwan and Malaysia will be unlimited and that the number of cross-continental extension flights will initially be increased to 12 per week. These weekly extension flights will be increased to 14 in 1998 and further increased to 17 in 1999, according to an official from Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).

Another meeting will be held before the end of 1999 to review the progress of the cooperative agreement and if all goes smoothly, the two sides may then consider completely opening their skies to each other, the official said.

From the point of view of local airlines, Tuesday's discussion will result in added flights to Malaysia for China Airlines and EVA Airways, the two Taiwan airline companies which operate international flight services, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION AGING FAST

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population, which currently stands at over 21 million, is aging fast, official statistics show.

A nation is considered an aged society when more than 7 percent of its people are over 65 years old, according to criteria set by the United Nations. Taiwan has been an aging society since 1993, when 7.1 percent of its population exceeded 65 years of age.

In 1986, those over 65 made up 5.22 percent of the Taiwan population, a percentage which had risen to 6.16 percent in 1990, 7.1 percent in 1993 and 7.6 percent in 1995. It will grow even faster in the 21st century, manpower researchers at the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) forecast.

The researchers said the aging of Taiwan's population has occurred faster than in many other countries, due principally to the post-World War II baby boom and the drastic fall in birth rates in recent years.
In addition, because more and more women today are entering the job market and in order to have more leisure time, many married couples now prefer to have fewer children or no children at all.

Improvements in living standards and better medical care now mean that the average life-span in Taiwan has been steadily increasing during the past decade. Recently released statistics indicate that average life expectancy here has now reached, 71.81 years for men and 77.76 for women.
This figure, although lower than the 79 years a Japanese person can expect to live, is still among the highest in Asia, representing an increase of more than 25 years since 1945.

A CEPD estimate indicates that the increase in the number of people aged 65 or over will be around 55,000 annually from 1996 to 2000, comprising 8.4 percent of the population. From 2010 to 2025, this annual increase will jump to 124,000, or roughly 16.5 percent of the population.

At present, one in every nine people in Taiwan is over 65, but by 2025, the ratio is expected to be one in five of the population. This means that while each citizen over 65 is currently being supported by eight working persons, by 2025, only four working people will have to provide support for one senior citizen, the CEPD predicted.

The increasing average life-span also means there will be more centenarians in Taiwan in the next century. There are currently 583 people in Taiwan who are over 100 years old, but this number will increase to over 1,000 by 2004 and exceed 5,000 by 2030, according to CEPD estimates. (H.C.M.)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACCUSED OF COLONIALISM

TEXT.P: Mainland China, which in past decades was at the forefront of the global struggle for decolonization, is today itself a colonial power, according to a report to the United Nations in Geneva on Monday.

The report from the international Mission Investigating Colonialism in Tibet, which visited Tibet, Nepal and India in April and May this year, analyzes for the first time the criteria of colonialism and examines mainland China's rule in Tibet. The report concludes that Tibet displays all the characteristics of a colonial territory.

"Not only is the form of administration and the use of the military to suppress dissent typical of colonial rule, but all of China's policies on culture, language, development and the undercurrents of racism are so obviously colonial," according to Prof. Cees Flinterman, one of the mission members. He also stated that the population transfer of mainland Chinese into Tibet, a key element of colonialism in the past, is today threatening the very survival of the Tibetan people.
The mission was organized by the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization, in association with the Tibet Support Group of the Netherlands and the International Campaign for Tibet.

DOC.HEADLINE: 391 PEOPLE DEAD IN INDONESIAN DROUGHT

TEXT.P: The number of deaths in Irian Jaya resulting from the current drought has reached 391 over the past few days, while thousands continue to starve and suffer the ravages of cholera and other drought-related diseases.

The new total of victims was reported during a meeting of a number of international organizations under the supervision of the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) on Sunday in the town of Wamena, the capital of Jayawijaya regency in Irian Jaya.
The meeting took place to discuss which types of assistance would best meet the needs of the suffering people in the region.
The spokesman said most of the deaths were caused by a lack of food and water, rather than by epidemics, although diarrhea, malaria and parasitic worms were also taking a toll.

He said that medical and food supplies are being flown in to prevent more deaths, but added that relief efforts are being hampered by difficult terrain and the haze from the many forest fires in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE AND DRUG DEALERS IN FATAL SHOOT-OUT

TEXT.P: Two people, a police officer and a suspected drug trafficker, were killed and one suspect and an officer were wounded in a fierce gunfight in a southern Taiwan city on Tuesday.
The shoot-out took place on Tuesday afternoon in Hsinhua, Tainan County, when five local policemen, acting on a tip-off, raided the hideout of alleged drug dealers and encountered two suspects.

The suspects, who were later identified as Hsieh Hsing-kuei and Liang Chih-tsai, opened fire on police while the officers were conducting body searches on the two, hitting officer Huang Ping-jeng in the chest and wounding officer Sun Fu-min. Huang died later at a local hospital, while Sun was listed as stable.
Hsieh was killed instantly when the other policemen returned fire, while Liang was wounded.

Ting Yuan-ching, director general of the National Police Administration, sent his condolences to the families of the dead and wounded policemen upon hearing of the incident and instructed the local police chief to take good care of them.
He also called on police nationwide to exercise maximum care while carrying out their duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-KOREA TRADE FRICTION GROWS

TEXT.P: Trade friction between the US and South Korea has escalated as Seoul warned that it would file a complaint with the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) if Washington imposes sanctions over car imports, according to reports from the world trade body on Tuesday.
The threat came after the US put South Korea on a priority list for possible sanctions within the next 18 months unless Seoul removes alleged car trade barriers.

Seoul claims that a decision by the US to impose sanctions unilaterally under its "Super 301" trade provisions will violate WTO rules. But the Seoul Foreign Ministry expressed optimism that the issue is likely to be solved through negotiations over the next 18 months. Other recent trade disputes, including telecom equipment and protection of intellectual property rights, have already been solved.
South Korea is trying to reach a fair compromise on the car issue "amid the ever-rising trade deficit with the US and difficult domestic economic conditions," the WTO report said.

The US complains that tariffs combined with complex customs and testing procedures limit US car sales to less than 1 percent of the Korean car market, Asia's second-largest. Total foreign car sales amount to 1.5 percent of the market.

The Korean government offered in recent negotiations to ease import procedures, but said it could not unilaterally agree to a US demand to lower the tariff on imported cars to 2.5 percent from 8 percent because this needed parliamentary approval.

Although Korea agreed in 1995 to impose a uniform tax on domestic and foreign cars, Korean vehicles still enjoy a price advantage because the taxes are imposed on a higher basic rate for foreign cars due to the tariff.
Seoul says that foreign car sales have remained sluggish, despite the 1995 accord that was meant to open the market, because an economic slowdown has resulted in a big fall in domestic car sales.

Some Korean MPs accuse the US of trying to destabilize the Korean car industry at a time when it is already suffering severe problems, with the nation's third-largest carmaker, Kia, on the brink of collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES TO COLLECT MONEY FOR INVESTING IN LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) and president of the giant President Group, is mobilizing local industrial and commercial enterprises to help establish a company which will invest in Central America.

The move comes in the wake of President Lee Teng-hui's September Latin American trip, on which he was accompanied by Kao and many local heavyweight entrepreneurs, including Wang You-theng, chairman of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce, and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.
Kao told the press on Tuesday that during the tour, they saw many trade opportunities in the region, which is seen as a business springboard into North American markets.

Kao said that he therefore plans to raise a total of NT$1 billion (US$34.965 million) to set up the Central America investing company, through which the group will be able to make comprehensive investments in the production of daily necessities in the region, where many goods essential to daily life, such as foodstuffs, have to be imported.

Kao indicated that one of the President Group affiliates, the President Enterprise Corp., has already decided to invest in the planned company, while the Sino-Japan Group has also expressed willingness to participate in the project.

Meanwhile, Kao noted that in order to encourage more local businesses to participate in the Latin American market, the CNFI will hold a workshop on the issue here on Wednesday, which will be attended by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and several foreign trade officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRY\COMMERCE SECTORS' ENERGY CONSUMPTION INCREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's energy supplies in the first seven months of this year increased by 3.4 percent to 49.71 million kiloliter oil equivalents (KLOEs) from last year, with consumption in the industry and commerce sectors posting the biggest annual increase of 7.4 percent, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The figures also show that oil accounted for 25.64 million KLOEs, or 51.6 percent of the total energy consumed, representing a decline of 1.3 percent from the same period of last year, while coal made up 14.36 million KLOEs, or 28.9 percent of the total, representing a rise of 12 percent.
Recorded consumption of other energy sources include nuclear power, at 5.25 million KLOEs, liquefied petroleum gas, at 2.57 million KLOEs and hydroelectric power, at 1.39 million KLOEs.

Taiwan consumed 42.8 million KLOEs of energy in the January-July period, an increase of 4.3 percent from the same period of last year, with an average consumption of 2.016 KLOEs per person, according to the DGBAS.
The island depended on imports for 95.9 percent of its energy in the same period, said the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT SHOULD HANDLE TAIWAN STRAIT PROBLEM: SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said the forthcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin should address the "problem of the Taiwan Strait," there being no such thing as the "Taiwan problem."

Siew made the comment in response to questions at the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday. He indicated that the security and stability of the whole region hinges on the development of the "problem of the Taiwan Strait."

Jiang's upcoming state visit to Washington in late October has caused much concern here in Taipei. Hau Lung-bin, legislator of the opposition New Party, demanded Taipei authorities be well prepared for how the Clinton-Jiang summit's dealings with the "Taiwan problem" could affect the island, so that Taipei's interests won't be damaged.

In response to Hau's question, Siew said, "We don't think there is any 'Taiwan problem.' There is only the 'Taiwan Strait problem,' which is the key to the security and stability of the whole region. Therefore, we hope it is Washington's understanding that the security of the whole region should be the subject of the summit."

Siew stressed Taipei has informed Washington through various channels that the United States should not engage mainland China at the expense of the interests between Taipei and Washington, adding that Washington has expressed repeatedly that the United States won't do so.
"Washington's policy toward the Republic of China is legally bound by the Taiwan Relations Act. Washington should adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act and other commitments to Taipei," Siew added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY-DEVELOPED NEURAL NET ICS SAID QUICKER AND CHEAPER

TEXT.P: A set of three neural net chips newly developed by a company in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park can reportedly help some applications run up to 100 times faster and yet will cost less than chips from Intel.

The neural net ICs -- NN1, NN2 and NN3 -- developed by Elan Microelectronics Corp. (EMC) have been successfully used in fingerprint identification systems, where they have worked 100 times faster than other models, according to EMC President Yeh I-hau.

Assisted by the Hsinchu Park Administration's Innovative High-Tech R&D Project, EMC collaborated with Startek Engineering Corp., another Hsinchu-based company that produces fingerprint identification and other security systems, to develop the "faster and cheaper" identification chips.

The newly developed ICs, said Yeh, have more neurals and neural weights (memory chips responsible for transmitting signals among neurals), making them capable of responding and calculating faster and giving them greater fault tolerance capacities.
The neural net chips would also work well in a wide range of applications, including automobile electronic locks, imaging identification, robotic arms, and other door security systems, Yeh noted.

Like the rest of the companies in Hsinchu Park, more than one-third of EMC's staff are holders of master degrees or higher. A total of 80 percent of EMC's 150 employees are working in research and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rebounded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 34.47 points to finish at 8,255.82.
The bourse opened at 8,285.89, and experienced a high of 8,325.61 and a low of 8,204.91.
Gainers outnumbered losers 220 to 155, with 84 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.74 billion (US$3.3 billion).

Among the eight stock categories, electrical engineering shares surged the most at 1.3 percent, ahead of a 0.6 percent rose by paper and pulp shares, 0.2 percent by textile stocks, and 0.1 percent by cement, foodstuff and plastic and chemical issues, respectively.
Construction stocks declined 0.5 percent, and financial issues remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, A.S.E., Macronix International, Winbond Electronics, Chuntex Electronic, ACER, Mosel Vitelic, China Steel and Siliconware Precision Industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SERIOUS ATTITUDE SHOULD BE TAKEN IN OPENING CROSS-STRAIT DEADLOCK

TEXT.P: The two sides across the Taiwan Strait -- Taiwan and mainland China -- should start to seriously think over the problems that will emerge following the resumption of cross-strait talks, a Taiwan heavyweight in mainland affairs has said.

Chiao Jen-ho, secretary-general and vice chairperson of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the remarks on Tuesday at a conference on cross-strait relations also attended by Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), and several scholars in the field.
The Republic of China authorities founded the SEF six years ago to deal with cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links.

Chiao stressed that now is still not the best moment for the two sides to talk about disputed political issues, adding that he thinks Beijing should make more efforts to gain the trust of Taiwan people, while Taipei should seriously prepare topics for the talks, which could be helpful for the further development of cross-strait links.

Wu said that his council is already engaged in drawing up timetables and issues for cross-strait talks under the government's principles for developing Taipei-Beijing relations, which he said include enhancing cross-strait exchanges and conducting dialogues practically.

The official also ruled out Taiwan and mainland China restarting communication -- which was closed unilaterally by Beijing in 1995 to protest ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to his US alma mater -- through political talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZI KING REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO ROC

TEXT.P: King Mswati III of Swaziland reaffirmed his commitment to the Republic of China here on Wednesday, saying that even though Swaziland's closest neighbor -- South Africa -- will switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing later this year, his country will continue to strengthen its relationship with the ROC.
The king made the statement at a news conference which marked the end of a six-day state visit to Taiwan.
Mswati told the press that during his stay in Taiwan, he discussed with President Lee Teng-hui several cooperative projects which are expected to bear fruit in the near future.

He also said South Africa's imminent switch of diplomatic allegiance will not affect Swaziland's longstanding relations with the ROC, even though Swaziland maintains close tariff and trade ties with South Africa. "Pretoria cannot represent all southern African countries and is not in a position to decide which countries Swaziland should recognize."
Earlier in the day, Mswati and President Lee signed a joint communique at the Presidential Office, reaffirming their commitment to further reinforcing bilateral cooperative ties.

The communique said the two leaders have exchanged views on the general world situation and have discussed many possible bilateral cooperative projects, adding that the ministers of foreign affairs of the two countries will sign a formal agreement to define the scope of the various cooperative projects.

Mswati said in the communique that he was impressed by the ROC's progress in economic development and political democratization. He also expressed his gratitude for all the assistance the ROC has extended to his country in agricultural development, small- and medium-sized enterprises, infrastructure construction, medical services and other related fields over the years.

The Swazi king also reaffirmed his country's unswerving support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the UN and other major international organizations, saying he is convinced that the ROC can make even greater contributions to world peace and prosperity if it is given the opportunity to take part in major world organizations and activities.

Mswati, who had voiced his support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations in a speech to the UN General Assembly debate before coming to Taipei, said he thinks the ROC should continue to seek a seat in the UN so that its voice can be heard in the international community.

For his part, President Lee said in the communique that the ROC appreciates Swaziland's firm support for the ROC's stance in the world arena. He also promised that the ROC will continue to assist the southern African kingdom with its economic development.

Following the press conference, President Lee presided over a military ceremony to bid farewell to the king, who is scheduled to travel to the Scottish capital of Edinburgh, where he will attend an annual summit of the British Commonwealth of Nations.
Prior to his departure, Mswati viewed a rehearsal of a variety of dancing and acrobatic performances to be given on Oct. 10 to celebrate the ROC's Double Ten National Day.
Mswati arrived in Taipei last Friday. While here, he underwent a physical checkup at National Taiwan University Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC BECOMES FIRST TAIWAN FIRM TO BE LISTED ON NYSE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), the world's largest semiconductor foundry service company, will be formally listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Wednesday (US time), sources from Wall Street reported on Tuesday.

The listing makes TSMC the first Taiwan company to offer shares on the NYSE in the prestigious stock market's 205-year history and also the first microchip processor in Asia ever to receive approval for listing on the NYSE, the sources noted.

Some 130 million shares of TSMC stocks released through American Deposit Receipts (ADR) by Dutch electronics group Philips, one of major share holders of TSMC, will be offered for trading. Underwriters of the stocks will include Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sach and Robertson Stephen.
The stocks, to be listed as TSM, are expected to see an opening price of US$25.5 per share, said the sources who preferred to remain anonymous.

If all TSM stocks sell out smoothly, Philips' shares in TSMC will be reduced from 31 percent to 29.5 percent. In a recent major move, Philips announced the release of one billion TSMC shares, in a drive to raise money to help finance other parts of its worldwide operations.

To welcome TSMC's joining the world's largest stock market, NYSE executives will host a reception on the first day of listing in honor of TSMC Chairman Chang Chung-mo and other officials. Wu Tzu-dan, director of Taiwan's Economic and Cultural Representative Office in New York, will also be present at the reception.

The NYSE currently lists more than 3,000 companies, only 340 of which are foreign corporations. Canadian companies top the foreign list with 62. By comparison, eight mainland Chinese companies have been approved to be listed since 1993, and nine from Hong Kong.

According to NYSE regulations, any foreign company applying for NYSE listing must have accumulated pre-tax business turnover exceeding US$1 billion during the last three years, with annual turnover of no less than US$250 million during the period.

In addition, foreign companies must have global assets reaching US$1 billion and the value of its publicly-issued corporation stocks must not be lower than US$1 billion. It should have more than 5,000 shareholders and the volume of the shares not concentrated (SNC) should total at least 2.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK CHIEF EXECUTIVE'S POLICY ADDRESS PREVIEWED BY LI PENG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) delivered his first policy address before the Provisional Legislative Council here on Wednesday afternoon, in which he outlined his plans to lead Hong Kong into the 21st century.
Informed sources said the speech was first delivered to mainland China's Premier Li Peng to be previewed.

During British colonial rule in Hong Kong, its governors delivered an annual policy address each October and this tradition has been maintained by the leadership of the HKSAR which was established on July 1 this year.
Since Tung's address will reflect the direction of the HKSAR government in the near future and into the next century, it has attracted a great deal of attention both in Hong Kong and abroad.

Local interest is focused mainly on Hong Kong's housing policy, as a shortage of housing and skyrocketing prices in Hong Kong's realty market are creating serious problems for the people there and Tung claims to be committed to resolving this problem.
The other main areas of local interest are the HKSAR's future education and welfare policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF TAIWAN'S HIGH-TECH INDUSTRY SURGING

TEXT.P: The annual production value of Taiwan's high-tech industrial sector is increasing as a result of efforts to upgrade industrial level, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Latest DGBAS statistics show that Taiwan's output of high-tech products was worth approximately US$93.2 billion last year, marking a 1.2-fold growth from the year-earlier-level.

The figure accounted for 42.3 percent of the total production value of Taiwan's entire manufacturing sector, up 14.9 percentage points from the 1986 level and up 9.5 percentage points from 1991, while exports of high-tech products reached US$53.1 billion in 1996, up 18.2 percentage points from a year ago.

The high-tech industry produces goods with high added-value and is characterized by complex and complicated manufacturing processes and high-quality human resources, enjoying a high ratio of capital invested in research and development. The chemical, machinery and electric and electronics sectors are included in the high-tech industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CONSIDER SELLING TAIWAN SUBMARINES: US THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The United States should revise its long-standing refusal to sell Taiwan conventional submarines or at least should not stand in the way of other countries, such as Russia and the Netherlands, trying to sell the island submarines in view of Beijing's efforts to acquire supersonic anti-ship missiles, an expert at the Heritage Foundation said Tuesday.

Richard Fisher, a senior policy analyst at the conservative think tank, told a Heritage Foundation panel discussion that the mainland Chinese navy is buying from Russia the supersonic Moskit anti-ship missiles to which ships not covered by the US AEGIS system are vulnerable.

In addition, Fisher said, Beijing is reportedly purchasing the even more frightening Yakhont anti-ship cruise missile, which is now just entering production in Russia. The Yakhont has a wider range than the Moskit and can be fitted into more ships and air platforms.

Fisher said that Beijing's acquisition of these supersonic missiles puts greater pressure on the United States not only to develop better anti-ship defenses, such as laser-based anti-missile defenses for ships, but also to consider revising its long-standing refusal to sell submarines to Taiwan.
"If we cannot develop adequate defenses to go after these new missiles," he went on, "then we have to consider selling Taiwan the ability to go after the platforms carrying these missiles."

He said that the United States should at least not stand in the way of other countries trying to sell conventional submarines to Taiwan or should even encourage other countries to sell Taiwan submarines in order to deter the mainland navy's new missiles.
Fisher warned that Beijing's increasing access to foreign weapons and technology from Russia, Israel and Europe is posing a threat to US interests in Asia.

He said that Beijing has made it clear that it wants Taiwan unified under its terms, wants to control the resources and sea lanes in the South China Sea, wants to sell more weapons in the international market and is increasingly uncomfortable with the US security alliance network in Asia.

If Beijing had a more modern and more effective military, he said, it would use it to buttress its diplomatic and political activities to achieve those goals. However, he added, it is clearly in the US interest to sustain the survival of Taiwan's democracy and freedom of the sea in the South China Sea, stem the sale of advanced weapons to rogue states, and maintain America's powerful position in Asia.

Therefore, he said, the United States should take up the issue with US friends and allies that are selling Beijing modern technology. "If the US keeps this problem under the hat," he said, "who is going to take our complaints seriously?"
