DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA MAY ATTACK US FORCES

TEXT.P: Mainland China's acquisition of weapons from Russia does not imply a serious threat to the United States, but it does raise the specter of a Beijing emboldened enough to do something very foolish, such as attacking Taiwan in a fit of pique, a retired rear admiral of the US Navy said on Tuesday.

Speaking at a panel discussion held by the Heritage Foundation, Eric McVadon expressed the fear that the mainland Chinese military, with its newly acquired Russian weapons, may even launch missiles and torpedoes at US aircraft carriers because of its frustration at US intervention in the conflict between Taiwan and mainland China.

McVadon said mainland China wants to obtain the capability to cope with US weapons systems, but is having a difficult time assimilating the foreign technology it acquires. For example, its aircraft industry is still struggling to integrate Israeli, Russian and European technologies into its J-10 indigenous fighter.

In addition, it still lacks the capability of in-flight refueling, while the Kilo-class submarines bought from Russia have become a problem rather than a panacea for the mainland Chinese navy, he said.

In McVadon's view, although the mainland Chinese military still has a long way to go to achieve modernization, the real concern is what they can do to "make Taiwan kowtow, and to create confusion, indecision, uncertainty and delay" among the military and political leaderships in Washington and possibly in Tokyo.

He believes that mainland China's acquisition of weapons is most usefully, if not solely, measured in relation to its ability to intimidate and defeat Taiwan and to deter, defeat or deflect US intervention.
"They want to be able to keep Taiwan under their thumb and to be left alone to do so," McVadon said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22 COUNTRIES VOICE SUPPORT FOR ROC'S UN BID AT UN DEBATE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 22 countries lent their support to the Republic of China's bid to rejoin the United Nations at this year's UN General Assembly debate, which started on Sept. 22 and ended on Oct. 7.
Nineteen of those countries are diplomatic allies of the ROC, while the other three -- Fiji, Jordan and Papua New Guinea -- are not.

This was the least support the ROC has received since it began promoting its UN bid five years ago. In 1993, 24 countries gave either explicit or indirect support for ROC UN representation. The number increased to 26 in 1994, 29 in 1995 and declined slightly to 28 last year.

Wu Tzu-dan, director general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said the number does not necessarily fully reflect the effect of the ROC's recent promotional activities. "Substance is more important," he said.

Wu pointed out that after five years of effort, the ROC's UN bid has become an attention-getting topic in the world body and that many UN members have now come to understand the issue and have expressed sympathy for the ROC's position. Looked at from this angle, Wu said, the ROC's UN drive has in fact made headway.
The ROC currently has 30 diplomatic allies, but four of them -- the Holy See, Nauru, Tonga and Tuvalu -- are not UN members.

While most of its allies explicitly drummed up support for the ROC's UN bid, several allies gave only veiled support or even completely avoided the topic in their speeches to the General Assembly debate this year.
On Tuesday, the last day of the debate session, three countries voiced support for the ROC's UN bid.
Kilroy Genia, Papua New Guinea's foreign minister, said he sees no reason for countries around the world to reject direct contact with Taiwan on economic and trade affairs.
Genia lauded Taiwan as a vibrant, robust economy and trade partner. He also urged Taipei and Beijing to resolve their differences through negotiation in order to maintain peaceful co-existence.
Speaking on the same occasion, Alpian Allen, minister of foreign affairs of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, appealed for world recognition of Taiwan's contribution to global development.

Allen said the people of Saint Vincent highly appreciate all the assistance Taiwan has given to them over the years. He also expressed his hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resume talks to mend their differences.

Meanwhile, Jean Mete-Yapende, minister of foreign affairs of the Central African Republic, urged the UN to uphold the principle of membership universality to facilitate the smooth proceeding of its various work programs. However, he didn't specifically mention the ROC's national title in his address.
The minister of foreign affairs of the West African island nation of Sao Tome and Principe, also an ROC ally, didn't address Tuesday's General Assembly debate session as originally scheduled.
The ROC lost its seat in the UN in 1971 when the world body accepted the communist government in Beijing as the sole representative of the Chinese people.

The UN General Assembly's steering committee on Sept. 17 rejected for a fifth straight year to consider the question of ROC representation. This year's petition, signed by 14 of Taipei's diplomatic allies, called for the re-examination of Resolution No. 2758, which expelled the ROC to make way for mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC REGION NOT YET FREE OF THREATS: PHILIPPINE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Philippine Defense Secretary Fortunato U. Abat Tuesday said that the Asia-Pacific region is not yet free of threats and challenges.
Abat made this assessment in his speech before a meeting of the heads of the defense colleges of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Mandaluyong City.
"For a long time, this area of the world was an arena of not only superpower engagements but also laboratories of surrogate conflicts," the defense chief said.
"These experiences not only exacerbated historical enmities but also created new constituencies who now nurture recently acquired objects of perceived injustices, hates and bitterness," he said.
"Here lies the dangers and challenges," he stressed.

"Although the nations in this part of the world have been organizing to ensure continuity of economic growth in an atmosphere of political stability, geopolitical realities acting in concert with the world order that is still in transition from the Cold War have prevented organizing efforts to assume a comprehensive character," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG BEST FOR NOBEL PEACE PRIZE: DAILY

TEXT.P: In its editorial, "Our Nobel nominee," The Ottawa Citizen said Tuesday that mainland China's leading dissident Wei Jingsheng deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.

The influential Canadian newspaper praised Wei for his courage, even in the face of continuing persecution, to defend his ideals. It was referring to Wei's letters from the prison, titled "The Freedom to Stand Alone," which challenged the repressive powers of Beijing's leadership.

His letters about Deng Xiaoping refer disdainfully (and humorously) to the paramount leader as "the person who is currently making the entire country read his selected writings," according to the Citizen.

Wei dismisses communist chieftains as "the incompetent generation of headstrong old men" and as "degenerate old revolutionaries," descriptions unlikely to get him the early medical parole he has so desperately sought, it added.

His letters include long essays full of advice and simple common sense, such as, "Every person has a share in the fate of his country; one shouldn't think this is the duty of just a few," the editorial pointed out.

The world can make a clear statement about mainland China's double standard on capitalist freedoms and personal freedoms for its own citizens later this week when the Nobel Peace Prize is awarded, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA HELPING US HEAL RIFT WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia is helping the United States heal a rift with Indonesia over US criticisms of human rights abuses by Indonesia in East Timor and elsewhere.

The mass circulation newspaper The Australian reported Wednesday that Australian Prime Minister John Howard and US President Bill Clinton had reached an undisclosed agreement in June to set up top level meetings between officials for a formal exchange of views about Indonesia.

The daily reported Howard's initiative to help the United States heal the rift between Washington and Jakarta was made during his recent visit to Washington after the tensions came to a head when Indonesian President Suharto decided to cancel plans to buy nine F-16 fighters and pull out of US-sponsored military education.
Indonesia is now planning to buy 12 advanced Sukhoi-30K aircraft from Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA IS WORRIED ABOUT LOSING EDUCATIONAL MART TO US, CANADA

TEXT.P: Australia is worried about losing its US$2.2 billion educational market in Asia to its major rivals -- the United States and Canada -- because Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson has become the dampening contributor to one of the country's lucrative sectors.

Leading Australian universities and IDP (International Development Program) Education Australia, a private company engaged in recruiting international students for Australian schools, have downgraded their estimates and warned for the first time that there could be a serious drop in the number of foreign students to Australia this year.
IDP chief executive Denis Blight admitted that the Pauline Hanson-inspired race debate was an "important contributor" to the expected downturn.
He told the IDP's Melbourne conference last week that early warning signs were apparent despite the latest research showing 17 percent growth in the local industry from 1996 to 1997.
The IDP's growth target of 89,000 overseas students studying in Australia by the year 2000 will be very difficult to meet, he said.
Up to early this year, Australia has attracted about 140,000 foreign students since the country started its educational export program in the mid-1980s.
The number of students from Taiwan alone is almost 8,000, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra.
Blight said Australia may be losing some of its educational market share to the United States and Canada in such lucrative and profitable markets as Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore.
The educational exports show "a worsening trend in Taiwan," he said.
He also said that the IDP is predicting a sharp flattening of growth in Malaysia and Thailand and a flattening in Hong Kong. Only Indonesia was listed as a growth target country.
The IDP said it was not possible to identify Australia-specific factors behind the expected slump in its educational exports in major markets in Asia.

"However, it is very difficult to discount the possibility that the debate associated with the activities of Pauline Hanson is an important contributor. We conclude that Australian universities face the prospect of a serious short-term slowing growth in international student enrollments. Ambitious enrollment targets will be difficult to meet," Blight said.
The IDP's rival, the government-run Australian International Education Foundation, recently dismissed concerns the race debate had directly harmed the country's educational export industry.

But the IDP said the damage done by the racial debate triggered by Pauline Hanson was greater than expected because many parents from Taiwan, Korea, Hong Kong and other Asian countries were worried about sending their children to study in Australia.
"Unless we take corrective action, we risk a shortfall in student enrollments in the latter part of this year and in 1998," he said.
The shortfall could mean a substantial slowing in the growth rate or even a reduction in enrollment numbers compared to early 1997, he said.
In order to make up for the loss of students from Taiwan, Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia, Australian universities are now actively promoting themselves in mainland China.
Mainland China's education minister is scheduled to visit Australia on October 20, the first visit in 20 years by a senior mainland educational official to the Down Under.

The Australian Vice Chancellors Committee is negotiating with its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Chinese Educational Association for International Exchange -- on a planned memorandum of understanding (MOU).
Educational officials said the MOU is aimed at substantially improving educational export opportunities, staff and student exchange and research links for Australia.

The mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Wednesday quoted Professor Kee Pookong of the Victoria University of Technology in Melbourne as saying that Australia is well positioned to take advantage of troubled relations between Beijing and Washington by luring mainland Chinese students to the Down Under.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS STILL SEARCHING FOR BLACK BOX

TEXT.P: Strong winds prevented the use of a helicopter to lift parts of the Garuda Airbus plane that crashed 40 km south of Medan, Indonesia 12 days ago.

Antara quoted Dr. Oeterjo Diran, chief of the crash's investigating team, as saying in Medan Tuesday evening that the team needs heavy equipment to lift the plane's wreckage from the muddy valley in order to facilitate the search for the aircraft's black box, a device containing flight data that could throw light on the cause of the crash.
So far, Diran said, rescue workers along with security personnel and local residents have been relying on mattocks to dig the aircraft out of the soil of the smog-shrouded ravine.
Officials from the local office of the Public Works Ministry will visit the crash site Wednesday to study the possibility of deploying heavy equipment to speed up the search, Diran said.
The Airbus A300 B4 plunged into the ravine on September 26 as it was approaching Medan's Polonia airport from Jakarta, killing 222 passengers and the entire 12-member crew.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENCY TURMOIL HAS SLIGHT IMPACT ON SINGAPORE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Singapore's Finance Minister Hu Tsou-Daw said in parliament on Tuesday that the region's currency troubles will have only a "very small immediate impact" on the Singapore economy, although growth might be affected next year if the problem persists.

The Singapore dollar's improved strength over regional currencies will affect Singapore's export competitiveness only if the Malaysian ringgit remains weak and even then, only a certain range of products will be affected, he said.

"Recent indicators show that the Singapore economy is on course to attain a 6 to 7 percent growth in 1997. For 1998, however, growth of total goods and services, particularly tourism, might be weaker, reflecting slower growth and poorer business sentiment in the regional economies," he told parliament.
"In the longer term, the impact will depend on how quickly the regional economies resume their normal growth," he added.
The finance minister pointed out that Singapore has emerged relatively unscathed from the currency crisis because of its strong political and economic fundamentals.
"We have high savings rates, substantial budget surpluses and large foreign exchange reserves. We also have large current account surpluses and strong inflows of direct foreign investment.
"All these are the outcome of prudent fiscal and monetary policies put in place over the years," he said.

By October 3, the Singapore dollar had gained 28.9 percent against the Thai baht, 39.2 percent against the Indonesian rupiah, 19.9 percent against the Malaysian ringgit, and 3.9 percent against the German mark.
At the same time, the Singapore dollar had lost 9.3 percent against the US and Hong Kong currencies, 9.4 percent against the Chinese renminbi and 4.6 percent against the Japanese yen.
"Overall, the Singapore dollar has remained firm against its trade-weighted basket of currencies," he said.
Hu also reiterated that Singapore will continue with its policy of allowing the gradual internationalization of the Singapore dollar.
In line with this policy, Singapore last year increased foreign banks' access to Singapore dollar loans by S$50 million, to S$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE HOPEFUL INDONESIA'S FOREST FIRES WILL BE TAMED

TEXT.P: Singapore is hopeful the forest fires in Indonesia that have shrouded the region in haze will be under control soon and has suggested that ASEAN ministers meet when the present crisis is over to discuss how to prevent a recurrence of the problem.
Singapore's Environment Minister Yeo Cheow Tong told the Singaporean parliament Tuesday that if the Indonesian government translates its words into action, the problem could be overcome soon.
He said he had been in daily telephone contact with his Indonesian counterpart over the past few days.
"Apart from registering our concerns with the Indonesian authorities and urging them to take effective actions to curb the haze problem, we have also offered our cooperation and assistance," he said.
On Monday, he noted, the Singapore Defense Ministry had sent a C-130 aircraft complete with crew and personnel, to release chemicals into the air to help counter the haze in badly-hit areas.

Commenting on the health effects of the haze, Yeo, who is also Health Minister, said particles in the haze irritate the nose, throat, airways, skin and eyes but that these "irritant effects" are mild and posed no danger to the general population.
As for the long-term effects of the haze, he said, Singaporeans are "quite safe" because they have been exposed to it for only short periods.
The Pollution Standards Index, he said, had gone up beyond 100 into the "unhealthy" range on only eight occasions this year, and even then for only short periods.
"It's unhealthy only if you are exposed for 24 hours over many, many years," he said, citing studies done in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR WAFER SUPPLIER TO FORM HI-TECH FIRE-FIGHTING BRIGADE

TEXT.P: A major wafer supplier in Taiwan announced on Wednesday that it will invest NT$1 billion (US$34.84 million) to form a high technology fire-fighting brigade so that it will never experience another fire incident like the one it suffered earlier this month.

Robert Tsao, chairman of United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), made the remarks at a news conference following a fire which broke out on Oct. 2 in a sealed fabrication building belonging to United Integrated Circuit Corp. (UICC), a UMC joint venture company.

Tsao said the fire was not extinguished completely until 5:00 a.m. on Oct. 5, after the fire had raged uncontrollably in the sealed facility for almost 36 hours, totally destroying the equipment inside.
He said the main factor which resulted in such heavy damage was thick smoke that prevented fire fighters from reaching the flames.

The UMC chairman said that the companies belonging to the UMC Group have therefore decided to work together to raise the funds necessary to form a specialized fire-fighting brigade, and will, in the near future, explore the use of the most advanced fire-fighting technology and equipment, especially the technology which allows fire-fighters to tackle blazes with high temperatures and heavy smoke burning out of control in sealed areas.
Tsao said the fire has resulted in losses to UICC estimated at NT$12 billion (US$418 million), but added that because the company is heavily insured, financial losses will be minimal.
Although full reconstruction of the facility will take at least one year, he said profit targets of UMC and UICC will be unaffected.

While awaiting the reconstruction of the UICC facility, the UMC Fab III, United Semiconductor Corp. (USC), and Nanya Technology Corp. will provide 15,000 eight-inch wafers per month to UICC, enabling the company to fulfill its commitments to its joint venture partners and foundry customers over the next year.

Tsao stressed that the fire will not affect the determination of UMC to invest locally. On the contrary, to make up for its losses, it will accelerate the pace of new wafer plant construction and its plan to move into the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park will remain unchanged.

The UMC Group will complete the construction of six wafer manufacturing facilities by 2000 with a monthly production capacity of 200,000 wafers and monthly revenues reaching NT$10 billion (US$348 million).

Tsao also announced that UMC will begin construction of an eight-inch wafer plant in Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park by the year's end, with a total investment of NT$35 billion (US$1.21 billion). The plant is expected to start production in May 1999, with a full capacity of 40,000 wafers per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIGNITARIES CONGRATULATE ROC ON ITS NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Congratulations from foreign dignitaries are streaming in with the approach of the ROC's National Day, known as "Double Tenth" as it falls on the tenth of October, the Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday.

Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman, Burkina Faso President Blaise Conpaore, Tonga's King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV and Tuvalu Governor Tulaga Manuella extended their congratulations to President Lee Teng-hui on the ROC's 86th birthday.

Tuvalu Premier Bikenibeu Paeniu sent his congratulations to his ROC counterpart Vincent Siew and Vice Premier John Chang, while Deputy Speaker of the Angolan parliament Joao Pedro Francisco also extended his congratulations to John Chang.

In the United States, senators John McCain, Jeff Bingaman and Pete Domanici and representatives Ed Royce, Lucille Roybal-Allard, Dana Rohrabacher, Jay Kim, George E. Brown, Jr., Bill Thomas, James Rogan, Ed Pastor, Matt Salmon, John Shadogg, Brian Bilbray, Bob Filner, and Randy Duke Cunningham sent their congratulations.

California Gov. Pete Wilson, Arizona Gov. Jane Dee Hull, New Mexico Gov. Gary Johnson, and Guam Gov. Carl T.C. Gutierrez, and Los Angeles, Phoenix, and other several US cities either sent letter of congratulations or dedicated Oct. 10 to be the ROC's birthday in their states or cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PM WILL VISIT SAUDI ARABIA IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto will begin a two-day official visit to Saudi Arabia on Nov. 8 in response to an invitation from King Fahd.
During the visit, Hashimoto will meet King Fahd and confer with a number of Saudi officials on key bilateral and international issues as well as other subjects.

A statement by the Royal court said the visit comes in the framework of promoting the economic relations and friendship between the two countries in the light of Japan's global importance in the economic and political arenas.
According to the Japanese Embassy here, Japan imports 20 percent of its oil needs from Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE LAUNCHES ONE-STOP CENTER FOR A SECURE NET

TEXT.P: Singapore has launched a one-stop center to prevent, detect and resolve online security breaches to help boost electronic commerce over the Internet.
The move was announced by Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Lee Yock Suan at the opening of the Comdex Asia '97 information technology exhibition in Singapore on Tuesday.
SingCert -- the Singapore Computer Emergency Response Team -- will coordinate emergency responses to security-related incidents that arise in Singapore.
It is a joint effort between the National Computer Board and the National University of Singapore.

SingCert will be manned by computer security experts who will respond to breaches of security through a hotline and e-mail. The entire local information technology (IT) industry and its users can access the service free of charge.
SingCert "is expected to give the industry confidence in deploying services over the Internet and Singapore ONE," Minister Lee said.
Speaking at the opening ceremony of the Comdex Asia exhibition, he disclosed that Singapore was "working on the policy and legal framework for IT commerce, on standardization and IT security."
He also said Singaporeans' response to the Singapore ONE (One Network for Everyone) multimedia network launched in June this year had exceeded expectations.

By the end of this month, some 2,000 households and businesses will have been connected to Singapore ONE. With the positive response, he said, "we will easily reach our target of 5,000 households and businesses by the end of the year."
"With this and other measures, we aim to develop Singapore as the IT hub of this region," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FRIENDS ASKED TO HELP ROC SOLVE PROBLEMS WITH M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and Australian politicians and government officials who are friendly to the Republic of China were asked Wednesday to help the ROC solve its problems with mainland China in order to realize "the dream of one reunited China."

In her speech marking the Double Tenth National Day, Maggie Tien, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Sydney, said: "We believe that our Australian friends will generously assist in fostering the environment conducive to peaceful solution of issues between the ROC and the PRC, such as having them work together on international occasions as equal members of international organizations."
She also urged overseas Chinese to "make concerted efforts towards ushering in the day of "one free and democratic China."

Speaking to about 500 overseas Chinese representatives and Australian friends at the Wentworth Hotel in downtown Sydney, Tien said: "The dream of one reunited China can only come true under the principles of freedom, democracy and equal wealth."

She took the opportunity to call on mainland China "to face the reality that China today is split into two political entities equally exercising exclusive jurisdiction on two separate Chinese territories, i.e. the mainland and Taiwan."
She also asked China to "stop all the moves aimed at suffocating Taiwan's international space and its efforts to make contributions to our region and to the world."
Tien said the Hong Kong model cannot be applied on Taiwan for the eventual reunification with mainland China.

"One can draw no parallel between Hong Kong and Taiwan and no way can the so-called Hong Kong model be applied on Taiwan," because the ROC has existed since the late Dr. Sun Yat-sen overthrew the Ching Dynasty and set up the first republic in Asia in 1912.

Tien said the price of founding the ROC was dear and the people and government of the ROC will continue to safeguard their hard-earned freedom and democracy along with other peace-loving and democratic countries.
"We are all aware that only with peace and freedom, can stability, development and prosperity be ensured in our region as well as the whole world," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX REVENUE UP, STOCK TRANSACTION TAX REVENUE DOWN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance said Wednesday that net tax revenue in September amounted to NT$126.1 billion (US$4.39 billion), up 24.4 percent from the same month last year.

Statistics also showed that stock transaction tax revenue was NT$8.5 billion in September, up 181.9 percent from September 1996. However, the amount was the lowest single-month total since March this year.

It was also a sharp decline of 54 percent from the stock transaction tax revenue of NT$13.1 billion in August, indicating that the turnover on the domestic stock market is not as brisk as it had been for the past several months.

As of the end of September, net tax revenue for the current fiscal year stood at NT$357.4 billion, up 21.6 percent from the same period last year, accounting for 26.9 percent of the overall target for fiscal year 1998, which started on July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.01 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$28.485.
The greenback opened at 28.500 and was traded between 28.460 and 28.510.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$445.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX KMT MEMBERS EXPELLED FOR DEFYING PARTY IN LOCAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Six ruling Kuomintang members who plan to run in the year-end local elections for county and city chiefs against the party's will were expelled Wednesday during a meeting of the KMT's highest decision-making body.
The KMT Central Standing Committee (CSC), in its regular weekly meeting, approved the expulsion of the six members, which had been proposed by the party's Evaluation and Discipline Committee.
The CSC said that it had no recourse but to make the decision because the six members had insisted on contesting the elections against party-sanctioned nominees, despite efforts to dissuade them.

The committee said, however, that if the mavericks have a change of heart and do not officially register their names on the election roster later this month, the expulsion order could be reconsidered in favor of a less severe punishment.

The individuals who were formally stripped of party membership in Wednesday's meeting and the races they intend to contest are: Legislator Lin Jih-jia (for Taipei County magistrate); Keelung City Council Speaker Hsu Tsai-li (Keelung mayor); Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Chiu Ching-chun (Hsinchu County magistrate); Yunlin County Council Speaker Chang Jung-wei (Yunlin County magistrate); Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Hsu Ching-yuan (Taitung County magistrate); and Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Fu Hsueh-peng (Miaoli County magistrate).
Fu Hsueh-peng and Chang Jung-wei had already quit the KMT earlier this month to show their determination to run in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 800 KILOGRAMS OF AMPHETAMINE SEIZED

TEXT.P: Police seized a record 800 kilograms of amphetamine in a raid Wednesday afternoon.

Police estimate that the amphetamine, in liquid form, was the largest seizure of the illegal substance ever by law enforcement authorities in Taiwan. It was estimated to have a street value of at least NT$300 million (US$10.45 million).
Police detained Yeh Tsou-fa in connection with the case and are still tracking other two suspects who remain on the run.

An initial investigation found that Yeh had opened a button-making factory in Chunan township in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan, as a cover for his illegal operation. He had stored the 800 kilograms of amphetamine in 10 large barrels and admitted to distributing the drug throughout the northern part of the island in plastic bottles.
Yeh said that with the price of the drug rising recently, he had sought to produce the substance himself along with other friends for the large profits to be made.
He denied that the liquefied amphetamine seized by police was smuggled from the mainland. The authorities said that they are trying to verify his story.

Police officers were tipped recently that drug traffickers had set up an amphetamine plant in Chunan, which culminated in Wednesday's swoop on the plant. During the raid, they also seized filtering equipment used in producing amphetamine and two remodeled toy guns.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO LOGO TO BE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: Renato Ruggiero, director-general of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), is to officially unveil the logo for the global trade regulatory body on Thursday.

"The adoption of an official logo by the World Trade Organization is another step in establishing this unique institution on a firm and lasting foundation. It is the visual representation of a dynamic organization with a vital role to play in ensuring the continued and rules-based expansion of trade worldwide," Ruggiero said.

The design is adapted from the logo originally commissioned by the Singapore government for the WTO's first ministerial conference which was hosted by Singapore in December 1996. In April 1997, the WTO General Council accepted Singapore's offer to transfer the logo to the WTO along with ownership of its copyright.

The original logo was created by Su Yeang Design, a Singapore-based graphic arts company, and selected from over 200 entries in a competition held by the Singapore government. "A hint of the globe is suggested by the six graphic arcs symbolizing the world trade with member nations meeting to forge strategic alliances," according to Ms. Su Yeang. "Dynamism and optimism prevail as the swirls integrate, encapsulating WTO's united spirit of promoting fair and open trade."

The unveiling ceremony will take place Thursday morning in the reception area at WTO headquarters. Ambassador Celso Lafer of Brazil, chairman of the WTO General Council, Ambassador Chak Mun See of Singapore and Ms. Su Yeang will be present for the presentation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON INCEPTION OF LOCAL-PRINTED AWSJ

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Wednesday's edition of local English-language daily The China Post.
A New Role Model for the Local News Media

Local readers will see the birth of a third English-language newspaper printed locally before the end of this year when the Asian Wall Street Journal will begin printing in Taiwan. The Asian Wall Street Journal (AWSJ)'s publication in Taipei, its seventh printing site in the region ... will be significant in several major ways.

One is that the publication here of the AWSJ will greatly benefit the paper's local readers, as the move will make it possible for it to reach subscribers and newsstand between 8:30 and 10:00 in the morning. In other words, local subscribers will be able to read the paper and get pertinent information at the start of their working day.

The AWSJ's publication here also could help Taiwan increase its financial visibility in the region and the rest of the world. This is because the paper, with its publication in Taiwan, will most likely expand its editorial staff here to step up its coverage of this island.

In terms of editorial content, however, the presence of the AWSJ can be expected to be a role model for the Taiwan press. The AWSJ, since its first entering the Asian market 21 years ago, has been a highly regarded newspaper in the region. The readers of the AWSJ are especially impressed by the paper's investigative-type coverage of news and its writing skills.

Apparently it was the fact that the local media can now enjoy full press freedoms that encouraged the AWSJ to reach the decision to start its publication in Taiwan. Being able to print a publication in an environment free of any political constraints is essential to the flourishing of any news media, and it seems to be especially significant to a newspaper like the Wall Street Journal group, which has always held the principle of freedom as a basic value in journalism.

Being a member of the local media industry, The China Post was pleased to help print and sell the AWSJ in Taiwan as its contracted partner in this country. That the Post decided to render such assistance to the AWSJ is because it believes that the increased role of such a paper will be beneficial to the local media and Taiwan society as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA TO SEEK IMPROVED FOREIGN TIES AFTER KIM'S PROMOTION: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The world can expect to see some changes in North Korea's foreign policy now that Kim Jong-Il has been named general secretary of that country's ruling Workers Party, an expert said here on Wednesday.

The appointment of Kim Jong-Il, son of former North Korean leader Kim Il-Sung, on Wednesday ended a three-year power vacuum in the party. He is expected to use his strengthened position to develop relations with the outside world as part of efforts to improve the communist country's deteriorating economic situation, said Lin Chiu-shan, a member of the Control Yuan and an expert in North Korean affairs.
Kim, 55, has been serving as Pyongyang's supreme military commander and de facto leader since his father's death in 1994.

Lin said that with his promotion to the pinnacle of power, Kim will now seek to enhance relations with arch-rival South Korea, the United States and Japan. However, it will take some time for those efforts to yield results, Lin added.

Lin, who has visited North Korea every year since 1991, said that Taiwan might be one of the targets for North Korea's foreign relations initiative. Pyongyang will seek to promote trade, investment and tourism exchanges with Taiwan as well as the expertise Taiwan can provide in agricultural development, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LEADERS IN URGENT MEETING TO SORT OUT FINANCIAL PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew told Cabinet members in charge of economic and financial affairs Wednesday to stabilize the local currency while holding down soaring interest rates and boosting the plunging bourse, according to a government spokesman.

David Lee, director-general of the Government Information Office, quoted Siew as depicting intervention by the Central Bank of China (CBC) to prop up the value of the New Taiwan Dollar as "a right move" during an urgent meeting called to address financial concerns sparked by an assault against the local currency mounted by foreign speculators.
However, Lee said Siew also asked Finance Minister Paul Chiu to keep a close eye on the bourse and take steps to consolidate the stock market whenever it is disrupted by "irrational factors."

Taiwan stocks have dropped sharply in the past two months with the leading stock price index shedding more than 2,000 points, due in part to attempts by the CBC to prop up the NT dollar by selling off nearly US$ 5 billion over a two-week period. The result has been an increase in the short-term interest rate of inter-bank loans and a depleted cash market.

Spectators' attack on the NT dollar followed a monetary crisis in Southeast Asian countries which has seen the currencies of Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia depreciate more than 20 percent one after another.

It is for this reason, Lee said, that the premier has asked P. K. Chiang , chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, to closely monitor the effects of the Southeast Asian financial crisis on Taiwan's economy, and to take precautionary measures for protecting the island's economic development and financial markets.

Other ministers attending the meeting included Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Justice Minister Liao Chen-hao and State Minister Shirley Kuo. They touted Taiwan's healthy financial and economic situation, which they said would exempt the island from the crisis which has beset its Southeast Asian neighbors, according to Lee.
In a related development, the Ministry of Finance announced a five-point list of urgent measures to strengthen the bourse after the meeting chaired by Premier Siew.

Vice Minister of Finance Wu Chia-sheng told a news conference Wednesday afternoon that the ministry intends to raise the ceiling on the level of foreign investment in the local bourse after consulting the CBC.

The ministry also extended the maximum period for extending loans of both money and stocks by bourse investors from the current six months to one year, a measure aimed at easing fluctuations of the stock market, according to Wu.
Also to be relaxed is the time limit for prospective expatriate stock investors to bring in capital, which will be extended from six months after the date of approval to one year.

The Ministry of Finance vowed to speed up the procedure for approving applications by foreign institutions to invest in the local bourse as well as those by domestic institutions to raise money from overseas sources.

Review by the CBC would be waived for such applications involving capital totaling less than US$50 million. However, the ceiling of US$600 million on cases related to those applications will be maintained under the new measures.

Another shot in the arm announced by the ministry Wednesday is the approval of two mutual funds with a combined capital of NT$13 billion, one each of which will be kept by Pan Asia Bank and the First Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RESPONDS TO AMCHAM DRESSING-DOWN (I)

TEXT.P: No matter how alluring the potential of unrestricted cross-strait trade and investment may be, economic considerations can never override those of national security, Premier Vincent Siew said in a speech to members of the American Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday evening.
Siew also said that Taiwan remains well on course to turn itself into an Asia-Pacific regional operations center (APROC), and that "we are highly optimistic about the outlook for the APROC plan."

In a keynote speech to the AmCham-hosted dinner party marking the ROC National Day which falls on Oct. 10, Siew responded to the AmCham's recent 1997-98 Taiwan White Paper, which cited a number of problem areas, by saying that Taiwan appreciates those comments.
"We have studied them all with great care. Some we feel are well justified, and some without sufficient ground," he said.

As to AmCham's assertion in the white paper that the APROC plan "is now seldom mentioned," and that "the beginning of the second stage on July 1 this year passed virtually unnoticed," Siew politely disagreed.

"Fanfare or not, much of the essential groundwork of the plan has been put in place," Siew pointed out, adding that well over half of the requisite new laws have been passed, with nearly all regulatory amendments already completed.

Important sectors have been opened to foreign investment, including the telecommunications, real estate, oil refining, and power generation industries. The procedures for entry and exit have been substantially simplified. Work permits are much easier to obtain and the validations terms have been extended.

Restrictions on capital movement have been greatly relaxed, with critical ceilings raised to several times their previous levels. Export processing zones have been transformed in line with the shift to high-tech industry. Customs clearance time at seaports has been slashed from seven days to four. The Kaohsiung Offshore Transshipment Center is up and running, with vessels already sailing directly across the Taiwan Strait, he noted.
"Though we may not yet have gotten everything right, I do believe there is a lot that we have gotten right, and much else very nearly so," Siew said.

"We are confident that basically our economy has a suitable engine--well conducted and with plenty of power. We'll go on making the needed adjustments, until that engine is running smoothly on all cylinders, taking us to our APROC destination in the 21st century."

On the AmCham white paper's accusation that Taiwan's tax rates are high, Siew said the Executive Yuan has adopted a proposal to integrate the business income tax with the individual income tax, doing away with double taxation on dividends and cutting the income tax burden on investors by 15 percent.
The "two-in-one" tax policy, expected to come into effect next year, plus the continuing economic liberalization, will undoubtedly raise Taiwan's international competitiveness, he noted.

On Taiwan's relations with archrival mainland China, Siew stressed that no matter how alluring the potential gains of removing all restrictions on cross-strait trade and investment may be, economic considerations can never override the dictates of national security.

Up to now, he said, mainland China has refused to withdraw its threat to use military force against Taiwan. "It has bullied and schemed to keep our 21.6 million people from a presence on the international stage in an effort to marginalize the ROC as one of its provinces.

"In such circumstances, how could our government agree to forging free and unfettered economic links between us? How could we be said to serve the best interests of our citizens if we were irresponsible in such a way? But having said that, I believe that the state of cross-strait relations is rosier than the picture in the white paper," Siew said.
How best to develop relations across the Taiwan Strait is an issue of constant and careful concern for our government, Siew asserted.
(to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM DRESSING-DOWN (II)

TEXT.P: Over the past decade, cross-strait relations have seen progress along the twin tracks of exchange and negotiation, he said.
"By fostering exchanges, we enhance mutual understanding and forge common interests. By pursuing negotiations, we resolve differences and build a stable and friendly relationship."

Though negotiations have been at a halt since June 1995, he said, exchanges have continued to broaden and grow. Taiwan's door has been more widely opened for various categories of visitors from the mainland. Increasingly more of the mainland's products have been approved for import to Taiwan, and the offshore transshipment center plan went into effect earlier this year.
These measures have deepened and widened the economic engagement between the people on either side of the Taiwan Strait, Siew said.

Indeed, it has been the consistent policy of the ROC government to work toward a united China that enjoys democracy, freedom, and social justice and equity. "Our ultimate goal is not only preservation of the security and well-being for our people in Taiwan but also improvement of the lives of our 1.1 billion brothers and sisters on the mainland," he added.

Siew said Taipei has declared many times in the past two years that the ROC remains ready and willing for cross-strait talks to resume, with no preconditions, and has urged that those on the mainland side should again take their places at the negotiating table.

"We therefore welcome the positive response made by (Chinese mainland) President Jiang in September and are hopeful that the Koo-Wang talks and other established channels of negotiations be immediately resumed in the interest of early resolution of all problems related to cross-strait exchanges and other issues of common concern," he added.

The Koo-Wang talks refer to a meeting between the heads of Taipei and Beijing's intermediary bodies in Singapore in April 1993 which set the framework for regular dialogue between the two sides. Those talks were unilaterally suspended by Beijing following ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June 1995.

On partnership with the United States, Siew said, "Whatever the state of our relations with mainland, we cherish our close friendly ties with the United States. The ties between us are numerous and firm."
In the last decade alone, he said, Taiwan's exports to the United States have increased almost 40 percent, while the island's imports have surged nearly fourfold.

Fully one-fifth of Taiwan's total trade has flowed to and from the United States. At present, the most important items of that trade, in both directions, are electronic equipment and machinery, along with their component parts. "It is little surprise that information products figure so prominently in our two-way trade, as America and Taiwan are, respectively, the world's largest and third largest suppliers of information products," he noted.

Some 40 percent of Taiwan's total trade is transacted with the United States, the premier said. The US maintains a substantial surplus in this trade, at about US$5.4 billion annually. That goes a long way toward offsetting Taiwan's own surplus in merchandise trade, he noted.

On the investment front, he said, some US$4.6 billion flowed into Taiwan from the United States between 1986 and 1996. That represented 26 percent of all Taiwan's inward foreign domestic investment, and made the US the second largest foreign investor in this economy.

Those figures speak for themselves. There obviously are strong attractions for US companies to invest in Taiwan. Indeed, AmCham says exactly that in the preface to the white paper. "Now my government's objective is to make those attractions so strong that the case for investing here is, quite simply, irresistible," the ROC premier said.
Siew expressed a big thank-you to the AmCham, which recently celebrated a presence of 46 years in Taipei, for all its efforts over those years.

He said the AmCham has done much in support of US-ROC business relations. "Not only have you provided vital lines of communication between your businesses and our government, but you have also played an important role in promoting intergovernmental dialogue," he concluded.

On AmCham's latest "door knock" visit to Washington, the AmCham delivered a very forceful message urging, among other things, Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization and visits to Taiwan by senior US officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PROTEST OVER LIEN VISIT TO ICELAND CALLED 'BARBARIC'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) of the Republic of China on Thursday called mainland China's protest over Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Iceland "barbaric and unreasonable."

MOFA Spokesman Roy Wu said the protest is baffling and unnecessary, adding that the move fully exposes the systematic nature of efforts by Beijing to block Taiwan's participation in the international community.

Wu noted that Iceland's Prime Minister David Oddsson and Foreign Minister Halldor Asgrimsson have both emphasized that Iceland is a sovereign nation and has the right to issue visas to foreign visitors and to meet them without interference from other countries.

The MOFA spokesman said that Lien's visit was supported by his countrymen and that the government of Iceland has also extended a friendly welcome to him. As the ROC vice president is traveling in an unofficial capacity, Wu said the content of his meeting with Oddsson will only be revealed later at an appropriate time.
Wu stressed that the ROC is a sovereign country, and its popularly elected government has both the right and the obligation to represent Taiwan's 21 million people in the international community.
Lien arrved in Reykjavik on Tuesday for an unofficial visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASS DEMONSTRATION PLANNED FOR CLINTON-JIANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Human rights activists in the United States will hold a large-scale demonstration when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin meets with President Bill Clinton on Oct. 29 in protest against Beijing's imprisonment of political dissidents, religious persecution and human rights violations in Tibet.
One of the organizers who requested anonymity said that the demonstration will take place in Lafayette Park near the White House.

It is estimated that over 2,000 people will attend the mass rally, including members of Amnesty International, the Robert Kennedy Human Rights Center, the International Campaign for Tibet, the AFL-CIO labor union, the Reform Party led by Texas billionaire Ross Perot, pro-democracy organizations and Taiwanese groups in the United States.
Organizers said American actor Richard Gere will also participate in the demonstration to protest against Beijing's suppression of Tibetan people and their culture.

Gere has previously testified before a US Congressional hearing on Beijing's policies in Tibet. A follower of the Dalai Lama, Gere said he is deeply inspired by the Tibetan spiritual leader, who has not harbored ill will toward Beijing despite years of unfair treatment and has firmly stood by his principles of nonviolence. (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu) ENDITEM ZCZC CEP005 10-09-97 POLICY ADDRESS NOT PREVIEWED BY LI PENG: TUNG CHEE HWA

Hong Kong, Oct. 9 (CNA) Tung Chee Hwa flatly denied rumors that his first policy address to Hong Kong's Provisional Legislative Council on Wednesday had been previewed by mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng.

At a press conference following his speech, Tung said that one of the most pleasing developments experienced since he assumed the post as chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) exactly 100 days ago, is the fact that Beijing has not interfered with his administration, "not even a little bit."
Tung added that he has not felt any form of interference or pressure from Beijing, nor has he received any suggestions as to what he should be doing.
The Beijing authorities, Tung stressed, simply told him "to go ahead with your work" and have not sought to interfere.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices skyrocketed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 205.38 points to close at the day's high of 8,461.87.
The bourse opened at 8,373.2, and experienced a low of 8,364.76.
Gainers outnumbered losers 380 to 49, with 35 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.67 billion (US$3.76 billion).

Electrical engineering shares rose the most at 3.5 percent, ahead of a 2.5 percent growth by financial shares, 2.3 percent by cement stocks, 1.9 percent by paper-making, construction, and plastic and chemical issues, respectively, 1.3 percent by textile shares, and 1.0 percent by foodstuff stocks.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were Mosel Vitelic, United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronix International, ACER, CIS Technology, Mitac International, Winbond Electronics, Chuntex Electronic, and Hung Fu Construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO CONSIDER GRAVEL IMPORTS FROM SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday asked government agencies to evaluate long-term demands for gravel and to study the possibility of importing gravel from mainland China, the Philippines or other Southeast Asian nations.
He said that importing gravel for use in Taiwan's construction projects may be cheaper than transporting the material from quarries on the eastern side of the island to the western side by sea.
Siew made the remarks upon hearing a report by the Public Construction Commission of the Executive Yuan.
Noting that the quality and progress of public construction projects have shown improvement over the past year, Siew urged the commission to work harder to support such projects.

Siew also asked the commission to continue to push for open, systematic and transparent procedures for undertaking public construction works, and to closely monitor any projects where abnormalities in the bidding process appear.

Siew noted that the public has responded favorably to the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model being utilized for the proposed high-speed rail system in Taiwan, under which the private sector will build and operate the railway for a designated period of time before transferring ownership and operations to the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CONTINUING TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: TUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) Tung Chee Hwa said Wednesday that despite its reversion to mainland China, Hong Kong will continue its role as a promoter of cross-strait relations.

After delivering his first policy address before the Provisional Legislative Council, Tung pointed out in a press conference that Hong Kong will still do its best to be helpful to the exchange of culture, trade and personnel across the Taiwan Strait.

The extensive exchange of trade and commerce between Hong Kong and Taiwan is important to both Hong Kong and the island, he said, noting that both sides worked hard to ensure the relationship would continue after Beijing took control of the former British colony on July 1.

Furthermore, Tung expressed a hearty welcome to tourism and investment from Taiwan, saying both provide chances to improve understanding between Hong Kong and Taipei now that Hong Kong is under mainland control.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE POLICEMAN KILLED IN GUN BATTLE IN TAIPEI COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Chungho in Taipei County, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A gun battle in Taipei County streets early Thursday morning left one police officer dead and two other officers wounded, one seriously.
Lin An-shun, 37, the police officer in charge of the operation, received gunshot wounds in the head and chest. He died en route to the hospital.

Another policeman, Hsu Chen-fa, was also shot in the head, and a third, Lee Jen-ho, was hit in the feet during the shooting. Despite being badly wounded, the police still managed to apprehend the suspect.
The suspect, identified as Chen Ta-ming, was wearing a bulletproof vest but sustained nine gunshot wounds. The police had received leads that he is involved in drug trade.
After emergency medical treatment and surgery, Lee and Chen are recovering from their injuries, while Hsu remains in critical condition.
According to the Criminal Investigation Bureau, another suspect managed to escape during the shooting.

Premier Vincent Siew expressed his deep grief and regret upon being informed of the shooting. He pledged to use all available resources to fight crimes, and stressed that improving social order is his administration's top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR FALLS ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The US dollar fell NT$0.005 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$28.480 on a turnover of US$290 million.
The greenback opened at 28.475 and was traded between 28.460 and 28.485.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SAID TO PROVIDE AID PROGRAM TO PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Stephen Sheng & Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is planning to provide assistance to the small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) of Paraguay, the central bank governor of the Paraguay said Wednesday.
He also said Taiwan's Central Bank of China had agreed to promote technical exchanges with his bank.
The governor visited Taiwan on his way home from attending the annual World Bank/International Monetary Fund meeting in Hong Kong.
He said negotiations on the aid program will begin early next year, adding that a request for technical exchanges has already been sent to Taipei.
The Paraguayan official said his bank wants to draw on the ROC central bank's experience in managing national finance and foreign exchange.
He added that most businesses in his country are small-and medium-sized and are in dire need of assistance.
The ROC has already helped establish a counseling center in Paraguay for would-be entrepreneurs and donated training equipment to it.

Taipei has also provided a US$9.5 million loan to Paraguay for the establishment of an industrial development fund, which also makes use of a US$20 million loan provided by the America's Development Bank.
Money in the development fund has been re-loaned to Paraguayan SMEs, with success so far.
Paraguay is the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America.
ROC President Lee Teng-hui visited Asuncion last month during a four-nation tour of Latin American diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES TO SIGN AGREEMENT WITH US AEROSPACE FIRM

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-ming is due to arrive in New York with a ten-member delegation on October 13 for promoting cooperation between the aerospace industries of the United States and the Republic of China.

Yin's delegation is scheduled to visit the headquarters of Sikorsky Corp. in Connecticut to hold consultations aimed at forging cooperative links between the American helicopter manufacturer and Taiwan's Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC).

After his arrival at Sikorsky's headquarters Saturday morning, Yin is scheduled to meet the company's chief executive for discussions about the signing of a strategic alliance agreement and the building of a base for future cooperation between the two sides.

Dozens of major multi-national firms have signed strategic alliance agreements with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), promising exchanges of technology and know-how in an effort to boost their standing in the Taiwan market.
Among the top 500 US industries, Sikorsky mainly manufactures high-performance helicopters. It has already built up a base for business cooperation in Taiwan.
Sources at the MOEA said signing a strategic alliance agreement with Sikorsky could raise the technological standard of Taiwan's aerospace industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN DISCOVERY TO IMPACT TREATMENT OF EPILEPSY, STROKES

TEXT.P: Canadian scientists have made an important discovery that may impact the treatment of debilitating diseases such as epilepsy and strokes.
The discovery, details of which were published in the current issue of Nature magazine, was made by scientists at the National Research Council's Institute for Biological Science (IBS).
Their research involves glutamate, one of the brain's major neurotransmitters that is largely responsible for a number of cognitive processes such as learning and memory.

In disorders such as strokes and epilepsy, an excessive secretion of glutamate results in an over-stimulation of glutamate receptors. This is believed to initiate a cascade of cellular events culminating in the death of nerve cells.
IBS researchers have focused on a glutamate receptor subtype called AMPA. The AMPA receptor is an ion channel that is closely associated with neuro-transmission and cognitive processes in the brain.

Ion channels are pores in the outer membranes of neurons that control the flow of ions in and out of these cells. Their activation is critical to the generation of nerve impulses. Over-stimulation of AMPA receptors have also been linked to neuronal damage and death associated with strokes.

It has long been assumed that the only function of the AMPA receptor is its ion channel activity. However, IBS researchers have identified a new role for the AMPA receptor; it can bind and activate a crucial intracellular signaling protein called a G-protein.

G-proteins, when activated, are known to be one of the cells' most important intracellular messengers, triggering a variety of responses, ultimately dictating changes in gene expression and cellular behavior.

It is well known that the activity of various ion channels can be affected by G-proteins, but scientists at IBS are the first to provide evidence that an ion channel can activate and modulate a G-protein.
The principal researchers Dr. Yizheng Wang and Dr. Jon Durkin are hopeful that this exciting discovery will have far-reaching research and clinical implications.

"One important point that arises from this study is that since we show for the first time that mutually independent signals are generated by AMPA receptor stimulation, drugs will eventually be developed that can selectively modulate one pathway without affecting the other," said Durkin, the project leader.
"This will result in therapeutic treatments that are more specific, with less side effects, than drugs currently under development," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA BLOCKS TAIWAN ROLE IN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A United Nations agency was forced to abandon joint sponsorship of a high-level meeting, with the World Trade Organization, after Beijing objected that the venue would provide Taiwan with a de facto political platform.
According to a Journal of Commerce dispatch from Geneva on Tuesday, the WTO will now be the sole host of the conference to promote market-access opportunities for the world's poorest nations.
"The Chinese forced this," commented a senior US official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
About 35 trade ministers representing some of the world's poorest countries, those with annual per capita incomes of US$500 or less, are expected to attend the meeting, scheduled for Oct. 27-28.

Following months of behind-the-scenes diplomacy in Geneva, Beijing and Washington decided in a special session of the WTO General Council on Tuesday that the meeting would be hosted by the trade watchdog body alone, in order to effectively prevent Taiwan from attending the meeting.

The dispatch noted that at the WTO summit in Singapore last December, trade ministers had agreed that the WTO, along with the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and other agencies, should organize a meeting to discuss ways to enhance trade opportunities for the world's poorest countries.
However, China remained adamant to the end that participation by UNCTAD would be seen as de facto participation by Taiwan in a UN meeting, said senior diplomats familiar with the matter.

With Taiwan being an observer at the WTO and China holding a seat on the United Nations Security Council, Beijing felt the joint sponsorship would be seen as mainland China and Taiwan participating under equal status at the same international conference.

The Journal of Commerce cited diplomats in charge of trade issues as saying that the insistence by a group of Central American countries -- including El Salvador and Costa Rica -- that Taiwan and other WTO observer nations not be excluded from the meeting left the UN agency with no alternative but to step aside.

But a number of WTO representatives noted that the political hiccup instigated by Beijing is unlikely to affect the substance of the meeting, which could climax with the United States, the European Union, Japan, and other powers making new market-opening commitments for the world's poorest countries, the journal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY: TURKISH ADOPTIVE PARENTS PREFER GIRLS

TEXT.P: More than 4,000 families have been waiting to adopt babies from orphanages in Turkey since 1990, with most of them preferring baby girls, according to a survey released on Wednesday.

The study of orphanages throughout Turkey found that more than 90 percent of the families would prefer an abandoned child aged up to three years. They want to adopt children at the earliest age possible, which they feel is the best situation for their own future as well as that of the infants, the survey said.

The survey also said that 70 percent of the families prefer to adopt girls because they can be helpful for housework and can take care of the adoptive parents during their old age. Another 20 percent prefer boys and 10 percent didn't indicate any preference.
Turkish law does not permit the separation of siblings in the adoption process. Thus, those children must wait until a family is found which wants to adopt siblings.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE GOV'T OKAYS URANIUM MINING DESPITE ABORIGINAL PROTEST

TEXT.P: The Australian government has given a green light for the mining of uranium at Jabiluka in Northern Territory in disregard of strong protests by traditional aboriginal owners.
Energy industry sources said on Thursday that the approval will greatly boost the country's uranium output.

Resources and Energy Minister Warwick Parer, who recently went to Taipei for the joint annual meeting of the Taiwan-Australia and Australia-Taiwan business councils, approved the application for uranium mining by the Energy Resources of Australia (ERA), one of the two uranium mining companies in Australia.

But the proposed Northern Territory mine still faces legal battles, including court action over the validity of the mineral leases and legal questions about the applicability of the agreement signed in 1982 to the new mining proposals, energy sources said.
When all these hurdles are successfully completed, Australia's uranium production will be greatly increased.
By the end of this year, Australia, one of the world's leading producers and exporters of uranium, will produce about 6,000 tons of uranium for export. the countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ISSUE SMART ID CARD TO CITIZENS

TEXT.P: The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) under the Executive Yuan Thursday revealed a government plan to replace the Citizenship Identification Card with a smart "IC" card by 1999.
The proposed IC card would incorporate the functions of the current ID card, National Health Insurance card and driver's license. It might also have other functions said officials with the RDEC.
Private firms are being invited to attend briefings on the project, which will cost an estimated NT$1 billion (US$35 million). They will also be invited to bid on the project.
A pilot plan will be carried out for at least six months next year before the current ID card is replaced by multi-functional smart card.
The new card is aimed at upgrading the government's efficiency and service to the people, the officials said.
Malaysia is the only other country planning to introduce such a card, said the RDEC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS ICELANDIC PRIME MINISTER (I)

TEXT.P: Despite a strong protest from Beijing, Icelandic Prime Minister David Oddsson hosted a dinner at his summer residence as scheduled on Wednesday, in honor of visiting ROC Vice President Lien Chan.

Oddsson told the press that Iceland's policy has always been and will continue to be to recognize the Beijing government, but this doesn't mean that Iceland cannot host private visits by senior officials from Taiwan.

"We cannot accept that other nations tell us when and how various private individuals visit our country," the Icelandic prime minister said, adding that it "won't be a problem" even if President Lee Teng-hui wants to make a sight-seeing trip to the North Atlantic island nation.

Describing the dinner party as pleasant and amicable, Lien recalled that he had discussed with Oddsson some practical measures for promoting tourism and academic and cultural exchanges between the Republic of China and Iceland. "We also explored the feasibility of exchanging professors and students and cooperating in oceanographic research," he said, adding that they had already reached consensus on these issues.

The vice president further said he sees no major difficulties for the two countries to exchange representative offices, but he added that the two sides have yet to work out a concrete plan in this respect.

Lien went on to say he admires Oddsson's spirit in ignoring the pressure from Beijing to invite him to visit Iceland, adding that Oddsson has accepted an invitation to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.
Lien again urged Beijing to understand that Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy is a necessity to maintain its survival in the international community, not a strategy to challenge or provoke mainland China.
Noting that the ROC is already the world's 14th-largest trading nation, Lien said it is incomprehensible that its leaders cannot "walk out into the world" with dignity.

The vice president said Taiwan must engage with other countries to upgrade its technology and sustain its economic development. "For instance, I have come to Iceland to talk about trade and investment, not to deal with any political issues," he pointed out.
Lien said Iceland attaches great importance to its trade with Asia, especially with Taiwan, which is Iceland's second-largest market in Asia, behind only Japan.
"After my few days' stay here, I find Taiwan has much it can learn from Iceland and that there is ample room for our two countries to cooperate," the vice president noted.

Noting that Iceland has the world's oldest system of parliamentary politics, dating back to 930 A.D., Lien said Taiwan can learn from Iceland's experience in pursuing social equality, fairness, justice, harmony and welfare services.

Lien said Oddsson has promised to improve visa services for prospective Taiwan visitors. ROC nationals currently make an average of six million overseas visits a year, only 5,000 of which are to Iceland. "Taiwan and Icelandic travel agencies should work hand-in-hand to lure more Taiwan visitors to this beautiful country," he said.

The deep-sea fishing industry is also a field suitable for ROC-Iceland cooperation, Lien said. Taiwan's fishing industry has developed rapidly over the last few decades, with annual production growing from NT$500 million (US$17.48 million) in 1963 to more than NT$84 billion (US$2.94 billion) in 1996.

Situated in some of the richest fishing grounds in the world, Iceland possesses advanced deep-sea fishing technology and seafood-processing expertise, Lien said, adding that fishing industry executives from both countries should meet to explore possible cooperative projects.

Lien suggested that Taiwan entrepreneurs should study the feasibility of investing in the high-energy-consuming metal refining industry in Iceland, as the volcanic island has abundant cheap geothermal-generated electricity. (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN MEETS ICELANDIC PM (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Reykjavik, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Touching on cultural and academic exchanges, Lien said National Taiwan Ocean University has already launched a cooperative project with Iceland in fishing technology research. "The ROC and Iceland can also promote exchanges in literature, theater, language, art and other related fields," he added.

Earlier in the day, Lien hosted a luncheon at an upscale Reykjavik restaurant in honor of scores of Icelandic politicians, socialites and media executives. Lien told his guests that he is hopeful his current sight-seeing, fact-finding visit will help boost bilateral friendship and cooperation.

Lien, who arrived in the Icelandic capital on Monday, is scheduled to leave for Austria on Thursday for a two-day "sight-seeing, transit" stay. He reportedly will then travel to Spain where he is expected to deliver a speech at a university in suburban Madrid.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DEFENSE MINISTER BLASTS US OVER RIFT WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia's Defense Minister Ian McLachlan has attacked the US Congress for criticizing Indonesia's human rights record, saying Washington is losing an opportunity to exert greater influence in the region.

Speaking on the eve of the annual Ausmin talks -- the foreign affairs and defense ministers' forum in Washington that is the successor to the ANZUS talks -- McLachlan urged the United States to increase its level of policy interest in Asia if it wants to enhance its future commercial and strategic leverage.

In a dispatch from Washington, mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Thursday quoted McLachlan as saying that the end of the Cold War competition has clearly brought profound changes to the Asian Pacific area.
"It is a region characterized by growth, energy, great diversity and, unlike postwar Europe, there is an absence of established ways to handle security differences peacefully," he said.
"In Southeast Asia, economic growth has created a number of vigorous states. Indonesia, in particular, will emerge over the coming decades as a significant power," McLachlan noted.
He said the US Clinton administration has taken a measured approach on Indonesian matters, but added that Washington's voice is not being heard as clearly as it could be.
"The voice that is heard is the voice of those people in Congress complaining about human rights," he said.

McLachlan's comments followed reports that Prime Minister John Howard and Australian officials are trying to mediate a rift between the US and Indonesia over Washington's attacks on Jakarta's human rights record.

Indonesian President Suharto has canceled a purchase order of US-made F-16 jet fighters, opting instead to procure combat aircraft from Russia. Indonesia has also dropped a joint military training program with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: METHANOL EXTRACTS MAY COMBAT HIV: INDONESIAN RESEARCHERS

TEXT.P: Methanol extracts from the Mahoni tree can fight HIV, the virus that causes the deadly disease AIDS, according to a research team from the faculty of pharmacy of Airlangga University in Surabaya, Indonesia.

"Our research show that traditional herbs are capable of combating the HIV virus, especially methanol extracts from the Mahoni tree," the Antara news agency quoted Dr. Wahyo Djatmiko, head of the faculty's phytochemistry laboratory and leader of the research team, as saying in Surabaya Monday.
He said that of 30 species of plants studied, only six were found to be capable of combating the virus.
These six species of plants contain flavonoid, sponin and tanin, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMOKERS AND DRINKERS MAY BE HIT WITH 'HEALTH TAX'

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) has proposed a "health tax" on cigarettes and alcohol as part of the government's efforts to control the scourge of these health-threatening products.
DOH officials are planning to have parts of the Health Insurance Law revised so that the tax can be imposed.
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) welcomed the proposal, saying it has the ministry's full support since the plan is aimed at improving people's health further.
MOF officials, however, said several related issues will have to be tackled before the proposal can become law.
They said it would not be necessary to revise the Health Insurance Law. An article can be added to the existing Anti-Smoking Law to create a legal basis for the health tax.
They said they also expect controversy to arise over whether the central government or local governments would be responsible for collecting the tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT CRIMES IN PAST 12 MONTHS LEAVE 4 POLICE DEAD, 12 INJURED

TEXT.P: There have been eight crimes in the past 12 months that have resulted in the death or injury of police officers in Taiwan, revealing that some criminals here are now more heavily armed than the police.

During the latest gun battle Thursday morning, a suspect shot at police with an Uzi and a .90-caliber handgun, killing one policeman and injuring two others, but the suspect, who was wearing a high-quality bulletproof vest, received no life-threatening injuries.
Four police officers have lost their lives since October 1996, while one was made brain-dead and 11 others were wounded, according to statistics by the National Police Administration.

A lawmaker said in a plenary meeting at the Legislative Yuan on Thursday that there are around 50,000 smuggled guns on the island, saying they are partly responsible for Taiwan's deteriorating social order.
Cheng Pao-ching of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party questioned the efficiency of the police, citing official figures that only around 2,000 illegal firearms are seized every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC CLOSES HIGHER ON 1ST TRADING DAY ON NYSE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang & Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's "white sun in a blue sky on a crimson background" national flag was hoisted inside and outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Wednesday to mark the first day of trading of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) shares on the world's largest and oldest stock market.

TSMC stock opened at US$24.8125, which was calculated in terms of its closing price on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday. As the company has long enjoyed a good reputation in the world semiconductor foundry service sector, share prices increased steadily from opening amid active buying. The price reached a high of US$26.1875 at one point, closing at US$26.125, a US$1.3125 or 5.29 percent rise.
More than 2.57 million TSMC shares changed hands, with turnover reaching US$67.38 million. TSMC was one of the few stocks which managed to post gains on Wednesday.

TSMC Chairman Chang Chung-mo made a special trip to New York to witness the listing of his company's stock on the NYSE. TSMC is the first Taiwan company permitted to trade its stock on the 205-year-old exchange.

At a reception hosted by the NYSE management to celebrate the TSMC listing, Chang said his company consistently posted 100 percent growth in its annual after-tax profits between 1991 and 1996. The world's largest semiconductor foundry service firm netted NT$20 billion in profits on a turnover of NT$40 billion last year, and its net profits are estimated at NT$14.2 billion this year, he noted.
