The TSMC took the lead in launching the chip foundry service in 1987 and dominated the market for seven years, Chang said, adding proudly that although some Taiwan, Singaporean and Malaysian companies followed in the footsteps of TSMC to offer similar services, many of them have come to understand that they stand only a slim chance of overtaking his company's lead in the field.
Chang went on to say that keen competition forced down wafer prices early this year, but that prices have gradually stabilized since April, "so our company's profitability won't be affected."

The 120 million TSMC shares to be traded on the NYSE in the form of American Deposit Receipts (ADR) were released by Dutch electronics giant Philips, one of TSMC's major shareholders. Philips originally planned to offer only 75 million shares for trading on the NYSE, but later increased the quantity due to hot market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TRYING TO SELL LNG TO M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia, one of the world's major producers and exporters of liquefied natural gas (LNG), is trying to sell LNG to mainland China, the mass circulation newspaper The Australian reported Thursday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported West Australian Premier Richard Court and Northern Territory Chief Minister Shane Stone met mainland Chinese Vice Premier Zhu Rongji to discuss the supply of LNG from gas fields off the northwest coast of Australia and in the Timor Sea.

The two secured an agreement with the mainland Chinese State Planning Commission to conduct a review by the end of this year on the viability of supplying mainland coastal provinces with LNG for power generation.
Currently, Japan is the only long-term buyer of Australian LNG.
Australia's LNG production is now about 7.5 million tonnes a year but could expand to up to 30 million tonnes a year by 2010, experts said.
As a result, Australian LNG producers have to look for markets in mainland China and elsewhere in Asia, including Taiwan, Thailand, India and the Philippines.
Taiwan already has 20-year contracts with two other major producers: Indonesia and Malaysia.
Court said LNG has to compete with the traditional source of power generation in Asia: coal.
"Compared with coal, which now accounts for 70 percent of all energy production in China, LNG is viewed to have strong environmental advantages," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S ELECTRONICS SECTOR TURNS IN SLUGGISH GROWTH

TEXT.P: Singapore's electronics production growth slowed to 3.7 percent in August -- down from 9 percent in the previous month -- a sign that all is still not well here with this vital sector.
Overall, output of electronics products in the first eight months of this year was marginally lower than the total for the same period last year.

Electronics production accounts for 46 percent of Singapore's total manufacturing output and is thus critical to the health of this sector. Manufacturing in turn generates almost a quarter of Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP).
An indication that the expected electronics recovery has yet to materialize fully came from the August trade figures released last month.
The key export of non-oil domestic products grew by 5.5 percent year-on-year, or about half of the double-digit growth forecast by analysts and economists.

Releasing the monthly industrial production index for August Wednesday, the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) said the output of disk drives saw healthy growth, though the growth rate was lower than before.
Higher output of telecommunications products and semiconductors was negated by declining production of personal computers and consumer electronics, it said.
The cumulative output of electronics for the first eight months of this year registered a marginal decline of 0.5 percent compared to the same months of last year.
Manufacturing output rose 6.5 percent in August compared to a year ago. While production by the chemical industry expanded, overall growth was pulled down by the electronics industry.
The EDB said cumulative output from January to August this year was a mere 1 percent higher compared to the same period of last year.

The star performer for August was the chemical industry, which saw a 30 percent increase in output. Its cumulative output for the first eight months of this year grew by an impressive 15.5 percent, with the major contribution coming from petrochemicals, the EDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CPC CHAIRMAN VOWS TO BOOST MARALE OF EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: The new head of state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) on Thursday pledged to strengthen safety measures to eliminate accidents and boost the morale of all CPC employees.

CPC chairman Chen Chao-wei said in his inauguration ceremony that sound industrial safety measures must be carefully implemented and that all CPC employees will be required to faithfully observe the measures.

The CPC has been plagued with a string of accidents in recent years. A huge gas explosion on Sept. 13 in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung claimed the lives of 11 people, prompting the resignation on Sept. 17 of former CPC chairman S.J. Lee.
The most recent CPC accident was an explosion on a CPC oil tanker on Tuesday near the Kaohsiung harbor, which killed two maintenance workers.

Chen said CPC employee morale is low because workers are worried about the possibility of pay cuts when the company is privatized in 2000. A new system of reward and punishment will be strictly applied as part of efforts to boost morale and he said he is also willing to have more contact with his staff and to hear their points of view.

Chen, who served as chairman of Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit System before taking over his new position, said he believes that if all CPC employees work as a team, the accident rate will be greatly reduced, but he admitted that his improvements will take some time.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAMOS WANTS MARCOS LOOT RETURNED

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Thursday said it is high time the Philippine government recovers the money deposited by former President Ferdinand Marcos in Switzerland, emphasizing that he would like to see this happen before the end of his term in June 1998.

Speaking to reporters, Ramos said he had asked the Presidential Commission on Good Government (PCGG) and the legislative liaison officers to secure at least a congressional resolution that would express the sense of urgency to the legislature for a settlement.

Ramos said the objective is clear -- to get the money transferred from Switzerland to the Philippines in the name of the Philippine government, while at the same time taking care of the claims of human rights victims of the Marcos regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA, TAIWAN BUYING AUSTRALIAN IRON, COPPER

TEXT.P: Mainland China will import increasing amounts of Australian iron and copper ore because of its growing demand for the products to fuel its economic growth, energy analysts predicted.
Mainland China imported about 23 million tonnes of iron ore and 191,000 tonnes of copper ore from Australia in fiscal 1996-97, according to official statistics here.

Taiwan did not import copper ore from Australia. But it imported 23,000 tonnes of refined copper from Australia in 1996-97. Taiwanese importers bought copper ore on the spot market, according to the Australian Department of Energy and Resources (DER).
Currently, mainland China's total imports of iron ore range from 40 million to 45 million tonnes a year and Australian officials predicted the figure could double by 2001.

Australia exported about 5.5 million tonnes of iron ore to Taiwan in 1996-97 and DER officials said they expect there will be steady increases in Australian iron ore exports to Taiwan because of new steel mills coming on line in a couple of years.
The officials said mainland China is expected to buy more iron and copper ore from major producers such as Australia to fuel its fast-growing economy in the next few years.
Mainland China is now Australia's third-largest iron ore market and second largest copper market.
Australia produced 152 million tonnes of iron ore in 1996-97 and 560,000 tonnes of copper ore. It also turned out 325,000 tonnes of refined copper in that period.
The mainland Chinese Ministry of Geology and Mineral Resources predicts mainland China will import about one million tonnes of iron ore and almost one million tonnes of copper ore per year by 2000.
Energy analysts said they believe Taiwan and mainland China could likely compete with each other in the import of iron ore and copper ore from Australia in coming years.
"But China would have upper hand because of its greater demand for iron ore and copper ore than Taiwan," one analyst said.
Australia, however, is expected to supply iron ore and copper ore to both sides of the Taiwan Strait because both countries are major importers.

"Australia is expected to try to satisfy both sides of the Taiwan Strait in the future," another analyst said. "Taiwan has been a reliable buyer of Australian iron ore and copper ore and Australian producers have high regards for Taiwanese buyers."
Australia now competes with South America, including Brazil, in the supply of iron ore and copper ore in the world market.
But the DER officials said Australia has the advantage of its proximity to Asia.

"As a producer of energy resources, we are more than happy to supply our iron ore and copper ore to any countries, including Taiwan and China, in the future," one senior official, who declined to be named, said in an interview with CNA on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of President Lee Teng-hui's National Day message issued on the eve of the Republic of China's 86th National Day, which falls on Oct. 10:
Ladies and Gentlemen:

Today is the 86th National Day of the Republic of China. We are gathered here not only to celebrate the awesome success of the founding of the Republic of China, but more importantly, to reflect upon the revolutionary ideals of our nation's founding fathers, to carry forward their nation-building spirit and to create much greater and brighter prospects for the development of our country.

Nearly a century ago, Dr. Sun Yat-sen drew up blueprints for the development of a democratic, free and equitably prosperous Republic of China. Although the tides of time have been rough, and our nation has encountered many obstacles throughout its 86 years of history, the Republic of China at long last stands tall and firm. At the heart of ROC's resilience are an unshakable belief in democracy and a responsible attitude toward history. Today, we can proudly say that in the areas currently under the jurisdiction of the Republic of China--Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu--the ideals of Dr. Sun Yat-sen have already been realized. With our spectacular success in building a full-fledged democracy, an open society, a prosperous economy, and good living conditions, we have written a new page in the history of the Chinese people.

The significance of history lies in its ability to pass the torch of wisdom from one generation to the next. The value of history, on the other hand, derives from its power to use its heritage to propel the human spirit forward into the future. Our achievements of today are possible only because of the firm foundation laid down by the countless brave and honorable martyrs who struggled and sacrificed before us. And now, having pushed our nation to new heights of development, we must continue our efforts. We must remain firm in upholding the ideals of democracy and freedom so that we can create a safer, more stable, and more dignified environment for the next generation, enable the ROC to overcome challenges and open new horizons in the face of fierce competition in the 21st century.
For these reasons, we must coalesce the energy of our people toward promoting a national re-engineering that continues to spur national development:

We must make constitutional reform the foundation for the realization of democratic ideals and must actively promote educational reform, judicial reform, administrative reform and cultural development, and establish a fair, just, modern, humanistic and compassionate society. At the same time, laws must be strictly enforced, crime must be effectively combated, and law and order must be strengthened to ensure the safety of the people and restore peace to society.

We will spare no effort in our drive to transform Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center. Capitalizing on our many existing advantages, we will make Taiwan a "technology island." At the same time, through the revision of laws and regulations, we will create a more liberal and global environment for economic development, eliminate barriers to investment, eradicate bottlenecks in development, accelerate upgrading of industry, and raise our international competitiveness. Meanwhile, we must emphasize environmental protection and ecological conservation to reach our objective of sustained development through moderate growth and rigorous conservation.

Guided by the principles of unyielding defense and effective deterrence, we must aggressively implement our troop reduction program and complete the acquisition of second-generation weaponry systems in order to build a modern national defense and better ensure our national security. Furthermore, we believe in ensuring regional security and prosperity as well as building a peaceful world, and we are willing to work together with other Asia-Pacific countries to promote regional security and stability.

We will continue to pursue pragmatic diplomacy and contribute to the global village. We will strive to participate in the international community, strengthen cordial and cooperative bonds with friendly nations and enhance substantive relations with those nations with which we do not maintain diplomatic ties. In addition, we will actively take part in international organizations and activities, so that nations around the world must acknowledge the reality of the ROC's existence and development. This will enhance our international status, uphold our dignity in the world and safeguard.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: It is our position that cross-strait relations can only be pursued on the conditions that the existence and development of the ROC are maintained and the security and welfare of the 21.6 million people in the Taiwan area are safeguarded. We have stated time and again our most sincere desire to pursue unification under democracy, freedom, and equitable distribution of wealth. Regardless of the fact that the mainland authorities have yet to respond with goodwill, we have repeatedly called for the two sides to end the state of hostility across the Taiwan Strait, resume negotiations, and engage in peaceful competition. We sincerely hope that Peking will adopt a pragmatic attitude and open mind and face up to the reality that Taiwan and mainland are ruled separately. We also hope that the mainland leadership will take positive actions to increase mutual trust, narrow the gap between the two sides, and allow for an historic new "win-win" era of cross-strait relations.

Ladies and gentlemen: During the past half century, we have worked together hand in hand with singular objective and created a world-renowned miracle in the areas of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu. We have also gradually established, for the Republic of China, an important position impossible to ignore in the international community. Looking to the future, we are fully confident of building on our present well-established foundation to achieve even greater development. It is our belief that as long as our people remained committed to the ideal of democracy, enthusiastically carry forward reforms, and actively pursue progress, we will surely be able to seize every opportunity to create advantages and open doors to ever more brilliant prospects for our nation in the 21st century.
In closing, I wish the Republic of China everlasting prosperity and to each and every one of you, good health and happiness. Thank you! (end)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES BEIJING TO RESUME NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: On the eve of the Republic of China's National Day, President Lee Teng-hui called upon Beijing to end hostility towards Taiwan, resume negotiations and engage in peaceful competition with the island.

Reiterating in his National Day message the ROC's desire to pursue unification with the Chinese mainland under the principle of democracy, freedom and equitable distribution of wealth, the president said it is Taiwan's position that cross-strait relations can only be pursued on the conditions that the existence and development of the ROC are maintained and the security and welfare of the 21.6 million people in the Taiwan are safeguarded.
He urged Beijing to adopt a pragmatic attitude and an open mind and face up to the reality that Taiwan and the mainland are ruled separately.

Lee said Taiwan hopes the mainland leadership will take positive actions to increase mutual trust, narrow the gap between the two sides, and allow for a historic new "win-win" era of cross-strait relations.

Declaring that Taiwan has realized the ideals of ROC founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sun, and that the ROC has established for itself an important position impossible to ignore in the international community, the president also encourages his fellow countrymen to seize every opportunity to create advantages and open doors to ever more brilliant prospects for the nation in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POURS COLD WATER ON BEIJING'S WTO ENTRY BID

TEXT.P: US Commerce Secretary William Daley poured cold water on hopes that remaining hurdles to Beijing's accession to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) could be cleared when mainland China's President Jiang Zemin visits Washington at the end of the month, according to reports from the world trade regulatory body on Thursday.

Daley said that a decision on mainland China's entry into the WTO should not be tied to a certain date or event. "It's much more important to be on the right way rather than trying to be rushing," he was quoted by the WTO report as saying.
Daley said Washington is not satisfied with results yielded in ongoing talks with mainland China led by US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, and is not optimistic.
"We have not seen the progress that we would have liked to see. It's difficult right now... because of the offers on the table so far," he was quoted as saying.

With both sides proclaiming that the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and Jiang should produce "tangible results," anticipation has been mounting in recent months that it could bring a breakthrough on the WTO issue.

Noting that the issue will be discussed in and around the summit, Daley said Washington is waiting for a proposal from mainland China to be tabled "that accomplishes not only what the United States is looking for, but many other countries too," according to the WTO report.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNSHINE BACK IN SINGAPORE, BUT HAZE TO RETURN

TEXT.P: The sun shone in Singapore for the second day Thursday.
For the first time in more than a month, people woke up Wednesday morning to blue skies and crisp, clean air.
The air pollution index was in the good-to-moderate range the whole day, with rain in the afternoon.

But the weatherman said the improved haze situation will stay for only a couple of days. After that, periods of hazy weather can be expected when prevailing southwest winds bring the haze from the Indonesian island of Sumatra back to Singapore.
The haze will not go for good until next month, when the northeast monsoon sets in.

The weatherman said, however, that the overall situation from now on will continue to improve gradually as more rain is expected. It will have a dampening effect on the forest fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan, he added.
The 24-hour PSI (Pollutants Standard Index) reading of 55 Wednesday was a pre-haze level, and at one point, the three-hour reading sank to a low of 31.
The PSI level was below 50 for 64 percent of the time last year, and between 50 and 100 for the rest of the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD NOT BE EXCLUDED FROM INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday said that it is unfair and unjust to exclude the Republic of China from the international community due to pressure from mainland China.

Siew told over 100 foreign reporters in Taiwan to cover the ROC National Day "Double Tenth" celebrations, that as the world is destined to move away from bloody confrontation toward peaceful and rational dialogue, it is the hope of the ROC to move forward hand in hand with the international community.

Siew said that whether the theater of operations is the Asia-Pacific region, Europe, America, Africa, or even the Chinese mainland, the ROC will do its best to strengthen regional economic cooperation, mutual help and international friendship. This is why President Lee Teng-hui participated in the World Congress on the Panama Canal and the Central American summit meeting in September and why he declared his willingness to embark on a "journey of peace" to the Chinese mainland, he added.

Addressing cross-strait relations, Siew stressed that while pursuing the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the ROC insists that this should not be achieved at the expense of the hard-earned democracy, human rights and freedom of the press of Taiwan's 21 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES BEIJING TO SHOW GOODWILL TOWARDS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew held out an olive branch to mainland China on Thursday, urging it to act positively towards Taiwan's call for an end to hostility across the Taiwan Strait and ring in a new era of "Chinese help Chinese" by joining with Taiwan in efforts to push ahead with cross-strait exchanges and dialogue.

At a rally organized by the government for overseas Chinese visiting Taiwan to celebrate the Republic of China's 86th National Day on Oct. 10, the premier expressed thanks to overseas Chinese for the warm reception they extended to President Lee Teng-hui during his Latin American trip early last month and the firm support they have rendered to the government by returning to their homeland to mark the country's birthday.

He ticked off the country's most notable achievements -- including the possession of the world's third-largest foreign reserves, becoming the world's seventh-biggest source of investment outflow and becoming the world's 15th-biggest trading nation, not to mention its much-publicized democratization -- putting them down to the tireless efforts of countrymen at home and the care and support of overseas Chinese around the globe.

Noting the historical events that have separated the ROC on Taiwan from mainland China for more than 50 years, the first native Taiwanese premier called on the Beijing to match Taipei's friendly gestures of renouncing force to reclaim the mainland and lifting a travel ban on people from Taiwan wishing to visit the mainland.

Thursday's rally, held at the Linkou Stadium in suburban Taipei, brought together more than 7,000 overseas Chinese from all over the world to watch a display of folk dance, martial arts, Chinese opera and performances by renowned local singers and entertainers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICELAND DAILIES PLAY UP PREMIER'S WELCOME TO ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Two leading Iceland dailies devoted significant space in their Thursday editions to remarks by Prime Minister David Oddsson that the island nation would welcome a sight-seeing trip by Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui.
The Morgunbladid and Dagur newspapers also said that Oddsson, although taking Beijing's protest at the visit to Iceland by ROC Vice President Lien Chan seriously, would never snub Taiwan's dignitary.
Oddsson told the two papers that he did not ask Lien to alter the itinerary of his visit and went ahead with a private dinner party in Lien's honor.

Although surprised by Beijing's fierce reaction, including the interruption of negotiations on a contract with an Iceland firm, the prime minister said he would not allow Beijing to dictate to Iceland who it can invite to visit.
The Morgunbladid also carried a picture showing Lien and his wife being warmly entertained by Oddsson and his wife.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTY ON 274 IT ITEMS TO BE GRADUALLY CUT TO ZERO BY 2000

TEXT.P: A session of the Legislative Yuan on Thursday ratified an agreement signed by 39 countries including Taiwan, regarding the Republic of China's implementation of a World Trade Organization (WTO) declaration on information technology (IT) products.
According to the terms of the agreement, the ROC should gradually cut tariffs on 274 IT items to zero in four stages by 2000, beginning from July 1, 1997.

The WTO convened a decisive trade ministers' meeting to discuss the tariff-cutting program on IT products on March 26 this year, with an agreement being reached by the 39 attendees. The document was ratified by the WTO on April 14.

According to the agreement, the WTO member-countries which attended the meeting must revise their tariff concession lists according to Article 28 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the forerunner of the WTO. The participating countries will then be bound by international law according to Article 2 of the GATT.
Although the ROC has still not been admitted to the WTO, it attended the March meeting and must therefore follow the tariff-cutting procedure if it still wishes to be considered for membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: "SUCH A LIFE" AWARDED BEST PICTURE AT ASIA-PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "Such a Life," directed by Chen Cheng-chih, on Thursday won the best picture award at the Asia-Pacific Film Festival, being held on Cheju Island, South Korea.

"I feel wonderful!" Chen said when he learned that his second film, which premiered at the festival, had won two awards -- best picture and a special "peace" award, in the Asia-Pacific region's most important film festival.

"Such a Life", based on a true story of 1950's Taiwan, depicts the unhappy life of a small boy living in a poor village in southern Taiwan, where many of the villagers were suffering from "black foot disease."

"Ah Chung" endured constant bullying by his classmates, but he didn't care, devoting all his time to providing for his grandfather, who had lost both feet to the disease. Ah Chung managed to eke a living selling popsicles on the street and sometimes stealing a few clams until he was caught and drowned while trying to escape.

The young protagonist "Ah Chung" was played by primary school student Lin Yi-chih, playing in his debut role. The film also featured Taiwanese puppet master Lee Tien-lu and Taiwanese opera actress Tung Mei-yun.

Another film from Taiwan -- "A Cha-Cha the Fugitive" won three awards -- best cinematography, best editing and best sound. The movie was directed by Wang Tsai-hsiang, famous for a series of controversial TV commercials for "Stimorol" brand chewing gum.
Taiwan's "Excessive for Beauty," a cartoon by five university students, won the award for best animated film.

Cheung Man Yuk took best leading actress for Hong Kong's "Comrades, Almost a Love Story," which was also won best screenplay, while Koji Yakusho won best leading actor for Japan's "The Eel," which also took the award for best director.
Eriko Watanabe won best supporting actress for Japan's "Shall We Dance," while Kim Il-woo won best supporting actor for South Korea's "Farewell My Darling."
Hong Kong movie tycoon Run Run Shaw, at 90 years of age, also received a special award for his contribution to the industry, although he did not receive the award personally.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TRANSPORT CRASHES, FIVE DIE

TEXT.P: An Air Force C-130 transport aircraft crashed at Taipei's Sungshan Airport on Friday morning as it attempted to land at a nearby military base, killing all five crew members onboard and injuring two other persons on the ground.

In a press conference held at 11:00 a.m., the Air Force General Headquarters reported that the military plane first tried to land at the Sungshan military base around 8:10 a.m. but had to abort the effort because of poor visibility.

The plane then circled around for a second landing attempt, when it suddenly nose-dived and crashed near the runway of the adjacent civilian airport. Killed in the mishap were the pilot and co-pilot, both Air Force majors, and three sergeants aboard the aircraft, who were on a routine transport mission from Pingtung to Taipei, according to Air Force spokesman Lee Tien-yu.

Lee said a preliminary investigation showed that low cloud cover near the airport was most likely the major factor behind the accident. Mechanical failure and human error also may have contributed to the crash. The true cause of the mishap will be known only after the plane's "black box" flight recorder is analyzed, he added.

Two Air Force guards near the military base, who were on duty when the C-130 nose-dived, were seriously burnt by the flames which erupted from the plane upon impact. They were rushed to a nearby hospital for emergency treatment.
The Air Force sealed off the Sungshan Airport immediately after the accident occurred and all inbound and outbound passenger flights from the airport were suspended until 11:30 a.m.
A drill by Air Force planes, scheduled to be staged Friday morning as part of the performances to mark the Republic of China's Double Tenth National Day, was consequently canceled.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POISED TO BECOME WORLD'S 3RD LARGEST IC SUPPLIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's up-and-coming microchip industry is expected to churn out US$66 billion worth of ICs and related products by 2005, making it the third largest IC producer in the world, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.
According to an MOEA survey, investment in Taiwan's IC manufacturing grew by a whopping 33 percent in 1996, much higher than the average 5 percent posted by the rest of the world.
The island's IC industry continued to flourish as the upstream feeder to computer and related information manufacturers last year.
In 1996, Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry chalked up US$24.17 billion worth of computers and related IT products, to rank third in the world, behind only the United States and Japan.
Among the IT products, the output of monitors, motherboards, computer mice and keyboards also made Taiwan the world's top supplier of those components.
The MOEA survey found that Taiwan currently ranks fourth in the world in the IC market, following the United States, Japan and South Korea.

With an increase in production being estimated at 30 percent this year, Taiwan's IC industry is fast catching up with that of South Korea and should move into third place by the turn of the century, MOEA officials speculated.
By the year 2005, they estimated, Taiwan's IC production will reach 11.3 percent of the entire output from the island's manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA HOPES TO VISIT TAIWAN AGAIN

TEXT.P: Gyalo Thondup, brother of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, said here Friday that the Dalai Lama hopes to visit Taiwan again.

Thondup, who was in Taipei as the head of a delegation of overseas Tibetans attending the Republic of China's Double Tenth National Day celebrations, said the Dalai Lama was impressed by what he saw during his first trip to Taiwan on March 22-27 this year and hopes to have another opportunity to visit the island.

Thondup said he witnessed the national day celebration in 1946, 1947 and 1948 while he was studying in Nanking on the Chinese mainland. Now, 49 years later, he is attending the event for the fourth time. It is also the first time he has come to Taiwan for the Double Tenth celebration, so named because it falls on the tenth day of the tenth month each year.
Thondup denied his trip is related to a Tibetan religious fund to be established in the name of the Dalai Lama, and stressed that his visit was "private" in nature.

But he said that Tibetans have lived in exile in India for 38 years and need support and assistance for education, employment and care for the elderly, adding that many nations have generously extended a helping hand.
He cited as an example the fact that India and other members of the international community have helped over 30,000 Tibetans study languages in India.

As to whether the Dalai Lama plans to visit Taiwan again, Thondup said that there are many difficulties involved in arranging for the exiled spiritual leader to visit Taiwan. However, following his March visit, "the gate is open, and the chances will be greater in the future," Thondup said.

He said that the Dalai Lama was grateful and deeply moved by the treatment extended to him by the ROC government and by the concern shown by the public and religious circles. "He felt like he was coming back home," Thondup added.
The Dalai Lama is keen to visit Taiwan again, and to increase exchanges between the local society and the Tibetan community in religious and cultural fields, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATORS URGE CLINTON TO UPHOLD SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) Thursday cautioned President Bill Clinton that improvement of the United States' relationship with mainland China should not be achieved at the expense of US relations with Taiwan.

Speaking on the Senate floor, Murkowski noted that as Washington prepares for the Oct. 29 summit meeting between Clinton and his communist Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, there have been press reports speculating on how the US government would respond to possible demands by Jiang regarding US relations with Taiwan.

Murkowski said that while he welcomes Jiang's visit to the United States and supports regular high-level dialogue with Beijing, he believes that "improving relations with the PRC need not, and indeed should not, come at the expense of our relationship with Taiwan."

The Republican senator from Alaska requested that the letter he and 10 other senators sent to Clinton last week be inserted in the Congressional Record of Oct. 9. In that joint letter, the senators urged Clinton to oppose any efforts at the summit by Jiang to diminish American support for Taiwan.

"We urge you to reject any plans for a 'Fourth Communique' on issues related to Taiwan; not weaken our defensive arms sales commitment to Taiwan; and not make any commitment to limit future visits by the elected representatives of the Republic of China," the letter said.

The 11 senators, led by Murkowski, pointed out that Taiwan has achieved "extraordinary progress" in democratization, with free elections, free press, strong trade unions and improved trading practices.

"We believe the American people are united in their support for freedom and democracy on Taiwan. Time and again, Congress has made clear our commitment to Taiwan, beginning with the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, and through many resolutions and bills since then," they wrote in the letter of Sept. 23.
"We in Congress are prepared to reiterate the commitment of the American people to freedom and democracy for the people and government of Taiwan," they said.

Among the senators who signed the letter were Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.); Senate Minority Leader Tom Daschle (D-S.D.); Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; and Sen. Craig Thomas (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
In his floor statement Thursday, Murkowski again urged Clinton to respect the views of the 11 senators that America's support for Taiwan's democracy and freedom cannot be sacrificed.

Murkowski also encouraged the Clinton administration to send high-level officials to Taiwan to further strengthen bilateral relations and to "work out the occasional disputes that cloud our relationship."

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CONCLUDES VISITS TO ICELAND
DOC.DATELINE: Reykjavik, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Lien Chan and his 20-member entourage left for Copenhagen Thursday after concluding a four-day private visit to Iceland.
From the Danish capital, Lien and his party will proceed to an unconfirmed destination for the second-leg visit of his unexpected tour of Europe which began Oct. 5.
On Wednesday morning, Lien, braving the North Atlantic icy winds, played golf with Presidential Advisor Hsu Li-teh and ROC Representative in Denmark Chen Yu-chu.

At noon, the Lien delegation lunched with the former Miss Iceland, providing Mrs. Lien an opportunity to remember the days when she won fame for Taiwan and herself by representing the island in international beauty contests.

During Lien's stay in Iceland, Icelandic Prime Minister David Oddsson hosted a dinner at his summer residence in honor of the ROC vice president and his entourage despite a strong protest from Beijing.
Oddsson, who emphasized Iceland's policy of recognizing Beijing as the sole Chinese government, said he does not see why Iceland cannot host private visits by senior officials from Taiwan.

After some five days of wide reports by Icelandic media of Lien's visit and Beijing's protests, which were considered by locals as "confrontational and unnecessary," the Icelandic people have gained considerable knowledge of Taiwan and its officials.

Even reporters from Taiwan were welcomed warmly by local residents, indicating that Lien's "icebreaking" visit here has indeed won publicity for Taiwan and gained friendship from the Icelandic people.
Some local Chinese immigrants have started to plan the establishment of a travel agency in Reykjavik exclusively for luring Taiwan visitors to the scenic North Atlantic island country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE PRESIDES OVER NATIONAL DAY RALLY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui presided over a Double Tenth National Day rally held in the Presidential Office plaza in downtown Taipei on Friday.
Braving a drizzle, some 250,000 people, including foreign dignitaries, overseas Chinese, members of the armed forces and students, attended the event.

Addressing the rally, President Lee noted that through the joint efforts of its people on Taiwan, the Republic of China has overcome numerous adversities and has achieved prosperity in a free and democratic environment.
Lee said that Taiwan has created an economic miracle which will continue to develop under the government's ongoing project to develop the island into an Asian Pacific business operations hub.

Lee stressed that the ROC has fully realized its goal of political democratization within a free society and that it now wants to share its experience in developing the economy with other nations in the developing world.

He also said the ROC wants to promote cross-strait relations with mainalnd China, in the hope that Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can eventually achieve the goal of unification on the basis of freedom, democracy and equitable distribution of wealth.

He urged Beijing authorities to be pragmatic and face the fact that China is currently divided and ruled separately, and urged that they work hard to improve the welfare of all Chinese people on the mainland in order to create a win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
National Day celebrations included a performance by marching bands and a mass rally. They were followed by an hour-long parade.

The parade included musical performances, folk and aboriginal dances and a lion dance. A 192-member security task force, including 80 elite officers from the National Police Administration, demonstrated martial arts techniques and hand-to-hand combat skills.

A fireworks display was held near the Tamsui River in Taipei at night to highlight the festivities. (By Lilian Wu) ENDITEM ZCCZ CEP007 10-10-97 TAIWAN FILM DELEGATION RETURNING FROM SOUTH KOREA WITH AWARDS

Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA) Members of Taiwan's film delegation began returning home from Cheju Island, South Korea, Friday after winning six awards, including best picture, in the Asia-Pacific Film Festival.

Under a government incentive program to promote the local film industry, the producers of the award-winning picture "Such a Life," will receive a cash prize of NT$1 million (US$34,965) while its director Chang Chih-yung will receive NT$300,000 (US$10,490).

"Such a Life" depicts the tragedy of a poor village in southern Taiwan during the 1950s where the residents suffered from a condition known as "black foot disease," caused by drinking contaminated water.

Another film from Taiwan, "Ah Cha-cha the Fugitive," won three awards -- best cinematography, best editing and best sound. Taiwan's "Excessive for Beauty," an animated film created by five university students, won the award for best animation.
David Tawei Lee, director general of the Government Information Office, is expected to present the cash awards to the winners on Oct. 16.
Film directors Wang Xiao-ti and Tsai Ming-liang, two other members of the Taiwan delegation, proceeded from Cheju to Pusan, also in South Korea, for another film festival there.

Although members of the Taiwan delegation acknowledged the hospitality of the Cheju film festival organizers, they said the sponsors were apparently not overly interested in showing the films, as only a limited number of the festival entries were shown to audiences there.
Taiwan delegates said that the experience could be used as a reference for Taipei organizers when they host the 43rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DELEGATION ARRIVES IN GERMANY
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two separate delegations of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Taiwan's largest opposition party, arrived in Berlin and Bonn on Thursday for a series of meetings and activities.

One of the groups, led by DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, will take part in the worldwide "Berlin Meeting" during their three-day stay there. It will also call on a number of German political heavyweights, including Herbert Knoblich, speaker of the Brandenburg State Parliament.

The Berlin Meeting is being organized by the Friedrich Naumann Foundation under sponsorship of Germany's opposition Free Democratic Party. Chairmen of major political parties dedicated to freedom and democracy from 20 countries around the world have been invited to attend the gathering.

Hsu's group, which includes DDP Legislator Parris Chang, Department of International Affairs Director Hsiao Mei-chin and Finance Director Yan Huang Mei-hsin, is scheduled to fly to Bonn on Tuesday to join the other DPP visiting delegation headed by Sisy Chen, director of DPP's Department of Information.
Chen's five-member group is to start its activities in Bonn by participating in a reception to celebrate the Republic of China's Double Tenth National Day.

Chen, the DPP spokeswoman, told CNA that the visits are aimed at studying Germany's policies and programs concerning family matters. Her delegation will visit German Federal Ministry for Family Affairs for an overview of the European country's welfare system.

Legislator Liu Chin-hsing, a member of the delegation, said the delegation also want to gain firsthand knowledge of the German medical insurance system, so as to apply that experience to the operation of Taiwan's national health insurance program.

The delegation will join Hsu's group before they call on the mayor of Bonn and leaders of the Social Democratic Party (SPD), the major opposition party of Germany, on Monday. The entire DPP delegation will then proceed to France for a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKISH JETS BOMB PKK CAMPS IN NORTHERN IRAQ

TEXT.P: Turkish troops continued their operations in northern Iraq by attacking and destroying positions of the outlawed Kurdish Workers' Party (PKK) with jet fighters, according to military officials on Thursday.

High-ranking Turkish military officials in Ankara said that government forces have killed more than 500 PKK rebels since some 15,000 troops, backed by armored units and air power, crossed into northern Iraq three weeks ago.

The ethnic PKK separatists use bases in northern Iraq to strike across the border. More than 26,000 people have been killed in the past 13 years of conflict between Turkish government forces and the PKK.

Meanwhile, Iranian Deputy Speaker of Parliament and National High Security Council Secretary-General Hasan Ruhani said that, "the presence of Turkish armed forces in northern Iraq was having the effect of increasing tension in the region," Turkey's semi-official Anatolia news agency reported Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RATED AMONG THE WORLD'S HIGHEST IN SKIN CANCER AND SUICIDE

TEXT.P: Australia was rated as having the world's highest rate of melanoma and has one of the most frequent occurrences of colon cancer, male suicide and female homicide among 20 of the most developed countries, according to a new survey.
The survey, conducted by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, showed Australia and New Zealand shared the dubious distinction of having the world's top skin cancer death rates.

The Sydney Morning Herald today quoted a report by the institute as saying that: "Malignant melanoma is the cancer that has shown the most rapid increase in incidence amongst most white populations in the last several decades."

For every 100,000 Australian males, 24.2 had melanoma in the mid-1980s, rising to 30.9 in recent years, surpassing the rate of occurrence among non-Maori New Zealanders and white Americans, who had the next highest levels.
Australia and New Zealand have seen the largest post-World War II increase in deaths from melanoma, rising by about two percent a year from 1950 to 1989, the survey shows.

Australian females were level with Canadian women in having the third highest homicide rate out of the 20 developed countries at 1.3 per 100,000 population. The other countries surveyed had less than one female homicide per 100,000 population, but the United States was far higher with four per 100,000.

"Homicide is still a cause for alarm in Australia, but because the differential between the United States and the rest of the world is so large and the rates vary from year to year, it is not such a major issue as it is for the United States," said Michael de Looper of the institute.
Australia also had the fifth highest male suicide rate across all age groups, trailing Switzerland, France, Denmark and New Zealand.
For young Australian males, "the rate is consistently among the upper third of developed countries for which data are available," the report says.
Australia ranked sixth for both sexes with its death rate from colon cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC COINS LAUNCHED IN SYDNEY

TEXT.P: The first nine of a total 52 different Olympic coins commemorating the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games were launched in Sydney for sale to investors and collectors worldwide.

The Royal Australian Mint and the Gold Corporation-operated Perth Mint will produce 240,000 gold coins (priced at A$380 each), 1.6 million silver coins (priced at A$259 each) and 28 million aluminum-bronze coins (priced at A$8.95 each).

Gold Corporation chief executive Don Mackay-Coghill, who helped establish the South African krugerrand on world markets, said he is planning to market more than A$300 million worth of Olympic coins in 52 countries.
He believes the Olympic coins will be attractive to both investors and collectors and that the demand will be quite high.
The coins feature designs depicting various kinds of sports that comprise the Olympic Games, which Sydney will host in the year 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PART OF QUEBEC REFERENDUM LAW RULED UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court of Canada on Thursday struck down part of the Quebec referendum law that limits third party spending.
The decision could cause problems for Premier Lucien Bouchard of Quebec, who is facing a federal government challenge on the legality of the province's unilateral declaration of independence.

An angry Bouchard said the court was denying 20 years of Quebec history. Since the referendum law has been in force, Quebec's separatist governments have held but failed two referendums. Ottawa is trying to block a third attempt by Bouchard's separatist government.
The ruling says Quebec's referendum law imposes restrictions that are unjustifiable under the section of the Charter of Rights that guarantees freedom of expression.

The law said those who want to get involved in the referendum campaign have to spend money for either the "Yes" side or the "No" side. There were no provisions for people to mount independent campaigns.
The case was brought by Robert Libman, former leader of Quebec's Equality Party.
He had wanted to run his own campaign instead of supporting either the official Yes or No sides.
Bloc Quebecois MP Michel Bellehumeur said the ruling effectively destroys the referendum law. "What is left of the law?" he asked.
Lower courts ruled the law was a justifiable restriction on free speech because it was meant to prevent those who have the most money from dominating a campaign and dictating the outcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRIAN PROFESSOR LOOKS FORWARD TO VICE PRESIDENT LIEN'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Dr. Gunther Winkler, president of the Institute of Chinese Culture here, is looking forward to Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Austria, saying he will be "pleased to meet an old friend."

Former president of Vienna University and expert in constitutional law, Winkler also serves as president of the Institute of Chinese Culture here. The organization is dedicated to promoting relations between Austria and the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Winkler said he expects to exchange views with Lien on constitutional issues and human rights.

Lien is expected to arrive in Austria this weekend after concluding his visit to Reykjavik, Iceland. His scheduled 48-hour stay in Austria will also take him to Tyrol province in the western region of the country, an area known for its beautiful Alpine landscapes.
Winkler said he will accompany Lien throughout the visit, which he described as a "transit stop."

However, because there are no official relations between Austria and Taiwan, and Communist China has warned of "very serious consequences" for European host-countries that receive Lien, his planned trip to Austria remains hush-hush even on the eve of his expected arrival.
An Austrian Foreign Ministry spokesman said he knew nothing about the visit, and Taipei's representatives here refuse to make any comment.
Lien has visited Austria several times in the past, most recently as a transit passenger en route to Ukraine last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE EMPLOYMENT HITS TWO-YEAR HIGH; NO INTEREST RATE CUTS SEEN

TEXT.P: Australia's employment rate hit a two-year high and unemployment rate fell slightly in September, dashing the hope of further interest rate cuts, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures showed total employment in September rose by 74,700, sending the unemployment rate down to 8.6 percent from 8.7 percent in August.

The higher-than-expected employment rate dashed prospects for a sixth official interest rate cut this year and sent the Australian dollar higher on Thursday, closing at US$0.73, up 1.33 US cents from Wednesday.

But the Australian stock market took a beating with its All Ordinaries Index closing 46.2 points lower at 2722.2 on Thursday due to comments by US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who said a continued run in the US stock market was "unrealistic" and disagreed that the US economy was in an era of inflation-free growth.

Australian economists believed the Reserve Bank of Australia, which cut official interest rates to 5 percent from 7.5 percent from July 1996 to July 1997, is unlikely to make further cuts by the end of this year.
Australia's inflation, measured by the Consumer Price Index, is now below the government target of 2 percent to 3 percent. It stood at about 1.6 percent recently.
Economists and government officials believe Australia's economy could grow up to 4 percent or 4.5 percent in fiscal 1997-98, up from the earlier target of 3.75 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT URGES TAIWAN TO REMOVE OBSTACLES TO LIBERALIZATION

TEXT.P: The European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) has suggested in its latest report that Taiwan speed up the removal of obstacles to liberalization.
The Taipei-based ECCT on Thursday released the report, which reviews the government's progress toward making Taiwan an Asia-Pacific regional operations center (APROC).

The report said the path to the realization of Taiwan's APROC goal is beset with a number of obstacles, and recommended that the government first lift foreign equity ownership limitations in the transportation industry.

The ECCT has been making this suggestion to authorities here for years, saying that it is difficult for foreign carriers and forwarders to select Taiwan as a regional hub as long as those limitations exist.

The council also noted that although immigration and work permit laws and regulations are being liberalized, they still do not permit a number of nationalities easy entry. It said that government efficiency and the transparency of laws and regulations remain promising fields for improvements.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's cross-strait policies -- especially the "three no's" that forbid direct trade, transportation and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China -- "act as a significant disincentive for foreign companies to locate their regional operations in Taiwan," the ECCT said, noting, however, that these policies are "possibly necessary based on political considerations."

The ECCT, founded in early 1988, is the major representative body for European commercial interests in Taiwan. It is aimed at advancing and promoting European business interests on the island, mainly by providing a forum for discussion of major issues and concerns.

In its APROC evaluation report, the council on the other hand congratulated Taiwan on the fact that its economy is still healthy and robust in the wake of economic crises in several of its Southeast Asian neighbors.

ECCT Chief Executive Officer Theo Stiftl said, "Taiwan has been able to avoid the recent financial turbulence of other Asian countries and indeed is on its way towards a reported growth rate exceeding 6 percent for 1997, which is a good performance by any country's measures."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WON'T ANNOUNCE TAIWAN INDEPENDENT NATION: HSU
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's largest opposition party said in Berlin Thursday that even if his party assumes power it would not declare the independence of Taiwan nation since this would provoke mainland China and endanger the safety of the island.

Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said in a symposium titled "Democratization and Taiwan's Relations with the World", that as Taiwan is a de facto independent state, the DPP will not make any unnecessary declarations to provoke Beijing.

"The DPP takes a realistic stance in Taiwan's relations with mainland China," Hsu told over 100 German and Taiwan participants in the symposium sponsored by the Free University of Berlin, saying that the DPP wishes to see improvements in relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Hsu said that any dialogue and economic engagement with Beijing, however, must be conducted on the basis of mutual trust. "On the part of Taiwan, there must be a coordinated strategy between the government and the private sector," he added.
On Taiwan's foreign relations, Hsu said that while stable relations with Beijing should be Taipei's top foreign policy priority, the island must continue to develop ties with the rest of the world.

The United States and Japan are two of Taiwan's most important allies in the world, Hsu said, adding that even without diplomatic relations, Taiwan's trade and cultural ties with these two countries have been flourishing for years.

Hsu noted that Taiwan has not developed the same close ties with Europe as it has with the United States and Japan. The Europeans, however, have demonstrated their principled support for Taiwan in the resolution for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations, he said.

Hsu said that the DPP, founded in 1986, has made significant contributions to Taiwan's democracy. "The DPP has grown and matured over the past 11 years. We have adjusted ourselves to the changing nature of politics in Taiwan," he said.

"DPP members are no longer the martial-law-defying street activists but responsible politicians," Hsu said, while expressing confidence that the DPP is well on its way to becoming Taiwan's ruling party.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON-BEIJING SUMMIT TALKS WON'T HURT TAIWAN: RICHARD BUSH

TEXT.P: The summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin scheduled for Oct. 29 will not hurt the interests of Taiwan, a top US official on Taiwan affairs said on Thursday.

Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), made the remarks in response to questions from reporters while attending a party hosted by the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. to mark the ROC's "Double Tenth" National Day.
Bush said that his impression is that the Clinton administration believes that the upcoming Washington-Beijing summit talks will not hurt Taiwan in any respect.
Jiang's coming visit to the United States has aroused concern over how the US government will respond to possible demands by Jiang regarding US relations with Taiwan.

Eleven senators, including Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss) and Senate Minority Leader Tom Daschle (D-S.D.) urged Clinton in a joint letter to oppose any attempts by Jiang at the summit to diminish American support for Taiwan.
Jason Hu, ROC representative to the United States, also said that the US government has assured Taipei on several occasions that the summit talks will not hurt Taiwan's interests.
Hu said that he has faith in the US government's good intentions and sincerity, but added that Taiwan should be careful about Beijing's possible attempts to damage Taiwan-US relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TEXTILE INDUSTRY FACING THREAT FROM SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The recent currency crises in Southeast Asia has caused a significant drop in the region's textile export quotations, posing a serious threat to the fourth quarter operations of Taiwan's chemical fiber industry.

The lowering of quotations by Southeast Asian chemical fiber manufacturers has resulted in a dramatic slide in the selling prices of Asian polyester yarns, polyester chips and polyester fibers, said a source from Taiwan's Far Eastern Textile Corp., adding that domestic chemical fiber and yarn-processing manufacturers will have to narrow their export quotations gap to equal those of Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand or face the prospect of stagnancy in the textile industry.

Another industry source said that quotations of Southeast Asian chemical fiber plants have fallen about 20 percent in less than a month, encouraging international businessmen to aggressively shift their orders to Southeast Asia.

The drop in export prices has also affected the textile market here. Because export orders have fallen off recently, domestic textile industry executives have turned to the local market, causing a drop in domestic product prices.

In addition, the selling back to the island by overseas Taiwan businessmen of products manufactured in Southeast Asia at lower prices has forced domestic producers to further cut prices, overshadowing the textile sector's fourth quarter operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HOSTS NATIONAL DAY PARTY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Foreign Minister John Chang hosted a cocktail party at the Taipei Guest House on Friday evening in celebration of the Republic of China's 86th Oct. 10 National Day.
About 6,000 guests, including foreign dignitaries, members of the foreign diplomatic corps and government officials attended the party.

Among the foreign well-wishers were Tuvalu Prime Minister Bikenibeu Paniu, Tonga's Prince Ma'atu, Deputy Speaker Maria Lydia Sanchez Valverde of the Costa Rican parliament, Deputy Speaker Andris Ameriks of the Latvian parliament, Deputy Speaker Antonio V. Cuenco of the Philippines' House of Representatives and former Russian first deputy prime minister E.O. Lobov.

Government officials attending the celebrations included National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh and National Security Council Secretary General Ting Mou-shih, as well as lawmakers and representatives of overseas Chinese communities around the world.
Earlier in the day, President Lee Teng-hui and his wife received some 170 well-wishers at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTERS EXPRESS FAITH IN ASIA'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: Economics ministers of 25 Asian and European nations give a clear but qualified thumbs-up for long-term growth in Asia, despite the recent currency turmoil that started in Thailand, a Japanese economic news magazine reported in its current issue which went on sale on Friday.

At an Asia-Europe Meeting held in Japan late last month, the ministers also urged smoother investment and trade between the two regions so that both can maintain sustainable growth, the Nikkei weekly said.

Economists said the announcement would itself have a salutary effect on the stabilization of Southeast Asian economies. They also agreed that the long-term potential of the region would not be damaged by the currency crisis. They cited the region's high savings rates, sound elementary education and significant infrastructure development over the past decade.

Still, they said Southeast Asian economies cannot avoid a short-term slowdown in direct foreign investment and economic growth. To regain global investor confidence, leaders in the region must embark on economic and financial structural reform, economists said. They also warn that liberalization, a means of honing international competitiveness, should not be delayed.

DOC.HEADLINE: STILL ROOM FOR FURTHER TIES BETWEEN ROC AND AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: There is still room for further development and cooperation in trade, investment and other ties between the Republic of China and Australia, according to the ROC envoy in Canberra.

In a speech marking the ROC's National Day on Friday, Wang Kuo-jan, acting representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canberra, said the bilateral relationship between the ROC and Australia is "healthy and friendly."
He said two-way trade was worth A$6 billion, with Australia enjoying a trade surplus of about A$1 billion in 1996.

"While this is a substantial amount, we should bear in mind that it represents only 2.1 percent of the ROC's total world trade. Clearly, then, there is still much room for further development and cooperation," he said.
Wang said the ROC economy has entered "a new growth circle." He said growth in 1997 will be 6.58 percent, the seventh-highest in the world, and will further grow to 6.7 percent in 1998.
More than 400 guests, including Australian businessmen, government officials, scholars, politicians and overseas Chinese leaders and students from Taiwan attended the celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK OF TAIWAN RANKS 11TH ON LIST OF TOP 20 ASIAN BANKS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Conrad Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Bank of Taiwan has been ranked 11th on the Bankers Magazine's list of the top 20 Asian banks excluding those from Japan, with total assets of US$3.59 billion.
Bankers Magazine is a periodical published by the Financial Times news service and the list appears in its October issue.
Two mainland Chinese banks -- Bank of China and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China -- occupy the top two positions on the list, with two others making the top 10.
The top 10 rankings are as follows:
1. Bank of China (mainland China, with total assets of US$13.74 billion)
2. Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, (mainland China, US$11.17 billion)
3. National Australian Bank (Australia, US$8.04 billion)
4. Commonwealth Bank (Australia, US$6.13 billion)
5. People's Construction Bank of China (mainland China, US$5.48 billion)
6. West Pacific (mainland China, US$5.05 billion)
7. ANZ Bank (Australia, US$4.97 billion)
8. Development Bank of Singapore (Singapore, US$4.96 billion)
9. Agricultural Bank of China (mainland China, US$4.83 billion)
10.Overseas Chinese Bank (Singapore, US$4.36 billion)

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDELA CONGRATULATES ROC ON NATIONAL DAY
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: South Africa President Nelson Mandela sent a message of congratulations to his Republic of China counterpart Lee Teng-hui on Friday in celebration of the ROC's 86th Oct. 10 National Day.
Mandela's message expressed his hope of enhanced cooperation and relations between the ROC and South Africa.

Rusty Evans, South Africa's chief executive foreign officer, read the message, along with a congratulatory note from Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, at a reception jointly sponsored by the ROC Embassy to South Africa and the ROC Consulate General in Johannesburg.

More than 1,000 guests, including South African officials, police and military leaders, legislators, trade and industrial executives, foreign envoys and heads of Chinese organizations in the country, attended the reception.

ROC Ambassador Loh I-cheng delivered an address to the guests in which he described the ROC's economic growth and political system aimed at achieving democracy and pursuing freedom. He stressed his country will keep fighting for its space in the international community and maintain efforts to safeguard human rights, freedom and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN FIRST LADY TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Paraguayan first lady Maria Teresa Carrasco de Wasmosy is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 15 for a five-day visit at the invitation of the Republic of China government.
This will be Mrs. Wasmosy's first trip to the Republic of China, although her husband, President Juan Carlos Wasmosy, has visited Taiwan on two previous occasions.

Paraguayan Ambassador Ceferino Valdez Peralta told CNA on Saturday that the ROC first lady, Mrs. Lee Tseng Wen-hui, invited Mrs. Wasmosy to visit Taiwan when she accompanied President Lee Teng-hui on a state visit to Paraguay in mid-September.
Valdez said Mrs. Wasmosy will be accompanied by several Paraguayan officials and the wife of Paraguay's minister of foreign affairs on her Taiwan trip.
While here, Mrs. Wasmosy will meet with President Lee and his wife and other senior officials, in addition to examining Taiwan's charity programs.
Valdez said Mrs. Wasmosy has long dedicated herself to charitable work as part of her efforts to help resolve the serious wealth gap problem in Paraguay.
The ambassador said Mrs. Wasmosy will also visit Shihtung Elementary School in suburban Taipei to spend some time with the expatriate Paraguayan children who are studying there.
Paraguay is the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America and the two countries enjoy close and cordial relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR FORECAST FOR TAIWAN'S CHIP MAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-tech industry was wrong when it bet last year that global demand for semiconductor chips would have emerged from a prolonged slump by now, The Wall Street Journal said on Friday in a report from Taipei.

As a result, the paper said, some of Taiwan's star electronics companies are bleeding money. While more-established rivals in Japan and South Korea have been curbing production, Taiwan's memory-chip makers face a murky future, it added.

According to the paper, Texas Instruments-Acer Inc., Taiwan's biggest maker of DRAM chips, chalked up losses of NT$667 million (US$23.4 million) in the first half of the year, compared with an NT$l.1 billion profit for all of 1996. The company, a joint venture between Acer Inc., Taiwan's biggest computer maker, and Texas Instruments Inc. of Dallas, recently slashed profit forecasts by 82 percent for the year.
Another semiconductor maker, Nan Ya Technology, a unit of Nan Ya Plastics Corp., predicts losses of at least NT$400 million, partly because of falling chip prices.
The drawn-out downturn is prompting some to question the long-term viability of Taiwan's semiconductor industry as it now stands.

To the nation's great pride, it pointed out, Taiwan has morphed from a maker of cheap goods and copycat items into the world's number four manufacturer of memory chips. "As latecomers to an industry dominated by giants from Japan, South Korea and the US, Taiwan companies found their niche by developing first-rate manufacturing processes to produce chips no longer profitable for others."

Taiwan's technological lag is most punishing when the chips are down, as now, the paper said. For a semiconductor factory, costs are determined chiefly by how many chips it's able to cut from a single silicon wafer; the more advanced its technology, the more chips it can produce per wafer and the more efficient the production process.

The escalating costs and exhausting pace of new technology could push some Taiwan players out of the business altogether, the report predicted, warning that in fact, the single-minded push to win market share could further delay any recovery in chip prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERIOUS GRAVEL SHORTAGE PREDICTED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is facing a serious gravel shortage next year, due to a depletion of gravel supplies from local rivers, according to a draft report by experts unveiled on Saturday.

The report, commissioned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), said local rivers are traditionally the main source of Taiwan gravel, but that the government has gradually banned gravel mining in several areas out of consideration of land and water conservation.

The report listed 25 rivers in Taiwan which could provide nearly 590 million tons of gravel. But with the depletion of gravel in central and northern Taiwan, there is no more gravel left there for mining. There are still about 27 million tons of gravel left in rivers in southern Taiwan, with around 280 million tons in central and eastern Taiwan respectively, but judging from demand in the local construction industry, supplies are expected to last only until the end of the year.

This means the supply of gravel will decline sharply, with shortages estimated to be between at least 4,000 and 5,000 tons per year, starting from 1998, a situation which will be further exacerbated by the construction of the new high-speed rail system between Taipei and Kaohsiung next year.

The shortage has caused the price of gravel to skyrocket, with sources saying that gravel mined from the Chouzuei River in Central Taiwan has risen from NT$52 (US$1.8) per ton in 1995 to NT$90 in 1997. Prices in northern Taiwan are even higher, in some cases surpassing NT$200 per ton.
In order to meet local demand, the MOEA has permitted gravel imports from other nations, in addition to lifting a ban on gravel imports from mainland China.

But sources say the cost of importing gravel is high, while importing from the mainland presents its own problems, since under the present policy, the government still bans direct cross-strait shipping. This means that mainland gravel has to be routed through a third country before it can enter Taiwan through Keelung Harbor in the north or Kaohsiung Harbor in the south.

With the handling capacity at these two international ports reaching saturation, the sources stressed the importance for the government to focus on opening more local ports and improving related wharf facilities, adding that the report has suggested that the government consider allowing imports through Anping and Putai Harbors in southern Tainan County, and Tamsui Harbor in northern Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICEMEN RECEIVE NEW BULLET-PROOF VESTS

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) has provided 12,000 new bullet-proof vests to Taiwan's police, following a rash of recent gun battles between the police and armed criminals which have resulted in the deaths of several policemen.

Police were elated to don the new vests, saying that they now felt much safer. They described the new vests as being more flexible and more adjustable than the old ones, as well as being lighter, the weight having been cut to 2.5 kilograms from the original 3.25 kilograms.
The old-style vests are notorious for their poor elasticity and clumsiness, making it difficult for the officer to use his radio or even draw his gun.
However, since there are currently more than 47,000 policemen on regular patrol, 35,000 of them will have to continue wearing the old vests for the time being until more new ones are delivered.

The NPA said that the old vests were purchased before 1994 and some of them have already passed their expiry dates. The new vests arrived only recently after extensive safety testing in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG AIRPORT OPENS NEW TERMINAL

TEXT.P: Taichung Airport officially opened its new terminal Saturday.
At the opening ceremony, Transportation and Communications Minister Tsay Jaw-yang said the building will help expand the transportation capacity of central Taiwan.
Beginning next year, there will be direct flights from the new terminal to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan to facilitate transportation between the two areas.
The original terminal was built 25 years ago. The 900 square-meter building has seen increasing traffic, especially since 1989, when the government amended laws to open sky.
In 1994, the terminal processed some 800,000 passenger departures. By 1996, that figure had doubled.

In order to meet the airport's growing needs, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications budgeted a new terminal for it in 1993, Tsay said, noting that the terminal's total cost was NT$250 million (US$8.7 million).
Vice Premier John Chang and Tsai Tuei, director general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, as well as Taichung City Mayor Lin Puo-jung and several legislators also took part in the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SYSTEMATIC CHANNEL URGED FOR HK-TAIWAN COMMUNICATION
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Cheng An-kuo, Taiwan's top representative in Hong Kong, said on Friday that Taiwan and Hong Kong should establish a systematic communication channel to lay a more solid foundation for relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Cheng made the remarks in a speech he delivered at a party marking the Oct. 10 National Day of the Republic of China in Hong Kong.

Cheng said that in the 100 days since the handover of the former British colony to mainland China, relations between Taiwan and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) have remained more or less the same, following the establishment between the two sides of a more open and official communication channel.

He stressed however that the present framework of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations does not fully reflect the current situation, which includes over two million visits and US$29 billion in trade volume between the two sides.
He advocated that Taiwan and Hong Kong build a more normal, stable and comprehensive relationship in order to lay the foundation for more solid cross-strait relations.

Paul Yip, special adviser to HKSAR Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa, said on the same occasion that relations between the HKSAR and Taiwan are bound to move forward, expressing the hope that both sides will work to overcome their difficulties.
Yip, who has been authorized by Tung to liaison with Cheng on Hong Kong and Taiwan relations, said he has no difficulty in communicating with Cheng.
Yip's presence at the party aroused attention, but he behaved discreetly and did not address those present, even though invited to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CLOSELY MONITORING BEIJING'S ACTIVITIES IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang said on Saturday that the traditional cordial relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay will not be affected by the development of Beijing-Asuncion trade ties.
Chang was commenting on reports that mainland China will open a commercial office in Paraguay, the only South American country to recognize Taipei rather than Beijing.
Chang said the ROC and Paraguay have enjoyed long-standing close and amicable relations which will not be easily affected by sabotage by mainland China.

"Our relations with Paraguay are firm and solid," Chang said, adding that Paraguayan first lady Maria Teresa Carrasco de Wasmosy is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 15 for a five-day visit at the invitation of the ROC government.
Chang went on to say he is convinced that even if Paraguay reinforces commercial ties with mainland China, it won't have a serious negative impact on official Taipei-Asuncion relations.
Mainland China has been courting Paraguay very intensively, in an attempt to lure away the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America.
Chang said ROC diplomatic officials have long been closely monitoring Beijing's activities in Paraguay.

Meanwhile, Paraguayan Ambassador Ceferino Valdez Peralta told CNA on Saturday that Mrs. Wasmosy will be accompanied by several Paraguayan officials and the wife of Paraguay's minister of foreign affairs on her Taiwan trip.
This will be Mrs. Wasmosy's first visit to Taiwan, although her husband, President Juan Carlos Wasmosy, has visited Taiwan on two previous occasions.

While here, Mrs. Wasmosy will meet with President Lee and his wife and other senior officials, in addition to examining Taiwan's charity programs. She will also visit Shihtung Elementary School in suburban Taipei to spend some time with the expatriate Paraguayan children who are studying there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US HELD HIGH-LEVEL MEETING IN NEW YORK IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Senior officials from the Republic of China on Taiwan and the United States met in New York in late August to discuss matters of mutual concern, sources revealed for the first time on Saturday.

According to the sources, Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, made an overseas trip before the start of President Lee Teng-hui's two-week, four-country Latin American tour in early September.
The sources said Ding represented Taiwan in high-level consultations with the United States during his August trip.

Although Ding himself would not confirm that the purpose of his trip was to meet with high-ranking American officials, a senior government official told the CNA that there are no major stumbling-blocks to high-level dialogue between Taipei and Washington.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, ROC-US communications channels are smooth and effective. "The two sides can fully exchange opinions and views on all topics of mutual concern," the official said.
The agenda of the August meeting was not divulged, but informed sources said the topics discussed might have focused on the three-way Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.
