In March 1996 when mainland China was conducting missile tests and war games in waters near Taiwan in the run-up to the ROC's first-ever direct presidential election, Ding, who once served as ROC minister of foreign affairs and de facto ambassador to the US, also made a secret trip to New York to meet with Samuel Berger, then US deputy national security adviser. Shortly after the Ding-Berger meeting, the US sent two aircraft carrier battle groups to waters near the Taiwan Strait and the missile crisis soon ended peacefully.

The complex and delicate relations have again become a focus of attention these days, as mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is scheduled to make an official visit to the United States in late October, during which he will meet with US President Bill Clinton to discuss a variety of issues.

Jiang will be the first mainland leader to hold a summit meeting with his American counterpart since the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in which mainland Chinese troops brutally cracked down on pro-democracy student demonstrators in Beijing.

Taiwan is concerned as to whether the upcoming Clinton-Jiang meeting will undermine ROC national interests. Jason Hu, outgoing ROC representative to the US, has repeatedly reminded the Clinton administration that the United States, while engaging with communist China, should not impair Taiwan's legitimate rights and interests.
Hu will return to Taipei later this month to assume the ROC's top diplomatic post as minister of foreign affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND LEADERS WORRY FINANCIAL CRISIS IS IMMINENT

TEXT.P: The leaders of mainland China's State Council and the People's Bank have warned repeatedly since the turn of the year that steps must be taken to avert a looming financial disaster.

The Chinese Rural Development, Trust & Investment Corp., whose total assets exceeded 20 billion yuan (US$2.4 billion), was ordered closed in the first quarter of this year because of illegal lending and having more than 10 billion yuan (US$1.2 billion) in irrecoverable credits.
State-owned enterprises being unable to repay loans has become common in mainland China, which has worsened the financial situation there.

According to the Beijing Financial Times -- sponsored by major mainland banks, including the People's Bank -- the total amount various financial organizations loaned illegally last year might exceed 690 billion yuan (US$83 billion).

Beijing authorities have thus been on their guard against financial crises this year. In his State of the Nation report in March, mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng said "harnessing the stock and futures markets and enhancing awareness of financial risk" would be the focus of his administration.
Meanwhile, Vice Premier Zhu Rongji told a panel discussion at the National People's Congress that financial systems should support all efforts to promote law and order and ward off financial crises.
In addition, the Supreme People's Court and Supreme People's Procuratorate both stressed their crackdowns against financial criminals in their annual reports in March.
Over a hundred experts in the fields of finance and law attending a recent seminar in Shanghai on the prevention of financial crises confirmed the crisis facing the mainland banking system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAKES DONATION FOR PARAGUAY'S ADMINISTRATIVE MODERNIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Sheng Li-kuo & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has donated US$100,000 to help Paraguay's Foreign Ministry establish computer networks that will help modernize the ministry.
Liu Tin-tsu, ROC Ambassador to Paraguay, formally made the donation Thursday on behalf of his government.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TO TIGHTEN FLIGHT SAFETY MEASURES

TEXT.P: ROC Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Huang Hsien-jung visited major military air bases on Saturday to chair seminars on flight safety measures, an Air Force spokesman said.
The spokesman said Huang has asked Air Force staff to make a comprehensive review of operations, training and logistic support in order to ensure flight safety.

Huang also drummed up the morale of Air Force personnel by encouraging them to redouble their efforts to complete their assignments and prevent the recurrence of any flight accidents, the spokesman said.

The spokesman said the Air Force has set up a temporary memorial hall at Taipei's Sungshan Domestic Airport for its five officers who were killed in a C-130 military transport plane crash near the airport on Friday.
The flight recorder on the ill-fated aircraft has been recovered, the spokesman said, adding that China Airlines will assist in decoding the data recorded in the device, also known as a black box.

If all goes well, the spokesman said, the cause of Friday's crash will become clear within a week. If China Airlines cannot decode the flight data, the spokesman said, the black box will then be sent to the United States for decoding.
The spokesman also said the bereaved family of each of the five deceased Air Force officer will be able to receive about NT$12 million (US$420,000) in consolation, compensation and pension funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN AUSTRIA FOR 2-DAY VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Vienna, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By C. L. Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Lien Chan arrived in Vienna from Copenhagen late Friday for a two-day private visit.
Lien was accompanied by his wife and a small entourage composed of officials, Lien's personal aides and academics.
Lien was greeted by Hsia Tien, ROC representative to Austria, and Dr. Gunther Winkler, first president of the Institute of Chinese Culture, at the Vienna airport.
Lien and his entourage will travel to a tourist area in western Austria near the border with Italy on Saturday for a one-day sight-seeing trip.
Lien had visited Iceland before coming to Austria. Earlier reports said Lien may travel to Spain for a private visit following his Austria trip, but Lien would not confirm such reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER OFFERS TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Government spokesman David Tawei Lee confirmed on Saturday that Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling has tendered his resignation to the Executive Yuan.
Lee said Premier Vincent Siew has not yet personally read Chiang's resignation because he was out of town to stump for Kuomintang candidates for the year-end mayoral and county magistrate elections.
However, Lee said, Chang You-hui, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, already informed Siew by telephone at Saturday noon of Chiang's offer to resign.
Siew is not expected to handle the issue until Monday, Lee said.

Reports said Chiang has decided to resign after a number of tragic accidents took place in the military in recent months. The latest incident involved the crash of a C-130 transport plane on Friday, in which five Air Force officers were killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR INDUSTRIAL ZONES TO BE ESTABLISHED IN EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Four industrial zones will be established in eastern Taiwan to facilitate economic development in the region, an official of the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said here Saturday.
He said the government has attached great importance to the development of the region, which lags far behind the western side of the island in industrial development.
Vice President Lien Chan urged entrepreneurs to move their bio-chemical and other high-tech industries to eastern Taiwan when he visited Hualien recently.
The official said his industrial development bureau adopted a plan to promote economic development in eastern Taiwan in June.
Under the plan, four industrial zones will be developed first to facilitate the establishment news factories in the region, which includes Yilan county, Hualien county, and Taitung county.

The Ho Ping Industrial Zone in Hualien will occupy 317.3 hectares. Total investment in the zone will amount to NT$22.5 billion (US$803.5 million). The other three are Feng Lin Industrial Zone, Li Chia Industrial Zone, and Chih Shang Industrial Zone. The three industrial zones will accomodate at least 2,000 manufacturers, the official said. He did not elaborate.

The government has adopted another plan to provide soft loans to investors in order to help develop tourism, information, communications, consumer electronics, semiconductor, precision machinery, aerospace, special chemical and pharmaceutical, medical, biotech, and other industries in the region. The loans will mature in 12 years, he said.
The government has also mapped out a plan to build new infrastructure in the region, he added. (by Ed Shay)

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PRIZE TO ADD PRESSURE ON LAND MINE PACT HOLDOUTS

TEXT.P: This year's Nobel Peace Prize should pressure more countries to join a ban on land mines, said a leading Canadian official.
Lloyd Axworthy, Canada's foreign affairs minister, called the awarding of the prize to the International Campaign to Ban land mines "good news."

Axworthy, himself considered a candidate for the prize because of his efforts on the diplomatic front, said he was not personally disappointed. He added he's delighted the Nobel committee had recognized the land mine issue, a recognition that should help move Ottawa's treaty process along.

In December, representatives from more than 90 countries will gather in Canada's capital to sign a treaty banning the use of anti-personal land mines. But such significant players as mainland China and the United States have been refusing to sign on.
Axworthy said the awarding of the prestigious prize on the issue should increase the diplomatic pressure on the holdout countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE HOPES PRIZE WILL ADD TO MOMENTUM AGAINST LAND MINES

TEXT.P: Nobel Peace Prize winner Jody Williams hopes the attention brought by the prestigious award will put pressure on more countries to sign a treaty to ban land mines.
She and the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines share this year's Nobel Peace Prize, which was announced Friday.

The United States is the most significant holdout on an international agreement banning land mines. Canada and its foreign affairs minister, Lloyd Axworthy, pushed on the diplomatic front for other countries to sign the treaty. The signing is scheduled to take place in Ottawa in December.

Axworthy, along with leading mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng, were among the nominees for this year's peace prize. Axworthy said with the award in hand, Williams may be able to mobilize a broader range of people toward the goal.
The movement to ban land mines was a favorite of Diana, Princess of Wales. She helped attract media attention to the cause, with trips this year to Angola and Bosnia.
The campaign began six years ago, launched by a few non-governmental aid agencies. Today it is championed by more than 100 countries and 1,000 aid agencies and humanitarian groups.

But big countries like the United States, Russia and mainland China have not joined the move championed by Canada, Britain, France, Germany and other middle powers and smaller countries to ban the weapons.
It is estimated that about 26,000 people are killed by land mines each year, most of them civilians. Thousands of others are maimed.
Russian President Boris Yeltsin indicated Friday that Russia will sign the international land mine treaty.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLUMNIST SEES FLICKERING HOPE FOR TIBETAN LIBERATION

TEXT.P: The slaughter of perhaps a million Tibetans and the continuing occupation of Tibet by mainland China has been one of the most ignored chapters of a century which is too full of similar atrocities.
One Canadian columnist hopes the movie "Seven Years in Tibet," which opens in Canada on Friday, will bring a flickering hope for Tibet's liberation.
Paul Stanway, writing for the Edmonton Sun, said a half-century of Tibetan protest has hardly made a dent in the international indifference.

The Dalai Lama has traveled the world urging governments to put pressure on mainland China -- to no great effect. Nations like Canada are more interested in doing business with mainland China than in complaining about Chinese depredations in one of the world's most remote countries, Stanway pointed out.

But that may be about to change. Hollywood has discovered Tibet and seems set to make it the cause du jour. The are no less than five other movies about Tibet due to follow "Seven Years" into movie theaters in the next year, he said.
For better or worse, people who couldn't find the Himalayas on a map are about to get a crash course in recent Tibetan history and international indifference, he noted.

Would mainland China respond to significant international pressure to quit Tibet? "We don't know, because there has never been any. But Tibet is certainly no longer as strategically important as it once was as a buffer between China and India. It's worth a try," he said.
If Mel "Braveheart" Gibson can give impetus to Scottish nationalism, maybe Brad Pitt can liberate Tibet. Stranger things have happened, he said.
In the movie, Pitt plays the part of Austrian explorer, climber and national icon Heinrich Harrer, a vocal voice of Tibetan protests against mainland China.

Now in his 80s, Harrer has for years been lauded as the epitome of the new, liberal, post-war Austria. Rugged and fearless, an Olympic skier, champion golfer and a member of the climbing team that made the legendary first ascent of the north face of the Eiger -- the deadliest peak in the Alps -- Harrer was the personification of Germanic manhood, Stanway said.

He was also a staunch proponent of Third World development, a pal of the Dalai Lama and admirer of pacifist Buddhism. Best of all, perhaps, he had spent the war years in internment in India and exile in Tibet -- the subject of the movie.

But renewed media interest in Harrer, spurred by the movie, prompted the German magazine Stern to take a look into his past. It turns out he became a Nazi in 1933 and also joined the SS, Stanway reported.

However, the movie is not about Harrer's motives for going to Tibet or whether there may have been some darker agenda (such as SS boss Heinrich Himmler's nutty belief that Tibetans were lost Aryans who might assist Germany in driving the British from India).
In exile he mellows, forms an affectionate relationship with Tibet's young god-king, the Dalai Lama, and seems genuinely horrified by its bloody annexation by the communist Chinese.
Which is what this movie is really about, Stanway said.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA SUFFERING FROM UNPRECEDENTED UNEMPLOYMENT WOES

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese state-owned enterprises failed to pay more than 10 million workers their wages in the first quarter of this year.

In addition, there are over nine million skilled workers out of work in mainland China, and an additional 30 million people employed in state-owned firms are seen as redundant workers who may well lose their jobs.
Even the Beijing news media have been reporting that the unemployment situation in mainland China is of unprecedented seriousness.

Since mainland China began implementing reform and open-door policies 19 years ago, its economy has experienced rapid growth while employment conditions have worsened. During 1978-1984, the growth rate of the mainland GDP was 3.3 times that of employment; but during 1985-1993, the difference enlarged almost 13-fold.

Local officials and heads of state-owned enterprises have suggested that increasing investment and easing monetary credit would be the only ways to decrease the deficits of state-owned enterprises and ease the growth of unemployment.
But a leading mainland economist, Dai Yuan-chen, opposes that suggestion and has argued that an over-supply of labor is an old problem for mainland China and one that will remain in the future.

However, Dai confessed that state-owned enterprises -- which employ 80 to 90 percent of the working populace -- not only can't absorb more workers but also are being forced by two consecutive years of losses to release redundant workers.

The high rate of unemployment in mainland China is exacerbated by the mentality of the unemployed, some of whom prefer receiving a minimum living allowance from the government to joining the private sector's work force, Dai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIREWORKS ACCIDENT IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN LEAVES ONE DEAD

TEXT.P: Celebrations of the Republic of China's Double Tenth National Day were marred Friday evening by a fireworks accident that left one man dead.

A Kaohsiung resident identified as Chiang Chin-teh, 36, was watching a Double Tenth fireworks display from the grounds of the Kaohsiung Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center when he was struck by a firework that fell from the sky after it failed to detonate.

He was rushed to a hospital where he received emergency surgery but was later declared brain dead. According to doctors in charge of the case, Chiang had lost too much blood and had been wounded too seriously in the intestines to be saved.
Chiang is survived by his wife, a son studying in primary school and a one-year daughter.
Earlier in the day, another tragedy struck Taiwan when an Air Force plane crashed at Taipei's Sungshan Domestic Airport, killing all five crew members on board and injuring two persons on the ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, THAI MONKS DEPORTED FROM INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Indonesian immigration authorities deported five Buddhist monks from Taiwan and Thailand on Friday for misusing their immigration permits, an official here said.

The Antara news agency quoted Zaiman Nurmatias, Indonesia's director for immigration control and law enforcement, as saying the monks were detained in Sumatra on Oct. 2 after being caught distributing religious brochures.
The monks had been in Indonesia since Aug. 20.
Immigration office also seized two Afghan nationals earlier this month for collecting donations at mosques and residential homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO REDOUBLE EFFORTS TO BUILD ROC INTO DEVELOPED NATION

TEXT.P: The government will step up efforts to build the Republic of China into a developed nation by the year 2000, according to high-ranking Executive Yuan officials.
That commitment is one of the policy priorities of the new Cabinet under Premier Vincent Siew, who assumed office on Sept. 1.
The Cabinet will also focus on carrying through the recent round of constitutional reform to establish a responsible and efficient government, as well as to ensure a stable system of party politics.

Energy will also be expended to realize the trans-century plan to build Taiwan into a high-tech island and an Asia-Pacific regional operations center (APROC) in order to further enhance Taiwan's economic strength.
On international front, the government will continue to promote "pragmatic diplomacy" to seek a proper status and role for the nation within the global community.

In addition, it will seek to upgrade the combat-readiness of the armed forces to safeguard national security and to ensure strategic equilibrium with the mainland in the interest of peace and improved relations across the Taiwan Strait.

With regard to internal affairs, the government will pursue a program of educational reform and high-tech development. It is committed to bringing an improvement in social order so that people may enjoy a better quality of life, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPING NATIONS MAY NOT BE REQUIRED TO CUT EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: A preparatory group for an upcoming United Nations conference on global climatic change may ignore a United States request that developing countries be obligated to cut greenhouse gas emissions after the year 2000, according to a report from the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Saturday.

The group plans to recommend that targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions be imposed on developed nations in order to combat global warming. However, they will not be required to take concrete measures, such as imposing carbon taxes, the report from the Geneva-based trade regulatory body said.

This position is being considered in a draft protocol compiled by the chairman, Raul Estrade Oyuela, who is in charge of mapping out reduction targets for the third Conference on the Parties of UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, to be hosted by Japan in Kyoto from Dec. 1-10.

Japan, the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand recently discussed the position at ministerial meetings in Honolulu, and it will be further discussed in talks to be held starting Oct. 22 in Berlin.

At the urging of pro-business members of the Republican Party, the US government is demanding that binding targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions within a certain period be imposed on developing countries as well as industrialized nations. But the chairman did not take up the US request, the WTO report said.
The chairman is hoping to require not only developed countries but also nations like South Korea and Mexico to reduce greenhouse gas emissions under certain conditions.

He is not planning to include in the protocol a demand by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) that developed countries compensate OPEC members because anti-global warming measures will reduce oil consumption, the WTO report said, citing opposition by developed nations and the difficulty of arranging such compensation.
His draft protocol says deliberations on proposed trading of quotas for carbon dioxide emissions between developed and developing countries will be postponed until 2000 or later, the WTO report said.

It has been proposed that when industrialized countries help developing nations reduce carbon dioxide emissions through technological assistance or other measures, the developed countries should be allowed extra emissions equivalent to the amount of the reductions.
At the UN Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, about 150 nations signed a nonbinding convention which aims at reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2000.
At the Kyoto conference, signatory countries are scheduled to adopt a protocol imposing legally binding numerical targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions beyond 2000.
The European Union has proposed that global emission targets for 2010 be set 15 percent below 1990 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROUND OF ROC-US WTO TALKS SOON

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and the United States will meet here on Thursday for a new round of talks on the terms of the island's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources with the Economic Affairs Ministry said Sunday.

Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Trade (BOFT) and David Burn, the US Trade Representative Office's director for Asian-Pacific affairs, will head their respective delegations during the week-long negotiations.

Topics to be raised will include Taiwan's system of government procurements and tariff reductions, as well as the opening of local agricultural, insurance, stock brokerage, telecommunications and service markets, the sources said.
The last round of the talks in January ended in a deadlock after the US side backtracked on an earlier consensus by demanding that Taiwan allow imports of additional farm products.

Moreover, citing an outbreak of mouth-and-foot disease on local hog farms in March, the US has seized upon the opportunity to urge Taiwan to open its door wider for the import of pork and related products, creating more headaches for Taiwan negotiators.

Taiwan currently allows the import of foreign pork, with the exception of pork bellies, offal and seasoned pork, at a tariff rate of 15 percent. It has also set quotas for its import of pork bellies after gaining WTO membership.
But the US has asked Taiwan to open its market to all categories of pork and pork products, and to lower tariffs on these items to 7.5 percent within six years after entering the WTO.

Taiwan has completed talks with 21 of the 26 WTO member states which have asked for bilateral negotiations on Taiwan's trade regime as preconditions for consenting to its admission into the world trade regulatory body.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGE IN NAME OF SOUTHEAST ASIAN GAMES SUGGESTED

TEXT.P: The Southeast Asian Games may soon be no more. At a meeting of Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) sports ministers on Saturday, a suggestion was made to change the name of the competition to the ASEAN Games after Cambodia is admitted into the grouping.
Indonesia's State Minister of Youth and Sports Hayono Isman said after the meeting that Dato Ajit Singh, the outgoing ASEAN secretary-general, had proposed the idea to him.
"He said we should consider changing the SEA Games into the ASEAN Games. And I told him that I would relay his thinking to my fellow ASEAN ministers," Hayono was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.
The suggestion will be discussed by the 10 ASEAN member countries individually and then jointly at the first ASEAN Sports Ministerial Meeting in Kuala Lumpur next month.
Hayono said the ASEAN Secretariat may not necessarily have to be involved in the staging of the games even though the event may bear the organization's name in the future.

However, no final decision can be taken until Cambodia is admitted to ASEAN. It was due to join the regional grouping along with Laos and Myanmar at the ASEAN ministerial meeting in July, but its application was put on hold after the nation was rocked by massive internal strife earlier that month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASSURED OF ABDUCTED MARINE POLICE OFFICER'S SAFETY ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Sunday that it has received assurances that a Taiwan marine police officer who was abducted to the mainland is safe and recovering in a hospital from injuries sustained in the incident.

The SEF had made an urgent appeal to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Saturday night for information on the condition of Chuang Cheng-yao. Chuang was attacked when he and his colleagues attempted to inspect a mainland fishing boat they suspected of smuggling goods into Taiwan during a routine patrol in waters near the offshore island of Matsu.

Chang Liang-jen, SEF deputy secretary-general, said that the semi-official body has sent a letter to ARATS, requesting that arrangements be made for Chuang to be flown back to Taiwan via Hong Kong as soon as his condition permits.
Chang urged ARATS to investigate the incident and to handle it in a proper manner.
Chang said that the SEF has also asked that the Chinese mainland authorities restrain fishermen under their jurisdiction from entering into restricted or off-limits waters near Taiwan.
Saturday's incident is the second such case in which local marine police patrolling the Taiwan Strait have been abducted to the mainland.

On March 8, 1991, three marine police boarded a iron-hulled mainland fishing boat near Pengchiayu off eastern Taiwan, whereupon they found a cargo of dry mushrooms and antiques in the hull which were apparently being smuggled into Taiwan.

But the three officers were surprised and overcome by the mainlanders following a melee in which one of the fishermen was shot dead. The three marine police were subsequently forced to go to Pingtan, Fujian Province, with the fishing vessel.

Through arrangements by Red Cross representatives from the two sides, the three officers, who had been charged and sentenced for excessive use of force, were repatriated without serving their time in mainland prisons.
Chou Hsien-kuang, the officer who had fatally shot mainland fisherman Lin Wu, was ordered to compensate Lin's family in the amount of 40,000 renminbi.
SEF officials said they do not know if mainland authorities will deal with Chuang's case in a similar manner of "sentence first, repatriate later."
A marine police spokesman said that two marine police patrol boats had come across three suspicious-looking mainland fishing boats around 5:00 p.m. Saturday, stopping one of them for inspection.

Mainland Chinese fishermen on the vessel attacked the officers with axes, wine bottles and clubs as they boarded the boat. Chuang received an injury to the arm during the scuffle. Another officer, identified as Chuang Wen-cheng, also received minor injuries.

As marine police were unable to gain entry to the captain's cabin, crewmen began to steer the fishing boat toward the mainland. Eight of the Taiwan officers opted to jump overboard rather than be taken to the mainland. They were later rescued. The injured Chuang, however, was forced to go to the mainland with the ship.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE ROCKS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake rocked Taiwan early Sunday morning, the Central Weather Bureau said. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.
The quake, measured at a magnitude of 5.8 on the open-ended Richter scale, occurred at 2:24 a.m. The epicenter was located offshore, 78 kilometers east of Ilan, in northern Taiwan.
Ilan experienced tremors measuring at a magnitude of 3.0 on the Richter scale, while the quake recorded a 2.0 in Hualien and a 1.0 in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND FISHING BOATS IN TAIWAN WATERS CAUSE HEADACHES FOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The problem of mainland vessels entering Taiwan's waters to fish has become more serious lately, the National Police Administration (NPA) said Sunday.

NPA officials said that the number of mainland fishing ships being turned away by marine police reflects the severity of the problem, noting that in 1992, officials had sent back 179 mainland vessels, with the total surging to over 1,200 the following year.
The number peaked at 2,200 in 1994, and dropped to slightly over 1,800 in 1995.

They said that mainland Chinese ships have entered Taiwan waters in droves recently, often in the dozens or hundreds. The fishing methods used by the trawlers have seriously disrupted the marine ecology and depleted fishery resources.
Groups of mainland fishing ships converging on a particular location not only destabilize fishing operations in the area, but also give rise to constant disputes over tangled nets.

The officials said the problem can be attributed in part to Chinese mainland authorities turning a blind eye to the activities of fishermen under their jurisdiction. Also, because of the depleted marine resources, Taiwan operators have given up fishing for themselves, and have resorted to purchasing the catches of the mainland fishermen and shipping them back to Taiwan for resale in local markets.

The officials said that the problem became worse after some mainland operators, under the pretext of fishing activities, began to engage in piracy or use their vessels for smuggling goods and human cargo into Taiwan.
Mainland spies could also be disguising themselves as fishermen to collect information on Taiwan's coastal geography, they added.

The officials said that marine police are now building large 2,000-ton patrol boats to beef up their enforcement capability. Marine police will also coordinate more closely with naval patrol vessels to crack down on mainland fishing ships entering Taiwan waters.
They also urged local fishing associations to discourage local fishermen from purchasing the catches of mainland operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STRONGLY REFUTES SAMOAN PM'S ALLEGATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday sternly refuted an allegation by Samoan Prime Minister Tofilau Eti Alesana that Taiwan has funded an anti-government march to be staged in his country.
"Alesana's allegation is unfounded and incorrect," said a ministry official in charge of East Asian and Pacific affairs who preferred anonymity.

The official was commenting on an Agence France-Presse (AFP) report which quoted Alesana as accusing Taiwan on Sunday of pouring money into an anti-government organization on Samoa, known as the Tumua ma Pule.

Alesana was quoted as claiming that Taiwan provided at least one million tala (about US$377,000) for the Tumua ma Pule to organize an anti-government march on Oct. 29 aimed at forcing Alesana to resign. "Taiwan was doing this in retaliation for Samoa recognizing China," the AFP report quoted Alesana as alleging. Alesana, however, declined to reveal the source of his information.
Responding to the report, the MOFA official said Samoa is far away from the Republic of China on Taiwan and has had limited contacts with the ROC government.

On the other hand, the official said, the South Pacific island nation has traditionally maintained close ties with communist China. For instance, mainland Chinese Vice Premier Zhu Rongji made a stopover in Samoa during his South Pacific tour earlier this year.

Noting that the ROC has few interests in Samoa, the official said that the ROC has never offered any financial aid to opposition groups in that country. Moreover, he said, the MOFA's annual budget is under the Legislative Yuan's tight scrutiny. "Alesana's allegation is totally groundless," he said, adding he suspects that mainland China might have purposely furnished the Samoan prime minister with erroneous information.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN SMUGGLING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: A human smuggling ring which methodically transported Chinese mainlanders to Taiwan via Kinmen, was busted by police Sunday.

The ring, masterminded by "snake head" Lin Chu-yuan, was found to have smuggled at least 10 Chinese from the mainland to Kinmen in two groups since early September this year. The actual number of persons transported through the sea route and the number of people involved in the smuggling operation could be much larger, the police said.
A "snake head" is someone who operates a human smuggling business, usually charging exorbitant prices.

Lin, 50, a former representative of Chincheng, the major township of Kinmen, and two accomplices were nabbed Sunday morning after Kinmen police captured five illegal mainland immigrants a day earlier.
The five mainlanders, three men and two women, said Lin's group had arranged for them to slip into Kinmen aboard a fishing boat for a fee ranging from 20,000 to 80,000 renminbi per person.

After arriving in Kinmen, the five were holed up at a local hotel, where they were waiting for the smugglers to give them fake ROC identifications, which are usually forged from stolen IDs obtained in Taiwan.
The five mainlanders were nabbed before they were able to sneak into Taiwan.

The police found a similarity with a previous human smuggling case which was uncovered on Sept. 5, when five other mainlanders were arrested in Kinmen on charges of violating the ROC's immigration law.
According to Lin's accomplices, Chen Tsung-ming, 49 and Chen Chin-chung, 33, the Sept. 5 human smuggling attempt was part of the same deal arranged by Lin's ring.
Saturday's crackdown seemed to corroborate persistent rumors of operators in Kinmen who act as go-betweens for the trafficking of humans across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO FEAR DEMOCRACY IN ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Jason Hu, Republic of China's top representative to the United States, urged mainland China's leadership over the weekend not to regard pluralistic democratic development in the ROC as advocating separatism.
Hu said democratization will not scuttle the prospect of national unification, but could in fact be the panacea to resolve the issue.
Hu made the statement Saturday when he was addressing the opening ceremony of a seminar in Washington D. C.

He said that Taiwan and Hong Kong, which came under to mainland Chinese rule on July 1 this year, differ in many ways. Accordingly, Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula cannot be applied to Taiwan.

In contrast with the colonial history of Hong Kong, the developmental experience in Taiwan and its democratic achievements will provide a feasible model for future unification of China, Hu told the seminar.

He expressed the hope that the handover of Hong Kong to Chinese rule offers Beijing a direct experience with democracy, enabling Beijing leadership to clearly evaluate the essence and value of democracy, which will in turn gradually diminish the resistance to democracy among the Communist hierarchy.

Hu said that unification between Taiwan and the mainland will not be achieved in a single leap, and that Beijing should continue to pursue reforms in order to narrow the gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Only when the fledgling democratic movement in the mainland reaches full bloom, will conditions be ripe for national unification.

He stressed that the policy of pragmatic diplomacy pushed by Taiwan is not intended to create cross-strait tension or confrontation. Rather, it arises from a need for Taiwan to secure its survivability and pursue its developmental goals.

Hu expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could put aside their differences on the question of China's representation in international arena and cooperate for mutual benefit based on parallel representation.

On relations with the United States, he said the ROC has gained the long-term support of the US Congress mainly because the ROC shares the same beliefs as the US, while lobbying efforts by the ROC in Washington play a relatively minor role.
Hu stated that it is "unwise and unnecessary" for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in a zero-sum game on Capitol Hill, or in any other setting.

He also urged the Beijing authority to resume cross-strait talks as soon as possible based on the principles of mutual respect and goodwill. He said that if Beijing merely attempts to block Taiwan's efforts to gain a greater profile in international community, it will only delay the peaceful unification of China.
Meanwhile, ROC Executive Yuan officials revealed Sunday that Hu will return to Taiwan to assume his new position as ROC foreign minister on Oct. 18.

Stephen S.F. Chen, deputy secretary-general to the president, who was originally scheduled to travel to Washington to replace Hu on Oct. 14, may have to delay his trip because US authorities have yet to complete the accreditation procedures, the Executive Yuan officials said.
John Chang, who was promoted to the vice premiership nearly two months ago, will officially turn over the concurrently held foreign minister's post to Hu in a ceremony scheduled for Oct. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFERS TO LIBERALIZE SERVICES MARKET

TEXT.P: Beijing plans next month to tackle one of the biggest sticking points in its efforts to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by submitting long-awaited proposals for liberalizing its services market, according to reports from the world trade body Sunday.

Beijing also promised to abolish agricultural export subsidies as soon as it joins the Geneva-based WTO and to end all remaining import licensing requirements once industrialized countries meet their commitment to remove textiles quotas early next century.

Long Yongtu, mainland China's vice minister for international trade, was quoted as saying that he had outlined Beijing's services proposals to WTO members this week, and that they might be further refined before being formally submitted.

Long, currently on a visit to London, will arrive soon in Geneva for bilateral negotiations with WTO member countries. He was quoted as saying that the European Union had called the outline "very comprehensive and positive." However, EU negotiators maintained that the proposals fell far short of the degree of liberalization required to satisfy terms for Beijing's WTO entry.

"The proposals offer a glimmer of hope, but no more. (Communist) China is going to have to move much further," an EU official was quoted as saying. "But at least Beijing appears at long last to be waking up to the importance of trade in services in these negotiations."

Meanwhile, WTO Director-General Renato Ruggiero warned that Beijing must agree to open wide its market for goods and services before it can win its long-sought admission to the world trade regulatory body.

Ruggiero suggested Beijing should not assume that any dramatic moves to settle US concerns during this month's visit to Washington by President Jiang Zemin would clear all remaining hurdles to WTO membership.

"China has to understand that her partners see her as the fifth exporter in the world ... and so they expect the Chinese market to be as open as the markets of all its partners are already," Ruggiero said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAID CURTAILING ROC INVITATIONS TO APPEASE CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia is curtailing its invitations to low-ranking Taiwan government officials to visit in order to appease mainland China, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review.

In a dispatch from Taipei, the Review's Bruce Cheesman reported that Taiwan was more concerned with Australia's "one China" policy than with the anti-Asian views of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson.

The daily reported that Canberra sent Resources and Energy Minister Warwick Parer to attend a business council meeting in Taipei in a very low-key fashion, unlike the highly visible visit by Primary Industry Minister John Anderson last year.

"In paying lip-service to Canberra's 'one China' policy, the announcement of the (Parer's) visit was delayed until the 11th hour. Without any fanfare, a marked contrast to the high-profile visit of Mr. Anderson last year, Mr. Parer did his utmost to be invisible," Cheesman wrote.
"Canberra's kowtowing to Beijing for most of the year led to speculation that visits by ministers to Taiwan were banned," the daily reported.

The daily also said that Australian diplomats forced the Australian New Zealand Bank to stop the head of the bank's operations in Taipei, Jeffrey Cox, from visiting China to attend the opening of a new branch in Beijing.

The daily reported that Taiwan has admonished Canberra through its trade offices in Australia for benefiting from rapidly increasing investment from Taipei without reciprocating through wider support for the island's bid to break out of its international isolation.
Taipei has made clear that increased investment from state-run companies depends upon better servicing of the bilateral trade ties between Taiwan and Australia.
The daily said Australia's "one China" policy was becoming more of a stumbling block for Taipei to boost its ties with Canberra.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL TRYING TO CONTACT ABDUCTED OFFICER

TEXT.P: The cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is closely watching developments in a case involving the abduction of a Taiwan marine police officer to the mainland, Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs said Monday.

MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh said the council has authorized the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to continue its contacts with the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to ensure the safe return of the officer as soon as possible.

The SEF was told that Chuang Chen-yao, who sustained a head injury during a melee on Saturday aboard a mainland fishing boat which was suspected of involvement in a smuggling operation, is in stable condition and receiving medical treatment at the Changlo Municipal Hospital of Fujian Province.
However, mainland authorities have refused to allow direct telephone contact between Chuang and any party on Taiwan, including members of Chuang's family and SEF officials.
MAC officials said the most critical issue at the moment is that mainland authorities have different perceptions from those on Taiwan regarding Chuang's role as a Taiwan-based marine police officer.

While Taipei maintains that Chuang was executing his duties properly, the mainland may hold a different attitude, which could result in a trial and sentencing for Chuang, in which case the timetable for his return to Taiwan would be "hard to predict," they noted.

According to a marine police spokesman on Sunday, two patrol boats had come across three suspicious-looking mainland fishing boats in waters near Matsu around 5:00 p.m. Saturday, stopping one of them for inspection.

Mainland Chinese fishermen on the vessel attacked the officers with axes, clubs and liquor bottles as they boarded the boat. Chuang sustained injuries to the head and arm during the scuffle. Another officer also received minor injuries.

As the marine police were unable to gain entry to the captain's cabin, crewmen began to steer the fishing boat toward the mainland. Eight of the Taiwan officers opted to jump overboard rather than be taken to the mainland. They were later rescued. The injured Chuang, however, was forced to go to the mainland with the vessel.

Chuang's abduction to the mainland was not the first such incident involving marine police. On March 8, 1991, three officers boarded a mainland fishing boat near Pengchiayu off eastern Taiwan, whereupon they found a cargo of dry mushrooms and antiques in the hull which were apparently being smuggled into Taiwan.

But the three officers were taken by surprise and overcome by the mainlanders following a melee in which one of the fishermen was fatally shot. The three Taiwan police were subsequently forced to go to Pingtan, Fujian, with the fishing vessel.

Through arrangements by Red Cross representatives from the two rival sides, the three officers, who had been charged and sentenced for excessive use of force, were repatriated without serving their sentences in mainland prisons.

SEF officials, who are continuing efforts to contact their ARATS counterparts over Chuang's condition in the wake of Saturday's incident, said they do not know if the mainland authorities will deal with Chuang in a similar manner of "sentence first, repatriate later."

Meanwhile, Chuang's father, who has tried in vain several times since Saturday to talk with Chuang over the telephone, appealed to the MAC to facilitate his travel to Fujian, saying that his son deserves proper care by the government after he went through the life-threatening ordeal for his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO CUT RESERVE REQUIREMENT FOR BANKS AT RIGHT TIME

TEXT.P: Y.D. Sheu, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), said Monday that the CBC will announce a reduction in the reserve requirement for banks at an appropriate time.
Sheu made the remarks at a joint meeting of the budget, finance, foreign and overseas Chinese affairs, and judicial committees in the Legislative Yuan.
Sheu said that the CBC will carefully evaluate the overall situation of capital markets, price levels and interest rates in deciding the best juncture for adjusting the reserve requirements.
He admitted that current reserve requirements for banks are slightly too high, but said that the cuts will be carried out in stages in order to avoid impacting the financial market.

He said that any time there is a cash shortage in capital markets, or if interest rates are too high, the CBC will consider cutting the reserve requirement. However, as there are many tools currently at the CBC's disposal, it will not cut reserve requirements for the time being.
Sheu also said that the CBC has released between US$4 billion and US$5 billion over the past three months to maintain the stability of foreign currency markets.

As to why the CBC has firmly maintained an exchange rate of NT$28.6 to one US dollar, Sheu said that officials have analyzed the overall situation and taken into consideration the best interests of the nation's economic development and export trade.
Sheu stressed that after financial markets become stabilized, the CBC will respect market mechanisms and will no longer intervene in the foreign currency market.

He also refuted the allegation that the CBC will use its powers to help create a favorable economic atmosphere for the ruling Kuomintang before year-end local elections, saying that the CBC maintains an independent, nonpartisan stance.
Legislator Hung Hsing-jung had questioned the strength of Taiwan's foreign currency reserves after the CBC recently dumped hundreds of millions of US dollars in the foreign currency market.

Sheu said that Taiwan has a foreign currency reserve of US$87 billion. Taiwan businessmen also invest about US$30 billion in the mainland, over US$30 billion in Southeast Asia and over US$10 billion in Europe and the Americas. In total, the level of foreign currency reserves is approximately US$160 billion, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES EDGE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices edged higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 1.29 points to finish at 8,463.16.
The bourse opened at 8,503.8 and experienced a high of 8,512.57 and a low of 8,444.18.
Losers outnumbered gainers 243 to 162, with 62 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.43 billion shares changes hands on a a market turnover of NT$100.61 billion (US$3.5 billion).

Electric engineering increased the most at 1.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.2 percent. Paper and pulp shares dropped the most at 1.1 percent, followed by financial stocks at 1.0 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, plastic and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, and cement and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA MAY BECOME ASIA'S LARGEST GOLD PRODUCER

TEXT.P: Director General of Mining of the Ministry of Mines and Energy Adjat Sudradjat said Sunday that Indonesia has the potential to become Asia's largest gold producer.
In his inaugural speech as a professor at Bandung's University of Padjadjaran, Adjat based his optimistic outlook on Indonesia's rich gold resources, political stability and favorable mining policy.
Adjat said the latest volcanological studies indicate that the making of volcanoes could simultaneously create mineral resources within the volcanic areas.
Based on such a view, Indonesia, which is home to at least 129 active volcanoes and 500 dormant ones, could be quite rich in gold reserves, he said.
According to the World Gold's Council's latest data, Indonesia produces 70 tons of gold per year, below mainland's yearly output of 100 tons.
Adjat said experts speculate that gold resources could be discovered soon in 15 volcanic arcs, but thus far mineral resources have only been found in seven of them.

The seven potentially gold-rich volcanic arcs include the Sunda-Banda arc (4,000 km), the Sumatra-Meratus (3,000 km), the Central Kalimantan arc (1,500 km), the North Sylawesi arc (1,500 km), and the Irian Jaya arc (1,200 km).

"Thus, the total area which has potential (mineral resources) covers between 600,000 to 1.5 million kilometers or 10 percent to 30 percent of Indonesia's total land territory," Adjat was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.
He said research on Indonesia's 129 active volcanoes are already available for mining investors to study.

Adjat said investors could also start exploration on the basis of a systematic geologic map completed by the Indonesian government in 1996, which covers the entire territory of Indonesia on a scale of 1:100,000 and 1:250,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS PROFIT RISE IN SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: Saudi American Bank (SAMA) has announced its third quarter results for 1997, which reflect its continued financial strength. Its earnings increased by 10 percent.

Meanwhile, the Saudi Hollandi Bank (SHB) reported a net profit of SR160.1 million (US$42.69 million) for the first nine months of 1997, compared to SR117.3 million (US$31.28 million) for the same period of last year, a 36.4 percent increase.

SAMA Managing Director Robert Eichfeld spoke of the emphasis on product innovation and cost control as being two of the key elements in its success. "We also enjoy the benefits of technology transfer from our principal overseas partner -- Citibank. Citibank's truly global experience, coupled with the excellent quality of our people locally, has been an added source of strength. Overall, we are ready to move with the country to the next stage of development."

SHB Managing Director Herman Erbe stated that the positive performance of the bank through the first nine months of 1997 is highlighted by total assets growth of 13 percent, reaching SR17.94 billion (US$4.78 billion), compared with SR15.87 billion (US$4.23 billion) for the same period of 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ESTABLISH "COMMERCENET TAIWAN" VIA INTERNET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Information Infrastructure (NII) Enterprise Promotion Association has signed a cooperative agreement with CommerceNet, the world largest organization of Internet service-providing firms.

The agreement, signed at the Technology Building in Taipei, established arrangements for CommerceNet to help Taiwan-based firms offer improved services via the Internet in line with the trend toward internationalization of electronic services.
Under the agreement, the NII association will establish "CommerceNet Taiwan," linking up partners from 14 similar organizations worldwide.
The agreement was designed by Hsia Han-min, president of the NII Enterprise Promotion Association, and Stephen Terry, chief executive of CommerceNet's International Department.
When CommerceNet Taiwan is set up, network services offering the latest service information in both English and Chinese will be made available, Hsia said after the signing ceremony.

The system will encourage Taiwan-based service providers to meet international standards, he said. This in turn will motivate multinational service providers to cooperate with Taiwan counterparts as local information, finance and distribution systems are increasingly exchanging information with counterparts in Europe, the United States and Asia, he said.
As one of the world's largest groupings of Internet service providers, CommerceNet is presently operating in 14 countries and has established partnerships with over 900 organizations, Terry said.

CommerceNet estimates that by the end of next year, another ten countries will be added, including new members ranging from government agencies to nonprofit organizations, business, research institutions and manufacturers, Terry said.

Enterprises in the fields of communications, finance and information are expected to be especially interested in participating, he added. (By Lawrence Chu) ENDITEM ZCZC CEP013 10-13-97 PRESIDENT RECEIVES VIRGINIA GOVERNOR

Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) President Lee Teng-hui extended a warm welcome to visiting Governor George Allen of the US State of Virginia on Monday and expressed his hope that Taiwan and Virginia can increase trade and economic relations based on their present friendly ties.

Noting that Virginia signed a sisterhood agreement with Taiwan in 1981, the president said he hoped Allen will meet with many local business leaders in order to boost mutual bilateral understanding during his stay in Taiwan.

Allen, who began his first visit to Taiwan on Saturday, called on President Lee on Monday morning, accompanied by ROC Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen. He told the president he is impressed by Taiwan's progress and prosperity and that he will work toward increased exchanges and cooperation between his US state and the island nation.
Later in the day, Allen met with several local business leaders, including Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, and S.S. Lin, chairman of Evergreen Marine Corp.
He is scheduled to leave Taiwan on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG GIVEN TWO-WEEK LEAVE TO RECONSIDER RESIGNATION BID

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said on Monday he will take a two-week leave to reconsider his resignation bid.
Chiang made the remarks after visiting a makeshift memorial hall at Taipei's Sungshan Airport to pay his tribute to the five Air Force officers who died in a C-130 transport plane crash last Friday.

Chiang told the press that he had explained to President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew the reasons for his resignation. "Both of them have asked me to stay on and advised me to take a two-week leave to reconsider."
The career serviceman-turned-defense minister first tendered his resignation on Saturday, and again on Sunday, to assume political responsibility for a spate of military mishaps in recent moths.
President Lee summoned Chiang to his official residence on Sunday and asked the minister to remain at his post for the nation's overall interests.
Premier Siew also met with Chiang on Monday, strongly urging him not to step down from his current position.

Siew was quoted by government spokesman David Lee as having told Chiang that would not be proper for any senior government officials to resign before the causes of the recent military plane crashes, including the crashes of two F-5 jet fighters in Hualien on Sept. 30, are determined.
The three-star general told the premier that he agreed to take up his current post some three years ago mainly out of a "sense of mission."

"I feel that all criticism directed at the military in the wake of the Oct. 10 C-130 crash has marred the military's reputation and my personal dignity," Chiang noted. "This is why I have decided to leave my post."

In response, Siew said the Ministry of National Defense is carrying out several critical projects aimed at restructuing the Ministry of National Defense, streamlining the armed forces and establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of mounting mainland Chinese military threats.
"This is not a suitable moment for you to quit," Siew was quoted at telling Chiang. "Our nation needs your service at the moment."

Siew further said he earnestly hopes that the recent C-130 crash will prompt the military to comprehensively review its training system and take effective measures to boost the morale of all servicemen. "I hope the tragic incident will serve to turn a crisis into an opportunity in our military training system."

Chiang, 75, has steadily climbed the ladder of military ranks since he graduated from the Chinese Army Academy. He has served as Army commander-in-chief, the vice chief of the General Staff, the personal chief of staff to the President, and national policy adviser before assuming his current post in late 1994.

Military observers said it will be difficult for the government to find a suitable replacement for Chiang at the moment. His departure will affect plans to trim military personnel, which will call for the retirement of a number of general- and colonel-level officers over the next few years. The program is a sensitive matter, the observers said, adding that few persons in the military other than Chiang have both the reputation and senior status needed to successfully oversee implementation of the plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG'S US VISIT NEEDS INTENSE SCRUTINY FROM TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Chang Lung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The political haggling over the relationship between Beijing and Washington prior to the state visit of mainland China's President Jiang Zemin to the United State seems to have come to an end.

The bilateral relationship has now been defined as a "constructive partnership" instead of the "strategic partnership" which was Beijing's original hope. The changes are being seen as evidence of the political compromise and diplomatic bargaining that has been going on.

Jiang's visit will be the first by a mainland Chinese head of state to the US in 12 years, following the 1985 visit to Washington by late mainland President Li Xiannian, so Beijing is attaching tremendous significance to the visit.

As far as Jiang is concerned, the visit is a chance to usher in the "Jiang Era" in the wake of the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party and to add to his domestic political assets by establishing personal international popularity.

There are differences between the US government and Capitol Hill (Congress) in terms of "China policy." Weighing the government's consideration of political reality and the basic contradictions between this and Congress' attitude towards Beijing, both the US and mainland China have agreed to establish "constructive partnership" relations leading into the 21st century instead of the former idea of "strategic partnership" relations.

Although there exist many obstacles in Beijing-Washington relations -- such as human rights, nuclear proliferation, arms sales, trade deficit, the new US-Japan defense guidelines and most of all, the "Taiwan Problem" -- improving bilateral relations with Washington is still Beijing's top priority.

It is Jiang's understanding that as the Beijing old guard and the indoctrination of Mao thought are gradually fading from mainland Chinese society and as the reform and open-door policy have crossed the point of no-return, there is a long way to go if mainland China wants to establish a cross-century infrastructure, the prerequisite of which is to have an appropriate international environment. This means that a stand against the US and Japan is not in line with the mainland's strategic goal.

Jiang Zemin's US visit will not only be a watershed in the development of relations between Beijing and Washington, it will also be an important factor in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and as such it is worthy of Taipei's intense scrutiny.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.003 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at the day's low of NT$28.477.
The greenback opened at 28.48, and had a high of 28.485.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$215 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHICKENS OBEY EX-NAVY LT. COMMANDER'S MILITARY ORDERS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Eastern Taiwan, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: All feathered two-legged residents freeze and raise their heads toward Fan, a retired naval officer, when he whistles his "one short note." They stand to attention like this for about ten seconds before they resume their normal activities.

Fan Kuang-fu, an ex-naval lieutenant commander, operates Taiwan's most disciplined poultry farm in the mountain village of Shoufeng in eastern Hualien County and most of his 7,000-odd chickens obey his whistled commands so accurately that they seem to have received strict military training.

When Fan whistles "one short note," which means "attention," the chickens stand still for about 10 seconds and when he whistles "two short notes," which means "fall in," the poultry start to approach the feeding station. However, the chickens do not start to eat until "three short notes" sounds, which means "chow time."
So astounding has been Fan's success in training his "chicken corps" that he was dubbed "the chicken commander of Shoufeng" by a local farmers' association on Sunday.
Fan, who ran a business in Kaohsiung after retiring from the navy, returned to his Hualien County home village to raise chickens when his business failed.

This venture also faced defeat in the beginning, when about one-third of his chickens failed to return home to roost at night. His stock continued to plummet on a daily basis, even though he cracked his vocal cords trying to call them home.
When most of his first batch of 1,000 chickens were gone, he went down to Hualien City to buy himself a whistle and began passing his military training on to his chickens.

Fan soon discovered that the chickens would listen to his whistle, which cheered him up considerably, but he also found that the poultry would not "listen to orders," unless they were hungry, leading him to perfect his two-and-three note command system.

Today, when Fan buys a new batch of chicks who do not know the rules, he is not at all worried that they will run off. "The small ones learn as quickly as little children when they follow their seniors and it isn't long before they listen too," a proud Fan says.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, NORTH KOREA TO EXCHANGE TRADE OFFICES

TEXT.P: North Korea has authorized its semi-official Committee for the Promotion of International Trade (CPIT) to exchange representative offices with the Taipei Import-Export Association (TIEP) before the end of this year to facilitate bilateral tourist and commercial exchanges, a senior ROC trade promoter said on Monday.

TIEP President Lee Tung-liang, who has just returned from a fact-finding trip to North Korea, said the committee has also been authorized to negotiate investment guarantees and tax exemption accords with Taiwan.

Lee visited communist North Korea last week at the invitation of the Pyongyang government. The new TIEP president said he was impressed by the keen interest shown by North Korean officials in reinforcing trade and economic ties with Taiwan.
Lee said he plans to invite the CPIT vice chairman to visit Taipei later this year to discuss technical details concerning the exchange of representative offices between the two organizations.
If all goes smoothly, Lee said, the two sides will seal an agreement in mid-December and that the respective representative offices will become operational by next January.

Lee said he will brief senior ROC officials on the results of his week-long visit. "I hope our government will support the TIEP in expanding commercial and tourist exchanges with North Korea," he added.

Lee said the TIEP will also invite other North Korean economic planners and trade promoters, including the vice chairman of the External Economic Affairs Commission under North Korea's Administrative Council, to visit Taipei early next year.

Lee, who concurrently serves as chairman of the giant Nan Lien Trading Co., said he will encourage the major TIEP members to pool their resources in order to boost trade with the reclusive Stalinist nation which is said to be in the throes of a major famine. In addition to promoting sales of Taiwan products to North Korea, Lee said, his company also plans to import certain North Korean products for sale in the local market.
