DOC.HEADLINE: THE HAZE IS BACK IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The haze returned to Singapore on Sunday after more than a week of clearer skies and light showers over the island.
At 7:00 p.m., the Pollutants Standard Index (PSI) reading reached 116, which is in the unhealthy level and at 9:00 a.m. on Monday, the PSI reading was 102, the Meteorological Service reported.
The rain which fell over the island in the last few days helped to clear the skies and on Thursday, the PSI reading dropped to a pre-haze low of 47.
But as weatherman had forecast earlier, the haze problem seems set to remain until next month, when the northeast monsoon sets in.

However, the Meteorological Service also said the overall haze situation will improve gradually as more rain is expected, which will have a dampening effect on the forest fires burning out of control on the Indonesian island of Sumatra.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER ON RELATIONS WITH PYONGYANG

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang said on Monday that he could not confirm whether the Republic of China is negotiating with North Korea on the exchange of representative offices.

"As a sovereign country, the ROC has maintained regular contacts with many other countries, but it remains premature to say that we are ready to exchange representative offices with North Korea at the moment," Chang told reporters.

Chang was responding to reports that North Korea has authorized its semi-official Committee for the Promotion of International Trade (CPIT) to exchange representative offices with the ROC's Taipei Import-Export Association (TIEA) by the end of this year and to negotiate investment guarantees and tax exemption accords with Taiwan.

Chang said that although the ROC once considered exchanging representative offices with North Korea, "there is still some way to go before this goal can be reached," adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will report any developments at the proper time.

TIEA President Lee Tung-liang, who has just returned from a fact-finding trip to North Korea, said on Monday he was impressed by the keen interest shown by North Korean officials in reinforcing trade and economic ties with Taiwan. Lee's visit was hosted by North Korean government authorities.
Lee said he plans to invite the CPIT vice chairman to visit Taipei later this year to discuss technical details concerning the exchange of representative offices between the two organizations.

If all goes smoothly, Lee said, the two sides will seal an agreement in mid-December and that the respective representative offices will become operational by next January to facilitate bilateral tourist and commercial exchanges.

Lee said the TIEA will also invite other North Korean economic planners and trade promoters, including the vice chairman of the External Economic Affairs Commission under North Korea's Administrative Council, to visit Taipei next year.

Lee, who concurrently serves as chairman of the giant Nan Lien Trading Co., said he will encourage major TIEA members to pool their resources in order to boost trade with the reclusive Stalinist nation which is said to be in the thores of a major famine. In addition to promoting sales of Taiwan products to North Korea, Lee said his company also plans to import certain North Korean products for sale in the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN TOURISM INDUSTRY BENEFITS FROM INDONESIAN FIRES

TEXT.P: Australia's tourism industry is reaping benefits from forest fires in Indonesia because many tourists are switching their travel plans to the Gold Coast and Cairns in Queensland, Australian travel agents reported on Monday.

Many leisure trips to Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand and other Southeast Asian countries have been canceled in the past two months and resorts on the Gold Coast and in Cairns are already reaping some of the benefits, they said.
Many members of the expatriate community in Southeast Asia have also moved to the relative safety of Australia until the haze covering large parts of the region clears, they said.
Other Australian tourist destinations, including Sydney and Melbourne, are also benefiting from the Indonesian fires.
The fires have produced heavy smoke that has spread to Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand, causing serious air pollution.

The Australian Tourism Commission said travel agents in Australia should take the opportunity to attract more tourists from Southeast Asian countries, because many people in the region can afford to travel to Australia due to its geographical proximity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE IMMIGRANTS LEARNING HOW TO COPE WITH AUSTRALIAN RACISTS

TEXT.P: Members of the Chinese community in Sydney have asked the New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council to organize a forum to teach them how to protect themselves from racist attacks and defuse the potentially violent situations which racism can spark.
The council said other ethnic groups, including the Korean and Vietnamese communities, have asked to participate in the forum.
The forum, the first of its kind, will be held in late November or early December and will be aimed at teaching Asian groups the skills needed to protect themselves in potentially violent situations.

A council spokesman said the Chinese community often has to bear the brunt of much of the harassment and taunting that occurs on a daily basis and that the forum "will teach Chinese how to deal with everyday racism. If this forum succeeds, we hope it will be copied by other groups."

Racial harassment has increased since Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson said in September 1996 that "Australia is in danger of being swamped by Asians." She demanded that the government stop Asian immigration. As a result, the Australian government has reduced the intake of immigrants to 72,000 in 1997-98, down from nearly 100,000 in 1996-97.
Ethnic Affairs Commission chairman Stepan Kerkyasharian said it is important for ethnic communities to know what protection they have, including racial vilification legislation.
"It is a sad reflection on our society that some community groups now feel the need to give themselves these tools so they can confront racism in an effective way," he said.
"It is true that Asian Australians are a visible group and therefore more susceptible to racism than other communities at the moment," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S GOLKAR TO UNVEIL PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Indonesia's dominant political organization Golkar will formally announce its candidates for the next president and vice president at a leadership meeting later this week.
The Jakarta Post quoted Golkar chairman Harmoko as saying on Sunday that the Golkar central board had drawn up a list of names.
Harmoko did not mention any of the names for the election scheduled for next March, but it is unlikely that Golkar will nominate anyone other than incumbent President Suharto.
The newly inducted 1,000 members of the People's Consultative Assembly will convene next March to elect a president and vice president and establish state policy guidelines.
Golkar secretary general Ary Mardjono said the Golkar leadership meeting will begin on Thursday and end on Saturday.
Golkar has won all six elections held under Suharto. Last May, in a landslide election victory, Golkar obtained 74.3 percent of the votes, a significant increase from the 68 percent it won in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO STEP UP TEXTILE PRODUCTION IN CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers in the upper and lower streams of the textile industry are planning to form integrated textile production systems in San Pedro Sula, Honduras and other industrial centers in Central America.

For this purpose, Lin Nung-chung, director general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, has visited Honduras three times this year, an official of the center said Monday.

Lin is currently on a two-week trip to Honduras to find out what the government can do to help the manufacturers carry out their plans in San Pedro Sula, where seven Taiwan investors have already set up garment and other textile manufacturing facilities.

Textile business is booming in San Pedro Sula, mainly because American and South Korean textile manufacturers are also coming in to take advantage of U.S. preferential textile trade treatment for Honduras and the low labor cost in that country, the official said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE TRADING TOPS 4.9 BILLION IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Trading in Taiwan's foreign exchange market reached US$93.6 billion in the first eight months of this year, according to statistics compiled by the Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China.

The record high performance is partly attributable to the unstable financial situation in Southeast Asian countries and the central bank's efforts to defend the New Taiwan dollar in the foreign exchange market, an official of the bank said Monday.

The trading totaled US$4,927 million in August, an increase of US$679 million or 11 percent over the same month of 1996. Trading between banks and their customers accounted for 41.8 percent of the total in August, the statistics showed. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUFFERS INCREASING DEFICITS IN TRADE WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CA) Taiwan's deficits in trade with Japan amounted to US$11 billion in the first three quarters of this year, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The deficits is expected to reach US$16 billion this year, an official of the ministry predicted Monday.

Taiwan's trade deficits with Japan increased from US$9.67 billion in 1991 to US$17.11 billion in 1995, a sharp increase of 76 percent in four years. The deficits dropped to US$13.83 billion in 1996, mainly because of the increase in the export of information products to Japan.

But the deficits began to rise again early this year due to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which depleted Taiwan's pork export to Japan, and due to a sharp reduction in Japan's import of information products from Taiwan.
Taiwan's trade deficits with Japan is attributable to a "structural imbalance" in trade between the two countries, the official said.

He said the ministry is expected to map out "a plan to promote foreign trade with Japan as a main target" by the end of this year, he added. Taiwan has implemented several plans to reduce trade deficits with Japan in vain. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN RETURNS HOME FROM EUROPEAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan returned home Monday afternoon after concluding his unofficial visit to Iceland and Austria.
Lien was reportedly forced to cancel a scheduled visit to Spain as a result of Beijing's pressure on the southern European country, which maintains no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
Accompanied by his wife and Senior Presidential Advisor Hsu Li-teh, Lien left here for Iceland Oct. 5 via Amsterdam.

During his stay in Iceland, Lien was entertained at a dinner hosted by Icelandic Prime Minister David Oddsson. They discussed promoting cultural exchanges and academic cooperation between Taiwan and Iceland.
Oddsson, who defied Beijing's request to reject Lien's visit, has also accepted Lien's invitation to visit Taiwan at an appropriate time.
Lien proceeded to Austria after concluding his visit to Iceland. But he was unable to tour Spain because of Beijing's blockade.

Lien refused to make any comment on his trip. But during his stopover at the Bangkok airport Monday afternoon, Lien told CNA that many world nations have attached great importance to the ROC's democratization and that he will continue to make overseas trips in the future.

Lien, who remained vice president after stepping down from his second position as premier on September 1, visited Ukraine, a former Soviet state that maintains no official relations with Taiwan, in August last year. In January this year, he toured Ireland, which also has no official ties with Taiwan and the Vatican, the only ROC diplomatic ally in Europe.

In related news, Vice Premier and Foreign Affairs Minister John Chang said that Lien's failure to visit more countries this time would not discourage his ministry from making "necessary contacts" with other countries.

He said that local media made "too many" reports about Lien's unannounced trip, enabling Beijing to act on information exposed prematurely in the Taiwan media by pressing the countries Lien originally planned to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE TOPPED US$174 BILLION IN JAN-SEPT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign trade reached US$174.09 billion in the first three quarters of this year, a moderate increase over the corresponding period of 1996, customs statistics showed.

Exports in the first nine months of this year amounted to US$89.78 billion, up 4.9 percent over the year-earlier period, and imports rose 11.8 percent to US$84.31 billion, the same statistics indicated.

As a result, Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$5.47 billion in the January-September period, a decrease of 46 percent. Officials of the Finance Ministry attributed the decline to the faster growth of imports, reflecting brisk domestic demand for foreign raw materials and equipment for production expansion.

The United States was the major overseas market for Taiwan products, taking 24 percent of the island's total exports in the period. It was followed by Hong Kong with 23 percent and Europe with 14.7 percent, the statistics showed. Important suppliers to Taiwan included Japan, the United States and Europe.
In September alone, the nation's foreign trade hit US$20.62 billion, a remarkable increase over the level of September 1996.

Exports last month hit US$10.87 billion, up 10.7 percent, and imports went up 26.3 percent to US$9.75 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of US$1.12 billion and making September the third month this year with a surplus exceeding US$1 billion, according to customs statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LOOSEN LIMITATIONS ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN BOURSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) and Central Bank of China (CBC) have reached consensus on loosening the current limitations on foreign capital in the local stock market, raising the ceiling on foreign investment from 25 percent to 30 percent of the market's total value.
CBC Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan on Monday over how far the planned adjustment could go, called 30 percent "acceptable."
Sheu also revealed that the central bank will not act on the plan, which is mainly aimed at encouraging investment in Taiwan's stock exchange, until trading on the New Taiwan dollar stabilizes.

The New Taiwan dollar began depreciating against the US dollar in September, when financial crises erupted in several Southeast Asian countries. The CBC has intervened to stop the fall of the local currency.
The crises in Southeast Asia also put a scare into local investors, triggering the Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted index to plunge more than 1,000 points over the past few weeks.
With capital leaving the Taiwan bourse, the MOF and CBC have been prompted to adjust relevant regulations to attract more foreign investment in the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN CONGRESSMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Klaus Buehler, a member of Germany's Parliament, or Bundestag, will arrive here Tuesday for a five-day visit.

During his Taipei stay, Buehler will call on National Assembly Speaker Fredrick F. Chien, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, and Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang, as well as other high-ranking governmental officials.
He will also visit several of the Republic of China's cultural and economic establishments, according to a news release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Buehler, who belongs to Germany's ruling party, the Christian Democrats, was first elected to his post in 1976. He also serves as the chairman of a parliamentary group dedicated to Bonn-Taipei friendship.
The congressman has made nine previous visits to the island, with the most recent being in late March 1996.
He is scheduled to depart Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1,300 FOREIGNERS COMMIT CRIMES IN TAIWAN SINCE JAN. 1994

TEXT.P: Over 1,300 foreigners committed crimes in Taiwan during the period from January 1994 to June 1997, according to the latest statistics by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
A total of 240, or 17.43 percent, of the foreigners who committed crimes were illegal workers here, while 755, or 54.82 percent were legal workers, the statistics showed.

The CLA also indicated that as of September, a total of 9,287 foreign workers were listed as having run away from their Taiwanese employers, adding that some 95 percent of those who were caught during the same month have been sent back home by local law enforcement authorities.
Theft was the most common crime among foreign workers, with 319 of them involved in 204 cases of this during the three-and-a-half-year period, the figures showed.
There were 83 foreign workers involved in a total of 54 cases of homicide during the same period, the CLA said, noting this is a disturbingly high figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD FORESTRY CONGRESS OPENS IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: Under the auspices of the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the 11th World Forestry Congress opened Monday in Antalya, southern Turkey.
More than 2,000 experts from over 150 countries gathered to debate current and future problems facing the forestry industry worldwide and to recommend global solutions.

The opening ceremony was chaired jointly by Turkish President Suleyman Demirel, Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz and FAO Director General Dr. Jacques Diouf. Their speeches emphasized that the world's soil, air and water resources are vital for all forms of life, and that the forests -- the "lungs of the world" -- are both the source and the preserver of these resources. However, they said, human activity is rapidly exhausting the planet's natural resources.

Conference organizers from Turkey's Forestry Ministry said that the general theme for the gathering is "Forestry for Sustainable Development: Towards the 21th Century." Related topics will be discussed by experts from around the world in 77 sub-sessions during the Oct. 13-19 congress.

In addition, the Turkish Forestry Ministry will also hold an exhibition titled "International Forestry and Forest Products," and a memorial forest park will be established, where the participants will plant floral specimens from their own counties.

The first World Forestry Congress was organized by the International Forestry Institute in 1926 in Rome, and subsequent meetings have been held in Budapest, Helsinki, Seattle, Madrid, Buenos Aires, Jakarta, Mexico City and Paris. The previous 10th Congress was once again held in Rome in June 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKISH TROOPS BEGIN WITHDRAWAL FROM NORTHERN IRAQ

TEXT.P: Turkish troops have achieved their objectives in an operation codenamed "Dawn '97," aimed at destroying guerrilla positions of the rebel Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and have begun withdrawing from northern Iraq on Monday, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported.
The operation accomplished all of its aims and the region has been "cleared of the majority of PKK terrorists," the commanders in charge of the offensive were quoted as saying.

The number of PKK separatists killed during the operation, which started at the end of September with the aim of eliminating the guerrilla fighters who use northern Iraq as a base from which to strike Turkey, was put at 816. Also, 18 rebels were captured, 17 surrendered, and a considerable amount of ammunition and food were also seized, Anatolia said, quoting military sources.
The number of Turkish government troops killed in the clashes was put at 15, with 58 soldiers reported injured.

Some Turkish forces will remain in northern Iraq to guard the border, supported by fighters of the Iraqi Kurdistan Democratic Party, to prevent the PKK separatists from infiltrating the area and taking it under their control again, the military sources said.

The PKK has been engaged in a bloody separatist campaign against the Turkish government since 1984. Centered in the southeast of country, the conflict has left more than 26,000 people dead over the past 13 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIQUE MOBILITY TO BUILD LARGE APU

TEXT.P: Unique Mobility Inc. of the United States, one of the world's leading developers of power systems for electric and hybrid electric vehicles, announced Monday plans to work with Deere & Co. and others to build a state-of-the-art, diesel-fueled auxiliary power unit (APU) for large hybrid-electric vehicles.
The Colorado-based company said in a press release that it has received an award of US$292,000 from the U.S. Defense Department to work on the project.

To build the APU, Unique Mobility will mate its new 75 KW (100 HP) permanent magnet motor generator, developed in collaboration with the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, with an 88 KW (118 HP) six-cylinder 6.8-liter diesel engine manufactured by Deere & Co., the document says, adding that Unique will also provide the power electronics and microprocessor controller required to run the system.

Large APUs could be used for buses, shuttles and medium duty trucks. They could also have applications on military, agricultural, construction and other off-road vehicles. These include crop harvesters, dirt excavators, passenger and product movers and other machines where an electric transmission will improve fuel economy, increase versatility and maneuverability, William Rankin, president of Unique Mobility, said in the press release.
For military applications, he continued, the APU can provide standby electric power, eliminating the need for the vehicle to tow or carry a separate generator.

A primary goal of this program is to develop a complete APU package -- an engine, generator, controls and mounting that can be provided to vehicle manufacturers interested in producing hybrid electric drive vehicles, Rankin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, NEW ZEALAND SIGN OPEN-SKIES PACT

TEXT.P: Singapore and New Zealand signed an open-skies agreement on Monday which will lift restrictions on air travel between the two countries.
The initialing of the agreement was welcomed as a timely development by Singapore Airlines and Air New Zealand, which recently formed a commercial alliance.
Airlines of the two countries can now fly whatever routes they choose between Singapore and any point in New Zealand and operate unlimited numbers of flights.
They can also fly beyond the two countries to any third point they wish, if authorities in the third area agree.
Singapore signed its first open-skies agreement with the United States in April this year, followed by a similar pact with Brunei in May.
SIA now operates seven round-trip flights per week on the Singapore-New Zealand route, while Air New Zealand operates five.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
