DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SINGAPORE TO HOLD WTO TALKS IN LATE OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore will hold another round of talks Oct. 27 on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said Tuesday.

Chen said the talks will be held when representatives from the two nations attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's Special Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore, scheduled for Oct. 27-28.

During the talks, Singapore is expected to present a list of 40 industrial products, including petrochemical, electric and electronics items, for which Singapore hopes that Taiwan will cut tariffs, Chen said.

Singapore will also request that Taiwan open maritime auxiliary services, including sea cargo handling, storage and warehousing in ports, agency services, freight forwarding and container station and depot services.

Taiwan and Singapore reached a preliminary agreement during ministerial-level talks last year to complete the maritime services talks before the year 2000. But Chen said that because a global framework has yet to be completed, it is doubtful that Taiwan can make any promises in that area in the absence of such an agreement.

Taiwan has completed negotiations with 21 of 26 WTO signatory nations which have requested bilateral talks over the past four years, and is hoping that talks with the remaining members can be completed soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices dropped on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 33.81 points to close at 8,429.35.
The bourse opened at 8,480.77 and experienced a high of 8,489.38 and a low of 8,391.3.
Losers outnumber gainers 238 to 151, with 79 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.07 billion (US$2.63 billion).
The turnover was not only the lowest this month but also the lowest since the May 27 amount of NT$73.60 billion (US$2.58 billion).

Except for construction stocks, which recorded an increase of 0.7 percent, all other areas saw a decline. Textile stocks dropped the most at 1.8 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 0.7 percent, financial stocks at 0.5 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.3 percent and electrical engineering shares at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHEN CROSS-STRAIT TALKS CAN RESUME IS UNKNOWN

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday that Taiwan cannot decide unilaterally when talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resume.
Siew made the remarks before the Legislature in response to reports that a task force on mainland relations, which has been idle for some time, will be back in action soon.
The reports surfaced following recent remarks by leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait appealing for the resumption of talks.

But, Siew said Taiwan cannot decide unilaterally either the timetable or the agenda for such talks. At the moment, only the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is making necessary preparations. If necessary, it will submit its proposals to the task force.

Siew said that the task force was set up to coordinate and integrate mainland policy between various government agencies. It will be convened by the vice premier on an irregular basis and will have no specific agenda.

Siew said many problems arise in the course of cross-trait exchanges, but the issues often remain unresolved because of a lack of consultation channels. He said that if technical issues cannot be worked out, it will be more difficult to build mutual trust.
On discussions regarding direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait, Siew said that the issue is not limited to matters of commercial interest and expediency.
He said that only on the premises of national security and dignity will it be feasible to discuss such issues.

Siew also said that, given the fact of separate rule on Taiwan and the mainland, the sovereignty of the Chinese nation should be shared by the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. He said that if mainland China can cast away its hegemonic mentally, it should not be too difficult to diffuse the row across the Taiwan Strait.

Legislator Chu Feng-chih of the ruling Kuomintang suggested that the Republic of China mobilize all private groups of friendly nations in Europe and the Americas to push for increased ROC involvement in the international community.

Siew lauded her suggestion, saying that participation in multilateral organizations has always been a policy objective of the government, including its bid to rejoin the United Nations and the World Trade Organization.
He added that the ROC hopes to share its developmental experience with other nations so as to repay the international community for the assistance it has received in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TOP BRASS CALLS FOR MORE POPULAR SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Huang Hsien-yung said on Tuesday he has asked his superiors to discipline him for the crash of a C-130 transport plane at Taipei's Sungshan Airport on Oct. 10, in which five Air Force officers were killed.
Huang made the statement after attending a joint funeral service for the five officers.

"As the top commander, I must assume responsibility for any accident or mishap in the Air Force. But I can't offer to resign. It's the authority of the president or the chief of the General Staff to order me to quit. I can only ask my superiors to reprimand me," Huang told the press.

Huang's remarks were seen as a response to demands by some lawmakers that he resign to take the responsibility for a spate of tragic mishaps involving the Air Force in recent weeks, including the crashes of two F-5 jet fighters in the mountainous region of eastern Taiwan near Hualien on Sept. 30.

Huang said that on Monday he presented to Gen. Lo Pen-li, chief of the General Staff, a report recommending a reprimand for himself over the C-130 crash and other accidents that have befallen his branch of service.

Huang said he could not agree with the view held by some lawmakers that Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling should step down to assume responsibility for the recent military mishaps. "The demand is unreasonable and unjustifiable," he claimed, adding that the minister is responsible for formulating military buildup policy and planning. "Under Chiang's leadership, our second-generation military buildup plan has been completed and our air defense capabilities have been beefed up. I see no reason for Chiang to quit at the moment."

Huang said the Air Force is conducting an overall review of its operations, management and training. "We have sent to the United States the flight recorder installed on the crashed C-130 transport for decoding. After the data contained in the device are available, we'll give the public a detailed report on the cause of the crash."

The Air Force has also asked China Airlines to help decode a voice recorder, which records all conversations in the aircraft cabin. "The data, expected to become available within a week, may also help us determine the cause," Huang said.

On the basis of data available at the moment, several factors, including inadequate training, the pilot's failure to abide by flight regulations, bad weather and possible errors on the aircraft's instrument panel, might have contributed to the crash.
Huang further said that some of the most critical questions may concern potential deficiencies in training procedures at the Air Force's wing-level units.

Huang said the Air Force General Headquarters has drafted a plan to discipline wing-level units in accordance with military regulations. The report will be made public after being approved by the General Staff Headquarters, he added.

In the wake of the incident, Huang said, the Air Force has examined its operations and management at all levels. "We have found that training for junior pilots must be reinforced," Huang said, adding that the Air Force has decided that all junior pilots must pass stringent qualification tests before they will be allowed to fly the country's newly acquired second-generation warplanes.

Huang admitted that the recent series of tragic accidents did have some adverse impact on the Air Force morale. "But the phenomenon will be temporary, and I earnestly hope that the general public will give more support and encouragement to all Air Force staff."

Huang also refuted speculation that an occasional mishap involving Air Force combat planes would undermine Taiwan's air defense capabilities. "Such speculation is unfounded," Huang said, assuring the public that with the gradual full deployment of second-generation warplanes, Taiwan can sustain its current air supremacy over the mainland for five to eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.001 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$28.478.
The greenback opened at the day's low of NT$28.472 and had a high of 28.484.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$158 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MOUNTS PROPAGANDA OFFENSIVE ON POLITICAL NEGOTIATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Chi-kuan & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is to publish an article in its Cross-Straits Relations Monthly that explains Beijing's standpoint on cross-Taiwan Strait political negotiations and marks a new propaganda offensive aimed at luring Taipei into such talks.
Reports have said that the October issue of the monthly, to be published later this month, urges early political negotiations between Taipei and Beijing.

The main points of Yu Liwen's "Starting Early Political Negotiations to Promote the Development of Cross-Strait Relations" were released Monday through Xinhua, the official mainland news agency, and in Tuesday's overseas edition of the People's Daily, indicating that Beijing views the article as highly significant.

The article reportedly covers the timing, mutual understanding and steps necessary for political negotiations between the two sides. It stresses that ARATS and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation can discuss the protocol for political negotiations, which signals that Beijing has appointed ARATS to pioneer such cross-strait talks.

Beijing has been increasing its efforts on the Taiwan issue since the handover of the former British colony of Hong Kong to mainland rule on July 1. In his political report at the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin discussed with unprecedented length the relationship across the Taiwan Strait and urged Taipei to respond soon to his call for political negotiations.
Later, mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen also said he hopes Taipei authorities will engage Beijing in a dialogue on procedures concerning political negotiations between the two sides.

These high-level statements and the fact that the monthly organ of ARATS, an association under the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland State Council, is to publish the aforementioned article all reflect that Beijing is pushing for progress on China's reunification.

As part of its attempt to achieve a breakthrough in cross-strait political negotiations, Beijing has advanced three "understandings" for proceeding with these talks: adherence to the "One China principle," though its political meaning can be left behind; equal negotiations under this principle; and allowing no interference from the outside world in the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ASE GROUP UNVEILS HUGE IC MARKET PLAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ASE Group, a major packager and tester of semiconductors, on Tuesday unveiled an ambitious NT$340 billion (US$11.9 billion) investment plan aimed at capturing 17 percent of the global semiconductor packaging market and 16 percent of the global semiconductor testing market by the year 2010.
Under the plan, the consortium will establish facilities in the new Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park, the announcement said.

One of Taiwan's biggest consortiums, the ASE Group currently controls three major stock-issuing companies: Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc., which is listed on the Taiwan bourse, and Fulei Electronics and Hungching Construction, both of which are traded on the US stock exchange.

At present, the mainstay of ASE's semiconductor production is in its plant in the Nantzu Export Processing Zone outside Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. Other facilities in Penang, Malaysia and the Philippines supplement the Taiwan plant's output.
ASE is currently the world's second largest manufacturer of integrated circuit (IC) packaging equipment.

ASE Chairman Jason Chang told reporters the investment plan is necessary due to the Kaohsiung facility's inability to meet expected future demand amid rising expansion in the global semiconductor sector.
Chang predicted that by 2010 the Taiwan ASE plants alone will hold 13 percent of the global IC packaging market, with business growing at an astonishing rate of 25 percent per annum.
By the same year, the ASE IC testing operations on Taiwan should control 12 percent of the world market, with business growing at an average of 32 percent a year, he said.
Combined with the consortium's overseas operations, ASE's IC packaging and testing operations are expected to bring in some NT$479.5 billion (US$16.8 billion) in revenues in the year 2010.
By that year, the consortium will employ some 56,000 people worldwide and command 17 percent of the global IC packaging market and 16 percent of the world IC testing market, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS INVESTIGATOR RECEIVES COLD SHOULDER IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: A United Nations investigator has found that human rights can be a very touchy topic in the United States, a country that frequently decries abuses in other nations, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday.

Concluding an 18-day U.S. tour last week, Bacre Waly Ndiaye, a Senegalese lawyer who holds the title of U.N. Special Rapporteur on Extrajudicial, Summary or Arbitrary Executions, said that when he arrived to investigate human rights abuses in the United States last month, he had decided to begin his probe at the top -- with President Clinton. He planned to subsequently work his way through Vice President Al Gore, the Supreme Court, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and other Washington luminaries.
But none of the nation's top officials would see Ndiaye.

Officials in the former Yugoslavia, Rwanda or Burundi are accustomed to international visitors sifting through evidence of rights abuses, the Journal said. But the United States is rarely such a prominent target. Ndiaye is only the second such U.N. monitor to visit the United States; the first came in 1994, to probe racial discrimination.

Ndiaye's trip has clearly made U.S. officials uncomfortable, and it was even suspected as being "an intentional insult to the United States and our nation's legal system" by Sen. Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, according to the Journal.

For his part, Ndiaye says he was "quite disappointed" that few federal officials would see him, noting that the State Department issues an annual survey of human rights abuses by other countries. But Ndiaye had audiences with lower-level officials at the departments of State and Justice, and the State Department wrote letters to prisons urging that he be granted access. And at state and local levels, Ndiaye has had better luck.

Washington is a signatory to various international agreements that cite the death penalty as being a violation of the right to life, urging that it be applied only in exceptional cases, and be banned outright in cases involving juvenile offenders.
But at a time when the United Nation's top human rights body is urging countries to work toward abolishing the death penalty, executions are on the rise in the United States, the Journal pointed out.

Fifty-seven prisoners have been executed in the United States so far this year, surpassing the total of 56 executions carried out in all of 1995, the highest number recorded in a single year since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in the 1970s.
"Only China has expanded death penalty laws at the same rate," Ndiaye says. And Beijing has not granted him permission to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE FIRMS BOOST STAKES IN FOREIGN COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Singapore companies invested an additional S$4.3 billion to buy shares of foreign companies in 1995, according to a study by the Singapore Department of Statistics.
This resulted is a hefty 60 percent jump in the holdings of foreign equity shares by Singapore companies as of the end of 1995, compared to the previous year.

The study showed that Singapore-based companies owned S$11.6 billion worth of quoted and unquoted shares in companies abroad at the end of 1995, up from S$7.3 billion worth of shares owned a year earlier.
The big increase in foreign share investments was in fact responsible for a significant 34 percent jump in portfolio investments during the year.
At last count, Singapore's portfolio investment abroad amounted to S$16.1 billion, representing one-sixth of the country's stock of investments overseas.

Portfolio investments comprise investments in paid-up shares of companies in which the investor has no influence over policies, as well as in preference shares, bonds, debentures and other securities issued by foreign governments and overseas companies.
The study, titled Singapore's Investment Abroad 1994-95, covered some 3,300 Singapore-based companies with investments overseas. It had been expanded to include the financial sector.
Consequently, information for the overall corporate sector's investment abroad has become available for the first time, the Statistics Department said.
Overall, the study showed that Singapore's external wing continued to expand vigorously, with total foreign investments up a robust 12 percent in 1995.

By the end of 1995, the total value of foreign assets owned by Singapore's corporate sector was estimated at S$97.7 billion -- equivalent to about 80 percent of the country's gross national product (GNP).
GNP measures the total value of goods and services produced by a country in a year, and includes remittances from Singaporeans overseas.
The department said that Singapore's stock of total direct investment abroad amounted to S$46.2 billion at the end of 1995, up 21 percent over the previous year.
Its share of total investment abroad increased from 44 percent at the end of 1994 to 47 percent at the end of 1995.

The increase was due mostly to growth in direct investment by Singapore companies expanding and acquiring equity interest in overseas affiliates (S$5.7 billion) and by reinvestment of profits (S$1.4 billion), the department said.

As a proportion of total investment abroad, portfolio investment rose from 14 percent to 17 percent while investment in other foreign assets decreased from 42 percent to 36 percent over the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: OTTAWA OFFERS LITTLE HOPE OF EARLY END TO MAERSK DUBAI SAGA

TEXT.P: A major Canadian newspaper said Monday that, 19 months after the Maersk Dubai saga began in Halifax, a legal life buoy still eludes the four Filipino sailors and Taiwan's prosecutor.
The Canadian government is offering players in the high-sea murder drama little hope of bringing court wrangling to a speedy conclusion, The Globe and Mail reported.

The four Filipinos, who testified in a Halifax court that they saw three Romanian stowaways thrown overboard the Taiwanese container vessel, have sought refugee status in Canada. However, there is still no word on their applications 90 days after hearings concluded last Friday, the daily said in a dispatch from Halifax.

Like unwanted castaways, the four sailors may share a sense of being adrift as they wait in Halifax to learn their fate, it said. "On the other side of the world, Taiwan's investigation" into the murder allegations against the ship's skipper and five other officers "also seems to be listing badly," it added.

In both instances, part of the explanation seems to lie in Ottawa, which last week lost another round -- probably the last -- in a long series of court battles generated by the Dubai saga, according to the report.
In the unhappy view of the Taiwanese government, the same Canadian Department of Justice that promised to help fell short when Taipei came looking for assistance last month, it pointed out.

It quoted Eddie Greenspan, a Toronto lawyer whose services were retained by Taiwan, as saying, "We thought and understood there would be full cooperation from the RCMP (Royal Canadian Mounted Police) and federal government.... The reception was less than favorable, almost downright rude."

The daily said that complicating everything was the peculiar status of Taiwan, "an international oddity that enjoys excellent trade relations with Canada but no diplomatic recognition." This may help explain why Ottawa has not been helpful to Taiwan's prosecutor Richard Su, who came to Ottawa early last month hoping to interview the four Filipinos, key witnesses in the whole incident.
In their series of short meetings, according to Greenspan, Canadian officials barely gave Su the time of day. Rather, they merely reiterated that the Filipinos had nothing to say, the report said.

"We're not asking for an act of recognition, we're asking for some assistance," Greenspan was quoted as saying. "There's a lot of things the Canadian government could do for the Filipino crew members to make it easier to facilitate their attendance.
"They could even indicate they would look favorably on their admission into the country, if they were to cooperate. There are carrots, and that's the ultimate carrot."

Su has been trying to get them to testify in a Taiwan court. They have refused to go, on the ground that death threats have been made to them and their families in the Philippines. And Su could not even meet them in Canada, as Ottawa refused to help him.
The Filipinos testimony is critical for Su's probe into the case. "If they don't come here, it will be very difficult for the judge to find the captain guilty," Su said in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S AIDC SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH US SIKORSKY HELICOPTER CORP.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Ranan Huang & Lawrence Chu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aero Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) and the US-based Sikorsky Helicopter Corp., one of the world's biggest manufacturers of helicopters, signed a strategic alliance Monday.

The pact was inked at Sikorsky's Connecticut headquarters by Eugene Buckley, president of the US firm, and, on behalf of the AIDC, by Yin Chi-ming, the Republic of China on Taiwan's vice minister of Economic Affairs.
Under the agreement, Sikorsky will explore avenues of cooperation with the state-run Taiwan firm in the hope of expanding both firms' shares of the Asia-Pacific and global markets.

Sikorsky became the 49th major multinational firm to sign a strategic alliance with Taipei under the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs' efforts to transform Taiwan into a major manufacturing center of the Asia-Pacific region.
Sikorsky was also the first helicopter manufacturer to sign a strategic alliance agreement with Taiwan.
In remarks delivered after the signing ceremony, Yin said the agreement would surely bring many benefits to both sides while also raising the standard of technology in Taiwan.

As one of the world's biggest helicopter manufacturers, with sales operations in some 45 countries worldwide, Sikorsky has promised to consider jointly developing the S-92 mid-sized transport helicopter with the AIDC, Yin said.
Yin also promised Sikorsky's president that Taiwan would be the ideal partner for the firm in the Asia-Pacific region.
Responding to Yin, Buckley said his company regards its strategic alliance with Taiwan as very important and that it has made future strategic cooperation with the island a major priority.
By strengthening bilateral cooperation, both sides can cope with the challenges in the increasingly globalized international market and achieve results that will satisfy all, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO LEAVE FOR US THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Republic of China Representative to the United States Stephen Chen is scheduled to leave for Washington, D.C. on Thursday evening to assume his new post.
The Clinton administration is expected to formally inform the ROC government of its consent to Chen's appointment on Wednesday morning, sources said on Tuesday.
Chen, incumbent deputy secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, will succeed Jason Hu, who has been appointed minister of foreign affairs.
Chen, a career diplomat, will be the ROC's seventh de facto ambassador to the United States since the two countries severed diplomatic relations in 1979.

President Lee is scheduled to preside over a swearing-in ceremony for Chen on Thursday morning. The new envoy to the US will then attend a luncheon hosted by Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan in his honor. During the luncheon, Chen is expected to brief members of the legislature's Foreign Affairs Committee on his plans for his new office.
Chen paid a visit to Premier Vincent Siew on Monday, bidding farewell to the premier and receiving instructions from him concerning his new assignment.
During their 30-minute talks, Siew emphasized the importance of ROC-US relations and urged Chen to continue promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation based on the successes already achieved.

In addition to reinforcing contacts with the US executive branch and Congress, Siew asked Chen to also boost engagements with the academic, commercial and industrial communities, as well as the major US think tanks and media organizations.

Chen, who has previously served a four-year stint as the ROC's deputy representative to the United States, said in a recent interview with the CNA that "do more and talk less" is the most important working guideline for engaging the United States, adding it is equally important to know how to "talk."

Touching on the establishment of a high-level dialogue channel between Taipei and Washington, Chen said cultivation of mutual trust is most critical. "Mutual trust and understanding will help ensure smooth communications."
With more than 30 years of service in the diplomatic arena, Chen is no stranger to mainland China's incessant efforts to block and squeeze Taiwan's presence in the international community.

Chen said he looks upon his new assignment as a challenge, adding that he will encourage all ROC officials stationed in the United States to work out innovative strategies to help cement bilateral ties and expand cooperation in various fields.

Observers said Chen's first test will come in the first few days of his new job, as mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is scheduled to leave for the United States on Oct. 26 for a state visit, during which Jiang will hold a summit meeting with President Bill Clinton, the first top-level tete-a-tete between the two sides since 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARD-SIZE PCS TO OPEN NEW DIMENSION IN INDUSTRIAL COMPUTERS

TEXT.P: Fully coming to grips with the trend of "miniaturization," researchers at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) have successfully created "card-size" 486 PCs, an innovation which is poised to open up a new sphere of applications for industrial computers.

After months of R&D, engineers at ITRI's Computer and Communications Research Lab have recently made a breakthrough in IC package technology by developing the know-how to produce a 0.75 mm ball-grid array (BGA), said Ho Tsung-cheh, a section chief at the lab.

The 0.75 mm BGA helps to miniaturize the chipsets and integrate key components into a high-density, compact unit, making the PCs very small -- about the size of a cigarette pack -- but highly functional and reliable, Ho said.

The research engineers encountered a number of problems in the miniaturization and integration process, mainly involving overheating and interruption, he noted, adding that when the 8.5cm x 5.4cm x 1.6cm PCs are connected to display panels and keyboards, they make perfect controllers for industrial systems, including automatic machinery, portable testing equipment and medical examining equipment.
The lab expects to produce card-size 586 Pentium PCs in March next year, and the still more cutting-edge 686 Pentium II models in later months, he added.
The card-size 486 PCs will debut at the 1997 Taipei International Electronics Show which opens Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE ASSETS TOTAL US$160 BILLION

TEXT.P: The government and private sectors of the Republic of China have owned US$160 billion of foreign exchange, Governor Y.D. Sheu of the Central Bank of China said Monday at the Legislative Yuan.

Answering a question by Legislator Hung Hsin-jung about the foreign exchange assets of the nation, Sheu said the Central Bank of the China has US$87 billion of foreign exchange reserves, while the private sectors have invested US$30 billion in mainland China, another US$30 billion in Southeast Asian countries, and US$10 billion in Europe and America. It is estimated that there are 37,000 Taiwan investors on the Chinese mainland.

Sheu said the foreign exchange reserves is managed on the basis of profitability, security and flexibility of investment. A considerable portion of the foreign exchange reserve is invested in U.S. bonds and treasury bills. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW SAYS GOV'T HAS HELPED STABILIZE FINANCIAL MARKET

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday that the Central Bank of China has taken effective measures to stabilize the financial market of Taiwan.
Siew made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan when answering an interpellation by Legislator Chu Feng-chih (KMT-Taoyuan).

The premier said the recent financial crises in Southeast Asian countries have made strong impact on the stock and foreign exchange markets of many other countries in the world. Taiwan's export trade and commodity prices would have been affected seriously, if the Central Bank of China had not taken effective measures to stabilize the financial market, he added.

He pointed out that Taiwan continued to enjoy trade surplus in September, and that economic indicators have proved that the measures taken by the central bank to stabilize the financial market are appropriate. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANKS INTERESTED IN OPENING OFFICES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Many Taiwan banks are interested in opening offices in mainland China to improve their service to Taiwan investors there, an official of the Bankers Association of the Republic of China said here Tuesday.
He said they are interested in setting up offices in Shanghai, Guangzhou, Beijing, Dalian, Pudong, and Shengzhen, because there are many Taiwan investors in those places.

Governor Y.D. Sheu of the Central Bank of China said Monday at the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan banks are encouraged to set up offices in mainland Chinese cities to familiarize themselves with the financial situations on the Chinese mainland and to improve their service to Taiwan investors there. This will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he added.
Sheu also said that the bankers association may set up its offices on the Chinese mainland first in order to improve service to its member banks.

The official of the association said however that mainland Chinese authorities have not responded to the association's proposal to set up offices on the Chinese mainland. He also quoted some bankers as saying that there is a long way for them to go before they can actually set up branches and operate freely without political risks on the Chinese mainland, because mainland China is still a centrally-controlled economy. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA COULD BE ASIA'S 'BRAIN TRUST': MANAGEMENT EXPERT

TEXT.P: Australia's human resources could make it "the brain trust" of Asia, according to Dr. Kenichi Ohmae, one of the world's best known management consultants.

In an interview with the Australian Financial Review, the leading business daily in Australia, Ohmae said Australia's greatest competitive strength is not in minerals and agriculture but its "human stock."

"Your people are creative, good quality, low cost -- frankly -- and hard-working. So, based on the quality of its people, there is no evidence that Australia has any trouble with being a leader in the Asia-Pacific," he said.

"Australia should be an Asian center for the information technology industry -- you have unique strengths. You are the biggest English-speaking country in Asia, you have a long history of market democracy, you have a large population of people who are networked already, you have an excellent education system, and a high-quality workforce," he commented.
"Don't concentrate on databases or networks -- you don't have to have these because you can buy them anywhere -- concentrate on software, on educational content, on medical content," he advised.
He urged Australia to ignore the chorus demanding subsidies or tax holidays for potential investors.
"Australia is inherently very, very attractive and I have never seen any need for subsidies or special tax incentives," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE GOV'T WANTS PORTS TO MATCH ASIAN COMPETITORS' PERFORMANCES

TEXT.P: The Australian government has demanded that maritime union workers here compete with their Asian counterparts in Singapore and other Asian countries.
Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith set the provocative new performance benchmarks for maritime unions and employers Monday.
He called for a 43 percent improvement in container handling rates in all Australian ports. But union officials rejected his call, calling the target unrealistic and unfair.
Reith also told employers that it was their responsibility to "explore the flexibilities" under the government's industrial relations legislation to speed up waterfront reform.
He said international competition demands that container movement rates must improve by more than 43 percent.
Container lift rates should reach an average of 25 lifts per hour from the current 17.4, Reith told a transport meeting in Melbourne.

The 25 lifts per hour would put Australia on a part with Singapore, the world's biggest container port, but Australian maritime unions maintain such a target is unrealistic because port operations are fundamentally different in the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN AGENCY PULLS OUT AFTER BEIJING BALKS AT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The diplomatic warfare between Beijing and Taipei continues here in Geneva.

A specialized United Nations agency based in Geneva was forced to withdraw from jointly hosting a high-level meeting with the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) to promote market-access opportunities for the world's poorest nations after Beijing objected that the venue would provide Taipei with a de facto political platform, according to reports of the world trade body on Tuesday.
"The Chinese forced this," noted a high-level US official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
About 35 trade ministers representing some of the world's poorest countries, those with per capita incomes of US$500 or less, are expected to attend the meeting, scheduled for Oct. 27-28.
Following months of behind-the-scenes diplomacy in Geneva, Washington and Beijing, a special session of the WTO General Council decided that the meeting will now be hosted only by the WTO.

At the WTO summit last December in Singapore, trade ministers agreed that the WTO, along with the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and other agencies, should organize a meeting to enhance trade opportunities for the world's poorest countries.
Mainland China was adamant to the end, however, that participation by UNCTAD would be seen as a de-facto participation of Taiwan in a UN meeting, the WTO report said.
Because Taiwan is an observer at the WTO and mainland China is a member of the UN, Beijing felt the joint sponsorship would be seen as mainland China and Taiwan participating in the same conference.

According to trade diplomats, the insistence by a group of Central American countries -- including El Salvador and Costa Rica -- that Taiwan and other WTO observer nations not be excluded from the meeting left the UN agency with no alternative but to step aside, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER ANNOUNCES SINGAPORE LAUNCH OF CYBER-TV

TEXT.P: Acer, the world's No.6 PC company, announced on Monday the launch in Singapore of the Acer Cyber-TV set-top appliance, offering an innovative hybrid of television and Internet expected to appeal to millions of TV users.
Shih Chen-jung, chairman and CEO of the Acer Group, made the announcement in a keynote speech at a press conference in Singapore.

The Acer Cyber-TV makes use of a standard wireless remote control to access all its features, just like any other audio or video player home users are used to. A separate wireless keyboard is used for typing e-mail and surfing the Internet. These enable users to watch their usual television programs and simultaneously use the Internet.
It also comes with a smart card reader that allows the user to slot in a smart card for online shopping, home banking and access to secured Internet information services.

"The Acer Cyber-TV set-top is Acer's jumpstart venture into the software and service business," Shih said. "We aim to deliver genuinely affordable and user-friendly products to households. It is our goal for everyone at home to be empowered with more intelligent choices of different services and a wider variety of entertainment and educational programs."

Central to the TV-centric concept is a specially designed user's interface by Acer. Once switched on, users will see their usual television programs, but an icon, codenamed Cyber-TV, will be positioned at the top left corner of the television screen to provide access to the Internet channels with just a click on the wireless remote control.

The Cyber-TV also allows the user to customize content such as local weather and traffic conditions, stock market updates and news taglines for easy, quick updates. This feature is made possible by using the latest "push" technology, Acer said.
Acer said that its choice of Singapore as the first launch site for this innovative product is in recognition of the country's significant progress in becoming an "intelligent island."
"Singapore has one of the best multimedia network infrastructures in the world today," said Lu Hung-yee, president and CEO of Acer Computer International Ltd.
The new appliance has been tentatively priced at S$495 and may be provided free of charge to home subscribers who may pay monthly fees for the services they use.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DEPUTY PM SAYS PAULINE HANSON REPRESENTS 'EVIL'

TEXT.P: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer has branded opponents of Australian investment in Asia, including One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, as "forces of evil."

In a dispatch from Bangkok, the mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Tuesday reported that Fischer lashed out at "those people back on Australia who want to stop investment going out or coming in."
Now visiting Thailand, Fischer made a vigorous defense of Australian investment in the Asian region, attacking Hanson's views on Asia and Asians.
Hanson, an independent member of parliament, came to international notoriety last September when she declared that "Australia is in danger of being swamped by Asians."
Fischer said his visit to Thailand was "part of an ongoing strategy of (Australian) engagement with Asia."

DOC.HEADLINE: US THE BIGGEST MARKET FOR TAIWAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The United States imported US$21.56 billion-worth of products from Taiwan during the first nine months of this year, making it the biggest overseas market for the Republic of China, according to statistics just released by the Ministry of Finance.
The nation's exports in the January-September period amounted to US$89.79 billion, with sales to the United States making up 24 percent of the total.

Hong Kong came second, with its purchases from Taiwan for the same period reaching US$20.63 billion, or 23 percent. Europe was the third-largest overseas market, with imports hitting US$13.24 billion, accounting for 14.7 percent of the total.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's imports in the first three-quarters of this year totaled US$84.31 billion, with Japan, the United States and Europe as the major suppliers.

Imports from Japan were worth US$21.41 billion, comprising 25.4 percent of the total imports, while imports from the US reached US$17.09 billion, or 20.3 percent and Europe was the third-largest supplier, with US$15.9 billion, or about 19 percent of the total.

Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$4.47 billion in its trade with the United States and US$19.21 billion in trade with Hong Kong in the nine-month period, but suffered a deficit of US$2.66 billion in trade with Europe and US$12.4 billion in trade with Japan, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKING DEPOSITS SURGE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Accumulated deposits at all banking institutions in Taiwan reached NT$16.96 trillion (US$593 billion) at the end of June, up 11.95 percent from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
The ministry said that the growth resulted mainly from more vigorous trade and exchanges in the local housing and stock markets than last year.

The statistics also show that accumulated loan volume released by banking institutions as of June hit NT$12.26 trillion (US$428.7 billion), an 8.35 percent rise in comparison with the level of a year ago.
The banking institutions included in the statistics were local banks, Taiwan branches of foreign banks, trust companies and postal remittance and savings banks.

The MOF said that most of the deposits are kept by banks in the island's metropolitan regions, such as Taipei City and County, Kaohsiung City and Taichung City, while these banks also provided most loan services over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO ADMITS MURDER, ROBBERY

TEXT.P: Filipino worker Jonathan Maala Burgos on Tuesday admitted to having murdered a Tainan woman and her two children after robbing her house on Sunday night.

Burgos, the boyfriend of a runaway Filipina named Babe who once worked as a maid at Huang Li-yen's home, admitted his guilt after intense questioning by police. He had denied any involvement in the murders since his arrest on Monday.
He confessed that he decided to rob Huang because both his father and son, who live in the Philippines, are ill, and he needed money badly.
Burgos, who had visited Huang's home several times when Babe worked there, said he knew where Huang kept her money.
He went to the apartment on Sunday night with the intention of stealing the money, but killed Huang, 32, and her children after Huang discovered him and a struggle ensued, Burgos said.

Police investigating videotapes obtained from a surveillance camera trained on the victims' apartment building found images of a man matching Burgo's description who appeared at around the time the crime was committed.

Huang was found brutally slain along with her 11-year-old son and seven-year-old daughter on Monday morning. All three had been stabbed and slashed to death. Huang's husband, a fruit wholesaler, had spent Sunday night at another of the family's residences in the city, which probably saved his life.

Police became more sure of Burgos' involvement on Monday when they found a fresh five-centimeter cut on his left hand and Burgos finally confessed after a pile of cash -- about NT$570,000 -- was found on Burgos' dormitory balcony. A handbag containing an estimated NT$700,000 had been stolen from the house.
Burgos told the police that he threw the murder weapon into a roadside garbage dump, burnt his bloodstained clothes outside his dormitory and threw the handbag into a ditch.
Meanwhile, police also found Babe on Tuesday. Although she was found to have been uninvolved in the crime, police said she will be repatriated because she is staying illegally in Taiwan.

About one-tenth of the foreign laborers in Taiwan are living here illegally, most of them having absconded from their original employers. Thousands of Filipinos who come to Taiwan on legal work contracts flee their legal jobs to avoid being sent home when labor contracts expire after two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROUND OF US-ROC WTO TALKS BEGINS WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and the United States will meet in Taipei on Wednesday for a 16th round of talks on the terms of Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported on Tuesday.

The two sides, to be headed by BOFT Director General Chen Ruey-long and David Burns, the US Trade Representative Office's director for Asia-Pacific affairs, will tackle issues including Taiwan's medical pricing system, infringement of commercial patents, Taiwan's WTO protocol and tariff cuts, BOFT officials said.

During the week-long meeting, the two sides will also discuss Taiwan's government procurement systems, as well as the opening of local agricultural, insurance, stock brokerage, telecommunications and service markets.

BOFT officials also revealed that the US side will ask Taiwan to impose import tariffs on US-made automobiles on an energy-consumption basis, rather than on an engine capacity basis, adding that this might present problems for Taiwan, since imposing auto tariffs according to engine capacity has long been standard international practice.
Some more sensitive issues still outstanding, such as Taiwan imports of US pork, cigarettes and alcoholic products, will not be included in this round of talks, they noted.

Taiwan has completed talks with 21 of the 26 WTO member-states which have asked for bilateral negotiations on Taiwan's trade regime as preconditions for consenting to its admission into the world trade regulatory body.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND ICELAND MAY ESTABLISH REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Foreign Affairs Minister John Chang said on Tuesday that his ministry is studying the feasibility of setting up a representative office in Iceland and of allowing Iceland to open its own representative office here.

Chang made the announcement at the Legislative Yuan while answering questions on the government's position on mainland China's continuing attempts to stifle the Republic of China's presence in the international community.
The questions were prompted by the cancellation of Vice President Lien Chan's scheduled visit to Spain during his just-concluded European trip as a result of Beijing's boycott.

Lien, accompanied by his wife and Senior Presidential Advisor Hsu Li-teh, made an unofficial tour of Iceland on Oct. 5-10, followed by a two-day visit to Austria. He returned home on Monday, canceling his visit to Spain at the request of the Spanish government.

Chang told legislators that the diplomatic setback will not discourage his ministry from developing relations with other nations, pointing out that as a sovereign state, the ROC has the right, the most basic right, to expand its space in the international community.

The foreign minister stressed that the ROC's efforts to develop foreign links is not aimed at provoking mainland China. On the contrary, he said, the ROC hopes to maintain stable cross-strait relations. The problem, he added, is that Beijing simply cannot grasp the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now divided and ruled by two governemnts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-MEXICO ECONOMIC MEETING SLATED FOR NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang is scheduled to depart for Mexico City on Saturday at the head of a government delegation to attend the ninth Joint Meeting between the Mexican and Taiwan Business Councils.

During the five-day meeting, Chang will familiarize himself with the business and investment climate in Mexico, and meet with Taiwan investors to know better their business development and the problems they have encountered there.

Mexico is Taiwan's major export market in Latin America and its third largest trading partner in that region. Taiwan exported US$470 million worth of merchandise to Mexico in 1996, up 20 percent over the 1995 level, while importing US$210 million worth of Mexican products, down 3 percent from the year-earlier level.

As of June this year, about 50 Taiwan businesses have relocated their operations to Mexico, mainly in the two-way trade and manufacturing sectors, according to tallies from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Business and investment relations between Taiwan and Mexico have been strengthened significantly since the MOEA established an economic affairs section under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Mexico in June last year, MOEA officials said.
The Mexican government has also often clearly shown its support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization, the officials noted.
Quoting an estimate released by the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council, MOEA officials said Mexico's economy is expected to grow 5 percent in 1997 and an even higher 5.5 percent in 1998.

Since the Mexican government embarked on a five-year economic revitalization plan in March 1995 to bolster the country's economy and stabilize the currency, the Latin American country has sustained economic growth of 5 percent annually, with this level expected to continue through 2000, the officials pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR END TO CROSS-STRAIT HOSTILITY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's largest opposition party said here on Tuesday that his party has deliberately toned down its pro-Taiwan independence advocacy in an attempt to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and facilitate an early end to cross-strait hostility.

"However, this does not mean that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has forsaken its goal of creating an independent Taiwan republic," DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said in a keynote speech to a seminar on Taiwan-mainland Chinese relations sponsored by the Paris-based International Relations Research Institute.

Hsu said the DPP has played a critical role in Taiwan's democratization, adding that the party, with a view to ensuring regional stability, now focuses on helping reinforce Taiwan's strength and international status rather than on promoting the independence movement.
On cross-strait relations, Hsu said, the DPP has consistently advocated that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait end their hostility and cultivate peaceful, friendly ties.

Claiming that the so-called "one China" policy has hindered Taiwan's bid to walk out into the international community, Hsu said Taiwan should get rid of this historical burden and present itself as a prosperous, vibrant new democracy with an independent, sovereign status to win more international recognition.
Hsu said his current European tour is part of the DPP's efforts to expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers through nurturing friendly ties with major political parties in other countries.

Hsu proudly said Taiwan has managed to outpace Singapore in democratic development mainly because of the existence of a strong opposition force on the island since the martial law era. He stressed that the DPP has played a positive role in pressing the ruling Kuomintang to undertake political reforms.

"The time is gradually ripe for the DPP to gain ruling power," Hsu said, adding that the party has won increasing popular support with its public opinion-oriented political platform, including upgrading Taiwan's international status and establishing a sound social welfare service system.

Speaking on the same occasion, DPP Legislator Parris Chang said Taiwan's future should be determined by the people of Taiwan in accordance with the underlying democratic principle of "popular sovereignty," adding that Taiwan's destiny should neither be determined by Beijing nor Washington.

Chang, an international affairs expert, said that Taiwan, with its achievements in economic development and political democratization, should increase contacts with the international community and break its Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation.

Touching on cross-strait relations, Chang said the DPP is willing to conduct peaceful negotiations and dialogue with Beijing based on the principle of equality and reciprocity in order to promote peaceful co-existence and co-prosperity.
Chang urged Beijing to give up its hegemonic mentality and not to treat Taiwan as another Hong Kong because Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, not a colony.
More than 50 Chinese and French academics attended the seminar moderated by professor Francoise Mengin, a Taiwan affairs expert.
Hsu, heading a high-level DPP delegation, arrived in Paris on Monday after attending a conference in Berlin of top leaders from democratic parties in major countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT URGED TO STEP UP DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Chung-ping, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China, said here Tuesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should step up dialogue for peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and Asia-Pacific region.
Lin said both sides of the Taiwan Strait should also face the fact of "separate rule."
Lin made the remarks in an address on the latest developments in cross-strait relations at a seminar at Columbia University.
Lin said that since Beijing lobbed missiles in waters near Taiwan in the run-up to the ROC presidential election in March 1996, it has adjusted its policy toward the island.

Beijing has tried every means to isolate Taiwan diplomatically, used the pretext of "one China" to stifle Taiwan's efforts to gain a greater profile in the international community, tried to weaken the island's economy by luring more Taiwan investment across the strait, stepped up contacts with Taiwan, modernized its army and sent out implicit signals to put psychological pressure on people on the island, he said.

Lin said the call Beijing has made since ROC President Lee Teng-hui's four-nation Latin American tour last month for both sides to prepare for political dialogue might be due to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin wanting to put on a peace-loving facade before his trip to the United States later this month.

Other reasons for the call, Lin said, could be that Beijing has finally realized that drastic actions to isolate Taipei would backfire and that Jiang wants to achieve something in cross-strait relations during his five-year term to further solidify his position.

Citing recent opinion polls on Taiwan residents' attitude toward cross-strait relations, Lin noted 35 percent of those polled said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should maintain the status quo and decide the future later, with 22 percent favoring both sides maintaining the status quo permanently.

Those who favored the status quo toward future unification and those who favored it toward future independence accounted for 14 percent and 11 percent respectively. Those who wanted speedy unification and speedy independence accounted for 5 percent and 10 percent respectively. The remainder of those polled had no opinion, he added.

He said that 44 percent of those polled called the ROC's diplomatic relations with other countries and cross-strait exchanges equally important. Those who said they believe that developing diplomatic relations is more important accounted for 31 percent, higher than the 23 percent who said the reverse.
The ROC is happy to see mainland China continuing to achieve stable development through its reforms, he stressed.

Lin left Taiwan for the United States on Oct. 9. Before visiting New York, he attended a seminar in Washington, D.C. on Saturday. He will speak on cross-strait relations at the New England School of Law in Boston on Friday.
Lin will return to Taiwan Oct. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON REUNIFICATION METHODS AT PRESENT MEANINGLESS: SIEW

TEXT.P: With Beijing still unwilling to accept the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are two political entities under separate ruling systems, it would be difficult and even "meaningless" to talk about the structure of a reunified China, said Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday.

As long as Beijing continues to refuse to accept any ideas from Taipei that go contrary to its notions, talking about whether Taiwan and mainland China would reunify under a "federal" or "commonwealth" formula just don't make sense, Siew said.
"The crux of the matter is Beijing's ideology," he added.

Fielding a question by Legislator Hung Hsing-jung (KMT-Changhua) at a Legislative Yuan plenary session, Siew said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will reunify naturally and peacefully once the standard of living on the Chinese mainland is significantly improved.

Noting that the late mainland Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping once said it would probably take several hundred years for Taiwan and mainland China to reunify, Siew said once income levels and the ways of life on the two sides become close, reunification would be an easy matter. "Where water flows, a channel is formed," the premier said, quoting an ancient Chinese proverb.
To reach a standard of living like Taiwan enjoys, he added, mainland China will have to do more than it has already.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC RULES OUT ANY ACQUISITION OR MERGER BID

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung-based China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said on Wednesday it has not negotiated any acquisition or merger bids with individual local business groups.
The company was commenting on a newspaper report that the Evergreen Group, which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet, intends to buy into the state-owned shipbuilding firm.
Earlier this year, the Formosa Plastics Group, Taiwan's largest private conglomerate, was also said to be interested in acquiring the CSBC.
"All such reports are not true," a CSBC spokesman said, adding that the company would not consider any acquisition or merger bid at present.

He noted that the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development has demanded that the CSBC complete its privatization by 2001 in accordance with a resolution reached at last year's National Development Conference.
To meet that deadline, the spokesman said, the CSBC is actively expanding its business and improving its financial status to facilitate privatization.
"We'll promote privatization by trading our stock on the Taiwan Stock Exchange," the spokesman said, adding that the CSBC labor union has agreed to the proposal.

The spokesman further said the company will re-evaluate its land assets and plans to trim its capital in order to facilitate its application for listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange. The CSBC currently has total assets of more than NT$35.6 billion (US$1.25 billion).
In addition to building commercial vessels, the CSBC is also capable of building various types of warships, including missile frigates and high-speed patrol boats.
