DOC.HEADLINE: THINK-TANK OUTLINES FACTORS INFLUENCING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Southeast Asia's currency crisis, the development of cross-strait trade relations, and rising risks of Taiwan's high-technology industries are three major factors that may exert impact on the island's economic growth over the next year, a private economic think-tank said on Wednesday.

Specialists at the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) said that in the short term, the New Taiwan dollar will maintain its fairly stable level of around NT$28.5 to the US dollar as a result of Taiwan's stable economic growth, sufficient foreign exchange reserves and protective manipulation of the currency market by the Central Bank of China.
However, they said, it is hard to say whether the NT dollar will maintain its strength in the long term, since there exist several factors that may trigger a currency decline.

These factors include mainland China's eventual depreciation of its renminbi as a result of efforts to sharpen its competitiveness against its Southeast Asian rivals on the world market, and the further depreciation of the Southeast Asian currencies as a result of the failure of a rescue plan to be implemented by the International Monetary Fund, CIER experts said.
If the renminbi depreciates, the NT dollar will have little choice but to follow suit, due to Taiwan's ever-increasing reliance on the mainland market, they pointed out.

With regard to cross-strait trade relations, the experts foresee a brighter future, on the grounds that both Taiwan and the mainland are preparing to enter the World Trade Organization, mainland China needs investment from Taiwan and Taiwan needs mainland China's vast markets. There is also high expectations by the international community of a thaw in ties across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, the CIER experts pointed out that risk factor in the island's high-technology industry, including computer and semiconductor manufacturing, are growing as a result of the short evolution cycle of the industry and the increasing number of industrial disputes in foreign markets.

Rather than putting all Taiwan's eggs in one basket, the experts suggested that the island should not rely too much on the high-technology industry alone, but should help develop or upgrade other, more traditional industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAO'S COMMENTS ON MAINLAND CHINA'S DESIRE TO RESUME NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: Vice Chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chiao Jen-ho observed on Tuesday that an article to be published in "Cross Strait Relations," a monthly magazine published by mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) is significant. However, he added that the article, entitled "Starting Early Political Negotiations to Promote the Development of Cross-Strait Relations" would be more pertinent and a better indication of Beijing's sincerity if its sentiments were disclosed in a direct statement to the SEF by ARATS.
Since the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, Beijing has urged early political cross-strait negotiations through various unofficial channels such as the magazine.

At a question-and-answer session with the press, Chiao stressed that with respect to mainland China's "one-China" prerequisite for negotiations, the ROC's Guidelines for National Unification contain a clear explanation on Taiwan's position on the issue, and that mutual understanding of the issue had been previously reached with Beijing. If Beijing is willing to act in line with that mutual understanding, the "one-China" issue presents no barriers, Chiao pointed out.

Premier Vincent Siew and Chang King-yuh, Chairman of the ROC's cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), have said repeatedly that Taipei does not rule out the possibility of political negotiations and that it is SEF's consistent desire to resume talks on policy dialogue, according to Chiao.
The MAC is the government organization charged with charting mainland policy in the absence of official diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KATHERINE CHANG TO BE ROC'S FIRST FEMALE AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Wednesday approved a proposal to appoint Katherine Chang, a career diplomat, as the new ROC ambassador to the Caribbean nations of Saint Christopher and Nevis and the Commonwealth of Dominica.
Chang, who currently serves as director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle, will be the Republic of China's first female ambassador.
The KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee approved Chang's appointment at its weekly meeting and the cabinet is expected to endorse the appointment on Thursday.

Chang, 45, graduated from the department of diplomacy of National Chengchi University and has a master's degree in public administration from the University of Long Island in New York. She has climbed the diplomatic ladder since joining the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1975.
Chang will succeed Steve Hsu, who until now concurrently serves as the ROC ambassador to all of its diplomatic allies in the Caribbean region.
Hsu expressed his intention to resign from his post after Saint Lucia switched diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing in late August.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Senegal's Prime Minister Habib Thiam and his wife are scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 20 on a six-day state visit at the invitation of the ROC government, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

During his stay in Taiwan, he will be decorated with the ROC's highest civilian honor -- Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon -- by President Lee Teng-hui, as well as meeting with Premier Vincent Siew and several other top-ranking officials.
Since Taipei and Senegal re-established diplomatic relations on January 3, 1996, officials from both sides have frequently exchanged visits, foreign ministry officials said.

Minister without Portfolio Chao Shou-po made a visit to the Senegalese capital of Dakar last month, when he was received both by Prime Minister Thiam and by Senegalese President Abdou Diouf, indicating the high priority Senegal places on its relations with Taipei.
This will be Thiam's second trip to Taiwan, and his 14-member entourage will include ministers responsible for foreign affairs and overseas nationals, agriculture, energy, mining and industry.
The delegation is scheduled to depart Taiwan on Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE 166.95 ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 166.95 points to finish at 8262.4.
The bourse opened at 8381.3 and experienced a high of 8392.54 and a low of 8259.91.
Losers outnumbered gainers 346 to 67, with 53 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.787 billion (US$2.48 billion).

Paper and pulp stock fell the most at 3.1 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks at 2.7 percent, financial shares at 2.3 percent, textile issues at 2.0 percent, electrical engineering shares at 2.0 percent and cement shares at 1.2 percent. Foodstuff issues dropped 1.1 percent, while construction shares fell 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND SCHOLAR COMMENTS ON RESUMPTION OF KOO-WANG TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is no longer opposed to the resumption of talks between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), but Beijing is adamant that talks on procedures concerning political negotiations should carry on from where the previous talks left off, rather than simply beginning again from scratch, observed Huang Chia-shu, a professor at mainland China's People's University on Tuesday.

Responding to questions from the media concerning an article urging political negotiations across the Taiwan Strait at an early date which was published in the overseas edition of the People's Daily on Tuesday, Huang said the article reflects to a large extent Beijing's attitude on the subject. The overseas edition of the People's Daily is seen as Beijing's leading media channel to the outside world, hence the intense scrutiny and interest aroused by the article.

Huang, whose writings on political negotiations across the Taiwan Strait are often published in influential papers and journals, pointed out that Beijing is not interested in resuming talks on economic affairs and protocols if talks on political negotiations are not included.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SHOWING SIGNS OF RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is showing signs of entering a recovery phase after months of sluggishness, a major private economic think-tank said on Wednesday.

In a regularly issued report predicting Taiwan's economic performance over the last quarter of 1997, the Chung-Hwa Institute for Economic Research (CIER) said the island has experienced steady economic growth throughout the year.
The finance sector has experienced the most ups and downs over the first half of 1997, averaging 6.6 percent economic growth during the period, the institute said.
One of the most remarkable achievements Taiwan's economy has seen over the past year has been in the production value,which registered the highest growth since 1991.

Available data indicates that Taiwan's economy is already well into a recovery phase and the CIER predicted that annual production value growth rates for the third and fourth quarters of 1997 will be 6.35 percent and 6.30 percent, respectively.

If achieved, the figure will place Taiwan's average annual production value growth rate for all of 1997 at 6.45 percent, the CIER said, adding that Taiwan's ongoing economic recovery was mostly the product of a recent surge in domestic demand for goods and services.
As consuming increases amid an improving economic atmosphere, share prices have been gradually rising and local residents have become increasingly concerned about their quality of life.

Combined with the economic stimuli expected in connection with the upcoming November 29 islandwide elections for county chiefs and mayors, overall economic growth could reach as high as 7.19 percent for the entire year, a full percentage point ahead of last year's tally, the CIER forecast.
In its previous reports this year, the institute predicted that the economy would grow by 6.83 percent in the first quarter, while the actual figure turned out to be 6.86 percent.
A 5.81 percent prediction for the second quarter of 1997 was met with a 6.34 percent result, while 6.4 percent prediction for the third quarter ended up close to the 6.35 percent actually recorded.
The fourth quarter growth estimate, at 6.3 percent, was revised from an earlier 6.26 percent prediction.
The think-tank also predicted that economic growth would top 6.61 percent for 1998, slightly higher than its earlier 6.5 percent prediction.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CSR CORP. REASSESSING ASIAN OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia's CSR Corp., a leading producer of construction materials, is reassessing its operations in Asia as a result of a sharp drop in infrastructure spending in Taiwan and fundamental changes in the Indonesian and mainland China plasterboard markets.

Alex Brennan, CSR executive director of finance and investments, told the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday that his company intends to consolidate its construction materials businesses into a single site in Taiwan.
"And we may have to divest some of the operations," Brennan said.
He admitted that his company had called the Asian markets incorrectly, announcing an aftertax writedown of A$96 million in its Asian operations.
He said CSR was considering the sale of non-strategic assets in Asia, including a kitchen business in southern mainland China.

"That doesn't fit with anything," he said. "We also have a very small insulation operation in Indonesia. Insulation is quite important to us in Asia, but this one isn't part of what we see as an ongoing plan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDGE AWARDS NT$38 MILLION TO RESIDENTS OF RADIOACTIVE BUILDING

TEXT.P: The Taipei district court has ruled that the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) under the Executive Yuan should pay a total of more than NT$38 million (US$1.33 million) to 48 residents of a radioactively contaminated building.
This is the first case where residents of buildings built with radioactive steel bars have been successful in gaining government compensation. Many similar cases are still pending.
According to the ruling Tuesday, the AEC must not only pay the plaintiffs over NT$38 million but also shoulder 35 percent of their legal fees.
Wang Yu-lin, one of the 57 plaintiffs who filed the class action suit, said Wednesday that although he thought the award was too small, he was happy to see social justice upheld at last.

But another resident, who requested anonymity, said the compensation would not make up for the damage to the health of those who still have to live in the building. She also urged the government to continue to give the residents annual physicals.
AEC Chairman Hu Ching-piao said he would consult with the council's lawyer before deciding whether or not to appeal the decision.

In the lawsuit filed with the district court, Wang and the other plaintiffs claimed that the AEC knew before 1985 that the building had an abnormally high level of radioactivity, but that the council had not acted to investigate this further, nor had it tried to fully inform the residents or improve the situation.
The people in the building did not learn they were being exposed to high levels of radiation until seven years later in Aug. 1992, when the media exposed the matter.
The plaintiffs had asked for NT$112.31 million (US$3.91 million) to compensate them for physical and mental suffering, as well as for the decreased value of their property.

But Judge Chan Wen-hsing, who presided over the case, ruled that nine out of the 57 plaintiffs could not demonstrate that they continued to live in the building for a long period after 1985, and that the remaining 48 could not fully prove all of the other losses, though they had spent money on medical expenses and additional medical insurance.

Chan said that she awarded the 48 plaintiffs nearly NT$38.46 million to compensate them for damage to their health, taking into consideration their social status, economic situation and other factors. Individual awards ranged between NT$200,000 (US$7,018) and NT$2 million (US$70,175).

Chan declined to award damages based on lowered property value, saying it was the builders that had used the radioactive steel bars and that the AEC had no universal obligation to monitor the radioactivity of steel bars for buildings before 1984.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA DOESN'T HAVE MAJOR OFFENSIVE CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: Mainland China continues to modernize its strategic and major conventional weapon systems but does not have the capability to project major conventional forces beyond its territory now or in the near future, according to the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS).

The London-based IISS said Tuesday in its "The Military Balance 1997/98" report that mainland China's main force elements, in terms of technology, remain well behind those of other major powers. It will take most of the next decade for mainland China to reach the technological level of, for example, the major NATO powers.

The annual report added that mainland China's overall military capability has changed little since 1996 and at present it does not have the resources to project a major conventional force beyond its territory.

Instead, Beijing appears to give priority to improving strategic forces, particularly missiles, as a credible deterrent, and to enhancing the mobility and capability of its military to deal with border threats and major internal security problems.

On July 1, mainland China received Hong Kong from Britain with no unexpected security problems. Relations with Taiwan, despite some major exercises by the navies of both mainland China and Taiwan in June 1997, remain relatively calm as far as military activities are concerned, the IISS noted.
The uncertainties in the international security environment since the end of the Cold War are now being reflected in arms-sale trends, said the institute.
After years of decline since 1987, an upward movement in the international arms trade is now clear, it said.
The top three arms suppliers remain the United States, Britain and France, which all recorded large increases in defense exports in 1996.
Eight states imported more than US$1 billion apiece in defense equipment in 1996: Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Japan, Britain, mainland China, Taiwan, South Korea and Kuwait.
In Southeast Asia, the major arms importers in 1996 were once again Indonesia and Thailand (at US$700 million each), Singapore (US$400 million) and Malaysia (US$350 million).
The IISS noted that mainland China's potential threat to regional security is one of the main reasons behind Southeast Asian countries' increased defense spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN NATIONS WILL SHOW ROBUST GROWTH: GOH

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in Hong Kong on Tuesday that he is confident that East Asian countries will grow robustly in the medium and long term, despite the recent economic hiccups.

Addressing the East Asia Economic Summit held in Hong Kong, Goh pointed out that the turmoil that has hit ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) currencies is a temporary, though painful, setback and could serve as a "wake-up call" to East Asian countries to take the tough measures needed to strengthen their economies.

"Those who espouse the theory that East Asia's rapid growth was largely a matter of perspiration rather than inspiration feel vindicated," he noted. "They feel that Asian economic growth will slow down markedly. Some have even pronounced the end of the Asian miracle.

"Such a view is too pessimistic. Just as the haze which blankets the region will clear, the miasma of uncertainty which has affected sentiment in Asia will, after a while, evaporate," he told businessmen, academics and politicians at the conference organized by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum.
If the current turmoil is viewed as a "wake-up call" to the region to get its economic house in order, he asserted, "we can turn the sentiment around, by strengthening our economic fundamentals."

Citing figures to back his upbeat assessment of the region's outlook, Goh pointed out that the World Bank was also bullish about the region's future, projecting in a report last month that East Asia will grow by an average of 7.6 percent a year over the next decade.

On rising labor costs, Goh noted that wages in the newly industrialized countries had grown by 12 percent a year since 1990, compared with 3 percent in the United States and 9 percent in France and Germany.
Unless labor productivity in East Asia grows more rapidly than elsewhere, countries in the region risk losing their competitive edge, he cautioned.
East Asian governments will also have to raise their investment in higher education to train more technicians and graduates needed in an increasingly skills and knowledge-driven economy, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar gained NT$0.002 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Wednesday, finishing at NT$28.480.
The greenback opened at today's low of NT$28.479 and had a high of NT$28.484. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$179.5 million. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR CHANGE IN BASIC POLICY TOWARD OUTER MONGOLIA: CHANG

TEXT.P: Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang said on Wednesday that there will be no major changes in the Republic of China's basic policy toward Outer Mongolia.
Chang was commenting on reports that the ROC government will look upon Outer Mongolia as a "special region" other than mainland China.
The ROC has traditionally regarded Outer Mongolia as part of its territory even though Outer Mongolia declared independence from China in 1921 and is now a United Nations member.

"We'll uphold this policy," Chang said, adding that the government does not oppose developing substantive ties with Outer Mongolia and is willing to assist it in economic development, but political relations between the two sides will not see any major changes at the moment.

Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC), suggested at a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee that the government treat Outer Mongolia as a "special region" other than the Chinese mainland and lift all unnecessary restrictions on bilateral trade and economic exchanges.

Noting that Outer Mongolia is not controlled by communist China and does not harbor any hostility toward Taiwan, Kao said the government should amend the current regulations governing investment and technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait and exclude Outer Mongolia from the provision of those regulations.

Kao said Taiwan should develop direct trade and economic ties with Outer Mongolia, open the local market to all Mongolian products and exempt Mongolia-bound investments from same restrictions imposed on mainland China-bound investments.
Kao said he is convinced that commercial, tourism and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Outer Mongolia will greatly increase by removing those restrictions.

Kao, who had been a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council before assuming his current post in September, further said the Dalai Lama's visit to Taiwan in March this year has helped boost the Tibetan spiritual leader's understanding of Taiwan's efforts on behalf of Tibetan people on the island.
"The visit has also helped reduce misunderstandings by the Tibetan government-in-exile in the northern Indian city of Dharmsala on the ROC's Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission," Kao added.

After listening to Kao's report, President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman, ordered all relevant government agencies to study the feasibility of removing unnecessary restrictions on trade and civilian exchanges with Outer Mongolia.
Lee also urged the MTAC to intensify contacts with exiled Tibetans in Nepal and India and assist young Tibetans in receiving education and finding suitable jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NEW SAUDI GAS FIELDS FOUND

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia announced Tuesday the discovery of two new fields of sweet natural gas with an estimated reserve of 7.5 trillion cubic feet.
The two additional fields will raise the total reserve of the sweet and sour types of natural gas in the country to 204 trillion cubic feet up to the current year.

With the discovery of these two fields, the increase in the reserves of natural gas not accompanying petroleum rose to 22 trillion cubic feet since Saudi Aramco started its program of drilling natural gas not accompanying petroleum in 1994, Petroleum and Mineral Resources Minister Ali Al-Naimi said.
Including that, the reserves of natural gas not accompanying petroleum rose to 69 trillion cubic feet, Al-Naimi added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO SERVE AS BRIDGE IN GROWTH NETWORKS: GOH

TEXT.P: Singapore will play a catalytic bridging role in building networks for growth between Asia, Europe and the Americas, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in Hong Kong Wednesday.

Speaking at the World Economic Forum Singapore Networking Lunch, he pointed out that the theme of this year's East Asia Economic Summit, which closed in Hong Kong on Wednesday, on how to strengthen the links between Europe, Asia and the Americas -- the three engines of global economic growth -- is most timely and relevant.
Singapore will play a catalytic bridging role in this respect, he said, through three kinds of networks: businesses, personnel, and knowledge and information.

At present, there are some 5,000 multinational companies located in Singapore, he said. About half of them have regional operations using Singapore as their base, while 850 manufacture for world markets.
There are also some 220 banks located in Singapore. And Singapore's foreign exchange market ranks as the fourth largest in the world.
"We are a major telecommunication and transportation hub," Goh said. All these offer a wealth of business links and partners, he added.
In addition, Singapore invested S$46 billion abroad in 1995 and operated eight major industrial parks in Indonesia, mainland China, Vietnam and India.

Singapore now ranks as the largest foreign investor in Malaysia and Vietnam, No. 3 in Indonesia, No. 4 in Thailand, and No. 6 in China, and has also significant investments in the Philippines and Myanmar.

"With all these investments at home and abroad, Singapore can be a global hub for manufacturing, services and finance," Goh said, adding that Singapore can provide the network of business especially for Southeast Asia and China.

He pointed out that one major factor behind Singapore's sustained economic growth is its huge investment in people and talent. Singapore has attracted talent from all over the world, and will be even more active in attracting top-notch personnel.
In today's high technology and information age, human talent, intellectual capital and the ability to add value and disseminate knowledge are keys to Singapore's success, he asserted.
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, for example, have set up their regional training centers in Singapore.

Goh said he was keen to see Singapore play the role of an interregional training center, where European and American managers can be trained before their assignment in Asia. Asian managers and engineers in turn can be trained in Singapore before they proceed to work in developed countries.
Hong Kong has succeeded in building networks between the East and West and has flourished as a vibrant hub with global links to southern China and Northeast Asia, he noted.
Singapore, too, is developing as a global hub on the strength of its connections to Southeast Asia and mainland China and the large presence of multinational companies in Singapore, he said.
Noting that Hong Kong and Singapore are complementary in many aspects, Goh said: "We must continue to strengthen this hub-to-hub relationship for greater mutual benefits."

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA MOVING DOWN PATH OF DISINTEGRATION

TEXT.P: Mainland China is expected to move towards the path of disintegration as a result of a series of internal trade wars among the provinces which the central government in Beijing is powerless to end, according to a leading China expert in Australia.

Writing on the opinion page of the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday, Dr. Robert Leeson, senior lecturer of the Economics Department of the Murdoch University in Perth, Australia, said Western commentators once misread the forces that were loosed by post-communist "reconstruction" in the old Soviet empire.
"It appears that a similar miscalculation is now being made about China," he said.

"As China opened up to international trade, by 1981 its ratio of trade to GDP (gross domestic product) exceeded that of Japan (14 percent); by 1985 that of the United States (19 percent); and by 1994 that of the United Kingdom (41 percent). South Korea seems next on the list to be overtaken," he said.
"But this `coming to market' has been accompanied by a series of internal trade wars, with large-scale tariff and non-tariff barriers to inter-regional trade," he said.

"There has been no `retreat from planning' in China; only the devolution of the planning process from the center to the regions. The strengthening of international trading ties has been accompanied by a conscious attempt by the provinces to strengthen their own local economic power by weakening inter-regional trading relations," he said.
He claimed mainland China's Ministry of Civil Affairs is now trying to stem on-going disputes over the "ownership" of natural resources by delineating all disputed regional and provincial boundaries.

"At the same time, local protectionism is rampant; the government of Zhejiang province has restricted the sale of silk cocoons to other parts of China; Guizhou province has banned the import of televisions, refrigerators and bicycles from other parts of China; Hunan and Guangxi are reported to be patrolling their borders to prevent inter-regional `smuggling,'" he said.
"By controlling inter-regional trade, they can act as a monopoly buyer of raw materials (at controlled prices) and benefit from the foreign exchange earned," he said.
"Beijing appears powerless to prevent this massive growth of provincial economic power; indeed some of its policies have unintentionally fostered it," he said.

"In the reform era, central political authority has progressively dissolved, leaving each province to become increasingly self-sufficient. The lessons of the 1930s is that this type of economic autarchy is often a prelude to conflict. But the territory we call China has not always been a single unified country or empire," he said.
"Before the communist take-over, it was often a collection of feuding provinces, dominated by warlords," he said.

"Each province is again acquiring an independent economic structure and a motive and a power to resist the center. The People's Liberation Army is also to a large extent economically self-sufficient," Leeson said.
"The way to do business in China is to ingratiate oneself with the local elite who operate independently from Beijing," Leeson said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO INTENSIFY PORT WAR WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: The US Federal Maritime Commission is preparing to escalate a port war with Japan by compiling a new list of companies to be hit with tougher sanctions, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Wednesday.
The FMC imposed fees on Japanese shipping lines as of Sept. 4, but these sanctions have failed to change Japanese port practices.
The new list is aimed at US-based companies that have ties to the Japan Harbor Transportation Association, the agency accused of stifling international competition at Japanese ports.
The FMC is also considering raising existing fees of US$100,000 every time a vessel from one of the companies calls at a US port. The first payments are due on Oct. 15.

Three of the companies hit by September's sanctions challenged the FMC's authority to impose fees. Mitsui OSK Lines, Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha and Nippon Yasen Kaisha claimed the duties would impede their competitiveness. They failed to convince the US Court of Appeals that they would suffer long-term damage although they estimate the costs to be US$17 million in the first year.

The Japanese government has filed an appeal with the FMC asking that any fees be placed in escrow. The FMC has not yet put forward an official request for increased or expanded sanctions, but it is "looking for ways to exert more pressure on the Japanese," according to the WTO report.

The FMC sanctions followed months of negotiations which failed to resolve differences over how to reform practices at Japanese ports, which foreign shipping companies claim are inefficient and costly.
The US complaint concerns stevedoring practices at Japanese ports which foreign shipowners claim keep prices high and prevent them from raising efficiency.

In particular, shipping companies have complained about a requirement that all changes to vessel schedules be made through the Japanese Harbor Transportation Association, which represents cargo-handling companies.
The European Union has also lodged a complaint with the WTO over Japan's harbor practices and has held talks on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPPING MAGNATE'S CALL RECEIVES MUTED RESPONSE FROM GOV'T.

TEXT.P: A call made by shipping tycoon Chang Yung-fa in a newspaper interview on Wednesday for Taiwan to open direct links with mainland China received a muted response from government officials, although some business moguls voiced their support.

Chang, chairman of the Evergreen Group, which runs the world's largest container fleet, told the China Times that the government should review its "no haste, be patient" economic policy toward the mainland and lift its bans on direct cross-strait postal, trade and transportation links at an early date.

Taipei's rigid ban on the direct links with the mainland in those three areas has cost local enterprises countless business opportunities and created difficulties for the people, Chang said in an interview published in Wednesday's edition of the Chinese-language daily. He added that he does not believe the direct contacts will endanger national security.

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's top policymaking body for mainland policy, said the time is not ripe for Taiwan to open direct postal, commercial, shipping and aviation exchanges with the mainland. The charting of government policy toward the mainland must take into account matters concerning the nation's security, he stressed.

Kuo Chen-fu, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said that "mutual respect" is the key factor in improving cross-strait relations. Until the mainland authorities agree to treat Taiwan as a political entity of equal status, there can be no talk of removing the ban on direct links, said Koo, who is Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing in the absence of official contacts.

Kuo said that prior to the opening of direct links, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must hold talks to tackle a range of unresolved technical issues. He once again urged the mainland to reopen semi-official talks with Taiwan, which were unilaterally suspended by the mainland in protest at President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that the economic policy toward mainland should be in accordance with the National Unification Guidelines. The offshore transshipment center which began operations earlier this year and several special economic zones currently in the planning stages are designed to facilitate cross-strait trade exchanges, Chiang added.

Liu Tai-ying, chairman of ruling Kuomintang's Business Management Committee, said that so long as the mainland authorities continue to regard the Republic of China as a local administration, the opening of direct links will harm Taiwan's businessmen's interests and also endanger the island's security.

Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, said that he supports the government's current policy toward the mainland. Commenting on Chang Yung-fa's remarks that he would be willing to go to the mainland as a "secret envoy" to help break the cross-strait economic and political deadlock, Wang said that it was wishful thinking on the shipping magnate's part.
Chang Yung-fa revealed in the interview that he visited Beijing two weeks ago but declined to confirm whether he met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, hailed Chang's call for direct contacts, saying that "the sooner the three links can be realized, the better." Continued delays will be detrimental to the interests of Taiwan businessmen, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER INT'L PAPER TO BE PRINTED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The International Herald Tribune, an influential daily newspaper based in Paris, is to launch a localization plan to have the publication printed in Taipei before the end of this year, according to the Government Information Office (GIO).

Kevin Murphy, chief of the Herald Tribune's Asia-Pacific regional affairs unit, met Wednesday with GIO Director-General David Lee to discuss the localization plan, which is expected to help boost its circulation here.

Murphy and Lee reached consensus on the arrangement, under which the Herald Tribune will deliver its daily editions to Taipei via satellite for printing and distribution, enabling Taipei readers to receive the paper in the morning hours. Currently, copies of the publication are flown in from Hong Kong and are available to local readers only in the afternoon.

It will become the second international newspaper to be printed locally. The Asia Wall Street Journal announced earlier this year that it will be printed by the Taipei-based English-language daily, the China Post, beginning from the end of this year.

The International Herald Tribune is co-owned by the New York Times and the Washington Post of the United States. It is now printed and distributed in 14 regions around the world. Hong Kong currently serves as the Asia-Pacific regional headquarters.
Under its ambitious Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center Plan, Taiwan hopes to attract more international media concerns to use the island as a regional base.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO SUPPORT FULL AUTONOMY FOR HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Australia will continue to support the full exercise of the autonomous status in Hong Kong because it will contribute to regional prosperity and security in the Asia-Pacific region, Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said on Wednesday.

In a speech to the Asia Society and the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, Downer said Hong Kong's remarkable economic development and emergence as a regional force in its own right would not have been possible without mainland China's economic reforms.

But, just as important, if not more so, he said, is mainland China's promise that its capitalist economy, free press, rule of law and evolving democratic institutions will be protected under a high degree of autonomy.

"It is this which will allow Hong Kong to continue to play a role in China -- and the wider region's -- economic development. It is this which will also contribute to regional prosperity and security," Downer said.

He said that the Asia-Pacific's quality of life depends on much more than sustained prosperity and enhanced security, and that Hong Kong is a gateway to substantial trade and investment in mainland China and a springboard for new business partnerships in Asia.

Downer said: "Australia's basic approach to Hong Kong's historic transition has been and will continue to be to support the full exercise by Hong Kong of the autonomy it has been promised by China in areas other than foreign affairs and defense.
"This is the most realistic and pragmatic way of advancing Australia's substantial economic stake in Hong Kong's future as an important economic regional player," he said.
Hong Kong is a major trading partner for Australia. There are about 350 Australian companies operating in Hong Kong with about 30,000 Australians living and working in the former British colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US OPEN ANOTHER ROUND OF WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and the United States gathered in Taipei Wednesday to begin a new round of consultations on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The Taiwan and US delegations were headed, respectively, by Chen Ruey-long, recently appointed director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), and David Burns, the US Trade Representative Office's director for Asia-Pacific Affairs.

At the beginning of the meeting, Burns congratulated Chen on his promotion by saying that he will be the last BOFT head to hold trade negotiations with the United States. The comment was taken as a sign that officials from the two sides have a good chance of reaching agreement on various trade issues in the 16th round of trade talks.

Discussions on the first day of the week-long trade negotiations centered on the capacity of assets held by foreign insurance companies to cover liability and on the ROC government's medical pricing system. The two sides, however, failed to reach any consensus.

During subsequent meetings over the next few days, discussions will focus on Taiwan's governmental procurement systems, and on the opening of local agricultural, insurance, stock brokerage, telecommunications and service markets.

Taiwan and the United States have conducted 15 rounds of trade talks since February 1994. Among 26 WTO signatory nations which have requested bilateral talks with Taiwan, agreements have been reached with 21 of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: A TASTE OF LIFE IN EXILE

TEXT.P: Although they are legal ROC citizens, entitled to vote or even to be elected president, they have not fared very well in Taiwan over the past 20 years or so.

They are 102 Tibetan children the ROC government received from India and Nepal following a failed uprising against Chinese Communist rule in Tibet some two decades earlier. They settled in the now-defunct Tibetan Children's Home, a charity organization established by the Chinese Refugees Relief Association, in Taipei in 1980.
Nearly 20 years later, the children, whose parents either perished or fled during the conflict, are now adults.

About half of them dropped out of the educational system after graduating from junior high school and joined Taiwan's fiercely competitive job market, taking jobs in the service industries or in the labor-intensive manufacturing sector.

Some of them even insisted upon working while they were still students, which contributed to the high ratio of dropouts among them. It also proved to be a major setback for the Tibetan Children's Home program, whose directors had hoped to provide the youths with a good education before they entered the world as adults.
Among the 102 Tibetans, only two managed to receive a college degree, and another one emigrated to the United States.

As for the rest, 19 are studying in high school-level vocational institutes, 11 are currently serving in the military, and two are serving jail terms. About a dozen others travel frequently among Taiwan, India and Nepal, "perhaps doing business," according to a consultant at the Tibetan Youths Home, which superseded the children's orphanage.

While most of the young men and women never regained contact with any of their family members, they consider the residents of the home to be their brothers and sisters. They live in a close-knit environment both physically and psychologically, but seldom make new acquaintances outside the group, said the consultant.

Although most of the Tibetans lead less-than-rewarding lives in Taiwan, none of them want to leave the island. One young man who arrived in the orphanage at the age of five, said he wants to earn more money in Taiwan after graduation to send to family members who still reside in Nepal.

Two sisters among the group are not so lucky. They also desire to accumulate a fortune in Taiwan, but have no one to share with their earnings. The sisters were too young when they first arrived here and they have no documents or information about their parents or other relatives.
Meanwhile, Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, said Taipei is continuing its policy of helping exiled Tibetan youths from India and Nepal.

Currently, he said, the commission welcomes high-school graduates to receive college or university education in Taiwan, hoping that the young Tibetan men and women will return to Tibet, India or Nepal after graduation to contribute more to their people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, JAPAN TO SIGN NEW AIR PACT NEXT MONTH
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan have finally agreed to sign a new aviation accord next month in Taipei, the Sankei Shimbun reported on Thursday.

The Japanese economic daily said in a Taipei-datelined dispatch that the new agreement will authorize Taiwan's EVA Air and Japan's Air Nippon to operate direct flights between Taiwan and Osaka's new Kansei Airport.
According to the paper, the two airlines are scheduled to start the new flight services early next year. Each airline will operate seven round-trip flights per week.
At present, Taiwan's airlines are only allowed to fly to Tokyo's Haneda Airport, the cities of Fukuoka and Nagoya and the prefecture of Okinawa.

The Sankei Shimbun said major Taiwan airlines have also expressed hopes to be granted the right to fly to other Japanese cities, including Hiroshima, Kagoshima, Sapporo, Miyazaki and Ishigaki, as well as to increase the number of weekly flights to Okinawa and Nagoya.

Negotiators from the two sides had met numerous times before finally reaching agreement to amend their existing air pact and sign a new accord to pave the way for increased flight services between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S CONDITIONS FOR TALKS UNACCEPTABLE: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Ho Chinping & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the ROC's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Wednesday that Beijing has responded favorably to calls for resumed dialogue but that Taipei cannot accept its conditions for such talks.

However, the MAC and Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will confer about matters of protocol as well as political topics to be discussed in accordance with developments in the situation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Regarding cross-strait commercial and trade links, pragmatic exchanges and negotiations on the basis of equality will proceed according to the requisites of maintaining the ROC's security and national dignity, Chang said. A new framework for economic relations between the two sides will gradually be developed accordingly, he emphasized.
Chang made the comments in an address to a gathering of a National Taiwan University alumni association on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW'S SHARED SOVEREIGNTY PROPOSAL AN INCISIVE REMARK: HK PRESS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew's proposed unification formula of "one country, shared sovereignty" was praised in the Hong Kong press as being "reasonable and incisive."

A column appearing in Wednesday's edition of the mass-circulation Oriental Daily News commented that Siew's proposal reflects the reality that the sovereignty of the Chinese nation not only belongs to people on the mainland but to people on Taiwan as well. In other words, it belongs to all Chinese people even though the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently under separate jurisdiction. Accordingly, Siew's formula was praised as rational and creative by the newspaper.

The Oriental Daily also noted that Taipei's prerequisites for resuming discussions with Beijing include the maintenance of the ROC's security and national dignity. Unless those conditions are met, the paper said, a return to the negotiating table is unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC SEEKING INVESTORS FOR PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) is targeting Taiwan's leading shipping companies and business conglomerates as potential investors to facilitate privatization of the state-run corporation, government sources reported on Thursday.

Some 20 would-be investors, including Evergreen Group, Yangming Marine Transport, Chinese Maritime Transport, Formosa Plastics Group, Tungtex Group, China Steel Corp. and Chi Mei Corp., will be invited to an investment workshop in late November to work out strategies for listing the Kaohsiung-based CSBC on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

According to officials from the Commission of National Corporations (CNC), which is actively pushing for the CSBC's privatization, the CSBC's four-year restructuring project embarked on some two years ago has shown little promise for the debt-ridden corporation.

The CSBC seems to have few choices but to accelerate the privatization process due to an assortment of factors, including a hefty payroll of 5,600 employees, a NT$14 billion (US$491 million) bill to be footed upon privatization as retirement pension funds or layoff payments, and continually sagging business turnover, CNC officials pointed out.

The CSBC, whose shareholders include the Ministry of Economic Affairs (holding 87.32 percent of the firm's stock) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (10.32 percent), currently has a capitalization of NT$16.9 billion (US$593 million).

To facilitate its application for listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the CSBC will re-evaluate its land assets and trim its capitalization by NT$5.9 billion (US$207 million) to some NT$11 billion (US$386 million), the officials noted.

The CSBC's large payroll is the major obstacle to the corporation's plans to go private, the officials said, citing comments by a spokesman for the Evergreen Group, which has indicated its interest in buying into the state-run shipbuilder. The spokesman was quoted as saying that Evergreen would like to take it over "right away," if the CSBC staff is not included in the transfer.
Earlier this week, CSBC authorities had categorically denied that the company was negotiating any acquisition or merger bids with local business groups.

Commenting on news reports that Evergreen, which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet, intends to buy into the CSBC, and that the Formosa Plastics Group, Taiwan's largest private conglomerate, is also interested in acquiring the CSBC, the spokesman said "all such reports are untrue."
In addition to building commercial vessels, the CSBC is also capable of building various types of warships, including missile frigates and high-speed patrol boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH EMPLOYEES URGED TO HEIGHTEN SAFETY AWARENESS

TEXT.P: Safety personnel in the nation's industrial sector should be given higher positions and employees at high-tech plants should be educated on fire-prevention techniques, participants at a seminar on safety awareness said.
The seminar on accident prevention in hi-tech industries was held at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Wednesday, in the wake of a recent series of fires there.

The participants were unanimous on the need to prevent the occurrence of such incidents in the future, especially after a disastrous fire at the United Integrated Circuit Corp., an affiliated company of major wafer supplier United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), in early October caused losses estimated at NT$15 billion (US$523.64 million).
Winbond Electronic Corp., another company in the park, also lost nearly NT$10 billion (US$348.43 million) as a result of a fire in October 1996.

Chen Huei-tai, manager of Fubon Insurance Company, cited figures for facilities in Silicon Valley in the United States to emphasize the magnitude of the losses suffered by the two companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

He said that data from a consulting company in Silicon Valley indicates that total losses from fires at the US hi-tech mecca amounted to only NT$800 million (US$27.87 million) over a ten-year period between 1983 and 1993.

Chang Chih-yuan, Winbond assistant vice president, said that in the past year alone, there have in fact been several fire-related accidents at the Hsinchu facility, causing losses of up to several hundred thousand New Taiwan Dollars for each individual company.

Chang attributed the frequent outbreak of fires in the industrial park to several reasons. For one thing, he said, companies are often in a rush to complete construction and request contractors to work overtime, often at the expense of proper safety precautions. At one time, Winbond had as many as 700 laborers on a single construction site.

Chang said substandard safety control techniques practiced by the companies is another factor. Factory equipment may originate from a variety of places, including Japan, Germany and the United States, and may utilize many diverse fire-prevention mechanisms, which makes it difficult to achieve an effective integrated safety system.

He also said that thermoelectric heaters are the most frequent sources of accidents, with between 50 percent and 60 percent of fire-related incidents at the park being directly attributable to heating units for factory equipment.
He proposed that resident companies in the facility work out a uniform safety code to govern the plant construction and operations.

Participants in the seminar also suggested that safety personnel be given greater authority in carrying out their duties and that a section of the industrial park in Hsinchu and of one located in Tainan be set aside for building fire-prevention training centers.
