DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED REACTION TO APPEAL FOR LIFT OF 'THREE LINKS' BAN

TEXT.P: The appeal of a Taiwan shipping tycoon to lift bans on three areas of direct contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait polarized the Legislature on Thursday.
Y.F. Chang, chairman of Evergreen Marine, criticized the government's continuing restrictions on the "three links" -- direct trade, postal and transportation exchanges -- with the mainland.
Chang also said that he is willing to act as an emissary on behalf of the ROC government in the cross-strait dialogue if the need arises. He made the comments in an interview published on Wednesday.

Legislator Hsieh Chin-chuan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said that Chang's remarks were based solely on commercial interests and that he had disregarded the safety of 21 million people on Taiwan.

Tsai Ming-hsien, another DPP legislator, said that Taiwan's security should be given the first priority, pointing out that at a time when Beijing still continues threaten Taiwan with the use of force, the ROC government will only bring humiliation upon itself if it is too enthusiastic in opening the three links.

Lee Ching-hua of the opposition New Party said that the government ban has become intolerable to Taiwan businessmen, and with its utility as a bargaining chip in dealing with Beijing gradually diminishing, it stands only as a self-defeating policy.

Lee questioned whether the "three no's" imposed by the government are an effective deterrent to mainland aggression against Taiwan, adding that if Taiwan wants to develop into an Asia-Pacific operations center and to join World Trade Organization, direct links across the Taiwan Strait are imperative.

Legislator Chu Huei-liang of the New Party said the blast by Y.F. Chang, who called restrictions on the three links "naive," and similar comments made recently by Wang Yung-ching, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group, reflect the sentiments of most Taiwan businessmen.

But she opposed the idea of business leaders like Chang acting as emissaries in the cross-strait dialogue, saying that they will be unable to maintain an objective stance because of their vested interests.

Legislator Chen Ching-pao of the ruling Kuomintang called for a review of the government's National Unification Guidelines, saying that the effectiveness of restrictions on direct contacts as bargaining chips with Beijing is rapidly eroding due to the massive influx of foreign capital into the mainland in recent years.
Meanwhile, an opinion poll showed that only 13.6 percent of the public believes that the ban on the three links should be lifted unconditionally.

The poll, commissioned by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and conducted in August, also found that 75.8 percent of the respondents felt that the direct contacts should be established under certain conditions.

The MAC noted that it is impossible to conduct direct trade without maintaining direct cross-strait transportation links, but that direct air and sea travel must involve matters of national security and dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US WTO TALKS NOT TO TOUCH ON 'NON-APPLICATION' CLAUSE

TEXT.P: Taiwan has absolute rights to determine whether to exclude mainland China from the application of multilateral trade agreements after it formally joins the World Trade Organization (WTO), a senior trade official said on Thursday.

"We can decide completely in our own right whether to employ the WTO's 'non-application' provision toward mainland China after we become a full member of the Geneva-based trade regulatory body," said Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).
Chen was commenting on reports that ROC and US negotiators will discuss the "non-application" issue during their current round of consultations on terms for Taiwan to join the WTO.

"We do not need to discuss this issue with any particular WTO member as a prerequisite for our entry to the organization," Chen said, adding that the issue is not included in the agenda for the 16th round of WTO talks between the Republic of China and the United States, which opened in Taipei on Wednesday.
The WTO charter provides for non-application of multilateral trade agreements between particular members.
Chen said Taiwan has not yet considered whether to employ this "non-application" clause toward mainland China after it joins the WTO.
Observers said Taiwan is not expected to reveal its stance on the issue until the last minute.
Touching on the current round of ROC-US WTO talks, Chen said the two sides have reached agreement on the issue concerning Taiwan's rates for mobile phone interconnection services.
American negotiators have asked Taiwan to lower the mobile phone interconnection charge, which stands at NT$1.6 (US$0.06) per minute at present.
"We have promised to review such service charges annually starting next year," Chen said, adding that the US delegation is satisfied with this promise.
According to a Taiwan-US telecommunications service agreement reached in July 1996, Taiwan will abide by general international regulations governing telecommunications service rates.

Chen said the state-run Chunghwa Telecom Co., which until now has dominated Taiwan's mobile phone service market, has reached agreements with private groups which have been granted licenses to operate mobile phone services later this year concerning the interconnection service charge. "Chunghwa Telecom has promised to adjust its rates annually based on its actual costs."

Another topic discussed on Thursday morning was an allegation by the United States that Taiwan Glass Co. has violated the fair trade law by dominating the island's float glass market. Chen told American negotiators that investigations by Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission did not substantiate the US allegation. "The Fair Trade Commission will further probe the issue if American businessmen can provide additional evidence," Chen said.
In the afternoon, the two sides discussed technical details concerning the establishment of an EMC examination system and certain alleged intellectual property rights violations.

The two sides will discuss issues related to tariff reductions on a number of industrial products, government procurement and opening of agricultural and service markets from Friday through next Monday.

The ROC-US WTO talks have lasted for several years. David Burns, the chief officer in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs at the Office of the US Trade Representative, said on Wednesday that he is convinced that Chen Ruey-long will be the last BOFT head to preside over the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUE OF THREE LINKS TO BE RESOLVED NATURALLY BY MUTUAL RESPECT: KOO

TEXT.P: In response to Taiwan shipping tycoon Chang Yung-fa's protest against Taipei's continuing ban on direct trade, transportation and communication links with mainland China, C.F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, said Wednesday that the interests of the nation must be Taiwan's top priority and that the issue of the "three links" would be resolved naturally if both sides could show respect to each other.
The key to the bilateral relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is whether Beijing will recognize Taipei as an equal political entity, Koo added.
Koo said that Taipei is not likely to open the "three links" in the near future, but he noted that there are in fact already some cross-strait links.

Koo also emphasized the development of relations between the two sides won't regress and that Taipei is indeed following a "no-haste, be patient" position. He added, however, this position is not intended to last forever but that it would change depending on conditions in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSICAL GIANTS PERFORMING IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A group of world-renowned classical musicians, including Chinese-American cellist Yo-Yo Ma, staged an open rehearsal Thursday in downtown Taipei's National Concert Hall to a packed audience.

In preparation for their long-awaited performance in Taipei with the National Concert Hall Orchestra, Ma, violinist Lin Chao-liang, and pianist Yefim Bronfman joined in a rendition of a Beethoven piece led by conductor Jaime Laredo.

Three of the musicians -- Yo-Yo Ma, Lin Chao-liang and Chang Yu-ting -- are scheduled to meet President Lee Teng-hui at the Presidential Office on Friday prior to the group's performance that evening at the National Concert Hall.
The members of the group said they had great expectations for their performance in Taipei and that working together presented them with a new artistic challenge.
They said they hoped to achieve new musical achievements performing together in Taipei and to present classical music lovers here with an evening of exceptional music.
Perhaps spurred on by the massive publicity here for the performance, Taipei has been struck with "classical music fever."

Tickets for Friday's performance were sold out two weeks ago, and public demand has been so strong that the event's organizers have promised to set up loudspeakers and a giant-screen television in the large square outside the concert hall so more people can enjoy the performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew will visit the United States Oct. 17-24, the Singapore Prime Minister's Office said Thursday.
He will deliver a keynote address at the Fortune 500 Forum in Boston on Oct. 23, the office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG USING HARVARD TO TRUMP CORNELL: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: A US expert on Asian affairs said Wednesday that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is insisting on speaking at Harvard University during his visit to the United States later this month because Harvard trumps Cornell University, where President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China delivered a speech in 1995.
Douglas Paal, president of the Asia-Pacific Policy Center, told a panel discussion here sponsored by the Heritage Foundation that Jiang is associated with a more moderate approach to Taiwan.
As a result, Paal noted, Jiang was embarrassed in 1995 and 1996 by the downturn in relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Apart from his visit to Boston for the Harvard speech, Paal said, Jiang's itinerary also includes a trip to Los Angeles after his talks with US President Bill Clinton in Washington in an effort to appeal to the strong pro-Taiwan elements there.

Paal said that the subtext is how to trump Taiwan and how to keep pro-Taiwan demonstrators away from the White House so that Jiang can show that Beijing is actually gaining an upper hand in Washington.
However, Paal said that this is really an uphill struggle for Jiang, especially in the US Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN EXPERTS TO MEET IN TAICHUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: The ninth annual Asia Outlook seminar is scheduled to kick off Friday in downtown Taichung with some 150 experts and strategists from Japan and Taiwan taking part.
President Lee Teng-hui, who was largely instrumental in establishing Asia Outlook and making it a regular gathering between Taiwan and Japan, will speak at the seminar's opening session.
Premier Vincent Siew will also deliver a keynote speech Friday.
According to C.F. Koo, chief of the Taiwan delegation, the annual meeting of Asia Outlook helps facilitate bilateral exchanges and understanding between the peoples of the two lands.
Although the two sides maintain no formal diplomatic relations, Koo said, Taiwan and Japan share common interests in many aspects and enjoy close two-way trade.
The Asia Outlook seminars also provided a channel for Taiwan and Japan's academics to exert influence on the Japanese legislature and government on issues related to Taiwan, Koo noted.

Members of the Taiwan delegation also include Taiwan Governor James Soong, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh, President of National Chengchi University Cheng Ting-wang and many business and industrial leaders.
Meanwhile, Masao Kamei, senior advisor of Sumitomo Electric Industries, and Hisao Kanamori, advisor of the Japan Center for Economic Research, will jointly lead the 50-member Japanese delegation.
Other prominent members of the Japanese delegation include Mineo Nakajima, president of the Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, and Aichi Kazuo, a member of the lower house of the Diet.

Asia Outlook, established in 1989, is aimed at pooling the wisdom of the business, political and academic elites of the two countries in an effort to create solutions that will bolster peace, security and well-being of the Asia-Pacific region.
The organization's annual seminars have been held alternately in Taiwan and Japan since its inception.
This year's seminar will conclude Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.038 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Thursday, finishing at NT$28.518.
The greenback opened at NT$28.483 and had a high of NT$28.550 and a low of NT$28.480. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$474.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES TUMBLE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 264.59 points to finish at 7997.81.
The bourse opened at 8177.39 and experienced a high of 8203.13 and a low of 7967.41.
Losers outnumbered gainers 408 to 29, with 24 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.46 billion (US$3.80 billion).

Electrical engineering shares fell the most at 5.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 4.2 percent, both textile and paper-making stocks at 2.5 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.2 percent, and plastic and chemical stocks at 2.0 percent. Cement issues dropped 1.8 percent, while financial issues fell 1.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAY SOON OPEN FUTURES MARKET TO FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Thursday said it was looking into the possibility of allowing foreign investment in Taiwan's soon-to-open futures market.

Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng told reporters that his ministry is eager for futures trading to begin here and that it had already requested opinions from the Central Bank of China on the prospect of allowing foreign investment in the new market.
He said research was underway to determine if foreign investment in the futures market should be permitted and, if so, what the ceiling on that investment should be.

Since the transfer of funds falls under the jurisdiction of the central bank, the ministry has twice formally requested the central bank's opinion regarding the opening of Taiwan's futures market to foreign investment, Wu said.
A specific outline of how the market would be opened up to foreign investment will be drafted after the MOF and central bank reach a consensus on the proposal, he said.
A package of detailed regulations drafted in conformity with the recently passed Futures Trading Law was approved at the Oct. 1 Cabinet meeting.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) and Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX) have both said they support Taiwan opening its futures market to foreign investment.
The CME and SIMEX on Jan. 9 both launched trading in Taiwan stock index futures, which have performed well enough to win the approval of financial scholars and the financial community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ELECTRONICS SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The 23rd TAITRONICS show opens Thursday in Taipei with 1,900 local and foreign electronics manufacturers participating.

The exhibitions are divided into eight sections, displaying consumer electronics, components, and parts; electronics manufacturing equipment; computer and peripherals, instruments and meters; foreign exhibitors' products; the presentation of trade media; telecommunications; as well as satellites and cable TV equipment. The products are displayed at the Taipei World Trade Center and Taipei Convention Center in 2,338 booths.

Premier Vincent Siew visited the exhibitions Thursday morning and talked with some of the exhibitors. The week-long exhibition is cosponsored by the Taiwan Electrical and Electronics Manufacturers Association and the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

CETRA Chairman Lin Cheng-huo said electronics products and electronics components and parts will be exhibited separately beginning next year for the convenience of the increasing visitors to the yearly event. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGES RISE 3.13 PERCENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan Thursday approved a proposal by the Council of Labor Affairs to raise minimum wages by 3.13 percent to NT$15,840 (US$555.78) per month, NT$528 per day, and NT$66 per hour.

The adjustment of minimum wages is based on the decisions reached in recent meetings of labor and management representatives from various sectors of the country as well as officials from various government agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and the Council of Labor Affairs.

The adjustment is aimed at raising the living standard of the people, and at the same time maintaining the economic competitiveness and labor productivity of the nation, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs said Thursday. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT WON'T INFLUENCE CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: KOO

TEXT.P: C.F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, said that Thursday he doesn't think talks between Taipei and Beijing will be influenced by the Oct. 29 summit meeting in Washington between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Koo also held that Washington won't act at the expense of Taiwan's interests and that the resumption of negotiations across the Taiwan Strait is necessary.

Next year may be a good time to resume cross-strait talks, Koo observed, noting that the ruling parties in mainland China and the Republic of China on Taiwan have both completed their respective 15th national congresses and that Jiang's Eight-Point Proposal will have been waiting three years. In addition, he said, mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng will be replaced in March 1998. The atmosphere is therefore appropriate for cross-strait talks, he said.

Since Washington also wants the "Taiwan problem" resolved, Jiang has done a lot recently to give the impression that Beijing is "kind to Taipei," Koo said, adding that this is just a trick by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE BUYS RUSSIAN MISSILE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) has bought a new Russian-made missile system that can knock out low-flying aircraft and helicopters.
The portable Igla missile system is the SAF's first Russian arms purchase, said Teo Chee Hean, Singapore's Education Minister and Second Defense Minister, on Wednesday.

The Igla missile, which weighs 16.8 kg, is portable, cost-effective, simple to operate and effective against counter-measures, such as flares, released by aircraft to evade missiles, said the Defense Ministry.
The SAF has the latest generation of the battle-proven Russian missile system, he said.
No details were released on the cost or number of the Igla missiles the SAF bought.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH: SINGAPORE'S ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS ARE SOUND

TEXT.P: Singapore's Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong stressed Wednesday that the country's economic fundamentals are sound despite the present currency turmoil in the region.
Singapore attracted a healthy S$6.9 billion (US$4.6 billion) in manufacturing investments in the first nine months of this year, he said.
The economy, he added, is on track to hitting this year's target growth rate of between 6 and 7 percent. In the first half of the year, the economy grew by 5.9 percent, he noted.
Goh made these points in a speech in Hong Kong to the Singapore Networking Lunch, organized by Singapore's Economic Development Board, The Straits Times reported Thursday.

Singapore officials said later that the nearly S$7 billion in investments to date, mainly in the electronics and chemicals sectors, compares well with the figure of S$8.1 billion (US$5.2 billion) in investments for the whole of last year, the report said.
Singapore looks set to hit its target of $8.5 billion (US$5.5 billion) in investments by the end of this year, they added.

In his speech, Goh repeated his view that while the ongoing currency turmoil might mean slower growth in the region in the next year or two, the medium and long-term prospects for ASEAN economies are good.
Goh was in Hong Kong for the East Asia Economic Summit organized by the World Economic Forum. He returned to Singapore on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAKARTA AIR POLLUTION CALLED 'DANGEROUS'

TEXT.P: Jakartans have been warned the city's air pollution, mainly from motor vehicle exhaust, is posing serious health and environmental hazards.

"The air pollution in Jakarta has reached a dangerous degree," the Indonesian Observer quoted Isna Marifa of Swisscontact, an organization that is sponsoring a clean air project for the city, as saying here Wednesday.

Air pollution here exceeds the standards set by the World Health Organization and the maximum limits set by the city administration, adversely affecting the health of the capital city's residents, according to a statement issued by Swisscontact.

The city's roads see traffic of some three million vehicles, 63 percent of which are motorcycles, 34 percent private cars and the remainder public transport and taxis, the statement said, adding that this total is expected to grow by about 15-20 percent annually.
Among the potential health hazards cited by the report are lower IQs caused by lead in the air, attention deficit disorder, genetic mutation and lung cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA DENIES ROC LAWMAKER ACCESS TO ABDUCTED POLICEMAN

TEXT.P: Legislator Tsaur Eel-jong (KMT-Matsu) on Thursday expressed disappointment at mainland China's refusal to allow him to meet with a Taiwan marine policeman who was abducted to the mainland on Sunday.

Tsaur left for the city of Fuzhou in mainland China's coastal Fujian province on Monday to seek the early return of Chuang Chen-yao, a local marine police officer who was abducted by mainland fishermen while performing a search of a mainland fishing vessel caught fishing illegally in Taiwan's territorial waters on Sunday.
Tsaur said Fujian officials in charge of Taiwan affairs told him that Chuang is in stable condition after receiving emergency hospital treatment for head injuries.
However, Tsaur said mainland officials refused to tell him where Chuang was sent after receiving the emergency treatment.

Tsaur quoted mainland sources as telling him that Chuang has been moved to another hospital, mainly in an attempt to reduce outside interference and provide him with better medical services, rather than because of any worsening of his condition.
The mainland officials also denied reports that Chuang has been admitted to a military hospital, Tsaur said.
During his stay in Fuzhou, Tsaur said he was not permitted an opportunity to meet with Chuang.

According to Taiwan press reports, the marine policeman was abducted when two Taiwan marine police patrol boats intercepted and boarded a mainland fishing vessel which had intruded into waters off the island of Matsu, which is controlled by Taiwan but located close to the mainland. Nine policemen who boarded the mainland fishing boat Ming Chang Yu 1448 were attacked by the mainland crew armed with knives, axes and bottles.

However, mainland authorities have a different account of the incident. The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) sent a letter to its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on Wednesday, saying that the mainland crew had accused Taiwan marine police of shooting at them while their boat was returning home.

The ARATS letter said that the mainland boat made no "suspicious" moves when intercepted and boarded by the police. It also claimed that the Taiwan move has affected the normal fishing operations of mainland fishermen.
SEF officials said copies of the ARATS letter has been sent to the marine police corps and the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
The marine police corps is expected to provide a more detailed report concerning the incident to the SEF, which will then inform the ARATS of Taiwan's version of the incident.
SEF officials said they will maintain contact with the ARATS in order to arrange a visit to the mainland by SEF officials and Chuang's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE TRADE RELATIONS WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will promote economic and trade relations with Mongolia, according to a report by the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission of the Executive Yuan.

Lee Hou-kao, chairman of the commission, pointed out in a report to the ruling Kuomintang Central Committee that Mongolia harbors no hostility toward Taiwan, and that it is not controlled by mainland China.

In the report, Lee said Mongolia should therefore be seen as a special region different from the Communist-controlled mainland of China. Taiwan should actively promote economic, trade, cultural, and other relations with Mongolia, he said.
Lee said that Taiwan businessmen should be allowed to make investment in Mongolia without restrictions, and that import of Mongolian goods into Taiwan should be allowed. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON ROC GOVERNMENT'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Thursday's edition of local English-language daily the China News.
Look Who's Talking Now

The government is under siege, but this time it is not from without. The island's most reclusive billionaire and long-time friend of President Lee Teng-hui, Evergreen Chairman Chang Yung-fa, has added his voice to a growing chorus of calls in favor of lifting the ban on direct cross-strait links.

Let's see where the battle lines have been drawn: On the one side, there is Formosa Plastics Group's Wang Yung-ching, President Enterprises' Kao Chin-yuen, Pacific Electric wire and Cable's Suen Tao-tsuen and 30,000 small- and medium-sized enterprises. On the other is Chinatrust Group Chairman Koo Chen-fu... KMT business manager Liu Tai-ying... The KMT and its traditional power base, however, is split, with the promise of more fireworks to come as players and followers rush to join the action.

It is hard to imagine how (President) Lee will be able to parry the latest blow to his "be patient, no haste" policy on mainland investment by Taiwanese companies. To be sure, Chang and Wang, Taiwan's two preeminent industrialists... will not be easily denied the pursuit of their aims. Both have multinational conglomerates that form a huge chunk of Taiwan's economy... If the government insists on squeezing them, they can afford to simply walk away...

So far, both have chosen to play by the rules... But their patience has been steadily running out. Operating costs are rising steadily, market share is vanishing before their eyes in China, and no progress seems to have been made in almost two years on improving mainland relations. Now that Beijing has shown a willingness to get talks back on track, the tycoons cannot afford the patience to stand by and watch while the government shuffles its feet and plays coy.

The government must accept that it can play a far more constructive role as adviser if it works with its business leaders, rather than against them... Taiwan should be seeking constructive talks with China on matters affecting its businesses as soon as possible, otherwise it will find that its worst fears have been confirmed -- that it is too late, and the cards they were holding up their sleeves for so long have vanished.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOME TO JOIN SICA

TEXT.P: Ernesto Leal, secretary general of the System for Integration of Central America (SICA), said here on Thursday that Taiwan is welcome to join SICA and that such a move will benefit both sides.
Leal made the remarks in a meeting with leaders of the local business and academic sectors while speaking on Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's decision to join the organization.

Lee made the decision during his September Latin American tour, during which SICA member-nations issued a declaration welcoming Taiwan to join as a non-regional member. Lee and the heads of state of four Central American countries also signed several agreements to boost mutual cooperation and enhance relations.
SICA is a regional organization comprising six central American countries -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama.

Leal argued that it is important for the ROC to grab the opportunity to join SICA, especially at the present time, when SICA members are seeking to strengthen trade and commerce relations with the United States and Canada.
According to Leal, President Lee decided to join SICA because "he realizes SICA's potential and because of his desire to cement substantive ties with countries in Central America."

He added that the ROC's participation in SICA will help the nation increase its presence in the international community and will enable it to use the region as a springboard to break into the North American market." "The ROC's participation in SICA will actually benefit both sides," he pointed out.
Leal also revealed that he had already exchanged opinions with Premier Vincent Siew and Vice Premier John Chang on issues related to Taiwan's participation in SICA.
Leal is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Asia-Pacific Public Affairs Forum, a private organization established to promote Taiwan's international image abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE SUPPORT UN MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: Most people in Taiwan support the government's efforts to join the United Nations, according to the results of a survey made public on Thursday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The survey found that 91.7 percent of those interviewed support the government's UN bid, with 80 percent saying that UN membership is vital to the nation's security and existence. Seventy-eight percent of the respondents view Beijing's objections as the biggest hurdle for Taiwan's admission to the international organization.

Asked what policy the government should adopt for joining the UN, 38.4 percent of those interviewed approve the "two equal political entities, which will eventually be united" policy, while 29.2 percent identify with the "one China, one Taiwan" policy. The "one China" policy won 16.1 percent approval, and "two Chinas" policy had a 6.2 percent approval rating.

Seventy-one percent of those polled said that the government should apply to join the United Nations as a full member, while 17.8 percent said that the government should join the organization as an observer.

Regarding the name the government should use when applying for UN membership, the Republic of China won 40 percent approval, followed by Taiwan (23.4 percent), the Republic of China on Taiwan (10 percent), and Chinese Taipei (11.2 percent).
The China Credit Information Service was commissioned by the Foreign Ministry to conduct the telephone survey of 1,067 adults around the island between Oct. 22-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK LOWERS BANK RESERVE REQUIREMENTS

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China on Thursday announced a cut in bank reserve requirements BY 0.5-1.5 percentage points in a bid to help ease the tight capital market which has caused local stock prices to plummet over the past few weeks.

The cut, effective immediately, reduced the requirements for check deposits by 1.5 percentage points (from 21.25 percent to 19.65 percent); demand deposits by 1.5 percentage points (from 19.25 percent to 17.75 percent); demand savings deposits by 1.5 percentage points (from 11.75 percent to 10.25 percent); time deposits by 0.5 percentage points (from 8.25 percent to 7.75 percent); and time savings deposits by 0.5 percentage points (from 6.25 percent to 5.75 percent).
The new reductions bring the average weighted reserve requirement down to 8.31 percent from the current level of 9.1 percent.

In a hastily called news conference, CBC Deputy Governor Liang Cheng-chin said that the move, the second by the CBC in less than a month, is expected to release NT$96 billion (US$3.36 billion) into the capital market. The CBC made a similar move on Sept. 25.

The inefficient money supply has caused interest on inter-bank loans to reach as high as 8 percent per annum or even higher, forcing local banks to raise interest rates to attract deposits and to reduce loans to customers. As a result, the private sector is now finding it hard to secure loan services.
Liang said that the CBC will continue to maintain a "moderate" monetary policy by intervening in the market to either retrieve or release money.

Meanwhile, as part of the government package of plans to revive the sluggish stock market, the Finance Ministry announced on Thursday afternoon that the ceiling on foreign investment in the local stock market will be immediately raised from 25 percent to 30 percent of total market value.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASS MEDIA GROWING FAST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: With the improvement in standards of living over the last few years, the mass media in Taiwan has continued to grow, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Regardless of keen competition from the electronic media, newspapers in Taiwan remain the main source of information for people who want to know what is going on in the world. As of the end of 1996, there were 361 newspapers registered in Taiwan, an increase of 26 over 1995, the DGBAS statistics indicated.

News agencies and magazines also saw faster growth last year, the statistics showing that there were 242 news agencies and 5,480 magazines in Taiwan in 1996, an increase of 24 and 233, respectively, over 1995.
Taiwan had 5,325 publishing houses, 550 more than in the previous year, and 1,615 record companies, 223 more than in 1995.

In addition, there were 2,506 TV program producers last year and 2,659 radio program producers, up 10.3 percent and 7.7 percent, respectively, over 1995, while the government approved 122 applications for the establishment of cable TV companies, 69 more than in 1995.

The motion picture industry, which has suffered a decline over the past few years, was the only exception. In 1996, there were 285 film-makers in Taiwan, four fewer than in the previous year. The government approved the release of 361 motion pictures, including 253 by foreign producers, a reduction of 14.5 percent over 1995.

However, the decline has not stopped Taiwan's film industry from winning international recognition. In 1996, Taiwan sent 144 pictures to international film festivals around the world, winning 13 awards and many more nominations in various categories.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SHOULD BE FIRM WITH JIANG: ANALYST

TEXT.P: Washington, Oct. 15 CNA) US President Bill Clinton should use his Oct. 29 summit with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin in Washington to make absolutely clear that mainland China's reunification with Taiwan must be achieved by peaceful means and with the consent of the 21 million people of Taiwan, an American expert on Chinese affairs said in a paper released on Tuesday.

In a paper entitled: "The US Agenda at the Clinton-Jiang Summit," Stephen Yates, policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a US think-tank, pointed that this US policy is firmly grounded in the principles declared in the three joint communiques between Washington and Beijing and in the policies outlined in the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979.

"Any resort to military intimidation or invasion will provoke an American military response. Given Taiwan's success at establishing democracy at all levels of government, any resolution to the cross-(Taiwan) strait dispute must come about by democratic as well as peaceful means," he said.

Yates also urged Clinton to make clear to Jiang that the US will not agree to stop selling defensive arms to Taiwan in order to get Beijing's commitment to stop selling missiles and nuclear technology to Iran and Pakistan.

The US policy analyst also suggested that Clinton raise security, trade and human rights issues with Jiang. Specifically, on security issues, Clinton should urge Beijing to be more open about its military spending and abide by international nonproliferation treaties and regimes.
He should also urge Beijing to reduce tariffs and non-trade barriers and insist that Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization not be held hostage to mainland China's separate application.

In addition, Clinton's values agenda should address religious persecution and human rights violations in mainland China. He should suggest that mainland China sign and ratify the two United Nations covenants on human rights, according to Yates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANK SETS UP SYDNEY BRANCH

TEXT.P: The International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) has become the first bank from Taiwan to have a largely unrestricted branch in Australia.

In an interview with CNA on Thursday, Jeff Cheng, the vice president and general manager of the new ICBC branch in Sydney, said the ICBC has room to expand now that the Australian government has allowed it to set up the branch.
Australia permitted the ICBC to set up a subsidiary in the Down Under, Cathay Finance International, in August 1986.
The subsidiary, however, was only allowed to accept 20 deposit accounts per year and could not offer its clients checking accounts, restricting its business substantially.

But the Sydney branch has no such restrictions. It can not only offer checking accounts but also accept many savings accounts. The only restriction is that the minimum amount to open an account is A$250,000 (US$184,000), with no restriction on the account size after that, Cheng said.
"I believe with our new branch we can do lots of business, particularly from Australia-invested Taiwanese companies," he said.

Up to the end of August this year, Cathay Finance International's outstanding loans to its customers stood at A$112 million (US$82.4 million), up A$2.6 million (US$1.9 million) from July's level. Its deposits totaled A$22.4 million (US$16.5 million), he said.
But it took 11 years to reach these amounts, he noted.
"From now on, we can increase our lendings and especially take more deposits from our clients at a rapid pace," he said.

He said as the two-way trade between the Republic of China and Australia is expected to increase steadily, the ICBC branch can expect more trade-related business from both Taiwanese and Australian traders.
Last year, the trade volume between the two countries was about A$6 billion (US$4.4 billion) in favor of Australia.

At the branch's opening ceremony Wednesday, Wang Kuo-jan, acting representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, said he expects the ICBC branch to play a greater role in servicing businesses related to trade between Taiwan and Australia.
This bilateral trade only accounts for some 2 percent of Taiwan's overall trade, Wang said.
"There is great room for trade between Taiwan and Australia to expand," he added.
The ICBC branch will also play a major role in helping boost Taiwanese investment in Australia and help overseas Chinese set up business operations here, he said.
The new branch will take over all of the operations of Cathay Finance International by the end of this year, he said.
Cheng said that the ICBC is planning to set up a similar branch in Brisbane to serve that city's many Taiwanese businessmen and immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDELA RULES OUT MEDIATION IN CONGOLESE CIVIL WAR

TEXT.P: South African President Nelson Mandela has ruled out mediation in the civil war in the Republic of the Congo.

Both parties involved in the Congolese civil war had wanted to visit South Africa about two months ago to consult Mandela, but he has instead referred them to Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, chairman of the Organization for African Unity.
"I didn't think it would be correct -- so soon after I'd been involved in what is now the Democratic Republic of the Congo -- to be involved in a neighboring country," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIES CAN STILL ACHIEVE 7 PERCENT GROWTH

TEXT.P: The fallout from Southeast Asia's currency crisis will be limited, and the Asia-Pacific region will still be able to achieve 6.5 to 7 percent growth this year, according to two economists from leading US stockbroking firm Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

Stephen Roach, the firm's chief economist, said he expects the shortfall in economic activity as a result of the currency turmoil to be contained to the four worst-affected countries -- Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia -- and not spread to the rest of the region.
That will not have a major impact on the global economy, he added. The ASEAN four account for just 3 to 4 percent of the global gross domestic product.

Excluding mainland China and India -- both unaffected by the recent developments in the region -- Asia accounts for a surprisingly small share of global gross domestic product (7 percent) and trade (4 percent), Roach pointed out.
The regional currency crisis is similar to the one experienced by Mexico in late 1994, and using Mexico as a model, the affected countries will take at least a year to recover.
Roach and Byron Wien, a Morgan Stanley strategist, spoke to Morgan Stanley Asia's clients on Thursday on the topic: "How long can the good times last?"

"Morgan Stanley's global economics team is forecasting a little more than 4 percent growth in world GDP over these two years, an outcome that would represent the sharpest increase since 1987-88," he said.
There is likely to be a confluence of upside growth surprises in the US, Europe and Latin America, and an emerging shortfall in Asia will be only partly offset.
Roach said Japan and the ASEAN region accounted for 12 percent of the global GDP, but 85 percent of the GDP producing regions of the world were showing surprising strength.
The US Federal Reserve Board is expected to raise the federal funds rate by 100 basis points next year and a similar tightening can be expected next year in Germany.

But given the 3.8 percent growth this year and the strong growth forecast for next year, inflation will accelerate to 3.1 percent next year from this year's 2.5 percent, which will spur the Fed into action. But the risk of a recession is not expected till late 1999, Roach said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CHANG HWA BANK'S SINGAPORE BRANCH INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Singapore Branch of Taiwan's Chang Hwa Commercial Bank was officially inaugurated on Thursday.
A cocktail reception celebrating the occasion took place at 7:00 p.m. at a local hotel, with hundreds of Singapore and foreign bankers and business leaders in attendance.

Tsai Mao-Hsing, Chang Hwa Bank chairman, and Ouyang Juei-hsiung, ROC representative in Singapore, addressed the gathering and Tsou Hong-tu, the president of Chang Hwa Bank, and Tung Cheng-hong, the general manager of the Singapore Branch, were on hand to greet the guests.
Chang Hwa Bank is the eighth Taiwan bank to set up a branch in Singapore and the second this year. On March 17, the International Commercial Bank of China also opened a branch in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH AIMS FOR `OASIS OF TALENT' FOR SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Wednesday spelt out his vision of Singapore as an "oasis of talent," serving as a hub for business, talent, knowledge and information, with global networks linking the world's three economic growth engines of Asia, Europe and the Americas.
To survive in the future, Singapore will need to be a "special place for special people," drawing top talent from its major trading partners to Singapore, he said.
Goh outlined his vision for Singapore in a speech in Hong Kong, The Straits Times reported on Thursday.
He pointed out that making Singapore such a special place will also benefit Singaporeans, who will enjoy a higher standard of living in a cosmopolitan city.

He told the gathering of top business leaders from around the world that Singapore thrives on and values foreign talent. The country welcomed foreign entrepreneurs, industrialists, bankers, scientists, engineers, academics, artists, artisans and even sportsmen into its society.
These new additions to Singapore will help the country establish links with its major trading partners and build up its networks abroad.
The drive to draw foreign talent will also impose discipline on Singapore as it will have to strive to make the country as attractive as possible.
In 10 to 20 years' time, he said, Singapore will be a more international, cosmopolitan city, as more foreigners move in. This will bring about a gradual evolution of Singapore society.
But some things will not change, he said, adding that the country will want to retain its core culture so that it remains distinctively Singaporean.
During a question-and-answer session following his speech, Goh was asked whether the government's open-door policy a sensitive issue in Singapore?
He acknowledged that some Singaporeans were concerned about whether they and their children will be able to compete with talent from abroad.
These concerns will have to be addressed, he said, adding that he would "take the time to address them."
But Singaporeans, he said, can see for themselves that foreigners have added value to the country. Without foreign companies, Singaporeans would not have the high standard of living they now enjoy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO HAVE BALANCED BUDGET SOON

TEXT.P: Canada's finances are in such a good shape that the government will finally be able to wrestle down the budget deficit, the nation's top financial official has announced.

Finance Minister Paul Martin unveiled a better-than-expected picture of Canada's federal deficit Wednesday when he told the House of Commons finance committee the latest deficit is C$2O billion (US$14.5 billion) lower than the previous year's.
Economists who looked into the deficit improvement were surprised at how fast the red has been evaporating -- faster than even the most optimistic forecasters had believed possible.

Martin said the 1996-97 deficit of C$8.9 billion (US$6.5 billion) represents 1.1 percent of Canada's gross domestic product, the sum of all goods and services produced in the country. He added that Canada will soon have the first balanced budget in a generation. The last time the books were balanced was in 1969-70.
"The books are not balanced yet," he cautioned. "The dividend will be small, but it will grow. ... There will not be an instant windfall."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF RAISES CEILING ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN LOCAL BOURSE

TEXT.P: In an attempt to boost the sagging local bourse, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Thursday raised the ceiling on foreign investment in individual publicly listed firms from the current 25 percent of total stocks to 30 percent, a move which will increase the quota of foreign investment in the bourse by US$17.4 billion.
Taiwan stock prices took another plunge Thursday, due to the shortage of cash on the financial market, with the benchmark index shedding 264 points and dipping below the average level of this year.

The move was announced by Minister of Finance Paul Chiu at a hastily-called press conference, after an emergency meeting with Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Liang Cheng-chin, Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Lu Daung-yen and other senior financial officials.
The maximum ownership of a firm by a single foreign investor was also raised from 10 percent of the company's floated shares to 15 percent, said Chiu.

Under the new measures, the quota for foreign investment in the local bourse will go up by US$17.4 billion to about US$93 billion, with US$56.2 billion-worth of quota still open for application, said the minister.
The statistics, prepared by the CBC, show that shares held by foreign institutions accounted for 4.29 percent of the value of total listed shares in August, compared to 3.53 percent last October.

The approved sum of foreign investment in the local bourse, which is still valid, stands at about 15 percent of the total value of listed shares as of Oct. 4, against 8 percent as of the end of last year, according to the same statistics.
Chiu said the new measures are part of the government's efforts to make the island into a regional financial center by 2000, when capital will be able to flow in and out of the island freely.

Response to questions from reporters, Liang said that the CBC's "moderate money supplies" policy didn't alter in the wake of Thursday's bourse plunge, with short term interest rates targeted at between 7 and 7.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO BOOST EDUCATIONAL EXCHANGES WITH SICA

TEXT.P: Ernesto Leal, secretary general of the System for Integration of Central America (SICA), suggested on Thursday that Taiwan boost educational exchanges with SICA member-nations as a means of cultivating talent with global vision.
Leal made the remarks during a meeting with Y.T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level academic research institute.

He proposed that Taiwan strengthen exchanges of teachers and students with SICA member-countries in order to cultivate talent with international vision, which he said will help the Republic of China in its bid to play a more active role in the international community.

According to Leal, SICA member-nations wish to strengthen mutual understanding with foreign countries through all kinds of exchanges and that both his current visit to Taiwan and ROC President Lee Teng-hui's September Latin American trip are aimed at achieving this purpose.

However, Leal went on to say that while the ROC is very welcome to "associate" with SICA, full membership in the regional organization remains very difficult, due to the great geographical distances and differences in the cultural backgrounds and customs of the two sides.
Echoing Leal's view, Lee agreed that educational exchanges will not only increase academic levels on both sides, they will also help reduce cultural barriers between them.
Leal is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Asia-Pacific Public Affairs Forum, a private organization set up to promote Taiwan's international image.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PEOPLE CREATE THE WORLD'S FOURTH-STRONGEST ECONOMIC POWER

TEXT.P: Chinese people around the world, who already constitute the world's fourth- or fifth-strongest economic power, are expected to become even more influential in the world economy, an ROC government report said on Thursday.

The Overseas Chinese Commission's report, entitled "Analysis of the Economic Power of Overseas Chinese," is based on statistics compiled by international magazines and organizations over the past five years, a commission official said.

The July 1992 issue of Britain's "Economist" magazine revealed that the mobile assets (with stock shares excluded) held by Chinese people (excluding those in mainland China) had reached between US$1.5 trillion and US$2 trillion.

A report published by professor Jau Mei-chiao of Hong Kong University in March 1992 said that about 80 percent of all overseas Chinese live in Southeast Asian countries, where they control over 50 percent of the economic power in the area.

The World Bank has predicted that the "Chinese economies" -- Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and overseas Chinese -- will become the world's fourth-strongest economic power in 10 years, behind only the United States, Japan and Germany.

The US-based "Fortune" magazine, in its October 1994 edition, said that Asian countries attracted US$63 billion in foreign investment in 1993, of which US$3.7 billion came from Japan, US$19.1 billion from Hong Kong, US$4.4 billion from Taiwan and US$2.7 from Singapore. The figure was described as clear evidence that capital from Chinese people played a vital role in foreign investment in those Asian countries.

Japan's Nihon Keizai Shinbun newspaper in October 1994 reported that overall production value by overseas Chinese was estimated at US$717.2 billion. In addition to the US$263.5 billion production value in Taiwan and US$697.6 billion in mainland China, production value by Chinese people around the world had a cumulative total of US$1.67 trillion, a figure exceeded only by the United States, Japan and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING FM REVIEWS HIS PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Outgoing Foreign Minister John Chang emphasized on Thursday that the Republic of China's efforts to raise its international profile is not aimed at challenging Beijing's legitimacy but rather at making Beijing accept the existence of the ROC as a sovereign state.

At a farewell press conference, Chang, who assumed his new role as vice premier on Sept. 1 but retained his position as foreign minister while awaiting replacement on Oct. 20 by his successor, Jason Hu, hinted that the ROC is expected to add one or two new additions to its roster of diplomatic allies by the end of the year.

Chang said that he is not a diplomatic militant, despite his now-familiar official war-cry: "fight fire with fire," adding that all he has done is try to represent the ROC in its capacity as a sovereign state.

Citing the improvement in the treatment accorded to President Lee Teng-hui during his stopover in Hawaii in early September, and the upgrading of levels of representatives to Taipei by several European states, Chang said that Taiwan's international status has improved during his over one year in office.

He said he disagreed with the view that Taipei's international diplomacy should take second place to its policy towards Beijing, saying that in fact "diplomacy is what makes the island different from Hong Kong." The former British colony reverted to Beijing's rule on July 1 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISRUPTIVE PASSENGER FORCES UNSCHEDULED LANDING

TEXT.P: An Eva Airways passenger flight from Amsterdam to Taipei via Dubai was forced to change course after a passenger became inebriated and insisted upon smoking aboard the plane, an EVA Airways spokesman said Friday.
As a result, the captain of the plane was compelled to land at Muscat Airport in Oman, where the passenger of Arabic origin was turned over to local police.
It is believed to be the first case involving violation of a smoking ban imposed by ROC airlines on all international flights.
The disruptive passenger, surnamed Alawamlah, boarded EVA Airways flight No. 876 at Dubai Airport, bringing with him a bottle of Scotch whisky.

Alawamlah soon became tipsy and began to smoke. One hour and 43 minutes after departure from Dubai, crew members tried in vain to prevent him from lighting up a second cigarette. When the flight captain attempted to dissuade him, he was threatened by Alawamlah.

The pilot then made the decision to land at the nearby Muscat Airport in Oman, where Alawamlah was placed in the custody of local police. Due to the delay, the plane arrived in Taiwan about two hours behind schedule at 1:00 p.m. on Thursday.
