DOC.HEADLINE: AMBASSADOR'S CHILDREN 'VERY TAIWANIZED'

TEXT.P: Among dozens of oriental-eyed, straight-haired Taiwan schoolchildren busily playing the traditional Chinese folk game "che-ling," two are particularly prominent with their green eyes, curly hair and relatively darker skin.

The two pupils, 11-year-old Anli and her younger brother Juofan, 10, are Paraguayans, but they can speak Mandarin fluently, wearing the same uniforms as other Taiwan children who attend their local primary school.

"If you really want to learn the Chinese language and Chinese culture, you must put the children in local schools," said Mrs. Ceferino Valdez Peralta, mother of the two children, and wife of the Paraguay's ambassador to the ROC.

Mrs. Valdez and her diplomat husband chose to send their three children, including the youngest, aged four, to attend Shihtung Elementary School and a local kindergarten in Taipei's suburban area of Tienmu instead of sending them to the nearby Taipei American School or the Taipei European School because they want the kids "to learn everything here."

Attending the Shihtung school for only four months, Anli and Juofan not only are able to handle their studies at the fifth and fourth grade level, they can also play traditional Chinese folk games like che-ling, lion dancing, and stilt walking.

Anli, who is as zealous as her mother in learning Chinese culture, found writing Chinese characters rather difficult at first, according to her teacher, "The words she produced look just great, although they appeared more as drawings than as writing."

The three Valdez youngsters were standing proudly alongside other students lined up under a banner at the gate of Shihtung Elementary School on Thursday morning to welcome Paraguayan First Lady Maria Teresa Carrasco de Wasmosy for a visit.

The children sang Mandarin, Taiwanese and Spanish ballads to greet Mrs. Wasmosy, who visited Shihtung to show gratitude for the efforts made by the elementary school in providing a comfortable learning environment for expatriate children.

Mrs. Wasmosy has long dedicated herself to charitable work as part of her efforts to help resolve the serious gap in wealth distribution in Paraguay. She arrived in Taipei on Oct. 15 for a five-day visit at the invitation of the ROC government.
Anli and Juofan's quick adaptation to their studies would not have been so easy if not for their parents' farsightedness.
The Valdez's had Anli and Juofan begin learning basic Mandarin conversation and the phonetic symbols before they headed for Taiwan.
The ambassador himself often appears at Shihtung, in jeans, to watch the children study and to take them home after classes.
Mrs. Valdez has also actively taken part in school activities at Shihtung, teaching a children's English class at the school every Wednesday afternoon.
Paraguay is the ROC's sole diplomatic ally in South America and the two countries enjoy close and cordial relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND POLICY PLANNING PANEL TO MEET ON 'THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's mainland policy planning task force will meet in the near future to discuss the "three links" issue, Vice Premier John Chang said on Friday.

Chang, who concurrently serves as the convener of the special task force, said the government has been paying close attention to public opinion with regard to direct communications, transportation and trade links with mainland China, commonly known as the "three links."
Chang said the opening of direct contacts across the Taiwan Strait is not a simple issue, but rather one which requires prudent evaluation from several different perspectives.
"National security is a priority concern in formulating our policy toward mainland China," Chang stressed, adding that the government must always remain cautious in tackling the "three links" issue.

Chang's remarks came after shipping tycoon Chang Yung-fa strongly urged the government in a recent newspaper interview to lift its rigid ban on direct cross-strait shipping, trade and communications links in order to sustain Taiwan's economic leverage.
Chang assumed his new role as vice premier on Sept. 1 but has retained his position as foreign minister while awaiting replacement on Oct. 20 by his successor, Jason Hu.

He also told a news conference on Thursday that the Republic of China's diplomatic policy is by no means aimed at challenging Communist China's legitimacy but rather at making Beijing accept its existence as an "equal political entity."

The outgoing minister of foreign affairs said he disagrees with the view that the ROC's diplomatic initiatives should take second place to its policy towards Beijing, stressing that the ability to conduct its own international relations is what makes Taiwan different from Hong Kong. The former British colony reverted to Beijing's rule on July 1 this year.

Despite his now-familiar war cry of "Fight fire with fire," Chang said he is not a diplomatic crusader, adding that all he has done is to merely exert the ROC's legitimate rights as a sovereign state.

Chang said Taiwan's international status has risen during his more than one year in the ROC's top diplomatic post, citing as evidence the improved treatment accorded to President Lee Teng-hui during his stopover in Hawaii in early September, and the upgrading of the levels of representatives to Taipei by several European states.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNDAMENTALS OF ECONOMY ROSY DESPITE SLUMP IN NT DOLLAR, SHARE PRICES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew stressed Friday that the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are in good order despite a slumping New Taiwan dollar and falling share prices on the local bourse.
Siew made the remarks in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan, saying finance officials had reached that conclusion in a meeting 10 days ago.

His comments followed another free fall in the stock market which saw the weighted index, the market's key barometer, shedding 165.66 points to end at 7,832.15 after plunging below the 8,000-point threshold Thursday.

Heavy selling of the New Taiwan dollar also emerged Friday morning amid signs that the Central Bank of China (CBC) seemed to abandon its defense of an exchange rate set at around NT$28.50 Thursday. The rate fell to NT$29.035 in the morning session in the forex market, the lowest rate in nearly a decade.

However, Siew said that Taiwan's exports, investment, price levels and employment rates have been good over the past year, which sets Taiwan apart from the Southeast Asian countries which are reeling from recent financial crises.
He said that the declining stock market has nothing to do with the nation's fundamental economic base.

Noting that deepening financial woes in Southeast Asia have resulted in currency devaluation of 20 percent or more in Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia, as well as slight depreciations of the Singapore dollar, Japanese yen and South Korean won, Siew said Taiwan could not remain unaffected. Those downward trends, coupled with a strong US dollar, have added to the pressure on the New Taiwan dollar.

As to whether finance officials should allow market mechanisms alone to determine the exchange rate of the local currency vis-a-vis the US dollar, Siew said that the CBC has chosen to take measures to stabilize the forex market because of abnormalities and psychological factors arising from the situation in Southeast Asia.

CBC Governor Sheu Yuan-dong echoed Siew's words by saying that the lackluster performance of the stock market has resulted in part from fears on the part of investors over the fate of the local currency.
Sheu also maintained that the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are sound, and that any "problems," whether in stock or forex markets are "not serious at all."

Sheu said that economic growth is occurring at a faster pace than that seen last year, and that foreign reserves stand at a healthy US$87 billion despite the recent selling off of US$5 billion to help buoy the exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar.

Taiwan has no foreign debt, and enjoys an overall trade surplus of US$10 billion. In addition, Taiwan has a stable price index level, the New Taiwan dollar has not been overvalued, and neither the island's large nor small-scale enterprises have reason to lose confidence, Sheu said.

Sheu said the financial crisis in Southeast Asia has seen limited effect in Taiwan, pointing out that total imports and exports to that region amount to less than US$1 billion, and that Taiwan's export goods do not overlap with those of the Southeast Asian nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG SPEAKS OF SINGLE-TERM AS HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR), said during a visit to Japan on Thursday night that he does not intend to seek a second term as the territory's administrative head.
In remarks to the press at a tea party, Tung made it clear that although he will serve as the HKSAR chief executive for only one term, he will do his best to lay a solid foundation for his successor.

Tung's disclosure came in response to a comment that, while his policy address before the Hong Kong Provisional Legislative Council earlier this month was imbued with a forward-looking perspective, its goals will hardly be achievable if he does not seek another term.

Tung explained that he had intended to serve only a single term when he took part in the election for the post last year, adding that by the time his present tenure expires, he will be too old to seek a second term.
According to the Hong Kong Basic Law, the tenure of the chief executive of the HKSAR is five years. A second and final term is allowable in the event an incumbent is re-elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CALL FOR ACTION TO HELP CONVICTED MURDERER

TEXT.P: Four legislators on Friday hosted a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, calling for the government to establish a private fund to render assistance to ROC citizens who have been discriminated against in foreign courts or who have encountered inhumane treatment overseas.

The hearing was held in response to an appeal by the family of Tzuo Ming-hsin, an ROC national and a permanent resident of Alaska who was convicted of first degree murder there eight years ago and sentenced to 198 years in jail.
The prisoner's sister, Tzuo Hsiao-ling, told the lawmakers her brother is innocent. The jury convicted him with no more direct evidence than a tape containing vague sounds and conversation, she said.
In addition, she said, her brother has been discriminated against and even tortured since he went behind bars eight years ago.
The legislators called for concerted efforts by the government, Taiwan private sector and news media both here and abroad to focus on the case and render Tzuo timely assistance.
If a private foundation can be established soon, there would be enough money to hire US-based lawyers to fight for Tzuo, enabling him to stand a better chance at justice, the lawmakers said.

Meanwhile, Dr. Yuan T. Lee, president of the Academia Sinica, the top research institute in the ROC, and the winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, on Thursday faxed a letter to ROC Representative in the United States Jason Hu, urging him to help Tzuo.
In his letter, Lee asked Hu to send ROC officials to contact Tzuo and his attorneys to see if there is anything Taiwan can do to help.
Lee also asked Hu to contact the US lawmakers who represent Alaska to see whether they would be willing to gain more understanding of Tzuo's case and thereafter voice their support for his cause.

Hu, who is departing his Washington post in two days to assume his new job as ROC foreign affairs minister, told Lee that he and his staff are trying their best to aid Tzuo. Since the Tzuo family is not rich, Tzuo Ming-hsin will need a great deal of outside money before he gets any access to justice, Hu said.
Human rights organizations and charity foundations would be good channels through which ROC diplomats could try to further Tzuo's cause, he added.
Meanwhile, Lee disclosed he had added his voice to the call to support Tzuo because the prisoner's son, Tzuo Tzu-cheng, wrote him to ask for help.

The junior Tzuo said he became acquainted with Lee two years ago when he knocked on a door along his newspaper route to collect his fee and was surprised to see the Nobel laureate appear. Tzuo said he immediately pulled out the card that identified him as a paper boy and asked Lee for his autograph.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ECONOMICS DAY TO DISCUSS ROC-GERMAN TRADE, INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Taipei Trade Office in Germany, Taiwan Trade Service of the China External Trade Development Council, Economic Development Corp. of Nordrhein-Westfalen and Dusseldorf City Government will jointly sponsor the sixth "Taipei Economics Day" in Dusseldorf on Oct. 31.
Lorenz Schomerus, state secretary of Germany's Ministry of Economic Affairs, has been invited to address the meeting on Germany's Asian-Pacific strategies.
Charles King, the Republic of China's representative to Germany, and Rainer Buhr, general manager of the Economic Development Council of Nordrhein-Westfalen, will speak at the opening ceremony.

Experts in trade and investment are scheduled to speak on a variety of topics, including technology transfers and strategic alliances between German and Taiwan firms. A panel discussion will be held in the afternoon for the participants to exchange views on problem areas for Taiwan investors in Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S 3RD LARGEST RATING AGENCY CREATED BY MERGER

TEXT.P: In a move that will create the world's third largest credit rating agency, FIMALAC of France Thursday announced an agreement to acquire Fitch Investors Service, L.P. from the Van Kampen Group of Grand Haven, Michigan and other investors, and merge with IBCA Limited, a London-based rating agency controlled by the French company.
According to a news release here Thursday, the new entity will be known as Fitch IBCA, Inc., and will maintain dual headquarters in London and New York.

It said that under the agreement a new US company controlled by FIMALAC will acquire 100 percent of Fitch for $175 million in cash. Fitch IBCA management will have a significant equity-based participation in the new company.

Fitch IBCA will have combined revenues of US$105 million and over 550 employees in 18 offices worldwide. It will rank among the other major rating agencies, Standard & Poor's Ratings Group and Moody's Investors Service, which together have long dominated the rating business.

FIMALAC, a diversified operating company created in 1991 with interests in industry, communications and real estate, is controlled by its chairman, Marc Ladreit de Lacharriere. Its shares trade on the Paris Stock Exchange. And now Ladreit de Lacharriere will be chairman of the new Fitch IBCA, while IBCA Chairman Robin Monro-Davies becomes vice chairman and chief executive officer, and Fitch President Stephen W. Joynt becomes president and chief operating officer.

"This merger constitutes a unique opportunity to bring much needed competition and an international perspective to the global ratings business," commented Ladreit de Lacharriere. "It also reflects FIMALAC's commitment to expanding its role as an international group and to pursuing its global development strategy. And Fitch IBCA is certain to be a formidable player in the global ratings business," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR PARTY LEADER'S DEFECTION SEEN A CATALYST TO AUSSIE LABOR PARTY'S RETURN TO POWER (I)

TEXT.P: The stunning defection of the leader of Australian Democrats to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is a "political earthquake" and appears to be a catalyst for the return to power of the ALP in the next election, political analysts say.

Senator Cheryl Kernot, one of the most popular politicians in Australia, announced on Thursday that she would quit the Senate and resign as leader of the Australian Democrats, the fourth largest party in this country, behind the Liberal, Labor and National parties.

One of her major purposes in joining the Labor Party, is to remove the coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard because of her outrage at the Howard government's policies and frustration that the Democrats were unable to influence them.

"I have reached the conclusion that, for me, the imperative at the next federal election lies not in battling to extract a share of the third party vote to keep balance of power in the Senate," she said.
"It is to play a more direct role in the removal of the coalition government. It is to stop the enormous damage the coalition parties are doing to the fabric of this society," she said.
The coalition government is formed by the Liberal and National parties.

Associate Professor C.L. Chiou of the University of Queensland said: "Kernot's defection to the Labor Party is a political earthquake because she is a popular and influential politician. She could be a catalyst for the return of ALP power in the next election."
He said Kernot will not only help the Labor Party win women voters, but also attract considerable votes from the Democrats Party she successfully led over the past four years.
The Democrats Party recently won an impressive victory in the election in South Australia, closing the Liberal Party's hold on power in the state government to a thin majority.
Chiou, who met Kernot twice, said she is friendly towards Taiwan and is sympathetic to Taipei.
"To me and many people, Cheryl Kernot is an intelligent, compassionate and farsighted politician with prime ministerial material," Chiou said.
Australian analysts said Kernot's departure was mainly due to "self-interest" in pursuit of her personal ambitions.
Howard even warned that her defection could rebound on the Labor Party, destabilizing current ALP head Kim Beazley's leadership and being perceived as a "betrayal of her own party members."
"Cheryl Kernot senses a leadership vacuum in the Labor Party and she wants to fill it," Howard said, adding "Kernot's decision was all about Cheryl Kernot's personal ambition, nothing else."
Chiou said Kernot has the qualities of a prime minister. But she is unlikely to become the leader of the ALP in the next few years.
"She could become the ALP leader in the future. She is only 48 years old and I believe she could wait until her time comes," he added.
Most Labor Party heavyweights rejected Howard's warnings, saying that Kernot would not threaten their positions.
Beazley said Kernot would "bring new ideas and new blood" to the Labor Party, playing an important role in the renewal and resurgence of the party.

"I'm delighted that such a talented and highly regarded leader of a political party will now seek to play a role in the renewal of the Australian Labor Party and in its return to government at the federal level," he said.

Beazley's deputy leader, former foreign minister and now opposition Treasurer Gareth Evans, said: "I feel absolutely no sense of personal threat whatsoever. This is a team exercise and, my God, what a fantastic new contribution to the team Cheryl's going to make."
Former Labor Party Prime Minister Paul Keating welcomed the move, saying Kernot would add "depth and luster and bring experience and understanding to the next Labor government."
Beazley has promised that he will "move heaven and Earth" to secure Kernot a senior Cabinet post if the ALP pulls off an improbable win at the next election.
ALP national secretary Gary Gray said Kernot would campaign across the country to boost Labor votes for the next election -- "not just in marginal seats but everywhere."

Democrats members did not feel bitter over Kernot's defection. Sam Hudson, Kernot's former chief of staff and the Democrats' honorary national secretary, predicted that party members would accept her decision and move on without resentment. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR PARTY LEADER'S DEFECTION SEEN A CATALYST TO AUSSIE LABOR PARTY'S RETURN TO POWER (II)

TEXT.P: Don Chipp, founder of the Democrats Party, said: "You've got to admire her courage for doing it, and her conviction."
A former Labor Party minister, David Beddall, even offered to vacate his seat of Rankin in Queensland for Kernot.

But Kernot could also contest the seat of Dickson in Brisbane in the election to become a federal member of the House of Representatives. She may even compete with Pauline Hanson at Oxley in Brisbane if former Queensland Premier Wayne Goss does not fully recover from a recent brain tumor operation, analysts said.

In a statement, Kernot said: "I am giving up the leadership of a party, I'm moving on my own to uncharted territories, I don't know whether I will win, succeed or fail and I am hurting a lot of people that I care very much about."
Kernot was critical of the coalition government's handling of Australian aboriginal people and the Asian immigration issue.

She made indirect reference to independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, saying she had watched as the coalition government allowed "an agent of division to vilify and scapegoat black Australians and migrants under the cloak of free speech."

"I have found it increasingly difficult to stand in the middle, trying to be endless fair to both sides (government and the opposition) when I have grown so alarmed by the kind of politics being played out by the coalition," she said. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR PARTY LEADER'S DEFECTION SEEN A CATALYST TO AUSSIE LABOR PARTY'S RETURN TO POWER (III)

TEXT.P: But Howard rejected her criticism, saying: "Cheryl Kernot has always taken what you could regard as the Labor point of view."

To the Democrats, the departure of Kernot is a great blow because she had led the party successfully since she took the reins. But the departure also reflected her limited ability to wield influence in the Australian political landscape, analysts said.
Some analysts said Kernot's switch to the Labor Party was the most important development since John Howard's triumph in March last year.

Michael Gordon, a senior writer for mass-circulation newspaper The Australian, said: "It represents a stunning coup for Kim Beazley and Gareth Evans, who began making overtures to Kernot in 1993, and a calculated risk for the former leader of the Democrats.

"While Kernot represents a long-term contender for the Labor leadership, the immediate consequence of the shift is to strengthen the position of Beazley, whose biggest achievement in the job has been a modest one: simply keeping the show together after last year's defeat (of Paul Keating)," he said.
Beazley was never in any danger of being challenged before the next election and, by enhancing the Labor Party's prospects, Kernot also has increased Beazley's chances to head the party.

Nor does her arrival change the dynamics of the contest between Simon Crean and Gareth Evans for the status of likely successor, for both see her arrival as a massive boost to the Labor Party's re-election prospects.
Gordon and some other analysts believed Kernot's arrival represents a circuit-breaker for a party struggling to present a new face to the electorate.
Kernot is expected to play a key role in arriving at a sensible compromise between market economics and government intervention, and selling it to the electorate, Gordon said.

Like former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke in 1980, Kernot can expect to play a critical role in the election campaign, commanding a profile disproportionate with the status of unelected candidate and certain member of the front bench if she succeeds.

But the key question is whether Australian voters will upgrade their view of the Labor Party in the light of their opinion of Kernot or simply downgrade their view of Kernot in the light of their view of the Labor Party.
Will Kernot, as Keating said Thursday, add luster to the Labor Party? Or will she be tarnished by the association?
"Will she be seen as someone who will make the bastards honest by joining them? Or will the disaffection with the main parties simply contaminate her?" Gordon said.
Will Kernot become the Australian leader at some point in the future?
"Let's see how she performs after joining the Labor Party," Chiou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BARGAIN NEEDED BETWEEN TAIPEI AND BEIJING

TEXT.P: A Washington think tank has suggested that new realities across the Taiwan Strait make it incumbent to have a new Beijing-Taipei bargain that can accommodate Beijing's imperative for "one China" and Taipei's desire for formal recognition as an autonomous political actor.

The Progressive Policy Institute said in a just-released paper that a new understanding would likely mean a protracted two-phase process: reaching an interim understanding meeting both sides' minimum needs and a commitment to pursue a long-term process of dialogue on what forms a "one China" arrangement might eventually take.

It said that the new interim understanding, to cover a period which could last a generation, would be based on a "one China policy" principle flexibly applied, adding that a cross-strait summit would be the appropriate forum to launch the framework for a new understanding, and that an initial quid pro quo would be at least a tacit for Beijing renunciation of the use of force in exchange of Taipei's renunciation of an independence option.

In returning for putting the independence idea in deep freeze, it argued, Beijing and Taipei could build on precedents to allow Taiwan membership in international organizations and work out formulas that would allow Taiwan the international political space it rightly deserves.

It went on to say that if mutually acceptable terms can be reached, Taiwan could join the United Nations system, even with a UN seat or observer status, and could be permitted full membership in such UN institutions as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, the International Atomic Energy Agency and other technical agencies.

Such a bargain is achievable if the political will exists on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, it said, but complicating matters is the fact that respective postures of both sides are shaped more by domestic politics than by calculation of respective interests.

It said that the question is whether Taipei is prepared to accept "one China, two administrations" rather than "one China, two sovereign governments." The difference is that, it noted, paradoxically, by conceding to Beijing the principle of ultimate sovereignty, the prospect of accommodating Taipei's desire for more political space, or formal political recognition, might be realized.

The report said that Taiwan's transformation from an authoritarian political system to a free-wheeling pluralism cannot be separated from a burgeoning sense of political identity, and it is the island's democratic political life, and not just its history or its vibrant economy, that is the primary cause of a feeling of separateness from life in mainland China.

It said that President Lee Teng-hui is correct in his assessment that the majority of the island's residents have little desire to be part of the People's Republic of China, adding that in polls over the past five years, nearly 70 percent of residents of Taiwan express this feeling indirectly by stating a preference for the continuation of the status quo.
The paper was prepared by Robert A. Manning while he was a senior PPI fellow. Manning is currently a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASSIVE OIL SPILL CLEAN-UP UNDER WAY IN SINGAPORE STRAITS

TEXT.P: Singapore is fighting its worst oil spill in history after a collision between a large crude carrier and an oil tanker in the Singapore Straits on Wednesday night spewed 25,000 tons of oil into the sea.
A major clean-up operation is now under way with 34 craft trying to prevent the spillage, initially estimated to be about 4,000 tons, from reaching the shores of Sentosa Island and Singapore.

The collision was foreseen by a port traffic controller, who alerted the vessels, which acknowledged the warning. But barely six minutes later, they crashed into each other, said an official of the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) on Thursday.

The Thai-registered crude carrier Orapin Global, which was empty, was sailing towards the Malacca Straits. Its bow was damaged. The Cyprus-flagged oil tanker Evoikos, which was heading towards Singapore, had two oil tanks damaged.
No one was injured in the collision, the MPA said.

The MPA said Thursday night in a statement that its helicopter reconnaissance earlier that afternoon showed thick patches of oil in the sea extending from south of Raffles Shoal to south of Sebarok Island, Jong Fairway, Sisters Fairway and Sinki Fairway.
Oil has also been spotted on the beaches of Sudong, Senang and Pawai islands.
MPA officials are investigating the cause of the collision.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY RAPS PREMIER OVER TIANANMEN REMARKS

TEXT.P: A Canadian newspaper slammed Alberta's Conservative Premier Ralph Klein Thursday for making remarks deemed insensitive to the human lives lost in Beijing's Tiananmen Square during the June 1989 massacre.
The Ottawa Citizen's comment on Klein, who asked Canadians to forget about the unpleasantness of Tiananmen, was "Shame on you."

The premier said that dwelling upon the tragedy will serve only to harm Canada's trade relations with Communist China. He was quoted as saying this week, after meeting Chinese officials in Beijing: "If you want to keep living and reliving those events, then I guess nothing will be accomplished. How long do you keep on doing this?"

Replied the Citizen in an editorial: "Dunno, Ralph. As long as we think people ought not to be shot for holding views contrary to those of their governments? As long as we value the freedoms underlying the free market you profess to represent?"

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN EXPECTED TO HEAD KMT MAINLAND OPERATION GUIDANCE GROUP

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), may soon be appointed convener of the KMT Guidance Group for Mainland Operations by KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, an informed source said Friday.
After the appointment, Lien will preside over all meetings of the group, which has nine to 11 members.
The guidance group is expected to hold a meeting soon after Lien's appointment, the source said. It has not held any meeting for about one year.
It remains unknown whether mainland affairs will be discussed in the meeting, he added. (by Ed Shay)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET EXPERIMENT IS ROBOTICS BREAKTHROUGH

TEXT.P: T.J. Tarn, professor of systems science and mathematics at Washington University in St. Louis, and his doctoral student Kevin Brady earlier this year became the first persons to control a robot live via the Internet.
Tarn presented a paper explaining the technical aspects of this accomplishment at the International Federation of Automatic Control Symposium on Robot Control, held in September, in Nantes, France.

On April 24, 1997, Brady pulled a joystick in Albuquerque, N.M., that controlled the motions of a Puma robot in Tarn's Washington University laboratory more than 1,000 miles away. Standing on a stage, Brady worked in tandem with the robot in front of hundreds of engineers who watched the robot on a video monitor at the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Robotics and Automation Society Flagship Conference.

The three-minute experiment was a difficult task for a robot: It involved avoiding a box placed in its path to perform a manufacturing task of picking up an object and placing it somewhere else. While picking up and moving an object is routine robotics work, avoiding the box and taking commands from a remote operator in real-time over a crowded public network was extraordinary.

The "teleoperations" feat was a major step for the burgeoning field of robotics, and a giant leap for telecommunications, adding a previously unexplored dimension to the Internet -- remote control -- and providing new horizons for other applications.

Tarn envisions long-distance learning and research opportunities where engineers and scientists, linked to a national laboratory, could electronically experiment with robots and other areas of service and manufacturing. Also, secondary school students could perform hands-on science and engineering experiments. People from divergent points then could share resources and save expenses.

According to the Robotic Industries Association, the industry's trade group, some 75,000 robots currently are at work in US factories, placing the United States second only to Japan in robotics usage.

While the automotive industry is the dominant user of robotics, there is growth in the appliance, pharmaceutical and textile industries. In recent years, the robotics industry has averaged a 35 percent annual growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO ATTEND CENTRAL AMERICAN MAYORS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih Friday accepted an invitation to attend Central American Mayors Conference in March, 1998.
The invitation was extended by Secretary General Ernesto Leal of the System for Integration of Central America, who visited Wu Friday morning.
Leal said that some 600 mayors are expected to attend the annual conference, and that he hopes Wu will make a speech at the meeting. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW INDUSTRIAL ZONE TO BECOME OPERATIONAL SOON

TEXT.P: The Yunlin Industrial Zone will become operational when its first-stage development plan is completed at the end of this month.

The industrial zone at Yunlin, central Taiwan, will accommodate 85 high-tech manufacturers, and is expected to generate at least NT$100 billion (US$2.56 billion) worth of industrial production each year, an official of the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said Friday.
The industrial zone will occupy 243.45 hectares, 93 hectares of which is being developed in the first stage.

Yunlin Magistrate C.Y. Liao said the industrial zone will be favored by manufacturers, because it is free from flooding during the raining season and the facilities in the zone are much cheaper than those in the Tainan science park in southern Taiwan. Several high-tech companies have shown keen interest in the zone, he added.
It will become one the three major science and industrial parks in Taiwan. The other two are the well-known Hsinchu Industrial Park and Tainan Science Park. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE PROMISES TO ASSIST IN TAIWAN'S SCIENCE DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Steven Chu, a Chinese-American physicist who won this year's Nobel Prize in physics together with two other scientists, said here on Thursday he is willing to assist both sides of the Taiwan Strait in scientific development.

Chu, a professor at Stanford University, told a news conference for Chinese news media that he has twice visited Taiwan over the past year. During those visits, Chu said he has established good relations with Yuan T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, and gained some understanding of Taiwan's eudcational and academic research systems and measures.

Chu said it is a critical and encouraging development for Taiwan that Academia Sinica, under the leadership of Yuan T. Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, has managed to attract scores of very outstanding scientists to return to Taiwan to join its research programs. "Many of them could have easily found very good positions at prestigious American research institutes."
However, Chu frankly pointed out that Taiwan still far lags behind the United States in scientific research and development.

Chu, who also once visited mainland China, said basic research facilities are not enough in both Taiwan and mainland China. "Moreover, they have to rely on the United States or European countries for the supply of advanced research instruments and equipment."

The 49-year-old physicist further said independent thinking is extremely important in scientific development. In this respect, Chu noted that significant differences exist between Taiwan and the United States. In Taiwan, students or researchers are usually statisfied with one solution to a single problem, while Americans like to seek different solutions to a same problem.
Chu also suggested that Taiwan imporve its overall educational and academic system by integrating teaching and research work in universities.

Chu said Taiwan's universities focus on teaching, while its Academia Sinica concentrates on research. "The separation of teaching from research will cause waste of resources and deprive talented students of rights to do research," he noted, adding it is unreasonable that academics with enough financial resources and advanced research equipment do not join teaching work.
At top-notch American universities, such as Stanford, Harvard and Berkeley, Chu said, many outstanding scientists are obligated to teach and guide students in research work.
Both Chu and his father are Academia Sinica academicians. They are the only father-son pair in the Taiwan's highest academic institute.

Chu was born and raised in the United States, but his parents came from the Chinese mainland in the 1940s. Chu said he treasures his Chinese roots and is willing to help boost scientific development in both Taiwan and the mainland.

Taiwan's National Science Council has invited Chu to visit the island and deliver lectures to its youths. Premier Vincent Siew has also sent a message to Chu congratulating him on winning the Nobel laurel.

Chu and two other scientists -- William Phillips of the Uinted States and Claude Cohen-Tannoudji of France -- shared this year's Nobel Prize in physics for developing ways of trapping atoms of gas and cooling them to within a millionth of a degree of nature's limit. The discovery has already led to more accurate atomic clocks and a new form of matter whose existence Einstein postulated in the 1920s.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD LEAD CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATIONS: SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew reiterated at the Legislative Yuan on Friday that negotiations across the Taiwan Strait should be led by the government as they concern the security and welfare of the 21 million people in Taiwan. These issues would be best served through the already established channels and systems, he said.

Siew made the remarks in response to a question from Hsie Gin-tsuan, a legislator with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), about the DPP's proposal to allow multiple parties to join the cross-strait negotiations.

Siew noted that the Republic of China already has the Guidelines for National Unification as its top principle for dealing with Beijing, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for dealing with political affairs and protocol, and the Straits Exchange Foundation -- a semi-official organization mandated by the MAC -- to act as the bridge between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Cross-strait negotiations would be best left to those established channels and systems, he stressed.

Technical and protocol affairs should remain Taipei's top priority, Siew said, adding that political topics, however, should not be ruled out. What is in dispute between the two sides are differences in systems and ways of life, the premier said, adding that the eventual reunification of the two sides will occur under the principles of freedom, democracy and equal prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON IVAN POSING THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Ivan, which has been gaining strength and approaching Taiwan, may pose a threat to the island beginning Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau reported Friday.

Ivan was upgraded to a "strong typhoon" at 3:00 p.m., when its center was some 1,336 kilometers southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun. It had developed winds of 53 meters per second by then.
It is moving westerly toward Taiwan, the bureau said.
Although the western Pacific usually sees few tropical storms in autumn, Ivan could still bring the island damaging winds and rain, it said.

The bureau warned Taiwan residents to be particularly careful of this and other "autumn typhoons," noting their arrival coincides with the northeast monsoon season and that the combination can cause torrential rains.

The impact of autumn typhoons on the island doubles when they are "fueled" by northeast monsoons, which significantly affect the climate in the Taiwan area during the fall and winter, bureau meteorologists said.
Another autumn typhoon, Joan, meanwhile, was spotted some 2,000 kilometers south of Ivan and moving along the same course toward the island, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYCE CANCELS PLANS FOR S'PORE DOLLAR FUTURES CONTRACTS

TEXT.P: The New York Cotton Exchange (NYCE) has called off plans to list futures contracts in Singapore dollars after it was forced to withdraw three other ASEAN currency contracts because of poor response.

Last month, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) had said that while the decision to launch Singapore dollar futures contracts was up to the NYCE board, it would nevertheless prefer that the listing be deferred because of the recent turmoil in Southeast Asian foreign exchange markets.
The NYCE said Thursday that it had given up the idea of listing the Singapore currency in the foreseeable future.
The NYCE board also decided to withdraw its three ASEAN currency contracts -- in the Thai baht, Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit -- following their lackluster performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES NARROWS TRADE DEFICIT

TEXT.P: The Philippine trade deficit narrowed to US$7.76 billion during the first eight months of this year, down 5.6 percent from the US$8.22 billion registered during the same period of 1996.

Data released by the National Statistics Office show exports in the January-August period rose by 22.8 percent to US$16.03 billion, outpacing imports, which increased by 11.8 percent to US$23.78 billion.
In August alone, total trade stood at US$5.55 billion, up 21.2 percent from the US$4.57 billion posted in the same month last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN PM TO VISIT S'PORE

TEXT.P: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi will visit Singapore Oct. 19-20, the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.
This visit, Prodi's first to Singapore as prime minister, underlines the close friendship and strong ties between Singapore and Italy, the ministry said.
Prodi will be accompanied by Italian Minister for Foreign Trade Augusto Fantozzi and other senior government officials, as well as by an Italian business delegation.
During the visit, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong will host a working lunch for Prodi, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TIES WITH US

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said on Friday that he looks upon his new assignment as a challenge and is optimistic about future bilateral relations.

Chen, who has previously served as a deputy secretary general to President Lee Teng-hui and a vice minister of foreign affairs, as well as spending four years in the US as a deputy ROC representative, left for the US on Friday evening to assume his new post.
He told the press prior to his departure that he will do his utmost to reinforce ROC-US relations, based on the achievements of his predecessors.

Chen's first test will come in the first few days of his new job, as mainland China's President Jiang Zemin is scheduled to arrive in the US on Oct. 26 for a state visit and summit meeting with US President Bill Clinton.
Chen said American authorities have repeatedly assured the ROC that they will not engage mainland China at the expense of Taipei.

The seasoned career diplomat said the ROC's consistent hope is that Taipei-Washington relations will develop parallel to Washington-Beijing ties. "We don't think our relationship with the US is part of the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties," he stressed.
Touching on his work plans, Chen said he will encourage all ROC officials stationed in the US to work out innovative strategies to help cement bilateral ties and expand cooperation in various fields.

In addition to reinforcing contacts with the US executive branch and Congress, Chen said he will also boost engagements with the academic, commercial, industrial and religious communities, as well as the major US think-tanks, media organizations and labor unions.

Noting that Taiwan's democratization is a major factor that has prompted the US to sell defensive arms to and develop friendly, substantive ties with Taiwan, Chen said he will strengthen contacts and communications with the US media in order to help more ordinary American citizens understand the ROC's efforts to promote democracy, freedom and human rights.

In the face of mainland China's incessant efforts to block and squeeze Taiwan's presence in the international community, Chen said he will uphold three principles: No retreat, no evasion and no concessions.

Earlier in the day, Huang Kun-hui, secretary general to President Lee Teng-hui, on Lee's behalf, conferred the Order of Propitious Clouds to Chen in recognition of his contribution to the nation and society during his service at the Presidential Office.
Chen, 63, will be the ROC's seventh representative to the US since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1979.

On Friday morning, Vice Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang presided over Chen's swearing-in, lauding Chen as an experienced, devoted and capable diplomat and adding that he is a suitable person to serve as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the US.
Chang also described current ROC-US relations as "strong, healthy and stable," but added that there is still ample room for further substantive growth in Taipei-Washington ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR SURGES

TEXT.P: The US dollar surged NT$0.982 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$29.50.
The greenback opened at 28.585 and experienced a high of 29.70.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$763.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH SOLOMON ISLANDS PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told visiting Solomon Islands Premier Bartholomew Ulufaalu on Friday that the Republic of China is willing to develop close relations with the Solomon Islands, as well as with other countries in the South Pacific.

President Lee spoke of the great progress the ROC has made in the economic and political fields, adding that the ROC wants to make a contribution to the international community by sharing its development experience with the developing countries and helping those nations with various construction projects.
He also expressed his appreciation for the South Pacific country's firm support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
Ulufaalu thanked Lee for the assistance Taiwan has provided to his country over the years. He also expressed his hope that relations between Taiwan and the Solomon Islands will be further enhanced.
Ulufaalu said that his country will continue to back up Taiwan's efforts to enter the United Nations, the South Pacific Forum and other international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISA RESTRICTIONS TO BE EASED

TEXT.P: Starting from November, foreign visitors will be issued visas allowing them to stay in Taiwan for up to 90 days, if their visits are for commercial purpose, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.

In line with the government's plan to turn the island into an Asia-Pacific regional operations center, as well as its efforts to join the World Trade Organization, the Foreign Ministry has decided to extend the stay of foreign visitors to Taiwan from the current 60 days to up to 90 days.
The only stipulation is that applicants must submit documents proving that their visits to Taiwan are to negotiate contracts with local enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SLIDE ON LOCAL BOURSE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan stock exchange continued to slide on Friday, with the weighted index, the key barometer of the local bourse, dropping by 165.66 points to close at 7,832.15.
The slide was the result of the recent persistent and heavy decline in electronics issues since Thursday, which has posed a serious threat to the government's currency defense policy.
A total of 22.5 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$13.71 billion (US$465 million). Losers outnumbered gainers 353 to 78, with 29 issues remaining unchanged.

The 10 most-heavily traded issues were: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; United Micro Electronics; Macronix International; China Steel; Mosel Vitelic Inc., A.S.E.; Acer; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Walsin Lihwa; and Compal Electronic.

Premier Vincent Siew called on the public to focus on the long-term development of the stock market. He expressed the belief that the packages announced by the Central Bank of China (CBC) and the Ministry of Finance Thursday will stimulate bullish behavior in the local bourse.

Siew made the remarks while answering questions from Kuomintang Legislator Chen Hung-chang on the CBC's measures to stabilize the New Taiwan dollar, which have provoked the continued plummet in the stock market.

Stressing that stabilizing the financial sector remains the government's top priority, Siew said the government will respect market mechanisms and will not intervene as long as the market performance remains normal.
He urged local stock market players, mostly individual investors, to have confidence in the government's prop-up measures and not to be influenced by speculation.

CBC Governor Y.D. Sheu also stressed that Taiwan's financial market is healthy and sound and that the local currency's exchange rate against the US dollar remains reasonable. He said the CBC's measures to defend the local currency have been effective and that some speculators have admitted their errors in speculating in the local foreign exchange market.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON GOVERNMENT'S DILEMMA ON MAINLAND POLICY

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Friday's edition of local English-language daily the China News.
Direct Links Create Policy Dilemma
As calls mount among Taiwan's high-powered business community to establish official cross-strait links, the government and President Lee Teng-hui have so far responded with nothing more than a shrug.
But their failure to react in a substantive way should not be seen as due to reticence or stubbornness. It is because they have no other choice.

The continuing ban on direct links is not just a government administrative policy. It is mandated by a binding directive passed in 1991 by the National Unification Council. Called the Guidelines for National Unification, the directive limits developing ties with (mainland) China to three very distinct phases, which are not meant to overlap each other.

The only way to legally initiate official cross-strait links is to annul the Guidelines for National Unification, which would essentially negate the sole reason for the existence of the National Unification Council.

This is obviously unacceptable to the government for a number of reasons, the foremost of which is that it would be tantamount to an admission of failure on the (mainland) China policy front. Such a move would also be seen in Beijing as yet another move by the president down his "splittist path." In addition, scrapping the Guidelines would leave the government with no long-term strategy for unification with (mainland) China...

Creating direct transportation, communication, and commercial links with (mainland) China is obviously a good idea, and indeed may be something that President Lee himself believes in. The dilemma isn't about whether he should, but rather whether he can afford to.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTIFICIAL PREGNANCIES MIGHT PREVENT BREAST CANCER

TEXT.P: Hormone treatment to give young women "artificial pregnancies" by mirroring changes to the breasts normally seen in expectant mothers may prevent breast cancer in high-risk women, a prominent Australian medical specialist has said.
Professor Allan Langlands of the Westmead Hospital in Sydney said such an approach may also help counter the increased breast cancer risk in women who delay childbirth.

Recent studies in Denmark and Canada show that survival rates are increased if radiotherapy is combined with chemotherapy after a mastectomy in premenopausal women with a high risk of recurrence, he said.
But it is not yet routinely offered to high-risk women, as its role in this group has previously been controversial, he noted.
Langlands said radiotherapy's role in breast cancer treatment had been undervalued and sidelined because of medical politics.
"A person has no chance of getting radiotherapy if the surgeon and medical oncologist don't offer it," he said.
Other experts said many women were not receiving radiotherapy after breast-conserving surgery despite long-standing recommendation for its use.
Langlands said Australian women were living in a breast cancer society partly because of the trend towards delayed childbirth and smaller families.
These factors, coupled with delayed menopause, early onset of puberty and less time breast feeding, were having a substantial impact on the rising incidence of breast cancer, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA: IN NEED OF SOME CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: Indonesia became the second Southeast Asian country after Thailand to bow down to an assault on its currency -- which has brought its value down by about 26 percent since August -- and ask for assistance from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

Only a few months ago, Indonesia seemed the least-likely among the regional economies to need the embarrassing assistance of the IMF. A conservative monetary policy, well-timed deregulation packages and high investment flows which financed the current account deficit made it the darling of western lenders, the WTO report said.
"Many observers are puzzled about the extent of withdrawal of confidence in the Indonesian economy," Dennis de Tray, country director for the World Bank in Jakarta, was quoted as saying.

The IMF and World Bank are likely to demand more specifics on budget cuts and banking reforms announced last month after the rupiah took a severe battering, and for less government support for wasteful projects and trading monopolies, many owned by relatives and associates of President Suharto.
"They need to give a signal to the world that this is a genuine effort and that no one will be spared," the banker was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGED NOT TO PUSH NORWAY, JAPAN TOO HARD ON WHALING

TEXT.P: Japan and Norway are likely to go their own ways if Australia pushes them too hard to control whaling at the international conference on whaling to be held in Monaco next week, according to the International Whaling Commission (IWC).
Dr. Ray Cambell of the commission told mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday that Norway and Japan could "go off on their own" and pull out of the IWC regime.

The future of the world's whales is under the spotlight in the tiny principality of Monaco, where officials from around the world will meet to map out a new global management regime at the IWC's 49th annual meeting.
Australia is expected to play a key role in the tussle between the whaling nations of Japan and Norway and more conservative-minded countries.

Australia's Environment Minister Robert Hill recently threatened to ban whaling and would propose what would amount to a moratorium on commercial whaling in the absence of enforceable international law.
Whaling would be allowed only within the 12 nautical mile territorial zone of each country and then only because it would be difficult for the world community to prevent it.
An IWC report has estimated that about 200 blue whales remain in the oceans of the southern Hemisphere and only 550 humpbacks in the western North Atlantic.

Under the current arrangements, Norway and Japan still send whaling fleets out under what they claim to be IWC rules, with Japan saying its whaling is for the purpose of scientific research only, although whale meat is still very popular in Tokyo sushi bars.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILLING TO HOLD DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said here on Thursday that his party is willing to accept an offer by Beijing to hold bilateral dialogue which he said should focus on peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

Hsu, who flew to Paris from Germany on Tuesday for a three-day visit, said that although the DPP will no longer openly propose Taiwan independence to avoid increasing the cross-strait tension, this doesn't necessarily mean that it has given up its call for Taiwan's eventual independence.

Sissy Chen, director of the DPP's Publicity Department, who accompanied Hsu on the trip, said that the DPP is willing to shelve the sensitive "sovereignty" issue and talk with Beijing on the establishment of postal, trade and transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China.

She also suggested that the proposed talks be held within the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), in which both Taiwan and the mainland are seeking admission, so as to further reduce the political sensitivity.

Commenting on Beijing's recent change in attitude toward the DPP immediately prior to a visit by mainland President Jiang Zemin to the United States on Oct. 26, Hsu said that it is because Beijing is trying to create a false impression in the international community that it is seeking peace across the Taiwan Strait so as to ease US concerns about the Taiwan issue. Beijing in the past has refused any contact with the DPP because of its pro-independence stance.
He described this as an indication that the Taiwan issue has attracted great concern from the world, a sure sign of the island's "internationalization."

In related news in Taipei, a ranking official with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said, however, that any negotiations with Beijing should be conducted by the government or its authorized agencies.

Hsu Ke-sheng, MAC vice chairman, said that although the government does not object to the opposition exchanging views with Beijing, it's impossible for any opposition party to talk with Beijing on the government's behalf.

Hsu stressed that the government's top priority for the moment is to resume the highest-level negotiations between the heads of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- the two intermediary bodies authorized by both sides to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.

SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan last met in Singapore in April, 1993 for historic talks, but Beijing unilaterally suspended a second round of talks scheduled for the summer of 1995, following President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States, which Beijing interpreted as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL MEETING ON TUNA HELD HERE

TEXT.P: A two-day international conference on tuna fishing opened here on Friday, with the participation of more than one hundred tuna experts from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and Indonesia, according to the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
The meeting, the ninth of its kind, will focus on seeking consensus on the management and development of the tuna fishing industry, the COA said.

Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and Indonesia are the four major tuna-fishing countries in Asia and the COA said all the four nations are highly concerned about the industry's future in the face of increased international restrictions on tuna fishing, in addition to several other factors currently plaguing the industry, such as a labor shortage, declining prices and pressure from global marine protection agencies.

Because of the likelihood of even greater pressure being exerted on the industry, the Taiwan tuna fishing sector has adopted concerted measures with neighboring countries to protect tuna resources and stabilize supply and demand and prices in the international market, the COA said.

Meanwhile, in response to international pressure on Taiwan to reduce the size of its long-line fishing fleet in a bid to protect fish stocks and maintain reasonable profits, the Taiwan Deep-Sea Tuna Fishing Industry Association said it will gradually replace the older tuna fishing boats among its more than 400 units, but insists on maintaining the current number of its long-line vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US TRADE TALKS IN THIRD DAY

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and the United States on Friday failed to reach agreement on the allocation of import quotas for rice in the third day of the current round of Taiwan-US trade talks on terms for Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The US side proposed that the allocation of quotas be conducted on a "first come, first served" basis, but Taiwan trade officials insisted on applying a bidding system to import quotas.

Taiwan agreed in earlier rounds of the trade talks that rice imports will be up to 4 percent of its annual consumption in the first year of WTO membership and that the percentage will increase gradually to 8 percent within six years.

Meanwhile, the officials also discussed the elimination of import tariffs on a variety of industrial products. According to a plan proposed by the Taiwan side, import tariffs on most general industrial products will be reduced to zero by 2002. Another list of 564 items, including beer, whisky, brandy, construction materials and medical items, will see tariffs eliminated by 2005, while import tariffs on 139 "sensitive" items, including cars, plywood and paper scrap will be reduced more gradually.

However, the two sides failed to reach consensus on these issues, with the US negotiators requesting that tariff reductions on the 564 items also be finalized by 2002 and that the list of 139 sensitive items be reduced.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES FACE MASKS TO INDONESIA

TEXT.P: On behalf of the government of the Republic of China, Dr. Pao-Sun Lu, representative of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Indonesia, on Friday donated a total of 100,000 face masks to the Indonesian government, while, Liu Shuang-Chuan, chairman of the Taiwan Business Club representing Taiwan investors in Indonesia, presented a cheque for 40 million rupiah for the purchase of 20,000 kg of rice, as a token of goodwill and friendship.
The donation ceremony was presided over by Coordinating Minister for People's Welfare Azwar Anas, in his capacity as Chairman of Indonesia's National Disaster Management Board.

"On behalf of the government of the Republic of Indonesia, I would like to take this opportunity to convey my heartfelt thanks and sincere appreciation for the social solidarity that has been shown by the Taiwan Business Club and the Taipei Economic and Trade Office," Anas said after receiving the donations.

Anas noted that the 100,000 masks are "extremely valuable," particularly at the present time, because of the haze enveloping a number of provinces in Sumatra and Kalimantan, while the rice will be sent to Irian Jaya to relieve the suffering being caused by a drought there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS TIME NOT RIPE FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The time is not ripe for opening direct cross-strait links, ROC Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday.

The premier told the legislature in an interpellation session that the government does not, and should not, have a time-frame for establishing direct transportation, communication and trade links with mainland China, adding that only if Beijing gives up its hostility toward Taipei, treats Taipei with due respect and negotiates with Taipei in a sensitive manner, will there be any possibility for these kinds of links.

Addressing legislators' concerns about the government's response to mounting calls from local business leaders for direct links with mainland China, Siew reiterated the government's stance -- that national security, dignity and the people's welfare should be taken into account when discussing the issue and that the major obstacles to this kind of contact are Beijing's refusal to accept Taiwan's existence as a sovereign political entity and its attempts to squeeze the island out of the international community.

In Beijing's view, the premier said, there is no clear distinction between politics and economics, which means that heavy economic reliance on the mainland will lead to the loss of the island's economic independence, which will threaten its security.
No country in the world, not even the US, preaches free trade without regard to its national security, said Siew, pointing out that the US is one of the most vocal supporters of free trade.

Commercial interests should not take precedence over political interests, especially while Beijing has not renounced the use of force against Taiwan. "We should be very cautious in our dealings with Beijing," said Siew.

Despite the lack of direct links, cross-strait trade is thriving anyway, said Siew, who once served as the head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the country's mainland China policy-making body. He promised to review the government's mainland policy and continue to weigh the possibility of negotiating with Beijing.

In a related development, the MAC said on Friday that the current policy toward the mainland of "be patient, no haste" will not change so long as Beijing fails to renounce its military threat against the island and does not accept Taiwan as an equal political entity.
Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the MAC, told a weekly press conference that the government's policy should juggle the interests of individual enterprises as well as those of the nation.

In a clear reference to one shipping tycoon's recent call for direct cross-strait links, Sheu said that the industrialists are entitled to air their personal opinions publicly, but the government should take the whole nation's interests into account before considering any change to the stated policy.

In defense of the off-shore transshipment center, established by the government to accommodate foreign ships sailing between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as a substitute for direct shipping links, Sheu said it has great potential and, if successful, will lead to the creation of a special economic and trade zone which will serve as a test-run for eventual direct shipping links with the mainland, said Sheu.

DOC.HEADLINE: `BE PATIENT, NO HASTE' POLICY CRITICALLY ESSENTIAL

TEXT.P: The government's exhortations to Taiwan's private sector to adhere to a policy of "be patient, no haste" in developing business in mainland China seems to have been misunderstood, an official involved with formulating Taipei's mainland Chinese policies said on Saturday.

Disregarding other critical factors, Taiwan's heavy reliance on economic and trade ties with the mainland alone can justify the exercise of restraint in dealings with mainland China, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

From a political point of view, he noted, Taiwan has no reason to free up restrictions curbing direct links with the mainland when Beijing still refuses to accept Taiwan's existence as a sovereign political entity and continues its never-ending attempts to squeeze the island out of the international community.

He said political considerations definitely play a decisive role in a nation's economic relations with any other area outside its borders, citing the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) countries' economic boycott of Warsaw Pact members, the US-led economic embargo against Beijing in the wake of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, and the US economic boycott of Cuba as examples.

Meanwhile, Dr. Chen Po-chih, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, urged the public to look at the figures to better understand the gravity of Taiwan's "risky reliance" on the mainland.

First, he said, Taiwan investments on the mainland have reached 2 percent of the island's GDP annually in recent years. That figure is the second-highest in the world, second only to Hong Kong's. By comparison, Japanese and American investments in mainland China stand at only 0.2 percent of their GDP, respectively.

Secondly, domestic investment takes up about 25 percent of Taiwan's annual GDP, while savings constitutes about 27 percent. As a result, the amount of money that Taiwan can safely spend on investments overseas is only about 2 percent, the professor pointed out.

Thirdly, Taiwan's exports to mainland China reached 25 percent of the island's entire export business in 1995, the highest proportion in the world. South Korea, which has the second-biggest proportion of exports going to the mainland, has a figure of only 16 percent, he noted.
Compared with most of the Southeast Asian countries, which put aside about 35 percent of their GDPs for domestic investment, Taiwan's home investment has been relatively low, he said.

Even more worrisome is that most of the out-bound Taiwan investment has been channeled into a single site -- mainland China. If the trend continues, he added, Taiwan's economic competitiveness in the world will surely be compromised to a grave level.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC URGED TO SET UP ASIA-PACIFIC FUND
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Economists from 13 Asia-Pacific countries have suggested that the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum set up an Asia-Pacific fund to ward off any possible financial crisis.

Fred Bergsten, a former head of APEC's Eminent Persons Group, said he and 12 other economists sent a joint letter to Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien in August pressing for the establishment of an international relief mechanism to maintain regional financial stability.

Bergsten, who now heads the International Economics Research Institute, a Washington-based think-tank, said the recent financial turmoil in Southeast Asia has caused much concern in the world financial community, prompting fears of a recurrence of the financial fiasco in Mexico a few years ago.

Bergsten said the letter didn't suggest how much money the proposed Asia-Pacific fund should have. "We think the amount should range between US$50 billion and US$100 billion," he said, adding that the larger the sum, the more effective it will be.
The Canadian government, which will host this year's APEC conferences, has not yet made a formal response to the proposal.
Bergsten said the realization of the proposal will require the full support of all the major Asia-Pacific countries, including Japan, the United States and Canada.

He said as the International Monetary Fund has limited resources to offer emergency loans to individual countries to help them stem a financial crisis, Asia-Pacific countries should establish a hedge fund in their own right to ensure their financial stability.
The proposal is expected to be discussed at the 1997 annual APEC ministerial-level conference and informal leadership meeting to be held in Vancouver in November.

APEC groups 18 economies, including Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, mainland China, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
