DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN VOWS TO CONTINUE PARTY DIPLOMACY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By M.J. Zhou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Friday that party-to-party contacts are most akin to government-to-government contacts and that he will continue to push for party diplomacy in the future.

Hsu made the remarks at the conclusion of a four-day visit to France which followed his attendance of an annual conference in Berlin of top leaders from democratic parties in major countries around the world.

His visits to the two European countries focused on observing the social welfare and education systems in those nations. During his French visit, he called at the headquarters of France's Socialist Party and visited several social, foreign and educational departments, as well as large French enterprises such as Dassault and Matra. Hsu's 15-member delegation also visited kindergarten education and children's protection institutions under the Paris city government.

Noting that French foreign officials said Taiwan should be encouraged in its push for pragmatic diplomacy to gain a greater profile in international community, Hsu said that France is happy to develop trade, technology, cultural and educational cooperation with Taiwan.

But he added that the officials also said that if Taiwan insists on developing formal diplomatic relations, France is afraid it will trigger a drastic reaction from mainland China, in which case, Taiwan cannot expect an advance, but may even see relations with France backpedal.

Describing this opinion as direct, Hsu said that most governments and peoples in Europe are friendly towards Taiwan and that if they did not have to worry about reactions from Beijing, they would already have accepted Taiwan as a full member of the international community in line with universally accepted norms.

In view of this situation, Hsu said that if Taiwan is to gain international support for its cause, it will have to increase contacts with the private sectors of other nations and step up international promotional campaigns.
He also said that Taiwan will have to consider the consequences of pushing for diplomatic activities and that it should avoid diplomatic confrontation that would be detrimental to Taiwan's security.
He stressed that both the DPP and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) are unanimous on major issues such as foreign relations and security in the Taiwan Strait that are crucial to Taiwan's best interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA TO SEND OFFICIALS TO SET UP FOUNDATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Gyado Thondup, brother of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, said on Saturday that the Secretariat of the Dalai Lama will send officials to Taiwan in mid-November to establish a Buddhist foundation.
Thondup said that the non-profit foundation will help strengthen religious and cultural exchanges between the people of Taiwan and Tibet.

The Dalai Lama's roving ambassador, who led a Tibetan delegation which attended the ROC's National Day celebrations on Oct. 10, made the remarks at press conference sponsored by the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.

The foundation's inauguration comes after months of coordination between the Buddhist Association here and the Dalai Lama's London Office, he said, adding that it was first initiated by the Dalai Lama after his visit to Taiwan on March 22-27 this year, when he decided that religious and cultural exchanges between Tibet and Taiwan should be enhanced.

Thondup said that those who will come to Taiwan to help establish the foundation will include one official from the London office of the Tibetan government-in-exile and another from the Dalai Lama's Secretariat who is fluent in Mandarin Chinese.

Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, said the commission will try to provide medical assistance for Tibetans in India who contract tuberculosis, a common complaint among those who flee from the high-altitude Tibetan plateau to the lowland Indian plains because of repression and persecution by mainland China.

Kao also said the commission will help Tibetan students who wish to come to Taiwan to study and receive vocational training. It will also study ways to invite Tibetan Buddhist monks to come here to preach, as well as conducting vocational training programs for Tibetans in India to help them find jobs there.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THINK-TANK WARNS AGAINST BOOMING CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: Warning that cross-strait trade with mainland China is booming again, a ruling party-organized think-tank urged the government to minimize the possible risks caused by overheating commercial activities with the mainland.

The Kuomintang (KMT) Mainland Studies Department pointed out in its official bi-weekly report that Beijing has followed calls made at the Chinese Communist Party's 15th National Congress for beefing up trade with Taiwan, using measures to attract Taiwan businessmen such as opening more sectors for Taiwan investment, raising the ratio of local sales to the total production by Taiwan-financed firms and lowering tariffs on raw materials imported by Taiwan investors.
As a result, the department said it anticipates another fever of mainland investment among the Taiwan business community which will bring mixed consequences for Taiwan's economy.

Although the thriving cross-strait trade could -- in the short term -- relieve Taiwan's heavy reliance on the US market, find an outlet for Taiwan's excessive capital and relocate the island's out-of-date industries to mainland China, thus upgrading the industries which remain, it would -- in the long term -- "hollow out" local industry, block the advancement of the island's industry, delay the achievement of Taiwan's goal of being a science\technology center, increase Taiwan's economic reliance on mainland China and thus give Beijing leverage to influence the island's politics, according to the report.

In order to avoid this unfavorable scenario, the department called on the government to carefully regulate the island's investment outflow to the mainland and cushion its negative impact on Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN BY 6 PERCENT THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Although it has lost its value by 6.81 percent so far this year, the New Taiwan dollar is still one of the least-devalued currencies of the four Asian newly-developed industrial countries, or "Asian tigers" said a senior official of the Central Bank of China (CBC) on Friday.

Compared with the South Korean won's devaluation of 7.65 percent and the 9.64 percent drop in the Singapore dollar, the NT dollar is the most steady among the four Asian tigers, with the exception of Hong Kong, which pegs its currency to the US dollar, said Liang Cheng-chin, deputy governor of the CBC, at a press conference.

In an attempt to calm panic on the financial market after the NT dollar took a plunge of 3.46 percent on Friday to 29.5 against the US greenback, Liang said the CBC gave up its defense of the value of NT dollar because of the significant changes on international financial markets, from which the Taiwan foreign exchange market cannot be excluded.
The CBC let the NT dollar drift on the market after having pumped more than US$5 billion into the market in two weeks in a desperate attempt to defend its value.
In response to criticism of the CBC's perceived policy flip-flop Liang urged the critics to save their breath until the impact of the CBC's measures takes effect.

As to the CBC's decision to lower reserve requirements for commercial banks twice in a single month, Hsu Chia-tung, another CBC deputy governor, said the moves were aimed at replenishing the market with more currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARSHER FIREARMS CONTROL STATUTES IN PLACE

TEXT.P: Both Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao and Interior Minister Yeh Chin-feng emphasized on Saturday that harsher penalties will help stop the rise in the number of gun-related crimes on Taiwan.
Liao said illegal firearms are posing an increasing threat to Taiwan's social order and that a crackdown on guns is now one of his top priorities.

Liao and Yeh spoke at the Legislative Yuan Saturday morning before a joint-committee plenary session. Shortly after their talk, the legislature passed revised firearms control statutes with unexpected speed.
The revised statutes stipulate that anyone who manufactures, sells or transports firearms, including guns and bombs, could face the death penalty plus a fine of up to NT$30 million (US$1.03 million).
Those who attempt to provide themselves or others with firearms to commit a crime could also face capital punishment and a fine of up to NT$50 million (US$1.72 million).

Anyone who -- without official authority -- modifies model or simulated guns into real firearms, or promotes and transports such modified guns, could face five years to life in prison plus a fine of up to NT$10 million (US$345,000), according to the new statutes.
Those who are found illegally manufacturing, selling or transporting ammunition could receive up to seven years in prison and a maximum fine of NT$5 million (US$172,000).
Taiwan's police seized 10,905 guns between January 1994 and June 1997 from underworld figures, Yeh said.

With their firepower becoming increasingly advanced and powerful, gangs have expanded their operations from illicit gambling, sex, smuggling and drug businesses to the rigging of public construction projects, and they are now openly challenging law-enforcement officers on the streets, Yeh noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CALLS FOR EARLY ESTABLISHMENT OF REGIONAL SECURITY MECHANISM

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday appealed for the early establishment of a regional security mechanism to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region.

Addressing the opening session of the ninth Asia Outlook seminar in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, Lee also expressed his hope that various forms of dialogue helpful to regional security will continue in the years ahead.

Lee said although mainland China's economic development has drawn much attention, its political reforms have made little progress. "Beijing's refusal to forsake its communist system and its incessant military buildups are major threats to regional security," the president pointed out.

On the other hand, Lee said, the Republic of China on Taiwan has become a full-fledged democracy following its first direct presidential election in March 1996. "The sharp contrast between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is an issue worthy of scrutiny when studying political development in East Asia," he said.

Although the world situation has gradually eased following the end of the Cold War, Lee said some disruptive factors still exist in East Asia, most notably the potential flash points of the Korean peninsula, the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea.

The president said, however, that one encouraging development is the fact that frosty cross-strait relations are gradually warming up through the ROC's constant calls for peace and its adoption of concrete goodwill measures.

"It is our earnest hope that constructive dialogue will be continued and a collective security system will be established in the near future to safeguard peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the West Pacific," Lee noted.

He went on to say that the Asia-Pacific security alliance has entered a new stage following the signing of new guidelines for defense cooperation between Japan and the United States in September. "We welcome this development as it is expected to have a positive impact on regional security and peace.

Lee also urged Japan to play a more active role in spurring regional economic development. "Except for Japan, most East Asian economies lack capital and technology," he said, adding: "Japan should use its economic leverage to assist other East Asian countries in upgrading their industrial and technological levels."
Speaking on the same occasion, C.F. Koo, leader of the ROC delegation to the seminar, said mainland China's development is the most critical variable in forecasting the future of East Asia.
Koo, a veteran business tycoon who also serves as Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, said he hopes communist Chinese leaders will honor their promise not to develop a military hegemony.

"It will contribute much to regional stability and prosperity if mainland China, following its recent economic reforms, can gradually develop a checks-and-balances power mechanism and ensure transparency in its policy-making process," noted Koo, who is also a senior adviser to President Lee.

Masao Kamei, a senior adviser to Sumitomo Electric Industries and leader of the 50-member Japanese delegation to the seminar, said the world is watching whether mainland China can honor its promise to maintain Hong Kong's capitalist system and lifestyle for 50 years following its takeover of the former British colony on July 1, 1997. "Mainland China's policy will determine whether Hong Kong can continue serving as a financial center and transshipment hub in Asia," he said.

Shirley Kuo, a former ROC finance minister and now minister without portfolio, said all Asia-Pacific countries should adopt a "soft" financial policy to facilitate the free flow of capital and boost regional economic development.

Addressing a lunch meeting, Premier Vincent Siew told all participants that Taiwan is located on an economic strategic point and stands a good chance to become an Asia-Pacific regional operations center and help nurture a new Asia-Pacific culture.
More than 150 international affairs experts, academics, business leaders and parliamentarians from Taiwan and Japan are taking part in the annual two-day seminar.

The Asia Outlook Forum, founded in 1989, is aimed at pooling the wisdom of the elite members of business, political and academic communities in Taiwan and Japan to help boost bilateral substantive ties as well as regional prosperity and stability. The forum holds its annual meeting alternately in Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US THINK-TANK URGES US TO MEDIATE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A US think-tank has suggested that the US government mediate between Taiwan and mainland China to help forge a new relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a leading Japanese paper reported here on Saturday.

Sankei Shimbun, in a dispatch from Washington, D.C., said that the Progressive Policy Institute (PPI), a Washington, D.C.-based think-tank, noted in a recent report that if relations between Taiwan and mainland China remain stalled, it will become an uncertain factor in Asia and will affect relations between Washington and Beijing.

The think-tank therefore suggested that the US government act to mediate between the two sides on the premise that Taiwan will forego complete independence and in exchange, mainland China will recognize Taiwan as an independent political entity and allow it to join the United Nations.

The think-tank also said that Taiwan has clearly rejected mainland China's "one country, two systems" formula, while Beijing's misgivings over Taiwan's alleged moves toward independence have also deepened. This is making the situation uncertain and might even be the cause of a potential flashpoint, threatening the overall situation in Asian stability and relations between the US and mainland China.

The PPI said that the Shanghai Communique signed in 1972 between Washington and Beijing, which deferred the question of Taiwan's ultimate stance indefinitely, and the Taiwan Relations Act signed in 1979 between Washington and Taipei, can no longer meet the needs of the current political situation. It is necessary for the US to forge new agreements with both sides of the Taiwan Strait, it suggested.

The PPI urged the US to induce Beijing to renounce its threat to use force against Taiwan, while persuading Taiwan not to announce independence. Under this premise, mainland China will recognize that Taiwan is an independent political entity under a tentative "one China" principle and will not oppose it joining the United Nations and related organizations.
In turn, Taiwan should work toward national unification under mutually agreed conditions form a long-term perspective, the PPI suggested.

The Shanghai Communique paved the way for then-US President Richard Nixon to visit mainland China and the eventual establishment of bilateral ties between Washington and Beijing, while the Taiwan Relations Act stipulates that the US should supply Taiwan with defensive weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH CEMETERY TO OPEN TO PUBLIC

TEXT.P: A nineteenth century French cemetery in Keelung, northern Taiwan, will be open to the public beginning Oct. 23, Keelung officials said Saturday.

The French Institute in Taiwan is turning the administration of the cemetery, which is the final resting place of some 700 French soldiers who were killed in Taiwan in the 1884 war between France and China, over to the city.

Some one square kilometer in size, the graveyard was established in 1885 and features a monument erected in honor of the French dead. Most of the names of those buried in the cemetery are no longer legible.
In 1884, during the Ching Dynasty, China went to war with France over French actions in Annam (current-day Vietnam), then a Chinese protectorate.

During the war, a French fleet attacked Taiwan and attempted to land on the island but lost many men in a battle with Ching troops. The French dead from that battle were laid to rest in the cemetery the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY OPEN OSTRICH FARMING

TEXT.P: Ostrich farming may be legally permitted in Taiwan soon after Taiwan's domestic investors gain sufficient know-how of this trade, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Saturday.

The government, however, will not lift the ban on live ostrich imports until potential investors thoroughly know the economic value of the artificially-bred ostrich, its market potential and the technology and management related to raising the birds, COA officials noted.
Taiwan has allowed imports of ostrich meat from the United States since early last year.

Since "ostrich fever" swept the island late last summer, some importers have been in contact with foreign suppliers, mostly in the United States and South Africa, over bringing live, artificially-bred ostriches into Taiwan.
Such imports, however, are not yet legal -- on the grounds that investors here still have little knowledge about this trade, the officials said.

To help the public gain more understanding of ostriches, the COA has contracted Professor Hsu Chen-chung of National Chunghsing University in Taichung to conduct a field trip to South Africa and Namibia to familiarize himself with ostrich farming and breeding technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL NOT COMPLICATE MARINE POLICE CASE: ARATS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China is studying the best way to handle the case of abducted marine policeman Chuang Chen-yao and will inform Taiwan once a decision has been reached, an official of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) said here on Saturday.

Zhang Shenglin, director of the ARATS Coordination Department who arrived here on Thursday to attend an award ceremony for a children's painting contest, said mainland authorities have no intention of further complicating the case.

Chuang, a Taiwan marine police officer, was abducted to the Fujian province port city of Fuzhou by mainland fishermen last Sunday while performing a search of a mainland fishing vessel caught operating illegally in Taiwan's territorial waters.

Professing a lack of knowledge of the details of the case, Zhang said she doesn't know how the mainland authorities will handle the issue, but pointed out that ARATS maintains regular contacts with its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and will inform it of any new developments.
Zhang said that as far as she knows, Chuang will be repatriated after mainland authorities have completed their investigation and after some related formalities have been taken care of.
She also said that the mainland authorities are well aware that Taiwan is very concerned about the outcome of the case.

According to Taiwan's initial investigation, Chuang was abducted when two Taiwan marine police patrol boats intercepted and boarded a mainland fishing vessel which had intruded into waters off the island of Matsu, which is controlled by Taiwan but located close to the mainland. Nine policemen who boarded the mainland fishing boat Ming Chang Yu 1448 were attacked by the mainland crew armed with knives, axes and bottles.

However, mainland authorities have a different account of the incident. The ARATS said in a letter sent to the SEF earlier this week that the mainland crew had accused Taiwan marine police of shooting at them while their boat was returning home and made no "suspicious" moves when intercepted and boarded by the police.

Meanwhile, Chairman Chang King-yuh of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said the government will explain the truth to mainland authorities through the SEF.
Chang said both sides of the Taiwan Strait should deal with the case strictly based on facts. "Only by so doing can the two sides develop peaceful, stable relations," he added.

In addition to the marine police case, Cahng said, there also are many cross-strait fishing disputes. "We hope the ARATS will resume consultations with the SEF as soon as possible on non-political administrative and technical issues arising from increasing civilian cross-strait exchanges."

Mainland China unilaterally suspended cross-strait dialogue after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark private visit to the United States in June 1995, which Beijing interpreted as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ DROPS TO 10-YEAR LOW AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national currency plunged again on Saturday to close at NT$29.76 against the US dollar amid expectations of further devaluation of the local currency.
The New Taiwan dollar lost NT$0.26 from Friday's finish of NT$29.5.

Saturday's finish was the lowest since November 1987. The local currency shed a total of NT$1.242 over the past two days, partly because the Central Bank of China (CBC) gave up its defense of the NT dollar's value.
The NT dollar opened weak at 29.65 against the greenback, and then fluctuated between 29.61 and 29.85 during the three-hour trading session.
Market turnover reached US$199 million aimd volatile trading.
Some currency dealers said the NT dollar is expected to fall further if the Central Bank of China (CBC) keeps its hand off the local foreign exchange market.

CBC Governor Sheu Yuan-dong said on Friday the central bank would "let market force determine the NT dollar's exchange rate" after having poured more than US$5 billion to shore up the local currency's value since the outbreak of the Southeast Asian currency crisis in July. But Sheu warned that the central bank may intervene again if speculation re-emerges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOURSE TUNMBLES AGAIN ON WALL STREET LOSSES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) tumbled again on Saturday as investor confidence was dampened by persistent drops on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).
The weighted Taiex index, the key baromter of the local bourse, shed 213.7 points, or 2.8 percent, to close at 7,618.45, the lowest in seven months. The loss followed a 165.66-point slide on Friday.
Market analysts attributed the substantial fall mainly to a loss of investor confidence in the electronics stocks, which have remained weak in recent days.
The poor performances of the NYSE and NASDAQ in recent weeks have also aggravated the bearish sentiment among local investors, the analysts noted.

More than 1.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.63 billion (US$2.72 billion) during the two-and-half-hour trading session. Losers outnumbered gainers 276 to 137, with 44 issues remaining unchanged.
Major blue-chip textile and paper stocks posted gains, while electronics issues suffered most drastic losses.

Market insiders said both institutional and individual stock investors had suffered tremendous losses as the local bourse shed 847 points, or 10 percent, over the week. It was the steepest weekly fall in three years.
Financial experts said the room for local share prices to fall further is limited.
Financial officials also reiterated that as the domestic economic fundamentals are sound and healthy, the local bourse will rally again in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN ENTREPRENEURS MEETING OPENS WEDNESDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 1997 East Asian Entrepreneurs Summit will open in Taipei on Oct. 22 with some 400 business leaders and scholars from at least 12 countries participating.

Topics of discussion at the annual meeting will include economic cooperation and investment opportunities in East Asian countries, as well as examples of successful business strategic alliances, technical cooperation, and technology transfer.

The meeting was held in Japan for the first time in 1990. Participants in Wednesday's meeting will come from Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Australia, the United States, India, Germany, mainland China, Israel, and Pakistan. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER NOT TO RAISE ELECTRICITY RATES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Power Company has no plan to raise electricity rates, although the recent devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar has push up the costs of power generation, Taipower General Manager C. H. Kuo said here Saturday.

The state-run power company relies heavily on imports of crude oil, coal, and other fuel for power generation. If the US dollar surges one New Taiwan dollar on the foreign exchange market, the company's cost of power generation will increase NT$1,450 million ( US$49.2 million), he said.
Taipower's current budget is based on the exchange rate of NT$27.5 to one US dollar. The US dollar rose to NT$29.76 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Saturday.
Kuo said Taipower is able to absorb the extra costs of fuel imports, because its surplus in the last fiscal year amounted to NY$30.4 billion. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDENCE IN TAIWAN STOCK MARKET TO RECOVER SOON

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Paul Chiu said Saturday that he believed investors' confidence in the Taiwan stock market would recover in just a couple of days.
The Taiwan Stocks Exchange weighted price index lost 213.7 points to close at 7,618.45 Saturday. The local bourse has lost 843.42 points, or about 10 percent, in a week.

Chiu said that Taiwan investors have apparently over-reacted in the stock market, and that their confidence should recover in a couple of days, because the financial and economic situation in Taiwan has returned to normal. There is no reason to be pessimistic about the stock market, he stressed.

He said the recent fluctuation in the stock market is attributable the persistent losses on the Wall Street and the financial crisis in Southeast Asian countries. Taiwan investors have over-reacted to the changes in the international financial situation, he added.
Meanwhile, Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang said Saturday that Taiwan's economy is "very healthy" this year. He made the remarks at college in Taipei county. (by Ed Shay)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CARS: TOO MANY MODELS, TOO FEW BUYERS

TEXT.P: Japanese auto dealers have tried just about everything to revive sales, but with Japan's economy on the skids, potential buyers aren't buying, BusinessWeek reported in its issue of Oct. 20.

In a special report entitled "Too Many Cars, Too Few Buyers," BusinessWeek said that despite a flurry of new launches, the April increase in Japan's consumption tax to 5 percent from 3 percent has caused car sales to decline for six months in a row.
Dealers sold 9 percent fewer cars in September than in the same month last year and several have now fallen into the red or gone bankrupt, it added.

So carmakers are desperately hoping their 1998 models will boost sales, the magazine said. The new lines of the Tokyo Motor Show in late October have the latest brake, engine, and transmission technology, more sporty designs and more environmentally friendly engines -- including a "hybrid" car that runs on a combination of gasoline and electricity.

But Japanese consumers are already overwhelmed with choices, BusinessWeek said. "There are over 190 car models available in the market," says Atsushi Fujii, member of the board of directors in charge of domestic sales at Nissan Motor Co. "And the average consumer can only remember about 11 of them."

Yet at the Motor Show, Japanese carmakers will be coming out with even more, according to BusinessWeek. Toyota wants to target young people with fun, European-looking models are a convertible sports car. It also plans to roll out the world's first mass-produced hybrid, with sales projected at 1,000 a month. Nissan, expected to unveil its own hybrid next year, will fight back with a 3-liter direct injection gasoline engine in its new Leopard luxury car. And Honda Motor Co. has already launched a hybrid counterattack with its own 1-liter, three-cylinder hybrid engine introduced in September.

"The competition in recreational vehicles is going to intensify," Enda Clarke, automotive analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson (Asia), says. And that's not the only place. With too many models chasing too few buyers, only the snazziest of cars will sell, he adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRADE MISSION TO VISIT TURKEY

TEXT.P: A Republic of China trade mission, representing 37 textile machinery, dye and fabrics manufacturers, will participate in trade fairs in Istanbul on Oct. 29-Nov. 2, said Peter Wen-Jung Huang, director of the Istanbul office of the Taiwan Trade Center, in a news conference on Friday.

The trade mission, organized by the Taiwan Foreign Trade Development Council, will also visit seven textile manufacturing centers in Turkey after participating in the TEXMAK '97 and TEXPO '97 trade fairs in Istanbul, Huang said.

The ROC is one of the world's leading manufacturers and exporters of textile machinery and fabrics, Huang said. "The textile industries of Turkey and the Republic of China do not compete with each other but complement each other," Huang told Turkish reporters.

Trade volume between the two countries in the first six months of 1997 stood at US$244 million, up six percent from last year. The ROC, the 15th-largest trading nation in the world, had a total trade volume of US$228 billion in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN BICYCLE MAKERS FEAR TAIWAN DUMPING

TEXT.P: Canadian bicycle makers are alleging that Taiwan and mainland China are dumping their bicycles in the Canadian market, a Canadian lawyer said on Thursday.

They want their government to continue imposing antidumping duties on imports from the two countries, fearing their industry will suffer if Ottawa fails to renew the duties, set to expire at year's end.
Without the duties, Canadian manufacturers will have trouble competing, the lawyer said.

"The Canadian industry has plodded its way back to profitability, but it's still in a very tenuous situation. If the massive dumping that occurred in the early '90s recurs, then they would definitely all be in a loss position and one or more would probably go bankrupt," the lawyer claimed.
Federal and Taiwan officials were not available for comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90,000 INDONESIANS FACING FOOD SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: At least 17 Indonesians from Irian Jaya who were believed to have perished in a forest fire, have been rescued, but 90,000 other locals still face severe food shortages and disease.
Health authorities now fear that cerebral malaria, which has apparently never occurred before in Irian Jaya, may become one of the biggest potential killers of those living in drought-affected areas.
Since relief efforts started on September 23, only 28 tons of rice have been distributed, while about 36 tons of food are needed every day, authorities said.
The authorities warned that the prolonged drought and freak storms are threatening Irian Jaya with famine within one or two months.
Malnutrition has already greatly weakened the people's resistance to illness and there have been several outbreaks of cholera, malaria and diarrhea.
Fires in Irian Jaya have already burned over 6,217 hectares of forest, shrouding the entire region in a thick choking haze.
The authorities said the number of victims will rise unless more intense relief efforts are made in the coming months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOYOTA LEXUS CARS RECALLED IN CANADA FOR WINTER SAFETY

TEXT.P: Toyota Canada has recalled 5,482 of its 1997 Lexus ES300 and Toyota Avalon and Camry passenger vehicles before the harsh winter season.

Under extremely low-temperature operating conditions, condensed moisture may freeze in the brake booster vacuum hose, affecting braking efficiency. Canadians often have to use their cars in temperatures of less than minus-20 degrees.
The cars are among the 232,846 vehicles which Transport Canada said have been recalled in Canada during the third quarter of 1997, bringing this year's total to 1,022,659.
A Transport Canada investigation influenced the recall by Suzuki Canada Inc. of 32,703 1989-94 Suzuki Swift passenger cars in areas of high road-salt use, east of the Manitoba-Ontario border.

Chrysler Canada also announced the recall of 17,000 1992-94 Mazda MX-3 vehicles located in the same area, while Polaris Industries Inc. has recalled 3,692 of its 1997-98 Polaris 600, 700, Ultra and XLT series snowmobiles for a possible steering problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S CHANGI AIRPORT VOTED TOP FOR 10TH YEAR

TEXT.P: For the 10th year in a row, Singapore's Changi Airport won the award as the world's most favorite airport by the London-based Business Traveler magazine.

The airport won an even greater share of the votes from more than 1,000 passengers in 47 countries, comfortably beating runners-up London Heathrow, Amsterdam Schiphol and London Gatwick, The Straits Times reported on Saturday in a dispatch from London.

The airport was also voted tops for personal safety and luggage retrieval, but came in second to Heathrow for customs clearance, passport control and incoming passenger clearance. It was third for duty-free shopping, behind Heathrow and Schiphol.
Singapore was also announced the runner-up -- by only five votes -- to London, in the favorite business city category of the award. Hong Kong was third and New York, fourth.
Singapore Airlines (SIA) was also voted among the favorites. Overall, the winner was British Airways, also for the 10th year running, with SIA second and Virgin, third.

All 10 of the best business hotels in the world were in the Asia-Pacific region, and once again, Singapore was near the top, with the Shangri-La, Singapore coming in third. First place went to the Oriental Hotel in Bangkok, while the Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong was voted second.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAZE IN INDONESIA WORSENS

TEXT.P: The haze in Indonesia has worsened, reducing visibility and affecting wildlife, reports said Friday.
Indonesia's Environmental Impact Management Agency said visibility was only about 100 meters -- considered almost zero visibility -- in several districts.

The Antara news agency reported Friday that 16,112 people in West Sumatra had been afflicted by severe respiratory infections, and 68 others had fainted in the choking haze in the province's capital of Padang.
Rasidah Rasyid, the head of the provincial health office, said the province had received 150,000 respiratory masks, not nearly enough for the province's 4.3 million people.
Parts of the capital of Jakarta were shrouded by thick haze on Friday, but an official said this was the result of pollutants rather than smoke from the forest fires.
Antara also reported that a fire that has destroyed 35 hectares of a state-owned timber estate in Banten, West Java was threatening the lives of protected local buffalo.
"The buffaloes went through our village and they looked vicious. There were dozens of them," said Cisukut villager Tarmin, who reported the case to the Ujung Kulon National Park authorities Friday.
Fires have also been affecting wildlife in East Kalimantan.
The news agency reported that fire had razed up to 30,000 hectares of forest in East Kalimantan, including 300 hectares of the 200,000-hectare Kutai National Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE VICTIMS FOUND AT INDONESIAN CRASH SITE

TEXT.P: Rescue workers have found the remains of three more victims of the Garuda Indonesia plane which crashed last month in northern Sumatra, near the city of Medan, Antara news agency reported on Friday.
A rescue team searching for the missing flight data recorder found the remains of two women and a man in a small village near the crash site, Antara reported.
After working for 20 days, the search and rescue team has yet to find the missing flight data recorder, known as the black box.
The crash took place on Sept. 26 as the plane was approaching Polonia Airport in Medan, killing all on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS IN INDONESIA THREATENED WITH STARVATION

TEXT.P: Villagers living in the remote interior of famine-stricken Jayawijaya regency in Irian Jaya, Indonesia are in urgent need of food, the head of the regency said.
"They are practically in an SOS condition and need all the help they can get," the Antara news agency quoted Wenas as saying on Friday.

Unless food and other daily necessities are sent soon, some 90,000 people living in the interior may suffer more and even starve, as their crops have been eradicated by the long dry spell and bush fires, he said, noting that the thick haze has made it increasingly difficult to send food to the villagers.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Health has sent doctors and paramedics along with a donation of Rp 100 million (US$28,600) and medicines to the remote and hunger-stricken villages in Jayawijaya regency, Irian Jaya.
The help is being flown to the remote places by Hercules aircraft and helicopters, Health Minister Sujudi told a congress of the Family Doctors Association in Jakarta on Friday.
Reliable sources said some 500 villagers in Jayawijaya regency have already died of hunger.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN MEDIA REPORT LESS ON ASIA THAN ASIAN MEDIA ON EUROPE

TEXT.P: European media do substantially less reporting about events in Asia than Asian media do about events in Europe, according to a new study commissioned by the Singapore-based Asia-Europe Foundation (Asef).

The four-month study, carried out by the Asian Media Information and Communication Center (Amic), examined how 15 Asian and 15 European newspapers and magazines reported events in the other region over a 10-day period from June 27 to July 6.
The period was deliberately chosen as it covered a major world news event for the year -- the handover of Hong Kong from Britain to mainland China on July 1.
Besides the main finding that the media in Asia carried more news on Europe than vice versa, the study showed that coverage of European events by Asian publications was more extensive.
Of the total of 3,725 news items studied, the European media carried only 749 reports on Asian events, despite a world event like the Hong Kong handover.

Another interesting finding was that while Asian publications generally tended to be neutral in their reporting of European events, there were more instances of negative reports about Asian events in the European media.

One explanation for this is the reliance of Asian publications on Western agencies, such as Reuters and Agence France Presse (AFP), for their coverage of Europe. Such agency reports tend to be neutral.
But more than half of the stories in the European media were obtained from their own correspondents and tended to be more opinionated and carry more personal viewpoints.
The study also found that Asian publications concentrated on Europe's sports and recreation stories, followed by economic, financial and business stories.
European publications, however, focused primarily on economic, business and finance stories about Asia.
Asef was established by members of the Asia-Europe Meeting (Asem) in February this year with the aim of engaging the civil societies of the two regions.

Commenting on the two regions' lopsided treatment of news about each other, Asef executive director Professor Tommy Koh said Friday: "The survey findings coincide with the historical perspective of Asian countries, which feel that Europe is important to them. But 10 years from now, there will be more balanced reporting by the two regions of each other."
The study will provide the focus for a dialogue on media understanding and cooperation by 40 editors from the two regions in Luxembourg next week, according to The Straits Times.
The meeting will examine the role of the media in promoting better understanding between the peoples of Asia and Europe.
Some of the other findings of the study:

-- European news that received prominence in Asia were the Wimbledon tennis tournament, the British royal family, the Mir space-station accident and expansion plans for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

-- Asian events that were well reported in European publications were the Hong Kong handover, Taiwan issue, beheading of a Japanese boy by a youngster, devaluation of the Thai baht and the Cambodian political crisis.
-- Few or no examples of a comprehensive Asian perspective were found in the European publications studied.
-- Asian publications had most of their European stories filed from London. European publications received most of their Asian stories from Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: REUTERS IS ASIA'S MAIN SOURCE FOR REPORTS ON EUROPE

TEXT.P: Reuters news agency is the main source of news for Asian publications that report on European events, according to a study by the Singapore-based Asia-Europe Foundation.

The number of stories from Europe by Asian news agencies such as Kyodo, Jiji Press, Xinhua news agency, Press Trust of India and Bernama (the Malaysian news agency) is relatively small, the study showed.

Meanwhile, the study also showed that Russian President Boris Yeltsin barely pipped the world's top woman tennis player Martina Hingis as the European personality most often mentioned in Asian publications.
Yeltsin was mentioned 33 times during the period covered by the survey -- from June 27 to July 6 -- on how the Asian and European media reported events and developments in the other region.
Apart from these, former Albanian President Sali Berisha and British Premier Tony Blair also received their fair share of publicity in Asia.
On the other hand, the top personality in Asia most frequently mentioned is hardly Asian at all -- former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten.
He was followed by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee Hwa.
The fact that these three topped the list is not surprising, considering that the Hong Kong handover was one of the top events in Asia for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC LEAGUE FOR FREEDOM AND DEMOCRACY MEETS IN MELBOURNE

TEXT.P: Dr. Chao Tze-chi, president of the World League for Freedom and Democracy, on Saturday urged all countries in the Asia-Pacific region to enhance security and economic cooperation in order to increase the well-being of all the people in the region and to usher in an age of peace and prosperity.

In a keynote speech Saturday at the opening in Melbourne of the 43rd Asia-Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy meeting, Chao said maintaining security and peace is very important for the countries and people in the region.

In his opening speech, Bob Halverson, speaker of the Australian parliament, said the countries in the Asia-Pacific region have to take active steps to further their economic cooperation so that they can make the area prosperous and peaceful.
He particularly urged all people in the region to promote human rights and eliminate racial discrimination.
More than 70 delegates from 17 countries are attending the two-day meeting in Melbourne.
The Taiwan delegation includes Lo Teh-ching, Chang Tsun-hung, Lin Yu-fang and Chen Yi-hsin, all of whom are legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASED M'LAND UNEMPLOYMENT SEEN AS THREAT TO GROWTH, STABILITY

TEXT.P: The surge in unemployment in mainland China's industrial heartlands is emerging as a dangerous threat to the economic growth and social stability in mainland China as the government there prepares to launch belated reforms of its "backbone" industries, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily's correspondent David Lague reported Saturday that the mainland Chinese government is "unable to nourish its sprawling and hopelessly inefficient state-owned sector."
The factories in Heilongjiang Province are starved of funds and millions of workers are unemployment or unpaid, the daily reported.
"They are all waiting for someone to feed them. In the past, the government could be relied on to supply food, but in the future it won't," a mainland businessman told the daily.
The daily said the industries which were once the backbone of mainland China's planned economy have been left languishing since market reforms began in the late 1970s.

About 100 million people were employed in more than 300,000 state-owned enterprises in mainland China, but Beijing has no choice but to cut many of them loose or risk drowning the entire economy in an ocean of red ink, the daily reported.

Many of these debt-ridden enterprises had already collapsed before the central authorities announced they would tackle state-sector reforms at last month's 15th Party Congress in Beijing, according to the Herald.

Estimates of the total number of urban unemployed or unpaid vary widely, but most analysts believe tens of millions of industrial jobs have disappeared and that this problem is certain to get worse, the daily reported.

The vice governor of Heilongjiang recently told the official China Daily newspaper that his province's state-owned industries had once employed more than eight million workers but that now 20 percent of these are unemployed and 30 percent of the remainder are under-employed.

But the Herald quoted a taxi driver in Heilongjiang's capital of Harbin as saying that the official estimates were conservative. "About 80 percent of workers from state-owned industries are unemployed or unpaid," the driver said.
"Almost every family has someone who has been laid off. I don't know how people survive," he said.

The Australian daily reported there were no obvious signs of unrest or tension in Harbin this week as people enjoyed the few remaining warm days before the onset of the traditionally cruel winter but that an oppressive security presence is a signal the authorities are taking no chances. On every street there were security police or the paramilitary People's Armed Police and plain-clothes officers mingling with the crowds, locals told the daily.

There have been reports of worker delegations protesting at factory offices and local government buildings, but the driver said local people had so far been giving the government time to solve the problem.
"Northeast people are famous for their passive attitude, but this won't last long. People can't live like this," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC NOT TO ADJUST GASOLINE PRICES IN NEAR FUTURE

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Company (CPC) will not adjust the prices of gasoline and other oil products in the near future, although the cost of oil imports has increased substantially due to sharp devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar in recent days.

A spokesman for the state-run oil company said Saturday that CPC depends on imports for most of its oil supply. Its import cost will increase NT$6,000 million (US$200.3 million) per year, if the US dollar surges one New Taiwan dollar in the foreign exchange market.

The US dollar has surged NT$1.242 in the past two days in the Taiwan foreign exchange market to close at NT$29.76 Saturday. The sharp devaluation of the Taiwan currency has generated a heavy pressure on the CPC to increase the prices of gasoline and other oil products, the spokesman said.
However, the CPC is able to absorb the extra cost of oil imports for the time being, because the company had a surplus in the first three months of this fiscal year, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TO BE HARD HIT BY DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: Hong Kong will lose about 90 percent of its transshipment cargo if Taiwan and mainland China open direct trade, the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Sunday.

The CEPD, citing a report made by the Hong Kong Economic Research Center, said that the port city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, with comparative advantages over several mainland Chinese ports, will be the biggest threat to Hong Kong's position as the region's major transshipment hub.
The CEPD also pointed out that Hong Kong will lose about 90 percent of the transshipment business across the Taiwan Strait if Taiwan and mainland China are allowed to conduct direct trade.
Hong Kong currently is the largest cross-strait entrepot in the absence of direct trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Although mainland Chinese ports such as Shanghai, Ningpo, Yientien, and Sheke have been re-emerging in recent years, the CEPD said Kaohsiung poses the biggest threat to Hong Kong in vying for transshipment cargo in the region due to its central location in Southeast Asia and its advanced world-class facilities.
However, Kaohsiung is less competitive than Hong Kong due to red tape and the lack of direct trade with the mainland, the CEPD noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU LAUDS SUCCESSOR AS CAPABLE DIPLOMAT

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China Representative to the United States Jason Hu on Saturday praised his successor Stephen Chen as a devoted and capable diplomat, saying that he is confident of Chen's ability to help strengthen ROC-US ties.

Hu left Washington, DC to return to Taipei for his new assignment Saturday morning with over 100 members of the Chinese community, Chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan Richard Bush and other ROC and US officials seeing him off at the airport.
Hu, the sixth representative to the US since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1979, will replace John Chang in taking over the top post at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

While expressing appreciation for the support the Chinese community has extended to him over the past 15 months, Hu also called for the overseas Chinese in the US to continue their cooperation with the new de facto ROC ambassador to the United States and to help promote friendly bilateral ties between the two countries.

Bush, when asked for his comments, said that Chen is a distinguished diplomat, who has served in the United States on four previous occasions, including a tenure as the ROC deputy representative there between 1989 and 1993. He said he looks forward to cooperating with Chen to create a close and productive relationship.

Bush also reiterated that the summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin scheduled for Oct. 29 will not hurt the interests of Taiwan, adding that he believes improvements in Washington-Beijing relations will not cause any problems for Washington-Taipei ties.

Chen, 63, arrived in Washington, DC on Saturday afternoon. He held a news conference in Twin Oaks compound, the former ROC embassy in the US, to meet with the local Chinese-language press shortly after his arrival. On Monday, he is scheduled to visit the American Institute in Taiwan and meet with Richard Bush.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEGO'S PUBLIC FUNERAL HELD

TEXT.P: The public funeral of Wego Chiang, the second son of the late Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, was held on Sunday at the Veterans General Hospital.

About one hundred ranking government officials, including Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, senior presidential advisor Lee Huan, Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, and Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, were present.

President Lee Teng-hui awarded several citations in recognition of Wego's outstanding contribution to this nation and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT). His coffin was draped with the national flag of the Republic of China and the party flag of the KMT.
Wego was later buried at the ROC Veterans Public Cemetery in Taipei County.
Wego, who had served as senior presidential advisor, National Security Council secretary general and in other high-level posts, was pronounced dead on Sept. 22 from multiple organ failure. He was 81.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRETIEN TALKS BUSINESS IN MOSCOW

TEXT.P: Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien arrived in Moscow on Sunday and spent most of the day at Russian President Boris Yeltsin's hunting lodge outside the city.

The two leaders are expected to discuss, among other things, the global ban on land mines. Canada hopes Russia will sign a Canada-led international treaty banning the use of anti-personnel land mines in December.
It is Chretien's first state visit to Russia. "This visit is overall ... a political visit," said a senior Canadian government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"However, when you look at the essence of our relations, a good part of it is to build up our economic relationship, our business relationship," the official noted.

Russia is recognized as one of the world's major developing marketplaces and Canadian companies are well established there in such sectors as mining, oil and gas production and environmental services.

But Russia is a difficult -- and sometimes dangerous -- place to do business. Organized crime has flourished since the fall of the Communist order. And foreign investors cannot count on the authorities to enforce the rules.

One of the biggest Canadian investors in Russia, the IMP Group of Halifax, has endured a campaign of police intimidation and official harassment since it rejected its Russian partners' bid to buy out its share of the Aerostar Hotel in Moscow.
When the company tried to collect C$4.9 million in damages awarded by Russia's Supreme Court recently, the Russian prosecutor-general blocked the enforcement of the decision.
The Canadian Embassy in Moscow has even had to step in to ensure the safety of company officials when they visit Moscow.
Chretien will ask Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin to try to find ways to deal with the Aerostar problem when they meet on Monday.

On Monday, Chretien will also meet with Canadian businessmen in Russia. Canadian investment in Russia totals about C$400 million, and the parties are looking to boost that figure. Bilateral trade was nearly double that amount in 1996.
Chretien's European trip will last 10 days, as he moves on to London and finally Edinburgh for a meeting of Commonwealth leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING AND THE WTO

TEXT.P: Communist China's hint this week that it may be ready to cut some of its highest tariffs in order to gain entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) is a welcome sign that it is finally waking up to the requirements of WTO membership.

But Sir Leon Brittan, European Union (EU) trade commissioner, was overly optimistic in calling the move a breakthrough which could usher in the last lap of Communist China's decade-old accession talks. More likely, that process "is just nearing the end of the beginning," according to an European newspaper.

The Financial Times said in an editorial that progress has been long stalled by Communist China's high-handed insistence that WTO membership was a political status symbol, to which it was entitled by right. Only recently does Beijing seem to have grasped that the organization is based on detailed and forcible rules and disciplines. However, formidable resistance from domestic lobbies continues to thwart efforts to open market wider.

Beijing deserves some sympathy. The West is pressing it for bigger concessions on WTO entry than most poorer members have been required to make. Not only do the United States and the EU want Communist China to cut average tariffs below those found in most developing countries; many of their demands, notably in services, extend far beyond the barriers of national borders into sensitive areas of domestic policy.

Nonetheless, Communist China's willingness to liberalize still falls far short of what is needed. Joining the WTO without pledging to lower its trade barriers would frustrate the central purpose of the exercise -- speeding the country's integration into the global economy. It could also deprive Communist China of a principal membership benefit by giving the United States and the EU political arguments for refusing to guarantee it non-discriminatory trade treatment after entry.

A still larger concern centers on Communist China's readiness to respect WTO rules. Unless it does so, its liberalization pledges will be worthless, and its membership disruptive. However, sincere Beijing's commitments, its capacity to deliver is unclear. Communist China's domestic market is far from unified and its legal system rudimentary. Beijing's ability to impose its will is in question, and is being tested further by the upheavals associated with economic reform, the Financial Times pointed out.

These problems and uncertainties do not argue for keeping Communist China out of the WTO. Nor should Beijing's frustration tempt it to walk away from the talks. That would risk scaring foreign investors, on whom Communist China's growth and exports depend, over fears that it was abandoning economic reform. Rather, a more creative approach is needed, the Financial Times said.

The aim should be a clear timetable for phased opening of Communist China's market after WTO entry. Communist China should make ambitious liberalization commitments, while being allowed reasonable time to adjust. The arrangement should be enforceable through the WTO disputes mechanism, carrying the threat of trade retaliation if Beijing ignored its obligations, the European economic daily newspaper said.

Such a compact would require Beijing first to provide more concrete evidence that it is willing to accelerate liberalization and is fully committed to core WTO disciplines. At the least, the United States and the EU should offer to grant Communist China the full rights and privileges of WTO membership on entry.

A political leap of faith is also needed. This month's summit between Presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin offers an ideal opportunity to make it. Both leaders should use the occasion to launch an initiative to reinvigorate the negotiations. It is also essential that Clinton demonstrate that the United States genuinely wants Communist China in the WTO by doing more to build bipartisan support in Congress, the Financial Times said.

"In any circumstances, (Communist) China's WTO entry will be a political gamble, for Beijing and the rest of the world. But its chances of success will be improve if it is made on realistic terms which all the players have confidence will be honored," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN UK BIDS FAREWELL
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Eugene Y.H. Chien, outgoing Republic of China representative in the United Kingdom, has called on the local Chinese community to continue supporting both the Taipei Representative Office here and his successor.

Chien, who will soon return to Taiwan to serve as an advisor to the National Security Council, made the call in a letter issued recently to the local Chinese community. He also expressed his appreciation to ROC nationals residing in the United Kingdom for their support and assistance during the past four and a half years.

"Because of Taiwan's increased economic clout and its remarkable progress in democratization, the ROC's image and status in the UK has been significantly upgraded, helping the two countries develop a bilateral comprehensive and across-the-board relationship," Chien said in the letter.

During his tenure here, two-way Taiwan-UK trade has jumped by 66 percent to US$5 billion annually, while the number of Taiwan students studying here also grew to about 13,000 from nearly 10,000 previously, according to the letter.

During the same period, 15 ministerial or vice-ministerial UK officials and 49 of their ROC counterparts exchanged visits. About 54,000 UK nationals have traveled to Taiwan, while 44 Taiwan firms launched investment projects in this European country, it pointed out.

Chien attributed all the progress in bilateral ties to the support of the ROC nationals residing here and the efforts made by the personnel of the Taipei Representative Office in the UK. He also thanked the UK government for adopting a more pragmatic approach in its dealings with Taiwan, which he said "has benefited the people of both countries."
He also called for continued support from the local Chinese community for the representative office and his successor, whose appointment will be announced soon by the ROC government.
Chien announced his departure on Oct. 6. The local Chinese community will hold a farewell party for him on Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S RETAIL SALES FALL 10.8% IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Singapore's retail sales in August fell by 10.8 percent from July, but remained at the same level as August last year, the Singapore Department of Statistics said Sunday.
The total retail sales value in August was estimated at S$2,021 million (about US$1,347 million), down from the July total of S$2,266 million, figures released by the department show.
Singapore's catering trade in August rose marginally by 0.6 percent over the previous month and 3.3 percent over August 1996, the department said.
The total value of catering trade in August was estimated at S$248 million, compared with S$246 million in July.

According to the statistics, all retail sales, except general provision and sundry shops, declined in August from the previous month: textiles, wearing apparel and personal effects (-21.4 percent), furniture and household equipment (-14.0 percent), motor vehicles (-9.3 percent), department stores and supermarkets (-9.2 percent) and petrol service stations (-2.7 percent).
General provision and sundry shops reported a rise of 1.8 percent in turnover in August over July.

Compared to August 1996, the overall retail sales index in August this year remained unchanged. The corresponding index at constant prices expanded by 2.8 percent, according to the Department of Statistics.
The catering trade, fast-food outlets and other catering establishments registered higher turnover of 3.5 percent and 0.4 percent respectively. Restaurants collected lower receipts of 0.8 percent.
Compared to August last year, catering trade in August 1997 increased by 3.3 percent. At constant prices, the index expanded by 1.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO US URGES SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Pan Ying-chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Representative to the United States Stephen Chen on Saturday asked the overseas Chinese community in the United States to have confidence in the ROC, saying that it is a free and democratic country, in sharp contrast to mainland China.
Chen made the remarks in his first press conference with local Chinese-language media at the ROC's Twin Oaks diplomatic compound shortly after his arrival in Washington, DC earlier in the day.

Chen noted that following the first popular presidential election in Taiwan last March, the American think tank Freedom House for the first time listed the ROC as a "totally free" country, while mainland China was rated "not free."

Asked to describe his feelings on taking up the new post, Chen said he feels it is a difficult task, but that he is willing to accept any challenge and do his utmost to help cement bilateral ties between the two countries and expand cooperation in various fields.

Chen's initial test will come in the first weeks of his new job, as mainland China's President Jiang Zemin will arrive in the United States on Oct. 26 for a state visit and hold a summit meeting with his counterpart President Bill Clinton on Oct. 29.

The US government has assured Taipei on several occasions that the Washington-Beijing engagement will not harm the interests of Taiwan, Chen said, adding that the ROC government has no intention of souring the summit atmosphere, and even would like to see the meeting prove successful.
The ROC's consistent hope is that Taipei-Washington relations will develop parallel to links between Washington and Beijing.

Chen cited reports that a 20-member delegation, headed by mainland China's State Planning Commission Vice Minister Zeng Peiyan, will arrive in the US prior to Jiang's visit to purchase aerospace products, cars, energy resources and chemical fertilizer, the total value of which could reach billions of US dollars.

In addition, Jiang will reportedly announce at the summit meeting plans to place orders for commercial airplanes manufactured by Boeing worth some US$2 billion. Those high-profile purchases will give Americans the impression that mainland China is an important market for US goods and a source of many job opportunities for the American people, Chen said.

In fact, Chen said, the mainland has to date imported only 32 aircraft made by Boeing, while China Airlines and EVA Air in Taiwan have purchased 38 planes from the American manufacturer. The ROC imported some US$18.41 billion worth of goods from the US in 1996, 50 percent more than did mainland China, making Taiwan the third largest buyer in Asia after Japan and South Korea.

Chen noted that the ROC should make more efforts to let Americans gain a better understanding of the close trade and economic relations between Taiwan and the United States as a way to win greater support among Americans.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS CONTINUE TO INCREASE

TEXT.P: The total value of orders placed with Taiwan manufacturers by foreign buyers might exceed US$10 billion in September, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Sunday.

He said the statistics being compiled by the MOEA indicate that Taiwan manufacturers received more export orders in September than in August, and that the demand for Taiwan electronics, information, and communications products in the world market remain strong.
Taiwan manufacturers received US$10.2 billion worth of export orders in August. They have received more than US$10 billion worth of export orders each month since March.

The official declined to predict whether the recent devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar may effectively boost Taiwan's export trade. The US dollar surged continuously in the past few days in the Taiwan foreign exchange market to close at NT$29.76 Saturday, which is a 10-year high.

He said it is hard to predict at the present time the effect of currency devaluation on Taiwan's export trade, because the currencies of many other countries have devaluated much more steeply than the New Taiwan dollar in recent weeks. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR SINGER IN GRAVE CONDITION AFTER CAR ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Popular singer and music producer Chang Yu-sheng is in grave condition after a car accident in suburban Taipei, police said Monday morning.

Police said Chang was driving alone in a Saab-900 sports convertible along the coastal Hsiping highway between Tamsui and Shanchih when he struck a light pole in the center median of the road. The concrete base of the light pole was completely destroyed due to the force of the impact.
Police are still investigating the cause of the accident.
Chang was found by passersby at 2:45 a.m., and was sent to the nearby Mackay Memorial Hospital.
Doctors said Chang suffered serious chest and head injuries. He showed no life symptoms upon arrival and remains in a coma after emergency treatment.
Chang, 32, is known for his high-pitched voice and vibrant songs, including hits such as "My Future is Not a Dream," "Big Sea" and "Take Me to the Moon."
His singing career had been in decline in recent years and he had shifted his energies to production and composing. He recently produced an album for another popular singer, Chang Huei-mei.
