DOC.HEADLINE: 853 MAINLAND INVESTMENT PROJECTS REGISTERED WITH GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: A total of 853 illegal investment projects worth US$3.7 billion made by Taiwan companies in mainland China were registered with the government prior to a Sept. 30 amnesty deadline, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Monday.

The Investment Commission under the MOEA said the figure represents a noticeable jump from the 806 cases worth US$2 billion which surfaced in 1994, when the government issued a similar amnesty, allowing local companies to register their illegal mainland investment projects without penalty.

In line with its policy aimed at cooling the mainland investment fever among Taiwan businesses, the MOEA issued the call again earlier this year, demanding that those companies which have launched operations on the mainland without government permission fall into compliance with new regulations promulgated on July 15.
Those who fail to register will be continuously subject to fines of up to NT$5 million until they withdraw the illegal investments, MOEA officials said.

According to the officials, the Investment Commission has compiled a list of about 700 local firms with illegal operations in mainland China and it will continue to screen the list in an effort to punish those who evade ROC regulations.

Taiwan still maintains a ban on direct investment by local firms in mainland China. Those enterprises which wish to launch operations there through branches or affiliates in third areas must first receive government permission.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER RETURNS TO WORK

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling has returned to work after Premier Vincent Siew formally rejected his resignation on Friday, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Monday.
"Minister Chiang resumed work on Saturday," the ministry said in a press release.

The 75-year-old three-star general offered to resign on Oct. 11 to take responsibility for the crash of an Air Force C-130H transport plane at Taipei's Sungshan Airport on the ROC's Double Tenth National Day.
Both President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Siew strongly urged Chiang to stay on for the country's overall interests.
Siew later gave Chiang a two-week leave for him to reconsider his resignation bid.
On Friday, the premier returned Chiang's resignation letter to which Siew attached a note saying he disapproved Chiang's request to step down.
An MND spokesman said although Chiang's two-week leave has not expired, the minister already returned to work on Saturday in consideration of the ministry's heavy workload.

Chiang had served as Army commander-in-chief, the vice chief of the General Staff, the personal chief-of-staff to President Lee Teng-hui and national policy adviser before assuming his current post in late 1994.

Military observers said it will be difficult for the government to find a suitable replacement for Chiang at the moment. His departure would affect plans to trim military personnel, which call for the retirement of a number of general- and colonel-level officers over the next few years, the observers said, adding that few persons in the military other than Chiang have both the reputation and senior status needed to successfully oversee implementation of the sensitive personnel reduction programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHOU CHUANG QUITS NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: New Party Legislator Chou Chuang on Monday said she had decided to withdraw from the conservative opposition party.

Making her announcement at the Legislative Yuan, Chou Chuang, a founder and heavyweight member of the New Party, said she made the painful decision after thorough consideration in an effort not to put the New Party in a dilemma.
However, she did not respond to reporters' questions as to whether she will participate in the year-end magistrate election in Taipei County.

Chou Chuang, defying the party leadership's decision to appoint Yang Tai-shun as the New Party candidate to run for the Taipei County magistracy, has insisted in taking part in the election as well. Her unwillingness to quit the competition has sparked an intraparty row in recent days.

Chou Yang-shan, convener of the New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee, said that although he felt remorse over Chou Chuang's decision to withdraw from the New Party, he believes the move will be helpful to party unity and its campaign activities in the forthcoming race for the magistracy in Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC NOT TO ADJUST OIL PRICES BEFORE MID-NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Domestic oil prices will not be adjusted before mid-November, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Chairman Chen Chao-wei said on Monday.

Fielding questions at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's budget, financial and economic affairs committees, Chen admitted that the CPC, the sole oil products supplier in Taiwan, is facing pressure to adjust its prices because of the recent currency fluctuation and hikes in crude oil prices in the international market.

Chen said the CPC's crude oil purchase costs would increase US$500 million if the local currency depreciated NT$1 against the US greenback. In fact, the New Taiwan dollar has devalued more than NT$1 over the past few days.

Moreover, international oil prices have risen to an average of US$19 to US$20 per barrel, higher than the US$17.5 projected in the CPC's budget plan for the current fiscal year, which started from July 1 this year.

"Against this background, we have felt the pressure to raise our product prices," Chen said, but he added that the state-run company has decided not to immediately pass on its increased costs to local consumers.

Chen apologized for the CPC over a spate of accidents at its oil refineries and distribution facilities in recent months, which have resulted in human casualties and heavy property damage. "We therefore will not adjust prices for our products for the time being," Chen noted, adding that local petroleum product prices will be maintained at the current levels until at least mid-November.

This was the first time that Chen testified before the Legislature since he assumed his current post on Oct. 9. Because of the frequency of public safety-related accidents at CPC facilities, the company has changed its top executive three times over the past year.
The Legislature's economic affairs committee has asked Chen to deliver a report next week on the company's plan to improve its safety measures and upgrade the morale of its staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTHING NEW IN JIANG ZEMIN'S CALL: MAC

TEXT.P: Sheu Kesheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), responded on Monday to a call by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin for political negotiations across the Taiwan Strait by describing the proposal as "nothing new."
Sheu said Jiang's call is no different from statements made in his political report delivered at the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party last month.

He reiterated the ROC government's standpoint on cross-strait negotiations, stressing that the suspended "Koo-Wang talks" and other established dialogue channels should be resumed immediately without preconditions from either side in order to address matters of protocol as well as political issues.

Jiang Zemin made his latest proposal on Sunday when he met with reporters from the US-based Time magazine in Shanghai. He said that negotiations must proceed under the principle of "one China," for the purpose of officially ending the state of hostility across the Taiwan Strait.

"We hope that the Taiwan authorities will earnestly respond to our suggestions and proposals and enter into political negotiations with us at an early date. On the premise that there is only one China, we are prepared to talk about any matter," Jiang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: AID FLOWS INTO IRIAN JAYA AS DEATH TOLL RISES

TEXT.P: More food and medical relief has poured in to help starvation-hit Irian Jaya as the death toll from this year's prolonged drought has reached almost 500 people.
One Hercules transport plane and two helicopters, dispatched from Jakarta by the Indonesian Armed Forces arrived in the province on Saturday to help airlift relief supplies.
The aircraft were to assist four Cessna aircraft owned by the private Missionary Aviation fellowship and one helicopter lent by the huge copper mining company PT Freeport Indonesia.
The death toll from the prolonged drought in the country's easternmost province increased to 493 people, Antara reported Sunday, quoting reliable sources.
It said the deaths were due to malaria and starvation which have especially affected those living in mountainous regions of Jayawijaya.
The Heath Ministry has also dispatched doctors and paramedics, along with a donation of US$28,000 and medicine to the remote and hunger-stricken villages in Jayawijaya.

The assistance was provided to the Coordinating Agency on National Disasters and will be flown to remote regions of Irian Jaya, Health Minister Sujudi told a congress of the Family Doctors Association here over the weekend.
The drought, which has wiped out much of the local yam crop, has led to the death of 493 people in the three remote districts around the Jayawijaya mountain range.

At least 416 people have died in Jayawijaya, 60 people in Merauke district and 17 in Puncak Jaya district. The Jayawijaya regent, J.B. Wenas, has said the drought is threatening at least another 90,000 tribespersons in the area, as serious food shortages continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS MAY HAVE TO PAY MORE FOR MEDICAL SERVICES

TEXT.P: Australians visit doctors more often than anyone else, according to the Australian Health Insurance Commission.
Statistics released by the commission show that Australians made an average of 11.2 visits to their local general practitioners in 1996, up substantially from an average of 4.5 visits in 1970.
The 1996 figure puts Australia well ahead of other countries in the rate of visits to the doctor and categorizes the nation as a doctor-dependent country, according to the commission.

The Sunday Telegraph newspaper quoted health economist Paul Gross as saying that the visitation rate in 1993 was 1.6 for the United States and 4.9 for France, while the visitation rate in the United Kingdom was about half that of Australia, he said. He did not have these countries' figures for 1996, but said the Australian figure was still well ahead.
Despite the high rate of visitation, GPs in Australia are locked in a battle with the federal government over their payments under the Medicare system.
Medicare payments to GPs has been increased by just 0.85 percent in the past two years, but doctors claim that in the same period, their costs have gone up by about 10 percent.
"We certainly want to make it very clear that the (Medicare) rebates are not keeping up with our costs," Australian Medical Association vice president David Brand told the Sunday Telegraph.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD TOURISM ORGANIZATION GENERAL ASSEMBLY OPENS IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: Istanbul is this week hosting the 12th General Assembly of the World Tourism Organization (WTO), where the world's top tourism decision-makers will be shaping the future of one of the world's most important economic sectors.

The biannual global summit brings together leaders of the tourism sector in order to make decisions that will successfully guide the industry into the 21st century. According to the WTO, international tourist arrivals will triple over the next two decades, soaring to 1.6 billion arrivals annually by 2020.

Tourism ministers and deputy ministers from about 120 countries, high-level officials, representatives of hotel chains, tourism companies, airlines, tour operators and educational institutions will be included amongst the 1,000 delegates from around the world who are expected to attend the summit this week.

Topping the agenda is a debate among tourism ministers and heads of delegations in which fundamental changes to modernize the WTO will be made so as to reflect the developments taking place throughout the world. In addition, a new secretary general will be elected for a four-year term, most probably acting secretary general Francesco Frangialli.

The Madrid based WTO is the only intergovernmental organization that serves as a global forum for tourism policy and issues. Its members include 134 countries and territories, as well as more than 330 affiliate members from the public and private sectors. The WTO's mission is to promote and develop tourism as a significant means of fostering international peace and understanding, economic development and international trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PANEL SET UP TO HELP MAKE S'PORE A GLOBAL CITY

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Sunday announced the setting up of the Singapore 21 Committee, whose task will be to look into the intellectual, emotional, spiritual, cultural and social needs of Singaporeans.
The 10-member panel, headed by Education Minister Teo Chee Hean, will suggest new ideas to make Singapore a global city and provide the best possible environment for Singaporeans.

It will look beyond securing economic and material comforts, and focus on "the heartware of Singapore -- our love for the country, our rootedness and our sense of community and nationhood," the prime minister said.

Speaking at the opening of the Second Triennial Conference for Grassroots Leaders, he explained that the committee would form five subcommittees, each concentrating on a dilemma facing Singapore and finding ways to resolve problems in that area.
The committee members -- eight new MPs and two nominated MPs -- will chair the subcommittees, responsible for five areas:
-- internationalization and regionalization versus Singapore as home;
-- a less stressful life versus retaining drive;
-- attracting talent versus looking after Singaporeans;
-- the needs of senior citizens versus the aspirations of the younger generation; and
-- consultation and consensus versus decisiveness and quick action.
The panel's deliberations will be completed by the end of next year, and a report will be submitted to the prime minister in the first quarter of 1999.
Goh first mentioned the committee at his National Day Rally speech in August.
Teo said afterwards that the committee would seek to establish a consensus among Singaporeans about the kind of society they want in the 21st century.
"However, we do not want to generate a list of things which the government and other government agencies have to do," he said.

"We want to draw up a wide range of initiatives not only for the government, but also for the community, voluntary organizations and even for individuals and families, perhaps reflecting attitudes which they should hold on various national issues."
The panel will hold focused group discussion involving small gatherings of Singaporeans, and seminars and forums for the general public.
Commenting on the committee's composition of mostly younger MPs in their 30's, Teo said they were chosen as they will form the core of Singapore's leadership in the next century.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE IMPORTERS WANT LOWER COAL PRICES FROM AUSSIE SUPPLIERS

TEXT.P: Japanese importers are expected to renegotiate prices of coking and steaming coal from their Australian suppliers this week, with the resulting price-levels to become a benchmark for Australian exports to Taiwan and South Korea.
Japan -- the biggest importer of Australian coal -- is expected to ask for price cuts of between 6 percent and 8 percent this year, industry sources said.
The sources believed Australian companies, including Shell Ltd., CRA Ltd. and BHP Coal Corp., will face tough bargaining.
Coking prices are generally set between Nippon Steel Corp. and the large Australian coal producers with negotiated prices coming into effect at the beginning of the Japanese financial year in April.
Last year Australian producers suffered price cuts of US$2.00 to US$3.00 a ton to a benchmark price of US$44.70.
After coking prices are set, the Japanese power utilities negotiate with Australian producers to fix the steaming coal prices, the sources said.
Last year, steaming prices dropped US$2.65 a ton and the sources said they expect a further US$2.00 cut, setting the steaming coal price at US$37.65 per ton.

Australia is facing tough negotiations in setting its coal prices because the recent strikes by coalmine workers would put exporters in worse conditions and Japanese buyers are expected to cash in on such Australian problems to ask for lower prices, the sources said.

Usually Australian exporters use the set prices of their coal with Japanese buyers to sell their products to Taiwan and Korea, two of the major importers from Australia. Australia exports about A$8 billion of coal to Japan, Taiwan, Korea and other countries each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHECKUP ON PUBLIC SUPPORT: SUHARTO

TEXT.P: President Suharto urged the ruling Golkar to ensure that the people support his renomination for the 1998-2003 presidency, saying he does not want to be seen as hampering leadership succession.

"We all have five months (until the March presidential election) to check whether (the people's trust exists), he was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying in an off-the-cuff remark after delivering an address at Golkar's 33rd anniversary reception here Sunday night.
Speaking in his capacity as the ruling organization's chief patron, Suharto was responding to Golkar's announcement minutes earlier that it was renominating him for another term of office.
Suharto said he wanted to be sure that people were not forced to support him.

"I hope their trust is not a pseudo one because if so I would be accused of obstructing succession, an obstacle to the regeneration process," he said. "I could also be accused of being a complacent Golkar cadre, being a president for six terms and now wanting a seventh term."
Suharto's audience of some 5,000 people was apparently moved by his search for assurance that they responded to many of his remarks.
When he said: Is it really true that the renomination is a reflection of people's trust for me?" some in the audience yelled: "It's true!"
Suharto was first elected president in 1968 by the Provisional People's Consultative Assembly and subsequently re-elected for five consecutive terms.
His current term will expire in March next year and the 1,000-strong People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) will meet to elect a president and vice president.

Golkar chairman Harmoko said earlier in the reception that Golkar was certain that "the nation's best son, who fulfills all the criteria as president for the 1998-2003 term, is Haji Muhammad Suharto."

The audience, which included Vice President Try Sutrisno and his wife Tuti, along with representatives of the ruling political parties from friendly countries, cheered and gave a standing ovation for the smiling president.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T INTERVENTION IN STOCK MARKET SEEN UNNECESSARY

TEXT.P: Although the stock prices have dropped sharply in Taiwan in recent days, the time is not ripe for the government to intervene in the stock market, because all economic fundamentals are stable, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.
The local bourse lost 843.42 points, or about 10 percent, last week. The weighted price index plunged 309.08 points Monday to close at 7,309.37.
The sharp decline in stock prices may hurt the confidence of private investors in the stock market, but it is not expected to hurt the fundamentals of the economy, the official said.

All economic fundamentals are rather stable, and the orders placed with Taiwan manufacturers by foreign buyers are increasing. The value of export orders received in September is expected to exceed US$10 billion, he said.
The government will let the market mechanism to function, and not intervene in the stock market, the official said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CURRENCY EXPECTED TO STABILIZE AT NT$30 TO US$1

TEXT.P: Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the ruling Kuomintang Investment Management Committee, predicted here Monday that the exchange rate between the New Taiwan dollar and the US dollar will eventually stabilize at 30 to one.

The US dollar rose continuously in recent days on the Taiwan foreign exchange market to close at NT$30.451 Monday. Liu said it is quite normal for the US dollar to hover between NT$29 and NT$30. The exchange rate will eventually stabilize at NT$30 to US$1.

Liu, who served as president of Taiwan Institute of Economic Research a few years ago, said that the international financial situation is changing quite rapidly, and that the US dollar is the only strong currency in the world nowadays.
He said the New Taiwan dollar is a relatively strong currency when compared with the Japanese yen and the currencies of some other countries.
Liu also said that the economic strength of Taiwan is pretty strong and that all fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are quite stable at the present time.

Taiwan's stock market will recover, foreign capital will flow into Taiwan , and the interest rates will decline, as soon as the exchange rate between the Taiwan currency and the US dollar stabilizes, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL DAMAGE TOPS NT$4.3 BILLION

TEXT.P: Torrential rains and typhoons which swept Taiwan during the June-September period have caused NT$4.38 billion-worth of damage to the local agricultural sector, the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Monday.
Of that total, some NT$2.1 billion-worth of damage was the result of three days of heavy rain which started on June 4, according to the COA.

COA statistics show that watermelons and vegetables in Tainan and Kaohsiung counties were hardest-hit by the June 4 flooding and further torrential rain on Aug. 7, while Taitung County's tomato crop was ravaged by typhoon Winnie on Aug. 18 and the forestry and fishery sectors and soil conservation facilities sustained heavy damage islandwide from typhoon Amber less than two weeks later.
As of Sept. 4, more than NT$330 million in cash aid and relief funds had already been released to help farmers resume their operations and compensate their losses, the COA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: APLFD MEMBERS SUPPORT ROC PARTICIPATION IN INT'L ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: The member countries of the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) on Sunday unanimously passed a resolution supporting an active role for the Republic of China in international organizations.

Coming at the conclusion of the APLFD's two-day annual meeting in Melbourne, the statement notes that the ROC is a fully democratic country. It has achieved spectacular economic development and is a major global economic force as one of the world's principal trading and investor nations.

The resolution also says the ROC has significantly contributed financial resources as well as technical expertise to many developing countries around the world. In turn, the international community has reacted positively to the ROC's quest for international participation as evidenced by its membership in the Asian Development Bank, the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, and its active role in various regional institutions of Southeast Asia as well as Central and South America.

"In view of the foregoing, be it resolved that the APLFD calls on its members to render full support to enable the ROC to play an even more active role in international organizations and institutions in the global community, thus contributing her share to the well-being of all peoples," the resolution says.

About 100 delegates from 14 countries, including the host Australia, took part in the meeting. They issued a joint communique at the conclusion of the meeting Sunday afternoon, calling for a strengthening of links among the peoples of the Asian Pacific region.

The communique also acknowledged the efforts of Bob Halverson, speaker of the Australian Parliament, in promoting regional economic cooperation, the universality of human rights and the growth of democratic institutions throughout the region.
It also acknowledged the call by Dr. Tze-chi Chao, president of the World League for Freedom and Democracy, for Asian peoples to develop a common consciousness to avoid the scourge of war.

Chao said: "Looking back on the history of the past half-century or more, we recall that the Second World War first erupted in Asia, and that the culmination of that conflict also took place in this region. During those years, the whole of Asia was consumed with incessant fighting and bloodshed.

"The Asian people suffered innumerable hardships in that horrific life and death struggle. And throughout the subsequent Cold War era, Asia continued to be shrouded in the clouds of gunfire. People's lives and property were subjected to untold destruction. The bitter agony of those times is still fresh in our memories."
Paul Tovua, parliamentary speaker of the Soloman Islands, spoke of the continuing need to build democratic institutions and uphold the principles of human rights in the Pacific Island states.

General Moon-Suk Lee, secretary general of the APLFD's Korea Chapter, warned of the dangers to mankind by the continuing presence of totalitarianism and said North Korea remains a destabilizing influence in the region.

The APLFD, formerly the Asian Pacific Anti-Communist League, was renamed seven years ago in the wake of the disintegration of the Soviet Union and its East Bloc allies. It presently has a membership of 30 countries.
Its annual meeting, hosted this year by the APLFD Australian Chapter, ended Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON WOMEN ENTREPRENEURS TO OPEN

TEXT.P: A conference on women entrepreneurs and their role in society will open in Taipei on Tuesday with over 80 women professionals from Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China and the United States participating.

The three-day conference, co-sponsored by the US-based Atlantic Council think tank and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), represents an important contribution to the body of research on the role of women in the local economy, TIER officials said.
The Atlantic Council has studied cultural, social and economic problems encountered by women entering the business world since 1996, and has launched a four-year research project, the sources said.
They said that Huang Mei-lun, wife of Vice Premier John Chang, will address the opening ceremony.

Wang Shaw-lan, a member of the conference organizing committee and publisher of the Min Sheng Daily mass-circulation newspaper, will deliver a speech on the role played by women in Taiwan's economic development.
Cheng Shu-min, chairwoman of the China Television Company, will preside over a seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. AMERICANS SEEKING TRADE OPPORTUNITIES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Traders are coming from Brazil, Argentina, and Chile to Taiwan to seek trade opportunities, an official of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Monday.

He said a trade mission, organized by Brazil Trade Managers Association, is in Taipei to meet with dozens of Taiwan suppliers. The Brazilian traders want to buy computer peripherals, plastic equipment, wooden kitchenware, and other household items.

Another Brazilian trade mission will also meet with Taiwan manufacturers this week to buy computer hardware and software, electrical wire and cable, ventilators, electronics connectors, communications equipment, and other products.
Argentina has stepped its efforts to promote the sales of beef to Taiwan. Chile is also trying to sell grape wine to Taiwan, the CETRA official said.
Meanwhile, the official said, Taiwan has attached great importance to the South American market. CETRA is planning to open trade offices in that part of the world, he added. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: `TAIWAN ISSUE' NOT ON CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT AGENDA

TEXT.P: Issues related to Taiwan are not on the agenda of an upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, new Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Monday.

"According to a briefing given by US authorities to our government, Taiwan is not among the eight topics to be discussed in the Oct. 29 Clinton-Jiang summit in Washington, D.C.," said Hu, who has just ended a 14-month stint as the Republic of China's de facto ambassador to the United States and returned this morning to Taipei to assume his new post.

While expecting Jiang to bring up Taiwan-related issues in a "certain form" during his talks with Clinton, Hu said he doesn't believe that the summit will lead to any break in Washington's present policy toward Taiwan.

"A basic understanding between Taipei and Washington is that the United States will not sacrifice Taiwan's interests in its engagement with Beijing and will not make any decision that might surprise or shock our government and people," the Oxford-educated minister told the local press after his swearing-in ceremony.

Hu, who was sworn in four hours after his return to Taipei at 6:30 a.m. on Monday, said he will try to achieve a new balance between promoting pragmatic diplomacy and improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that pragmatic diplomacy "is a necessity like life, as worth treasuring as breath and as natural as sunlight," Hu said he is convinced that mainland China's incessant attempts to suppress Taiwan's pragmatic diplomatic activities is mainly a result of Beijing's misunderstanding of the ROC's policy goals.

The former government spokesman who seems blessed with boundless energy and enjoys an easy rapport with people, said at his swearing-in ceremony that on his way from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to Taipei early this morning, he felt an impulse to jump out of his car and declare to the people that "he's back" to take up his new assignment as the country's top diplomatic officer.

"Today is the most glorious day of my life, as I have been pursuing a diplomatic career since picking the department of diplomacy of National Chengchi University as my top choice 30 years ago," an elated Hu said, adding that he will dedicate himself fully to promoting pragmatic diplomacy in a manner more acceptable to all the people of Taiwan.
Vice Premier John Chang, who was also Hu's immediate predecessor, lauded Hu as a knowledgeable, capable and smart diplomat, most suitable for his new job.

"I'm convinced that Hu, as our country's 13th foreign minister, will be able to open a new chapter in our diplomatic history," Chang said. He also encouraged Hu "never to give up" in carrying out diplomatic work.
Chang also explained his advocacy of "fighting fire with fire" in expanding the ROC's diplomatic frontiers during his 22-month stint as the minister of foreign affairs.

"To develop diplomatic ties with other countries is to defend our sovereignty, consolidate our international status, create an international climate favorable for cross-strait dialogue and negotiations on an equal footing, as well as to maintain the dignity of our 21.5 million people," Chang said, adding: "To protect our liberal, democratic way of life from any threat, we should neither become self-suspicious nor confine ourselves to this small enclave. We should never retreat and should always walk out bravely and firmly into the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIA WON'T EXPORT NATURAL GAS

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia has no plans to export natural gas, as domestic demand continues to rise quickly, Saudi Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources Ali Al-Naimi said Sunday.

Naimi noted that downstream and natural gas infrastructure development is "completely open" to foreign investors. "Opportunities will flourish for investors as we foresee substantial growth in this sector," he said.
Saudi Arabia is planning to add five trillion cubic feet of recoverable gas to its reserves each year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WAFER INDUSTRY RANKS 2ND IN COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer industry has greatly sharpened its global competitiveness recently and currently ranks second in three different categories -- manufacture, design and packaging of wafers -- behind Japan, the United States and South Korea, respectively, according to a survey prepared by the state-financed Industrial Technology Research Institute.

The report, which won a prize for distinguished study from the Economics Ministry, analyzed the worldwide integrated circuit industry in 1996, saying that Taiwan in the early 1990s lagged behind, in relative terms, in wafer design and packaging, while concentrating its efforts on improving the manufacturing process, which is why Taiwan's market shares failed to increase in line with its technological edge.

Given the huge amount of investment needed in wafer development and the construction of wafer factories, IC manufacturers globally are forming joint ventures to design and produce new products, with the purpose of sharing both R&D costs and the risks of competition.
As a result, the report pointed out, new industrial alliances are sprouting up in the field, while the competition between different alliances is intensifying.

Against this background, the report urged the industry to speed up its globalization and step up the interaction between up- and down-stream firms to fulfill the government-set goal of churning out US$66 billion-worth of IC products by 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S SEPTEMBER TRADE GROWS BY 11.7 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Singapore's total trade at current prices grew by 11.7 percent in September, with increases in both exports and imports by 8.8 percent and 14.6 percent, respectively, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) said on Monday.
Non-oil domestic exports increased by 9.4 percent, while re-exports also increased by 10.5 percent in September. However, oil exports declined by 2.5 percent.
The total value of Singapore's external trade in September amounted to S$34,380 million, an increase of 16.8 percent over August, figures released by the TDB show.
Of this total, exports were valued at S$16,964 million, while imports, at S$17,416 million, marked an unfavorable balance of S$452 million.
On a monthly basis, non-oil domestic exports rose by 15.8 percent, following a moderate growth of 5.5 percent in August, the fourth consecutive month of positive growth, the TDB said.
Growth was reflected in key electronic products such as semiconductors and printed circuit boards, while that of disk drives recorded more moderate growth of 9 percent.
Re-exports rose strongly by 20.6 percent, partly boosted by re-exports of old aircraft. Increases in re-exports of electronics and related products also contributed to the strong growth in this area.
Non-oil imports continued to expand strongly by 20.3 percent in September, reflecting large increases in electronic components and parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES SUBIC BAY CHIEF TO ATTEND TAIPEI SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority (SBMA) Chairman Richard Gordon will leave for the ROC on Tuesday to represent the Philippines at the East Asia Economic Summit in Taipei.
Gordon, the only Filipino invited to the affair, will present the story of the Philippines' transformation from the " Sick Man of Asia" to Asia's newest "Tiger Economy."
He will also focus on Subic's successful transformation from an American naval base to a thriving and successful freeport.
In his presentation, Gordon will focus on the economic measures being undertaken by the Ramos administration to sustain economic growth despite the ongoing regional currency crisis.

The SBMA chairman will also assure financial managers attending the summit of the Philippines' sound macro-economic fundamentals which have made it possible for the country's economy to rebound, despite the recent attacks on the Philippine peso and other regional currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS URGE PEACEFUL RESOLUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS

TEXT.P: Leading lawmakers from Taiwan on Sunday called for mainland China to resolve the Taiwan problem through peaceful means and urged member countries of the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy to play a role.

In a panel discussion at the APLFD annual conference in Melbourne, Legislator Chang Chun-hung, a leading member of the Democratic Progressive Party in Taiwan, said he was exploring new means of promoting improved relations between Taiwan and mainland China.
He expressed concern that lingering tensions between Taiwan and China could eventually lead to disaster.
Chang said he hoped that the APLFD members can help to build a constructive dialogue in Asia that would serve to avert such conflicts.

Legislator Chen Yi-hsin of the New Party asked Beijing to give up its insistence Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China. He said only by recognizing the reality of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can the issue of China's unification be resolved.
Chen said Taiwan has completed its democratic transformation peacefully and expressed hope that mainland China can do the same.
He said a peaceful solution to the problem of the Taiwan Strait would enhance the peace and progress of both the Asian region and the global community.
In his paper presented at the conference, Professor Tai Wan-chin of Tamkang University urged the United States to play a practical and constructive role in cross-strait affairs.
He urged Washington to be straightforward in safeguarding the security of Taiwan and not to maintain an ambiguous stand in dealing with the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar surged NT$0.69 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$30.451.
The greenback opened at 29.80 and was traded between 29.70 and 30.50.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$520 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES TUMBLE 301.67 ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 301.67 points to finish at 7316.78.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7579.86 and experienced a low of 7274.97.
Losers outnumbered gainers 391 to 49, with 18 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.80 billion (US$2.68 billion).

Electrical engineering issues fell the most at 6.1 percent, followed by construction shares at 5.1 percent; financial shares at 3.2 percent; foodstuff stocks at 3.0 percent; paper and pulp stocks at 2.5 percent; plastic and chemical issues at 2.3 percent; cement shares at 2.0 percent; and textile issues at 1.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRECIATION OF TAIWAN DOLLAR WON'T PUSH UP CONSUMER PRICE INDEX

TEXT.P: The rapid depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar in recent days is not expected to trigger an upward spiral in Taiwan's consumer price index for the time being, a government official said Monday.

Hsu Chang-yao, an official with the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), said that despite its fall against the greenback, the NT dollar has remained relatively strong compared with other major international currencies such as the Japanese yen and German mark.

Hsu noted that the while the NT dollar has shed 7 percent against the US dollar over the past few days, the Japanese yen has plunged 10 percent against the greenback and the German mark even more than that.

Japan is Taiwan's largest source of imports, accounting for 25-30 percent of the island's total import value, while imports from Germany account for 4 to 5 percent of the total. The pressure for a price rise in imported goods is therefore limited, the official said.
The prices of industrial and agricultural materials on the international markets are stable, he said, adding that the wholesale price index has been dropping for the past few months.
A DGBAS report issued earlier this month estimated the overall consumer price index will rise 1.67 percent in 1997 but noted that this figure might be as low as 1.5 percent, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANS IMPORT OF FRESH FRUITS FROM PART OF FLORIDA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has banned the import of fresh fruits and fruit trees from part of Florida in order to protect Taiwan fruits from the invasion of Mediterranean fruit flies, an official of the Council of Agriculture said Monday.

He said Mediterranean fruit flies, which can destroy fruits and other crops quickly, have been found in Hills Borough, Polk, Manatee, Orange, and Sarasota counties in Florida. The United States government has banned the exports of fruits from the area.
The Council of Agriculture announced on Oct. 16 that fresh fruits and fruit trees from the five counties and its surrounding area had been temporarily banned from import into Taiwan.
Taiwan is one of the major importers of citrus fruits from Florida. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PROBE OF MAID'S DEATH IN TAIWAN TO BE LIMITED

TEXT.P: A law enforcement official in the central Taiwan city of Taichung said Monday that while local prosecutors will cooperate fully with Manila's investigation into the death of a Philippine maid in Taiwan, the local prosecutor's file on the case will be off-limits to Philippine investigators because of there is no legal basis for giving them such access.

Responding to reporters' questions, Chen Chung-ming, director of the Taichung District Prosecutor's Office, said that if Philippine investigators contact his office through diplomatic channels, it would explain in detail its reasons for ruling out foul play in the death of Elyrose M. Miguel and closing the case.
However, Chen said, a foreign government cannot receive access to official investigation files without a statutory basis for this.
Miguel, who arrived in Taiwan in early March, was found dead on March 24 at her Taichung workplace, the office of Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Yen Ching-piao. She had been hired by Yen's wife.
Although no suicide note was ever found, prosecutor Lee Yueh-chih, who presided over the autopsy, said she discovered many notes written by Miguel showing she was in a state of deep depression.
Polygraphs and related examinations on Yen and his family turned up no evidence suggesting foul play, Lee said.
Philippine President Fidel Ramos, however, has reportedly ordered his government to investigate the death of Miguel after her family raised suspicions to the Philippine Labor Ministry.
Miguel's body was sent back to Manila in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PM VISITS JAKARTA

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong will make a working visit to Jakarta Oct. 20-21, the Prime Minister's Office said Monday.

Goh, who will be accompanied by senior officials, will hold discussions with Indonesian President Suharto on the regional currency problem, the upcoming APEC (Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation) Leaders' Meeting in Vancouver and the informal ASEAN Summit that Kuala Lumpur will host in December.
Goh and Suharto last met in March, when they jointly opened the Karimun Marine and Industrial Complex and Karimun Sembawang Shipyard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND TRADE INCREASES

TEXT.P: Despite the government's "no haste, be patient" economic policy toward mainland China, direct trade between Taiwan and the mainland reached US$7.32 billion in the first six months of this year, up 5.4 percent from the same period last year, a government report said Monday.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said that Taiwan-made products accounted for 11.7 percent of mainland China's total imports in 1996. The figure was behind Japan's 21 percent, but ahead of the United States' 11.6 percent and South Korea's 9 percent.

Exports to the mainland accounted for 14 percent of Taiwan's total exports last year, compared with South Korea's 9.6 percent, Japan's 7.1 percent and the United States' 2.6 percent, revealing the island's relatively high dependence on the mainland market.

Compared to 1990, Taiwan's 1996 exports to the mainland as a precentage of its overall exports grew 10.6 percentage points, while Japan saw an increase of 4.5 percentage points, South Korea 8.5 percentage points and the United States 0.9 percentage points.

South Korea's exports to mainland China in the first half of 1997 reached US$6.65 billion, representing an increase of 18.2 percent over the same period last year. Japan's exports to mainland China reached US$12.7 billion, a decline of 3.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LAWYERS, ACCOUNTANTS TO BE ALLOWED TO PRACTICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan has promised that three years after the island's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) it will allow foreign lawyers to form joint ventures with their local counterparts and will permit foreign accountants to practice here, said an official on Monday.

Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that in the round of bilateral talks with Washington on Taiwan's WTO bid, that is currently underway here, Taipei agreed to allow foreign lawyers to practice in Taiwan in fields related to the laws of their own countries or international law on the condition that they first provide legal counseling in Taiwan for two years and have practiced law in their homelands for at least three years.

Taipei also promised to open its service markets to foreign Certified Public Accountants, whose services vary little from country to country, provided that foreign countries also grant Taiwan accountants similar rights as called for in WTO regulations. However, in order to shield local accountants from fierce foreign competition, foreign CPAs should obtain local licenses before operating on the island, Schive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRIME MINISTER ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Senegal's Prime Minister Habib Thiam arrived in Taipei Monday night at the head of a 27-member delegation for a six-day visit.

During his stay here, Thiam will meet with President Lee Teng-hui and be decorated with the Republic of China's highest civilian honor, the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon. He will also visit Premier Vincent Siew and several other top-ranking officials.

Officials from the ROC and Senegal have frequently exchanged visits since the two countries reestablished diplomatic relations on January 3, 1996. ROC Vice Premier John Chang, who assumed his new post in September, visited the African country in January and May this year during his tenure as ROC minister of Foreign Affairs.
Thiam is scheduled to depart Taiwan on Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: LITHUANIAN PM VOWS TO BOOST TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Lithuania has expressed a keen interest in reinforcing relations with the Republic of China, a local newspaper said on Tuesday.

The China Times quoted Lithuanian Prime Minister Gediminas Vagnorius as saying in a recent interview with the paper that he hopes the two countries can exchange representative offices in the first half of next year to facilitate bilateral engagements.
Vagnorius, who once visited Taiwan in August 1992, said Lithuania and Taiwan already signed an agreement on the exchange of commercial offices in July 1991.
"We hope the accord can be implemented as soon as possible to facilitate bilateral trade, investment and tourist exchanges," Vagnorius was quoted as saying in the interview.

Vagnorius first assumed the Lithuanian premiership in 1991, shortly after the Baltic country declared independence, but stepped down in 1992 after an alliance composed of former Communist Party members won the parliamentary election. He managed to reclaim the office in November 1996 after his Conservative Party formed a coalition cabinet with the Christian Democratic Party and the Central Party.

Vagnorius said he vividly remembers his previous visit to Taiwan. Describing Taiwan as a "new, outstanding and strong" country, Vagnorius said he admires its achievements in economic and political reforms, adding that Lithuania has much to learn from Taiwan, particularly its strategies for economic development and trade promotion.

The Lithuanian prime minister said he thinks the international community should give Taiwan more recognition and support. "This is not only because Taiwan is an economic powerhouse but also because Taiwan can assist mainland China in political democratization," he noted.
Lithuania recognizes mainland China, but Vagnorius said his country would be willing to host visits by senior ROC officials if they present applications.
Asked whether he is likely to visit Taiwan again, Vagnorius said he needs time to make necessary preparations. "At least, I must wait until my country is admitted to the European Union (EU)."

Vagnorius further said the Lithuanian government will take concrete steps to show its sincerity in welcoming Taiwan investors. "We hope to win Taiwan investors' confidence in our investment climate and administrative efficiency."

Vagnorius said Taiwan investors are welcome to buy into large Lithuanian private enterprises or to invest in its major infrastructure construction projects. To facilitate its "free economic zone" project, Lithuania is constructing an airport at Siauliai and a seaport at Kleipeda. "Taiwan investors are welcome to invest in the two projects."

Lithuania will also offer preferential tax incentives to Taiwan entrepreneurs intending to invest in its free economic zone, Vagnorius said, adding that Taiwan investors can use his country as a bridgehead to tap markets in Russia and the EU because Lithuania has signed convenient export/import agreements with those two entities.

Lithuania declared independence from the now-defunct Soviet Union in 1990 and is now recognized by more than 60 countries around the world. It has also joined the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and several other major international organizations. It is now a quasi-member of the EU and a "peace partner" of NATO.

As Lithuania has encountered some difficulties gaining full membership in both the EU and NATO, Vagnorius said he sympathizes with Taiwan over all the discrimination it has endured in the world community. "I wish your country a prosperous future," he said at the end of the interview.
