DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA EQUALLY IMPORTANT: BOEING
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By J.C. Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan and mainland China are important markets for the Boeing Corporation, the giant US aircraft maker said on Monday.

Boeing estimated that over the next 20 years, Taiwan's commercial aircraft market will reach around 200 units valued at US$22 billion, while the market scale of mainland China will stand at 2,200 units worth US$140 billion.

Although there seems to be a big difference in the figures, Boeing said both Taiwan and mainland China are equally important to any aircraft maker, taking into account the differences in size of their population and territory.
According to Boeing, Taiwan aviation companies, along with their Japanese, Singaporean, and South Korean counterparts, are the best in Asia in managing their fleets.

International civilian aviation authorities estimate that the Asia-Pacific region will be the world's fastest-growing market over the next five years in terms of air passenger and air cargo business, outpacing projected worldwide annual growth rates of 6 percent and 9 percent, respectively, in those areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PRIME MINISTER DECORATED

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon on visiting Senegalese Prime Minister Habib Thiam in recognition of his contribution to promoting friendly cooperative ties between the two countries.
Speaking on the occasion, Thiam said the decoration, the Republic of China's highest civilian honor, is the greatest laurel of his life.

Noting that the friendship between the Republic of China and Senegal is based on their common ideals of upholding peace, justice, freedom and solidarity, Thiam said he is convinced that bilateral relations will become even closer and more cordial in the years ahead.
Thiam lauded President Lee for his achievements in promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan and for his efforts to boost ROC-Senegal cooperation.
Thiam, heading a 27-member delegation of senior Senegalese officials, arrived in Taipei on Monday for a six-day visit.

Officials from the ROC and Senegal have frequently exchanged visits since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in January 1996. ROC Vice Premier John Chang visited the West African country in January and May this year during his stint as minister of foreign affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN EXECUTIVE SWIMS TO SHORE AFTER 17 HOURS ADRIFT

TEXT.P: A Siemens business executive swam safely to shore Monday after drifting in the sea for nearly 17 hours, police said Tuesday.

Michael Maquet, sales director for the ASP Line of Business Siemens Nixdorf Information Systems, Taiwan branch, and Horst Mueck, chairman of Bayer Taiwan Company, went sailing in a catamaran off Paishawan, Shihmen Village, Taipei County, on Sunday afternoon.

Because of unusually high waves in the area, the craft carrying the two men capsized three times. After the third time, Mueck managed to climb back aboard the catamaran, only to find that Maquet was missing.
Mueck promptly returned to shore after finding no trace of Maquet. Helicopters, coast guard vessels and fishing boats were mobilized to search for Maquet.

Maquet's Taiwan-born wife Chang Shih-hwa was waiting anxiously onshore at Paishawan, but had to return home after the rescue operation was called off around 8:00 p.m. She returned to Paishawan again at 4:00 a.m. Monday, hoping for a miracle.

Later, Maquet said he had survived by keeping his cool and by a strong will to live. Knowing that a rescue team would attempt to find him, he utilized his skills as a trained lifeguard in continuously kicking his feet to keep warm. He said he was able to see the shore from time to time throughout the ordeal.

After nightfall, he realized that nobody would come for him during the evening hours. In order to orient himself, he remained still so as to test the direction of the current, which enabled him to be certain that he was drifting along the shoreline.

Maquet said that he was carried by the current of the sea, and that after nearly three hours in the Paishawan area, he began drifting in a northeasterly direction toward Keelung for six more hours. Later, he began drifting back to Paishawan, and then to the east.
He approached the shoreline on three occasions, but each time had to yield to the strong current in order to conserve his energy.

At around 6:00 a.m. Monday, fortune turned his way as he drifted near Keelungyu and he successfully fought to reach the offshore islet, where he rested for half an hour before he gathered enough energy to find a group of soldiers who were stationed there. He was treated to a hot meal and eventually reunited with his family.

Maquet estimated that he had drifted about 65 kilometers in the sea and at one time spotted a fishing boat just five meters away. Although he shouted to his utmost, the ship slowly sailed away to his dismay.
Although the 53-year-old German businessmen is an experienced seafarer, he vowed that he will not go out on the catamaran again without proper safety equipment, such as flares or rescue balloons.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SOAR 417.27 ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday due to government action to bolster the flagging bourse, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 417.27 points to finish at 7734.05.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7468.83 and close at the day's high of 7734.05.
Gainers outnumbered losers 429 to 34, with 9 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.94 billion (US$4.20 billion).

Financial shares rose the most at 6.7 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks at 6.0 percent; electrical engineering issues at 5.9 percent; textile stocks at 5.2 percent; construction shares at 5.1 percent; paper and pulp issues at 4.2 percent; cement stocks at 3.5 percent; and foodstuff issues at 3.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL GETS FIRST BOEING 747-400 DESIGNED UNDER NEW CONCEPT
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By J.C. Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The first Boeing 747-400 passenger plane designed under new concepts to better accommodate the needs of passengers was turned over to China Airlines at a ceremony in Seattle on Monday afternoon.

A CAL spokesman said that, in order to expand its flight services and speed up the phase-out of aging aircraft, it will introduce five Boeing 744-400 and eight Boeing 737-800 passenger planes to its fleet by late 1998. It is expected that the CAL fleet will increase from the current 44 aircraft to 56 by the end of next year.

After the addition of the new planes, CAL will undertake to make some adjustments in its plane assignments and flight routes. The 747-400s, which have the biggest passenger capacity, will fly the trans-Pacific flights to North America.
MD-11 planes will fly to destinations in Russia and Europe, while Airbus models will service cities in the Asian Pacific region.

Beginning next January, CAL will increase the number of weekly Taiwan-Los Angeles flights to 14 from the present 11. Expansion of the schedule to two flights daily is expected to remain a lucrative prospect.

Meanwhile, Catherine Chang, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Seattle, said during the ceremony that if domestic carriers can make joint purchases of aircraft, they would be in a better position to negotiate prices. She said this would also help to upgrade the aviation industry in Taiwan and to develop the local parts and components market.

Chang, who was recently appointed as the ROC ambassador to Saint Christopher and Nevis as well as to Dominica, said that during her three years in Seattle she has steadily worked to promote cultural and trade exchanges between Taiwan and the western part of the United States.
Taiwan's first woman ambassador also revealed that Washington Governor Gary Locke, the first Chinese-American governor in the United States, will visit Taiwan next April.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA DENIES REPORT ON 'NON-APPLICATION' CLAUSE

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Tuesday denied that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has delivered a report on whether to exclude mainland China from the application of multilateral trade agreements after it is admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan floor session, Wang said the WTO charter provides for non-application of multilateral trade agreements between particular members.

"Whether to employ the non-application clause toward Beijing concerns our overall policy toward mainland China, and we must address the issue in accordance with our National Unification Guidelines," Wang said.
At the moment, Wang said, the government has not yet begun to mull the issue, nor has the economics ministry released a report on the topic.

The priority tasks for the MOEA at present are to speed up bilateral consultations with Taiwan's major trade partners on the island's WTO accession terms, Wang said, adding that the ROC has wound up bilateral talks with 21 of the 26 WTO members which have expressed intention of conducting negotiations with Taiwan.

Wang said many factors should be considered in determining whether to employ the "non-application" clause toward mainland China, including whether or not cross-strait relations have entered a medium-term stage as well as the possible impact of such action, or lack of it, on Taiwan's agriculture, manufacturing and service industries.
"We don't need to make a decision at the moment," Wang said, adding that the government will make an appropriate decision at the proper time based on national interests.

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said last week that Taiwan has clearly defined rights to determine whether to employ the "non-application" clause toward mainland China.
"We do not need to discuss the issue with any particular WTO member as a prerequisite for our entry to the organization," Chen said.
Both Taiwan and mainland China are WTO observers. It remains uncertain when the two Chinese economies will become full members of the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND, FOREIGN POLICY ARE OPPOSITE SIDES OF SAME COIN: HU

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Monday described the government's mainland and foreign policies as being opposite sides of the same coin, saying that they are inseparable and that neither side can be said to be more important than the other.

Hu, newly sworn in as the nation's top foreign affairs official after serving as the ROC representative to the United States, said that Washington's stand of refusing to act as a mediator between Taipei and Beijing remains unchanged.

He added that Beijing should not continue to use the channel provided by its Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) and Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- the respective intermediary bodies between the two sides -- a "chip" in bargaining for a political settlement. He said this could increase the risk of misjudgment on the part of both sides due to the lack of more open and direct channels of communication.

Hu asserted in a news conference Monday night that Taipei has always been willing to communicate with Beijing and knows the importance of dialogue. The aim of diplomatic exchanges, he said, is to allow people in both Taiwan and mainland China, as well as in the international community, to fully comprehend the true meaning of pragmatic diplomacy.

By doing so, Hu explained further, Taipei hopes to convince Beijing that it is unnecessary to restrict Taiwan's diplomatic presence and to achieve its goal of "burying the hatchet" with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE EXPLAINS STANCE ON DIRECT TIES WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Responding to calls by the local business community to open direct trade and transport ties with mainland China, President Lee Teng-hui was quoted on Tuesday as saying that Beijing's ambition to swallow Taiwan must be taken into account.
Taichung Mayor Lin Poh-jung told a conference which he chaired that Lee had asked him to convey the government's stance on cross-strait relations during a 40-minute meeting on Monday morning.

According to Lin, the ROC president is deeply concerned over the increased calls by local businesses to open direct trade, shipping and postal delivery services with the mainland, citing worries over the effect upon national security.

Lin, quoting President Lee, warned the public that the Chinese Communists have spared no efforts to swallow Taiwan and are trying every means to eradicate the influence of the United States and Japan in Asia.

Lin said he was told that Taiwan's security will be threatened if the government impulsively opens direct trade and transport ties with mainland China. As the head of state of the Republic of China, Lin said, President Lee always bears in mind the nation's security and the safety of the public.

Lin said Lee had repeated earlier warnings to the business community over Beijing's strategies to absorb Taiwan capital into the mainland economy. Lin said local firms should exercise caution when considering investments on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers amounted to US$10.89 billion in September, a single-month high, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Tuesday.
The amount marked a 3.62 percent year-on-year rise, according to ministry tallies. September was also the seventh straight month that export orders broke the US$10 billion mark.

Ministry officials said the record-setting amount of the export orders indicates that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are rosy and robust. "Local stock investors should keep confidence in the market," an official urged.
Information-technology (IT) and communications products remained the best-selling item, garnering US$1.91 billion worth of orders in September, up 9.66 percent from the year-earlier level.
Electronics followed with US$1.86 billion in orders, marking a 23.42 percent year-on-year growth.
September's orders for both IT and communications products and electronics were single-month highs.
Orders for textiles, however, saw a 4.71 percent decline to US$1.28 billion in September.
Chang Yao-chung, director-general of the MOEA's statistics department, said IT, communications and electronics industries have become the driving force of Taiwan's export growth.
As Taiwan is highly advanced in these fields, Chang said, the recent currency fluctuation is not expected to have a significant impact on orders for electronics, IT and communications products.
Noting that the fourth quarter is traditionally a boom season for these three industries, Chang said the current upward trend in export orders is expected to continue in the months ahead.
The United States remained Taiwan's largest source of export orders, contributing US$3.41 billion worth of orders, which marked a 6.57 percent year-on-year gain.
Orders from Europe picked up 13.13 percent to US$1.922 billion, while orders from both Hong Kong and Japan declined, down 0.26 percent and 24.82 percent, respectively.

Chang said a combination of factors, including a slowdown in Japan's IT industry, the fluctuation of currency exchange rates and the lingering effects of the foot-and-mouth disease that hit local hog population in mid-March, has resulted in the double-digit fall in orders from Japan.

Meanwhile, an opinion survey conducted by the MOEA in September found that most local exporters are optimistic about their future business prospects, with 31.45 percent of the respondents expecting their orders to increase in October and 41.54 percent expecting the orders to remain at least at the September's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ACCUSES CHINA OF DOPING OF ITS SWIMMERS, OTHER ATHLETES

TEXT.P: Stunned by unbelievable feats by Chinese swimmers and other athletes recently, Australia has accused mainland China of doping its swimmers and other athletes again and asked for serious investigations in a bid to stop the illegal practices.

Australia will host the next world swimming championships in Perth in January 1998 and its head swimming coach Don Talbot has alleged that "the Chinese are doing things they shouldn't be doing, no doubt about that."
More than two years ago, Australia made similar accusations against mainland Chinese swimmers and other athletes.

In a recent sports competition in Shanghai, mainland Chinese swimmers and stars of track and field and weightlifting made tremendous improvement and performances, which stunned the sports world, including Australia.
As a result, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has sent a drugs expert to mainland China for an investigation into alleged Chinese doping.
Australian swimmers at a national camp in Hobart in Tasmania have been stunned by the extraordinary Chinese times and results filtering through from the Chinese National Games in Shanghai.
"It is very disappointing they (Chinese swimmers) are back on drugs but I plan to use it as a motivation," said Samantha Riley, a swimming star in Australia.
Olympic silver medalist Scott Miller said that if drug-testers do find evidence of drug abuse in mainland China, "they should ban the whole country."
Talbot is worried that even if IOC drug testing is stepped up in China, cheats will escape because they are using undetectable growth hormones.
"If we are serious about drug testing, then you have to do more than pee in a bottle," Talbot told reporters.
He called for the introduction of blood testing to help detect the illegal use of hormones.

In response to comments by Talbot and Australian swimmers, FINA honorary secretary Gunnar Werner said the complaints about mainland Chinese drug-taking came only from the leading swimming countries, including the United States and Australia.
"The problems occur for Australia, the United States and to some extent Canada. Except for them, nobody is that afraid of the Chinese swimmers," he said.
He said the Australian claims of mainland Chinese doping were very natural because Australia will be the venue of the coming world swimming championships.
"I'm a little disappointed with that counter-reaction without any proof. I think they should not start the day after a new world record," he said.

But many foreign observers believe the Shanghai games reflected that mainland Chinese provinces have increased their systematized doping of their athletes after the Atlantic Games in 1996 so that they can win in competitions.

Forbes Carlile, who is a member of the World Swim Coaches' anti-doping commission, said: "They (the mainland Chinese athletes) have had a huge improvement in the last 13 months and how do they explain such dramatic increases in nearly every event in swimming? It will be a battleground in Perth if there are positive tests. We can't stand by and watch this happen."
At the 1996 Atlantic Games, the mainland Chinese won only one swimming medal and blamed their poor results on inadequate training methods.

At the recent Shanghai games, records have been smashed in weightlifting and track and field. Three world records have been set by male lifters and the females have bettered world standards in all eight weight divisions.

In the track and field events, Li Xuemei clocked a phenomenal 10.79 seconds for the 100 meters, which bettered that of US world champion Marion Jones who clocked at 10.83 at the world championships in Athens. Li only clocked 11.2 when she competed in Athens.

In the 1,500-meter event, there were 12 female mainland Chinese athletes who clocked under four minutes. In comparison, the previous fastest time in the world this year was three minutes 58 seconds, set by Briton Kelly Holmes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN GOV'T ISSUES WARNING ON ESCALATING FIRES

TEXT.P: With thick haze continuing to blanket most parts of Sumatra and Kalimantan, the Indonesian government issued another warning Monday that brush and forest fires could escalate.

Indonesian Minister of the Environment Sarwono Kusumaatmadja said Monday the latest evaluation by the Meteorological and Geophysics Agency revealed that the dry season could last for another two weeks. He said this should serve as a warning to people living in fire-prone areas.

"This year's dry season is different from those of previous years. For the first time ever the dry season deviated (from the normal pattern)," Sarwono was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying after a meeting of ministers.
"The extended dry spell may add to the risks already facing the people," he said.
Indonesia has been hit by a severe drought largely blamed on the El Nino effect. The drought has contributed to widespread forest fires.
Fires, meanwhile, have caused choking smog over a large part of Southeast Asia.
Although the government has said the situation was improving, aggravating haze returned to Pekanbaru, Riau on Monday, just as locals had again become accustomed to waking up to blue skies.
Visibility was reduced to only 500 meters Monday, causing the closure of the Simpang Tiga Airport.
Simpang Tiga was among 13 airports across Sumatra that have been closed due to limited visibility since Saturday
After three months, the haze has yet to ease in Palankaraya, Central Kalimantan.
Indonesia's efforts to douse the fires were further boosted Monday as the French and Japanese governments announced they would aid in the fight.
France will donate US$78,600 worth of firefighting equipment, while Japan will send 30 firefighters and two helicopters to Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONSULTATION TO BE BASED ON MUTUAL RESPECT

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said Tuesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should conduct consultations based on mutual respect.
Chang made the remarks in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Chang said that for years Taipei has hoped to promote cross-strait exchanges in a mutually beneficial way so as to advance understanding between the two sides. But both sides have to rely on consultations to solve the problems that arise during the process of exchanges, he said.

Chang said that such consultations have to be based on mutual respect. He criticized Beijing for harboring hostility toward Taiwan, noting that its efforts to isolate the island from the international scene have never ceased.

The Republic of China renounced the use of force to solve cross-strait problems in 1991, when it terminated the Period of National Mobilization for the Suppression of Communist Rebellion, but Beijing has yet to reciprocate, Chang noted.

He expressed the hope that after cross-strait talks resume, Taipei and Beijing will to consult on technical problems so that the interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can be protected. In addition, the talks could also target policy or political problems, he said.

He stressed that the purpose of the talks would be to create a peaceful and stable cross-strait relationship so that both sides can move toward helping each other, adding that this is also the crux of President Lee Teng-hui's statement that "Chinese should help Chinese."
The door for cross-strait talks is always open, Chang said. Although all factors point toward such talks resuming sometime next year, Beijing must first give a positive response, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-RELATED INDEX AND STOCKS PLUMMET IN US

TEXT.P: The recent free fall of the Taiwan stock market is taking a toll on related indexes and stocks in the United States, as the Dow Jones Taiwan Stock Index has almost plummeted nearly one-third from its previous high.

The Taiwan Stock Index dropped another 301 points Monday, adding to an aggregate 900-point decline over the previous six trading sessions. The negative impact was so pervasive that not only Taiwan stocks, but Taiwan-related stocks and indexes in the United States as well, are suffering huge losses.

The Dow Jones Taiwan Stock Index Options, traded in the Pacific Stock Exchange, fell to 175.78 on Monday, approaching its lowest level since its initial trading in January. On Aug. 4, the index stayed at 247.99.

The ROC Taiwan Fund dropped another US$1 1/16 to 9 1/2, just a fraction above its year-to-date low of 9 3/8. Less than one month ago, it stood at US$13 1/2. The drop is equivalent to almost 30 percent of its value.
As for shareholders of the Taiwan Fund, also traded on the New York Stock Exchange, they cannot be pleased with their investment, losing almost US$7, or 25 percent, per share.

The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's American Depository Receipt (ADR), which just started trading on Oct. 8 and was a darling for investors at that time, dropped to US$22 on Monday, a US$11 1/8 loss over seven 7 trading sessions
It is still unclear if and when the Taiwan stock market will recover, but some investors are betting it will recoup its recent losses and start buying calls of Dow Jones Taiwan Stock Index Options.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANKER CAPTAINS IN OIL-SPILL COLLISION ARRESTED

TEXT.P: The captains of the two tankers involved in last Wednesday's collision in the Singapore Strait, which resulted in Singapore's worst-ever oil spill, have been arrested, according to Singapore Maritime Port Authority (MPA).

Jan Sokolowski, a Polish national, captained the Orapin Global, which is owned by Thai International Tankers, headquartered in Bangkok. Michael Chalkitis, a Greek, skippered the Evoikos, which is owned by Zebra Shipping of Cyprus.
The MPA said the 130,000-ton tanker Orapin Global had cut into the wrong lane and was facing oncoming traffic when it overtook another vessel in the Singapore Strait minutes before the collision.
This information came from video footage of radar trackings from its Vessel Traffic Information System, which showed the paths taken by both ships in the final 13 minutes before the collision.

A transcript of the conversation between the radar operator and the officers from the two ships revealed that the Thai-registered vessel was warned three times -- the last time six minutes before colliding with the Evoikos near the boundary which separates eastbound and westbound shipping lanes in the strait, the MPA said.
The Orapin Global, which had no cargo, was moving from east to west in the strait, while the Evoikos was heading east towards Singapore, carrying 120,000 tons of marine fuel oil.
They collided at 8:54 p.m., five kilometers south of Pulau Sebarok island. Visibility was about eight kilometers.
Although investigations were still going on, congestion and lack of visibility can be ruled out as causes of the accident, the MPA said.

In an update on the oil-spill clean-up efforts, the MPA said the slick had spread into both Indonesian and Malaysian waters, but Sentosa Island and the Singapore mainland have not been hit and there had been no disruption to shipping.
Although the spillage is under control, clean-up operations are expected to take several more days as the oil is very thick.
Some 50 boats and over 300 personnel have been involved in the clean-up, which was into its sixth day on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHOLIC ALLIANCE TO PROTEST RELIGIOUS PERSECUTION BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Catholic Alliance of the United States announced Monday that it will hold a prayer and solidarity rally in front of the White House to protest Beijing's persecution of Catholics and other people of faith in mainland China.

The rally, scheduled to begin at 4:30 p.m. on Oct. 27, the eve of Communist Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Washington, will include a candlelight vigil to remember those people persecuted and held captive because of their religious beliefs.

Keith Fournier, president of the Catholic Alliance, said in a news release that in addition to his organization, several other religious groups will also participate in the rally, including the Cardinal Kung Foundation, a group that advocates religious freedom in mainland China.

"China's continued persecution of Catholics and other people of faith dominates today's headlines, literally compelling us to call for action from our president and our elected leaders in Congress on the eve of Mr. Jiang Zemin's visit," Fournier said.
"We are calling all people of faith to a day of prayer and solidarity to show support for our brothers and sisters who are being persecuted for their faith in China," he said.
Fournier urged US President Bill Clinton to firmly address this issue with his Communist Chinese counterpart when he arrives in Washington next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW URGES CONFIDENCE IN TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday that he sees no reason to be pessimistic about Taiwan's economy given that the island's economic fundamentals are sound.

"The stock market is the window of a country's economy and part of the reflection of its economic strength. The local bourse reflects on the economic fundamentals in Taiwan, but it is also subject to a variety of news. The psychological factor plays a role in the stock market," Siew said.

The financial turmoil in Southeast Asia and the plunge of Wall Street last week has eroded investors' confidence, the premier noted. The local bourse slid 1146.38 points in just a week to end at 7316.78 Monday, with the New Taiwan dollar breaking the mark of 30 to the US dollar the same day, dropping to a ten-year low of 30.451.

"Economic problems should be resolved with economic measures. If the impact of the international financial situation on the local bourse is short-term and immense, the government should take some action. If it is long-term, the government should keep its hand out and let the market follow the world trend," Siew said while answering questions at the Legislative Yuan.

On the government's action to bolster the flagging stock market, he said that the government has no intention to intervene in the bourse, but that the moves are aimed at restoring market order and helping the market mechanism.

Siew said that most of the measures announced by Finance Ministry late Monday have been studied for some time. "We believe the moves will help stabilize the stock market. And we hope that they can have long-term effects on the local bourse, not only just one or two days," Siew added.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu announced late Monday several measures to encourage buying and deter selling on the bourse, including increases on margin lending and short sale deposits. The moves proved efficient as the local bourse soared 417.27 points to 7734.05 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPENSATION GIVEN TO FAMILIES OF AIR CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Garuda Indonesia handed symbolic compensation to the beneficiaries of the national flag carrier's Airbus A-300-B4 crash victims, in 10 cities simultaneously on Monday.

The state airline company's spokesman Pujobroto was quoted by state-run Antara news agency as saying Monday that the awarding of the compensation took place in Medan, Pekanbaru, Palembang, Padang, Banda Aceh, Jakarta, Yogyakarta, Surabaya, Semarang, Balikpapan and Denpasar.

Each compensation package consists of Rp$40 million from the Jasa Raharja insurance company, US$200,000 from Asuransi Jasa Indonesia, Rp$5 million in funeral expenses and Rp$3 million in baggage losses.
Meanwhile, in Medan, the relatives of some 57 crash victims Monday received compensation money from PT Garuda Indonesia and PT Jasa Raharja.

The heir of every dead victim received Rp$40 million in insurance claims from PT Jasa Raharja, US$20,000 as a token of sympathy from PT Garuda Indonesia, and Rp$7 million to Rp$8 million in lost luggage compensation.
According to data from Jasa Raharja, there were altogether 77 deceased persons from North Sumatra who were entitled to the compensation payments.
A Garuda airline flight departing from Jakarta for Medan crashed on Sept. 26 this year at Buah Nabara village in Sibolangit district, killing all 234 people onboard.

Suhaimi Pulungan, operations director of PT Jasa Raharja, said the insurance company was paying out insurance claims to the heirs of 116 other victims of the same crash residing in other cities in Indonesia.

Not all the relatives of the 234 victims could received the insurance money on Monday, due to difficulties PT Jasa Raharja was experiencing in establishing contact with some deceased person's families, including those of 34 foreigners, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S CRUCIAL NON-OIL EXPORTS GET 15.8 PERCENT BOOST

TEXT.P: Singapore's crucial non-oil domestic exports shot up by a strong 15.8 percent last month compared to a year ago, boosted by exports of key electronic products to the United States and Europe.
It was the strongest month of growth in exports of made-in-Singapore goods since January 1996.
Analysts and economists said they were "pleasantly surprised" by the unusually strong trade figure, which is a barometer of Singapore's manufacturing sector, according to The Straits Times.
The market had expected 5.9 percent to 6.8 percent growth in September, following August's moderate 5.5 percent growth.
But the better-than-expected performance failed to impress the stock market, and The Straits Times Industrials Index closed down 32.47 points at 1,794.92 Monday.
Last month's S$8.46 billion (US$5.42 billion) worth of non-oil exports marked the fourth consecutive month of positive growth this year.
Releasing the data, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) said, "Growth was reflected in key electronic products, such as semiconductors and printed circuit boards assemblies."
Computer disk drive exports recorded a more moderate growth of 9 percent. Singapore is the world's leading maker of disk drives.

On a three-month moving average basis, non-oil domestic exports rose 9.4 percent in September. This could signal healthy growth in the months ahead, economists said, adding that some volatility could still be expected.
Singapore's non-oil domestic exports to key markets -- the United States, European Union and Hong Kong -- grew 13.6 percent, 16.9 percent and 33 percent respectively.

Made-in-Singapore exports to Malaysia grew 6.7 percent year-on-year, up from August's 3.4 percent, while exports to Thailand rocketed to 27.5 percent, a big improvement on the 0.7 percent decline in August.
A TDB official maintained that the regional currency turmoil had so far not affected Singapore's foreign trade.
Boosted by the strong export performance, Singapore's total foreign trade grew 16.8 percent last month year-on-year to S$34.4 billion (US$22.1 billion).
Total exports rose 15.7 percent to nearly S$17 billion (US$10.9 billion) and total imports rose 18 percent to S$17.4 billion (US$11.2 billion).
Re-exports -- goods shipped through Singapore's ports -- rose 20.6 percent to S$7.3 billion (US$4.7 billion).
Oil exports -- the only negative element in September's trade -- fell 7.6 percent to S$1.2 billion (US$769 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: NUCLEAR POWER PLANT OPERATORS MEET IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Tokyo Center of the World Association of Nuclear Operators (WANO) held a semi-annual meeting in Taipei Tuesday with some 30 experts from Japan, South Korea, India, Taiwan, mainland China, and other countries participating.

A spokesman for the Taiwan Power Company said the WANO was established eight years ago with a coordination center in London and a regional operation center each in Atlanta, Moscow, Paris, and Tokyo. The unofficial organization has 148 members from 35 countries.

In today's meeting, the participants reviewed their various cooperation projects, and discussed new programs and budgets for 1998. They also exchanged experience in the operation of nuclear power plants and visited Taipower's third nuclear power plant in the afternoon. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: HONG KONG IS WELCOME TO OPEN OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday that the government of Hong Kong Special Administrative Region is welcome to set up an office in Taipei.
Siew made the remark at the Legislative Yuan when answering a question by an overseas Chinese legislator elected from Hong Kong.
Siew said his government "would be glad" to see the opening of such an office in Taipei on a reciprocal basis. "But the other side has not asked to do so."
He pointed out that the Statute Governing the Relations with Hong Kong and Macao permits such an arrangement.
The premier said his government is very concerned about the welfare of Hong Kong people, and hopes that they will continue to be able to enjoy freedom and democracy. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ZEMIN'S REMARKS CRITICIZED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Jiang Zemin of mainland China is in no position to compare cross-strait relations with the Civil War of the United States, James Chug, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said here Tuesday.

Jiang, who is scheduled to visit the United States on Oct. 26-Nov. 2, was interviewed in Shanghai by the Washington Post on Oct. 17. In the interview, he quoted from Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address and compared the relations between Taiwan and mainland China with the situations of the American civil war.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the 45th Overseas Chinese Day in Taipei, Chu said the Communist Chinese leader is in no position to make such a comparison. The goals of American Civil War was to liberate slaves and to promote freedom and equality, while Communist China denies its people freedom and equality, he explained.

While many people on the Chinese mainland drive luxurious European cars, 240 million mainland Chinese still live under the "abject poverty line" set by the United Nations, Chu pointed out. The economic development in mainland China has resulted in a wide gap between the rich and the poor. "Is there equality on the Chinese mainland?" he asked.

There is a clear similarity between Abraham Lincoln's idea "of the people, by the people, and for the people" and Dr. Sun Yat-sen's idea in his "Three Principles of the People," Chu said, adding that "Therefore, only the Republic of China is in a position to promote freedom and equality for the Chinese people," he stressed. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 19TH PACIFIC PRIVATE SCHOOL EDUCATION CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The 19th Congress of the Pan-Pacific Association of Private School Education (PAPE) is slated to take place on Oct. 27-30 in Taipei.

Around 400 educators, scholars and experts from the Republic of China and 13 other countries and areas in the Pan-Pacific region are expected to take part in the four-day conference to be held at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, according to the Republic of China Private School Association, sponsor of the congress.

During the meeting, the participants will exchange experiences on private education and work out ways to increase cooperation among PAPE member-countries to promote the development of private education in the Pan-Pacific region.
President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew have been invited to speak at the opening ceremony and dinner banquet on Oct. 27. respectively.

Papers and reports to be presented during the meeting will include: "Do Gifted and Talented Approaches Work for the Disadvantaged" by Dr. Henry M. Levin of the United States; "Anytime/Anyplace Learning Increases Opportunities for Lifelong Education and Training" by Dr. Richard H. Lytle of the US; "Resume of the Professional Background, Experience and Training" by Dr. H.R. Keels of the US; and "Vocational and Technological Education Reforms in Taiwan" by Dr. Louis K. Chang of the ROC; "Canadian Private Schools Respond to New Demands" by Graham Baldwin of Canada; "Quality Diversity And Choice: Strengthening Australian Education through the Private Sector" by Dr. Peter W. Harris of Australia; "Reform and Private Education in the United States" by Andrew W. Corcoran of the US; and "Sustainable Excellence for Thai Private Education in the 21st Century" by Dr. Leo Visith Srivichairatana of Thailand.

PAPE, which has its headquarters in Tokyo, was jointly established by private education associations of the region in November, 1979, with the purpose of strengthening exchanges among member-countries and promoting the development of private education in the region.

PAPE currently has 13 members -- ROC, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Canada, Thailand, the Philippines and Singapore. In addition, delegates from Macau will attend the conference for the first time as observers.

Katsuaki Hirukoshi of Japan currently serves as PAPE chairman, with Kim Kui Nyeon of South Korea, Anthony Si-an Chen of the ROC and Peter W. Harris of Australia as his deputies. Chen also serves as the chairman of the preparatory committee of the Taipei congress and Lin Cheng-tse, a legsilator, is secretary general.
The ROC, as the host of the 1997 congress, will have the biggest presence at the meeting, with 400 delegates, followed by Japan, with 66, South Korea, with 36 and the Philippines, with 18.
Since its establishment 18 years ago, PAPE has held its annual congress in various member-states and this will be the third time Taipei has hosted the event. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HOST 1998 MATHEMATICS OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has won the right to host the 39th Mathematics Olympiad in July next year, the Ministry of Education (MOE) reported on Tuesday.

This is the first time that the ROC has been granted the right to sponsor an international Olympic academic contests, the ministry said, adding that more than 1,000 hopefuls from 85 countries and areas are expected to take part in the extravaganza.

Chen Chao-ti, dean of College of Science of National Taiwan Normal University, who has many times headed local students to participate in international academic contests, said it's a hard-won achievement for Taiwan to host the event.

It takes 40 years for Romania, which hosted the first Mathematics Olympiad back in 1959, to win the right to host the contest again in 1999, Chen said. Among Asian countries, Japan has not had the opportunity to host the event, while South Korea has been picked to sponsor the contest in the year 2000.

Taiwan began to take part in the annual mathematics competition for senior high school students in 1992. Because of the outstanding performance of ROC students and the strenuous efforts of the domestic mathematics community, Taiwan has managed to win the hosting right, Chen said.
Over the past six years, Taiwan on average ranked 10th in the annual two-day contest. The best record was seen in 1993 when Taiwan garnered the fifth place.

Chen said the contestants are usually senior high school students with special talent in mathematics. The test items are consistently very difficult and mainly aimed at testing the participants' creativity and logic thinking ability.
The contest is purely an academic event completely immune to politics, Chen said, adding that mainland China is expected to send a team to take part in the 1998 Olympiad.

Chen said the MOE and the National Science Council will jointly earmark NT$37.2 million (US$1.25 million) to finance the event, while National Taiwan Normal University will be responsbile for organizing the contest.

A special committee composed of mathematicians from Academia Sinica and National Tsinghua University will be formed to select entries to be recommended by experts from around the world. Contestants will be required to solve six questions within two days.

The Mathematics Olympiad was held for the first time 1959, with the participation of only four countries -- Czechslovakia, Poland, East Germany and host Romania. After more than 30 years of development, the number of participating countries has greatly increased.
There are also international physics and chemistry Olympiads, but they are held separately on different dates, with different participating countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar gained NT$0.164 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$30.615.
The US currency opened at the day's low of NT$30.5 and had a high of NT$31.05. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$665 million. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: RAMOS WANTS CURRENCY ISSUES TO TOP DECEMBER'S ASEAN SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Tuesday expressed support for the proposal of outgoing Secretary-General Ajiit Singh of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to have the current currency problem in Southeast Asia top the agenda when ASEAN heads of government meet in an informal summit in Kuala Lumpur in December.
Ramos told Singh of his support during the latter's farewell call in Malacanang. Singh will be succeeded by Rodolfo Severino.
"I can foresee we will be having serious discussions on the currency problem," Ramos said during the meeting.

Presidential Adviser for Foreign Affairs Apolinario Lozada said Ramos raised the idea of setting up a common fund and facility for ASEAN member-countries in the wake of the weakening of local currencies against the US dollar. The fund would finance the massive infrastructure requirements of less-developed economies in ASEAN.
"Despite our temporary difficulties, we can put up a fund to serve as a guarantee to help these members," he said.

Ramos, who just completed a visit to newly-admitted ASEAN members Myanmar and Laos, said the Philippines is enhancing its political, economic and social ties with these countries to speed up their inclusion into the mainstream of development in ASEAN.

DOC.HEADLINE: PESO HOLDING UP DESPITE PHILIPPINES' LOW FOREX RESERVES

TEXT.P: The Philippine peso appeared to be much stronger than other currencies in Southeast Asia during the past week vis-a-vis the US dollar despite the country's relatively small US dollar reserves, the head of the Philippine Central Bank said Tuesday.

Speaking during a Legislative-Executive Development Advisory Council meeting in Malacanang to an audience of Cabinet officials, legislators and representatives of the business community, Central Bank Governor Gabriel C. Singson said, "The peso has held its ground better than many currencies in the region despite having the smallest dollar reserves."
As of Sept. 30 this year, the country's Gross International Reserves (GIR) stood at US$10.9 billion.
As of December 1996, Singapore had Southeast Asia's largest GIR at US$75.7 billion; followed by Thailand, US$38.6 billion; Malaysia, US$26.9 billion; and Indonesia, US$19.3 billion.

"I believe the Philippine economy is holding up reasonably well during a period of tremendous financial stress in the region. Provided that prudent financial policies are maintained and structural reforms are sustained, the economy will be able to recover rapidly from the current crisis," Singson said.

Singson said on the basis of "sustained good underlying economic fundamentals," the recovery of the peso is "already long overdue" but being held back by continuing weakness in neighboring currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL'S COMMENT ON CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Beijing will inevitably resume its dialogue with Taipei after having taken a wrong policy toward Taiwan, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday.

Chiao Jen-ho, secretary general of the SEF, said in an interview with CNA that consultation and contacts are the best way to promote mutual understanding and alleviate hostility between the two sides. He declined to comment on President Lee Teng-hui's recent prediction that cross-strait dialogue would resume in February, three years after Communist Chinese leader Jiang Zemin issued his "eight-point" policy toward Taiwan.

Chiao said Taiwan can not accept any precondition for the resumption of cross-strait dialogue, when he was asked to comment on Jiang's recent remark that the two sides can talk anything under the principle of "one China." Jiang made the remark a few days before he leaves for an official visit to Washington this weekend. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION GROWING STEADILY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index reached 133.86 in September, a hike of 9.4 percent over the same month of 1996, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs Tuesday.

Chang Yao-chung, director general of the Statistics Department of the MOEA, said the production of metal machinery, information and electronics products, chemicals, and daily necessities grew steadily over the past year. The production of electrical and electronics equipment in September was 25 percent more than a year earlier.
He said however that the possible impact of recent fluctuations in the Taiwan foreign exchange and stock markets on industrial production deserve special attention. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS MAKE FORBES WORLD LIST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Jeniffer Huang & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan companies have made Forbes magazine's list of the world's top 100 small-sized enterprises for their commendable performances in returns on investment, transactions and profit growths.

The most recent issue of Forbes ranked CMC Magnetics, a cassette tape manufacturer; Primax Electronics, a computer peripherals maker; and Taiwan Mask, a processor of semiconductor-related products, as the world's 21st, 75th and 89th best small-sized enterprises, respectively.

All of the top 100 companies had annual turnovers of between US$5 million and US$500 million. They were cited for posting investment return rates of no less than 11 percent in the most recent year, and all registered steady growth in their transactions and profit margins, according to the magazine.
Firms from 32 countries and areas made the top-100 list, with Britain leading the array with 16, followed by Canada with 11.

According to the Forbes survey, CMC Magnetics posted a net profit of US$19.3 million as of the end of 1996, as compared with a transaction record of US$98 million and a market value of US$1.12 billion. Its latest investment return rate reached 16.3 percent, and its price-earning ratio topped 59.9. Its profit per share averaged US$0.06 in the most recent year, with this expected to reach US$0.13 next year. Its latest stock price was US$3.20 per share.

Primax Electronics' net profit was US$17.9 million, as compared with a transaction record of US$209 million and a market value of US$490 million. Its latest investment return rate topped 27.6 percent, and its price-earning ratio reached 24.7. Its profit per share averaged US$0.13 in the most recent year, with this expected to improve to US$0.15 next year. Its latest stock price was US$3.15 per share.

Taiwan Mask posted a net profit of US$16.8 million, as compared with a transaction volume of US$44 million and a market value of US$847 million. Its latest investment return rate was a whopping 46.1 percent, with its price-earning ratio reaching 44.4. Its profit per share averaged US$0.13 in the most recent year, with this expected to climb to US$0.21 next year. Its latest stock price was US$5.84 per share.

The top five companies on the Forbes list were the Netherlands' Aalberts Industries, Sweden's Allgon, France's Altran Technologies, Britain's Andrews Sykes Group and Indonesia's Argha Karya, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT OFFICIALS CLEARED OF ESPIONAGE CHARGES

TEXT.P: Two former Macau-based Kuomintang (KMT) officials were cleared of espionage charges on Tuesday by the Taiwan High Court and were immediately released on bail.
The court ruled that there is no positive and reinforcing evidence other than the defendants' confessions to connect Wu Taoming and Chang Lu-chung with charges of spying for mainland China.

Although the defendants confessed to the investigators earlier in the proceedings, a panel of three judges said that since Chang and Wu backed away from the confessions during the trial and since it is well-provided in ROC law that defendants should not be convicted solely on a confession alone, there was insufficient evidence for a conviction.

Even if the defendants did pass to Beijing information they learned at the KMT 14th National Congress as the prosecution claimed, they could not be convicted, because information released by the KMT, a political group, is not considered "state secret" and is thus not protected by the espionage law.

After handing down the judgment, the court freed Wu and Chang on bonds of NT$200,000 and NT$100,000 (US$6,666 and US$3,333), respectively and prohibited them from leaving the country, pending the possibility of an appeal by the prosecution in Taiwan's Supreme Court.

Prosecutor Chang Ching-yun, who led the government's case against Wu and Chang, and Investigation Bureau official Chang Fu-hsiung, who conducted the inquiry into the case, expressed surprise at the not-guilty verdict, but refused to say whether they would appeal.

Huang Yao-yu, KMT director general for mainland operations, would not comment on the judgment, although another senior KMT official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that his party never had any intention of prosecuting the case but that law enforcement authorities had insisted on bringing the case to court.

Wu, alias Ng Wah, and Chang, were KMT officials posted in Macau who were arrested on Feb. 27 in Taiwan by the Investigation Bureau on charges of leaking "military secrets" to Beijing, including a list of KMT secret agents operating in mainland China.
The two defendants were jubilant at Thursday's ruling, saying that the court has vindicated their claims of innocence.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR VETERAN JOURNALIST SCHEDULED FOR WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: A memorial service for veteran journalist Ouyang Chun will be held at the Hsin Yi Club of the Combined Services Force in Taipei on Wednesday morning.
Chun, who was a journalist for some 60 years, died of pancreatic cancer in Taipei on Oct. 6 at the age of 81.

Until his death, he was publisher and director of the News Mirror Weekly, a magazine devoted to journalism. During his long career, he also worked at various newspapers, including the Central Daily News, the China Times, the China Daily News and the Taiwan Shin Wen Daily News.

He also taught journalism at several universities, including National Taiwan Normal University, National Cheng Chi University, Chinese Culture University, Tsing Hua University and the World University of Journalism and Communications.
The memorial service is being jointly sponsored by some 40 journalist associations, newspapers, news agencies and universities.

Liu Shau-tang, publisher of the Biographical Literature magazine, will speak on Chun's life and career at the service, while memorial songs will be sung by the choir of the World University of Journalism and Communications. By H.C.M.)

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA RELEASES POLICE SUICIDE STATISTICS

TEXT.P: A total of six policemen have committed suicide so far this year, according to statistics released by the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

Meanwhile, an NPA official said that from the beginning of 1991 to Oct. 20 this year, 59 policemen have committed suicide, a figure which breaks down to 15 in 1991, four in 1992, nine in 1993, 10 in 1994, six in 1995, nine in 1996 and six to date this year.

He said that the police suicide ratio is slightly higher than that of the general populace, pointing out that in 1996, the police suicide rate was 10.99 officers out of every 100,000, while the figure for the general populace was 7.3 persons out of every 100,000.
The NPA official described emotional problems and work pressure as being the two major reasons for the higher rate of suicide among police officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS: THIS IS TO REPLACE ITEM-23. TKS

TEXT.P: President Jiang Zemin of mainland China is in no position to compare cross-strait relations with the Civil War of the United States, James Chu, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said here Tuesday.

Jiang, who is scheduled to visit the United States on Oct. 26-Nov. 2, was interviewed in Shanghai by the Washington Post on Oct. 17. In the interview, he quoted from Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address and compared the relations between Taiwan and mainland China with the situations of the American civil war.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the 45th Overseas Chinese Day in Taipei, Chu said the Communist Chinese leader is in no position to make such a comparison. The goals of American Civil War was to liberate slaves and to promote freedom and equality, while Communist China denies its people freedom and equality, he explained.

While many people on the Chinese mainland drive luxurious European cars, 240 million mainland Chinese still live under the "abject poverty line" set by the United Nations, Chu pointed out. The economic development in mainland China has resulted in a wide gap between the rich and the poor. "Is there equality on the Chinese mainland?" he asked.

There is a clear similarity between Abraham Lincoln's idea "of the people, by the people, and for the people" and Dr. Sun Yat-sen's idea in his "Three Principles of the People," Chu said, adding that "Therefore, only the Republic of China is in a position to promote freedom and equality for the Chinese people," he stressed. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: US ASSURES TAIPEI OF NO HARM FROM DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The US authorities have repeatedly assured Taipei that the upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland China counterpart, Jiang Zemin, will not harm the Republic of China's interests, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.

Hu, who has just ended a 14-month stint as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the United States and returned this week to Taipei to assume his new post, said that even if Taiwan is mentioned in the Oct. 29 Clinton-Jiang summit in Washington, D.C., he doesn't believe it will lead to any break in Washington's present policy toward Taiwan.

"A basic understanding between Taipei and Washington is that the US will not sacrifice Taiwan's interests in its engagement with Beijing, and will not make any decision that might `surprise' our government and people," Hu said in answer to an inquiry by Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party at a Legislative Yuan plenary session.
Hu said as far as he knows, Washington would rather not talk about Taiwan during the summit, while Beijing is believed to want to raise the issue.

Even if Beijing insists on talking about Taiwan, Hu said he believes that both the US and mainland China will try their utmost during the summit to "seek consensus in their differences," so as to enhance mutual understanding, which will lead to better relations between the two sides.
He added that if Washington and Beijing can "reach consensus in their differences," relations between Washington and Taipei will actually be improved.

He reiterated Taipei's stance of seeking a parallel existence with Beijing on an equal footing in the international community, and of the desire for continuing active and cordial relations between the ROC and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS VINCENT SIEW'S INNOCENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Tainan branch of the Taiwan High Court on Tuesday rejected an appeal filed by former legislative election candidate Trong Chai which accused Premier Vincent Siew, Chai's rival in the 1995 legislative elections in Chiayi City, of violating the Election and Recall Law.
The judges rejected Chai's appeal, saying that Siew, who narrowly beat Chai to win the single seat in Chiayi City, was innocent.
Chiayi City was one of the most hotly contested constituencies around the island in the 1995 legislative elections.

Siew, representing the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), defeated Chai, who represented the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the elections to mark the first triumph in legislative elections for the KMT in Chiayi City, which is a stronghold of DPP and other non-KMT forces.
Chai, a former politics professor in the US, was elected the only legislator representing Chiayi City in 1992 elections.
Following this setback, Chai filed a lawsuit with the Chiayi District Court against Siew, accusing Siew of disseminating misleading propaganda against him which led to his eventual defeat.

The Tainan High Court upheld the verdict handed down by judges of the Chiayi District Court stating that Siew was innocent, citing the fact that all Siew's "propaganda" against Chai was later verified as truth rather than fabrication.

The "propaganda" included Siew's assertions that Chai had a NT$1 million investment in a local cable television network and a US$50,000 investment in a motel in the United States, as well as holding a position as a professor at a US university.
Although Chai's appeal was rejected, he has the right to reappeal, the judges said.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA EXPERIENCING SEXUAL AWAKENING

TEXT.P: Prostitution, once almost extinct at the height of Communist control, is now booming in most mainland Chinese cities and towns and the competition for clients can be fierce, according to a report by the mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald.

In a dispatch from Beijing on Tuesday, the daily's correspondent David Lague reported sex has caught on as a marketing tool in the once prudish mainland China as economic reforms overlap with an increasingly liberal society.

Salespeople are taking advantage of the increasing sexual awareness of modern mainland Chinese only a generation after Maoist propaganda attempted to suppress eroticism among the masses, the daily said.

In presenting a paper at an international population conference in Beijing last week, a researcher at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences said although the ultra-leftists of the Cultural Revolution had branded sex sinful, this attitude is now fading fast, the daily reported.
"Along with the popularization of scientific knowledge on sex and opening up of sex culture, sex is no longer synonymous with dirt, obscene ideas or animal desire," the researcher said.

In a survey of 911 couples in Shanghai, the researcher said, 62.5 percent of women aged between 50 and 64 had never heard of or experienced orgasm but only 24.4 percent of women aged 30 or under gave the same answer.

"Among the older women, 61.7 percent stated that they had rarely experienced any pleasure in recent sexual life, if at all, while only 19.3 percent of the younger women made the same statement," he said. The daily said younger people in mainland China are expected to be more responsive to sales campaigns with sexual themes.
In mainland China as elsewhere, there is now a debate about the exploitation of human sexuality, particularly when it dwells on the female form, the daily reported.
For some mainland Chinese, the loosening of social and political controls over sex and sensuality has transformed their lifestyles and the atmosphere of many towns and cities, the daily said.
It is well known in Beijing that many gay men meet at Dongdan park in the center of the city, although homosexuality is still not readily accepted in the wider community, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AREA OF BETEL PALM CULTIVATION QUADRUPLED IN TAIWAN IN TEN YEARS

TEXT.P: Compared to ten years ago, the area of arable land given over to betel palm cultivation in Taiwan has quadrupled to 56,581 hectares, producing 1.6 times more betel nut, at 160,000 tons, while the market value has trebled to NT$13.61 billion (US$453.66 million) and its proportion of the total agricultural\livestock sector has risen from 1.6 to 4.2 percent, according to statistics issued on Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The crop from the betel palm, the betel nut, chewed mainly by Taiwan's blue collar workers for its mild stimulant effect, has a retail price of about NT$8 apiece on average, is about four times the wholesale price.
The data also shows that in 1995, about 10 percent of Taiwan's population aged 15 and over chewed betel nut, about 1.6 percent fewer than the previous year.

However, the DGBAS pointed out that despite this downward trend in the percentage of consumers, the incidence of oral cancer, widely believed to be a disease related to the habit of betel nut chewing, has risen, claiming the lives of 4.9 persons per 100,000 of the population in 1996, an increase from the 1.4 persons per 100,000 recorded ten years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIYIH CONTRACTED TO MAKE LIGHTS FOR S-92 CHOPPERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Taiyih Industrial Co. on Tuesday struck a deal with Luminator Aircraft Products Co. of the United States to jointly produce lighting systems for S-92 helicopters to be made in Taiwan and other Asian countries, according to sources from the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).
Taiyih Chairman Wu Chun-yih and Luminator Chairman John Hartzler jointly inked the cooperative agreement Tuesday at the IDB, with IDB Director General Wang Ya-kang witnessing.
The Tainan-based Taiyih, which also maintains a large-scale production outlet in mainland China, is one of the leading manufacturers of motorbike and automobile parts in Taiwan.

Under the agreement, Taiyih will invest NT$100 million (US$3.3 million) in the joint venture for the production of various lights for S-92 helicopters, including search, landing, glare shield, utility and thunderstorm lights, while Luminator will transfer its production know-how to Taiyih, IDB officials said.

Taiwan's Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) signed a strategic alliance with the US-based Sikorsky Helicopter Corp., one of the world's biggest manufacturers of helicopters, in mid-October for industrial cooperation.
Under the alliance, AIDC and Sikorsky will jointly develop in Taiwan the technologically advanced cockpit section of the S-92 mid-sized transport helicopter.
Other purposes of the cooperation include joint exploration of the booming aerospace spare parts market in the Asian-Pacific region.

Commercial production of the 20-seat S-92 choppers, currently being developed under concerted efforts from Taiwan, the United States, Japan, Brazil, Spain and mainland China, is expected to begin in 1999.
The market of S-92s will reach 700 units in the next 20 years worldwide, with Taiyih enjoying a sales share of US$200 million by the year 2002, according to Sikorsky estimates.

A study by Boeing predicted that production of passenger aircraft will top some US$50 billion annually in the next several years, with the market of interior decoration and facilities reaching US$1.2 billion, which includes a US$150 million market for lighting systems.
Sikorsky, which maintains 45 sales operations worldwide, became the 49th major multinational firm and first helicopter maker to sign a strategic alliance with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Meanwhile, the head of Taiyih said the cooperation with Luminator will upgrade the company's levels of production toward aerospace lights and lighting systems for railways and mass rapid transport systems.
Luminator has also authorized Taiyih as its sole agent in the Asia-Pacific area for its advanced lighting/signal systems and night vision systems for aircraft and ships, said Wu.
