DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH PRESIDENT BECOMES CAUTIOUS IN ENGAGING ROC: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Czech President Vaclav Havel has become more cautious in engaging the Republic of China under pressure from Czech business people hoping to enter the vast mainland Chinese market, Hsieh Hsin-ping, the ROC's chief representative to the Central European country said on Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Hsieh said although the Czech Republic attaches great importance to Taiwan's economic strength and political democratization, it also sets its eyes on the immense mainland market.

After some Czech business heavyweights expressed their dissatisfaction with Havel's friendly policy and gestures toward Taiwan, Hsieh said, the Czech president has become more cautious in dealing with affairs related to Taiwan.
"We should face up to this phenomenon and step up efforts to work out reciprocal cooperative projects to sustain friendly ties between the two countries," Hsieh told the lawmakers.
For instance, Hsieh said, the government should encourage state-run enterprises to cooperate with the Czech Republic's Skoda Heavy Machinery Co.
"By so doing, we can help Havel convince Czech businessmen and politicians of the benefit in developing closer ties with the ROC," Hsieh noted.

The ROC's de facto ambassador to Prague said the Czech Republic keenly welcomes Taiwan investment. Hualon Textile Co., one of Taiwan's largest textile companies, has set up a fabric production facility in the Czech Republic, and the state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. has signed a cooperative accord with the Prague-based Aero Vodochody Co. on joint production of small aircraft.
"These two examples indicate that there is ample room for the growth of trade and economic cooperation between our two countries," Hsieh said.
The Czech Republic recognizes Beijing but maintains friendly ties with Taiwan. Vice President Lien Chan managed to make a private visit to the Czech Republic in June 1995.

Asked about the possibility of President Lee Teng-hui visiting Prague, Hsieh said he has never presented a formal request for such a visit, but added that the Czech government's basic stance is that it would not stop any person from taking a vacation on its territory.

The ROC opened a representative office in Prague in January 1992, while the Czech representative office in Taipei became operational in November 1993. The Czech Republic was the first Central European country to set up a representative office in Taiwan.

Havel, a poet-turned-politician, has been friendly toward Taiwan. His first wife, who died a few years ago, once visited Taipei. Havel's second wife was scheduled to visit Taiwan earlier this month, but canceled her travel plan at the last minute because of pressure from Beijing.
Havel once used his speech to the annual United Nations General Assembly debate to deliver an appeal for Taiwan's bid to rejoin the world body.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DEPRECIATION MAY RESULT IN BIGGER TRADE GAP WITH US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar's depreciation in recent weeks may result in Taiwan scoring a record high trade surplus with the United States, according to the US Department of Commerce.

The newest statistics released by the Commerce Department show that Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$7.87 billion with the United States in the first eight months of this year, making it America's sixth-largest source of trade surplus after Japan, mainland China, Germany, Canada and Mexico.

The figure reflects a 9.1 percent increase over the same period of 1996 and a sharp contrast to the sluggish performance by the other three Asian dragon economies -- Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea.

The Commerce Department attributed Taiwan's increased trade gap with America to the economic recovery in both countries, which it said has led to strong demand in the United States and booming exports by Taiwan.

The figure, though already a record high compared with those contracted in the same period over the past eight years, may further widen for September and October, due to the sharp depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against a robust US dollar in recent weeks, observers said.
Taiwan registered a record high trade imbalance of US$16 billion with the United States in 1987, when the local currency stood around 35-40 against the greenback.

The figure continued to narrow following the New Taiwan dollar's gradual appreciation since 1990. Taiwan's trade gap with the United States dropped by 50 percent during the period between 1989 and 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TWO-WAY TRADE CONTINUES TO CLIMB

TEXT.P: As of Oct. 18, Taiwan's two-way trade this year amounted to US$187.31 billion, up 7.5 percent or US$13.9 billion over the same period of the previous year, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Wednesday.

Taiwan exported US$96.89 billion worth of merchandise between Jan. 1 and Oct. 18 this year, while importing US$90.42 billion in goods, leaving a trade surplus of US$6.47 billion in favor of the island, according to officials from the MOF Department of Statistics.
Exports in this period rose 5.1 percent or US$4.75 billion compared to the same period of 1996, with imports climbing 10.2 percent or US$8.34 billion over the year-earlier level, the officials noted.
In the first half of October, Taiwan's exports soared 8.1 percent to US$7.11 billion, while imports dropped 7.9 percent to US$6.11 billion, leaving the country a trade surplus of US$1 billion.

The MOF officials attributed the continuing rise of exports to the beginning of the peak season for electronics businesses, and the sharp decrease in imports to a reduction in the amount of crude oil and weaponry brought to the island this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SPOKESMAN DENOUNCES DPP HEAD'S `THREE-LINKS' PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Tsai Pi-huang gave Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang a good dressing-down on Wednesday for Hsu's proposal to conduct negotiations on "three direct links" -- trade, postal and transport -- with mainland China.
Hsu made the proposal during a visit in Paris on Oct. 16, in response to an offer by Beijing to hold bilateral dialogue focusing on peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

DPP Public Relations chief Sissy Chen, who accompanied Hsu on his trip, said the DPP is willing to shelve the sensitive sovereignty issue and talk with Beijing on the establishment of postal, trade and transport links between Taiwan and mainland China

Tsai blasted Hsu's proposal, accusing him of "dancing to Beijing's tune," and of being "ignorant of the danger to Taiwan residents," adding that only a very few people in Taiwan would agree to such unconditional links.
The proposal also reveals Hsu's "limited" style, which shows his inability to be a national leader, Tsai commented.

Citing the major factors underlining the risk to Taiwan in opening the three direct links with the mainland at present, Tsai noted Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, the fact that such links would involve not only economic, but political and security issues, and the fact that Taiwan residents' common wish of opening direct air links with the mainland is subject to certain conditions.

Participation of government officials from both sides of the Taiwan Strait is required to talk about any kind of links, Tsai noted, pointing out that such talks have been impossible so far because of Beijing's insistence that no talks can take place unless Taipei accepts Beijing's "one country, two systems" arrangement, and Taipei recognizes Beijing as the central government of all of China.

Before Beijing ends its hostility toward Taipei and before Taiwan gets concrete assurances of its security, talks on "three direct links" will only create a false sense of rapprochement across the strait, confuse the international community and risk a lessening of Taiwan's vigilance, Tsai warned.

From the points of view of national interests, security and the people's common wish, the best course of cross-strait action for the moment should be a resumption of talks to seek solutions to technical problems arising from increased exchanges across the strait, and to raise the issue of finding ways to bring cross-strait hostility to an end, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT UNLIKELY TO BRING NEW STATEMENTS ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton is unlikely to make any new statements on the subject of Taiwan when he meets with his communist Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at their Oct. 29 summit in Washington, Harvey Feldman, senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, said Tuesday.

Feldman told the conservative think tank's roundtable meeting for the Asia-Pacific press in Washington that he believes Jiang will raise the issue of US relations with Taiwan at the Washington summit.

More specifically, he said, Jiang is likely to call for an end to US arms sales to Taiwan, ask the United States not to support the "splitist" forces in Taiwan, and urge the United States to "agree" to Beijing's claim that "Taiwan is part of China" instead of merely acknowledging the claim without contradicting it.

Feldman, a retired US foreign service officer who had served as the State Department's country director for the Republic of China on Taiwan before Washington shifted diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, said that he doesn't believe the United States will change its position on the subject of Taiwan. "In fact, my understanding is we already assured the ROC that nothing is going to change, as far as US policy is concerned," he said.

Despite Beijing's pressure, the Clinton administration has basically told the mainland Chinese leadership that the United States will not sign a fourth joint communique on the subject of Taiwan at the summit, Feldman said, adding that Jiang can instead expect a reiteration that the United States will follow the "traditional one-China policy."
On whether Taiwan will be allowed to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) ahead of mainland China, Feldman said the issue is not solely up to the United States to decide.

The United States has adopted a nominal position since the Bush administration that it will not hold Taiwan's entry to the WTO hostage to mainland China's accession. However, there is an apparent consensus among WTO members that Taiwan will have to wait until mainland China gets in, he said.
Feldman pointed out that the United States has not yet reached agreement with Taiwan on its offer regarding WTO accession, and that movement on this front has been "very, very slow."

DOC.HEADLINE: WESLEYAN COLLEGE TO HOST US PREMIERE OF 'THE SOONG SISTERS'

TEXT.P: The US premiere of the Hong Kong motion picture "The Soong Sisters", a docu-drama on the lives of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, Madame Sun Yat-sen, and Madame H.H. Kung, will be held Nov. 11 in Macon, Georgia, the home of Wesleyan College.
All three Soong sisters attended Wesleyan College, which has been invited by Golden Harvest Films, the producer of the movie, to host the premiere.

The film, directed by Mabel Cheung Yuen-ting, was released in Asia in May to a flurry of news coverage. Also in May, Wesleyan was the recipient of a US$6 million anonymous gift in honor of the Soong sisters.

Cheung, who was born and raised in Hong Kong and attended New York University's film school from 1982 to 1984, will be on hand for the opening, which will take place during "Wesleyan Herstory Week," an annual campus-wide celebration of the college's past.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BOX FROM INDONESIAN AIR CRASH FOUND

TEXT.P: The black box flight data recorder from the Garuda Airbus which crashed near the Indonesian city of Medan on Sept. 26, was finally found by a search team on Tuesday, after a search which lasted for 25 days.

A Garuda official said investigators would now be able to hear the entire conversation which took place between the pilot and the air controllers at Medan's Polonia airport prior to the crash which killed all 234 people on board, the worst disaster in Indonesia's aviation history.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN IMMIGRANT NAMED CANDIDATE FOR 1998 BRISBANE ELECTION

TEXT.P: A 22-year-old Taiwan-born immigrant who has lived in Australia for nine years has defeated all contenders to win the nomination of the Liberal Party as its candidate to run in the 1998 Legislative Assembly election in Queensland.
Steven Huang, who has just graduated from the University of Queensland with a degree in politics, is the first Taiwan-born immigrant to be nominated for such an election.
Huang will compete for the constituency of Sunnybank in Brisbane, the third-largest city in Australia.
There are at least 20,000 immigrants from Taiwan currently living in Brisbane, Gold Coast and other Queensland cities.
Huang was unavailable for comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MANUFACTURER RECALLS DEFECTIVE ADAPTERS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Compal Electronics Inc., a publicly listed adapter-manufacturing company in Taiwan, said on Wednesday it has resolved issues related to a shipment of defective AC adapters to US-based Dell Computer Corp.
Compal made the statement after a CNA dispatch from Washington said Dell is voluntarily recalling AC adapters supplied with its Latitude LM notebook computers and port replicators worldwide.

A Dell spokesman was quoted as telling the CNA that the adapters being recalled were all made in Taiwan by Compal Electronics Inc. He said Dell has received 111 reports of the adapters' connector pins breaking off from the adapter and remaining in the power cord, posing a shock hazard, but that no injuries have been reported.

Commenting on the report, Compal said the defective AC adapters were shipped to the United States a few months ago. "We have already supplied Dell with non-defective replacement adapters and no faulty adapters have been found in any subsequent shipments," a company spokesman said.

The spokesman admitted that Compal has lost slightly more than US$1 million for the defective shipment, adding that the loss will be listed in the company's financial report for the third quarter of this year.

The recall report caused dramatic falls in prices for Compal stock and other related electronics issues in early-morning trading on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, although it managed to recover some ground in the late session.

Dell is recalling the adapters in the United States and throughout the world through its resellers. The black AC adapters are four inches long by 2.25 inches wide and have one attached cord and one detachable power cord.
Dell sold the AC adapters with the Latitude LM notebook computers and port replicators, but they were also sold separately in the US for about US$39.

Dell said it is recalling the faulty adapters in response to concerns raised by the US Consumer Product Safety Commission and urged its customers to immediately stop using the defective adapters and contact the company to receive a free replacement.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices slid on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 41.58 points to finish at 7692.47.
The bourse opened at 7752.32 and experienced a high of 7835.55 and a low of 7529.36.
Losers outnumbered gainers 335 to 113, with 19 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$160.55 billion (US$5.26 billion).
Financial shares rose the most at 4.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.

Electrical engineering issues fell 3.7 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares at 2.5 percent; textile issues at 1.6 percent; cement stocks at 1.5 percent; construction shares at 1.3 percent; and foodstuff shares at 1.0 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELL ANNOUNCES RECALL OF MADE-IN-TAIWAN AC ADAPTERS

TEXT.P: The US Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Tuesday that Dell Computer Corp., in cooperation with the commission, is voluntarily recalling the AC adapters supplied with its Latitude LM notebook computers and port replicators.
A spokesman with Dell of Round Rock, Texas told CNA in a telephone interview that the adapters being recalled were all made in Taiwan.
He said Dell has received 111 reports of the adapters' connector pins breaking off from the adapter, posing a shock hazard. But no injuries have been reported, he added.
The recall will cover more than 233,000 AC adapters.

Dell's direct sales force, Internet ordering site and toll-free number sold the AC adapters with the Latitude LM notebook computers and port replicators from June 1996 to October 1997. The adapters also were sold separately in the United States for about US$39.
The adapters are black, four inches long by 2.25 inches wide, and have one attached cord and one detachable power cord.
The safety commission said in a press release that consumers should stop using these AC adapters immediately and contact the company to receive a free replacement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DEPRESSANTS SAID LINKED TO SLEEP, SEX PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: A survey released Tuesday indicated anti-depressants are likely responsible for sexual dysfunction and sleep disturbances in more than one million Canadians.
The survey of 1,300 people across Canada suggested that about three million Canadians suffer from depression and one-third of them seek professional help.

"If patients are asked if they have a sexual problem, studies have quoted between 50 and 90 percent of men and women taking anti-depressants as saying they have sexual problems," said Dr. Pierre Assalian, the executive director of the Canadian Sex Research Forum.
The study indicated that Canadians taking anti-depressants are three times more likely than the general public to report that they "always" experience a sex-related problem.

Those problems range from lack of desire or interest in sex to difficulty obtaining and maintaining an erection. Assalian noted that the study suggested that the overwhelming majority -- more than 90 percent -- of patients on anti-depressants did not realize their medication was contributing to their sleep and sex problems.
The highest rates of depression occur among adults aged 20 to 57. Females have higher rates of clinical depression than males by a ratio of two to one.
The survey indicated that 6 percent of the general public say they "always" experience at least one sex problem and have trouble sleeping at least once a week.
But four times as many people -- about 24 percent of those who take anti-depressants -- say that's their experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CURRENCY CRISIS SEEN HITTING AUSSIE EDUCATIONAL EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The currency crisis in Southeast Asia is likely to hit Australia's US$2.2 billion educational exports, the mass circulation newspaper The Australian said Wednesday.
The currency crisis started in Thailand and spread to Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines and South Korea.
The Taiwan currency has also fallen to a ten-year low this week.
Australian universities are worried that some international students from Southeast Asia may suffer financial hardships during their study in Australia.
While feedback is still sketchy at this stage, many schools are monitoring the situation, the daily reported.

The daily said any downturn in enrollments would be a blow for Australian universities, because many of them are desperate to lure more overseas students to compensate for cuts in the federal education budget.
The number of foreign students, particularly from Asia, has also shown signs of declining because of the racial debate sparked by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson.
The daily reported that the Pauline Hanson-inspired race debate is deterring Asian students from choosing Australia as a study destination.
The financial upheaval in Southeast Asia has seen the currencies of Thailand and Indonesia lose 33 percent of their value against the US dollar in recent months.

The daily quoted Denis Blight, chief executive of IDP Australia, a major promoter of educational exports, as saying that he expects the Southeast Asian situation to have only a short-term impact on Australia's educational exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: SE ASIAN CURRENCY CRISES SEEN AFFECTING WIDER REGION

TEXT.P: The currency and stock market crisis now hitting East and Southeast Asian countries is likely to also affect Japan, mainland China, South Korea and Australia, according to a market analyst.

Simon Ogus, executive director for Asian economies with the investment bank SBC Warburg in Hong Kong, said the Asian crisis will depress global growth by about a tenth next year, representing foregone activity of US$118 billion -- including about US$3 billion in Australia.
As investors continued a big sell-off in some regional markets Tuesday, Ogus said the crisis was set to go deeper and wider.

He said the epicenter of the economic earthquake -- Southeast Asia -- could no longer expect to escape with a mere slowdown and was now heading for a "full-blown recession and a full-blown banking crisis."
He said overall the slowdown would cut the expected rate of global economic growth by 0.4 of a percentage point next year or about one-tenth of the growth forecast by the International Monetary Fund.
He estimated growth in Australia would be slashed by 0.8 of a percentage point next year.
He said investors were continuing to desert the region because Asian governments were failing to address their problems credibly.
Ogus predicted the biggest economies of Asia -- Japan, South Korea and mainland China -- would suffer a market slowdown because of the current crisis in Southeast Asia.

He said that the economy of North Asia most vulnerable to contagion from Southeast Asia is South Korea, which is suffering a wave of corporate bankruptcies that are in turn damaging bank balance sheets.

"Korea is a big boy; if it spreads to Korea, it spreads to China, and the world has a problem," Ogus said. Korea would be injured because its exports to Southeast Asia would slow and because it would lose money on loans to Southeast Asia.

He said mainland China could be infected through two channels. First demand for its exports will likely slow as Korea and Southeast Asia buy less from it. Second, interest rates in Hong Kong will rise, making it more expensive for mainland Chinese firms to raise funds.
He said Japan is likely to see its economic growth next year depressed by 0.6 of a percentage point, while growth in mainland China was forecast to fall to 7-8 percent from the current 10 percent.

Taiwan has become the latest hit with its currency and stock markets falling after the Central Bank of China gave up defending the New Taiwan dollar. Some analysts believe the Taiwan currency could drop to NT$31 to one US dollar.

Peter Clay, treasury strategist with ABN-Ambro in Sydney, warned that Australia's current account could deteriorate markedly over the coming year, with its deficit blowing out to 5 percent by mid-1998.
He attributed the problem of Australia to the fallout of slow growth in East and Southeast Asia because about 60 percent of its exports now go to the region.
As a result, he said, the Australian dollar is headed for a 5 to 10 percent depreciation.

In Hong Kong, shares continued to sink as new worries emerged about the cost of maintaining the peg of the Hong Kong dollar to the US dollar, with the benchmark Hang Seng Index ending 4.4 percent lower Tuesday.
South Korea saw its currency fall further to 924.90 to one US dollar Tuesday, a seven-year low.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei Stock Average closed down 0.49 percent the same day as the stock market reacted coolly to the Japanese government's new economic stimulus package.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE BANKS AMONG THE STRONGEST IN ASEAN REGION

TEXT.P: Singapore banks are among the strongest in the region in terms of size and capabilities compared to their ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) counterparts, said some local bankers and observers.
They questioned the incentives for local banks to form alliances or mergers with other financial institutions within the region, The Straits Times reported Wednesday.
These were some of the views of market players and observers in a mixed reaction to Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's remarks at the East Asia Economic Summit held in Hong Kong last week.
Goh had called for East Asian banks to form strategic alliances among themselves to become strong regional financial institutions so as to better tackle foreign competition.
Besides getting banks to merge within national boundaries, they could hold stakes in other banks within the region to produce stronger regional banks, he added.

In a positive reaction to Goh's call, a senior Singapore banker said that strategic alliances among ASEAN banks would bring about economies of scale and free up Singapore's scarce resources for redeployment to other sectors.
Local banks were not averse to the idea of strategic partnerships with financial institutions in neighboring countries, the daily said.

The report quoted a a Development Bank of Singapore (DBS) spokesman as saying: "Part of DBS' strategy has been to seek out expansion opportunities in the region, whether it is through the opening of branches, establishing subsidiaries or entering into strategic alliances.
"Such alliances for us could take the form of marketing arrangements, joint product developments and joint ventures."

An Overseas Chinese Bank spokesman also said the bank would be open to opportunities to form cross-border alliances when the timing and situation are right, although it did not have any such arrangements to do so now.

At the other end of the scale, however, market observers not too keen on the idea felt that the only tangible benefits that would be derived would be those of a larger size and greater market access, as Singapore banks are already among the strongest in ASEAN.
Furthermore, access to other markets will come about eventually with the liberalization in accordance with the World Trade Organization guidelines, they pointed out.
Hence, such alliances may not do much to boost Singapore banks' efforts to become major Asian financial institutions, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOURTH COMMUNIQUE UNLIKELY: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday the chances are slim that Washington and Beijing will sign a fourth communique in the coming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

Hu said the possibility of a fourth communique is very remote, adding that Washington has repeatedly assured Taipei that the Clinton-Jiang meeting, slated for later this month, will not hurt Taiwan's interests.

Hu told the CNA that Washington has made it clear that the US side will not raise the Taiwan issue during the meeting and that if the mainland Chinese side touches on the issue, Beijing will be asked to subject its wording to the existing limit, under which the US acknowledges Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a part of China, without actually agreeing with it.
He refused to confirm whether ROC National Security Council Secretary General Ting Mao-shih had exchanged opinions with US State Department officials on the summit during an August visit to New York.

Meanwhile, Jan Jyh-horng, head of the Department of Research and Planning under the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, called on the people of Taiwan not to be influenced by Beijing's propaganda and expressed the belief that Washington will not be manipulated by Beijing in the upcoming meeting. Asked when will be an appropriate time for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to rekindle talks, Jan said the doors to a resumption of cross-strait negotiations are always open, but he added that Taiwan will not reopen talks with the mainland if Beijing refuses to drop its insistence on such talks taking place under its "one China" formula.

He said Beijing's insistence on its version of "one China" totally contradicts the consensus reached in a 1995 meeting between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, under which the two sides agreed to interpret the "one China" principle on their own terms.

Questioned on whether Taiwan and mainland China will resume talks in February as President Lee Teng-hui intimated to a group of Japanese reporters last week, Jan said Lee was only trying to say that next spring might be the proper time.
According to Jan, a number of countries, including the US, have expressed the hope that the two sides can reopen talks as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL PROMOTES ROC SME'S TO ASEAN WORKSHOP

TEXT.P: Ni Chang-i, director general of the ROC's Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SME) Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, on Wednesday introduced Taiwan SMEs and Small- and Medium-Sized Industries (SMIs) at an ASEAN workshop being held in Singapore.

The three-day Workshop on Promoting ASEAN SME/SMI Through Private Sector Institutions was jointly sponsored by ASEAN and the United Nations Development Program (UNDP). Some 50 delegates from ASEAN countries attended the workshop which opened on Tuesday.

Ni, who was on an overnight visit, was the only speaker from the ROC to address the workshop on the development and promotion of SME/SMIs in Taiwan and the role of the government and business associations.
Ni pointed out that SMEs are the foundation of the ROC's economic development and also the main source of the ROC's economic vitality.
In recent years, the number of SMEs has expanded to a proportion of about 97.97 percent of the total number of companies in Taiwan, he said.

SMEs have contributed approximately 40 percent of the ROC's industrial output and generated more than 50 percent of the ROC's exports by value. They also provide over 70 percent of employment opportunities in the country.
In view of the current volatile global economy, he noted, SMEs will continue to be major players in the ROC's economic development, he said.
In his address, Ni briefed the ASEAN delegates on the present situation of SMEs and the government's guidance policies and measures for promoting SMEs in the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS ALLOWED TO STUDY AT 73 MAINLAND UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's senior high school graduates can from now on legally study at 73 selected mainland Chinese universities and colleges, according to a new set of regulations unveiled by the Ministry of Education (MOE) on Wednesday governing accreditation of academic degrees conferred by universities or colleges in mainland China.
Under the regulations, the ministry will recognize degrees conferred by schools on the approved list if the recipients have reported their study plans to the MOE in advance.
Nevertheless, the ministry said, certain degrees conferred by some communist ideology-oriented departments at the listed schools will still not be accredited.

Minister of Education Wu Jin said the ministry has considered a combination of factors in preparing the list of approved schools, including academic levels, teaching facilities, the government's mainland policy and manpower planning guidelines, as well as the living conditions in various mainland areas.

Teacher-training universities are excluded from the list because mainland China still focuses heavily on ideological indoctrination when training its teachers, Wu said, adding that schools of Western medicine are also excluded, in line with Taiwan's manpower planning policy which considers Taiwan to have sufficient supplies of trained doctors. In addition, only three mainland schools of traditional Chinese medicine managed to make the list.

Among the listed schools are Beijing University, Chinese People's University, Qinghua University, North China Jiaotong University, Nankai University, Nanjing University, Xiamen University, Shandong University, Fudan University, Beijing University of Traditional Chinese Medicine and Beijing Foreign Studies University.
In fact, many Taiwan students have been traveling to the mainland to receive tertiary education since long before the government released its approved list.

Mainland academic degrees conferred on Taiwan students before Sept. 18, 1992 when the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area was implemented, will still not be recognized, Wu said, adding that those who received mainland degrees between Sept. 18, 1992 and Oct. 22, 1997 will be accredited so long as they can pass a qualifying exam in no more than two attempts.
From Wednesday, no mainland degrees offered to local students by schools not on the approved list will be accredited.
Wu also announced that the government has decided to open local graduate institutes to mainland Chinese college and university graduates.

He said his ministry will coordinate with the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy on mainland China, in drafting regulations to govern mainland college graduates intending to pursue master's or doctoral degrees in Taiwan.
Wu said the ministry will only formulate a legal framework, leaving local universities to decide whether or not and how to recruit mainland graduate students.

Responding to Wu's announcement, Tamkang University, which has maintained close ties with several mainland universities, said it plans to implement a cross-strait exchange program for graduate students.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUGE GRANITE DEPOSITS FOUND IN CENTRAL SULAWESI

TEXT.P: Hugh deposits of natural resources such as granite, lying beneath Galumpang, Buol-Tolitoli regency, Central Sulawesi, could be mined for at least 700 years.

The Indonesian Observer quoted Gumyadi, the regent of Buol-Tolitoli, as saying that the latest mining research found that the granite deposits beneath the regency will last hundreds of years, as long as the mining companies and the residents take care of the environment.

According to Gumyadi, PT Mayorindo Granit, a national mining company based in Jakarta, has found a huge fossilized granite structure measuring 1,250 meters by 300 meters, five meters beneath the surface.
In addition to the national mining companies, geologists from Malaysia are now exploring the granite deposits of Galumpang.
They described the fossilized granite deposits as each being more than a kilometer long and spread across a wide area from the north to the south," the regent said.

Other mining companies, he said, are now intending to open up granite mining areas. A company led by former director of Garuda Indonesia, R.A.J. Lumenta, has confirmed an investment of 30 billion rupiah to build a granite rock processing plant, capable of handling 300 cubic meters per month, in Galumpang.
Gumyadi said granite mining will become one of the biggest contributors to the local economy.
"I am optimistic that the granite deposits here are very promising for the future," he added.
The granite market in Europe today is in good condition, while domestically, a square meter of granite rocks is priced at 600,000 rupiah, ten times more expensive than marble rocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.404 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$30.211.
The greenback opened at 30.690 and was traded between 30.201 and 30.690.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$453.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO HELP HANDLE INDONESIA'S MONETARY CRISIS

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong on Tuesday pledged to extend assistance to Indonesia to complete the efforts of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in gaining back the people's trust in the Indonesian economy.

Indonesian President Suharto told Goh of the ongoing monetary crisis here, Minister/State Secretary Moerdiono said at the Merdeka Palace here following the two leaders' meeting, according to a report by the official Antara news agency.
Suharto also explained to his guest the results of the meeting between Indonesian officials and the IMF team, Moerdiono added.
Asked whether Singapore will pump in funds, Moerdiono said officials of the two countries will soon meet regarding this.

On the progress of the dialogue between Indonesian officials and the IMF, he said the discussion is approaching its final stage. "We hope the dialogue will wind up before the end of this week," he said.
Moerdiono said Goh had noticed the World Bank's evaluation that Indonesia has a strong economic foundation.
He said the prime minister believes that the policies implemented by the Indonesian government at the start of the crisis will help Indonesia weather the monetary turmoil.
"He also thinks that the loss of confidence on the part of investors has weakened the rupiah. He said that to handle the problem, (the government) has to gain back their confidence," Moerdiono said.
The two heads of state also discussed preparations for the APEC meeting in Canada next month and the informal ASEAN summit conference in Kuala Lumpur, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA ONE OF FASTEST GROWING TOURIST DESTINATIONS

TEXT.P: Russia, followed by mainland China and Turkey, were the world's fastest growing tourist destinations last year in terms of increased number of tourist arrivals, the World Tourism Organization reported in Istanbul Tuesday.

The organization, which is holding its general assembly meeting in Istanbul, reported in its publication "Tourism Highlights 1996" that in 1996 some 14.59 million tourists visited Russia, the world's 14th biggest tourism destination, a 57.49 percent jump from 1995.

The number of tourist arrivals in mainland China, the world's sixth leading travel destination, rose 13.63 percent in 1996 to 22.77 million. Turkey, the world's 19th most popular travel destination, attracted 7.97 million travelers in 1996, up 12.47 percent from the previous year.

The report said that the ten leading destinations -- France, the United States, Spain, Italy, Britain, mainland China, Mexico, Hungary, Poland and Canada -- accounted for 52 percent of the world volume of tourism flows. Some 62.41 million tourists visited France last year.
Greece and Switzerland were the biggest losers in tourism in 1996, with tourist arrivals plunging 11.28 percent and 7.83 percent respectively to 8.99 million and 10.60 million, the report said.

In terms of tourism earnings, Poland, Australia and Turkey recorded the biggest growths in 1996. Poland increased its tourism earnings 27.27 percent to US$8.4 billion, while the tourism earnings of Australia leaped 22.58 percent to US$8.7 billion, and Turkey bolted 20.27 percent to US$5.96 billion.
The United States was biggest tourism earner in 1996 with international tourism receipts at US$64 billion, up a healthy 5 percent.
Global tourism earnings increased 6.5 percent in 1996 to US$425 billion and the number of foreign tourist arrivals around the world rose 5.5 percent last year to 595 million, the report said.

The World Tourism Organization, entrusted by the United Nations with the promotion and development of tourism, also forecast that 700 million international tourists will be traveling by the year 2000 and one billion by 2010.
The organization stressed that tourism is the world's largest growth industry with no signs of abating in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVALUATION OF NT DOLLAR TO HAVE LITTLE IMPACT ON RETAIL PRICES

TEXT.P: The devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar will have little impact on domestic retail prices as Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain healthy, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The DGBAS cited steady price levels of agricultural and industrial raw materials, the relative appreciation of the NT dollar against the German and Japanese currencies, and a decline in the per unit labor cost in the industrial manufacturing sector.

The DGBAS said in a press release Wednesday that according to the macroeconomic pattern it has charted for Taiwan, retail prices will rise by between 0.5 percent and 0.6 percent for each incremental decrease of NT$1 against the greenback. However, this formula is valid only on condition that other major currencies remain steady against the US dollar.
The exchange rate of the NT dollar against the US dollar has dropped more than NT$1 since Oct. 17, when the Central Bank of China abandoned its strategy of intervening to prop up the local currency.

However, the impact on local retail prices will be partially offset by the steady prices of imported agricultural and industrial raw materials, which dipped by 5.5 percent in the January-September period, and the 3.6 percent decline in the per unit labor cost of industrial output. That decline is due to a 6.7 percent growth in productivity over the first seven months of this year and a relative low increase of 3.1 percent in wages.

The NT dollar's appreciation against deutsche mark and yen -- by 9.3 percent and 13.3 percent, respectively, in the first nine months of this year -- will also cushion the negative impacts, given Germany and Japan's combined 30 percent market share of Taiwan's imports.

Theoretically, devaluation of the local currency will drive up the price of imports and raise retail prices. Currently, however, consumer goods account for only about 10 percent of Taiwan's total imports, and 6.6 percent of the island's consumption volume, while raw materials account for more than 70 percent of imports. Thus, the DGBAS predicted that local consumers will feel the pinch of price hikes, if any, sometime between two to seven months after the readjusted exchange rates went into effect.

The DGBAS blamed the recent Southeast Asian financial crises for the 10.2 percent devaluation of the NT dollar since the beginning of this year. The decline is similar to that experienced by the Singapore dollar but lower than the 33.8 percent loss suffered by the Thai baht, 23.2 percent decrease of the Philippine peso and 34.5 percent dip of the Indonesian rupiah.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECORDS TRADE SURPLUS OF US$5.47 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports totaled US$89.78 billion in the first nine months of this year, while imports totaled US$84.31 billion in the same period, recording a trade surplus of US$5.47 billion, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday.

BOFT officials said that Taiwan's exports between January and September relied mostly on heavy industry and chemical industry products, as well as on light industry products. Electronics, information and telecommunications products formed the bulk of exports, showing steady growth, while steel, optical instruments and basic metals and basic metal products also grew rapidly.

Taiwan's steel, semiconductor and computer companies have continued to expand their production capacities since July 1996, which has inspired the growth of the manufacturing industry and has helped the increase in exports.

Exports of other light industry products grew by only 3.4 percent in the nine-month period. This low growth was attributed to a decline in labor-intensive products, such as toys, furniture, shoes, pottery and porcelain, due to fierce competition from Southeast Asia and mainland China.

Exports of agricultural and processed agricultural products have been affected by the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic in March, with processed agricultural products declining by 34 percent and agricultural products also dropping by 19.1 percent.
In terms of countries and regions, Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$19.21 billion with Hong Kong in the first nine months of this year.

Taiwan's exports to Japan registered negative growth of 13.3 percent in the same period, while imports grew by 3.9 percent. The negative growth was attributed to the decline of machinery equipment exports by 13.6 percent, while the FMD outbreak also took a toll on Taiwan's pork exports to Japan.

Taiwan's imports of Japanese parts and components meanwhile continued double digit growth, further widening the trade deficit, while Taiwan's exports to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) recorded only 6.8 percent growth and an increase of 22.0 percent in imports, the result of the current financial crisis in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEASURES TO DISCOURAGE AWOL FOREIGN LABORERS DISCUSSED

TEXT.P: A high-ranking labor affairs official said Wednesday that the government intends to step up efforts to prevent foreign laborers from fleeing their jobs.

Hsu Chieh-kwei, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, said that as of the end of September, about 30,781 foreign workers in Taiwan had gone AWOL from their jobs. The figure represented 12.4 percent of the total number of foreign workers in Taiwan, which stood at some 248,000, he noted.

Hsu said that 21,033 foreign workers who absconded from their contracting place of employment have been located and detained, but another 9,263 are still at large, posing a serious threat to social order and disease control efforts.

Hsu said his council is studying ways to reduce the number of workers on the run, including raising the reward offered for tips leading to the capture of illegal foreign laborers and imposing heavier punishment for those who hire such workers. He made the remarks in response to questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, adding that the proposed measures would require approval from the legislature.

According to current regulations, any employer who is caught hiring an illegal foreign worker faces up to six months in prison or a fine of up to NT$90,000. If an employer is caught hiring two or more foreign workers, the penalty will increase to a maximum of three years in prison or a fine of up to NT$300,000.

Hsu also mentioned a previously discussed plan to require compulsory savings for foreign laborers as part of efforts to dissuade them from running away. He said that he had met with his counterparts from Thailand, the Philippines and other Southeast Asian countries for talks on related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US ECONOMIC MEETING RESCHEDULED

TEXT.P: A meeting between economic officials of the vice-ministerial level from the Republic of China and the United States will be delayed until early next year, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Wednesday.
BOFT officials said that the dialogue, originally set for late November in Washington, D.C., will be delayed until January 1998.
ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and US Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers are expected to lead their respective teams in the meetings.

BOFT officials said that the US side asked for the postponement because it is busy preparing for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Vancouver, Canada, scheduled for late November. It is understood that several US financial affairs officials, including Summers, will participate in the APEC meeting.

BOFT officials said the recent financial crisis in Southeast Asia and the state of cross-strait relations will be the focus of the US side in the January talks, while the ROC will be concerned about the time frame for the signing of the proposed American Free Trade Area agreement. (By Lilian Wu) ENDITEM ZCZC CEP030 10-22-97 TAIWAN TO BE BRIEFED ON US-MAINLAND SUMMIT TALKS

Taipei, Oct. 22 (CNA) Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Wednesday said that the United States will brief Taiwan on the summit talks between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin shortly after their meeting on Oct. 29.
"The US government will send someone who either participated in the meeting or is at least very familiar with the details to brief the ROC representative office in the US on the event," Hu said.
"The ROC government, after being informed of the outcome of the meeting, will decide whether any response is warranted," he said.

The ROC and the US maintain both regular as well as non-regular communication channels at various levels to facilitate the exchange of information and opinions, Hu said, adding that there are no barriers to communications between the two countries.

Asked if he will reiterate the ROC's stance on the upcoming US-mainland summit when meeting on Thursday with Daryl Johnson, director general of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, Hu said that the US government has repeatedly given assurances that its contacts with Beijing will not harm the interests of Taiwan. "On this, we can feel their sincerity and good intention," Hu said.
He added that he believes the possibility is slim that the Washington-Beijing summit talks will bring any change to the current US policy toward Taiwan.

Taiwan hopes that Taipei-Washington ties will be basically parallel to Washington-Beijing ties, Hu said, pointing out that when it comes to regional security and certain other key policy issues, the Americans prefer to work within a Washington-Beijing-Taipei triangular framework.

Hu also reaffirmed his determination to pursue pragmatic diplomacy in order to increase Taiwan's profile in the international community, saying that the ROC cannot survive without maintaining an active presence in world affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN AIR CRASH INQUIRY MAY TAKE AT LEAST THREE MONTHS

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Communications Minister Haryanto Danutirto said Wednesday that it may take between three and eight months to discover the cause of the Garuda Airlines crash last month in northern Sumatra that killed 234 people.
Search teams found the flight data recorders on Tuesday. Haryanto said the "black boxes" will be opened and analyzed in Australia by a special task force.
"The results of the analysis will be discussed, and this takes a long time, maybe three, six or eight months," he was quoted as saying by Indonesia's state-run Antara news agency.
The minister did not say whether the results would be made public, but indicated he plans to discuss that matter with Commission V of the House of Representatives.
"Commission V has the right to decide whether or not to publish the results," he said.
The black boxes from Garuda Airlines flight 152, an Airbus A-300B4, were found at about 1:40 p.m. local time on Tuesday.
One of the devices holds the cockpit voice recorder, containing the entire conversation between the pilot and air traffic controllers at Polonia Airport.
The plane crashed on Sept. 26, 1997, killing all 234 people onboard.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ADMITS HUGE LOSSES IN OVERSEAS EXPLORATION

TEXT.P: Despite huge losses resulting from overseas oil exploration, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Wednesday that prospects have improved in recent years, with the success rate of drilling ventures climbing from 13.8 percent to 25 percent.

Responding to news reports that it had been misled by international oil brokers and lost heavily in its overseas oil exploration activities, the state-run CPC admitted that it has run up a total of NT$14.8 billion (US$493.33 million) in non-recovered investments over the past 27 years in 11 overseas joint ventures for oil exploration.
But the company also said that the results of its foreign ventures are improving, with the success rate on an upward trend.
Recent news reports claimed that a single botched investment in an oil field in Kazakhstan, central Asia, incurred a US$15 million loss for the CPC.

However, the CPC said that as a state-run firm it is obliged to follow government policy in exploring overseas prospects, such as its investment in Kazakhstan. Citing an estimated oil reserve of 88 million barrels, a projected life span of 15 years and a potential 15.9 percent return on the investment annually, the company defended the project as worthwhile. It said it proceeded with the investment only after receiving a go-ahead from the Executive Yuan.

The US$15 million funneled into the Kazakhstan project is the start-up cost needed before the oil field can begin to produce, and although there are differences between the CPC and its Kazakhstan partners over management procedures, the company is trying to sort those problems out, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENEGAL PREMIER CALLS ON ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Visiting Senegalese Premier Habit Thiam called on Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang Wednesday.
Thiam , who arrived in Taiwan at the head of a 27-member delegation on Monday night for a six-day visit, asked Wang to encourage Taiwan investment in his western African nation.
Wang agreed to hold presentations for local businessmen on Senegal's investment environment, but stopped short of making any firm commitments.
Senegal, which extended diplomatic recognition to the Republic of China in January 1996, is one of 30 states that maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE PASSES DRAFT ON EXCLUSIVE ECONOMIC ZONES

TEXT.P: Ship owners will be subject to 10 years' imprisonment and fines of up to NT$100 million (US$3.28 million) if caught dumping waste in Taiwan's exclusive economic zones, according to a draft law passed by a Legislative Yuan committee on Wednesday.

Following the lead of neighboring countries which have either created or announced plans for exclusive economic zones in recent years, the Executive Yuan drafted regulations to govern the operation of such areas and sent them to the Legislative Yuan for screening in 1992.

Under the draft regulations passed Wednesday, the government will regulate and impose penalties on ship owners for violating the laws governing the nation's exclusive economic zones and offshore areas.

If ship owners are found guilty of dumping, releasing or disposing waste materials in the exclusive economic zones or offshore areas, they face up to 10 years in prison, a fine of NT$100 million (US$3.27 million), or both.
Ship owners that deliberately destroy natural resources or cause damage to the environment will receive sentences of up to five years in prison, NT$50 million (US$1.64 million) in fines, or both.
Ship operators that construct artificial islands within the ROC's exclusive economic zones or offshore waters, will be fined between NT$10 million and NT$50 million.

Those that conduct exploration, development, or business operations in those areas without permission will be fined between NT$1 million and NT$5 million. The ships along with their cargo and equipment will be confiscated.
Owners of vessels that lay undersea cables without permission will be fined between NT$20 million and NT$100 million.
The draft regulations also stipulate that those who insult, coerce or threaten law enforcement officials will be prosecuted under the ROC Criminal Code.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100 BLACKFACE SPOONBILLS MAY FLY TO SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Over 100 blackface spoonbills, an endangered species, will fly to a river in southern Taiwan for winter, officials of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.
They said they have been able to pinpoint the whereabouts of the usually elusive birds with the help of transmitters attached to them.

COA Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung, COA Forestry Department Deputy Director Lee San-wei and other officials made the remarks as they inspected the mouth of Tsengwen Creek in Chihku Village, Tainan County.
Wildlife conservationists estimate that there are only about 300 blackface spoonbills left worldwide.

Beginning in late September each year, large numbers of the endangered migratory birds arrive at Tsengwen Creek for winter, where they remain until March or April. As a major habitat for the rare species, the creek has become a focus of attention for international wildlife conservation groups.

To better understand the behavioral patterns and natural habitat of the blackface spoonbill, the COA has cooperated with Japanese ornithological societies in using transmitters to trace their movements.
COA officials said that the government will also appropriate money in the next fiscal year to establish a blackface spoonbill sanctuary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN VOW TO DEFEND RIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Suao, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Indignant at what they perceive at hegemonic intervention by Japanese patrol boats near the Tiaoyutai Islands, Taiwan fishermen vowed on Wednesday to protect their rights in the traditional fishing grounds "by all means necessary."

Suao-based fishermen met Wednesday to vent their indignation at the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency, whose patrol boats, they said, routinely ram into Taiwan fishing vessels, cut fishing nets and damage equipment whenever they inadvertently enter the 12-mile zone around the Tiaoyutai Islands, which have been unilaterally claimed as Japanese territory by Tokyo.
The fishermen said that if the government will not take action to protect their rights, they will use "all means" to fight the Japanese by themselves, including arming their vessels.

Tseng Chin-shun, owner of the "Tseng Chin Shun 133" and Liu Chiu-hai, skipper of the "Hsin Lin Po 26," said bitterly that waters surrounding the Tiaoyutais have been traditional fishing grounds for Taiwanese for hundreds years.

Numerous historical documents prove that the Tiaoyutais were part of Chinese territory, and gravestones found on the islands bear Chinese characters indicating that the deceased were residents of Ilan, eastern Taiwan, they pointed out.

Deprived of their traditional fishing grounds, the fishermen have steered clear of the 12-mile exclusive zone around the Tiaoyutais, called the Senkakus in Japan, despite their insistence that the Japanese sovereignty claims are unilateral and unjustified.

Nevertheless, the fishing vessels sometimes drift into "prohibited" areas, especially during the days when the "Pakua Current," a strong and turbulent seasonal tide, is at its apex, as has been the case in recent days, they lamented.
It is particularly difficult for them to keep the nets, often stretching more than one kilometer in length, from drifting into the 12-mile zone when the current is strong, they noted.
Whenever the Japanese patrol boats spot the nets, they cut them without hesitation, the fishermen added.

In a one-week period since Oct. 16, they said, eight Suao-based fishing boats allegedly operating outside Tiaoyutai waters were badly damaged after being rammed by Japanese patrol boats. Damages to the boats and fishing gear exceeded NT$2.5 million (US$83,000), not to mention the threat to the fishermen's safety and lost income, they added.
They categorically demanded that the government dispatch warships to their aid so long as it continues to claim the Tiaoyutais as Republic of China territory.

The uninhabited Tiaoyutai archipelago, claimed by mainland China as well as Taiwan and Japan, lies in the East China Sea about 200 kilometers northeast of Taiwan and 300 kilometers west of Japan's Okinawa prefecture.

The islands, thought to be rich in oil reserves, first came into spotlight when their control, along with that of the Ryukyu Islands, was handed over to Japan by Washington, which had administered the island chains since Japan's defeat in the Second World War.

The dormant dispute erupted once again following the erection of a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands in July last year by a group of Japanese rightists. The dispute sparked anger in the Chinese communities in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.
