DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSY IS CHARACTERISTIC OF DPP: HSU

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Thursday that controversy is normal for the opposition party and that disagreements will by no means undermine its chances of winning next month's mayoral and magistrate elections.

Hsu, who has been under fire in recent days over a proposal to conduct negotiations on direct trade, postal and transport links with mainland China, defended the position, saying that it is not uncommon for members of the 11-year-old party to voice differing opinions over major issues.
Hsu made the proposal during a visit in Paris on Oct. 16 in response to an offer by Beijing to engage Taipei in a bilateral dialogue aimed at ensuring peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

Controversy is a characteristic, as well as a political asset, for the DPP, Hsu asserted, adding that DPP is an open and democratic party whose members are allowed to debate freely before any major policy position is established.
"The DPP will never forsake its tradition of respecting the free expression of differing opinions simply to avoid controversy," he noted.

Compared to the rival Kuomintang and the New Party, "wherein major policies are not produced through democratic processes," the DPP stands a better chance to win the year-end elections, Hsu said in denying that internal discord will hurt his party's performance in the upcoming local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS PREMATURE : MAC

TEXT.P: Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Thursday that it is still too early to discuss direct trade, postal, and transportation links with mainland China.
Sheu was responding to local media reports that MAC is now discussing the timing for opening the "three links."

Speaking at a public hearing on the issue convened by the opposition New Party at the legislative yuan, Sheu reaffirmed that direct cross-strait links are a complicated matter and must be considered on the premises of national security, dignity, and public welfare.

He said that the biggest hurdle for the opening of the direct links lies in Beijing's continued denial of the fact of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and its efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally. In addition, mainland China also refuses to forswear the use of force against Taiwan, he said.

New Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua and National Taiwan University Professor Chang Ling-cheng disagreed with Sheu's remarks, saying that the government is dragging its feet on opening transportation links under the pretext of national security.
Professor Chang added that mainalnd China is the only major trading partner with whom Taiwan's trade surplus is growing, and that the continued ban on the three links reflects an "ostrich mentality."

Conversely, Chang Liang-jen, deputy secretary general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), backed Sheu's position, saying that although cross-strait exchanges have been going on for over a decade, such contacts are still in the early stages and the opening of the three links remains premature.

He said that after the ROC and the US severed ties in 1979, Beijing had delivered a message to Taiwan compatriots indicating that it would not hesitate to use force to bring about the island's unification with the mainland. Later, the threats gave way to appeals for direct links with Taiwan, Chang said.
But he claimed that such overtures are also rooted in political strategies and asserted that any dialogue with Beijing should first address technical problem arising from cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DREYER'S ICE CREAM FOUND CONTAMINATED

TEXT.P: Five flavors of Dreyer's ice cream have been found to contain a strain of listeria, the Department of Health (DOH) said Thursday.

Chen Shu-kong, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the department has asked Jade Arrow Enterprise, the Taiwan importer of Dreyer's, to recall and destroy the contaminated products, which were produced between June 30 and July 31.
The flavors being recalled are Rocky Road, Butter Pecan LT, FFY Marble, Strawberry (sugarless) and Vanilla.

Following reports earlier this month that Hong Kong authorities had found Dreyer's vanilla ice cream and Cookies 'N Cream ice cream bars to contain listeria monocytogenes, the DOH tested Dreyer's products in Taiwan and discovered five of 14 different products contaminated with the bacteria.
Listeria monocytogenes can cause fever, nausea, vomiting and meningitis.
The DOH has notified Dreyer's Taiwan distributor to recall the five contaminated products. Taiwan does not import Cookies 'N Cream ice cream bars.

The department said it suspects the products became tainted during production and has asked the Bureau of Commodity Inspection & Quarantine to increase its inspection of imported ice cream for the time being.
Chen said the bacteria is most likely to affect the young, the old and pregnant women but that the average healthy person is usually impervious to it.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY SEEK CONCRETE US COMMITMENTS DURING SUMMIT: KMT

TEXT.P: Mainland China's President Jiang Zemin may ask Washington for concrete commitments on opposing Taiwan independence and ROC participation in the United Nations as well as on a halt of arms sales to the island, according to Kuomintang (KMT) sources.
Jiang is scheduled to visit the United States on Oct. 26 and to hold a summit meeting with US President Bill Clinton in Washington on Oct. 29.

In the latest issue of Mainland Affairs Biweekly, a periodical of the KMT Mainland Operations Department, published on Wednesday, it was reported that the Clinton-Jiang meeting will address issues of "mutual strategic interest" between Washington and Beijing. Hence, the publication said, the outcome of the summit should be closely scrutinized, although its substance and conclusions are hard to predict.
Prior to Jiang's visit, Beijing launched an all-out propaganda offensive, saying that Jiang must not return from his US visit "empty-handed," noted the biweekly.

The purpose of the propaganda campaign is to influence the international community into supporting Beijing's calls for the resumption of negotiations across the Taiwan Strait on its own terms, the biweekly added.

As to halting its export of nuclear technology to Iran, the report continued, Beijing is likely to agree to US requests, but the concession will by no means come without costs. One condition could be a request that Washington reciprocate by freezing arms sales to Taiwan or by making a concrete measure of similar magnitude.

Beijing is currently planning to convene a national conference on Taiwan affairs, and what Jiang gains from the Washington-Beijing summit will most probably emerge during the course of that conference, the KMT publication stated.

It added that Beijing's policy toward Taiwan is also likely to be clearly outlined at that time, which will have a significant bearing upon the future direction of relations between Taipei and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL NOT SILENCE PROTESTS AGAINST JIANG

TEXT.P: The White House said Wednesday that Washington would not silence protests during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit here next week, noting that it considers it a positive thing for "leaders of a totalitarian system" to see a healthy debate on controversial issues.

"It's welcome to democracy," White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry told a regular press briefing when asked to comment on remarks by a mainland Chinese embassy official earlier in the day urging the US government to silence demonstrators. "That's not going to happen," McCurry added.

McCurry said that Washington has tried to help the Beijing leadership understand the vibrant political culture that the American people have, the way in which Americans freely express their ideas, and the importance they, as a free people, attach to the right of dissent, the right of expression, and the freedom to openly express one's views.
The press secretary said that Washington has made it clear to Beijing that "they can anticipate seeing that reflected in the very healthy debate about China that will occur during the state visit."
"They will be able to read in our newspapers, see in our streets, encounter anecdotally the way in which Americans deal with controversial issues," he said.
"And we think that will be a positive and good thing for leaders of a totalitarian system to see that healthy debate should not be feared," he went on.

In fact, he said, Washington believes Beijing should embrace such debates because mainland China's move toward a market economy requires the political freedoms that are associated with a democratic system.

Meanwhile, Jeffrey Bader, director of Asian Affairs at the National Security Council, said at a Foreign Press Center briefing here that a state visit involves first-class treatment of the visitor, and there are certain perquisites and certain protocol arrangements associated with it.

At the same time, Bader pointed out, there are Americans who have strong feelings about one or another aspect of Beijing's policy -- whether in the area of human rights or Tibet or something else -- and that the US Bill of Rights guarantees the right to demonstrate.
"We are not going to abrogate the US Constitution in order to provide the right atmosphere for this visit," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FORGES PUBLIC HEALTH ACCORD WITH SOUTH AMERICAN GROUP

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has recently forged an agreement with the Convention of Hipolito Unanue in South America to accelerate health cooperation with countries in that continent.
The Convention of Hipolito Unanue, a South American public health cooperative organization headquartered in Lima, Peru, counts Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela as its members.

Secretary-General Juan Luis Gonzalez Reyes of the convention and Taipei Representative in Peru Hung Ming-tah jointly signed an agreement on Sept. 16 on closer public health cooperation between Taiwan and the member countries of the Unanue Convention, according to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Under the five-year agreement, the ROC government will render assistance to Unanue member countries to help improve health conditions in the region and foster cooperation in related matters.

It is hoped that by forging ties with the regional health organization, Taiwan will stand a better chance of moving ahead a step in its bid to enter the World Health Organization, the MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK CHOOSES NOT TO SCREEN FILMS ON TIBET

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's private film distributors, under Beijing's political authority, have chosen not to screen Hollywood's latest films depicting Tibet's struggle against Communist Chinese domination, a Canadian newspaper said Wednesday.

The Globe and Mail noted that the distributors buckled on "Seven Years in Tibet" and "Kundun" without the urging of Beijing, although Hong Kong is supposed to enjoy autonomy in such decisions about film distribution, not to mention freedom of speech.

"Seven Years in Tibet," starring Brad Pitt, is a rendition of an Austrian mountain climber's encounter with Buddhism and the young Dalai Lama in the lead-up to China's invasion of the Himalayan territory, according to the Mail. Director Martin Scorsese's "Kundun chronicles Tibet's resistance against Beijing in the 1950s, which was assisted by the US Central Intelligence Agency.

In an editorial, the Mail said there is no bigger thorn in mainland China's side than Tibet. The popularity in Hollywood and worldwide of the remote autonomous region, as well as its religiously motivated resistance to political domination and desire for self-determination, is an irritant to atheist and chauvinist Beijing.
Beyond Beijing, however, Tibetan independence is a taboo subject for many Chinese of Han origin, said the editorial titled, "Hong Kong's Tibet threat."

And threats to the cultural and territorial integrity of the Chinese motherland, whether from Tibet, Taiwan, Muslim-dominated areas or the Southeast Asian Spratly Islands, are fiercely resisted by Chinese nationalists of all kinds, it said. "Most of all by the dictatorship in Beijing," it added.

"It's this chauvinist Han nationalism that makes China the bad guy in the eyes of Tibetans and their sympathizers," it said, noting there is no doubt that in "Seven Years in Tibet," the Chinese are the bad guys, portrayed as conniving, strident and ruthless.

That's all the more reason for Hong Kong to have tolerated the films -- to show that the experimental, free Chinese city-state can take the criticism and refute it in open debate, the Mail said. "But no such luck," it opined.

It pointed to "a certain irony" in one special Chinese region, Hong Kong, failing to identify the experience of another, Tibet. But then again, it concluded, magnanimity and brotherly love have rarely been characteristics of those who feel pressure bearing down upon them from above.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEDERATION OF LATIN AMERICAN BANKS TO HOLD MEETING IN MIAMI

TEXT.P: The Federation of Latin American Banks will hold its 31st general assembly Nov. 17-18 in Miami, Florida.

The federation said in a press release that nearly every bank in Central and South America will be represented at the gathering, which is to discuss the global economy and banking outlook for Latin America.

In addition to the some 800 bankers from Latin America, the federation said, bankers from the United States and Europe will also attend the meeting. This will be only the second time in 31 years that the general assembly has been held outside of Latin America.

Top executives and leading economic authorities from both the public and private sectors will address economic, financial and regulatory issues that affect hemispheric banking, the press release reported.

The meeting seminars will focus on topics including a global vision of Latin America, a global economic and banking outlook, a global regulatory environment and its impact on business, and business strategies.

The Federation of Latin American Banks was founded in Argentina in 1969 as a non-profit organization and now represents 900 banking and financial institutions in 19 countries throughout Central and South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 10 PERCENT OF YOUNG QUEENSLAND STUDENTS SAID DRINKING REGULARLY

TEXT.P: More than 10 percent of Year 7 students (normally aged 11 or 12) in Queensland, Australia drank alcohol regularly last year, according to a new survey by the Department of Education and the University of Queensland.

Alcohol consumption among Year 12 students has also increased dramatically over the past three years, according to the survey conducted late last year of 3,600 children from the Queensland State's private schools, the mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported Thursday.
The survey also shows 20 percent of Year 12 students were regular marijuana users, while more than half had tried the drug.

One in three Year 12 students were regular cigarette smokers. About 15 percent of boys and 10 percent of girls in the final year of primary school reported they drank alcohol in the week before being survey.
The survey found 10 percent of Year 7 children had sniffed intoxicants, such as glue.
The leader of the survey, Associate Professor John Lowe, said the consumption of alcohol, cigarettes or illicit drugs within the week before completing the survey indicates regular usage.
The survey found 58 percent of males and 53 percent of females in Year 12 drank alcohol during the previous week -- an 8 percent rise on a similarly survey conducted in 1993.
The National Drug and Alcohol Research Center said the proportion of younger alcohol users is a concern.
"The reality is 60 percent of drug-related deaths in young people are because of alcohol," according to the center spokesman Paul Dillon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL MOVE ON 'MAD COWS'

TEXT.P: The European Commission is preparing to ensure that supplies of "life-saving and essential" medicines continue, despite a controversial ban on the use of cattle derivatives, according to a just released report by the World Trade Organization.

The move is part of a rare breakthrough in a dispute between the European Union and the United States over EU plans to protect the food chain from those parts of cattle most at risk of carrying the BSE mad cow disease.
The commission is also seeking support for allowing the use of derivatives of tallow, providing they are manufactured under specified conditions.

The proposals fall significantly short of satisfying US demands for ending the dispute, which began in July when the EU banned the use from January 1, 1998, of "specified risk material" in cattle, mainly the brain and spinal cord.
The EU will make its next move in the light of recommendations it hopes to receive from its veterinary science committee, which has been asked to clarify advice it made on tallow last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL ASSERTS NO CHANGE IN US POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States does not intend to seek improved relations with mainland China at the expense of Taiwan, a senior Clinton administration official said Wednesday.

Briefing the press on the forthcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and his Communist Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, the director for Asian affairs at the US National Security Council, Jeffrey Bader, said that US policy on Taiwan is guided by the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, which is US law. However, he added that the 1982 joint communique between Washington and Beijing also applies in terms of US arms supplies to Taiwan.

The Taiwan Relations Act requires the United States to provide sufficient weapons of defensive nature to Taiwan for its own security, while the 1982 communique declared that the United States would gradually reduce its arms sales to Taiwan both qualitatively and quantitatively, as the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait decreased.
"We have not changed, nor are we changing, our policy on arms sales to Taiwan," he said.
According to Bader, the United States does not anticipate announcing new policies with regard to Taiwan at the Clinton-Jiang summit.

Bader also gave assurances that the United States will not change its policy of allowing Taiwan leaders to enter the United States for private visits or transit stops. Nor will Clinton sign a fourth joint communique on the issue of Taiwan with Jiang at their Oct. 29 summit in Washington.

"We have a 'one China' policy, and we encourage resumption of cross-strait exchanges in a constructive way between the PRC and Taiwan," he said, adding that the Clinton administration has made it very clear that these basic elements of US policy "are not going to be changed in the lead up to or during or as a consequence of his (Jiang's) visit."

Asked if Clinton and Jiang may address the Taiwan issue in a joint statement at the end of their summit, Bader said he does not know at this point what form of public announcements may result from the summit, because those matters are still being discussed between the two sides.
"But whatever the form is, there will not be a fourth communique," he said.
He stressed that whatever is said about Taiwan in public statements at the end of the summit will be consistent with the principles governing the long-standing US policy toward Taiwan.

Asked how the United States would react to a proposal from Beijing to condition its nuclear nonproliferation on an end to US arms sales to Taiwan, Bader pointed out that under the Taiwan Relations Act, the United States is committed to providing sufficient arms to Taiwan for its defense.
"This is the standard we use for deciding what arms to sell to Taiwan. We do not accept linkage to other extraneous subjects," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL OPEN FREIGHT-FORWARDING

TEXT.P: Mainland China has agreed to open a part of its shipping market to European companies for the first time, according to a just released report from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO).
The agreement means EU companies can conduct freight-forwarding activities in the mainland market.
The WTO report said that Communist Chinese Vice Minister for Communications Liu Songjin said two licenses "would shortly be granted to EU firms."
Previously, the only such licenses had been granted to two US companies, which led to complaints from the EU.
According to the WTO report, Liu said the freight-forwarding market would be "opened to all competitors as soon as possible."
Beijing has also agreed to "normalize" its relations with Denmark, which have been "reduced to the bare formalities as a result of disagreements over human rights," the WTO report added separately.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar gained NT$0.019 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$30.230.
The US currency opened at NT$30.200 and had a low of NT$30.085 and a high of NT$30.450. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$495 million. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 132.54 points to finish at 7825.01.
The bourse opened at 7739.55 and experienced a high of 7901.81 and a low of 7669.76.
Gainers outnumbered losers 297 to 109, with 62 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$163.45 billion (US$5.36 billion).

Financial issues rose the most at 3.9 percent, followed by electrical engineering issues at 1.2 percent; both textile shares and construction issues at 0.9 percent; foodstuff stocks at 0.8 percent; and both plastic and chemical shares and cement stocks at 0.1 percent. Paper and pulp shares fell 0.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'US-CHINA RELATIONS ACT' INTRODUCED INTO US SENATE

TEXT.P: US Senator Joseph Lieberman (D-Conn.) has introduced a bill in the Senate that he says would encourage the integration of mainland China into the world community while protecting US economic and political interests and preserving US values.

The bill, cosponsored by three other senators, is titled "The United States-China Relations Act of 1997." It would grant mainland China permanent most-favored-nation trade status upon its accession to the World Trade Organization.

One provision would require the US president to submit an annual study to the Congress, analyzing the impact of existing bilateral trade agreements with Beijing on US employment, the balance of trade and US international competitiveness. Another provision would require the president to develop criteria for the support of Beijing's participation in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and G-Seven meetings.

The president would also be required to establish a bilateral committee on energy security and another bilateral committee on food security. These two committees would help develop a bilateral policy for securing a stable supply of energy from politically volatile regions and securing food for the large population in mainland China.
In addition, the bill calls for the establishment of a commission to promote the rule of law, respect for individual rights, religious tolerance and civil society in mainland China.

Another commission would be formed to prepare a province by province profile of mainland China. This profile would serve as a basis for consideration of transactions with mainland China by the Export-Import Bank and Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) in the identified provinces. Regions that have acceptable human rights, labor and environmental standards would be eligible for assistance from OPIC programs.

One provision in the bill expresses the sense of the Senate that the president and Congress should continue to expand contact and exchanges between US and mainland Chinese national security personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AUSSIE PM CONDEMNS JOHN HOWARD FOR LACK OF LEADERSHIP

TEXT.P: One of Australia's former Liberal Party prime ministers has condemned the current Liberal Prime Minister John Howard for his policy to slash immigration and his failure to stem racism in public discourse and convince people that Australia's future is in Asia.
Malcolm Fraser, four-time prime minister between 1975 and 1983 and a long-serving Liberal leader, said Howard and other Australian leaders have no long-term means to keep the country strong and safe.

Speaking on television in Canberra Wednesday, Fraser blasted Howard's refusal to condemn Queensland Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson and his view that free speech allows racist comments.

"This used to be a country in which those who had racist views would be regarded as outcasts. We need to re-emphasize that those who express racist views ... are unacceptable in civilized society," he said.
Fraser stressed his belief that Australia's only future is with Asia.

"There is no other future for us. Those who want to take us back to the past should be cast aside," he said, adding, "We need a full-blooded commitment to that future from all Australians and Australian institutions but especially from those who lead or aspire to lead us into the next century."

Addressing the issue of immigration, he said: "Large scale immigration is always a sensitive issue but (before) there was understanding between Australia's leaders that this was vital for the security of our children and therefore racial issues were off-limits in the political arena. We need seriously to ask ourselves why people throughout Asia do not yet believe that rejection of Pauline Hanson and what she stands for is adequate."
Hanson last year demanded that the government stop Asian immigration and she formed the One Nation Party to advocate her "four ones" -- one nation, one flag, one race and one language.

Fraser said if Australia has only 20 million to 25 million people by the year 2050, Asia would see the country as "insular and selfish," but that with a population of 40-50 million it would have a reasonable voice.
"The idea of growing Australia to secure the future of Australian children has blown away in the dust," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN ACCUSED OF TAKING STRONG-ARM ACTIONS NEAR DIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan fishermen in Suao, Ilan are accusing Japan of taking strong-arm actions against Taiwan fishing boats operating on the seas near the Diaoyutai islands, and saying that they would form a self-defense force to protect their fishing fights in the area.

An official of the Suao Fishermen's Association said Thursday that at least three Taiwan fishing boats have been struck and damaged by Japanese patrol boats recently. The fishing nets and other fishing tools of at least five other Taiwan boats have also been cut or dragged away by the Japanese purposely.
The fishermen in the Suao area have shown strong anger, saying they would set up a self-defense force to protect themselves, he said.
Japan, Taiwan, and mainland China have simultaneously claimed sovereignty over the tiny uninhabitable islands in the East China Sea.

An official of the Council of Agriculture Thursday asked Taiwan fishermen to avoid fishing near the disputed islands before Japan and Taiwan reach a relevant fishery agreement. The council will look into the accusations and try to contact the Japanese side for this matter, he said. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS, SCHOLARS WORRIED ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Several legislators Thursday expressed their worry that the up-coming talks between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Washington may hurt Taiwan.
Jiang is scheduled to leave for the United States this weekend for a week-long official visit.
The legislators expressed their worry at the "Forum on National Affairs" of the Legislative Yuan.

Tsai Ming-hsien (DPP-Taichung City) urged the U.S. government not to hurt Taiwan for the sake of economic benefits. He also urged Taiwan's diplomats to pay special attention to the talks between Clinton and Jiang in Washington.
"Taiwan people are unwilling to accept the Chinese Communist regime as their ruler. The U.S. government should respect the wish of Taiwan people and help Taiwan join the United Nations," he said.
Pan Wei-kang (KMT-Taipei City) said that, facing the challenge of "Clinton-Jiang talks," the government should really do something about it. "Making a pep talk to the people is not enough."

Cheng Pao-ching (DPP-Taoyuan County) said Jiang's talks with Clinton in Washington could upgrade U.S. engagement with mainland China from "strategic dialogue" to "strategic partnership." If this happens, the military cooperation between Washington and Beijing will be strengthened, and Taiwan's security may be endangered, he said.

Chu Huei-liang (NP-Taipei City) said that, facing the challenge of "Clinton-Jiang talks," the ruling and opposition parties should hold consultations so as to reach a consensus on how to handle the relations with mainland China.
Meanwhile, at a public hearing sponsored Thursday by NP Legislator Chen I-hsin, several scholars expressed their worry about the possible impact of "Clinton-Jiang talks" on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

T. L. Chiu, a researcher at the Academia Sinica, pointed out that Beijing is sending out many messages to convince the United States that the situation in the Taiwan Strait is peaceful, and therefore the United States need not sell advanced weapons to Taiwan.

He pointed out that Washington and Beijing have made it clear that they are not going to sign a fourth communique during Jiang's visit to Washington, but Taiwan could still be hurt if a joint statement were issued at the end of Jiang's visit to Washington.

Chiu said Taiwan could be hurt badly, if in the joint statement the United States promised not to support Taiwan's bid to join world organizations, expressed the hope for peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, or said anything that could reduce U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 22ND IOSCO ANNUAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The 22nd annual conference of the International Organization of Securities Commission (IOSCO) is scheduled to open here Nov. 5, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) said on Thursday.
More than 800 academics and financial experts from Taiwan, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Australia and the United States are expected to take part in the conference, according to the SEC.

There will be six panel discussions in the conference, focusing on management, development, the integration of Asian financial markets, the impact of foreign capital and other related issues, the SEC said.

The SEC said IOSCO's granting Taiwan the sponsorship of this year's conference is proof of the international community's recognition of the development of Taiwan's financial sector and will also help this nation speed the pace of its capital market's globalization.
Taiwan joined IOSCO, which currently has 81 member states, in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAID TO BE A HAVEN FROM ASIAN ECONOMIC TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Despite a plunge in the Australian currency Wednesday, Australian Treasurer Peter Costello, has declared that his country would be a haven from the financial crisis that has hit many Southeast Asian countries.
The Australian dollar hit a 28-month low against the US dollar Wednesday, closing at 71.25 US cents.
But Australia's All Ordinaries Index closed 32.2 points higher at 2682.9 the same day.
There was also good news on the inflation front. As measured by the Consumer Price Index, inflation here fell 0.4 percent in the September quarter and by 0.3 percent over the same period last year.
Costello said the inflation results confirm that Australia's economic fundamentals are "exceptionally strong" and "among the best" in the world.

"As people from outside look at the Australian economy, they see a growth economy with low inflation, a strong fiscal position, a good independent monetary policy and a sound financial system," he said.
"And these are the things on which there is a premium in world economies," he said.
He noted Australia's exports to the four financially troubled countries -- Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia -- only account for 11 percent of its total exports to Asia.
Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and mainland China all combined account for about 46 percent of Australia's overall exports.
Costello said the problems in Southeast Asia have also caused a ripple effect in the major economies of the region.
With the plunge of shares on the Hong Kong stock market, analysts said investors are scrambling to get out of Asia and that safe havens like Australia are being hit as well.
Thailand's currency hit a new low as party leaders haggled over forming a new government.
The leadership of Japanese Prime Minister Hashimoto was drastically weakened as markets gave the thumbs-down to his latest economic revival plan.
With all these developments, Costello put on a brave face and declared that the upheaval would make Australia a "premium" economy for international investors.
But Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street investment bank, said the Asian crisis is "likely to be a major economic shock for both Australia and New Zealand" in the coming year.

The Australian Bureau of Agriculture Resources and Economics and the National Farmers Federation warned Wednesday that Australia's beef and wheat exports to Asia are being threatened by the Asian currency crises.

The depreciation of the Australian currency, however, may cause problems for the country's coal and iron ore exports to major markets such as Japan, Korea and Taiwan because importers are expected to demand lower prices.

Australia's educational exports are also bracing for hard times as more and more parents in financially troubled Asian countries are expected to tighten their belts and avoid sending their children abroad as the result of the financial crisis at home.
Australia's tourism industry is facing similar problems due to the expected decline in the number of Asian tourists from Taiwan, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines to Australia in coming months.
As a result of a cut in immigration intake, Australia is expected to experience a slump in its property industry, which has been in the doldrums since the early 1990s.
Analysts said whether Australia would become a real haven for many investors remains to be seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG YING-FENG: A LIFE OF ARTISTIC CREATION (PART I)

TEXT.P: He led a life of imagination and inspiration, blending traditional Chinese aesthetics and Buddhist imagery with avant-garde artistic concepts. When he died, he left behind a creative legacy of enduring beauty and a touch of the divine.

Yang Ying-feng, a Taiwan-born sculptor who achieved international fame with his Oriental-flavor modernistic sculptures, died of a lung ailment on Oct. 21 at a Buddhist monastery in the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu. He was 71.
A versatile and prolific artist, Yang left behind a large collection of artworks, ranging from blockprints, bronze and stone sculptures to landscapes.
A gifted man with a burning thirst for knowledge, Yang never hesitated to attempt new things. His artistic style evolved with age, shifting from realism to the abstract.

In the latter stages of his career, Yang dedicated himself to stainless steel sculpture. He injected life and vigor into dull, staid stainless steel plates, a product of modern technology. The dazzling array of stainless steel sculptures Yang created over the past 20-odd years clearly reflects his views of the universe and his pursuit of conformity between humanity and providence.

The master sculptor started his career by creating blockprints featuring Taiwan's rural landscape and life. Those works, dating mostly from 1951 to the early 1960s, reflected his deep feelings for his native land. In addition to projecting realistic images, some of his early creations were also infused with abstract concepts.
Hsieh Li-fa, an art historian, described Yang's blockprints as "incorporating a deep indigenous consciousness with avant-garde artistic ideas."

Yang began to experiment with sculptures depicting the human body and religious themes in 1954. His feminine figures reflected Oriental concepts of beauty and taste. During this period, Yang also took inspiration from the Buddhist deities carved in grottoes at Yungang on the Chinese mainland to create a unique series of sculptures in religious motif.
His breakthrough came in 1963 when he traveled to Italy to pursue higher learning. The themes and subjects of subsequent works became deliberately more abstract, linear and stylized.

Yang found residence in the scenic eastern Taiwan city of Hualien after his return from Italy in the late 1960s. His creative endeavors also entered a new stage. He began to use axes to chop wood and stones into grand and impressive shapes, which represented not only beauty and grandeur but also his philosophical outlook.

Yang became internationally renowned in 1970 when he showed to the world his massive stainless steel sculpture entitled "Blessing of the Phoenix." The work, featuring a traditional Chinese theme with modernistic sculpting techniques and concepts, was a major attraction at the 1970 Osaka Expo. It received rave reviews from art critics around the world.

From then on, Yang focused his energies on sculptures using the stainless steel medium. Through his works, Yang conveyed his concepts of the universe, nature, humanity and beauty, as well as his understanding of Buddhist scripture and doctrines. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG YING-FENG (PART II)

TEXT.P: Huang Tsai-lung, curator of the Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts, said Yang's stainless steel sculptures, which are designed to form an integral part of their surroundings rather than being objects to be viewed solely on their own, demonstrate unique lineal beauty and are imbued with deep sensitivity of feeling, taste and philosophical thought. "Yang's works are full of cultural diversity and symbolic meaning. In addition to showing the qualities of maturity and refinement, his works provide a rich source of inspiration," Huang noted.

Yang was the first Taiwan artist to explore the art of stainless steel sculpture and, many of his works have been installed outdoors at Taiwan's major tourist resorts and in front of high-rise commercial buildings. One of his stainless steel works -- "East-West Gate," created in 1973, is on permanent display on New York's bustling Wall Street. "Yang's artistic spirit, together with his works, will permanently bless all those public places," Huang said.

During his lifetime, Yang's works were exhibited in nearly every major art capital of the world and a definitive retrospective of his work, covering the master sculptor's major creations throughout his 60-year career, has been going on at Japan's Hakone Open-Air Arts Museum since Aug. 1.

Due to his failing health, Yang was unable to attend the opening of the Hakone exhibition, which will last until Oct. 26, but shortly before the opening, Yang recounted to the local press some of the formative events that led him into the arts world.
Recalling that his mother, Buddhism and traditional Oriental aesthetics have extensively influenced his creative work, he said the image of his mother was his first-hand experience of beauty.

Born in Ilan, a scenic, rainy city on Taiwan's northeastern coast in 1926, Yang was raised by his maternal grandparents after his parents traveled to the Chinese mainland to launch a business career while he was still a child.

"I'll always remember the words my mother said to me on the eve of her departure for the mainland: `Do you see the moon? The place Mom wants to go can also see this same moon. I'll be watching over you just like the moon does,'" Yang recalled.

He said he used to believe that the moon acted as a mirror and could reflect his image to his mother. "I felt a deep sense of happiness every time I saw moonlight, and this feeling has been a major source of inspiration for my creations."

Yang was reunited with his parents in mainland China after he finished his elementary education in Taiwan and he was enrolled in a Beijing high school. On one occasion, he toured the city of Datong, in northwestern Shanxi province, a visit which turned out to be a turning point in his life.

Yang said he was almost overwhelmed upon seeing a cluster of carved Buddhist figures in the grottoes of Yungang on the outskirts of Datong. "I stood in awe when I saw these imposing Buddhist images. They were depicted in simple lines, but managed nevertheless to inspire a vigorous, powerful sense of divinity and grandeur in my mind."
So moved was he by the magnificent artworks that Yang said the desire to pursue a career in the arts began to ferment in his mind.

After graduating from the school in Beijing, Yang went to Japan in 1943 to receive his tertiary education. He was admitted to the architecture department of the Tokyo Fine Arts College and attended classes given by noted Japanese architect Isoya Yoshida, who had a special affinity for ancient Chinese (Tang Dynasty, A.D. 618-907) architecture. Yang later described the Northern Wei Dynasty (A.D. 220-589) stone-carving art and the Tang Dynasty architecture as the two most distinct expressions of traditional Chinese aesthetics.

Yang returned to Taiwan after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949, working first as an art editor for the "Harvest" agricultural magazine, which allowed him to gain first-hand information and a well-developed sense of Taiwan's farming community and inspired him to create woodblocks featuring scenes of everyday rural life.

Yang had been troubled by skin and lung ailments since the beginning of this year. He spent most of his last days of life at the Fayuan Buddhist Temple, where one of his daughters is a practicing Buddhist nun and where his ashes will be interred following a funeral service on November 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA INCREASING SERVICES TO TAIPEI TO 20 TIMES WEEKLY

TEXT.P: Beginning Friday, Singapore Airlines (SIA) will have another weekly flight from Singapore to Taipei, bringing its total services on that route to 20 times weekly, SIA announced Thursday.

SIA will also increase its services to Beijing, from 12 to 14 times a week, and to other destinations, including Seoul, from 17 to 18 times weekly; Vancouver, from twice weekly to three times a week; and New Delhi, (from January 1, 1998) from four to five times weekly.

As a result of a codesharing arrangement between SIA and Air New Zealand after the signing of an open-skies agreement between the two carriers' home countries earlier this month, Auckland will be served non-stop daily by SIA.
SIA's network now spans 76 cities in 41 countries, the airline said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH CEMETERY IN KEELUNG OPENS TO PUBLIC

TEXT.P: A 19th century French cemetery in the northern Taiwan port city of Keelung was formally opened to the public on Thursday.

Keelung Mayor Lin Shui-mu and R.T. Yang, director of the European Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), jointly presided over a ceremony marking the opening of the 112-year-old graveyard.

Amid the boisterous sound of gongs and drums and following a spirited lion dance performance, Yang presented the key to the cemetery to Lin, symbolizing the transfer of its administration to the Keelung City Government.
The French Institute in Taiwan, which represents French interests on the island in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, turned the cemetery's administration over to the MOFA earlier this week.

The graveyard, which covers roughly one square kilometer, was established in 1885 by the French government to inter the remains of some 700 French troops who were killed in Taiwan in the 1884 war between France and Ching Dynasty China.
In that year, the Manchu government went to war with France over French actions in Annam (present-day Vietnam), then a Chinese protectorate.

During the war, a French fleet attacked Taiwan and attempted to land on the island, losing many men in a fierce battle. The French war-dead were laid to rest in the Keelung cemetery the following year. A monument was also erected in the cemetery in honor of the dead, but today, few of the names of those buried in the graveyard are still legible. The remains of another two French officers who also died in the 1884 war and were originally buried in Penghu, were reburied in the Keelung cemetery in 1954.

Lin said the French Institute in Taiwan had until recently been responsible for the upkeep of the cemetery, adding that the city government will gradually refurbish the area, plant more flowers and trees and build additional walking paths, in order to make the site more pleasant for local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN STATES SHOULD WORK TOGETHER TO MEET FINANCIAL CRISIS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Financial authorities of the four "Asian tiger" economies and mainland China should act in concert to defend their currencies rather than resign them to irrational sliding, a renowned economic scholar said here Thursday.

The call by Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a private think tank, came in the wake of the Hong Kong stock market plunging sharply Thursday for the second day in a row.

Noting that Hong Kong, like Taiwan, has solid economic fundamentals and huge foreign exchange reserves but still fell victim to a strong expectation that its currency would drop, Wu called the depreciations unreasonable and blamed speculators for these and the falls on the Hong Kong and Taiwan stock markets.

Speculators, Wu said, are using the financial crisis plaguing Southeast Asian countries to fan public anticipation that the Hong Kong dollar will be the next domino falling in a wave of devaluation that has swept Southeast Asia, even though the Hong Kong economic situation does not justify the expectation.

To shield the currencies of regional states from foreign speculators' irrational attacks, Wu said, the region's states, especially the four so-called Asian Tigers -- Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore -- should join hands along with mainland China to take on the speculators.

Warning a devaluation of the Hong Kong dollar would trigger a round of devaluation in neighboring states -- which would fear their exports would not be competitive otherwise -- and wreak havoc with the regional economy, Wu proposed that APEC (the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum) install a mechanism through which countries can jointly intervene in case of such a financial crisis.
He also called on the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) to keep the New Taiwan dollar stronger than NT$30 to 1 US dollar.

Given that the greenback has risen against the world's major currencies about 2 percent thus far this year, Wu said he believes a commensurate devaluation of the NT dollar would be acceptable, which would place the Taiwan currency better than NT$30 to one US dollar. Any devaluation beyond that range should be met with strong government intervention, he said.

Taiwan has seen its currency shed 10.2 percent of its value against the US dollar since the beginning of this year, including a 7 percent plunge last week after the CBC, which had thrown more than US$5 billion into propping up the NT dollar, abandoned its intervention attempts on Oct. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL: TAIWAN FINANCIAL MARKET NOT TO BE AFFECTED BY H.K.

TEXT.P: The recent surge of interest rates and plunge of stock market in Hong Kong is unlikely to hurt the financial market of Taiwan, Han Chi, director general of the Banking Department of the Central Bank of China, said Thursday.

The Hong Kong government Thursday pushed overnight interests as high as 300 percent. The mortgage rates went up 0.75 percent to 9.5 percent as a result. Hong Kong's main stock index was down by 14 percent Thursday, the biggest loss since August. The stock market has lost 40 percent of its value since then.

Han said he believed Taiwan's financial market is immune to the drastic changes in Hong Kong. "Because our financial market is very healthy, and the financial systems of Hong Kong and Taiwan are different," he said.

Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng said Thursday that the impact of financial crisis in Southeast Asia on Taiwan's stock market can be reduced to a minimum, because the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are sound.

Wu pointed out that Taiwan's economic growth is expected to reach 6.6 percent this year. It has trade surplus and a big amount of foreign exchange reserves. The growth rate of private investment in Taiwan is highest in five years, and foreign capital accounts for about four percent of Taiwan's stock market only.
In addition, he said, his ministry is able to keep the Taiwan stock market healthy. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE AUGUST SALARIES TOP NT$35,000

TEXT.P: Taiwan workers earned an average monthly salary of NT$35,319 in August, up 4.54 percent from the same month of last year, the latest statistics released on Thursday by the cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.
The DGBAS tallies also indicate that monthly salaries from January to August averaged NT$40,003, an actual annual increase of 3.05 percent after a 1.36 percent adjustment to account for inflation.

As of the end of August, a total of 5.57 million workers were employed in the industrial and service sectors, up slightly from the total recorded at the end of July, according to the statistics. The service sector absorbed about 47 percent of Taiwan's overall working population, nearly half of which were female.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMANY IS ROC'S BIGGEST TRADE PARTNER IN EUROPE

TEXT.P: Germany is the Republic of China's biggest trade partner in Europe so far this year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance.
Trade with Germany in the first three-quarters of this year amounted to US$6,683 million, an increase of some US$200 million over the same period of last year, the statistics show.

Exports to Germany in the first nine months of this year reached US$2,656 million, while imports from the European country were worth US$4,027 million, resulting in a trade deficit of US$1,371 million.
France was Taiwan's second-largest European trade partner in the same period, with two-way trade volume hitting US$4,222.9 million for a deficit of US$2,250.7 million for Taiwan.
However, Taiwan enjoyed a surplus of US$954.6 million in its US$3,858.8 million-worth of trade with the United Kingdom, the island's third-largest trade partner in Europe.
Germany was the world's second-largest trading nation overall, behind only the United States in 1996, with foreign trade last year exceeding US$957 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING RENTS CAUSE DROP IN TAIPEI POPULATION

TEXT.P: Taipei's population has fallen to less than 2.6 million since March this year, statistics compiled by the Taipei Municipal Government show.
As of the end of last year, the ROC capital's population was 2,605,374 but the figure fell to 2,595,699 in March this year, rising slightly to 2,596,155 by August.
Taipei municipal officials attributed the population decline to the rising cost of apartment rental in the metropolitan area.
Women outnumbered men in the city, with 99.63 men for every 100 women. This is in contrast with the figures for 1988, which indicated that there were 102.88 men for every 100 women at that time.

Meanwhile, the divorce rate has been rising steadily in the city. In 1996 there were 5,500 divorces in Taipei, some 1,000 more than 10 years ago. However, the average annual number of marriages remains unchanged, at around 20,000 per year, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL UNIVERSITIES URGE MORE GOVERNMENT SPENDING

TEXT.P: The presidents of 11 of Taiwan's national universities called on Thursday for the government to spend more on further education, saying that budgets for national universities have posted negative growth for the past six years, if inflation rates are taken into account.

Chen Wei-chau, President of National Taiwan University, said in the unprecedented joint press conference that the government's budget for national universities increased 36 percent in fiscal 1998 from fiscal 1992, while the number of students grew by 30 percent and spending on each undergraduate rose 4 percent. However, he pointed out that the consumer price index rose 21.47 percent during the six-year period, making the spending on each student actually show a decline of NT$32,000.

Deducting the newly-established retirement fund, pay raises for faculties and insurance premiums from the budget, the actual spending on each student will drop NT$48,000 in fiscal 1998 compared with fiscal 1992, Chen said.

"Government spending on each undergraduate in Taiwan is much less than in neighboring countries," he said, citing as examples ROC government spending for each student at about NT$200,000 in fiscal 1998, compared with Hong Kong's Chinese University, at NT$520,000 in 1995, Hong Kong University's NT$920,000 in 1996, Osaka University's NT$1.04 million in 1997 and Tokyo University's NT$1.5 million in 1997.
Chen said that in line with the government's goal of upgrading national competitiveness and establishing Taiwan as a high-tech island, investment in further education should also be boosted.

National Central University, National Chengchi University, National Cheng Kung University, National Chung Cheng University, National Chunghsing University, National Taiwan Normal University, National Taiwan Ocean University, National Tung-hua University, National Tsiunghua University and National Chiao Tung University were also represented at the press conference .

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR TO ATTEND CABEI ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Y.D. Sheu, in his capacity as board member of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration (CABEI), will attend the bank's 37th annual board meeting slated for Oct. 30-31 in Guatemala City, the CBC announced on Thursday.
A delegation composed of ROC government officials will also take part in the annual conference, the CBC said.

The ROC joined the CABEI as a non-regional member in 1992, along with Argentina, Colombia and Mexico and has maintained close relations with the bank ever since. In May, the CABEI issued NT$6.8 billion-worth of bonds denominated in New Taiwan dollars.

The CABEI, which was set up in 1961 to boost the central American region's economic and social development, currently has five regional member-nations -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNEMPLOYMENT DOWN TO 2.84 PERCENT FOR SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dipped slightly in September to 2.84 percent, or 268,000 people without work, bringing the average jobless rate in the last nine months of this year to 2.77 percent, according to figures released on Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figures reflect a drop of 0.19 percentage points, or 19,000 persons less than in the previous month, and a 0.16 percentage points dip from the same period of last year after seasonal adjustment.

Due to the reopening of the island's schools after the summer break, which removed some student workers from the job market, Taiwan's workforce shrank by 22,000, or 0.23 percent in September, but was still 86,000, or 0.91 percent higher than the same period of last year, according to the DGBAS.

The workforce participation rate -- the ratio of the workforce to those aged 15 and more in the overall population -- stood at 58.18 in September, representing a 0.24 percent decrease from the previous month and 0.35 percent drop from the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG FINANCIAL TURBULENCE MIGHT INFLUENCE TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: A high-ranking ROC economic official said on Thursday that Hong Kong will be able to weather the current financial crisis as it retains abundant foreign exchange reserves and a sound financial system, but that if it fails to recover from the turmoil in a short time, Taiwan's economy might be affected.
Hong Kong's key Hang Seng share index plunged 1,211.47 points on Thursday to finish at 9766. The drop of 10.4 percent marked the fourth-biggest percentage fall in a single day.

Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said that whether or not the turbulence in the Hong Kong stock market will trigger a depreciation of the Hong Kong dollar needs to be closely watched. Depreciation of the Hong Kong dollar would benefit Hong Kong's exports, thus making Taiwan's exports face more severe competition, he added.

Hong Kong law stipulates that the Hong Kong dollar should be pegged to the US dollar, Lin said, adding that if depreciation occurs, the Hong Kong government will intervene. It is believed that the Hong Kong government will be easily able to protect the Hong Kong dollar's position in relation to the greenback, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 400,000 ILLEGAL ALIENS LEAVE SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: Nearly 400,000 visa overstayers, including those who have violated labor and residence rules, have left Saudi Arabia, according to a Saudi immigration official.

"A total of 399,815 expatriates who have been residing the country illegally have returned to their respective countries since the campaign (to expel them) started three months ago," said the official. In the meantime, he added, the Interior Ministry has "regularized" the resident permits of 166,755 other foreign workers.
The official said Saudi Arabia was making an all-out effort to repatriate the illegals, adding that the government was paying for their tickets, food and accommodation in most cases.
According to government sources, the overstayers are mostly from Egypt, India, Indonesia, Sudan, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Chad and Ethiopia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES, US TO HOLD TALKS ON PORK

TEXT.P: The Philippines and the United States will hold talks in Geneva next month to try to settle a row over the Philippines' pork import policy, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Thursday.

The Philippines agreed in the 1995 Uruguay Round world trade pact to open its market to pork and poultry imports, but US officials say it has failed to live up to its commitment by administering quotas for those products in such a way as to discourage imports.
US officials warned that a case may be filed against the Philippines at the WTO unless the pork import guidelines are amended, the WTO report said.
However, Philippine Secretary of Agriculture Salvador Escudero is reportedly lukewarm to changing the guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO RETURN KIDNAPPED POLICE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) called on Thursday for mainland China to repatriate a Taiwan coast guard official who, the SEF said, was kidnapped after a brawl with mainland Chinese fishermen earlier this month.

In a letter to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the SEF disputed Beijing's claims that the official, Chuang Chen-yao, beat the mainland fishermen and destroyed their equipment, saying that he was beaten and kidnapped while carrying out a regular inspection of the mainland vessel which was intercepted in Taiwan territorial waters near the frontline island of Matsu.

The fishing boat refused to stop for an inspection as ordered by a Taiwan patrol boat, according to the SEF. Instead, it led police on a 30-minute chase before Taiwan policemen were able to board the vessel.
The fishing boat then rammed the patrol boat in a desperate attempt to escape, while the fishermen attacked the police with sticks and broken bottles, said the SEF.

Two policeman, including Chuang, were injured in the fray. One managed to leave the mainland boat after it sailed too close to the Fujian coast, but Chuang was held hostage and taken to Fujian, said the SEF in its letter.
The SEF urged the mainland authorities to make haste with Chuang's repatriation and to allow his family to visit him in the meantime.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING VESSEL DETAINED BY INDONESIAN NAVY

TEXT.P: The Indonesian Navy on Sunday detained a Taiwan fishing boat allegedly caught fishing illegally in Indonesian territorial waters off the coast of northern Irian Jaya.
Antara news agency quoted a navy official as saying on Thursday that the Taiwan vessel Jin Hun Shin was detained 10 nautical miles from the beach.
According to the official, the vessel was only licensed to fish in Sulawesi waters.
The 62.32 ton ship is commanded by Tou Seah Chun, an ROC national, and has a 12-member crew, nine Indonesians and three from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-MEXICO ECONOMIC CONFERENCE ENDS

TEXT.P: The ninth ROC-Mexico Joint Economic Conference concluded Wednesday in Tijuana, Mexico, with the two countries agreeing to sign several agreements to boost bilateral trade ties.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang, chief delegate of the ROC delegation, gave a keynote speech at the one-day conference which was attended by more than 100 business executives from the two countries.

Chang and his Mexican counterpart, Jaime Zabludovsky, also reached agreement on several issues of mutual concern, including the setting up of a regular channel for dialogue among ranking trade officials, the signing of accords on investment guarantees and the temporary admission of goods, to further strengthen two-way trade and commerce relations.
Zabludovsky also expressed his country's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The two countries are expected to sign an agreement on Taiwan's membership of the world trade regulatory body, as bilateral talks on the issue have now almost concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS MAY BE HIT BY VOLATILE HK DOLLAR: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export business will face a serious challenge if the Hong Kong dollar continues to fall, officials from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Friday.

A depreciated Hong Kong currency will weaken Taiwan's competitiveness on the international markets as the former British colony is Taiwan's major competitor. The fall will also cut back Taiwan's exports to Hong Kong, Taiwan's second largest export outlet, consequently diminishing the island's trade surplus, an MOF spokesman said.

Hong Kong and the United States have traditionally alternated as Taiwan's largest export markets. In the first three quarters of this year, 23 percent of Taiwan's exports were directed toward Hong Kong, as compared with 24 percent to the American market, according to Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Statistics Department.

Hong Kong is also Taiwan's largest source of trade surplus, Hsu noted. Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$25.1 billion with Hong Kong in 1996, as compared with the island's overall positive trade balance of US$13.5 billion in the same year.
Taiwan would have suffered a trade deficit last year, mainly because of a huge deficit with Japan, had the island not enjoyed a mammoth surplus with Hong Kong, Hsu said.

If the Hong Kong currency continues to depreciate, the competitive edge of Taiwan's exports will be reduced. Since about half of Taiwan's exports to Hong Kong are destined for mainland China, a similar fall of the mainland renminbi could spur even greater losses to Taiwan exporters, he added.

Meanwhile, Hsu said the currency crises in Southeast Asian countries will have little adverse impact on Taiwan's exports as those economies generally have much weaker foundations than does Taiwan's, and their export products and major export outlets are different from those of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VOWS TO DEFEND FISHING RIGHTS AROUND TIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday expressed concern over Japan's alleged high-handed actions against Taiwan fishing boats operating in waters near the Tiaoyutai islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, mainland China and Japan.

Reiterating the Republic of China's sovereignty over the uninhabited Tiaoyutais, the ministry said the ROC government must receive guarantees on the rights of Taiwan fishermen to operate in traditional fishing grounds near the disputed island group before it will sign a new fishery accord with Japan.

"We have asked the Council of Agriculture to investigate reports that eight Suao-based Taiwan fishing vessels have recently been rammed by Japanese patrol boats when they were operating in waters near the Tiaoyutais," said Chang Chin-chu, director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department.
Chang said the MOFA has also ordered the ROC's representative offices in Tokyo and Okinawa to look into the incidents and convey the ROC's grave concern to the Japanese government.
Negotiators from Taiwan and Japan met twice last year to discuss the ROC's traditional fishing rights in waters surrounding the Tiaoyutais, but failed to reach an agreement.

As Japan intends to finalize fishing rights negotiations with mainland China and South Korea before striking a deal with Taiwan on similar issues, a planned third round of Taipei-Tokyo fishery talks has been put on hold.
"We'll push Japan to conduct a third-round meeting with our country as soon as possible to resolve the longstanding disputes over Tiaoyutai fishing rights," Chang said.

He went on to say that the MOFA has also asked the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, which handles exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, to probe the latest dispute.

Chang said the government has consistently upheld three principles in dealing with fishing disputes with Japan: insisting on ROC sovereignty claims over the Tiaoyutais, handling the issue in a peaceful and rational manner, and defending local fishermen's legitimate rights and interests.

The Suao Fishermen's Association complained on Thursday that at least three local fishing boats have been struck and damaged by Japanese patrol boats over the past week, and fishing gear belonging to five other local fishing vessels has also been destroyed or confiscated by the Japanese.

The fishermen in the Suao area claimed that the actions by the Japanese coast guard have cost them more than NT$2.5 million (US$83,000) in damages to their boats and equipment. They vowed to form a self-defense force to protect themselves if the government fails to take effective measures to safeguard their rights and interests.

The fishermen said the Japanese have consistently mercilessly rammed into Taiwan fishing boats, cut their fishing nets and damaged their other equipment whenever the ships inadvertently enter the 12-mile zone around the Tiaoyutais, which Japan has unilaterally claimed as its territory.
The Tiaoyutai archipelago lies in the East China Sea about 200 kilometers northeast of Taiwan and 300 kms west of Japan's Okinawa prefecture.

The uninhabitable islets first came into limelight in 1972 when their control, along with that of the Ryukyu Islands, was handed over to Japan by the United States, which had administered the island group since Japan's defeat in World War II.

The sovereignty dispute erupted once again in July 1996 when a Japanese ultrarightist group erected a makeshift lighthouse on one of the Tiaoyutai islets. The move angered people in Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND GOLF COURSE APPROVED

TEXT.P: A task force under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) that screens proposed Taiwan investments in mainland China on Friday approved the first project to build a golf course there.
MOEA Vice Minister Yin Chi-ming said a Taiwan businessman surnamed Cheng has applied to build a golf course valued at US$5 million on Hainan island off China's southeastern coast.

Yin noted that the government has agreed in principle to allow local businessmen to invest in golf course facilities on the mainland, and will review such applications on a case-by-case basis in the future.
The golf course was one of 30 investment projects worth a total of US$72.89 million approved by the MOEA task force on Friday.

Other approved projects involve four listed companies in Taiwan's stock market, including proposals by Eagle Food with an estimated value of US$30 million, and by Walsin Lihwa, Everlight Chemical, and Acer, valued at US$3.5 million, US$2 million and US$1 million, respectively. (By Lilian Wu) ENDITEM ZCZC CEP005 10-24-97 BEIJING THREATS HINDER CROSS-STRAIT TIES

Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) Lin Chung-ping, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Thursday that mainland China's unwillingness to renounce the use of force against Taiwan has become a major hurdle to improved cross-strait relations.

Lin made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in a public hearing on the impact of the upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin upon cross-strait relations.
Lin stressed that the welfare of 21 million people on Taiwan must not be compromised by improved Washington-Beijing ties.
Lin declared that the ROC is happy to see the US engagement with mainland China, saying that communication helps to promote understanding and defuse confrontation.
He said that the interaction between Washington and Beijing will also contribute to the overall stability of Asia and Pacific region.

Washington has promised to inform Taipei of anything arising from the Clinton-Jiang meeting which relates to Taiwan, Lin said, adding however that the United States has repeatedly stated it has no intention of acting as a mediator between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Nevertheless, Lin said, Washington is hoping that cross-strait dialogue can be resumed soon, although it will not interfere with the timing, form or content of the talks.

Lin said that the ROC hopes the Beijing leadership has consolidated its power base after the Communist Party congress, and that it can accept the fact of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin said that if both Taipei and Beijing could put aside their differences over the issue of sovereignty, and resume talks without prior conditions, then such a pragmatic approach would contribute to the stability of the Taiwan Strait, and also help to promote cross-strait economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREX RESERVES DROP TO NEW LOW

TEXT.P: As of the end of September, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves dropped to US$85.75 billion, their lowest level in 15 months, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Friday.

CBC officials said the September figure represents a US$2.04 billion decrease from the previous month, and attributed the drop to the CBC's interference in the foreign exchange market in the wake of the currency crises in Southeast Asian nations.
The falling amount also ousted Taiwan from the top-three list of the world's largest forex reserves holders.

In a bid to stabilize Taipei's foreign exchange market and to deflect the impact of the Southeast Asian currency crises, the CBC has sold some US$5 billion since July, resulting in a steady drop in the island's forex reserves, down from June's US$90.02 billion to US$88.77 billion in July, and from August's US$87.79 billion to US$85.75 billion in September.

The CBC also stepped into the foreign exchange market in March 1996, when mainland China lobbed missiles near Taiwan in an attempt to influence the outcome of the island's first popular presidential election. Forex reserves plummeted to US$82.55 billion then, down from US$90.08 billion in the previous month.
This year, after the cross-Taiwan Strait tensions eased, forex reserves gradually rebounded to reach US$90.08 billion and US$90.02 billion in May and June respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES TUMBLE

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, shedding 105.97 points to close at 7,719.04.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7,536.03, and experienced a high of 7,735.48.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 340 to 97, with 34 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$135.27 billion (US$4.42 billion).

Electrical engineering stocks dropped the most at 1.8 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.7 percent, textile stocks and foodstuff shares at 1.4 percent respectively, financial shares at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent. Paper and pulp shares record an increase of 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIALS DENY NOT TO TALK WITH TAIWAN DURING LEE'S TENURE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Chang Lung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Officials from mainland China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs (COTA) on Thursday denied reports that Beijing will refuse to negotiate with Taiwan for the remainder of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.
The officials remarked that promoting political negotiations across the Taiwan Strait is and will remain of utmost significance to Beijing, and that this cannot be done without talking to Taipei.

Reports had quoted former US Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Affairs John Holdrige as saying he had been told by Xiong Guangkai, deputy chief of the general staff of the People's Liberation Army and military representative to COTA, that as long as Lee Teng-hui remains the ROC president, it is unlikely talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can be resumed.
Informed sources in Beijing say that although some Communist officials have no desire to deal with Lee, such opinions do not reflect the mainstream point of view among the leadership hierarchy.

Observers also point out that while Lee has only two and a half years remaining in his second and final term as ROC president, he has another four years left as the recently re-elected chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

And, while mainland China's President Jiang Zemin was recently re-elected as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party for another five-year term, he would be facing the constraints of time if he pinned his hopes on waiting for Lee to bow out as either the ROC head of state or as the KMT party leader.

The observers said that resuming the cross-strait dialogue, and beginning negotiations on a political settlement, remains the established policy of Beijing, regardless of whether Lee or anyone else is the ROC president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO IMPROVE SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday reaffirmed the government's determination to improve social order and urged the public to give officials "more time" to produce results.
Siew made the remarks in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Siew admitted that social order has not seen marked improvement over recent months, but said that the current problems likewise did not arise overnight. Rather, as they are related to complex political and social changes occurring after the lifting of the martial law in Taiwan, Siew appealed for a little more time to deal with the problem.

Noting that he has focused on bettering social order through both short- and long-term approaches since assuming his post in September, Siew said a spiritual revitalization is also crucial to the improvement of social order.

The Executive Yuan passed several measures on police administrative reforms in a floor meeting Thursday. These included upgrading the ability of law enforcement officials to investigate and prevent criminal cases, expanding the rank-and-file police force, beefing up marine security, and sending officials overseas to German and Japan to observe police administrative reforms in those countries.

Meanwhile, the brutal murder of plastic surgeon Fang Pao-fang, his wife and a nurse at a Taipei clinic Thursday afternoon shocked the nation and dominated discussions in the legislative session on Friday.

The murder of the three victims, all found blindfolded, bound, gagged and shot with a single bullet to the head at close range, recalled the gangland-style killing of former Taoyuan Magistrate Liu Pan-you and seven others at his residence in November 1996.

Legislator Peng Shau-ching of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party asked Interior Minister Yeh Chin-feng and National Police Administration Director-General Ting Yuan-ching to step down if they fail to solve the latest high-profile murder case within two weeks.

Peng said the fact that the killings took place in broad daylight, and that the clinic is located on Roosevelt Road near the Presidential Office, Judicial Yuan and the Ministry of Justice, shows the degree of both the ruthlessness and the audacity of the killers.

Peng claimed that criminal elements have familiarized themselves with the methods used in the Liu murders, but that police have yet to learn how to solve such cases. He said Taiwan has become a haven for criminals, with a helpless government and a fearful public.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE WARNS OF TROUBLE OVER TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said in Boston on Thursday that there is still some danger of trouble with mainland China over deeply emotional issues like Taiwan.
He served the warning in his speech to a Fortune 500 Forum on the subject, "The Prospects for East Asia."
"No (mainland) Chinese leader can afford to be branded as the man who lost Taiwan," he said. "But the danger of a military conflict between China and the United States is low.

"Chinese leaders know that US military superiority is overwhelming, and will remain so for the next few decades," he told an audience of business leaders and CEOs from the top 500 companies in the United States.
"They will modernize their forces not to challenge America but to be able, if necessary, to pressure Taiwan by a blockade, or otherwise to destabilize the economy," Lee asserted.
He said mainland China wants to grow quickly to become "an industrial power within 30 years."
"Their market may become as big as America's, enough to give it leverage over the countries of East and Southeast Asia," he pointed out. "This is the area in which China can increase its influence."
Speaking of relations between the Washington and Beijing, Lee said he believes the signs are good for a period of "workmanlike relations" between the two.
"A stable relationship is possible and confrontation need never happen because both the United States and China want to avoid confrontation and its costly consequences," he said.
He was of the view that mainland China's challenge is "to reassure the world, especially its neighbors, that a resurgent China will be a responsible one."

Membership of international organizations like the World Trade Organization (WTO) is essential to ensuring that mainland China becomes a responsible member of the international community as it becomes a major stakeholder in the key institutions of the post-Cold War era, he said.

Lee also noted that US policy on mainland China has gradually taken shape. "President Clinton's stated policy is engagement in depth. At the same time, he has strengthened ties with Japan in the US-Japan Defense Guidelines and increased its access to bases in the region," he said.
Mainland China has been outspoken in its opposition to this extension of the US-Japan security pact but will tolerate the present arrangements, he added.
