Mainland China too is courting members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) so that they will stay "neutral" in any US-China dispute, he pointed out.

It is against this background that ASEAN countries have to seek stability and growth, Lee stressed, noting that the original five countries of ASEAN were brought together by the common enemy of communism.
He pointed out that the present nine member countries of ASEAN do not have a common enemy to unite them. "If China is prudent and tactful, there will be none," he observed.
"On issues involving its sovereignty, like Taiwan, Tibet and Hong Kong, ASEAN will not want to be involved," he said. "Over the Spratlys, ASEAN cannot remain neutral," he added.

On other issues, he asserted, ASEAN is likely to be torn between two strong currents: "the need to retain American presence, and the need to develop a viable long-term relationship with a huge neighbor."
He pointed out that ASEAN's ties with and leanings towards America derive from the long period of the Cold War. "It is in US interests to preserve these ties," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WANTS TO ENGAGE AS WELL AS DETER PLA

TEXT.P: Washington's military engagement with Beijing is aimed at both articulating US policies and intentions and demonstrating US military capabilities in order to deter the People's Liberation Army "in the event of the relationship going in the direction no one wants," a US defense official said Thursday.

Randall Schriver, senior country director for mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Mongolia in the Office of the Secretary of Defense, told a briefing sponsored by the US Institute of Peace on the Oct. 29 summit between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin that "it is important for them (the PLA) to understand our capabilities and know what we can bring to bear on a situation which would involve conflict that, again, no one wants."

Schriver said that Washington's objectives for a military relationship with Beijing have been consistent, among which are developing a better understanding of PLA's modernization efforts, pursuing the relationship to sustain the support of US allies who do not want to contain Beijing, and promoting operator-to-operator dialogue to avoid misunderstanding on the ground.

In preparing for the summit, Schriver said, the US Defense Department is working hard on a military maritime safety agreement in line with the objectives of minimizing misunderstanding and miscalculations at sea.

He said that the Pentagon is also trying to articulate the framework for military contacts between the two sides consisting of high-level contacts, professional and functional exchanges, confidence-building measures, and participation in multilateral forums. "We want to have presidential endorsement so as to allow us to pursue contacts through that framework."

Meanwhile, he said, the Defense Department is working hard trying to reach an agreement with the PLA on cooperation in humanitarian and disaster relief which he emphasized is very important as part of confidence-building measures as well as being a strong signal to the region that the two sides not only are not adversaries but also can work together on problems and regional challenges.

He noted that Washington originally proposed joint humanitarian relief exercises during mainland Chinese Defense Minister Chi Haotian's visit here last December but has not been able to get agreement from the PLA. Now, the US side hopes to institute a gradual approach beginning with exchange of information and seminars between the two militaries about their respective experiences.
While defense officials view the summit as a very important event, he said, it is also only one event in the Pentagon's very long-term engagement strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALY IMPROVES VISA SERVICES TO ROC NATIONALS

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals with a visa to any of the seven Schengen Convention countries will be able to make visa-free visits to Italy starting Oct. 26, a senior official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.
R.T. Yang, director of the ministry's European Affairs Department, told a routine news conference that Italy will begin to implement the Schengen Convention on Oct. 26.

"The Italian Economic and Cultural Promotion Office, which represents Italian interests in Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, has informed us that ROC passport holders with a visa to any of the countries that are signatories to the Schengen Convention can enter Italy freely from Oct. 26," Yang said.

He further said the Italian representative office has promised to begin issuing "Schengen" visas to ROC nationals as soon as possible. Once this is done, ROC citizens who obtain a visa to visit Italy will also be able to visit any of the seven other Schengen Convention countries -- the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Spain, Portugal, Germany and France.

Meanwhile, Yang said, the Italian government has announced that ROC nationals who have been granted the right to reside in Italy will no longer need to apply for an entry visa if they want to re-enter that country after a short leave.
"We welcome this new measure," Yang said, adding it is expected to help boost bilateral exchanges and reinforce substantive relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DIPLOMAT WARNS OF PROBLEMS IN CLINTON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: A potential blowup on the Korean Peninsula, the stability of the Taiwan Strait and the threat to democracy in Hong Kong are serious issues which will face US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in their talks next week in Washington.

In an interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's "Late Line" program Thursday night, former US Ambassador to mainland China James Lilley sounded out that warning ahead of the Clinton-Jiang summit.

"We have very serious problems with China that we have to get on ... and the No. 1 priority is dealing with North Korea," Lilley said. "I can tell you, if you don't (resolve them), two to three million people will lose human rights that could cause deaths. You have to deal with that now."
Next in line comes the issues of the stability of the Taiwan Strait, the threat to democracy in Hong Kong, trade issues, nuclear proliferation and the Tibetan problem.

Also being interviewed in the same program, Australia's former Prime Minister Bob Hawke agreed with Lilley's views that the problems involving North Korea and the stability of Taiwan are very serious.

Speaking on the same program, Nancy Pelosi, a Democratic member of the US House of Representatives, said: "It is inappropriate to give red carpet treatment to the head of a regime that continues to violate human rights and abuses in mainland China and in Tibet, and continues to proliferate the weapons of mass destruction."
In a blunt remark, Lilley said: "We got to get the Japan-US security treaty understood by China and perhaps even bring China into talks as a partner into the triangular relationship."

He said mainland China, the United States, Japan and South Korea are the keys to resolving the North Korean problem. "The sooner they solve the problem, the better. And China has to be a partner," he said.
Lilley said another critical issue between Clinton and Jiang will be the security and prosperity of the Taiwan Strait.
"We almost had a shootout there in March 1996. And finally I have one point to make -- that is, we have got an experiment going in Hong Kong where democracy is under threat," he said.

He noted that although prosperity is being maintained after the handover of the former British colony to mainland China, "it seems to me that is crucial to watch closely. And I don't think they know which direction they will go, whether it is going to change China or whether Hong Kong will change or both will change."
Lilley said China always gives the US lectures about its "unity, sovereignty, and Taiwan."
"The Chinese give us moralistic lessons almost every day. We get sermons on sovereignty, unity ... we get these lectures constantly," he said.
"And when they (China) start talking about sovereignty and Taiwan, we talk about human rights and democracy, Hong Kong, Taiwan and China.

"It seems to me now that we've got other subjects to deal about -- nuclear proliferation, trade and North Korea and the stability in the Taiwan Strait -- that sort of things is the real issue," Lilley said.

On the issue of human rights, Tibet and other problems, Hawke disagreed with both Lilley and Pelosi. He said the Washington has to discuss the problems with mainland China through bilateral dialogues instead of public platforms.

"There is no difference that we have the same objective and we want to achieve our objective," Hawke said. "But we are much more likely to achieve our objective if we don't get on our platform and preach them (China) moralities, but recognize the cultural differences of China," Hawke said.

Pelosi disagreed with Hawke's views, saying the United States is not preaching its values to mainland China. Rather, "we are only saying to China that your own constitution gives certain guaranty to your people."
"We are talking about honoring your constitution and hopefully honoring the declaration of human rights because China is a signatory of the declarations of human rights," Pelosi said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTENTIAL AGENDA JIANG-CLINTON SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Less than a week before Jiang Zemin's summit with US President Bill Clinton in Washington, a noted US scholar on Asian affairs warns that the meeting should not be expected to solve a multitude of difficult, often intractable, issues and disputes between the United States and China.

In a 25-page Asia Update entitled "The 1997 Sino-American Summit," published this week by the New York-based Asia Society, David Shambaugh, professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University, points out that historical experience suggests that "expectations should not be falsely raised, as they often go unfulfilled, leaving Beijing and Washington blaming each other for retrogression."

It is unlikely that the two sides will produce a joint communique, but they are likely to release a joint public statement and hold a news conference with the two presidents, Shambaugh predicts. "One unresolved issue about the public statement is how the two sides should characterize their relationship, i.e. whether to define it as a 'partnership' and, if so, what kind?" he says, adding that the terms "strategic partnership" (which China has used to describe its relations with Russia and France) and "constructive partnership" are being considered.

According to Shambaugh, who is presently working on a book entitled "China's Military Enters the 21st Century, " the potential agenda for the Jiang-Clinton summit can be divided into two categories: "action items," involving agreements that will likely be reached, and broader issues for discussion, over which differences exist or where cooperation will be sought.
He lists the likely "action items" as including:

--an agreement to regularize and enhance strategic dialogue between the two governments, including agreement to hold regular annual summit meetings between heads of state, as well as regular consultations in each capital between foreign and defense ministers and their principal deputies;
--a new and expanded set of military-to-military exchanges;
--a Military Maritime Cooperation Agreement;
--a Chinese agreement to buy up to 30 Boeing aircraft, and perhaps other large commercial deals;
--the implementation of the 1985 US-China Nuclear Cooperation Accord.
--the establishment of a "communications link" (a.k.a. hotline) between the two presidents.
--the establishment of a bilateral Human Rights Commission to be administered by nongovernmental organizations, and the implementation of a regular human rights dialogue between the two governments.

--the possible reactivation of activities in mainland China by the US government's Trade and Development Agency and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, as well as the extension of Export-Import Bank financing for US companies doing business in mainland China. All of these activities were suspended as part of the 1989 post-Tiananmen sanctions;
--an agreement to bolster US support for development of mainland China's legal system;
--an agreement to bolster US support for pollution abatement programs in mainland China;
--an agreement to cooperate in drug enforcement and other joint measures to combat organized crime;
--an agreement to broaden cooperation and research in space technology; and
--a stated commitment to deepen academic exchanges and expand the Fulbright program.
However, Shambaugh noted, behind these anticipated agreements and action items, each side has an agenda of "deeper and more troubling issues."

As the author of "The 1997 Sino-American Summit" sees it, it would seem likely that the Chinese government will come to the summit with a slate of items on their broad agenda with the United States. They include lifting the remaining Tiananmen sanctions and a US agreement to drop its annual attempt to pass a resolution condemning mainland China's human rights conditions at the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME SE COUNTRIES ASK ROC TO HELP ADDRESS FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Some Southeast Asian countries have approached the Republic of China for assistance in addressing their financial crises in recent months, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said on Friday.

"Since the outbreak of the Southeast Asian financial turmoil in July, several countries in the region have sought financial assistance from the ROC," said Chang Chin-chu, director of the ministry's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department.
Chang said those countries have expressed the hope that the ROC offers them loans to help prop up their currencies.

"In consideration of our own financial situation and the fact that the ROC is not a member of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, we have been very cautious in handling the issue," Chang said, adding: "We think it is better that such assistance is offered through international organizations."
Chang would not identify the countries which have requested financial assistance from the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: XIAMEN TO HOST CROSS-STRAIT TRADE AND COMMERCE SYMPOSIUM
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Chang Lung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The "Cross-century Symposium on Trade and Commerce Across the Taiwan Strait" to be held in the mainland city of Xiamen, Fujian Province, Dec. 7-9 is likely to have an impact on Taipei's "no haste, be patient" policy regarding Taiwan's reunification with mainland China.

This will be the year's largest meeting concerning cross-strait relations to be sponsored by mainland China, and it is expected to provide guideposts of Beijing's efforts to get cross-strait talks back on track.

Especially noteworthy is the fact that Chiao Jen-ho, secretary-general and vice chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has been invited to the symposium even though the protocol dialogue between the two sides has not yet resumed.

This indicates that Beijing is trying to use trade and commerce to make a breakthrough in cross-strait relations. By doing so, Beijing can on the one hand make its own Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and Taipei's SEF work with each other again, and on the other can put some pressure on Taipei's "no haste, be patient" policy.

The symposium, sponsored by ARATS and backed by the All-China Federation of Taiwan Compatriots and other mainland organizations, has been organized by ARATS Executive Vice Chairman Tang Shubei, who will take part in the meeting from beginning to end. It has not yet been announced whether or not ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan will also attend.

The meeting is a step toward Beijing's goals of negating Taipei's "no haste, be patient" policy and achieving "the political goal (of Taiwan's reunification with mainland China) through trade and commercial pressure."

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: IT IS BEIJING THAT HINDERS "THREE DIRECT LINKS"

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Friday that it is Beijing that hinders the opening of direct transportation, communication, and trade links between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland.

Answering a question by Legislator Chen Chi-mai (DPP-Kaohsiung City), Siew said that, for the sake of national interest and security, the government must ban the "three direct links" at the present time.
He said only on the basis of mutual trust and mutual benefit can the three links perform normally.

The premier said that he is not opposed to the opening of the three direct links, and that he fully understands the business sector's hope for an early lifting of the ban. "But we have to wait until the time is ripe, otherwise it would be very dangerous to us."

Taiwan has banned direct trade, communication, and transportation links with mainland China since Communist troops occupied the mainland in 1949. Beijing has stepped up its efforts to push for the opening of the three links in recent years.

Siew said the time to open the direct links is not ripe because Beijing still harbors hostile attitude toward Taiwan. He urged those who hope for an early opening of the direct links go to the other side of the Taiwan Strait and say the obstacle to doing so lies in Beijing. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED NOT TO NEGLECT CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Legislator Parris Hsu-cheng Chang Friday urged the government not to neglect the possible effect of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Washington next week.

At the "Forum on National Affairs" of the Legislative Yuan, Chang described the visit as the beginning of "a second normalization" of the relations between mainland China and the United States. He said the two countries may hold summit meetings each year from now on, and the relations between them may improve substantially.

Chang, who is also the representative of the Democratic Progressive Party to the United States, said mainland Chinese leaders are trying to influence American political leaders' attitude toward Taiwan.

He said that, although the U.S. government has made it clear that Washington and Beijing are not going to sign a "fourth communique" during Jiang's state visit to Washington, a "statement" may be issued at the end of his visit, and the statement may include a "Taiwan clause."

In the statement, Beijing could reiterate its principle of "one China," urge Washington to refrain from supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, and ask Washington not to support Taiwan independence, the lawmaker of Taiwan's major opposition party said.

He said Taiwan should not neglect mainland Chinese activities in the United States, because Beijing wants to persuade Washington into endorsing its "unification policy" toward Taiwan, make Taiwan look like an obstacle to the development of U.S. relations with mainland China, and eventually cut off Taiwan's lifeline. (by Ed Shay)

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF NATIONAL INTEREST

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Friday at the legislative Yuan that the government can review the policy aimed at encouraging Taiwan businessmen to "make no haste, and be patient" when making plans to invest in mainland China.
Siew said however that "we must not lose sight of our need to safeguard our national interest and sovereignty, when we do the reviewing."
He made the remarks when answering a question by DPP Legislator Shih Ming-teh, who asked the premier to shed more light on the government's policy toward mainland China.

Siew pointed out that over the past 10 years more and more Taiwan businessmen have made investment on the Chinese mainland. Only investments in the infrastructure and a few other special sectors of mainland China have been restricted under the policy.
He said the government has to maintain the restriction, because the Chinese communist regime still holds hostile attitude toward Taiwan.
The premier said the ban on direct trade, communication, and transportation links with the Chinese mainland can also be reviewed on the basis of national interest and safety. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE ISSUES NEW PORNOGRAPHY GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: The Singapore Broadcasting Authority (SBA) reiterated Thursday that the target of its war on the Internet is pornography.

Since the SBA knows, however, that it would be impossible to block access to the proliferation of pornographic sites on the Net, it will focus instead on stopping pornographic sites which children can reach easily, said SBA chief executive officer Lim Hock Chuan on Thursday.
"The SBA is not out to eliminate all these sites, that is certainly not the way we approach the regulation of the Internet," he said.
He estimated that there are almost a million pornographic sites in the world, with about 25 million pages devoted to sexual content.

To give the local Internet industry and surfers a clear idea of what the SBA considers obscene and pornographic, the authority has released more specific guidelines, including listing several forms of sexual perversion in the new Internet Code of Practice, which was released Thursday.
For instance, pornographic content has been clarified to include material that depicts nudity or genitalia, or of people clearly engaged in sex, "in a manner calculated to titillate."
This does not include content that has an "intrinsic medical, scientific, artistic or educational value."
The new code also spells out what it considers to be sex with children.
Previously, pedophilia was mentioned in passing. But under the new code it is defined as any content on sexual activity with "a person who is, or appears to be, under 16 years of age."
The revised code also adds three more areas of sexual content to its list of sexual perversions not seen in the earlier version: incest, bestiality and necrophilia.

While the SBA does not have any employees dedicated to sniffing out pornographic sites, it has eight staff members who, aside from their own duties, also surf the Internet regularly, Lim said, adding that if any objectionable sites based in other countries are uncovered, local Internet service providers would then be asked to filter the offending sites from the public.
About 100 sites have so far been banned.
If the site is hosted in Singapore, then the owner of the site would be asked to remove the prohibited content. To refuse is to risk a fine, he said.

However, Lim said that the SBA has never used its legal powers in this regard. In the four instances when prohibited material was found on local sites, the content was always removed promptly, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE ATTENDS RECEPTION MARKING RETROCESSION DAY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui attended a cocktail reception hosted by the Taiwan Provincial Government (TPG) in Chunghsing New Village in central Taiwan on Friday to mark the 52nd anniversary of the retrocession of Taiwan to the Republic of China after 50 years of Japanese colonial rule.
Lee said he was delighted to attend the reception on the eve of Taiwan Retrocession Day, which falls on Oct. 25.
The president lauded all the people of the island for their diligence and devotion to helping develop Taiwan from a poor agrarian society to an economic powerhouse in the Asia-Pacific region.
This is the first time that Lee, who once served as governor of Taiwan, has attended Retrocession Day celebrations since the central government decided to downsize the provincial government.

Lee took the opportunity to explain the main purpose of this policy. "The streamlining of the provincial government is primarily aimed at minimizing the overlapping of functions of government agencies at different levels so as to cut red tape and enhance administrative efficiency," the president said, adding that the decision is the result of a national consensus.
Noting that the staff of the provincial government staff is a valuable workforce, Lee said the government will make the best possible arrangement for all the 120,000 TPG employees.

The president further said the TPG streamlining is only part of a comprehensive government restructuring plan aimed at trimming the government hierarchy and upgrading the country's international competitiveness.
According to a package of constitutional amendments passed in July this year, all provincial-level elections will be suspended after the current terms expire late next year.

Lee admitted that the TPG downsizing involves many difficult and complicated problems. "For the sake of our country's long-term development, we should overcome all obstacles and work hand-in-hand to ensure the smooth implementation of the streamlining plan."

The president went on to say he appreciates the devoted service of the TPG staff and the Taiwan Provincial Assembly over the years. "Our country needs your continued services. I hope all of you will stand united and cooperate closely with the central government to complete various ambitious trans-century construction and reform projects."

Speaking on the same occasion, Taiwan Governor James Soong, who was vehemently opposed to the TPG downsizing plan but threw his support behind the project after the National Assembly passed the related constitutional amendments, said that over the past five decades the TPG has consistently cooperated with the central government to build the island into a prosperous economy.

Soong said that while he does not oppose overall government restructuring in order to upgrade government efficiency, "the restructuring plan should be drafted jointly by the central, provincial and other local-level government agencies to ensure its feasibility and perfection."

Vice Premier John Chang, Haitian Ambassador Sonny Seraphin and many other senior central, provincial, city and county government officials, provincial assembly deputies, county councilors and representatives of social groups also attended the cocktail reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN MEETS FOREIGN DIGNITARIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Friday called on the international community to make investments in Taiwan and stressed the Republic of China government's determination to step up cultural development.

While meeting with Albert Roynolds, who served as Ireland's prime minister from 1992 to 1994 and is currently a member of parliament, Lien expressed the hope that Irish enterprises can invest in Taiwan, noting economic liberalization and globalization are set policies of the ROC government.
Lien told Roynolds that the ROC government has been actively pushing for the privatization of its state-run firms and that it welcomes foreign companies to take part in the drive.
This was the second meeting between Lien and Roynolds. They first met when Lien visited Ireland in June.

Later, in a meeting with David Rockefellor Jr., president of the US-based Asian Culture Council (ACC), Lien stressed the ROC government's determination to boost Taiwan's developments of cultural activities in an effort to upgrade the island's quality of life.
Although Taiwan's annual per-capita income has hit US$13,000, Lien said, the spiritual dimension of Taiwan people's lives needs to be further elevated.

For his part, Rockefellor said the ACC is very willing to strengthen cultural and artistic exchanges with the ROC in order to boost mutual understanding and communication between the people of the two countries.
Rockefellor was accompanied by Douglas Hsu, president of the ROC-US Asian Culture Foundation, while Vice Presidential Secretary-General Su Chi was also present.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.135 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$30.365.
The greenback opened at 30.280 and was traded between 30.280 and 30.550.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$341 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS DEFENDS GOVERNMENT'S HANDLING OF FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Friday's edition of a local English-language daily, the China Post.
The Criticism of CBC Policy

The Central Bank of China (CBC) has in recent months remained a target of harsh criticism in the media, first for its persistent defense of the New Taiwan dollar and more recently for its sudden abandonment of the battle to let the local currency determine its own value in accord with supply and demand.
What (CBC Governor) Sheu (Yuan-dong) and his colleagues failed to recognize beforehand was an unexpected effect that the neighboring market crisis had on Taiwan.
The authorities at the CBC had thought that the Southeast Asian markets' financial problems would be brought under control quickly with the aid of the International Monetary Fund.

But to the disappointment of the CBC, the Thai government, when it announced a long-awaited crisis-tackling package in late September, failed to restore market confidence and, as a result, sparked a new round of speculative currency attacks.

When the CBC kept selling greenbacks to safeguard the value of the NT dollar, the bank was actually creating a ground for a growing crunch in local currency funds and, because of this, a surge in interest rates. A tightening money market not only hit investors, but also put additional pressure on an already falling stock exchange. So investors and stock buyers all vented their anger at the CBC.

However, the legislative request for Sheu's resignation and some of the criticism leveled at him ... do not seem to be entirely justifiable. No central bank in the world would stand idly by when a nation's currency comes under unreasonable speculative attacks.

Should Governor Sheu finally step down under pressure from legislators and others, it would seriously undermine the credibility of the CBC, an institution which is supposed to function independently from political influence. ... If the CBC must listen to politicians, its governor would never be able to make independent judgments in setting monetary policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, MAINLAND NUCLEAR COOPERATION NEEDS TO BE CLOSELY WATCHED

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Friday that talks regarding nuclear cooperation at the upcoming summit meeting between the United States and mainland China need to be closely monitored.

Hu said that US President Bill Clinton and his mainland China counterpart Jiang Zemin are expected to reach several agreements at the summit meeting on Oct. 29, including maritime military cooperation aimed at teaming-up marine rescue efforts and non-nuclear proliferation cooperation.

Hu made the marks while answering questions from legislators who expressed concern that nuclear cooperation between the US and the mainland will have profound impact on the military balance in the western Pacific Ocean over the next 10 or 20 years.

Despite a Washington-Beijing nuclear cooperation agreement signed 12 years ago to facilitate the exchange of nuclear cooperation and technology for peaceful purposes, the US government has never issued any permits allowing any such exports to the mainland for fear that the mainland authorities might fail to honor the agreement and transfer the technology to the manufacture of nuclear weapons, Hu said.

But now American people feel that the mainland authorities seem to realize that they have an obligation to observe international practices with regard to the control of radioactive materials, or they will also become a victim, Hu said, noting that the US and the mainland have a chance of reaching a new nuclear cooperation agreement at the summit talks which will mean that the US government will agree to put the previously-signed pact into effect.
Hu said that if the agreement promotes the export of nuclear power facilities to the mainland, the ecological environment is also sure to be affected to some degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO IMPROVE RELATIONS WITH ROC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is glad to see the United States and mainland China increase their exchanges, and would be glad to see Jiang Zemin's up-coming visit to Washington successful, a spokesman said here Friday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, said also at a regular press conference that "benign exchanges" between Washington and Beijing may enhance the stability and prosperity in the Asian Pacific region.

He said the Republic of China government has stressed several times that American relations with Taiwan and with mainland China are parallel, and therefore hopes that the U. S. government will improve its relations with Taipei when its tries to improve its relations with Beijing.

The spokesman said the ROC government appreciate the repeated assurance made by the U.S. government that Taiwan's interest will not be hurt in the summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Washington on Oct. 29.

In spite of the assurance by the U.S. government, "we still hope that the U.S. government will avoid hurting our interest in the summit for the sake of peaceful development in the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the welfare of the 21 million people on Taiwan."
Jiang is scheduled to leave Sunday for an eight-day official visit to the United States.

Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen also said at a press conference Friday that the ROC government would be glad to see Jiang make a successful visit in the United States, if the visit can help promote prosperity and peace in the Asian Pacific region. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: POULTRY FARMERS HURT BY EGG OVER-PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: An over-production of eggs has hurt Taiwan's poultry farmers, an official of the Chinese Poultry Farmers Association said on Friday.

He said egg prices in Taiwan have fallen drastically this year due to over-production and are currently at around NT$1 (about 3 US cents) apiece on the local market, which is lower than actual production costs of about NT$1.6 (5 US cents).
As a result, almost all the island's 1,700 poultry farmers are losing money, the official said.

Hsieh Shih-chuan, one of Taiwan's principal poultry farmers, has a laying flock of 300,000 hens that are kept in computerized chicken shelters and produce high-quality eggs which have been well received in the market. But he said that he too has been suffering as a result of the low prices.

At present, there are some 27 million hens in Taiwan, producing 76,500 crates of eggs (about 15 million eggs) per day. However, current daily demand in Taiwan is for only about 60,000 crates, with more than 200,000 crates already in stock.

Because of this heavy financial pressure, some poultry farmers have already started working on ways to resolve the over-production problem, with plans which include the elimination of some three million of the less-productive hens, egg-promotion campaigns aimed at the general public and the development of the egg-processing industry to handle the extra eggs.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DENIES `NO CONTACT WITH LEE TENG-HUI' REMARKS

TEXT.P: A ranking official with mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) denied on Friday that ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei has said that Beijing will not have any contact with ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

A Washington Post dispatch from Beijing on Oct. 22 said that during an interview with the US paper at his Beijing office on Oct. 14, Tang said that Beijing will have no contact with Lee and that the so-called "Taiwan issue" will not be solved in the next two years while Lee is still in power.
ARATS is the mainland organization in charge of handling exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official contact.
The official, who asked not to be named and was also present at the Oct. 14 interview, said that Tang didn't make the remarks.

Tang simply reiterated the calls made by mainland President Jiang Zemin at last month's 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) that both Taiwan and the mainland should return to the negotiating table to work out a way to "end the hostility across the Taiwan Strait under the `one China' principle," according to the official.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) questioned a similar remark made by Xiong Guangkai, the People's Liberation Army's deputy chief of general staff, that Beijing will not conduct any dialogue with Taiwan while Lee is in office.
Xiong's remarks contradict the statement made by Jiang at the CCP congress, said MAC Vice Chairman Hsu Ke-sheng.
Mainland Vice Premier Zhu Rongji has also urged both sides to make arrangements for the opening of political negotiations, indicating that Beijing is still seeking dialogue with Taipei, he added.
But if the remarks by Tang and Xiong are true, then Taipei will consider Beijing insincere in proposing the dialogue, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION STANDS AT 21.61 MILLION

TEXT.P: The population in the Taiwan area stood at 21.61 million as of the end of September, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior.
This figure, which was released on the eve of the Taiwan Restoration Day, is more than three times that of 50 years ago.

Taiwan was ceded to Japan in 1895 following China's defeat in the first Sino-Japanese war (1894-95). The island was restored to China on Oct. 25, 1945 after Japan's surrender at the end of World War II.
A census conducted in 1946 indicated that there were 6.09 million people in the Taiwan area, for a population density of 169 persons per square kilometer, compared with the present 600 persons.

With improvements in the standard of living and better medical care, the life span in Taiwan has also greatly extended during the past five decades. In 1951, the life expectancy was 53.3 years for men and 56.3 years for women, but this has now risen to 71.9 years for men and 77.7 years for women, according to the statistics.

However, the improvement in the living conditions in Taiwan has cut down the family size drastically, with the average family reduced from 6.09 persons in 1951 to 3.51 persons at present, the same statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN WIDENING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan expanded to US$12.40 billion for the first nine months of this year, up 21.27 percent from the same period of last year, signaling that more effort should be made to improve the trade imbalance, according to statistics compiled by customs officials.

The figure shows that Taiwan exported US$9.0 billion-worth of goods to Japan during the nine-month period, a decline of 13.31 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports from Japan increased 3.8 percent to reach US$21.47 billion.
Two-way trade with Japan accounted for 17.47 of Taiwan's total trade with foreign countries, which stood at US$174.1 billion as of the end of September.

Customs officials attributed the drop in exports to Japan to the ban on pork exports to Japan due to the March epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease on the island. The depreciation of the Japanese yen was also one of the leading factors that reduced imports from Taiwan.

The five leading categories enjoying the largest percentage growth in exports to Japan were: steel and related products; optical instruments; seafood; porcelain; and electrical engineering products, while the top five import items in terms of percentage gains were: precious stones; gold; electrical engineering products; processed foods and drinks; and communications products.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM TO SUE FCC

TEXT.P: Following similar moves by neighboring countries, Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. announced on Friday that it will take court action against a United States Federal Communications Commission (FCC) order to cut international settlement rates on overseas calls.

Chunghwa Telecom said that reforms of settlement rates should be based on a global basis and that the FCC's unilateral decision to set up benchmark levels without specific cost data is a violation of other countries' jurisdictions, adding that Japan's KDD, Hong Kong's HKTI and Singapore's ST have filed lawsuits against the FCC's policy order.
Settlement rates are the amounts telephone companies charge each other to complete link-ups of international calls.

The FCC announced on Aug. 28 that it will continue with its plan to cut the rates by up to 70 percent starting in January 1999 at the latest, setting lower benchmarks for international settlement rates in a bid to reduce a US$5.5 billion payment deficit by US phone companies to their foreign counterparts.
The decision imposes a ceiling on the settlement rates which US carriers have to pay other regional telecommunications operators.

As Taiwan, along with Japan, Singapore and Hong Kong, are categorized as high-income nations by the FCC, settlement fees paid to telecommunications operators of these countries will be reduced from the current US$0.57 per minute to just US$0.15.

If the FCC implements the new move, Taiwan will see a loss of about NT$2.6 billion in international settlement rates each year, Chunghwa Telecom estimated, as the number of calls from the US to Taiwan is greater than the number made from Taiwan to the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S SEPTEMBER FOREX RESERVES STILL RANK THIRD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign exchange reserves at the end of September totaled US$85.7 billion, US$2 billion down from the August level but still the third-highest in the world behind only Japan and mainland China, according to statistics released on Friday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
A CBC official said that Japan held the largest forex reserves in September -- US$220 billion -- followed by mainland China, with US$130 billion and the ROC, with US$87.8 billion.
The US$2 billion decrease was due to the CBC's selling of the greenback in order to safeguard the New Taiwan dollar.

The decline of the country's forex reserves has ignited discussion on the rankings of the world's forex reserves, with unofficial figures revealing that Hong Kong's forex reserves have climbed to US$88.1 billion. However, the CBC official said that Hong Kong's official forex reserves figure at the end of September was about US$66 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES COUNTRYMEN TO RECREATE `TAIWAN EXPERIENCE'

TEXT.P: On the eve of the 52nd anniversary of Taiwan's retrocession, President Lee Teng-hui on Friday urged his countrymen to recreate the successful past experience of Taiwan by embarking on a course of spiritual reform.

In a nationally televised message, Lee said that any kind of reform has its origin in the spirit and called on the people of Taiwan to base their relationships on kindness and affection, respect and caring, to abide by the law, to enrich the meaning of their lives through industriousness, to improve their potential through improved efficiency and to enhance the social harmony through dialogue and cooperation.
"In order to create a brighter prospect for the nation, to develop a more beautiful homeland for our future generations," Lee said, "we should work together to pursue our goals."

The president pointed out that the Taiwan experience was molded out of the "Taiwan spirit" -- made up of the people's undauntedness, their refusal to concede defeat, their honesty, hard work and thriftiness -- and the "Taiwan vision," -- a peace-loving and tolerant attitude. It is the Taiwan spirit and Taiwan vision that developed into what he called "gemeinschaft", or "everybody in the same boat, pulling together," which has helped the country overcome numerous hardship and challenges over the last 52 years.
He encouraged his countrymen to help pave the way for the country's long-lasting peace and prosperity via reforms of the Constitution, administration, judiciary and education system.
Taiwan's Retrocession Day, which falls on Oct. 25, marks the restoration of Taiwan to the Republic of China's rule in 1945 after a half-century of Japanese occupation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SINGAPORE TO HOLD 2ND ROUND OF TALKS ON WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will hold its second round of bilateral talks with Singapore on its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Oct. 27, in a bid to become a member of the world trade regulatory body as soon as possible.

Both countries will discuss matters such as tariff rate reductions on some 40 petrochemical, electronics and electrical products, as well as the opening up of the shipping service industry market, a subject of particular concern to Singapore.
The talks were originally scheduled for the end of August but were postponed until Oct. 27 for various reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA MAIN OBSTACLE HINDERING ROC'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Mainland China's opposition is the main obstacle hindering the Republic of China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Legislative Yuan Vice President Wang Jin-pyng said on Friday.
Wang made the remark at a seminar on Taiwan's WTO entry organized by the legislature's financial sub-group, a group formed by Premier Vincent Siew when he was a legislator.

A WTO official in charge of admission affairs who also attended the seminar praised the sub-group for its efforts to push for Taiwan's WTO entry and said that the world trade regulatory body's secretariat will continue to assist Taiwan in its efforts to join.
Addressing the seminar, Wang indicated that the ROC has in recent years made great strides in its preparations for WTO entry, including the opening of its markets and the lowering of trade barriers.

He pointed out that although most of the bilateral talks between the ROC and its trade partners on WTO entry have been completed, seven years after its application for membership of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the WTO's predecessor, the ROC still cannot be accepted as a WTO member, with the main reason being opposition from mainland China.

The Legislative Yuan heavyweight emphasized that the ROC is the world's 14th-largest trading nation with the third-largest foreign exchange reserves and is the world's seventh-largest foreign investment nation, adding that as such an important trading nation, it is unfair not to allow ROC entry to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TOURIST GROUPS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that the government is to study the feasibility of allowing tourist groups from mainland China to visit Taiwan.

Siew said that visits by mainland Chinese tourist groups will be sure to help promote understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, thus helping to create a more peaceful cross-strait atmosphere.

Responding to questions from legislator Ting Shou-chung of the ruling Kuomintang, Siew said however that problems might arise if groups of mainland Chinese are allowed to enter Taiwan, including their safety and the possibility of their running away, adding that the government will have to consider these questions very carefully first.

Currently, most people from the mainland can only apply for permission to enter Taiwan to visit close relatives or attend funerals, although the government allows 13 categories of professionals to visit Taiwan for the promotion of academic or cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AN IMPORTANT MARKET FOR US

TEXT.P: In face of mainland China's emergence as a major market for the US, officials from the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday said the government should make it clear to the US that Taiwan is also an important market for America.

Although mainland China is emerging as a potential market for the United States, the officials said the economic potential of Taiwan as a major market for US products and its plan to become an operations hub in the Asia-Pacific region are also great.

Statistics show that Taiwan-based carriers have purchased 39 Boeing airplanes worth US$3.2 billion in recent years and that Taiwan is the fifth-largest market for US agricultural products. Over the past seven years, Taiwan has imported a total of US$19.6 billion-worth of farm products from the US, an average of US$2.8 billion per year, in comparison to mainland China's US$530 million.

Although mainland China is much bigger than Taiwan in terms of the size of its population and territory, the officials pointed out that Taiwan's imports of US goods have far exceeded those by the mainland over the past 10 years.

As to the possible effects on Taiwan of the upcoming US visit by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, the officials predicted that Jiang's meeting with US President Bill Clinton will have only a limited impact on Taiwan, as the two sides remain in dispute on a number of major issues.

The officials stressed that the Republic of China government has no intention of meddling in the US' dealings with other countries and that it will be delighted to see the Clinton-Jiang meeting help the mainland open up and produce positive results to help stabilize the situation across the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region.

As the ROC government has repeatedly made it clear to Washington that US engagement with mainland China should not hurt Taiwan's interests and as Washington has repeatedly assured Taiwan that no such thing will happen, the MOFA officials said they believe that the Clinton-Jiang meeting will not damage Taiwan's interests or the island's relations with the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOL PLAYS ROLE IN SOUTH AFRICAN ROAD ACCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Police statistics have revealed that alcohol played a role in between 4.8 percent and 16 percent of fatal accidents across the country, the Ministry of Transport said Thursday.
A spokesman for the ministry's "Arrive Alive" campaign warned motorists they would be harshly dealt with if caught driving while their alcohol level was above the legal limit.
The Ministry of Transport once again urged the public to drive with care and consideration. "Above all, don't drink and drive," the spokesman said.
Motorists found guilty of drunken driving face fines of up to 120,000 rand (about US$25,500) and/or six years' imprisonment.
For the first time offense, the driver's license can be suspended for a minimum of three months. For a second offense it can be suspended for one year, and for five years on a third offense.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIOACTIVE SCRAP METAL TO RETURN TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A batch of scrap iron and steel from Australia which was found to be contaminated by radiation will soon be shipped back to its Australian exporter, sources from the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Friday.

In a routine check in May for radioactivity, the Fengyuan-based Feng Hsin Iron & Steel Corp. found that within the batch of Australian scrap iron and steel there was an abnormally radioactive item weighing about 24 kilograms.

The honeycomb-shaped unknown article was later found to be emitting radioactivity at the rate of 1.5-1.8 micro Sievert (uSv) per hour, which is about 15 times higher than the allowable background level of 0.1--0.2 uSv per hour, according to AEC officials.
The contaminated article was found to contain radium 226, a natural radioactive nuclide, the officials noted.
Since the discovery, the AEC and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have worked together to contact the Sydney-based exporter and gain an early return of the toxic shipment.
The Australian company has recently agreed to recall the contaminated scrap and said it will be responsible for related costs.
Taiwan's steel processing industry uses scrap iron and steel from overseas as one of its main raw materials.
In addition to establishing radiation checkpoints at seaports and on freeways, the AEC has also asked iron and steel works to equip themselves with similar checking facilities, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH OPTIMISTIC REGION WILL RECOVER IN A FEW MONTHS

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in London on Wednesday that he is optimistic that the economies of Southeast Asia will recover in the next few months, The Straits Times reported Friday in a dispatch from London.
"Confidence will bounce back within a few months; we should be back on the road to recovery," he was quoted as telling a gathering of Singaporean university students in Britain.
"Regional currencies have been undervalued. There has been an over-correction. Their values will begin to go up," he said, giving his view of the recent currency turmoil in the region.
He asserted that Indonesia's efforts to restore confidence in its economy will have a positive ripple effect on Southeast Asia, putting the region back on track in the next few months.

Indonesia, he said, is negotiating with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and will put together and implement a package of measures that will exercise a positive influence on the Malaysian and Thai economies as well.
Singapore offered Indonesia aid to strengthen its foreign reserves and the rupiah after Prime Minister Goh's meeting with Indonesian President Suharto on Tuesday.
Singaporean and Indonesian ministers have been directed to work out ways to implement the agreement, understood to include financial help.

Speaking to Singaporean students in London on Wednesday, Goh noted that the last few months had been bad for the region, with economic troubles compounded by the haze and accidents such as last week's oil spill off Singapore's south coast.
The region's leaders would have to concentrate on changing the present negative sentiment, he said.
"It's a question of sentiment, saying the right things and doing the right things," he was quoted as saying.
The Singapore Trade and Industry Ministry had confirmed that Singapore was on target to reach about 7 percent growth for the year, he noted.
What is uncertain is the outlook for next year, with regional tourism slowing and Singapore earning less from investments in those countries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLDWIDE TELEVISION SUMMIT TO BE HELD IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: The Third Worldwide Television Industry Summit Conference will be held Nov. 24 in New York with the participation of senior broadcasting and telemedia executives from around the world.

The conference, which is produced by the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences (NATAS) of the United States in association with trade publication Variety, will focus on key topics of finance, emergent technologies and corporate convergence.
Emilio Azcarraga Jean, chief executive officer of the Group Televisa, the largest media company in Mexico, will open the one-day conference.

Panelists of the conference will include Cheng Su-ming, board chairman of the ROC's China Television, George Vradenberg of America Online, Kay Koplovitz of USA Networks, and other prominent speakers from the US, Germany, France and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON OUTLINES JIANG SUMMIT AGENDA

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said in a major speech on Friday that at the summit with his communist Chinese counterpart next week, he will reiterate US support for the "one China policy" and the position that the future of Taiwan can only be settled peacefully by Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He noted that the one-China policy, followed by the United States since 1979, "has allowed democracy to flourish in Taiwan and Taiwan's relationship with the PRC to grow more stable and prosperous."

Clinton gave his speech in the auditorium of Voice of America's head office in Washington. The speech was beamed live through VOC's broadcasting systems to an estimated 100 million listeners around the world in seven languages.

In the speech, designed to set the tone for Clinton's summit with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin in the White House on Oct. 29, Clinton stressed that the US does not seek to isolate mainland China, because such a policy is "unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous."

He pointed out that mainland China now stands at a crossroads. Whether it will emerge as a stable, open, non-aggressive power that embraces free markets, political pluralism and the rule of law, will affect the whole world for decades.

Clinton said his administration intends to work with Beijing to expand areas of cooperation, while dealing in a forthright manner with their differences. "Next week, President Jiang and I will discuss our visions of the future and the kind of strategic relationship we must have to promote cooperation, not conflict."

On the subjects on the summit agenda, Clinton said he and Jiang will discuss the steps they can take together to advance the peace process on the Korean peninsula. They will also look at ways to strengthen military-to-military contacts, decreasing the chances of miscalculation.

Another important issue to be discussed is how to keep weapons of mass destruction out of unstable regions and away from rogue states and terrorists. While acknowledging that mainland China has already joined a number of international arms control regimes, Clinton pointed out that Beijing "still maintains some troubling weapon supply relationships."

"At the summit, I will discuss with President Jiang further steps we hope China will take to end or limit some of these supply relationships and to strengthen and broaden its export control system," he said.

Clinton did not name the countries to which mainland China has supplied dangerous weapons or technology, but it is known that officials from his administration have been trying hard to persuade Beijing to stop transferring nuclear technology to Iran and Pakistan.

Other issues on the agenda include joint efforts to fight drug trafficking and international organized crime, ways to narrow the trade imbalance and bring mainland China into the World Trade Organization, and steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat global climate change.

In an apparent effort to silence critics of his soft approach toward Beijing's human rights abuses, Clinton devoted a major portion of his speech to the need for political reform to go hand-in-hand with the economic development in mainland China. He said Beijing has stifled political dissent in ways which are "fundamentally wrong." This has caused problems in its relationship with the United States.
In Clinton's view, greater openness will speed mainland China's economic growth, enhance its world influence and stabilize its society.

"Without the full freedom to think, to question, to create, China will be at a distinct disadvantage competing with fully open societies in the Information Age, where the greatest source of national wealth is what resides in the human mind," he said.

"China's creative potential is truly staggering. The largest population in the world is not yet among its top 15 patent powers. In an era where these human resources are what really matters, a country that holds its people back cannot achieve its full potential," Clinton said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng on Saturday called once again for the resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue to pave the way for peaceful reunification of China.

In response to US President Bill Clinton's speech on Friday ahead of the visit to Washington next week by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, in which he mentioned that the "Taiwan issue" should be solved peacefully by the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Sheu reiterated Taipei's desire to see better relations between Washington and Beijing.

Taipei is pleased to see the US and mainland China engaging in closer exchanges, showcased by Jiang's Oct. 29 visit to the US, Sheu noted, stressing that friendly Washington-Beijing interactions are beneficial to the stability and prosperity of the Asia-Pacific region and the Taiwan Strait.
Sheu pointed out that relations among Taiwan, mainland China and the United States at present run parallel to one another, rather than forming a single triangle.
He also urged the US to improve its relations with Taiwan and not to harm the island's interests while mending fences with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES HOLDING UP TALKS ON LINKS WITH BEIJING OVER POLITICS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew denied on Friday that the government is holding up talks on direct links with mainland China as political leverage on Beijing, saying that the time is not yet ripe for such links.

Given Beijing's repeated attempts to disrupt the peace across the Taiwan Strait over the past year, Taipei-Beijing ties are nowhere near normal and do not warrant direct shipping, communication and trade links, said Siew at the Legislative Yuan.

In defense of the government's "be patient, no haste" policy to curb the island's investment in mainland China, Siew said that as a government with an overall policy of "laissez faire," it should not and does not prohibit businessmen from venturing into the mainland China market, but rather relies on moral persuasion on the one hand to check "unreasonable" local desire for investment in mainland China, while on the other hand making some industries and areas off-limits to would-be investors.
This approach, which he said is also employed by the United States, doesn't conflict with the administration's stated free trade policy, according to Siew.

The premier, who once served as Taiwan's chief official for mainland affairs, disputed an opposition legislator's criticism that his administration has failed to come up with a policy for dealing with Beijing.

"Responding to Beijing's provocations cautiously to avoid the further deterioration of the cross-strait situation is in itself a policy to counter mainland China's strategy," said Siew, adding that the worldwide call for Beijing to resume friendly dialogue with Taipei vindicates Taiwan's long-standing policy of engaging mainland China in peaceful talks.

He dismissed as a "half-empty, half-full" case the question of which side -- Taipei or Beijing -- calls the shots in the development of cross-strait ties, emphasizing that the Beijing regime has come a long way in relaxing its dictatorship since embarking on the path of a free market economy 20 years ago. The premier expressed optimism that the ideals of democracy, freedom and equal distribution of wealth will eventually take root in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGED TO REVIEW CURRENT MAINLAND CHINA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Tien Chang-lin, former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, on Friday urged Taiwan to review its mainland China and foreign policy on the eve of mainland China's President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States.

Tien said that the Taiwan issue is only a part of the framework of the strategic partnership between the United States and mainland China and that the Korean peninsula, the Middle East, nuclear nonproliferation and trade issues all highlight the importance of that partnership.

Referring to the mainland, Tien said that it is undergoing a series of changes, beginning with the reversion of Hong Kong to mainland rule in July, followed by the 15th Communist Party congress in September, Jiang's trip to the US in late October and the choosing of a candidate for the premiership early next year.

In view of this, Tien said Taiwan has to take into consideration the changing world situation and conduct an overall evaluation of current policy, from the point of view of protecting the interests of the people of Taiwan.

On US-mainland China relations, Tien said that despite differences between the two sides, Jiang's visit to the US and US President Bill Clinton's scheduled reciprocal visit to the mainland early next year points to the development of closer relations.

The US even believes that maintaining good relations with mainland China is helpful to stability in the Taiwan Strait, Korean Peninsula and Middle East, Tien said. In this way, Taiwan has to take into account the three-way interaction among Taipei, Beijing and Washington.

Tien, who is a frequent visitor to both Taiwan and mainland China, said that he mentioned to the ROC government a year ago that Taiwan has not faced facts in forging some of its policies and that there should be more than one approach when dealing with cross-strait relations.

The former chancellor noted that Taiwan business tycoons such as Wang Yung-ching of Formosa Plastics Group, Chang Yung-fa of the Evergreen group and Kao Chin-yen of the President Group, have all criticized ROC government policy on the ban on "three direct links" -- trade, postal and transportation -- with the mainland, as well as its "no haste, be patient" policy toward investing in the mainland.
Under these circumstances, Tien said, the ROC government should develop an overall plan regarding trade and investing in the mainland while stepping up communications with local business leaders.

Tien said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should also engage in political negotiations to terminate the current state of cross-strait hostility, under the "one China" principle championed by Beijing.

He said that as a Chinese-American, he is willing to work toward promoting cross-strait understanding. He is scheduled to leave the US this weekend to visit Thailand, Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET, BANKS TO START FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan announced on Saturday that it will implement a five-day workweek every other week for civil servants, starting next year.
The Executive Yuan said that the stock market and banks will also fall in line with the plan, while schools will implement the plan from the start of the new semester which begins in February.

In order to compensate for the additional time off work to which members of the workforce covered by the regulations will be entitled, about half of the current national holidays will be incorporated into the two extra Saturday morning holidays each month, the Executive Yuan said.

Some national holidays will remain, including the founding day of the Republic of China (Jan. 1), the Chinese New Year, Tomb-Sweeping Day, Dragon Boat Festival, Moon Festival, ROC National Day (Double Ten Day) and Sun Yat-Sen's Birthday (Nov. 12).
The Executive Yuan also announced that all teaching hospitals under the Ministry of Education will retain their current five-and-a-half-day out-patient service.

Certain professions, such as hospital medical staff, police, firefighters, penitentiary and probation officers, air controllers, transportation, meteorological and customs officers, will also be unaffected by the new regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD PRESIDENT TO ARRIVE FOR FIVE-DAY STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: President Idriss Deby of the Republic of Chad will arrive in Taipei on Sunday for a five-day state visit at the invitation of ROC President Lee Teng-hui, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Saturday.
This will be Deby's first trip to the Republic of China, the ministry said in a press release.
President Lee will preside over a welcoming ceremony with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute, for the Chad head of state at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.

While here, Deby will meet with Lee to exchange views on the international situation and matters of mutual concern. He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments and meet with local government officials and business leaders to gain a better understanding of the ROC's economic and cultural development.

Deby will be accompanied by a 16-member entourage whose members will include Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Mahamat Saleh Annadif and Minister of Finance, Economy, Planning and Territory Development Biehara Cherif Daoussa.

Deby won Chad's first post-independence presidential election in July 1996 and formed a government in May 1997. Under his leadership, the central African country resumed full-fledged diplomatic relations with the ROC on Aug. 12, after a 25-year hiatus.

Chad has a population of about seven million on a land area of 1.28 million square kilometers. Taiwan was Chad's fifth-largest export market in 1996, purchasing US$4 million-worth of goods, mostly cotton, which is Chad's principal export item.

The ROC first established diplomatic ties with Chad in January 1962, but severed those links on Dec. 27, 1972, one month after Chad signed a communique recognizing the government in Beijing. The two countries restored diplomatic relations in August this year when Chad Foreign Minister Mahamat Saleh Annadif visited Taipei and signed a communique of mutual recognition with then-ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs John Chang, who is now vice premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OF JUSTICE REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO CRACK DOWN ON

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao on Saturday reaffirmed his determination to crack down on bribery in the local election in late November.
Liao said that his ministry will insist on a clean election and vows to do its best to drive money and violence out of the mayoral and county magistrate election on Nov. 29.
Between 1991 and 1997, over 6,000 election bribery cases have been brought to court and over 2,600 people have been convicted, according to statistics released by the ministry.
Liao said that prosecutors will relentlessly pursue any irregularities in the upcoming election and that his ministry's determination will not succumb to any outside influences.
He also appealed to the island's voters to report any irregularities they discover in the election campaign, saying that the identities of the informers will be protected.
If those accused of bribery are convicted, the informers will receive cash rewards -- as much as NT$5 million (US$163,934) if those convicted are election candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAIRMAN OF HOOVER INSTITUTE TO VISIT TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: Herbert Hoover III, chairman of the prestigious Hoover Institute of Stanford University, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit.
Hoover will be accompanied by the institute's President John Raisian, Vice President Thomas Henriksen, and senior fellows Raymond Myers and Larry Diamond.
The Hoover Institute is one of the most important think tanks on the West Coast of the United States and is famous for its influence in politics and international relations.

During their stay in Taiwan, Hoover and his group will meet with ranking ROC government officials, take part in a seminar on the outlook of US foreign policy at National Taiwan University and visit the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University.

Lo Jyh-yuan, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, hosted a farewell party in honor of Hoover and other specialists Friday evening and briefed them on the latest political and social developments in Taiwan.
During the party, Hoover showed keen interest in the ROC's current diplomatic policies and asked many questions about Taipei's efforts to rejoin the United Nations.
The Hoover Institute has maintained close academic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIPEI PROSTITUTES TO TAKE PART IN AIDS CONFERENCE IN MANILA

TEXT.P: Two of Taipei's formerly licensed prostitutes left for Manila on Saturday afternoon to take part in a conference on AIDS.

The two delegates, who were wearing sunglasses and identified only as Miss Kuan and Li-chun, will attend the Fourth Asia-Pacific AIDS Conference in Manila from Oct. 25-29. They are being accompanied on their trip by a Miss Wang, who described herself as a representative of a local women's group and an interpreter.
They were seen off at the airport by some 20 former colleagues who held posters and banners protesting the Taipei city government's decision last month to abolish the city's legalized prostitution.

Before boarding the airplane, the women called on the city government to reverse its decision, saying the ban will cause more social problems than it will resolve. They said the hardship the ban is forcing on their families is only the tip of the iceberg of the problems that will develop.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY GIVE `CONSOLATION MONEY' TO MAINLAND FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan does not rule out the possibility of giving "consolation money" to mainland Chinese fishermen allegedly injured by Taiwan marine police in a recent clash in waters off the island of Matsu, which is controlled by Taiwan but located close to mainland China, a senior ROC official said on Saturday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was commenting on a demand by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) that Taiwan compensate the injured mainland fishermen.

The ARATS on Friday sent a note to its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), accusing Taiwan marine police of "unjustifiably seizing and firing on mainland fishermen, who were in turn forced to defend themselves" and demanding Taiwan pay reasonable compensation to the injured fishermen.

In response, Sheu categorically rejected the mainland demand for compensation because, he said, the Taiwan marine police were performing their public duty when they intercepted the mainland vessel fishing illegally in Taiwan's territorial waters on Oct. 12.

Sheu further said that Chuang Chen-yao, a marine police officer who was abducted to the mainland during the incident, was defending his own physical safety when he opened fire at the armed mainland fishermen. "Against this background, how can we compensate the mainland fishermen?" Sheu asked.

Nevertheless, Sheu said, Taiwan would be willing to study the feasibility of offering some "consolation money" to the mainland fishermen who were allegedly injured in the incident, with a view to maintaining harmonious relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Sheu also urged mainland authorities to send Chuang back to Taiwan as soon as possible to avoid complicating the incident.
He said the MAC has authorized the SEF to discuss the issue with ARATS. "We hope a satisfactory solution will be worked out in the near future," he added.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
The ARATS said in its latest note to the SEF that Chuang has basically recovered following medical care in Fujian province in southeastern China.
The ARATS hinted that mainland authorities would allow Chuang to return to Taiwan if Chuang "compensates for the Fujian fishermen's medical expenses and economic losses."

It further said details related to compensation will be finalized by personnel from the Fujian and Taiwan Red Cross organizations or other non-governmental bodies, adding the Fujian Red Cross Society will arrange for Chuang's return to Taiwan at the earliest possible date.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REPRESENTATIVE MEETS WITH US CONGRESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new representative to the United States, Stephen Chen, paid calls on several US congressional leaders Friday to get acquainted and seek support for Taiwan's cause.

Chen, who succeeded Jason Hu as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the United States on Oct. 17, met with a number of House and Senate leaders Friday to convey President Lee Teng-hui and Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu's goodwill and express Taiwan's appreciation for the lawmakers' support for the island.
Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.) told Chen during a 30-minute meeting he is a staunch supporter of the ROC.

On the imminent Clinton-Jiang summit in Washington on Oct. 29, which will be Chen's first serious test in his new post, Chen reminded Lott that relations among Taiwan, mainland China and the United States at present run parallel to one another, rather than forming a triangle.
Chen stressed his hope that the results of the summit will not endanger the ROC's interests or the cooperative ties between Taiwan and the United States.
Lott echoed Chen's view, adding that Beijing should no longer try to block Taipei's efforts in the international arena but instead accept the fact that the ROC is a sovereign political entity.
He urged mainland China to refrain from resorting to intimidating moves against Taiwan.
Lott, an admirer of the ROC's democratization, accepted Chen's invitation to pay a visit to Taiwan sometimes in the future.

On Friday, Chen also met with Rep. Dan Burton, chairman of the House Government Reform & Oversight Committee, and Rep. Christopher Cox, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee, to exchange views on a wide range of topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG'S VISIT TO US `SYMBOL OVER SUBSTANCE'

TEXT.P: Mainland China's President Jiang Zemin begins his "most important foreign venture" on Sunday, eager to please and desperate to be liked in the United States, a major Canadian newspaper reported on Friday.
The Globe and Mail said the paunchy leader has been boning up on his stilted English, asking aides to prepare a few good jokes and telling US reporters what an ordinary guy he is.

The 71-year-old Jiang has agreed to an itinerary that goes to the symbolic heartland of the US, including the sunken battleship Arizona in Pearl Harbor, colonial Williamsburg, Independence Hall in Philadelphia and the New York Stock Exchange. He will even deliver a speech to students at Harvard University, complete with questions from the floor, the daily said in a dispatch from Beijing.

"This is all about image-building," the daily quoted a Western diplomat in Beijing as saying. "He wants to try to change American perceptions of China, to demystify himself and his country a little bit," the diplomat was quoted as adding.
"It's symbol over substance, but that doesn't mean it's unimportant," the report quoted another observer as saying.

It pointed out that 25 years after Richard Nixon's historic visit to mainland China, the two countries are still struggling to understand each other. As recently as 18 months ago, their relations were at an all-time low after a bitter wrangle over the granting of a US visa to Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui and the dispatching of two US aircraft carriers near Taiwan during a series of Chinese missile tests near the island, it noted.

Since then, both have worked hard to heal the wounds. The daily quoted Dave Lambton of the National Committee on US-China Relations as saying: "I think both sides were extremely alarmed at how the whole Taiwan situation could run out of control.

"Particularly in Washington and among many in Congress, they came to the conclusion that US-China relations are not just about trade, and not just about human rights. They're about war and peace. If there is no common understanding about our objectives in the world, we could end up in a military conflict."

More important than setting up a hotline between Jiang and Clinton is "communicating in some way with the broader public... to change America's mind about what is this place, China," Lambton was quoted as saying.

This may be difficult, despite Jiang's desire to do so, said the Mail's Beijing correspondent, Rod Mickleburgh.
