The goodwill and curiosity from Deng Xiaoping's 1979 visit are long gone and Jiang is likely to meet with frequent public protests and an official reserve befitting the politics of welcoming someone who presides over a country that continues to jail its dissidents and justify the massacre of hundreds of unarmed civilians in 1989, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DENOUNCED FOR ATTEMPTING TO LURE AWAY ROC ALLY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Saturday denounced mainland China for attempting to use its leverage in the United Nations to lure away one of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies, the Central African Republic.

The ministry said in news release that Qin Huasun, mainland China's permanent representative to the United Nations, had intended to drive a wedge between the ROC and the Central African Republic when he visited the latter earlier this week to inspect the operations of UN peacekeeping forces there.

Qin visited the Central African Republic Oct. 21-23 in his capacity as reigning chairman of the UN Security Council for November. The visit was mainly aimed at reviewing current UN peacekeeping force operations as a reference for deciding whether the mission will be continued after its three-month term expires at the end of this month.

However, the ministry said, Qin deliberately included in his five-member delegation officials from mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, such as the deputy director of the ministry's African Affairs Department and the translation division chief.

"The move has not only confused the government of the Central African Republic but also 'spotlighted' Qin's attempt to take advantage of his UN position to sabotage our relationship with Bangui," the press statement said.

It further said the ministry has ordered the ROC Embassy in the Central African Republic to closely monitor developments in that country and remind its government that its contact with mainland China should not undermine its relations with the ROC.

The ministry said the ROC Embassy had expressed its grave concern over Qin's activities in the Central African Republic. In addition to urging that country to take note of mainland China's plot to sabotage its ties with the ROC, the embassy also reaffirmed the ROC's firm commitment to continuing various bilateral cooperative projects and assisting Bangui in rebuilding its battered economy following three mutinies last year.

During his visit, Qin had met with the Central African Republic's senior leaders, including its president, prime minister, minister of foreign affairs and the speaker of its parliament, in addition to inspecting several UN peacekeeping force bases. Qin also managed to deliver a speech to that country's parliament, soliciting parliamentary support for resumption of diplomatic ties between Beijing and Bangui.

The Central African Republic first established diplomatic relations with the ROC in 1962, but switched its diplomatic recognition to mainland China in 1964. It cut links with mainland China in 1966, and resumed official ties with the ROC in 1968. In 1976, it again switched its diplomatic allegiance to Beijing. The country resumed full-fledged diplomatic ties with the ROC on July 8, 1991 and on the same day, Beijing cut off its links with Bangui.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE DEPOSITS IN TAIWAN BANKS SOAR TO NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Foreign exchange deposits in Taiwan banks totaled NT$424.6 billion (US$14.88 billion) at the end of September, which is a record high, according to statistics compiled by the Central Bank of China.
The total of deposits is NT$25,400 million (US$890 million), or 6.4 percent, more than a month earlier.

The Economic Research Department of the central bank attributed the recent increase in foreign exchange deposits to Taiwan's trade surplus and the increase of new deposits by importers, who had bought extra amounts of foreign currencies to avoid anticipated risks in the foreign exchange market. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRIME SYNDICATES SAID SMUGGLING IMMIGRANTS INTO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Asian crime syndicates are bringing a flood of illegal immigrants from mainland China and other places in Asia into Australia, experts said at a recent meeting in Sydney.

Police officials said at the meeting of the Australian Academy of Forensic Sciences that Asian crime syndicates are bringing "ready reserves of criminal labor" into Australia to conduct extortion, prostitution and drug smuggling.

Dr. Richard Basham, a renowned expert on Asian crime, told the gathering of senior police and forensic experts that immigrants, particularly from mainland China, were being forced into crime in "near slavery" conditions to repay debts to criminal groups for entering Australia.
Basham said the illegal immigrants were forced to repay more than A$15,000 (US$10,500) to those who brought them to Australia.
"Failure to repay such debts will invoke serious sanctions, including murder," he said.

He told the meeting that police should regard official documents from Asian countries with suspicion, warning of corrupt consulate officials who provide phony documents for illegal entry into Australia or legitimate documents to undesirable immigrants.

Basham said sophisticated schemes involved mainland Chinese government enterprises bringing fake or real employees on temporary visas into Australia, with these people then sometimes being forced to pose as employees in legitimate businesses and to siphon money into criminal accounts.

Calling human smuggling a "serious threat" to Australia, he warned that criminal syndicates could smuggle increasing numbers of immigrants into the country unless immigration laws are substantially tightened.
Australia is seen as a "soft target" for illegal immigrants because the success of English-language programs has allowed them to pose as students, Basham said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN EXPERT SAYS KIDS NEED FATTY FOODS

TEXT.P: Restricting the fat intake of children could mean a loss of energy and nutrients, a leading Canadian expert said.
Speaking at a scientific conference in Perth Friday, Professor Stan Zlotkin, a Canadian expert in pediatrics, said the key to health is a moderated amount of all food groups.

"There are a number of case reports where individuals have said to themselves, especially parents, that if a little bit of fat restriction was good, then a lot of fat restriction must be even better."
He said low-fat diets for children could mean a loss in energy and nutrients that other foods can't easily compensate for.
"I would like to suggest we should offer children a variety of tasty, age-appropriate foods in moderation and that whenever possible that appetites dictate quantity of intakes," he said.
"Any message of fat restriction may give the wrong message to certain people," he cautioned.
He said concerns had been expressed about the misapplication of the dietary message of cutting fat and that it could make things worse for some adolescent girls already preoccupied with thinness.
"I would also like to suggest that we not specifically restrict any food or food group because it is a 'bad food' -- because there really is no such thing," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW EXPECTS REGION'S RECOVERY IN TWO TO THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew predicts that Southeast Asia's economies will take two to three years to recover from the current financial turmoil.

But how fast they get back on track depends on whether governments have the political will to "do the unpleasant quickly and thoroughly," as the root causes of the crisis are political factors, he pointed out in a keynote address to top businessmen at a Fortune 500 Forum in the US city of Boston on Thursday.
Lee said that Southeast Asia's economies are now closely integrated into the world's financial markets and subject to their harsh discipline.
Governments will have to reform their financial institutions, enforce rigorous supervision of their banks and be disciplined in their macro-economic policies.
"Those governments that have the political strength to do the unpleasant quickly and thoroughly will reap the best rewards," he said.
He pointed out that in nearly every economic crisis, "the root cause is political, not economic."
For example, Thailand's problems from its burgeoning current account deficits, inflexible exchange rate regime and over-investment in property, had long lain dormant and ignored.

They were not dealt with because Thailand has had a rapid turnover of prime ministers and cabinets in the last five years, with none staying in office long enough to tackle the problems. In addition, many Thai leaders in government and opposition have personal interests in the fates of finance companies and banks and there is "a natural reluctance to discipline them."

"So warning signs were ignored and remedies postponed. When the attack on the Thai baht came, billions of dollars were spent in defending the baht, all to no avail. This increased the eventual costs."
The baht crisis spread to the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia. Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore were also not spared.

But Singapore's currency was not attacked as badly, he noted, because fund managers knew it had annual budget and current account surpluses, zero foreign debt, strong reserves of over US$80 billion (S$127 billion) and banks with the highest credit rating in Asia.
The countries that have been hit could overcome their setbacks "within two to three years" if their governments tackle the basic weaknesses, he said.
Basic conditions for rapid growth remain, such as high savings, pro-growth and pro-business governments and hardworking people. Also, weaker currencies will boost exports.
"The lesson they have learned and cannot afford to forget is that savings and borrowings must be channeled into productive investments," Lee said.

The currency crisis will also force most, if not all the countries in the region to liberalize and become more market-oriented, he predicted, citing Indonesia's deregulation and Thailand's impending financial reforms worked out with the International Monetary Fund as examples.

In his 30-minute speech and in the 10-minute dialogue that followed, Lee also made a strong pitch for the United States to strengthen its economic links with ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) and gave his reading of the situation in mainland China, Japan and North Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW CALLS FOR ASEAN-US FREE-TRADE PACTS

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew has called on the United States to consider forging free-trade agreements (FTAs) with Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries, saying they would benefit both sides economically and ensure continued US engagement in the region.

"FTAs will provide a framework that can ensure that economic links between the US and Southeast Asia remain deep and broad and so make it worthwhile for the US to stay engaged in the region," he said.
Lee made the call in a speech to 150 top business leaders at a Fortune 500 Forum in Boston.
Highlighting the advantages of such FTAs, he said they could help the US maintain its predominant economic and technological position in the world, especially vis-a-vis mainland China.
It will help US firms tap into the important ASEAN market, and the market will be able to absorb the higher-technology goods from the US as it develops further, he said.
ASEAN countries face stiff competition from mainland China, because it has lower labor costs, he said.
FTAs would reduce the comparative advantage which mainland China enjoys from lower costs.
"A stronger US-ASEAN linkage will bring economic benefits to both sides and also ensure that there will be no major East-West divide down the Pacific Ocean," he added.

Although he noted that FTAs are not popular with American unions or politicians, he said: "As captains of industry, I hope you will persuade your Congressmen that this goal of extending your influence into the future through FTAs is one worth achieving."

DOC.HEADLINE: HAZE IN PARTS OF INDONESIA WELL ABOVE DANGEROUS LEVEL

TEXT.P: The haze covering most of Central Kalimantan, Indonesia has reached a dangerous level, the Antara news agency reported from Palangka Raya.

Antara quoted Tukik B. Toemon, chief of the Central Kalimantan health service, as saying Friday that the content of dust particles in Central Kalimantan has reached 2,910 micrograms per cubic meter, or 11 times the "tolerable" limit of 260 mg/m3.
The amount of pollution is also far above the "dangerous" level of 1,041 mg/m3, he noted.
He said people had been told to minimize their outdoor activities and close the doors and windows in their homes to prevent the dust from coming in.
According to a local official, 11 people died from July to September because of the haze, while 23,303 others suffered pulmonary problems.
Meanwhile, in Banjarmasin, South Kalimantan, the Syamsuddin Noor Airport was closed Friday due to the thick haze that covered the city.
The government has once again vowed to be tough on those caught setting forest fires, declaring that this time it would get "serious" by taking legal action.

Fires have destroyed at least 300,000 hectares of forest and brush this year, primarily in Sumatra and Kalimantan. The fires have also caused a severe haze that has disrupted life not only in Indonesia but also in neighboring Malaysia and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUO OFFERS TO RESIGN AFTER TRAGEDY

TEXT.P: Luo Wen-jia, head of the Taipei Municipal Information Department, announced on Saturday night that he will resign to take responsibility for a tragic incident at an activity organized by the Taipei City Government.

Luo stressed that he was willing to resign from the post in a gesture of responsibility for the tragedy at the Keelung River Park, which injured 47 people, and said the city government would immediately deliver compensation money to the victims.

Luo's statement came in the wake of the accident occurring on Saturday afternoon during a massive tug of war contest involving about 1,500 people that was organized by the municipal government to mark Taiwan's Retrocession Day.

The rope being used in the contest suddenly snapped less than one minute after the activity began, with the sudden and powerful force unleashed sending participants tumbling down to the ground, injuring a total of 47 people.
The injured, including three men who were seriously wounded, were rushed to nearby hospitals. Two of the three men had their left arms dismembered and the other one suffered internal bleeding.

All three have already undergone surgery and remain hospitalized for further treatment. The two men whose arms were completely severed had them successfully reattached, although doctors were unable to say whether they will regain complete functions.

Meanwhile, the Taipei City Government has formed a special task force to manage the aftermath of the accident, with Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian stressing that the Taipei City Government will assume full responsibility for the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN TOURISTS VISIT BALI

TEXT.P: A total of 124,582 foreign tourists arrived in Bali on direct flights from abroad in September 1997, an increase of 16.2 percent over the 107,189 persons who did so during the same month last year, Antara news agency reported from Denpasar.

The Bali tourist office in Denpasar disclosed Saturday that most of the foreign tourists were from Asian Pacific countries, which accounted for 77,241 of the arrivals in September 1997, increasing from 58,950 over September 1996..
The number of Australians, who are particularly fond of the resort island's natural beauty and of lying on the beach, increased from 24,766 in September 1996 to 33,884 in the same month this year.

The Japanese, who have a particular interest in Indonesia's cultural diversity and the beauty of its tourist spots, also increased in number from 21,899 in September 1996 to 29,162 in the same month of 1997.
In the meantime, the number of Taiwan tourists choosing to vacation in Bali increased from 8,488 in September 1996 to 8,727 in the same month this year.
On the other hand, the number of tourists from Southeast Asian countries visiting Bali declined slightly in September 1997 totaling only 9,483, compared to 9,501 in the same period of last year.
European tourists coming for a holiday to Bali in September 1997 totaled 31,100, a decline of 2.4 percent compared to the 31,870 arrivals in September last year.
The number of American vacationers in Bali declined from 5,944 in September 1996 to 5,800 in the same month in 1997.

In anticipation of the drop in the number of foreign holidaymakers from Southeast Asian countries, Europe and America, the Bali tourist office has launched a promotion in target countries such as Germany, the Netherlands and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR NATIONS TO MEET IN GENEVA

TEXT.P: Developing nations will push for wider trade concessions at next week's meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Geneva.

"We will put up a strong fight to clinch the rights of zero-tariff access to the developing markets," Bangladesh's Commerce and Industry Minister Tofael Ahmed, who will head a 48-member group from less-developed countries at the meeting, was quoted by a WTO report as saying Saturday.
The meeting, co-sponsored by UNCTAD, will deal with the impact of the 1994 Uruguay Round agreement concluded in Marrakesh on the international trade of poor countries.
"We were pledged much compensation at the Marrakesh meeting. But nothing significant was really available," Ahmed was quoted as saying.
"We have opened our market, but got virtually nothing in return. They are cashing in on our liberalization but we are gradually being marginalized," he said.
He said export growth in the less-developed countries had slumped to 14 percent since the WTO was founded in 1995 from 17 percent earlier, according to the WTO report.
Officials said the group of poor nations would also seek the removal of non-tariff barriers used by developed countries to restrict trade.
The Bangladeshi minister said zero-tariff access would help poorer economies deal with pressures of the free-trade regime, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH EXPECTS ASIAN CURRENCIES TO STABILIZE

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said he does not foresee another round of speculative attacks on Asian currencies, and that stabilization should follow after the shock on Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index last week.

Hong Kong appears to be the last post under siege by currency and share speculation in the region, he told the British Broadcasting Corporation in a television interview aired on Friday, The Straits Times reported Sunday in a dispatch from Edinburgh.

Before the crisis, he pointed out, there had been a need to adjust regional currency values, and stock markets were at an all-time high some months ago. But the sentiment now is too negative. "My sense is that it is over-corrected," he was quoted as commenting.
Noting that Taiwan's economy and the South Korean currency had also taken a beating, Goh was quoted as saying: "So after Hong Kong, where do you go? Another round?

I don't see the possibility of another round because currencies have gone down, in my view, by too much already in value. So I would expect that after Hong Kong, we should see some stabilizing factors in play."

As to when recovery could be expected, Goh said a lot will depend on the package of measures Indonesia plans to implement in negotiation with the International Monetary Fund, supplemented by help from Singapore.
This, backed by strong political will from Jakarta, should see confidence rebound and a positive ripple effect in the region, he said.
In today's world, it is not possible even for sound economies like Singapore to escape completely unscathed from such crises, he noted, simply because the global economy is now very interdependent.

On whether Singapore could withstand the pressure of the present situation, he said the country could carry on for some time, as its fundamentals are sound, there is no overseas debt and surpluses are good.
"We will just have to sit out this turmoil in the region, and hopefully play our part to restore confidence in the region," he was quoted as saying.
However, he noted that after the value of Asian currencies settles down, exports from Asia will become cheaper compared to those from the West.

"I think we're going to see, maybe after some time, a surge of exports from Asia to Europe, to America. Would the currency speculators then focus on the West and say their currencies are over-valued against the currencies in the East? I think we have to watch out for that volatile movement from East to West, West to East."

Goh said he expected currency volatility to be a topic of "robust discussion" at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Edinburgh, which went into its second day of closed-door executive discussions on Saturday.

The four-day meeting, he noted, should see consensus on key areas such as getting Commonwealth economies to open a debate on the need to keep the international trading regime open, and to consider having a new round of trade negotiations under the World Trade Organization sometime early in the next century.
The Commonwealth, he added, should also help its 54 member nations integrate themselves into the world economy and keep up with changes, especially in information technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEBY OF CHAD VISITS TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Idriss Deby of the Republic of Chad arrived here Sunday for a state visit at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui.

While here, President Deby will meet with President Lee to exchange views on the international situation and matters of mutual concern. He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments.

Other officials accompanying President Deby on the visit include Mahamat Saleh Annadif, minister of foreign affairs and cooperation, and Biehara Cherif Daoussa, minister of finance, economy, planning and territory development.
They are scheduled to depart from Taipei on Oct. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE DEPUTY PM ON VISIT TO M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tan Keng Yam and a 12-member delegation left Sunday for a weeklong visit to mainland China.
Tan, who is also defense minister, is the first full minister from the Singapore Defense Ministry to visit mainland China.
The trip, which includes stops in Beijing, Shanghai, Suzhou and Wuxi, will allow the Singapore mission to meet China's political, economic and defense leaders.

Tan made the visit at the invitation of General Chi Haotian, mainland China's defense minister and vice chairman of the Central Military Commission (CMC), mainland China's highest military body, said the Singapore Defense Ministry.
During his four-day stay in Beijing, Tan will have meetings with senior mainland Chinese political and defense leaders.
He will call on National People's Congress Chairman Qiao Shi, Vice Premier Li Lanqing and CMC Vice Chairman Zhang Wannian.
The Singapore delegation includes parliamentarians and senior officials from the Economic Development Board and ministries of defense, education and foreign affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRIME SYNDICATES BRINGING CRIMINAL LABORERS TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Asian crime syndicates are bringing a flood of illegal immigrants from mainland China and other Asian countries into Australia with the aid of corrupt officials here and sham English language courses, according to Australian police.

The police said Asian crime syndicates are bringing "ready reserves of criminal labor" into Australia to conduct extortion, prostitution and drug smuggling, a closed meeting of senior police and forensic experts said.

Dr. Richard Basham, a renowned expert on Asian crime and a member of New South Wales Police Commissioner Peter Ryan's advisory group, told a recent meeting in Sydney that immigrants, particularly from mainland China, were forced into crime, such as prostitution in "near slavery" conditions, to repay debts to criminal groups for entering Australia.
Basham said mainland Chinese immigrants were forced to repay more than A$15,000 to criminals who charged usurious interest rates.
"Failure to repay such debts will invoke serious sanctions, including murder," he said.

He told the meeting of the Australian Academy of Forensic Sciences in Sydney that police should treat all official documents from Asian countries with extreme caution when exchanging information with their Asian counterparts.
Basham warned of corrupt consulate officials in Asian countries who provide phony documents for illegal entry into Australia as well as legitimate documents to undesirable immigrants.
He said some sophisticated schemes involved mainland Chinese government enterprises bringing fake or real employees on temporary visas into Australia.
He said these employees were sometimes forced to pose as employees in legitimate businesses, siphoning money into criminal accounts.
He warned that Chinese triads and other criminal syndicates could increasingly smuggle immigrants into Australia unless immigration laws were substantially tightened.

"Human smuggling ... representing a serious threat to Australia under false names and pretenses provides a ready reservoir of criminal labor and they are unlikely ever to cooperate fully with police, taxation and other authorities," Basham said.
He said Australia was already seen as a "soft target" for illegal immigrants because of the success of English-language programs that allowed illegal immigrants to pose as students, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE PART IN INDONESIAN HANDICRAFT SHOW

TEXT.P: Indonesia will hold a special handicrafts exhibition dubbed the "First Jakarta International Handicraft Trade Fair '98, which will feature participation by 200 domestic and foreign businessmen.

All member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations as well as Taiwan, South Korea, Bangladesh, Egypt, Iran, Morocco and Tunisia are scheduled to take part in the exhibition, while buyers are expected to come from Australia, the United States and European countries.
The exhibition will be held at the Jakarta Convention Center from April 30 through May 4, 1998, Muchtar, the head of the National Export Development Body, said here Saturday.
"The exhibition is expected to be held every year," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying.
He added that the event will focus on gift and houseware products.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TYCOONS MAY BE HARDEST HIT BY STOCK SLUMP

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's spectacular stock plunge has wiped billion of dollars off the bourse with the territory's well-known tycoons seeing a massive amount of their wealth disappear in a matter of days.

The top three Hong Kong families may have lost a combined HK$52 billion in the value of their holdings in their flagship companies within the last one week, the Singapore Business Times reported on Sunday.
Well-known tycoon Li Ka-shing may well turn out to be the biggest individual loser, with the net worth of his stock-holdings at Cheung Kong Holdings now down by about HK$16 billion, the report said.
Li, known popularly as "Superman" in the territory, controls about 771 million shares at Cheung Kong, which, at the closing price of HK$76.10 on Oct. 17, were valued at HK$58.7 billion.
But the stock plunge trimmed the price to HK$55 Saturday, reducing his net worth to HK$42.4 billion.
In percentage terms, Li's losses were also the biggest among the top tycoons in Hong Kong, the report said. But Cheung Kong is just one of Li's many companies, it added.

The popular billionaire remained cautiously optimistic on Thursday, saying: "Rising interest rates will undeniably cause market turbulence in the property market. We are likely to see a small consolidation in property prices."

Walter Kwok and his family, which controls Hong Kong's biggest property group Sun Hung Kai Properties, saw their holdings in the company reduced by HK$21 billion within a week, down to HK$68 billion from HK$89 billion.
Meanwhile, Lee Shau-kee, who until last week was arguably Asia's richest man, may no longer own that distinction, the report said.
His holdings at flagship Henderson Land was down HK$14.24 billion to HK$49 billion from HK$63 billion.
It was reported that Lee's position as the ninth richest man in the world -- based on a ranking by Forbes in July -- may have slipped to 35th.
The chairman of Henderson Land saw his wealth halved in less than four months, the report said.
Macau gambling tycoon Stanley Ho lost about HK$76.6 million in Shun Tak Holdings, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL NOT LOWER BAR FOR BEIJING-WTO DEAL

TEXT.P: The United States is open to mainland China's membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO), but is unwilling to make concessions for a deal at next week's Beijing-Washington summit, according to reports from the world trade body Saturday.

"We would welcome (mainland) China's accession to WTO on normal terms," the WTO report quoted US National Security Advisor Sandy Berger as saying. "We have been very clear, ourselves, that we're not going to lower the bar for the summit."
US trade negotiators have been discussing WTO membership with Beijing over several months, however, progress has been very slow.

"In order for this to make sense to the United States, (mainland) China has to not only accept the privileges of being a member of the WTO ... but also has to accept the obligations and responsibilities," Berger was quoted as saying.

He added that Washington would like Beijing to sign an information technology agreement dealing with duties on computers and computer chips, but he added: "I don't know that they intend to do it," the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER RETURNS FROM MEXICO

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang returned on Sunday after the conclusion of the ninth ROC-Mexico Joint Economic Conference in Tijuana, Mexico.
Chang Chang-pang, chief delegate of the ROC contingent, gave a keynote speech at the one-day conference on Wednesday, which was attended by more than 100 business executives from the two countries.

Chang and his Mexican counterpart, Jaime Zabludovsky, also reached agreement on several issues of mutual concern, including the setting up of a regular channel for dialogue among ranking trade officials, the signing of accords on investment guarantees and the temporary admission of goods, to further strengthen two-way economic relations.

Zabludovsky also expressed his country's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO). The two countries are expected to sign an agreement on Taiwan's membership of the world trade regulatory body soon, as bilateral talks on the issue have now almost concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO ERADICATE ILLEGAL FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Deep-Sea Tuna Fishing Industry Association on Sunday urged relevant government authorities to crack down on illegal fishing boats in order to avoid potential international fishery disputes.
The association made the call after an international meeting on tuna fishing and related issues held here, which was attended by more than 100 representatives from Taiwan, Japan and South Korea.

As a result of an international ban on drift-net fishing and the increased enforcement of exclusive 200-nautical-mile economic zones within the international community, the association said more Taiwan operators are using illegal fishing vessels to poach in territorial waters of foreign countries. Their actions have aroused strong protests both from legal operators and from other countries.

It said that there are currently about 160 illegal fishing vessels worldwide, nearly double the figure of around 83 a decade ago, with around 10 percent of the overall number owned by operators from Taiwan, Japan and South Korea.
According to the association, the illegal fishing ships are mainly aging vessels which are either unregistered or which fly the flags of countries that do not strictly enforce pertinent regulations.

As those illegal fishing boats are poaching without restriction by either national laws or international practices, their operations have seriously depleted international fishery stocks and have lowered international market prices, the association pointed out.
It said that as a result, Japan, which is Taiwan's major export market for tuna, has strongly protested, asking authorities here to take concerted efforts to stem such illegal operations.

While urging the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the provincial-level Taiwan Fisheries Bureau to quickly respond, the association also called on the local fishing sector to exercise self-restraint so as to protect both its own interests and the image of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DEPRECIATION MIXED BLESSING FOR LOCAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: High technology and traditional industries have fared differently in the latest round of NT dollar depreciation, officials of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Monday.

The exchange rate of the NT dollar against the US dollar hovered around NT$28.5 in mid-October, but has since dropped, reaching NT$30.49 to US$1 in mid-day session on Taiwan exchange market Monday, after the Central Bank of China adopted a hands-off attitude and allowed the local currency to float on exchange markets.

The officials said that the information and semi-conductor industries have benefited from a devalued NT dollar, adding that manufacturers in those sectors have their hands full processing orders from the United States.

In contrast, more traditional industries such as textiles have suffered because the degree of the NT dollar's depreciation has been less than that of currencies in the Southeast Asian nations, making it more difficult for textile products to gain inroads into that region. In the traditional export market of the United States, exporters also face stiffer competition from Southeast Asia.

The local machinery industry has seen little progress so far this year in attempts to boost exports to Germany and Southeast Asian markets, the officials said. They added that the effect of the NT dollar's depreciation on that sector will not be known until sometime next year.

The officials said the biggest beneficiary of the recent currency depreciation will be Taiwan businessmen with investments in the electric, electronics and information industries in Southeast Asia. They had previously received orders in Taiwan, with prices quoted in terms of a stronger NT dollar, and are currently delivering goods from their plants in the Southeast Asian nations.

With global demands for personal computers expanding, Taiwan, on the strength of its technological edge over the Southeast Asian nations and the advantage of a devalued local currency, can look forward to expanding its exports to Europe and the United States, they said.

But manufacturers in the textile industry, while losing orders to Southeast Asian nations whose currencies have dropped between 30 percent and 60 percent in value over recent months, have suffered a double-edged blow as textile imports into Taiwan from Indonesia and Malaysia have also increased.
