DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD 50 NATIONS TO ATTEND TAIPEI TRAVEL FAIR

TEXT.P: A record attendance of 50 nations is expected for the Taipei International Travel Fair (ITF) early next month, officials from the Taiwan Visitor Association, sponsor of the tourism extravaganza, said Monday.

The officials said that the ITF, held every two years, has attracted between 20 and 30 participating countries in the past. But the number surged to 50 this year, with more than 500 exhibition booths.

Noting that the number of Taiwan people making overseas trips is increasing every year, with the amount predicted to top 6 million in 1997, they said that the lure of potential Taiwan tourist dollars has contributed to the increase in ITF participants this year.
Japan will sponsor 60 exhibition booths, the most among all participating countries, the officials said.

Domestic tour operators will also promote Taiwan at the fair, hoping to introduce the island's newly developed attractions to overseas operators after the local tourism industry has suffered diminishing profits in recent years.
ITF'97 will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center from Nov. 6 to Nov. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST ASIAN CORD BLOOD BANK TO BE SET UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taiwan will set up an umbilical cord blood bank early next year to benefit patients suffering from leukemia and other blood ailments, the non-profit Chinese Blood Services Foundation said on Monday.

"We have purchased all needed equipment and will start to collect cord blood late this year or early next year," said Chang Ying-erh, chief executive of the foundation. "If all goes well, the long-planned cord blood bank, the first of its kind in Asia, will become operational by the end of next January."

In the initial stage, Chang said, the foundation will cooperate with National Taiwan University Hospital and Taipei Municipal Hospital for Women and Children to solicit the consent of would-be mothers to donate their placenta.

"With their consent, we'll extract umbilical cord blood right after they give birth," Chang said, adding that the extracted cord blood will be specially treated and then stored in ultra-low temperature liquefied nitrogen. "In this way, the cord blood can remain usable for more than 10 years."

Cheng Jen-wei, a member of the foundation's research department staff, said umbilical cord blood contains rich blood-making cells, which can be transplanted to help treat many malignant diseases. Medical doctors have traditionally relied primarily on transplants of bone marrow stem cells. Such surgical procedures, however, are often hindered by difficulties in finding donors with matching bone marrow and by technical complications in obtaining donor organs.
After years of study, Cheng said, scientists have discovered that umbilical cord blood, which has traditionally been discarded, contains rich blood-making stem cells.

"The collection of umbilical cord blood is like waste recycling and will not cause any negative effects on donors' health," Cheng said, adding that the probability of rejection in cord blood transplants is even lower than that for bone marrow transplant, with a success rate exceeding 70 percent.

The world's first umbilical cord blood transplant was performed on a five-year-old "Fanconi anaemia" patient in the United States in 1988. The operation was successful. Since then at least 22 cord blood transplant medical teams have been established around the world. The United States and many European countries have set up umbilical cord blood banks.

According to domestic medical records, National Taiwan University Hospital completed the island's first umbilical cord blood transplant operation in 1995. Though the operation was successful, the young patient died 146 days after the transplant because of a relapse of leukemia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL WANG TO HEAD CENTRAL NEWS AGENCY

TEXT.P: Bill Wang, director of the Washington Bureau of the Central News Agency (CNA), was approved Monday by the CNA Board of Directors to become the new president of the news organization.
Wang will succeed Kemin Shih, who has been reassigned by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be the ROC representative in Norway.
Wang, 52, a graduate from the Department of Journalism of National Chengchi University, obtained master's degrees from both Central Michigan University and Harvard University.

An experienced journalist, Wang has been a CNA reporter in Taipei, CNA correspondent in the Middle East, director of the CNA Foreign Language Department and vice president of the agency. He has also served briefly as editor-in-chief and vice president of the China News, one of the two major English-language daily newspapers in Taiwan.
Wang is expected to assume his duties as CNA president sometime in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES FELL ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices fell on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 56.51 points to finish at the day's low of 7,662.53.
The bourse opened at 7,719.86 and experienced a high of 7,788.42.
Losers outnumbered gainers 233 to 156, with 78 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89,86 billion (US$2.95 billion).

Electrical engineering issues fell the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.0 percent, textile shares at 0.7 percent, financial stocks at 0.6 percent, cement and foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent respectively, paper and pulp and plastics and chemical issues at 0.2 percent respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SUED BY CITY COUNCILORS

TEXT.P: Taipei city councilors from the New Party on Monday filed a suit against Mayor Chen Shui-bian for allegedly endangering public safety.

New Party Councilors Fei Hung-tai, Chin Li-fang and Chiang Li-an filed civil complaints of assault and battery on behalf of the families of three men who were critically injured during a massive tug-of-war held Saturday afternoon at the Keelung River Park.

Forty-two others, including the ambassadors from three of the ROC's diplomatic allies, sustained minor injuries to their hands or arms when the rope being used in the contest broke, sending the participants tumbling to the ground. The event was organized by the Taipei City Government to mark Taiwan's Retrocession Day.

Officials from the Taipei District Court, however, indicated that the city councilors cannot legitimately file the suit, saying the court can only hear the case if it is filed by an injured party. Prosecutors, meanwhile, agreed to look into whether any person or party should bear responsibility for the accident.

Mayor Chen on Monday approved the resignation of Luo Wen-chia, head of the city government's Information Department, who offered to step down immediately after the incident "to take responsibility for the tragedy."
Chen would not comment directly on the lawsuit, but said he is willing to cooperate with and assist any necessary investigations into the case.

Chen Chien-chih, speaker of the Taipei City Council, authorized a change of Monday's agenda at the council to debate the mishap, and requested that the mayor and his aides be present for interpellations.

Describing the accident as the result of "major negligence," Chen said the city government can hardly absolve itself of all blame for using an inappropriate rope, for failing to take out insurance on the contestants, and for recruiting academics, rather than sports officials, to sponsor the event.

In the mishap, two men's left arms were completely dismembered when the rope being used for the tug-of-war snapped about one minute after the contest began, with the sudden and powerful force unleashed sending participants reeling, injuring a total of 45.
The force of the surge was unexpectedly powerful because some 1,600 people were engaged in the tug-of-war, using a rope which could not withstand the strain of so much tension.

After marathon operations late Saturday, surgeons at Mackay Memorial Hospital successfully reattached the two men's severed arms. There is a possibility they will regain 60 percent to 90 percent of the functions of those limbs after undergoing follow-up surgery in about three months, one surgeon said.

The third person critically injured in the accident, a 67-year-old man, sustained severe internal bleeding. He remained in intensive care for observation after doctors operated on his liver and spleen.

Mayor Chen, who met Sunday with surgeons from Taipei's major hospitals and asked them to do whatever they could to help the three men, promised that the city government would pay compensation and all medical bills for the injured, including costs for plastic surgery, special nurses and rehabilitative therapy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DEPRECIATION HELPS COMPUTER EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The recent depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar is expected to help boost exports of locally made notebook computers, which have been declining since the beginning of this year, industry sources say.

The sources predicted that "exports of Taiwan-made notebook computers will expand next year," as the depreciation of the local currency has made Taiwan's notebook computers more competitive against Japanese products in the international market and will drive more Japanese computer firms to shift production back to Taiwan.

Compared with the same period of last year, most Taiwan computer companies posted noticeable drops in revenues and profits in the first three quarters of the year upon the effect of a 4 percent depreciation of the Japanese yen against the US dollar since last October.

Tallies compiled by the Institute for the Information Industry show that the stake enjoyed by Taiwan notebook computers in the world marketplace has fallen to the current level of 29 percent from the previous 34 percent share posted since late last year.

However, with the local currency falling by 9 percent against the greenback over the past year, business sources said Taiwan's notebook computer makers will regain their competitive edge and can look forward to expanded export markets.

Experts estimate that the scale of the international notebook computer market will continue to grow from the current 15 million units sold annually to 26 million units by 2001, a faster rate of increase than that forecast for the information industry as a whole.
The experts also predicted that Taiwan's notebook computer production will stabilize in the coming year, with manufacturers reporting increased profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MEDIA PRODUCTIONS ALLOWED TO USE TAIWAN PROCESSING FACILITIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese media productions, including movies, audio recordings, radio broadcasts and TV programs will be allowed to use Taiwan processing facilities in the future, the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.
But a MAC official said the finished products will have to be shipped out of Taiwan upon completion and will still be banned from display, broadcast or distribution in Taiwan.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said the move is in line with a government plan to develop Taiwan into a media center in the Asia and Pacific region and to promote cooperation between the mass communication industries on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

Under the new regulations, Taiwan businessmen who can submit commission papers to the Government Information Office (GIO) will be able to apply for permission to process mainland China movies, audio recordings, TV and radio broadcast programs.

Sheu said the government will also consider permitting mainland newspapers and magazines, in addition to books, to be displayed in Taiwan, through events such as trade fairs and exhibitions, although their sale in this country will still be prohibited.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS TO PROTEST JIANG-CLINTON MEETING

TEXT.P: Several US-based pro-Taiwan independence groups will rally in front of the White House to protest the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, the Taiwan Independence Joint Alliance said on Monday.

The alliance said in a news release that the activity, titled "Safeguard Taiwan Sovereignty, Oppose Chinese Hegemony," will be attended by more than 1,000 supporters on Wednesday, the day of the scheduled Clinton-Jiang meeting, in a gesture to convey the Taiwan people's determination to build an independent nation to the international community.

A spokesman for the alliance said the public protest will begin in the morning with a march around the White House, followed by a rally at nearby Lafayette Square. In the afternoon, pro-Taiwan independence supporters, along with human rights and independence activists from other Asian nations, will march from the Washington Monument to Capitol Hill, where they intend to issue a petition to the US Congress, asking its support for independence movements in Taiwan and other Asian countries.
The activities will culminate in front of the mainland Chinese Embassy, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DEFENDS `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday again defended the government's "no haste, be patient" investment policy toward mainland China, stressing that the policy is aimed primarily at safeguarding Taiwan's security and ensuring its continued economic growth.

Lee made the statement while meeting with winners of this year's Outstanding Business People Award sponsored by the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China. The winners included local entrepreneurs, trade representatives of foreign countries and senior executives of foreign companies stationed in Taipei.

As a national leader, Lee said, he has consistently mulled issues from an overall perspective in order to understand the "big picture" to boost the well-being of all ROC nationals. "The policy has no correlation with my personal likes or dislikes."

The president said he has always been concerned about relations across the Taiwan Strait. "I have repeatedly held out the olive branch, but have yet to receive any reciprocal response of goodwill from the mainland leadership," he said regretfully.
Lee said that despite Taiwan's repeated calls for resumption of cross-trait dialogue, which mainland China unilaterally suspended in mid-1995, Beijing authorities are still unwilling to resume talks.
"If non-political issues related to the interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot be resolved, how can we conduct political talks with the mainland?" Lee asked.

Turning to the "three links" issue, Lee said the topic has seen frequent debate over the past few years. "Speaking responsibly, I have to say that the time is not yet ripe for the opening of direct cross-strait trade, communications and transport links," he asserted.
Lee further pointed out that uncertainty reigns in relations with mainland China because it is a despotic, totalitarian regime and lacks a clearly defined policymaking system.

"Against this backdrop, we should remain cautious and prudent in dealing with the `three links' issue, because at stake is our national security, social stability and the well-being of our people," the president explained.

Lee went on to say that Taiwan's economic prosperity is no windfall bonanza but the outcome of the concerted efforts of all the country's people over the past five decades. "We must therefore be very cautious in forging ties with mainland China in order to protect these hard-won achievements."

Commenting on recent appeals by several local business heavyweights for early opening of direct cross-strait links and the further liberalization of investment in mainland China, Lee said those business people may be pursuing their own agendas and putting their personal business interests first. "But it is crystal clear which should take precedence when personal or corporate interests conflict with the overall national interest," he said.

Touching on Taiwan's economic future, Lee said he is optimistic about the country's economic prospects. "Our people's diligence and devoted efforts, plus a sound economic policy, have enabled us to exploit our limited resources to the maximum extent over the past decades," he noted, adding that the island's economy will continue to grow steadily, with this year's growth rate expected to reach 6.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PAYING CLOSE ATTENTION TO CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The ROC government will closely monitor developments in the upcoming summit between US president Bill Clinton and his mainland China counterpart Jiang Zemin on Oct. 29, said Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Monday.
Jiang and Clinton are expected to confer on the establishment of a new stage in their bilateral relationship, as well as covering topics such as trade, arms proliferation and human rights.

Sheu pointed out during a news conference that the Foreign Ministry will assert Taipei's stance whenever necessary and reiterated that he doesn't think the summit will proceed at the expense of the US relationship with Taiwan. The MAC will react in a timely manner to developments at the summit which touch on the sensitive cross-Taiwan Strait issue, Sheu added.

He declined to comment on a report that the government has established an ad hoc committee to monitor the summit, saying only that the Foreign Ministry, the MAC and other relevant organizations will scrutinize the meeting closely.

Sheu reasserted the MAC's standpoint that it is good to see engagement between Washington and Beijing, adding that Taipei approves of Jiang's US visit, since benign interaction between the US and mainland China is helpful to the stability and prosperity both of the Asia-Pacific area and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW RECEIVES OUTSTANDING TRADE PROMOTERS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew Monday urged Taiwan and foreign business leaders and trade promoters to help the Republic of China government build Taiwan into an Asian Pacific business operations center.

Siew met Monday with 14 outstanding Taiwan businessmen, four executives of outstanding foreign trade offices in Taiwan, and five outstanding foreign business executives in Taiwan. The business leaders and trade promoters will be honored in a ceremony marking Merchants Day on Nov. 1.

In the meeting, Siew said the business leaders and trade promoters have made tremendous contributions to the promotion of trade between Taiwan and foreign countries and to the economic prosperity of Taiwan.
They have also achieved great success in transferring high technology and providing necessary services to Taiwan, he added.

Siew said the ROC government is trying to upgrade its economy and build Taiwan into an Asian Pacific business operations center. In this process the assistance of local and foreign business leaders and trade promoters is very important, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MAPS OUT STRATEGIES TO RAISE TAIWAN'S COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Monday spelled out a six-point strategy to help raise Taiwan's international competitiveness.

During a keynote speech at a seminar studying ways to bolster industrial and commercial development, Wang said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has decided to take a six-point approach to sharpening Taiwan's competitive edge in the international market.

The strategy includes the following angles: creating investment niches for potential investors; developing scientific technology industries; beefing up small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs); bolstering export competence; strengthening infrastructure; and expanding international cooperation, he noted.

Wang said newly established investment projects expected to become operational this year amount to NT$281.6 billion (US$9.39 billion), up 33.3 percent over the year-earlier level. The domestic investment climate will be further improved after an investment coordination center and a "single-desk" service station under the MOEA are completed.

To enhance sci-tech development, Wang said the MOEA will see to it that 10-20 percent of the R&D funds to which state-run enterprises are entitled will be allocated annually to sci-tech development and related industries.

The ministry will also further relax regulations on over-the-counter applications by sci-tech companies and will spend some NT$200 million (US$6.66 million) in fiscal 1998 to foster the development of more sci-tech talent, he added.

To beef up the development of SMEs, Wang said his ministry will help proprietors by allowing easier access to funds on easier terms, providing access to industrial land and implementing a computerized service network providing the latest market information.

The MOEA already has a map outlining a 30-market exploration plan to expand Taiwan's exports to the United States, Japan, Europe and Southeast Asia. The ministry has also worked out a NT$150 million (US$5 million) program to open up new outlets for Taiwan exporters in India, Pakistan, Australia and New Zealand, Wang noted.

On the infrastructure front, Wang said, the ministry will make more industrial land available, strengthen the development of water resources and accelerate energy supplies, which includes liberalizing the production and distribution of oil products and privately run power plants.

To expand international cooperation, the ministry will continue to push for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization and will seek to establish regular, high-level official communication channels with 17 countries, including Germany, Belgium, Austria and Singapore, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY T0 MONITOR TAIPEI STOCK MARKET DURING CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The rate of fall of the Taiwan stock market has been deemed relatively small-scale in comparison with that of the US, Hong Kong and Japan recently, but the Finance Ministry will closely monitor further changes during the Washington-Beijing summit on Oct.29, Wu Chia-sheng, administrative vice minister of the Finance Ministry, observed on Monday.

Commenting on suggestions from certain quarters concerning ways to stabilize Taipei's stock market, such as suspending same-day trading (buying and selling shares on the same day), or decreasing the upper and lower limit on the rise and fall of shares on the Taiwan stock market's weighted index -- the share market's key barometer -- Wu said that although the time is not yet ripe for evaluating the feasibility of the suggestions, the Finance Ministry will take them into consideration.

During the summit between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland China counterpart Jiang Zemin, Wu said the ROC Finance Ministry will pay close attention to every possible factor that may have an impact on Taiwan's stock market, including economic and non-economic factors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD PRESIDENT WELCOMED WITH FULL MILITARY HONORS

TEXT.P: Visiting President of the Republic of Chad, Idriss Deby, was welcomed on Monday with full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute, at a ceremony presided over by President Lee Teng-hui at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.
Deby, accompanied by a 16-member entourage, arrived in Taipei for the first time on Sunday for a five-day state visit.

In an address at the welcoming ceremony, Lee lauded Deby as an outstanding leader who has managed to lead his country to achieve great progress in political reforms and economic development in a short period of time.

Lee said the ROC government and people welcome Deby's visit and hope it will help the Chad leader better understand Taiwan's latest developments and thus contribute to the expansion of bilateral cooperation in various fields.

Responding to Lee's address, Deby said he is delighted to make an official visit to the beautiful island of Taiwan. In addition to conveying his country's respect and friendship to the Republic of China, Deby said, he and his entourage hope to draw inspiration from Taiwan's experience in economic development during their visit, which is also expected to serve as a bridge and catalyst for closer bilateral cooperation.

The Chad president pointed out that many people in his country still remember the competence and down-to-earth working style of ROC agricultural experts stationed in Chad in the 1960s and are grateful for their legacy.
Deby further said he is convinced that there is ample room for the two countries to cooperate now that they have resumed full diplomatic ties.
The ROC and Chad restored official ties on Aug. 12, 1997 after a 25-year hiatus.

While here, Deby will exchange views with Lee on the international situation and other matters of mutual concern. He will also visit some cultural landmarks, as well economic and trade establishments, before departing on Oct. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-AUSTRALIAN TIES RECOVERING (I)

TEXT.P: Unofficial relations between the Republic of China and Australia are recovering gradually and steadily as a result of improving ties between Canberra and Beijing, according to a survey by the CNA.

In an interview, Gary Klintworth, a China expert at the Australian National University in Canberra, said relations between Taiwan and Australia are showing signs of gradual recovery following a disruption between late 1996 and early 1997 because Canberra wanted to restore its strained ties with Beijing.

The strained ties were caused by a wave of incidents in 1996, namely Australia's support of the US sending aircraft carriers to the waters near Taiwan in March, Canberra's allowing the Dalai Lama to visit Australia, sending a senior minister to Taipei and renewing a military pact with the US

Good relations between Taipei and Canberra were disrupted because Australia refused to grant a visa to Yang Shieh-chien, a high-level ROC official, in late 1996 when he was invited to give a keynote speech at an annual Australia-Taiwan Business Council meeting.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu was also refused a visa to visit Australia in late 1996.

But these refusals did not sour ties between Taiwan and Australia until Canberra refused another visa,. this time to Vice Minister Ming Chen-kuo of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, in early 1997.
China experts said Canberra deliberately denied visas to these senior Taiwan officials in order to pave the way for the first visit of Premier John Howard to Beijing in late March.
They said Australia was worried that the visits of Taiwan officials could provide excuses for mainland China to criticize the sincerity of Canberra's efforts to mend ties with Beijing.
They said Australia values ties with both mainland China and Taiwan, but Canberra gives its priority to Beijing because of the size of the mainland market and its political muscle.

Under the one-China policy, Taiwan comes second, although Australia values the Taiwan market, the experts said. That's the reality and it's very hard for Taipei to make any breakthrough in its current ties.
Official relations between Taiwan and Australia are beyond reach for the foreseeable future, the experts predicted.
Two-way trade between mainland China and Australia totaled about A$8 billion in 1996 and it is expected the figure will increase in the next few years.
Trade volume between Taiwan and Australia was almost A$6 billion during the same period and it is also expected to grow steadily in the years to come, the experts said.

Howard went to Beijing in March, and other senior Australian officials, including Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, have also visited mainland China in the past few months to successfully mend ties.
Klintworth and Greg Austin, of the Asian Studies department at the Australian National University, believe bilateral ties between Australia and mainland China have now returned to normal.
They said the improved relations between Canberra and Beijing will also help gradually restore the disrupted ties between Taiwan and Australia.
Last month, Australia sent Energy and Resources Minister Warwick Parer to attend the annual Taiwan-Australia Business Council meeting in Taipei.

The experts said that on the surface, it seemed Canberra was downgrading its ties with Taipei by sending a junior minister and not a cabinet minister such as Primary Industries Minister John Anderson, who went to Taiwan in 1996.
But in substance, Parer is closer to Howard than some other senior ministers in Australia.

"We don't think our ties with Australia have downgraded just because Canberra sent Warwick Parer," said Wang Kuo-jan, acting representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK MARKET REBOUND HINGES ON US RECOVERY

TEXT.P: The recovery of the Australian stock market will hinge on a recovery on Wall Street this week, Australian economists and analysts predicted.

The Australian stock market lost nearly 122 points last Thursday and Friday, wiping off about A$19 billion in its market capitalization in just two days because of fallout from the US, Hong Kong and other major Asian bourses, they said.

The analysts predicted the loss will affect Australia's biggest floating of government-owned telecommunications firm -- Telstra -- and reduce Australia's government proceeds from the flotation, estimated at up to A$14 billion in a historic privatization program.
Since reaching a record high of 2779.2 on Oct. 1, the All Ordinaries Index dropped 7.8 percent last week alone.
Analysts attributed part of the decline to the size of the falls in Northern Hemisphere markets, which averaged three percent.
The Hong Kong bourse rebounded last Friday following massive support in the form of buying from mainland China, rising 6.9 percent to close at 11,144.34.
The analysts believe the Wall Street bourse could also rebound this week, adding some impetus to the Australian market.
Economists pointed out that another major factor for a possible recovery in the Australian stock market is that the country's economic fundamentals remain good.
"Short-term prospects of the Australian stock market are gloomy, but the long-term outlook is bright," one said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-AUSTRALIAN TIES RECOVERING (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: He said two-way trade between the two countries will increase gradually. Cultural and educational ties will also increase steadily, he said, pointing out that although the number of students and tourists from Taiwan is declining as a result of racial debate sparked by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, he believes these ties will return to normal, especially if Australia continues to make more promotions and brush aside fears of such racism.
Some Australian politicians agreed with Wang's views, saying the ties between Taiwan and Australia stand separate from Canberra's ties with Beijing.
Bob Sercombe, Federal Member of the House of Representatives, said: "Taiwan is a crucial market for Australia. I don't think Australia will ignore Taiwan."

"Australia recognizes Taiwan's achievements in democracy and freedom and economic development. Australia and Taiwan have something in common," he said, adding that there is still room for expansion in the field of trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19TH PACIFIC PRIVATE SCHOOL EDUCATION CONGRESS OPENS

TEXT.P: The 19th Congress of the Pan-Pacific Association of Private School Education (PAPE) opened here on Monday, attended by over 400 educators, scholars and experts from the Republic of China and 13 other countries and areas in the Pan-Pacific region.

During the four-day meeting, the participants will exchange experiences on private education and work out ways to increase cooperation among PAPE member-countries to promote the development of private education in the Pan-Pacific region.

Papers and reports to be presented during the meeting will include: "Do Gifted and Talented Approaches Work for the Disadvantaged" by Dr. Henry M. Levin of the United States; "Anytime/Anyplace Learning Increases Opportunities for Lifelong Education and Training" by Dr. Richard H. Lytle of the US; "Resume of the Professional Background, Experience and Training" by Dr. H.R. Keels of the US; and "Vocational and Technological Education Reforms in Taiwan" by Dr. Louis K. Chang of the ROC; "Canadian Private Schools Respond to New Demands" by Graham Baldwin of Canada; "Quality Diversity And Choice: Strengthening Australian Education through the Private Sector" by Dr. Peter W. Harris of Australia; "Reform and Private Education in the United States" by Andrew W. Corcoran of the US; and "Sustainable Excellence for Thai Private Education in the 21st Century" by Dr. Leo Visith Srivichairatana of Thailand.

Also Monday, ROC President Lee Teng-hui received the heads of the delegations of PAPE member-countries at the Presidential Office, where he told the educators that private education plays a very important role in Taiwan's education system, with private college and university students accounting for over 70 percent of the total number of undergraduates and private senior high and occupational schools training 61 percent of the students in these categories.
He pointed out that the ROC government in July enacted the "Private School Law" to further encourage the development of private education.

PAPE, which has its headquarters in Tokyo, was jointly established by private education associations of the region in November, 1979, with the purpose of strengthening exchanges among member-countries and promoting the development of private education in the region.

PAPE currently has 13 members -- the ROC, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Canada, Thailand, the Philippines and Singapore. In addition, delegates from Macau are attending the conference for the first time as observers.

Katsuaki Hirukoshi of Japan currently serves as PAPE chairman, with Kim Kui Nyeon of South Korea, Anthony Si-an Chen of the ROC and Peter W. Harris of Australia as his deputies. Chen also serves as the chairman of the preparatory committee of the Taipei congress and Lin Cheng-tse, an ROC legislator, is secretary general.

Since its establishment 18 years ago, PAPE has held its annual congress in various member-states and this is the third time Taipei has hosted the event. South Korea, the Philippines and the United States have been named to host PAPE's 1998, 1999 and 2000 congress, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMY CONTINUES UPWARD SWING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy continued to flash a safe "green light" in September, indicating that the domestic economy is on the track of steady growth, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Monday.
It was the 11th straight month that the country's overall economic performance has received a "green" rating on the CEPD-designed five-color scale for stable growth.

The composite index of economic performance received a score of 31 points in September, up five points from August, signaling that the economy continues to gain momentum and is approaching a state of "heating up," said CEPD Economic Research Department Director Thomas Yeh.

The CEPD uses a five-color rating system to emasure the country's monthly economic performance. A red light means the economy is overheated; a yellow-red light indicates the economy is heating up; a green light reflects steady growth; a yellow-blue rating signals an economic slowdown; and a blue light represents an economic recession.

Ratings are determined according to nine major economic indicators: export value, new export orders, industrial production, manufacturing inventories, total employment outside the agricultural sector, money supply, stock prices, the check default rate and bank lending to the private sector. The minumum score for a healthy "green" rating is 23 points.

During the month of September, the nine indicators showed mixed performances. Three indicators -- export value, industrial output and the check default rate showed marked improvement, driving up the overall performance score. The ratings for the remaining six indicators remained at the same levels as the previous month.

In all, September's leading indicators edged up 0.7 percent from August to 105.1, a sign that the domestic economy will remain strong over the next three to five months. The index of coincident indicators also rose 1.4 percent from August to 104, a solid evidence that September's economic performance was better than the previous month. Both figures are based on an indicator of 100 in 1991.

Yeh said the rises in export value and industrial production indicate that the domestic economic recovery continues to pick up steam, while the improvement in the check default rate reflects brisk domestic business activities and better financial status of local business people.

"All these are encouraging signs that our economy is moving an upward swing," Yeh noted, adding that the recent fluctuation in the local foreign exchange and stock markets will only have a limited effect on the country's economic growth and that this year's growth rate will reach 6.5 to 6.6 percent.
Yeh further said the devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar will benefit exports of some Taiwan products. "The effect will become clear in the next few months," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO `GRASSROOTS AMBASSADORS' VISIT CHIAYI CITY MAYOR

TEXT.P: Three "grassroots ambassadors" from the Philippines visited Chiayi City Mayor Chang Wen-ying on Monday.
Anas Tacia R. Eslava, Lucila L. Esdrelon and Virgilio S. Gadiano told Chang that they were impressed by a flower garden in her city, adding that they found Chiayi to be "really clean and beautiful."

The goodwill ambassadors are making a two-month visit to Taiwan to promote agricultural exchanges, help gain a better understanding of each other's agricultural development and strengthen friendship between the two countries.
Mayor Chang said she visited the Philippines this June and that she found the Southeast Asian country to be beautiful and worth visiting. She also introduced her guests to her city's scenic spots.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SERVICE INDUSTRY TO GET MORE PROSPEROUS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The service industry in Taiwan will become more prosperous because the overall economic condition will get better next year, according to a survey report by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

The report predicts that next year Taiwan's foreign trade will grow moderately, the income of consumers will increase, commodity prices will remain stable, and the relations between Taiwan and mainland China will improve. Under such an economic condition, the service industry will become more prosperous, it said.
The survey report reveals that 52.9 percent of the respondents in the service industry believe that their business will be better next year than this year.
The service industry will be able to improve its service and sharpen its competitive edge after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization (WTO), the report says. (by Ed hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE EXPERTS EXPECT NO BIG BREAKTHROUGHS AT SUMMIT

TEXT.P: China watchers in Singapore shared the views that the Clinton-Jiang summit on Wednesday will be a significant meeting but not one producing immediate, concrete results.
Analysts said they do not foresee any major breakthroughs in the series of thorny problems that have plagued relations between mainland China and the United States over the years.

Academics at Singapore's East Asian Institute, the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies and the Political Science Department of the National University of Singapore (NUS) pointed out that most of these problems are fundamental yet complicated issues which require more than political will to resolve.
A senior political science lecturer at the NUS said the Taiwan issue remains the "bone of contention" between Beijing and Washington.
Most of the analysts agreed that Beijing authorities will pressure President Clinton to make a statement that reaffirms Washington's "one-China" policy.
However, Clinton has made such statements in his past four meetings with Jiang Zemin, so the reaffirmation at the end of this summit should not be seen as a major breakthrough.

As for the contentious issue of mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization, an East Asian Institute expert predicted that any real achievement on the issue would have to wait until Clinton's return visit to Beijing next year.

Professor Wang Gung-wu, director of the East Asian Institute, pointed out that the summit comes at a time when Sino-US relations are fraught with many difficulties. Thus, he said, this summit meeting is "something significant."
Most of the experts here felt that though the United States and mainland China remain divided over human rights, bilateral relations will not be greatly affected by this.

Clinton cannot afford not to talk about human rights because of pressure at home, a scholar commented. But the Clinton administration has come to attach less importance to human rights because they know the US policy on mainland China cannot be dominated by one issue alone, he added.
Nevertheless, despite their differences both countries are keen to maintain peace and security and the balance of power in the Asia-Pacific region, the experts concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-MAINLAND CHINESE SENTIMENT SAID STILL TO EXIST IN US

TEXT.P: Although US-mainland Chinese relations have been heading in a positive direction recently, anti-mainland sentiment still exists among several major groups in the United States, according to the Indonesian Observer.
"The recent uproar over political contributions to the Democratic Party has again revealed the existence of such sentiment," the newspaper said in its editorial Monday.

The editorial, titled "President Jiang's journey," pointed out that this visit, the first by a mainland Chinese leader to the United States in 12 years, comes at a time when relations are plagued by a range of issues including US ties with Taiwan, a multi-billion dollar trade imbalance and the question of human rights.

"President Jiang Zemin acknowledged that there are different views on some issues -- particularly Taiwan -- but stressed that both countries have the responsibility to promote stability and prosperity between them," the editorial said.

"It would be too much to expect President Jiang's current visit will be able to remove all obstacles between the two great superpowers, but it is a great opportunity to pave the way for better understanding and the long-term preservation of peace in the Asia-Pacific region," the editorial added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL GOVERNMENT BUDGET TO INCREASE 3.8 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The budget of the Republic of China central government for fiscal 1999 will amount to NT$1,271.4 billion (US$41.68 billion), an increase of 3.8 percent over the budget for the current year, according to a report by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) of the Executive Yuan.

Of the total budget, NT$21.7 billion will be earmarked for diplomatic spending and NT$12.9 billion for judicial spending, an increase of 26.9 percent and 40 percent respectively over the current fiscal year. The spending for education, science, and cultural development will account for 16 percent of the total budget, as compared with 15.3 percent for the current year. It is guaranteed in the Constitution that spending for this purpose shall not be lower than 15 percent of the central government budget.
The 1999 budget is based on the calculation that the economy will grow between 6.5 percent and 6.6 percent in the new fiscal year, which begins on July 1, 1998.
The report was made Monday in a meeting presided over by Premier Vincent Siew. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BULGARIA'S MUSIC PIRATES UNDER FIRE

TEXT.P: The world's record companies are considering asking the European Commission to crack down on rapidly growing music piracy in Bulgaria, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Monday.

Piracy has long been regarded as one of the principal problems facing the international music industry. Bulgaria, which has relatively weak copyright legislation, has emerged as one of the world's largest sources of counterfeit compact discs.

The International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), the London-based body which represents the world's record companies, is considering making a formal complaint to the European Commission against Bulgaria, the WTO report said.

Nic Garnett, the federation's chief executive, was quoted as saying that the IFPI's efforts to lobby the Bulgarian authorities have proved unsuccessful, as have its attempts to take legal action against pirates in the country.
"The response from the Bulgarian government has been totally inadequate," he said. "Our next step may be to petition the European Commission to bring a trade complaint against Bulgaria."

The increase in Bulgarian music piracy comes amid growing concern among record companies about escalating counterfeiting worldwide. Sales of pirated recordings breached US$5 billion for the first time last year, the WTO report said.

Until recently, music pirates tended to concentrate on cassettes, a declining format which is significantly less profitable for record labels than compact discs. However, sales of counterfeit CDs have soared in the past year, as the cost of CD production equipment has fallen.

Bulgaria has become one of the prime sources of pirate CDs, as local manufacturers have stepped up production and exported counterfeit products throughout Europe. The IFPI suspects more than 15 million pirated CDs are now manufactured there each year, representing one in eight of all those sold worldwide, the WTO report said.

Following the federation's lobbying efforts, the Bulgarian police raided several compact disc factories this summer. Yet the anti-piracy drive faltered in July, when a court case against a suspected pirate collapsed.

By contrast, attempts to force the mainland Chinese government to crack down on music piracy are showing signs of success. Garnett said that after a frustrating period when little progress was made, there had been "a considerable improvement in the situation" in recent months, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL MARKETS DIVE AGAIN

TEXT.P: The Australian financial and security markets suffered big falls Monday after being hit last Thursday and Friday as the result of fallout from the Asian financial crisis.
The All Ordinaries Index plunged 84.3 points to close at 2477, wiping off about A$13.4 billion (US$9.2 billion) on Monday alone.
Monday's fall brought the total decline since last Thursday to more than A$30 billion (US$20.6 billion).
Meanwhile, the Australian dollar plunged to 68.63 US cents, hitting a four-year low.
Analysts said the Australian financial and security markets will remain volatile unless Wall Street stages a rebound at once. But they doubted the US market would come to the rescue.
They noted Asian markets, including Hong Kong's, suffered more beatings Monday, and said there seems to be little chance of recovery in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL WANG TO HEAD CENTRAL NEWS AGENCY

TEXT.P: Bill Wang, director of the Washington Bureau of the Central News Agency (CNA), was named Monday by the CNA Board of Directors as the new president of the news organization.
Wang will succeed Kermin Shih, who has been reassigned by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be the ROC representative in Norway.
Wang, 52, a graduate from the Department of Journalism of National Chengchi University, obtained master's degrees from both Central Michigan University and Harvard University.

An experienced journalist, Wang has been a CNA reporter in Taipei, CNA correspondent in the Middle East, director of the CNA Foreign News Department and vice president of the agency. He has also served briefly as editor-in-chief and vice president of the China News, one of the two major English-language daily newspapers in Taiwan. Wang is expected to assume his duties as CNA president in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG'S US TRIP SEEN AS FULL OF DANGERS DUE TO TAIWAN, TIBET ISSUES

TEXT.P: The upcoming summit meeting between the presidents of mainland China and the United States -- the first of its kind since the late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping's trip to America about 18 years ago -- will be fraught with difficulties thanks to the issues of Tibet and Taiwan, The Canberra Times said Monday.

In an editorial headlined "Jiang's US Trip Full of Dangers," the daily said: "The visit of Chinese president Jiang Zemin to the United States is filled with risk. It has the capacity to set the tone for a relationship that will be pivotal to the security and prosperity of the world -- as China takes its place as a new global powerhouse."

The editorial continued, however, "The prospects for success are limited, since no major initiatives are expected but its capacity for disaster are manifest, ranging from hostile demonstrations to the physical safety of the Chinese leader. Little wonder that professional diplomats take such a jaundiced view of such summitry. The game is rarely worth the candle."

The daily said the Deng visit to the United States in 1979 was a different matter because it was useful in establishing a new image of the Beijing leadership and allaying the fears of a generation raised on a diet of propaganda that pictured mainland China as an expansionist threat.

"However, all the progress of a decade was lost with the horror of Tiananmen Square in 1989. The images of bloodshed and the single man confronting the tank remain indelible in the American psyche," the editorial noted.

"Also, since then there has been a highly visible campaign from the Dalai Lama to highlight Chinese oppression in Tibet. This has added force with the release of big Hollywood films on the subject, with simplistic plots and characterization totally ignoring the oppressive theocracy that stultified Tibetan society for centuries," it said.

"There is a strong Taiwan lobby in the United States that is pressing for an independent state despite the US government's official 'One China' policy. The religious Right has taken up cudgels against Beijing on grounds that Christianity is being repressed on the mainland," it added.

"Together these pressure groups represent a volatile mix. The potential for a serious diplomatic incident is a matter of obvious concern which has not been assisted by the attitude of (Clinton) Administration spokesmen appearing to relish the prospect of Jiang Zemin's being exposed to American 'democracy in action,'" the daily opined.

It noted that Clinton has contributed to the volatility of the situation by the radical change in his policy settings toward mainland China. "For nearly three years, he sought to tie the trade relationship to human rights. The Chinese called his bluff. They also accused him of attempting a policy of containment," it said.

"If the trip can produce a friendly atmosphere and a cooperative attitude on both sides, real progress can be expected to follow on the knotty issues of North Korean intransigence, China's progress into the World Trade Organization, expanded trade within the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation and a permanent resolution of Taiwan's status," the editorial said.

"One serious blunder on either side could place all progress in jeopardy. The Chinese leadership set the timing and the agenda for the trip. If it has misjudged the mood of America, the consequences will be serious," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON CLINTON'S DEALINGS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Monday's edition of local English-language daily The China Post.
Clinton Should Encourage Glasnost in Beijing
In a sense, communist Chinese leader Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States, which started yesterday (Oct. 26), is truly historic...

President Clinton,... is right to seek cooperation instead of confrontation with mainland China, believing that isolation of mainland China is a policy that is "unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous."
What Clinton wants to do is to encourage mainland China to make more changes towards freedom and democracy through constructive engagement with the United States...
Clinton (is) right in his view that greater openness will speed mainland China's economic growth, enhance its world influence and stabilize its society.
It is, therefore, important for President Clinton to urge his communist Chinese counterpart to stop human rights abuses and to adopt a policy that promotes glasnost.

The 71-year-old Jiang, unlike the Long March veterans, is an intellectual by communist Chinese standards who is more or less susceptible to the Western way of thinking. President Clinton should use his influence to let his guest know that suppressing human rights, stifling dissent, muscle-flexing against Taiwan as a policy is "unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous."

In the long run, the importance of mainland China's openness and glasnost far surpasses such issues... as arms exports, the greenhouse effect and the Taiwan question. Clinton knows it (better) than anybody else and he should convince Jiang that "without the full freedom to think, to question, to create, China will be at a distinct disadvantage competing with fully open societies in the Information Age, " as he said last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES TURNOVER OF MANUFACTURING SECTOR INCREASES

TEXT.P: The sales turnover of the Taiwan manufacturing sector increased 13.8 percent in September from the same month of last year or 3.9 percent from August, according to a government report issued by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Monday.
The report also found that the orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in September posted an 8.6 percent gain from the year-earlier level but were down 1.2 percent from August.

Meanwhile, a CEPD survey showed that 6 percent of the industrial executives interviewed said that the economic situation in September was "good," compared with 3 percent charted in the August poll, while those who called the economic situation "bad" dropped 1 percent to 19 percent. Those who labeled the economic performance "normal" stood at 75 percent, down two percentage points from the previous month.

A total of 22 percent of the respondents predicted the economy will gain momentum in the next three months, while 73 percent forecast that the economic situation will remain unchanged. Only 5 percent of the manufacturers predicted a change for the worse.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE SURGED 8.5 PERCENT IN JANUARY-AUGUST

TEXT.P: The trade between Taiwan and mainland China rose 8.5 percent to US$15.21 billion over the first eight months of this year, including a 2.2 percent drop to US$1.8 billion in August due to typhoons halting customs processing for two days that month, according to preliminary figures from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

In January-August, Taiwan exported US$12.79 billion in goods to mainland China, accounting for 16.2 percent of the island's total exports and representing an annual growth rate of 6.3 percent as mainland China's booming exports increased mainland demand for semi-finished products and components from Taiwan, said the BOFT.
Taiwan imported US$2.42 billion worth of mainland goods during the same period, or 3.3 percent of the island's total imports in those months.

That dollar figure represents an annual increase of 10.5 percent, which the BOFT attributed to Taiwan's economic recovery entailing increasing demands for semi-finished products and raw materials from mainland China.
Two-way trade was US$10.36 billion in Taiwan's favor, which translates into a 3.1 percent growth, similar to the 3.8 percent growth seen in the same period of last year.

Cross-strait trade reached US$1.8 billion in August, including a 4.4 percent decline to US$1.5 billion in exports and a 10.5 percent increase to US$296 million in imports, giving the island a trade surplus of US$1.21 billion with the mainland, or 7.4 percent lower than it enjoyed in the same month last year.

Although the mainland's fast-growing exports have stimulated Taiwan's own exports, the BOFT warned that the increasing appreciation pressure building up on the mainland currency by mainland China's huge current account surplus, coupled with the mainland's blunted competitive edge after the sharp depreciation of currencies in Southeast Asia, might dampen its orders for Taiwan's products.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS ATTEND APEC MEETING IN S'PORE

TEXT.P: Two officials from Taiwan are among those attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) senior officials' meeting which opened here Monday.

Shen Kuo-hsiung, director of the Department of International Organizations of the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, flew into Singapore from Taipei last Saturday for the meeting, while Chen Jui-lung, director-general of the ROC Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), arrived here Monday.

The two-day meeting is being chaired by Leonard J. Edwards, Canada's assistant deputy minister for trade and economic policy. It was convened to discuss and finalize preparations for the Ninth APEC Ministerial Meeting and the Fifth APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting to be held in Vancouver next month, said an APEC Secretariat official.
Chen, who recently assumed his post at the head of the BOFT, will return to Taipei on Tuesday, while Shen will follow the next day.

DOC.HEADLINE: GCC RAILWAY PROJECT TO COST US$30 BILLION

TEXT.P: A project to link Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) member states by a railway line will cost about US$30 billion, according to a study conducted by the group's secretariat.
The study, however, also found that the proposed rail project linking Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman and the UAE will bring considerable economic, political and social benefits.

"This project is more feasible and beneficial as the railway network is much better than a road network in transporting goods between the six GCC states," the study said. According to the study, the GCC states have already spent about US$30 billion on expressways linking the member states with a total length of 55,000 kilometers of asphalt road.

These roads require US$3 billion annually for maintenance. The study also pointed out that the GCC countries would require 300,000 trucks to transport its industrial and agricultural products instead of the current 100,000 vehicles in use.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOT YET TIME FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH M'LAND CHINA: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: In another public response to the latest call from Taiwan's business community for direct links with mainland China, President Lee Teng-hui told a group of businessmen Monday that "the time is just not ripe yet" for such links.
Lee pointed out to a group of distinguished local businessmen that the authoritarian regime in Beijing lacks established institutions and could leave anyone dealing with it in the lurch.

Citing national security concerns and the need to ensure the welfare of all of the people in Taiwan, the president said that before any possible opening of direct shipping, trade and postal links with mainland China, the administration has to carefully study what problems might arise from this.

"It is understandable that businessmen are eager to seek safeguards for their interests," Lee said. "But as a national leader I have to take into account the welfare of the entire people of the nation."

Lee initiated the so-called "no haste, be patient" policy to persuade Taiwan businessmen to cool their fervor to make investments in mainland China, hoping this would press Beijing to renounce its hostility toward the island.

Regretting that the mainland leadership has so far snubbed his repeated offers of an olive branch, Lee said that authorities here have always kept the door open to negotiations while Beijing has turned up its nose at all of Taipei's proposals to resume the cross-strait dialogue.

Asserting that no personal bias is involved in the government's mainland policy, Lee said that there is no question that national security, social stability and the interest of the whole people should take precedence over the gain of individual businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CAN VISIT M'LAND CHINA IN 'APPROPRIATE' CAPACITY: BEIJING OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Lee Teng-hui, president of the Republic of China, can fulfill his hope of a "journey of peace" to mainland China providing he makes the trip in an "appropriate capacity," said a Beijing official for Taiwan affairs on Monday.

Backing away from Beijing's insistence that Lee could only visit mainland China as the head of a Chinese province, Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, told a group of Taiwan reporters that Lee's capacity is "an issue that could be negotiated."

Disputing as groundless a Washington Post report that Beijing would not deal with Taiwan as long as Lee holds the reins of state in Taipei, Tang asked Taiwanese reporters who are visiting here along with a Taiwan youth group, "Whom should we deal with other than Lee?"

Tang said that the dialogue between Taipei and Beijing can resume whenever Taiwan authorities respond affirmatively to mainland President Jiang Zemin's proposal of ending cross-strait hostility under the principle of "one China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERESTS WON'T BE HURT IN SUMMIT TALKS: HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu reiterated on Monday that the United States has assured the Republic of China on many occasions that the coming summit talks between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will not hurt the interests of Taiwan.

Hu said that even with Washington's reassurances, Taipei still has to watch closely the results of the summit meeting, and at the same time prepare itself for any possible changes in US policy toward mainland China or Taiwan.

Two working teams -- one at the Foreign Ministry and the other at the National Security Council -- have been formed to help the government grasp the developments at the summit talks on Oct. 28, Hu said, adding that the teams will work round the clock Oct. 28-30.

Responding to questions from legislators, Hu said that what most concerns the government is whether the Washington-Beijing talks, the first of their kind in 12 years, will endanger the security of Taiwan. Jiang is expected to demand that the United States halt its arms sales to Taiwan, but Hu said he doesn't believe Clinton will make any concessions on this or other Taiwan issues.

Hu said that the ROC government has made its demands clear that the US government should not engage Beijing at the expense of Taiwan, and that when the United States improves its relations with mainland China it should also increase its exchanges with Taiwan. While saying that he believes the US government has shown good will to Taiwan's demands, Hu said that the ROC government's next goal is to make Washington treat its relations with Taipei parallel to its ties with Beijing.

Asked whether there is a "hot line" between Clinton and President Lee Teng-hui and if he ever met Clinton during his recently-concluded tenure as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the United States, Hu said that national security concerns prevent him from answering such questions.

Hu stressed the importance of "pragmatic diplomacy," saying that the ROC has no choice but to make more efforts to expand its profile in the international community amid Beijing's persistent attempts to shunt Taiwan aside internationally.
Hu, however, stressed that pragmatic diplomacy is not aimed at creating "two Chinas" or an independent Taiwan but rather at securing Taiwan's existence in the international community.
The government realizes that "the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will serve the interests of both sides, while the long-term separation won't do any party good," Hu said.

Hu urged Beijing to stop fighting "zero-sum" battles with Taipei in the international community, saying that Taiwan has no intention to fight against mainland China internationally. Taiwan would instead like to enhance its communication with the mainland to seek mutual trust for cross-strait relations, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL TO VISIT MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will travel with a postal delegation to the mainland next month, SEF officials said Tuesday.
The delegation will be led by Wang Wei, deputy director-general of the Directorate General of Office.

Accompanying the delegation will be Lee and another SEF official, You Juei-teh, director of SEF's Department of Legal Service, as well as five officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The group will leave for the mainland Nov. 10 to visit postal establishments in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Fuzhou and Xiamen. It is expected to return to Taipei Nov. 23.

SEF officials said that though the SEF and its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- have yet to resume formal talks and regular communication channels, contacts between the two intermediary bodies have been smooth and uninterrupted.

Regular dialogues between the SEF and ARATS were suspended by Beijing following President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995. With leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait expressing desire to resume talks in recent months, there has been speculation that the dialogue could restart early next year.

Observers note that with the visit to Taiwan of Liu Kangchi, ARATS deputy secretary-general, in early August to attend a seminar, and Lee's visit to the mainland next month, time could be ripe for the long-anticipated resumption of cross-strait talks.
