DOC.HEADLINE: FUND MAY BE RELEASED TO DEFEND STOCK MARKET: CHIU

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu on Tuesday repeated calls on investors to have confidence in Taiwan's economy and said that his ministry is considering the release of a stock relief fund to stabilize the local bourse.

Chiu made the remarks after an emergency meeting with Central Bank of China (CBC) officials this morning in the wake of a US stock market rout on Monday, in which the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted by 554 points, the largest single-day drop in history.

The slide has triggered a chain reaction in stock markets worldwide. The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, fell by 452.52 points to 7,210.01, or a 5.93 percent decrease, the largest point fall and the largest percentage fall since June 7, 1990 and Oct. 8, 1994, respectively.
The market turnover shrank to NT$79.6 billion and a total of 1.71 billion shares changed hands.

Chiu told CNA that the Finance Ministry and the CBC decided at Tuesday's meeting to provide the local bourse with sufficient floating capital and that officials will release a stock relief fund if such a move becomes necessary to help stabilize the stock market.

The nation's chief finance official also called on stock investors to remain calm, saying that Taiwan's economy is in good shape and the local stock market is relatively stable compared with the bourse in other countries.

Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng revealed that the Finance Ministry is poised to take necessary measures to reinvigorate the stock market, but denied that the ministry is planning to suspend daily trading or to narrow the 7 percent cap on the market's daily increase and decline limit.

Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said he believes that Taiwan will soon recover from the financial upheavals currently plaguing the whole world, stating that Taiwan's economy is sound and good.
He stressed that the CEPD respects measures by other government agencies to simulate the stock market and that maintaining Taiwan's economic growth remains the council's top priority.

Meanwhile, academics and scholars praised the government's determination to defend the local bourse, saying that intervention under the present circumstances will be helpful to rebuilding investor confidence amid the serious crisis.

Cheng Yuan-po, a research fellow at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, said the monetary turmoil originating in Southeast Asian countries has unleashed a "vicious cycle" in global stock and financial markets and that many governments have already begun to take measures to defend their economies.

Chung Chin, a researcher with the Institute of Economics under Academia Sinica, said the effect of the government's intervention measures remain to be seen, but voiced support for such moves. He attributed the wave of stock market declines worldwide to a lack of confidence.

Chung expressed the belief that the government's announcement of its intention to release funds to defend the stock market will help restore investor confidence, thus forestalling further damage to the local economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUPS TO PROTEST CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Anti-nuclear and pro-Taiwan independence groups will stage demonstration here to protest Wednesday's meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at the White House.

The Green Party, Taiwan Independence Alliance and legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced in a press conference Tuesday morning that they will gather at the 2-28 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei on Wednesday night for a demonstration and sit-down vigil.

The groups said they will urge the United States not to pursue business interests with mainland China at the expense of Taiwan and not to bow to the lobbying efforts of US businessmen who seek the sale of nuclear equipment and technology to the mainalnd.

Kao Cheng-yen, convenor of the Green Party, said that US businessmen, targeting the mainland nuclear energy market, have been aggressively lobbying Washington to lift its ban on nuclear exports to the mainland.

Pro-Taiwan independence activist and DPP Legislator Chen Yung-hsing said the US should not export nuclear reactors and related technology to the mainland as it would pose threat to the Asian and Pacific region.
Legislator Hsieh Tsung-min, also of the DPP, said nuclear energy proliferation is contrary to the world trend, and the US must oppose such sales in the interest of world peace.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for a Taiwan independence alliance in the United States said it will mobilize overseas Chinese to parade around the White House and march to Capitol Hill on Wednesday. He said the group will urge the United States to respect the rights of Taiwan people to choose the course of their own future.

The organization will also join other groups in a demonstration in front of the Washington Monument on Wednesday as well as mobilize Taiwanese groups in Philadelphia, New York, Boston and Los Angeles to protest Jiang when he visits those cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSIAL CIRCUS TO DEBUT TUESDAY NIGHT

TEXT.P: The American Universal Circus will make its debut in Taiwan on Tuesday amid claims by local animal rights activists that the spectacular performances are a result of cruel training methods.

The New Aspect Cultural and Educational Foundation, the local sponsor of the event, said that Tuesday night's performance in Taipei County is a charity event to entertain and benefit children from orphanages and disadvantaged groups. The circus will stage more than 200 paid performances around the island during a six-month period, it said.
Until Nov. 16, the circus will remain in Chungho, Taipei County, under a big top which can accommodate some 4,000 spectators. The price of admission ranges between NT$500 and NT$1,800.

The American Universal Circus, organized by British promoter Philip Sandey, is composed of some 80 performers including trapeze artists and acrobats from around the world. The animals include seven tigers from a circus in America, seven bears from the Moscow State Circus and four sea lions, as well as performing dogs, cats, horses and geese.

Sandey said in a press conference on Monday that the performers and animals are like a happy family, denying that the animals had been trained with cruel methods, such as the use of whips, as claimed by the local animal rights activists.

Hsu Po-yun, president of New Aspect, said that the introduction of the animals into Taiwan for the performances has obtained approval from the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, signaling that the international watchdog organization is confident of the organizer's ability to protect the animals.

Hsu said that the company has made every effort to protect the public's safety during the performances, adding that each spectator is insured against accidents in the amount of NT$500,000 and that each performer and staff member is insured for NT$2 million.

Legislator Chao Yung-ching said Monday that he would push for a ban on performances by the domesticated animals on the basis of an animal protection bill, which is currently under review in the Legislative Yuan. He indicated that he will also attempt to push through an amendment to the ROC Wildlife Protection Act, eliminating a clause that allows performances by wild animals in circuses.

Ling Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that animal performances under professional supervision are rarely prohibited anywhere in the world. Approval for the circus to tour Taiwan lies within the power of the Education Ministry, rather than his council, Lin said, adding that the COA will look into any allegations of abuse regarding the animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEEN ELIZABETH ATTENDS OPENING OF TAIWAN-INVESTED FIRM

TEXT.P: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain on Monday pressed a button to open a Taiwan-invested computer peripheral production facility in Scotland.

The plant, with six production lines, was invested by Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Tatung Co., which was the first Taiwan business group to invest in Britain, starting in the 1980s.
This was the first time that the British queen has attended Taiwan-related business activities, marking a new milestone in substantive relations between the Republic of China and Britain.

Queen Elizabeth said in her brief address that she was delighted to see the opening of the new plant, saying it indicates that Britain is an ideal investment destination in Europe for Taiwan investors.

The Chunghwa plant is expected to help revitalize the British economy, the queen said, adding she is convinced that the new jobs and opportunities offered by the facility will give Scottish residents more confidence in their future.
On behalf of the Glasgow community, Queen Elizabeth accepted a batch of computers donated by Chunghwa Picture to four elementary schools in the region and Glasgow University.
The British government is attaching great importance to the Chunghwa investment project as it will create the largest number of jobs ever by a foreign company in Scotland.
Scottish Secretary Donald Dewar, ROC Representative to Britain Eugene Chien, and more than 100 other European and Asian well-wishers also attended the inaugural ceremony.

Speaking on the occasion, Chunghwa President Lin Chen-yuan said the company has decided to set up the plant in Scotland mainly because the region is a stronghold of high-technology industries. In addition to the large cluster of computer companies in the region, Scotland also offers adequate supplies of skilled labor and trained professionals as well as other advantages.
Lin expressed his gratitude for the financial subsidies and other investment incentives offered by the British government.
Chunghwa unveiled its US$2.07 billion (1.26 billion British pound) investment plan in late 1995 and construction began in 1996. The first-phase construction was completed earlier this year.

The plant will manufacture computer monitors and cathode ray tubes. Initially, the facility will be able to produce 7.2 million units annually, with capacity increasing to 10 million units when construction is completed.

Tatung Co. Chairman Lin Ting-sheng also traveled from Taiwan to Scotland to attend the opening of the new Chunghwa plant. He said that following the opening of the Scotland factory, Chunghwa Picture Tubes will build a production facility in the United States in the near future.
Chunghwa already has production facilities in Taiwan's Taoyuan and Yangmei districts, mainland China's Fuzhou city and in Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS HOLD RECORD HIGH LEVELS OF NT DOLLARS

TEXT.P: Foreign nationals possessed a record high of 59.23 billion in deposits in New Taiwan dollar accounts at islandwide banking institutions in September, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Tuesday.
The figure represents an increase of NT$6.64 billion from August and accounted for 8.72 percent of September's total cash in circulation, according to the CBC.
Foreigners were allowed to hold bank accounts in local currency in Taiwan beginning in 1994.
New Taiwan dollar deposits possessed by overseas nationals totaled 31.36 billion in 1996, jumping from 21.17 billion in 1995 and 7.43 billion in 1994, CBC statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG'S DIPLOMATIC GUIDELINES TOWARD US TAKE POSITIVE TONE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's changes in the wording of Beijing's guidelines for its relationship with Washington underline the positive tone he hopes will take root at his first state visit to the United States this week, boosting relations between the two major powers.

Before the most recent changes, the diplomatic guidelines read that Beijing and Washington should aim at "increasing mutual trust, diminishing trouble, promoting cooperation, and preventing confrontations."

The principle of "increasing mutual trust and diminishing trouble" appeared first in a speech of Deng Xiaoping, the late paramount leader of mainland China, about the Beijing-Washington relationship after the Tienanmen Square massacre in 1989; Jiang added "promoting cooperation and preventing confrontations" several years later. The combination of the two formed Beijing's diplomatic guidelines toward Washington.

When Jiang met with Samuel R. Berger, assistant to the US President for National Security Affairs, on Aug. 13, however, he didn't repeat the above diplomatic principle but instead said the two sides should "expand common ground, enhance trust, diminish differences and join hands to create the future."

The differences in the wording are plain. Negative words such as "trouble" and "confrontations" have been replaced by positive terms like "trust" and "create the future." The final phrase is especially indicative that Jiang has long been preparing for his visit and is keeping his eye on long-term bilateral relations between Beijing and Washington.

The Jiang additions to the Deng diplomatic guidelines were published one month after Jiang was elected general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) at the 14th CCP National Congress; while the latest guidelines were officially promulgated one month after he was re-elected to the top CCP spot at the party's 15th National Congress.
This indicates that having won the internal power struggle and solidified his authority, Jiang can commit himself to promoting the development of foreign relations, especially with the United States.

Although both Washington and Beijing are hoping to improve their bilateral relationship, a number of factors are working against a large change for the better and so Jiang's achievements during his current US visit will probably be limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGNITY IS TOP CONCERN IN ARRANGING LEE'S M'LAND VISIT: SIEW

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui would make a "journey of peace" to mainland China only if such a visit could take place in a dignified manner, Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday.

Siew made the statement at a Legislative Yuan question-and-answer session. His remarks followed local press reports which quoted Tang Shubei, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) as saying that Taiwan's top leader is welcome to visit the mainland in an appropriate "capacity."

Siew said President Lee already declared in his inaugural speech that with the support of the 21 million people of Taiwan, he is willing to make a "journey of peace" to the mainland to forge rapprochement.

The premier, who once served as chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said the proposed "journey of peace" would be in national interests and win popular support only if it takes place in a dignified manner.
"So our stance is that whether President Lee would visit the mainland hinges on the way the journey would take place," Siew said, adding "dignity" is the top concern.

Siew, who had handshakes with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin when he twice represented President Lee in the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum during his stint as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Taiwan has consistently kept its door open for cross-strait talks.

It was Beijing that unilaterally suspended regular cross-strait dialogue in mid-1995, Siew noted, adding that the ROC government has repeatedly called for early resumption of cross-strait consultations. "We hope mainland China would make a positive response to our call and resume bilateral talks without imposing any preconditions. Although we hope to resolve some non-political administrative and technical issues first, we do not rule out the possibility of conducting political talks," he added.
Siew went on to say that the direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait would be possible only when the cross-strait relations are normalized.

"The greatest obstacle to the opening of direct cross-strait trad communications and transport links is Beijing resistance to recognize Taipei as an equal political entity," Siew stressed, adding that the country would make concessions on the "three links" issue simply for joining the World Trade Organization or for facilitating the development of Taiwan into a regional business hub.
Siew further said the government has been closely monitoring developments in the mainland president's current visit to the United States.

"Although the US government has repeatedly assured us that the upcoming summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and Jiang will not undermine our national interests, we are still paying close attention to the event," Siew noted, adding the ROC insists that Taipei-Washington relations run parallel to Beijing-Wanshington ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE PROMOTERS TO DEMONSTRATE IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Nine leaders of the Taiwan Independence Party (TIP) left for the United States Tuesday afternoon to stage demonstrations in Los Angeles and Washington on the occasion of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's state visit to the United States.

TIP Chairman Lee Chen-yuan said at a pre-departure news conference that Jiang is expected to reiterate Beijing's claim that "Taiwan is part of China" when he meets with President Bill Clinton Wednesday at the White House. And President Clinton has said that Taiwan issues should be resolved in peaceful ways by the Chinese on the two sides of the Taiwan Straits.
"But Taiwanese are not Chinese. Taiwan is Taiwan, and China is China. This is the position of the Taiwan Independence Party," Lee said at the press conference.

Lee said Taiwan's future and safety are very important to the Taiwanese people. Therefore, the nine TIP leaders want to stage demonstrations in the United States to make their ideas known to the American government and people, and to let Jiang know that he has no right to interfere with the self-determination of Taiwan people.
The nine TIP leaders will join with Taiwanese American sympathizers of Taiwan independence in demonstrations during Jiang's visits to the two cities this week.

One supporter of TIP chased and beat a photographer at the pre-departure press conference after the latter was found not a news reporter. The violence led to a brief confrontation with the police. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE BOURSE TUMBLES IN MORNING TRADING; CURRENCY DIPS SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Australia's stock market tumbled in morning trading, while its currency fell slightly against the US greenback, amid bearish sentiment as investors continued to dump shareholdings along with the local currency, analysts said.

They said the All Ordinaries Index plunged 188.8 points to 2288.2 in the first trading hour because many investors dumped shares. The Australian dollar fell to A$1 to 68.50 US cents, down from Monday's closing level of A$1 to 68.85 US cents.
"Many investors do not want to keep their shares and the market is getting jittery. The Australian currency is facing depreciation pressure," one analyst said.
Analysts believed the security and financial markets will continue to be chaotic as many investors are unsure when the crisis will end.
If selloffs continue in the next few days, the index could fall below the 2000 barrier and the Australian dollar could breach the US$0.65 mark, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE GOLD INDUSTRY UNDER THREAT AS SWITZERLAND SELLS RESERVES

TEXT.P: Australia's gold industry, the world's third biggest bullion producer and exporter, is under serious threat after Switzerland announced the sale of 1,440 tons of bullion reserves.
Analysts predicted that bullion prices could slump to as low as US$250 per ounce.
Australia produced about 300 tons of gold in fiscal 1996-97 and production is expected to rise to 330 tons before settling at a lower volume, analysts said.

Australia sells its gold to many countries, including Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore. Its gold industry, worth about A$4 billion a year, is braced for further sharp falls amid warnings of mine closures, a halt to exploration and a new round of merger activity, analysts said.
Gold prices plunged to US$308.05 per ounce in Asian trading on Monday due to speculation over the Swiss selloff, the lowest price level in more than 12 years.
In the Australian stock market, investors on Monday wiped A$1.3 billion off the market value of listed gold producers with the gold index diving 141.1 points or 11 percent to 1108.3.
Analysts said the Asian currency crisis meant the traditional support given to gold by Asian investors had vanished.

A Macquire Equities gold analyst in Sydney, Grant Craighead, said: "The next few days are critical to see if gold can hold its current support levels. We are moving into territory we have not seen for some time."
Another analyst said gold prices could plunge to as low as US$250 per ounce sometime next year if investors increasingly remain sidelined.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN COLUMNIST SUPPORTS TIBET'S INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Tibet should be an independent nation, but "political reality dictates otherwise," a Canadian analyst said Monday.

Beijing,, which does have some legitimate historical claim to Tibet, "will never voluntarily relinquish this highly strategic nation," observed Eric Margolic, foreign affairs analyst for the Sun newspapers in Canada.

Margolic, who has visited Tibet and met its spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, reported that 5 million of Tibet's 7 million people have been detached from their homeland and absorbed by neighboring mainland Chinese provinces. "Millions of Han Chinese settlers have been moved into Tibet, turning Tibetans into a minority in their own nation," he added.
Beijing sporadically tries to eradicate Tibetan culture and religion, he said. He emphasized, "While China condemns Israel in the UN for colonizing the West Bank, it colonizes Tibet."

Chinese rule has brought some benefits, a fact overlooked in the West, according to the analyst whose article appeared in the Monday edition of the Ottawa Sun. "China built roads, schools, power lines and hospitals; it ended illiteracy and serfdom," he pointed out.
However, with these benefits came "political and cultural repression, Red Guards and China's dreaded gulag system, the 'lao gai,'" he noted.

No Western nation dares incur Beijing's wrath by recognizing Tibet, and Tibetans themselves lack the necessary arms to oust Beijing by guerrilla warfare, he wrote. Besides, he continued, an independent Tibet would probably be gobbled up by India -- just as India annexed Bhutan, Goa, Sikkim and ethnic-Tibetan Ladakh without a peep of protest from the West.
What is the realistic course of action for the West? "The best we can do is keep pressing China to allow Tibet full political, cultural and religious autonomy and cease colonization," he suggested.

The exiled Dalai Lama says he will agree to such a solution, Margolic pointed out; "but Beijing fears him, and even a semi-free Tibet that might come under Indian influence." Uprisings in Muslim Xinjiang already make Beijing "nervous and truculent," he noted.

In conclusion, he said keeping up demands for Tibetan autonomy is a good fight. "Just don't allow Hollywood to hijack, commercialize and cheapen this issue," since there is no faster way to undermine and sully a just cause than making it the subject of brainless films, posturing politicians and vapid cocktail parties, he said.

He ridiculed Hollywood's "champagne liberals" for making Tibet "a highly fashionable cause" these days. Hollywood's Tibetan passion in making such films as "Seven Years in Tibet" is "a self-serving fad," he said. He reminded readers that Hollywood people, particularly actors, are "the great know-nothings of our age." "When one of them start talking about politics, economics or social policy, switch channels," he advised.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RATED 4TH FOR SOCIAL STABILITY IN ASIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been rated the fourth most socially stable economy among 12 countries and areas in Asia in 1997, said the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy (PERC).
In the findings of a survey devoted to social unrest in Asia, PERC said that Singapore was regarded by respondents as the most socially stable economy in Asia.
On a scale of zero to 10, Singapore was ranked top with a level of less than one, showing that it has the lowest degree of risk for social unrest among the 12 Asian economies surveyed.

Japan was second, with a level of marginally above one, followed by Hong Kong at 2.7. The ROC ranked fourth with a level of about 3.5 on the scale for 1997, showing a big improvement from last year's 4.5.
Next, in descending order, were Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, mainland China, Vietnam, India, South Korea and Indonesia, with a rating of 6.6.
PERC said that Singapore's performance in the recent Southeast Asian currency crisis had enhanced its reputation as a regional financial center.

Singapore has done its best to maintain a low profile and has avoided direct criticism of Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, a vocal critic of the alleged role of Western speculators in the recent crises, PERC said in the latest issue of its newsletter, Asian Intelligence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASMANIAN TIGERS PREY ON CATTLE

TEXT.P: Attacks by Tasmanian tigers preying on livestock of villagers in Obinaho district, Jayawijaya regency, are causing fear among the part of the population.
Obenaho district chief CB Imbiri was quoted by Indonesia's Antara news agency as saying in Wamena on Monday that the rare predators started attacking cattle in July 1997.
Imbiri said the attacks in September and October were mostly by the bigger and stronger males.
The villagers of Wambalfak, near the capital of the subdistrict, are frequently attacked by the Tasmanian tigers, and are increasingly afraid to go out into the fields, he said.

Villagers have tried to catch the huge cats alive to prove to the outside world that they still exist in the high forested plains of Jayawijaya. Tasmanian tigers are believed to have been extinct since 1930.
"We have not succeeded in catching them, because they are so fierce and highly alert to imminent threat," Imbiri said.
The villagers have spotted their hiding places in caves, dug holes and set up traps.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL COTTON INDUSTRY MEETING UNDER WAY IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: The 56th plenary meeting of the International Cotton Advisory Committee (ICAC) was held Monday in Asuncion, with about 400 participants from more than 30 countries.

Official delegations are made up of government representatives and advisors from the private sector. The delegation of the Republic of China is lead by Mr. Juhn C.C. Deng, the director of the Economic Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.
Deng said that the ICAC is an intergovernmental organization, the majority of whose members are cotton producers.

Although the ROC does not produce cotton, it is a major importer of the commodity. In order to keep abreast of current trends in the production and marketing of cotton, the ROC sent a seven-member delegation comprised of government officials and industry specialists to the ICAC meeting.
Discussion at the committee's plenary meeting will center on recent developments in supply of and demand for cotton, as well as industry trade patterns and price levels.

It was noted that, while cotton has maintained a strong share of the textile fiber market in the United States, it has declined in importance in Europe and the developing countries. On a global basis, cotton's share of that market has fallen from 50% in 1987 to 45% in 1995. Current forecasts suggest that the share will drop further to 43% in the next few years.

The ICAC was found in 1939 by 10 cotton-producing nations. Its first plenary meeting was held in Washington the following year. In the fifth meeting it was decided to invite importers of cotton to join the organization.

Currently, the ICAC has about 40 members. The ROC, under the name "China (Taiwan)," has been a member for about thirty years, although mainland China has recently expressed interest in joining, to the exclusion of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST ASIAN AEROSPACE FASTENER PLANT BORN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The first professional aerospace fasteners production facility in the Asia-Pacific region was born in Taiwan on Tuesday.
Taiwan's Royal Aerospace Industry Co. struck a technological cooperation deal with NAFCO of the United States for joint production of aerospace fasteners on the island.

The cooperative project, mediated by the Industrial Development Bureau and the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development under the Minsitry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), marks a critical step forward in the local private sector's participation in producing high value-added aerospace parts and components.
The agreement was signed by Royal Aerospace Chairman Huang Meng-chu and NAFCO Chief Executive Willy Robin at the MOEA auditorium, with Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming witnessing.

Under the agreement, NAFCO will transfer technological know-how for Royal Aeropsace to produce aircraft/spacecraft fasteners, including internally threaded fasteners, self-locking press in inserts, self-locking nut plates, collars and tube fittings.
Royal Aerospace has invested NT$200 million (US$6.57 million) in building the aerospace fasteners production facility.
Speaking on the occasion, Yin said fasteners are indispensable key components and parts in the aerospace industry. Their market prices are 50 times those for traditional screws and nuts.

"Once its products pass certification, the company will be able to receive orders incessantly," Yin said, adding that the Royal-NAFCO cooperative project marks the beginning of the local traditional screws/nuts industry moving toward high-technology and toward the international aerospace market.

Yin said the demand for aerospace fasteners in the booming Asia-Pacific region will increase substantially in the years ahead, with the annual sales expected to reach US$400 million to US$600 million.
In addition to setting its eye at the Asia-Pacific aerospace market, the Royal-NAFCO joint venture is also expected to become a major fastener supplier for the domestic high-speed railway system.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES BIGGER IMPACT IF SOUTHEAST ASIAN CRISIS SPREADS NORTH

TEXT.P: Australia, already hit by the financial and securities turmoil in Southeast Asia, is worried the current crisis will spread north -- to Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea -- as the majority of its exports go to this region.

Treasurer Peter Costello told reporters Monday that Australia's economy would be hit much harder if the current crisis affecting Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia spreads to Northeast Asia.
He said the impact from Northeast Asian on Australia's economy would be larger because the volume of its exports to that region is much larger than that to Southeast Asia.

Australia's exports to Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea exceeded A$29.2 billion in fiscal 1996-97. Exports to Japan were worth A$15.373 billion; to Korea, A$7.13 billion; to Taiwan, A$3.62 billion; and to Hong Kong, A$3.1 billion.
This comes in comparison to the combined export volume of A$8.55 billion to Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia during the same period.

Australia's exports to those four Southeast Asian countries account for about 10 percent of its total; but exports to the four Northeast Asian economies account for about 37 percent, according to official statistics.
Costello conceded that the impact upon Australia of the Southeast Asian economic crisis will worsen if the current turbulence in regional financial markets spreads to the northeast.

He said Australia, however, was insulated from the worst of the turmoil in the region by its domestic economic and budgetary reforms and by its relatively small dependence on trade with Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines, the four countries at the center of the Asian crisis.

"When growth turns down in those countries, that will have an effect on Australia, but it will not be a large effect on Australia because Australia's exports by destination into those areas is around 10 percent," he said.

"If other countries with whom we trade should get into difficulties, that too would affect Australia. If other countries in North Asia were affected, that would have another effect on Australia," he added.
In a speech in Melbourne last night, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer played down suggestions that Northeast Asia could be a victim of sentiment against the region's economic performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE REGISTERS HISTORIC DROP

TEXT.P: North America's financial markets were shut down Monday amid a panic-driven selloff that resulted in the biggest point losses in their history.
The New York Stock Exchange, the world's most important stock market, was shut down for the day at 3:30 p.m. EST after the Dow Jones industrial average lost 554.26 points to close at 7161.1.
That was the biggest daily point loss ever, surpassing the record set on Oct. 19, 1987 -- Black Monday.
In Canada, the Toronto Stock Exchange was shut down after losing 434.3 points, or 6.12 percent of its value, to close at 6599.2.
Both markets were ordered to take a 30-minute break earlier in the day. But the decline continued immediately after trading was resumed.
Most market experts said the dramatic drops went far beyond their expectations of the impact from turmoil in Asian markets, especially in Hong Kong.

Finance Minister Paul Martin of Canada called for calm during a parliamentary session, claiming Canada's finance is in extremely good shape and saying he is totally confident of the country's economic future.
In Washington, politicians made similar calls but still could not stop the market from entering a free fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR NOSE-DIVES TO TEN YEAR NADIR AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar shed 0.29 against the US dollar Tuesday, falling to 30.8 against the greenback, its lowest level in ten years and three months, with trade volume swelling to US$382 million.

With the plummet of global stock markets sparking huge demand here for the perceived safety of the US dollar and the mass exodus of capital from the Taiwan market, the local currency dropped to 30.95 before recovering some ground to close at 30.8. It might dip below the psychological mark of 31 on Wednesday, depending on what if any action the Central Bank of China takes, analysts said.
The NT dollar opened at 30.51 and was traded in a broad range between 30.51 and 30.95 in Tuesday's session.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS CAN BE TAMED THROUGH REGIONAL COOPERATION: ADB

TEXT.P: The AIDS epidemic which threatens Asian economic development can be tamed through regional cooperation and shared responsibilities, said a senior official of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on Tuesday.

"The AIDS epidemic is the enemy of Asian promise," ADB Vice President Peter Sullivan told delegates here at the fourth international congress on AIDS in the Asia-Pacific region. "It threatens in a material way the progress that Asia has made over the past several decades. It imposes huge economic costs on societies, families and individuals, and endangers the economic development of the countries of Asia that have so boldly introduced growth-enhancing economy-wide reforms."

Regional or multi-country approaches can be effective since there are similarities in the nature of the epidemic, he said, citing cultural and socioeconomic factors which facilitate the transmission of HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.

Widespread poverty, rapid population growth, increasing mass migration of labor and a thriving tourism industry will facilitate the rapid spread of HIV throughout the region, Sullivan said, noting that forecasts have said that by the turn of the century more new HIV-infections will occur in Asia than in the rest of the world combined.

He pointed out that the private sector can play a major role by providing care facilities, research and development initiatives, and financial and other types of contributions for anti-HIV/AIDS activities.

The ADB has been promoting economic cooperation in the control and prevention of HIV/AIDS in the greater Mekong subregion, which encompasses Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam and mainland China's Yunnan Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLEGATIONS OF MOLESTATION AT PRIMARY SCHOOL SHOCK TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taichung Prosecutors' Office has begun an investigation into allegations that a teacher, two guards and a janitor were involved in molesting students who attended the primary school where they worked.

Prosecutor Wu Tsuei-fan said that the molestation victims include nine girls and one boy, all from the same primary school in Taichung. To help protect the victims' identity, Wu refused to disclose the name of the school.

School counseling staff first notified authorities of their suspicions after learning in counseling sessions that some students might have been subject to sexual abuse at school. The follow-up investigation discovered 10 students may have been molested by school faculty and staff between 1995 and the end of 1996.

Wu said that most of the victims are from single-parent families or broken homes. They were usually taken to classrooms or remote places around the school on Wednesday afternoons, when the school didn't have regular classes, he said.
The children, some of them also victims of incest, would receive NT$10 to NT$200 (US$0.33 to US$6.56) after being molested or even raped, Wu said.

The four suspects were laid off following the allegations, he said, adding that the preliminary investigation points to the four committing their crimes individually rather than in concert with each other.
Wu said that efforts will be made to find out if there are any more people who should be charged or other victims in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEBY OF CHAD VISITS JOB TRAINING CENTER

TEXT.P: President Idriss Deby of the Republic of Chad said here Tuesday that he will send his countrymen to Taiwan to learn professional training systems in order to develop human resources in his country.
Deby made the remarks after he visited a job training center at Taichung, central Taiwan.

Accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason Hu and officials of the Council of Labor Affairs, Deby watched students learning how to operate or repair air conditioning equipment, electronics appliances, milling machines, and other kinds of machinery at the training center.

Hu said the Republic of China government, which has sent a medical team to Chad, plans to send an agriculture promotional team to that country to help enhance the friendly relations between the two countries.

Deby arrived here Sunday for a five-day state visit at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui. Other officials accompanying President Deby on the visit include Mahamat Saleh Annadif, minister of foreign affairs and cooperation, and Biehara Cherif Daoussa, minister of finance, economy, planning and territory development. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: BOT MODEL GOOD FOR PROMOTING DIPLOMACY: HU

TEXT.P: The build-operate-transfer (BOT) model now popular in the business sector could also be used in promoting the Republic of China's international relations, Jason Hu, new minister of Foreign Affairs, said Tuesday.
Hu made the remarks when he accompanied Chad President Idriss Deby on a visit to a farm in Taichung, central Taiwan. The African leader arrived here Sunday for a five-day visit.

Under the BOT model, private enterprises build and operate a project and then transfer it to the government after a specified period of time. The most recent example is the first high speed rail in Taiwan to be built by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Consortium.

Past setbacks in the ROC's attempts to develop relations with African nations led Taipei to exert relatively little effort in the region for nearly a decade, resulting in many nations in that continent lacking an understanding of the ROC, Hu said.
But when African nations understand Taiwan better, they will know that the ROC is a trustworthy friend, he said.

Hu said that now is the time to rethink foreign policy, adding that if Taiwan gets its friends to understand that bilateral relations will cover more than just one area then the relations could turn out to be more lasting.

Hu said that bilateral relations should be grounded on mutually beneficial cooperation. Citing the BOT model practiced on major public works, he said this same model could apply to diplomatic efforts.

Noting that many countries need help with their basic construction works, he said that if Taiwan could help them with these then this would not only help forge more lasting relations between the ROC and those countries but also help increase their understanding of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said at a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday that the current focus of diplomatic efforts is wider than soliciting more countries to establish formal ties with the ROC.

Chen said that for the survival and development of the 21 million people on the island, the government will also have to develop substantial ties with those nations that currently do not maintain official relations with the ROC.
Chen noted that in addition to having diplomatic ties with 30 countries, the ROC is also actively promoting substantial relations with over 140 additional nations.

He said that the government will also actively participate in international activities and organizations, adding that the ROC currently participates in 42 international organizations and over 930 non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC SUMMIT TO STRESS STRENGTH OF APEC ECONOMIES

TEXT.P: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leaders are expected to make a strong statement on the positive long-term growth prospects of Asia-Pacific economies at their annual summit next month to help restore financial stability to the region and revive investor confidence, said a senior APEC official Monday.

Leonard Edwards, chairman of the APEC Senior Officials' Meeting which opened in Singapore on Monday, said the economic fundamentals of Asian countries remain strong and that APEC economies are on track in their trade liberalization goals.
The two-day APEC meeting was held to prepare for the Fifth APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting, to be held in Vancouver, Canada next month.

Commenting on the regional financial crisis and trade liberalization, Edwards said: "The message that we are getting is one of continuing interest in liberalization. Canada's view is that liberalization can strengthen economies and help them withstand the buffeting that they have faced in the last few months.
"More open economies with better supervision and a freer flow of goods and services create a sounder basis from which economies can go forward."
The APEC leaders' note of confidence in the Asia-Pacific region would be reflected in their declaration winding up the summit meeting on November 25, Edwards said.
The turmoil following the collapse of the Thai baht in early July has sent regional stock markets and currencies reeling.
The rout has even dented sentiments in Europe and the United States.
Ambassador John Wolf, the US coordinator of APEC affairs, said APEC members have been showing "a lot of vitality" in bringing down trade barriers and making headway in many sectors.

Edwards said leaders would also pledge their commitment at the Vancouver meeting for "a continuing strong momentum on investment and trade liberalization and give a strong endorsement on the need for infrastructure development."
He underscored the importance of infrastructure development and said it is vital to economic growth and opening up markets.
Canada also wants to see greater private-sector involvement in the APEC process, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SIGN INDUSTRIAL ALLIANCE PACT WITH MERCK AG

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is slated to sign a letter of intent with Germany's Merck AG on Wednesday forming a strategic industrial alliance.
Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and Merck Chairman Hans J. Langmann will jointly ink the pact at the ministry.
Under the agreement, both sides will first cooperate on chemical and display technologies and eventually jointly explore Asia-Pacific markets.

The pact will be the 50th of its kind since the MOEA embarked on a mission in 1993 to form strategic alliances with foreign enterprises. It will also be the sixth signed between Taiwan and a German firm, said MOEA officials.
Merck is a world-renowned multinational enterprise which produces precision chemicals, electronic chemicals, laboratory reagents and biochemicals.

Merck maintains 28 production centers around the world and 166 sales footholds in 47 countries. Having 27,000 employees worldwide on its payroll, the company posted a business turnover of nearly US$4.2 billion last year.
The German chemicals giant first stepped into the Taiwan market in 1972. Since 1991, it has expanded into joint ventures with Taiwan firms to produce electronics-related chemicals here.

Merck has invested about NT$1.8 billion (US$60 million) in its Taiwan joint-venture firms, including Merck Taiwan, which produces lab reagents, detergents and biochemicals; Merck Display Technology, which makes liquid crystals and ITO coatings; and Merck-Kanto, which turns out process and integrated chemicals.
The cooperation projects under the 49 strategic industrial and business alliances the MOEA signed prior to the Merck deal total US$4.1 billion.

Among the investments covered by these agreements are the US$1.7 billion Germany's Siemens has put into the production of 256M memory, and the US$330 million Philips of the Netherlands has committed to production of high-definition color displays.
In addition, MOEA officials noted, 23 multinational corporations, including Texas Instrument and Dupont, have established their Asia-Pacific operations centers in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST JIANG-CLINTON SUMMIT ERA RIGHT TIME TO IMPROVE TIES WITH US: HU

TEXT.P: Relations between mainland China and the United States are expected to become closer in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit, which will simultaneously offer a golden opportunity for Taipei to improve its ties with Washington, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.

Hu said that while improving ties with mainland China, Washington should improve its relations with Taiwan on a parallel track. "Otherwise, when the balance of power across the Taiwan Strait favors one side over the other, the peace and stability that both the US and Taiwan have tried hard to secure in the region will be seriously impeded," he noted.

While Washington and Beijing are engaging in fence-mending, Taipei should further boost its diplomatic efforts toward America, seeking stronger support from the US people and increasing their understanding of Taiwan, Hu stressed.

Echoing remarks made two days ago by Premier Vincent Siew that the United States should integrate Taiwan into a US-inspired regional peace system, Hu said he does not see any reason for the US and Taiwan not to cooperate, since the two states share a common national founding spirit and identical goals for the region.
He also said he does not exclude the possibility of President Lee Teng-hui making a "journey of peace" to mainland China when the time is ripe for such a visit.
Hu's remarks came during a luncheon in the central city of Taichung in honor of President Idriss Deby of the Republic of Chad, who is currently in Taiwan for a five-day state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC APPROVES US$1.09 BILLION INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's per-project investment in mainland China has been reduced in recent months due to brakes applied by the ROC government, although the total number of investments has surged, according to statistics prepared by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

In the first three-quarters of this year, the ministry has approved 441 investment projects in the mainland, an increase of 54.7 percent over the same period of last year, with an increase in value of only 14.3 percent, for a total of US$1.09 billion.
An amnesty for firms investing in the mainland without government approval is also responsible for the sudden jump in the number of projects, said the MOEA.

Since the amnesty ended on Sept. 30, the 75 new projects in September alone was 3.69 times greater than the same period of last year, while the monetary value, at US$161 million, was 2.5 times greater.

The five mainland coastal provinces of Jiangsu, Gwangdong, Zhejiang, Hebei and Fujian are Taiwan investors' favorite locations, grabbing a joint share of 89.2 percent of Taiwan's total investment, 58.99 percent of which went into electronics\electrical appliances, non-metal manufactured products, basic metals and related products, textiles and comestibles.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN GEM POLISHERS EXPLOITING CHILDREN

TEXT.P: More and more children are working for low pay cutting and polishing precious stones in western India, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday.

"Diamonds, rubies and sapphires are associated with the world of the rich and glamorous," Bill Jordan, Secretary General of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU), was quoted as saying.
"Multinational and local companies are making vast profits, but at best they turn a blind eye and at worst they are happy to reap the benefits (from the exploitation of children)."

The WTO report said India is the world's diamond- and gemstone-cutting center, polishing about 70 percent of the global diamond yield. Yet the workers often receive poverty wages and work in conditions that leave them with lung disease and half-blind.

An estimated 10 to 20 percent of the 800,000 people in India engaged in diamond cutting and polishing are children. Trade unionists say employers prefer children since they are easier to exploit and much cheaper. Wages average just 1 percent of the wholesale price of each diamond.

Although the gem and jewelry industry currently provides 17 percent of its export earnings, India does not mine the diamonds and gemstones polished there. Its main supplier of diamonds is the Rio Tinto-controlled Argyle mine in western Australia, followed by the Central Selling Organization, the marketing arm of De Beers, based in London, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE, DEBY EXCHANGE CITATIONS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui and his Chad counterpart Idriss Deby on Tuesday exchanged citations, in a move symbolizing solid and long-lasting friendship between the Republic of China and the Republic of Chad.

Lee conferred the Order of Brilliant Jade with Grand Cordon on Deby in recognition of his outstanding contribution to enhanced bilateral ties, while Deby decorated Lee with the Grand Cross Medal, Chad's ultimate symbol of respect.

The conferment ceremony was held at the Presidential Office on Tuesday evening, witnessed by Vice President Lien Chan, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, his Chad counterpart Mahamat Saleh Annadif and other ranking officials from both sides.

After the ceremony, both heads of state expressed the sentiment that the conferment was not directed only toward the two of them, but also to their two countries. Both men vowed to further strengthen cooperative bilateral ties.

Lee said Deby's visit is particularly significant since the two countries resumed formal diplomatic relations just two months ago after a 25-year hiatus. The two governments maintained cordial and close ties between 1962 and 1972.

On Monday, Deby said in a welcoming ceremony in his honor that many Chad people still remember the competence and down-to-earth working style of ROC agricultural experts stationed in his country in the 1960s and are grateful for their legacy.
Maintaining close ties in the fields of agriculture and medical care, the two countries should further bolster relations in many other fields on a basis of reciprocity and mutual trust, Lee stressed.
Deby, accompanied by a 16-member entourage, arrived in Taiwan on Sunday for a five-day state visit, his first visit to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT HONG KONG: LIEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not Hong Kong, and the "one country, two systems" formula Beijing applies to Hong Kong is totally unsuitable for Taiwan, Vice President Lien Chan told a French weekly magazine recently.

In the Oct. 27 issue of Marianne, Lien told French readers that unlike Hong Kong, which was formerly a British colony, Taiwan is the seat of the Republic of China, a sovereign nation and Asia's first republic, founded in 1911.

Taiwan firmly opposes Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, which apparently ignores the ROC's existence and negates the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are two distinct political entities separated by the Taiwan Strait, Lien stressed.
The magazine devoted five full pages of its latest issue to a report on Taiwan, filed by Sylvie Levey, who interviewed Lien in person at his office on Aug. 5.
The report was accompanied by a photo of Lien bearing the caption: "Vice president of democratic China," together with the national flags of the ROC and the PRC.

Responding to a question from Levey on Taiwan's position when the Chinese communists become capable of launching a military attack on Taiwan, Lien said that the ROC armed forces are currently working on a buildup of second-generation military equipment and that the island's overall combat readiness has already been significantly bolstered, adding that Taiwan will counter without hesitation any military assault from across the Taiwan Strait.

In the article, Levey pointed out that the ROC capital, Taipei, is one of the most important financial hubs in Southeast Asia today and that Taiwan's per capita income is 26 times that of mainland China.
She also wrote that Taiwan categorically rejects any attempt at "peaceful reunification" of mainland China and Taiwan on terms set by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN FIRMS INVESTING IN BRITAIN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based ADI electronics firm is to open a plant in northeast England, its first in Europe, sources in Britain's Ministry of Trade and Industry said on Tuesday.
The new factory of ADI, the seventh-largest computer monitor producer in the world, is expected to create about 600 jobs for Britain, according to the sources.
ADI, which employs about 3,000 people in its facilities in Taiwan, mainland China and Thailand, posts annual sales of US$1 billion, with the European market absorbing half of its production volume.

Meanwhile, the sources said another Taiwan computer giant, Acer Sertec Inc., is to open a plant in Wales to manufacture computer-related products. The new project is expected to provide more than 1,000 jobs for local workers.

The two new facilities will be the second and third owned by Taiwan electronics firms who have ventured into Britain, following the opening on Monday of a production facility in the Scottish city of Glasgow by Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND INVESTMENT HITS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Approved inbound investment hit a new high of US$3.23 billion in the first nine months of this year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Wednesday.
The ministry said the record-setting amount indicates that Taiwan's general investment climate and the liberalization of its trade regime have won much recognition in the global business community.
The amount marked a 96.72 percent increase over that registered in the same period of last year, and even exceeded the inbound investment recorded for the whole of 1995.
The number of approved inbound investment projects for the nine-month period reached 489, up 42.15 percent from the year-earlier level.
With the overall investment amount growing faster than the number of investment projects, ministry officials said, the scale of foreign investment in Taiwan has gradually enlarged.

The officials further said foreign and overseas Chinese entrepreneurs still focused their investment in electronics, electric appliances and metal industries as well as service, insurance and international trading businesses, accounting for more than 70 percent of overall inbound investment for the January-September period.
In September alone, approved inbound investment amounted to US$272 million, in 74 projects, including three large investment plans filed by American and Japanese business groups.

Ministry tallies also showed that the MOEA's Investment Commission approved 517 outbound investment projects, with an accumulated amount of US$2.22 billion, during the first three quarters of this year.

The outbound investment amount marked a 48 percent year-on-year rise, while the number of projects increased 46.5 percent, indicating local business people have remained active in launching overseas ventures.
Overseas investment focused on setting up holding companies and investing in electronics and electric appliance industries as well as trading and transport services.
Major investment destinations included the Virgin Islands, United States, Singapore, Panama and Hong Kong, accounting for 78 percent of approved overall outbound investment.

In September, monthly outbound investment totaled US$289 million, up 85.3 percent from the same month of last year; while the number of approved projects more than doubled the year-earlier figure to 68.

Major outbound investment projects during the month included a US$65.3 million plan filed by Far Eastern Warehousing Co. for setting up a warehousing facility in Panama and a US$50 million project filed by CIS Technology for producing microcomputers and related products in the United States.

Meanwhile, MOEA officials said, Taiwan's per-project investment in mainland China has declined in recent months due to brakes applied by the ROC government, although the total number of cross-strait investment projects has surged.

In the first three quarters of the year, the MOEA approved 441 investment projects on the mainland, an increase of 54.7 percent over the same period of last year, with an increase in value of only 14.3 percent, for a total of US$1.09 billion.
An amnesty for firms investing on the mainland without government approval is also responsible for the sudden jump in the number of projects, the officials said. The amnesty ended on Sept. 30.

The 75 new investment projects approved in September alone was 3.69 times greater than the same month of last year, while the monetary value, at US$161 million, was 2.5 times greater, indicating that the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland China has not completely discouraged local business people from launching new ventures across the Taiwan Strait.
