DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE DELEGATION SCORES MILLIONS WORTH OF BUSINESS IN LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade-promotion delegation scored millions of US dollars worth of business in Latin America during a recent visit to several spots in the region, the China External Trade Development Council (CEPD) said on Tuesday.

The "1997 Latin American Trade Promotion Delegation," composed of 24 local manufacturers of different sectors, scored more than US$10 million worth of in-site and follow-up business in Puerto Rico, Venezuela, Peru and Brazil during its stay from Oct. 4-25 in those places, according to the semi-official trade organization.

The trade-promotion delegation, the first of its kind ever to visit Puerto Rico, was warmly received there and, along with local executives, attended a trade seminar presided over by Puerto Rican Economics Minister Carlos Vivoni, the CEPD said.

The delegation's visit to Venezuela and Peru also drew warm responses from the local business communities because of the improved economic situation there. While in Venezuela, the delegation reached agreement on several issues of bilateral trade cooperation with its local counterparts.

The CEPD, however, pointed out that the group's efforts to explore the Brazilian market were less successful, as the country is troubled by high inflationary pressure as a result of its overheated economy. It urged Taiwan's manufacturers of computers, telecommunications equipment and car accessories to explore the vast Brazilian market, as it is rife with potential business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOWS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING MONTREAL PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to support the Montreal Protocol's phasing-out agenda for ozone-threatening gases, including chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said Wednesday.

Taiwan also vows to help terminate the use of the pesticide methyl bromide, widely used by strawberry and tomato growers and one of two compounds that slipped through the 1987 Montreal Protocol phasing out Freon and other CFCs, IDB officials noted.

CFCs, used in refrigerators, air conditioners and aerosol cans, are believed to have depleted the protective ozone molecules in the earth's upper atmosphere, allowing in harmful ultraviolet radiation that can result in illnesses and damage fishing and agriculture.
Delegates from 167 nations which were signatories of the Montreal Protocol met last month in Montreal to mark the 10th anniversary of the breakthrough treaty on global warming.

During the meeting, the participants agreed that significant progress had been made worldwide during the last decade to protect the ozone layer. But controversy over the threat posed to the ozone layer by methyl bromide has been growing.
The participants also agreed to allow more time for the use of asthma aerosol cans as there is yet no substitute for this form of the medicine.

Diminishing the use of CFCs and methyl bromide in Taiwan would have no major impact on the domestic industrial sector since the island imports all its methyl bromide, while only the Formosa Plastics Group, which produces HCFC-22 in its Kaohsiung plants, would be slightly affected, IDB officials said.
Under the IDB's programs, new imports of ozone-depleting substances will be effectively controlled and exports of such domestically-produced substances will also be managed, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE WOULD BRING IMMEDIATE DISASTER: MAC

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), remarked in the Legislative Yuan plenary session on Tuesday that Taiwan independence would bring immediate disaster to all the people on the island.
Premier Vincent Siew echoed Chang's view.

Responding to a suggestion by Yeh Chu-lan, a lawmaker with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), that the island declare itself "the Republic of Taiwan," Chang called this "impossible" and said it would bring "immediate disaster" upon Taiwan. Although mainland China joined the United Nations in 1971, Chang continued, the Republic of China still exists in the international community, and Taipei is furthermore addressing the improvement of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chang also pointed out that the consensus on the nation's direction painstakingly reached at the National Development Conference by the ruling party and the DPP can be an asset, both in dealing with pressure and challenges from Beijing and in engaging the international community.

Taipei would like to establish a "step-by-step but without time schedule" relationship with Beijing based on mutual interests, Chang noted, adding that as the systems and ways of life on the two sides become closer, cross-strait peace and stability should improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD ALLIANCE TO SAVE SPOONBILLS TO BE ESTABLISHED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) and the University of California at Berkeley will inaugurate in Taipei on Oct. 31 their international alliance to save the blackfaced spoonbill and its habitat.
Wildlife conservationists estimated in 1995 that there were only about 400 blackfaced spoonbills left worldwide.

Some 300 of these birds migrate every winter from the north to the wetland at the mouth of Tsengwen Creek in Chiku Village, Tainan, southern Taiwan, making the place the major habitat of the endangered species on the globe.

Dr. Yuan T. Lee, president of the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, will be honorary convenor of the alliance, while NTU professors Hsia Chu-jeou, Wu You-hua, Lo Shang-lian and Liu Hsiao-ju will join officials from Berkeley's SAVE (Spoonbill Action Voluntary Echo) as co-founders.

According to Hsia, an establishment gala will be held Oct. 31 at the gate of NTU, highlighted by a simultaneous video conference between the two universities depicting concerted efforts on behalf of the spoonbill and calling for suspension of the development of the Pingnan Industrial Zone near the Chiku wetland.
As of Oct. 23, more than 100 blackfaced spoonbills had reached the Chiku wetland for their winter stay.
Hsia noted that large numbers of other migratory birds, including many endangered species, begin arriving in late September every year at Tsengwen Creek, where they remain until March or April.

To better understand the behavioral patterns and natural habitat of the blackfaced spoonbill, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has cooperated with Japanese ornithological societies in using transmitters to trace their movements.
COA officials said they have been able to pinpoint the whereabouts of the usually elusive birds with the help of the attached transmitters.
The government will also allocate money in the next fiscal year to establish a blackfaced spoonbill sanctuary near Chiku, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHAD AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: Chad's new ambassador to the Republic of China, Salim Abderaman Taha, presented his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui at the Presidential Office on Wednesday.
Lee extended a warm welcome to Taha, saying he hopes Taha's stint in Taipei will prove to be pleasant and fruitful.
The president said the ROC and Chad should intensify exchanges in various fields now that the two countries have resumed diplomatic relations after a 25-year hiatus.

Chad's president, Idriss Deby, is currently on a five-day state visit to the ROC. "Your president told me that he hopes a special task force will be formed to monitor and evaluate our various cooperative projects," Lee said, adding that Deby's suggestion indicates that he attaches great importance to ROC-Chad relations.
Lee also reaffirmed the ROC's commitment to assisting Chad in its economic development.
For his part, Taha said he feels honored to become Chad's first ambassador to the ROC since the two countries resumed full diplomatic ties in August this year.
Taha further said the people of Chad are also satisfied with the resumption of official ties with the ROC and look forward to seeing closer cooperation between the two countries.

"I'll dedicate myself to promoting exchanges and cooperation between our two countries," Taha said, adding that he expects support from President Lee and the ROC government to ensure that his work proceeds smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING ISRAELI ENVOY CITED

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday presented a medal to Gad Modai, outgoing Israeli representative to the Republic of China, in recognition of his contribution to promoting economic cooperation between Israel and the ROC.
Wang said at the presentation ceremony that Modai has made strenuous efforts to boost trade between Taiwan and Israel since he assumed office in July 1994.

Through Modai's efforts, ROC-Israeli trade has grown substantially in the past few years and the two countries have managed to hold vice ministerial-level conferences annually to review bilateral trade ties and discuss cooperative projects in aerospace, communications, electronics and biotechnology industries, Wang said.
During Modai's tenure, Wang said, the ROC and Israel have signed many cooperative agreements.

In addition, Wang said, Modai had helped arrange for former Vice Economics Minister Lee Shu-jeou to visit Israel twice. A 70-member delegation, composed of senior executives from major Taiwan business groups, accompanied Lee on his second visit to Israel, during which time several Taiwan companies managed to form strategic alliances to jointly tap the Asia-Pacific market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAY ASSIST IN REPAIR OF ASUNCION INT'L AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By L.K. Sheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Leila Rachid Lichi told local media Tuesday that the Republic of China will soon send a team of experts to here to inspect the Asuncion International Airport.

Rachid said that during her visit to Taiwan Oct. 14-19, ROC President Lee Teng-hui told her that Taiwan would send a team of experts in two or three weeks to Paraguay to decide whether to supply US$40 million toward the repair and maintenance of the airport.
The team will decide whether the aid would be in the form of loans or donations after the inspection tour, she said.

Paraguayan Defense Minister Hugo Estigarribia Elizeche announced in early October that repair and maintenance on the airport could wait no longer. As the government cannot spare the needed US$40 million, it would ask the ROC for assistance, he said.
Liu Ting-tzu, ROC ambassador to Paraguay, has already conveyed the request to the ROC government.

Estigarribia said the airport is barely usable right now and that if repair work doesn't begin immediately, international civil aviation safety authorities may order its closure, given that it would have to bear additional air traffic if a US airline goes through with its plan to begin flights to the Paraguayan capital at the end of the year.
The airport, about 16 kilometers from downtown Asuncion, was built 30 years ago. Its sewage system and runways are in poor condition, and its radar is out of order.
Safety experts warned Paraguay four years ago to begin repair work immediately.
Local civil aviation officials also said that if repairs don't begin soon, then the airport's condition could endanger the some 800 passengers daily and residents in the surrounding area.
Paraguay's executive branch did not include a request for airport repair and maintenance in its most recent budget proposal submitted to the congress.
A new radar system and communications equipment, as well as runway and terminal maintenance, will cost an estimated US$60 million. Paraguay might also ask Spain for assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGES IN JIANG'S US VISIT SCHEDULE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Chang Lung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: There has been no change in the schedule of the current state visit of Jiang Zemin, president of mainland China, to the United States, said Tang Guoqiang, spokesman of mainland China's Foreign Affairs Ministry, on Tuesday.
Tang made the remark in response to a report that Jiang's US sojourn, scheduled to last from Oct. 26 until Nov. 2, would be extended by one day.
Jiang will follow the original schedule and fly back home Nov. 2 after his visit to Los Angeles, his last stop in the United States, Tang stressed.
However, Tang did not disclose the exact time of Jiang's landing in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU SAYS US WILL NOT FORCE TAIWAN TO NEGOTIATE WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Wednesday that although the United States hopes to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait enter negotiations, it will not intervene, nor will it try to force the ROC to negotiate with the mainland.

Hu made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan in which Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh voiced concern that the US may force Taiwan to negotiate with mainland China after the current meeting between mainland President Jiang Zemin and US President Bill Clinton.

He noted that both Beijing and Washington want to extract something from the Clinton-Jiang meeting. Jiang wants to solidify and strengthen his leadership stature from his US trip, while Clinton hopes to reap some substantial gains, but neither side has pinned much hope on any substantial improvement in bilateral relations.

Hu said that if relations between the US and the mainland continue to improve, Taiwan-US relations will be the first to be affected, which is why Taiwan has repeatedly emphasized to the US that if it improves relations with the mainland, it is time to also upgrade its relations with the ROC, adding that Washington-Beijing relations should run parallel to Washington-Taipei ties.

But he said the effect of improved Washington-Beijing relations -- whether it will tempt Beijing to adopt a tougher or more moderate stance toward Taipei, or whether the emergent power of the mainland will prompt it to step up its campaign to isolate Taiwan internationally -- remains to be seen.

However, he also said that the meeting is not expected to result in a substantial improved Washington-Beijing relationship, because the differences between the two sides are far greater than the points on which they agree.

He said the ROC has yet to see anything likely to undermine ROC interests in the Clinton-Jiang meeting, and that the ROC will continue its communications with the US in every respect, from the Congress to the Executive branch, the academic as well the private sector, so that the ROC will have other mechanisms in place to prevent the US executive branch from endangering the ROC's interests.

Hu also said that the US will continue its policy of helping Taiwan to join international organizations, adding that the US has expressed support for Taiwan's entry to some organizations it is considering joining. He didn't elaborate.

The foreign minister said that Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, will come to Taiwan right after the Clinton-Jiang meeting, his first visit to the ROC since assuming the AIT chairmanship earlier this year, when he will answer concerns regarding Taipei-Washington relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DIRECTS OFFICIALS TO STUDY MEASURES TO STABILIZE FINANCIAL MARKET

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday that the government has taken appropriate action to deal with the recent fluctuation in Taiwan stocks and currency, but he also urged officials to make further studies of measures to stabilize the financial market.

The plunge of the Taiwan stock exchange on Tuesday, in which the weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell over 400 points, became the focus of heated debate in the regular Kuomintang Central Standing Committee meeting on Wednesday.

C.F. Koo, a business tycoon and KMT standing committee member, appealed in the meeting for the government to pay close attention to the storm in the local bourse, but to respect the market mechanism when handling fluctuations in the stock market.

Wang You-cheng, another KMT standing committee member and chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, said that the government has persuaded business leaders to intervene in the stock market to prop up share prices, but that in the longer term, it should use the stock stabilization fund to solve the stock crisis.

Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng categorically denied reports that his ministry is considering cutting the stock transaction tax in order to salvage the sluggish stock prices, stressing that the ministry has never considered such a proposal.

He was responding to reports that due to the consecutive daily slide of the Taiwan stock market, the government will consider cutting the stock transaction tax for those who hold on to their stocks for a long period of time.

He also denied rumors that the stock stabilization fund, which was set up early last year when mainland China carried out missile tests in waters near Taiwan in the runup to Taiwan's presidential election, had been used to intervene in the stock market, adding that the fund is only a temporary measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SAYS CROSS-STRAIT TRADE SHOULD BE MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$10.4 billion with mainland China in the first eight months of this year, making the mainland Taiwan's largest source of trade surplus, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday.
MOEA statistics show that Taiwan exports to mainland China in the first eight months of the year grew by 6.3 percent, up 3.1 percent from the same period of last year.

Chang Yao-tsung, director general of the Statistics Department under the MOEA, said trade activities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be mutually beneficial, as trade dependence on each other has greatly increased. Political and economic uncertainties in mainland China will also hurt Taiwan's economy, he noted, adding that the two sides should cooperate positively.

While briefing Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Taiwan's recent economic situation, Chang said the recent plummet of the local bourse is a consequence of both the worldwide financial turmoil originating in Southeast Asia and the lack of investor confidence, which totally contradicts Taiwan's brilliant economic performance.

According to Wang, Taiwan's industrial production has posted increases for the last fifteen consecutive months. The average industrial production index in the first three quarters of the year was up 6.6 percent from the same period of the previous year. During the same period, the manufacturing sector enjoyed a 7.7 percent growth rate, faster than the average for the past five years.

In addition, exports set a record single-month high of US$10.8 billion in September, up 10.7 percent from the corresponding month in 1996, with foreign orders worth nearly the same amount, also a record high, placed with Taiwan manufacturers in September.

Chang forecast that Taiwan's exports of high-tech products to Southeast Asian countries may expand in the months ahead, while more traditional exports may be affected by the recent depreciation of currencies in Southeast Asian nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENDING TAIWAN A US OBLIGATION: WEINBERGER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Victor Lai & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Minister Casper Weinberger said in an interview on Wednesday with Japan's Mainichi Shimbun that it is the moral obligation of the US to defend Taiwan, although he said he is worried about the Beijing's trend towards offensive military development.

Asked about relations between Beijing and Taipei, Weinberger was quoted as saying that Beijing's leaders should be made to understand that if mainland China attacks Taiwan, it will be confronted with a decisive defense, and that under the terms of its obligation to defend Taiwan, the US will take strong action in support of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY SAYS OFFICIALS ROUTINELY USE TORTURE IN TIBET

TEXT.P: A study completed by the Boston-based Physicians for Human Rights shows that communist Chinese authorities continue to routinely use torture as a means of political repression, punishment and intimidation in Tibet.

Allen Keller, a professor at New York University School of Medicine and a member of the International Advisory Board of Physicians for Human Rights, revealed the findings of the study Tuesday when he testified at a hearing before the House Subcommittee on International Organizations and Human Rights.
The new study substantiated the finding of a similar study by the organization in 1989 that under communist Chinese rule, torture of Tibetan political prisoners was routine.

The 1997 study includes a survey of 258 Tibetan refugees and extensive medical examinations of those Tibetans who indicated that they had been tortured. It was found that detainees in Tibet are subject to repeated episodes and multiple forms of torture.

Commonly reported forms of torture include beatings, electrical shocks, being suspended or restrained in painful positions, witnessing others being tortured, burned with cigarettes or other hot objects, exposure to extreme temperatures, being forced to stare at the sun, sleep deprivation, mock execution, and having blood drawn against the individual's will.

Keller said Physicians for Human Rights cannot say whether the Clinton administration's "constructive engagement" policy toward Beijing is the reason for the poor human rights situation in Tibet but that the organization certainly joins other human rights group in observing that the policy does not appear to be working.

"PHR strongly urges the administration to reestablish human rights linkage to those things that China most desires: a state visit by the president of the United States, permission to import high technology American goods and admittance into the World Trade Organization," he said.
Keller urged Beijing to take the following actions:
-- End the vilification campaign against the Dalai Lama and the abuses associated with it, including political re-education at monasteries and other means of control; and
-- Release all those detained as prisoners of conscience. (Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG SNUBBED BY VIRGINIA'S GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin was snubbed Tuesday by Virginia's governor, George Allen, who backed out of a formal luncheon in Jiang's honor and, instead, sent his wife to deliver a pointed statement reminding the mainland leader of the "universal human principles" of freedom, liberty and representative democracy.
Allen, who just returned from a visit to Taiwan on Oct. 11-13, was originally to host the luncheon in Williamsburg, a replica of pre-revolutionary America, before Jiang's state visit to Washington.

Instead, a spokesman told CNA, Allen decided Friday to accept an invitation to campaign for the Republican candidate for governor, Jim Gilmore, who is leading his Democratic opponent, Don Beyer, in the Nov. 4 election by a comfortable margin of seven percentage points according to a recent opinion poll.

The governor said in a statement read by his wife, "Virginia is the birthplace of American freedom -- where the seeds of individual liberty, self-government and free enterprise were planted, took root and have yielded an abundant harvest -- one of the most uplifting and successful influences in the history of mankind."

Noting that Thomas Jefferson, the second governor of Virginia, was the author of the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom and the Declaration of Independence, Allen said that Virginia is proud that one of its sons wrote words that are "universal" in their meaning for all people declaring that "all men are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable rights ... of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness" and that governments "derive their just powers from the consent of the governed."

The governor said that Williamsburg offers a unique insight into America's courageous and spirited beginning in Virginia. "May this treasured setting provide you with a greater understanding of, and appreciation for, the universal human principles upon which America is built -- freedom ..., liberty ... and representative democracy."

Allen's repeated emphasis on the word "universal" is an apparent rebuttal of Jiang's claim that human rights is a relative term, and that mainland China should be judged by a different set of standards.

"I believe the most important, the most fundamental human right is how to ensure that the 1.2 billion Chinese people have adequate food and clothing," Jiang told US journalists before embarking on the visit.
Jiang has said he hopes that his current visit will enhance the understanding, broaden common ground and deepen cooperation between mainland China and the United States.

Jiang and his wife were greeted by a red-coated fife-and-drum corps upon their visit to the Governor's Palace at the tourist village. Jiang put on a black three-cornered hat from the colonial era, emulating the late Deng Xiaoping who captured the American people's imagination by donning a cowboy hat in Houston during his 1979 US visit.

Some 100 demonstrators were kept 250 yards from the building. They held placards demanding human rights in mainland China, freedom for Tibet and revocation of mainland China's most favored nation trading status.

Jiang and his entourage later flew into Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Washington, where they were greeted by Vice President Al Gore. Clinton arranged a private meeting with Jiang Tuesday night in the White House to ease the way for Wednesday's summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RELEASE ABDUCTED MARINE POLICE OFFICER

TEXT.P: ROC Interior Minister Yeh Chin-feng on Wednesday again urged mainland China to repatriate a Taiwan marine police officer who was abducted by mainland Chinese fishermen earlier this month while he was conducting a search of a mainland fishing vessel intercepted in Taiwan territorial waters off the island of Matsu, which is controlled by the Republic of China but located close to the mainland.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Yeh denied that the ROC government has agreed to foot the medical bills of mainland fishermen who allegedly were injured by Taiwan marine police in the Oct. 11 clash.

Yeh said the National Police Administration, which is under the jurisdiction of the Interior Ministry, has asked the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to negotiate with mainland authorities for the early return of Chuang Chen-yao, the abducted officer.

Yeh quoted a police investigation report as showing that the mainland fishing boat was caught operating in Taiwan waters on Oct. 11, "so it was appropriate and necessary that our marine police patrol boat intercepted and boarded the intruding mainland fishing vessel to conduct routine checks."

Yeh said that although the marine police officers carry powerful firearms, they didn't open fire, in an effort to avoid escalating tension across the Taiwan Strait. "Their self-restraint deserves praise," the minister noted.

She expressed regret that no officer from the Matsu Garrison Command was in command of the marine police vessel at the time of the confrontation, saying that according to government regulations, the military's Matsu Garrison Command is responsible for patrolling the waters surrounding Matsu, while the marine police are only required to play a supporting or auxiliary role.
Yeh admitted that the inexperience of the marine police Matsu division chief, who assumed his post only recently, was also a factor contributing to the failure of the operation.

The officers failed to take preemptive action to control the situation after they boarded the mainland fishing boat. As a result, Yeh said, armed mainland fishermen managed to abduct Chuang and flee back to the mainland.

Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, said earlier this week that mainland China would return Chuang if Taiwan compensates the injured mainland fishermen.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng responded that Taiwan would not pay compensation because its officers were performing their official duties, but he added that Taiwan does not rule out the possibility of offering "consolation" money to the fishermen allegedly injured in the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar gained NT$0.035 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$30.835.
The US currency opened at NT$30.83 and was traded between NT$30.7 and NT$30.84.
Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$371.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MEETING TO ADDRESS ASIAN CURRENCY CRISIS

TEXT.P: Asia's currency crisis, which has been blamed for causing global stock turmoil, will be among the topics discussed by the 18 leaders of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) countries, a ranking Canadian official said Tuesday.
The agenda of next month's APEC summit in Vancouver will have to be reorganized to deal with the issue, Canada's Trade Minister Sergio Marchi said.

The host country noted that the entire agenda of the APEC countries can't be scrapped because of all the work that has been going on throughout the year. Canada, as APEC's 1997 host, has held four ministerial meetings before the Nov. 24-25 summit.
"Clearly I think the leaders will be engaged on the currency issue," he said. "And I've talked about putting in place a process by which that discussion can take place."
Marchi made the comments as the Canadian dollar showed signs of resistance to the panic selling that started Monday with the collapse of equity markets worldwide.

Meanwhile, rumors were circulating that some Asian countries like Thailand and Indonesia will be looking for a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the larger industrialized countries, much like Mexico got in 1995 to shore up its currency.

Stanley Fisher, first deputy managing director of the IMF, said in Washington the organization is ready to help countries hit by market turbulence and is in talks with nations in Asia and Latin America.
Marchi, when asked about such aid, was non-committal. "I think it would be premature right now to advocate what is good and what is bad," he said.
"I would be more keenly interested in making sure we've got a process by which these and other alternatives can be housed and discussed and aired properly."
The proposal for an "Asia Stability Fund" has met with opposing voices on the grounds that it would duplicate the functions of the IMF.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS MAINLAND CHINA TO SIGN HUMAN RIGHTS COVENANT

TEXT.P: Australia has welcomed mainland China's signature on the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR) and wants Beijing to move a step forward by signing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said on Wednesday.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Downer said: "Australia hopes that China will also consider early ratification of the ICCPR, which would complement ratification of the ICESCR and significantly strengthen international support for the International Bill of Rights."

He said Australia welcomes mainland China's signature in New York on Tuesday of the ICESCR because the covenant "is a central element of the international human rights legal framework, and China's accession to it will give a significant boost to the objective of promoting universal adherence to the rights set out in the covenant."
Political analysts said mainland China still has a long way to go to improve its human rights record, despite its signing of the covenant.
"So long as political prisoners and dissidents are in jail, Australia, as a democratic country, will express its concern and raise the issue with mainland China," one analyst said.

The analysts said mainland China will remain under international pressure because it has no political freedom, freedom of speech or freedom of religion, and the abuse of human rights in Tibet is serious.

The year 1998 marks the 50th anniversary of the UN General Assembly's adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which, together with the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, comprise the International Bill of Rights -- the foundation on which the international human rights legal framework is built.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STOCK MARKET REBOUNDS AFTER WALL STREET REBOUND

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market, buoyed by Tuesday's Wall Street rebound, itself rebounded strongly in early morning trading on Wednesday.
The All Ordinaries Index on Tuesday plunged 177.8 points, or 7.2 percent, as world markets crashed after Wall Street recorded its largest-ever one-day fall.
Tuesday's plunge, the biggest one-day decline since the market crash of 1987, saw A$27.4 billion wiped off in Australia.
But the index rebounded strongly in the first hour of morning trading on Wednesday, rising 167 points to about 2,466 after plunging to 2299.2 at Tuesday's close.
The Australian dollar rebounded on Tuesday, rising to 69.41 US cents from Monday's closing level of 68.50 US cents, and continued its gain on Wednesday, jumping to 70.70 US cents.
Brokers and dealers believe that if Wall Street continues its bullish run in the coming days or weeks, the Australian stock market and foreign exchange market will follow suit.

"We hope there is a silver lining coming out from the big black clouds of the past few weeks," one broker said, adding that the recent plunge in the Australian stock market might reduce the government's income from its floating of telecommunications giant, Telstra, to only A$12 billion, down from the original target of A$14.2 billion.
The floating of government-owned Telstra, the biggest in Australia's history, is part of the Australian government's efforts to privatize public enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAKARTA WANTS CURRENCY EARLY WARNING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Indonesian President Suharto will seek support at next month's APEC summit for urgent action to check the regional currency turmoil which has spread around the world, said his special adviser Tuesday.

Professor Bintoro Tjokronamidjojo, Indonesia's ambassador for APEC affairs, said Suharto would propose the setting up of an early warning system to avert a future currency crisis and a standby emergency fund to help troubled economies recover from their financial problems.
"The currency crisis in Southeast Asia is a common concern which needs concerted efforts by APEC leaders," he was quoted as saying.

Bintoro was in Singapore to attend a two-day APEC Senior Officials' Meeting which ended Tuesday. He said the standby fund Indonesia would propose to the APEC summit next month in Vancouver would supplement the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and provide short-term reserves for members hit by currency turbulence.

Contributions to the fund should come from APEC member-economies as a reflection of solidarity, he said, noting that Singapore and Malaysia had pledged financial assistance to help Indonesia weather its economic crisis. The IMF is finalizing an aid package for Indonesia.
Elaborating on the early warning system, he said it could help flash warning signals to APEC economies heading for financial troubles before the situation becomes a full-blown crisis.

"The warning bells should be sounded when a country's fundamentals are not right, such as when its current account deficits and short-term lending get too high. Such a mechanism will help avert a crisis," he said, adding that it would also sustain stability in the financial markets by preventing excessive fluctuation of currencies.
Bintoro acknowledged that Southeast Asian countries ravaged by the currency debacle must take immediate steps to reform their financial and trade sectors.
For Indonesia, he said the current economic crisis "is a blessing in disguise as we know our weaknesses now."
But he remained optimistic about the region's continued growth prospects.

Reflecting the urgency to take collective action to stabilize the financial markets in Asia, APEC's deputy finance ministers and central bankers will gather in Manila Nov. 19-20 to put up a rescue package for consideration by the APEC leaders at their Nov. 25 summit, APEC officials said.
The currency crisis is likely to dominate the leaders' discussions although APEC officials said they did not expect any immediate concrete measures to come out of the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 120.45 points to close at the day's low of 7,089.56.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,391.31.
Losers outnumbered gainers 246 to 166, with 53 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.34 billion (US$4.45 billion).

Electrical engineering shares declined the most at 5.4 percent, followed by construction stocks at 2.2 percent, cement shares and plastic and chemical stocks at 0.8 percent, respectively, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and paper-making shares at 0.3 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, ACER, Mosel Vitelic Inc., Macronix International, A.S.E., China Development, Inventec Computer Inc., Winbond Electronics, and Cathay Life Ins..

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI EDITORIAL SAYS HUMAN RIGHTS PROTECTION IS IN BEIJING'S INTEREST

TEXT.P: The threat of trade sanctions no longer hangs over mainland China-US relations, but that does not mean concerns about human rights abuses in mainland China should be allowed to slip off the agenda of this week's summit between US President Bill Clinton and his communist Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, a Bangkok-based English daily pointed out on Wednesday.
"The Nation" said in its editorial that the communist government in Beijing will have to understand that they cannot have progress without human development.
"They (Chinese communists) cannot win the respect of the international community as long as citizens are locked up for expressing opposing opinions," it stressed.

The newspaper urged Clinton to assert Washington's right to sponsor human rights resolutions in the UN General Assembly and explain its obligations as a member of the international community to do so.
The motions have never been passed but they are of acute embarrassment to Beijing, it added.

"The US president should also make it clear that he is prepared to work towards building a solid relationship with China, but that will require trust and sincerity from both sides, the paper indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: US 'DOESN'T SUPPORT' TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that the US stance on the Taiwan independence issue is that the US "doesn't support" Taiwan independence.

A local newspaper reported on Wednesday that during talks between US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and mainland China's Foreign Minister Qian Qichen on Sept. 23 at the United Nations, Albright told Qian that the US "was opposed to" Taiwan independence.

The China Times said that in the past, the US has always used the phrase "does not support" to describe their stance, instead of "is opposed to," adding that Beijing is urging Washington to state clearly that "the US is opposed to Taiwan independence and Taiwan's admission to the United Nations" in a joint declaration to be issued following the summit talks between US president Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

While answering questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, Hu said that he knew of the meeting between Albright and Qian in September and that the phrase Albright used to describe the US stance on Taiwan independence was that the US "doesn't support" Taiwan independence.

He noted that the US has made clear both its approval of the progress Taiwan has made in democratic development and its opinion that cross-Taiwan Strait disputes should be resolved by the people of the two sides of the strait through peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA CONDEMNS ZAMBIAN COUP

TEXT.P: The South African government has condemned the attempted coup in Zambia and said it fully supports the Zambian government's measures to defeat the plotters and assert its authority.
Acting Foreign Minister Valli Moosa said in a statement Tuesday that Deputy President Thabo Mbeki had been in touch with various presidents and governments in the region on this "serious matter."
Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo is currently accompanying President Nelson Mandela on a visit abroad.

The statement said "our government views the attempted coup d'etat in the Republic of Zambia in a very serious light, considering it an unconstitutional and unacceptable action against a democratically elected government."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MARKETS REBOUND IN HECTIC TRADING

TEXT.P: The Australian financial and security markets rebounded strongly in hectic trading Wednesday as Wall Street and Hong Kong share prices staged heavy gains.
The All Ordinaries Index surged 144 points to close at 2443.2 on Wednesday while the Australian currency jumped to 70.54 US cents from Tuesday's close of 68.83.

Economists said they believed the gains could gather momentum in both financial and security markets in the next few days in Australia and the United States. They said their optimistic forecast was based on economic fundamentals in Australia because the current interest rates are very low and inflation is also only 1.6 percent.
There is little worry of economic recession, they said.

Although they believed Australia's economic growth could not grow at 4 percent or above during the current fiscal year, which ends in June 1998, they predicted the target of 3.75 percent could be achieved.
Some Australian exports, especially the education and tourism sectors, could be hit considerably due to the financial and security crises in Southeast Asia, they said.
But the impact will not be as high as earlier expected, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON BOURSE TURMOIL

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Wednesday's edition of local English-language daily The China Post, titled: "Investors Need to Remain Calm During Turmoil."

"Under the influence of the world financial market turmoil, the Taiwan Stock Exchange yesterday (Tuesday) tumbled as much as 5.93 percent to close at 7,210 points, the largest single day fall in the bourse's recent history. The foreign exchange market, too, underwent a large decline, as the New Taiwan dollar was down 38 U.S. cents to 30.8 against the U.S. dollar at the close of the morning session.

"Yesterday's (Tuesday's) see-offs on both the local stock and forex markets were sparked by news that the Dow Jones industrial average of the United States in the preceding day plummeted an astonishing 554 points...
"The Dow's own historical crash...was triggered by a continuous plunge of the Hong Kong stock market.

"The chain-reaction volatility in the world's stock and currency markets...has once again demonstrated how one country or one region's financial woes can quickly affect other markets with the increase of globalization.

"The problem now faced by us in Taiwan is...how to overcome the psychological impact those foreign markets may have on local investors and traders, should the transactions in those countries remain volatile.

"To maintain the stability of the financial markets, the most important thing is to first stabilize the exchange rate of the NT dollar.... Over the past three months, the Central Bank of China (CBC) took strong measures to defend the NT dollar by continuing to sell foreign exchange in the market. But the CBC finally...had to succumb to mounting depreciatory pressure to let the local currency determine its own value in the marketplace.

"The policy change of the CBC's was right. This is because central bank intervention can only help raise market expectations at a time when the financial markets around the world continue to undergo wild fluctuations and investor confidence is fragile.
"All this, however, is not to say that the CBC must stand by idly if and when speculation becomes rampant.
"In response to the plunge of the local stock market yesterday, the Ministry of Finance...held a special meeting...to discuss market-boosting measures.
"One important thing that the government can and should do at this point is to urge investors to remain calm and not to engage in panic selling."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF WILL NOT CUT TRANSACTION TAX TO STABILIZE BOURSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Wednesday flatly stated that it will not reduce or cancel the stock transaction tax for the sake of stabilizing Taiwan's stock market.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday experienced a continued decline in the weighted index, the key barometer of the local bourse, despite a rebound in share prices on the New York Stock Exchange which triggered a recovery in major markets around the world.

Concerned over the local market's decline, legislators had suggested either canceling or reducing the transaction tax as an incentive to encourage stock investors to hold on to their shares for a longer period of time.
However, MOF Vice Minister Yen Ching-chang indicated that adjusting or canceling the stock trading tax outright is not "a panacea for stabilizing the bourse."
Yen claimed that the current 0.3 percent taxation on share trading activities does not constitute a burden to investors.

Meanwhile, the MOF also declared that there is no need to implement an automatic mechanism for suspending trade on the local bourse, such as that set up in the United States following the stock market crash of October, 1987. The ministry added that the existing 7 percent ceiling on the rise and fall of share prices which is currently in use has the same stabilizing effect as the US system.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND URGED TO RELEASE TAIWAN MARINE POLICEMAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Wednesday urged mainland Chinese authorities to repatriate a Taiwan marine policeman who was abducted to the other side of the Taiwan Strait on Oct. 11, adding that there will be no compensation to mainland fishermen involved in the case.

The SEF said in a news release that it is greatly concerned over recent remarks made by Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). Tang said that the abducted officer, Chuang Cheng-yo, is in good condition and that he will be allowed to return to Taiwan once he reaches an agreement over compensation with two mainland fishermen who sustained injuries in a scuffle involving Chuang and another marine police.

The two Taiwan marine police officers boarded a mainland fishing boat they suspected of smuggling goods into Taiwan during a routine patrol in waters near the offshore island of Matsu on Oct. 11. Overcome in the ensuing scuffle, Chuang, who received an injury to his arm, was taken to the Fujian Province port city of Fuzhou by mainland fishermen. Several of the fishermen also reportedly suffered injuries during the incident.

SEF officials said that Chuang has no liability to compensate the injured mainland fishermen, claiming that they are to blame for the incident because they were trespassing in Taiwan's territorial waters and had attempted to hinder Chuang in his search of the fishing boat.

The SEF added, however, that in consideration of the fraternal bonds between people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan authorities are willing to offer condolence money to the injured fishermen. But the gesture of condolence and the return of Chuang are two different matters, it said, adding that mainland officials should not link them and should release the officer at an early date.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 167,000 COUPLES WED IN TAIWAN LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 167,314 couples got married in Taiwan last year, up 3.67 percent from the year-earlier total, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
The average age of grooms was recorded at 31.3 years, while that of their brides was 28.8. The two averages were by far the highest for newlyweds since 1987, said ministry officials.

Among the couples taking wedding vows in 1996, the MOI figures indicated, more than 150,000 bridegrooms, and a similar number of brides, were entering into their first marriage, registering a 3.36 percent and a 3.38 percent rise, respectively, in that statistic compared with the 1995 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD AND ROC PLEDGE TO EXPAND COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Visiting President Idriss Deby of Chad and ROC President Lee Teng-hui pledged Wednesday to expand cooperation between the two countries in multilateral organizations and reaffirmed respect for each other's national sovereignty and territorial integrity.

In a joint communique signed by the two heads of state at the end of Deby's five-day visit, Chad pledged its support for the ROC's full participation in international organizations, including the United Nations. The two leaders also emphasized the necessity of resolving conflicts through peaceful means.
Deby invited Lee to visit Chad, an offer which was accepted by Lee according to the communique, although no date was set.
After the signing ceremony, Deby and his entourage expressed thanks to the ROC president for the warm reception they received in Taiwan, and bade farewell to their hosts.
Lee and several senior government leaders saw the delegation off at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute.
Deby and his entourage arrived in Taiwan on Oct. 26. They are scheduled to depart on Thursday.

Earlier Wednesday, Deby called on Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang, whereupon he urged Wang to strengthen ROC economic ties with Chad and to encourage local businessmen to invest in that central African nation.
With a land area 30 times that of Taiwan, and a population of only 7 million, one-third of Taiwan's 21 million, Chad is a ideal location for local investors, Deby said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD DIAMOND CONFAB TO CONVENE IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Indonesia's South Kalimantan is set to host the World Conference on Diamonds in February 1998, in the capital city of Banjarmasin.

An official with the provincial administration was quoted by state-run Antara news agency as saying Wednesday that at least 400 foreign participants and 200 local entrepreneurs are scheduled to attend the conference.
In the run-up to the event, he said the province is preparing to upgrade its jewelry houses in Martapura district, known as a center for diamond handicrafts.
The official said the conference will open opportunities to local diamond merchants, especially those seeking foreign business partners.
He said an exchange of information on the world diamond market will be a featured activity at the event.
"We hope also that the conference will showcase the latest diamond jewelry handicraft technology," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-NEW ZEALAND TRADE CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A trade conference between the Republic of China and New Zealand opened here Wednesday, with Chen Jui-lung, director-general of the ROC Board of Foreign Trade, and Alastair Bisley, New Zealand's deputy vice minister for foreign and trade affairs, heading their respective delegations.
The two-day conference is the fifth such meeting between the two countries despite the absence of diplomatic ties between Taipei and Wellington.
The two sides exchanged views on the lowering of tariffs for agricultural and fishery products during the first day of meeting, according to Chen.
Taiwan promised to enact new rules to cut tariffs on beef products and to change the category under which imports of blue cod are currently classified.
They will discuss mutual cooperation measures in Thursday's meeting before finalizing a bilateral accord for the ROC's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
In an unrelated development, Chen said that Singapore has cut from 40 to 17 the number of products on which it will ask Taiwan to slash tariffs.
Singapore's new list of requests was presented at a meeting with ROC negotiators in Singapore on Monday, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTS IN PLASTIC SURGERY CLINIC MURDER REMAIN UNIDENTIFIED

TEXT.P: A high-ranking police official said Wednesday that two at-large suspects in the kidnap and murder of a high school student might have also committed the brutal murder of three victims at a plastic surgery clinic in Taipei.

However, Ting Yuan-ching, director-general of the National Police Administration, denied a newspaper report that police had obtained sufficient evidence to conclude that Kao Tien-ming and Chen Ching-hsing were responsible for killing plastic surgeon Fen Pao-fan, his wife and a nurse on Oct. 23. The pair are currently wanted for the abduction and murder of the teenage daughter of well-known TV entertainer Pai Ping-ping in May.

Ting said that blood samples collected at the scene, which was believed to belong to the suspects, was analyzed to be type B and a sperm sample gathered from the body of the nurse indicated a type A origin. Although Kao Tien-ming's blood type is "B" and Chen Ching-hsing's is "A," the evidence is insufficient to prove that they or anyone else is responsible for the criminal act, Ting said.

Responding to questions from legislators at the Legislative Yuan, Ting said that the most reliable and scientific method of identifying the suspects is through DNA analysis. But Ting also noted that the police do not have either Kao's or Chen's DNA profiles.

Prosecutor Liu Ching-wang said that, within legal limits, law enforcement officials will attempt to obtain blood samples from the parents of the two fugitives in an attempt to construct DNA profiles. But she refused to confirm whether investigators have already obtained such samples or whether DNA testing is under way.
Liu said that she does not rule out the possibility that the three people murdered in the clinic were killed after Kao had undergone plastic surgery on his eyebrows to change his appearance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HELPS EARTHQUAKE RELIEF IN CHILE
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Stephen Shen & Debbie Kuo)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative in Chile Wang Fei on Wednesday presented a check for US$20,000 to Chilean Interior Minister Carlos Figueroa, to help finance earthquake relief work currently under way in northern Chile.

The northern region of Chile was stricken by an earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale on Sept. 14, which killed eight people, left more than 20,000 others injured and destroyed at least 6,500 homes.
To help the Chilean government's relief efforts, the ROC government decided to contribute US$20,000. It made a donation of same amount to Chile six years ago in the wake of a disastrous flood there.

According to Wang, overseas Chinese and Taiwanese expatriates in Chile have been a major source of charitable donations in the South American country. They launched a successful fund-raising drive after a hurricane hit the Chilean capital Santiago in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSTON TRADE OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Hu Chung-chu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Miguel San Juan, chairman of the international trade committee under the Greater Houston Partnership, on Wednesday announced that he would lead a delegation to Taiwan for a three-day visit beginning Nov. 16.

He indicated that during his Taiwan stay, he is planning to talk about issues concerning the implementation of direct flights between Taipei and Houston with relevant Republic of China officials. The delegation will also visit the offices of China Airlines and EVA Airways Corporation, two major flight service providers on the island.
San Juan added that he will also call on economics and trade officials to discuss matters regarding the promotion of trade links.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR IMMEDIATE RESUMPTION OF 'KOO-WANG' TALKS

TEXT.P: In a formal response to the conclusion of the high-profile Clinton-Jiang talks, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) again held out an olive branch to Beijing on Thursday, urging it to resume dialogue with Taipei immediately and unconditionally.

The Cabinet-level agency, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said the Republic of China's stance on the Oct. 29 summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, is crystal clear in maintaining that their talks should not impinge the ROC's national interests.

The agency also said in a press release that the United States should upgrade its relations with Taipei in a manner parallel to the improvement in its ties with Beijing in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit.

To cope with the post-summit situation, the MAC said, the ROC government will seek to reinforce high-level security dialogue and exchanges with the US administration and simultaneously take active steps to break the current cross-strait impasse and establish a mechanism for positive bilateral interaction.

In fact, the MAC said, the ROC has always kept its doors open for cross-strait consultations. "Exchanges and consultations have been the two key elements in the implementation of our mainland policy," it noted.

The MAC further said Taiwan's promotion of cross-strait dialogue and political consultations are aimed at creating a peaceful atmosphere, stabilizing bilateral relations and safeguarding security in the Taiwan Strait. "So our mainland policy goals fully comply with the US position on maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region," the agency explained.

It pointed out that the greatest obstacle to cross-strait relations lies in Beijing's recalcitrant "one China" sovereign concept and its reluctance to face up to the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are currently under separate rule.

Touching on future cross-strait relations, the MAC said the ROC's consistent stance is that the two sides immediately resume the "Koo-Wang" talks and all institutionalized communications channels without setting any preconditions.
It added that preliminary consultations for an end to cross-strait hostility can also be discussed in the Koo-Wang framework.

The Koo-Wang talks refer to a meeting held in Singapore in April 1993 between C.F. Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). It marked the highest-level cross-strait talks since the Chinese Communists took control of the mainland.

The top negotiators from both sides were originally scheduled to meet again in the second half of 1995, but mainland China unilaterally suspended the conference and closed all other dialogue channels formulated in the first Koo-Wang meeting to vent its anger at ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark private visit to the US in June that year.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, NEW ZEALAND SIGN WTO ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Thursday formally signed an agreement with New Zealand on the terms for Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The accord was inked in Taipei by Chen Jui-lung, director-general of the ROC's Board of Foreign Trade, and Alastair Bisley, deputy secretary of the New Zealand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
New Zealand is the 16th WTO member to seal a formal pact on Taiwan's accession terms.

Bisley said New Zealand is satisfied with the conclusion of WTO talks with Taiwan. "We also hope that your country will finalize all bilateral and multilateral consultations and enter the world trade regulatory body as early as possible," he told a news conference held at the end of the two-day ROC-New Zealand trade consultations.
For his part, Chen said the signing of the ROC-New Zealand WTO agreement marks a big step forward in Taiwan's bid to join the Geneva-based world trade body.
To date, Chen said, the ROC has completed bilateral talks with 21 of the 26 WTO members who expressed intentions to hold such consultations, and has even sealed formal pacts with 16 of them.

The five trade partners with which the ROC has yet to finalize WTO talks are the United States, Canada, Switzerland, Singapore and the 15-member European Union. Chen said only a few issues remain to be resolved with those major partners.
Five other WTO members -- Hong Kong, Thailand, Mexico, Hungary and Argentina -- have completed consultations with the ROC, but have yet to sign a formal accord.

Chen said the Oct. 27-28 round of talks with Singapore has achieved concrete results. Singapore originally demanded that Taiwan cut tariffs on 40 kinds of industrial products, but the number has been trimmed to 17 following the latest round of negotiations. Chen said Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will further discuss the issue with his Singaporean counterpart when he attends the annual ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Canada next month.

Asked whether the just-concluded summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin would enable mainland China to join the WTO ahead of Taiwan, Chen said Taiwan leads the mainland in WTO talks at the moment and that Taiwan's trade regime is far more compliant with WTO requirements than is the mainland's.

In addition to WTO-related issues, Chen said Taiwan and New Zealand have also reached consensus on eight other topics, including protection of intellectual property rights (IPR), tourism cooperation and avoidance of double taxation on investors from both sides.
Chen said the two countries will sign a tax exemption accord once New Zealand's parliament passes the Taiwan-drafted pact.

Meanwhile, Chen said, Taiwan and New Zealand are scheduled to sign an IPR protection accord before the end of this year. The ROC's Fair Trade Commission is discussing fair trade rules with relevant New Zealand authorities as well as ways to promote cooperation among small- and medium-sized enterprises.

Chen said New Zealand has promised to offer three-year multiple-entry business and tourist visas to Taiwan visitors in the near future. The two sides will also reinforce cooperation in research on energy resources, fishing resources conservation, and plant and animal quarantine.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FEAR TAIWAN'S BARGAINING POSITION IS WANING

TEXT.P: Worried over a possible strategic alliance between the United States and mainland China in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit, several legislators said on Thursday that Taiwan's bargaining chips are diminishing and its clout in the international community is waning.

Legislator Chen Chi-mai from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said during a national affairs forum at the Legislative Yuan that the three-way relations among Taiwan, the United States and mainland China have become increasingly problematic following the Clinton-Jiang meeting.

Chen said Washington, with the encouragement of Beijing, may inadvertently "sell out" Taiwan over business interests which include the prospect for mainland orders of Boeing aircraft and nuclear facilities, serving up the island as "fish and meat," with the Americans and mainland Chinese supplying the "knife and chopping board."

Cheng Pao-ching, another DPP legislator, said he worries that Taiwan will be eventually sacrificed in the manner of a "second Yalta agreement." Claiming that Taiwan's ordeal has just begun, Cheng stressed that the government should make its voice louder to let the international community know that both Taiwan and mainland China are sovereign political entities.

The Yalta Conference, among Allied leaders Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin on Feb. 4, 1945, resulted in the Soviet occupation of disputed border areas with China and the capture by the Chinese Communists of weaponry and military equipment left by the Japanese in Manchuria. Those developments are said to have contributed to the eventual defeat of the ROC Nationalist forces when China's civil war began in earnest in 1948.

New Party Legislator Hau Lung-ping, meanwhile, said it is clear that relations among Taiwan, the United States and mainland China are triangular in nature, but that the sides of the triangle are not of equal proportion. Taiwan's position is apparently much weaker than that of Washington and Beijing, which now seem on equitable footing, he noted.
Hau suggested that Taiwan begin talks on the "three links" and other business and trade issues with the mainland under the "one China" principle without further delay.

If Taiwan continues to refuse discussion on the three links--direct trade, postal and transport contact with the mainland--the island will soon lose its bargaining chips, which will ultimately victimize all 21.3 million Taiwan residents, he states.

Another New Party legislator, Chen I-hsin, said the ROC government should assert more clearly its adherence to the "one China" principle and its position that Taiwan is a part of China. However, he noted, the "China" to which the ROC refers is by no means the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAI LING ON MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: In an article published by The Wall Street Journal Wednesday, Chai Ling, a leader of the 1989 student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, expressed her hope that America's leaders will not back down in confronting mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on subjects like human rights and political freedom.

Now a MBA student at Harvard Business School, Chai said in the article, titled "China: No Food Without Freedom," that Americans need to recognize their fears of mainland China are overblown. "The Chinese government needs US support just as much as the US needs China, if not more. China needs the American market, technology and exports just as much as the US needs access to China's market. President Jiang needs American support to further consolidate his power back home."

America should firmly and forcefully communicate its values and basic respect for human rights," she wrote. "Those who believe in waiting for the free market to bring about freedom in China are mistaken."

The best way to promote mainland China's prosperity and the prosperity of the firms doing business there is to push for greater freedom and human rights, Chai said, adding, "China is enjoying today's prosperity despite, not because of, its form of government."

The functioning of a free market requires a society that allows and respects the freedom of its own people, she wrote, "and a free society requires the release of political prisoners, including well-known freedom fighters like Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan, as well as thousands of anonymous victims who are still held in prison camps across the country."
Concluding the article, Chai said the United States "can play an instrumental role in mainland China's transition to a free society and thereby help China improve its economic growth and prosperity."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN TO BOYCOTT EU-ASIA MEET IF MYANMAR EXCLUDED

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) decided on Thursday to postpone the annual European Union-Asia meeting as a result of the EU's stance regarding Myanmar's participation in the ASEAN-EU Joint Cooperation committee.

According to a statement released on Wednesday by Myanmar Resources Development, Ltd., a high-ranking ASEAN source was quoted as saying at last week's meeting in Manila of the group's standing committee that, "If the EU doesn't back down, that might spell the end of the ASEAN-EU dialogue relationship."

Next month's Bangkok gathering of EU and Asian leaders will aim to create another APEC-style dialogue between two of the world's most dynamic economic markets. However, the EU has recently told ASEAN that it would only accept Myanmar as an observer to the two meetings, not as a full participant.
However, it was noted that at last month's ASEAN Regional Forum in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the attending EU delegation sat down with Myanmar in a full consultative role, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUCENT TECH. INSTALLS TAIWAN'S WIRELESS NETWORK

TEXT.P: Lucent Technologies of the United States announced Wednesday that it has deployed the initial phase of Taiwan's first national Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) 1800 network, connecting networks for KG Telecom and Tuntex Telecom, two of Taiwan's licensed wireless service providers.

Lucent has already installed more than 350 base stations and four mobile switching centers under a US$140 million contract originally signed with the two Taiwan wireless service providers last April. The project will be completed in two years.

With the GSM 1800 network, KG Telecom and Tuntex Telecom have now entered into a roaming agreement that allows them to offer their subscribers seamless national wireless coverage. Their subscribers can now make and receive phone calls at any location in Taiwan.

Lucent technologies, which has the world-renowned Bell Laboratories as its research and development arm, designs, builds and delivers a wide range of public and private networks, communications systems and software, consumer and business telephone systems and microelectronic components. It has 119,000 employees in more than 90 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN SEEN FACING 'WORLD-CLASS CRISIS'

TEXT.P: Japan is a country particularly vulnerable to an acute financial crisis because of inherent problems in its banking system, according to a leading authority on international finance.

In an interview with the Australian Financial Review in Sydney, Dr. Morris Goldstein of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, DC, said problems with financial systems are "fairly widespread" among the major economies of Northeast Asia -- Japan, South Korea and mainland China.
"But if you look at where systematic risk is largest, it's in Japan -- there's no doubt about it, because it comes on top of other things that have happened there," he said.

He said Japan's banking system had been in a slow-motion crisis for five years, with the economy stagnant, too. But Japanese authorities have failed to act decisively to address the country's problems, said Goldstein, former deputy head of research for the International Monetary Fund.
He said Japan was set for "a truly world-class banking crisis." So far three Japanese banks have collapsed.
"Another two or three banks will collapse this fiscal year to the end of next March and the Deposit Insurance Corporation is supposed to support them, but they have no funds left," Goldstein said.
"The problem has become so big that it is politically impossible to use public funds to rescue them," he said.

He said the economic crisis in Asia is unusual because it is moving from small countries like Thailand to bigger ones. Financial crises typically begin in a major economy and then infect smaller ones, he said.

He said the Japanese banking system will be further damaged by the crisis which started in Thailand, whose economy is only half the size of Australia's, because Japanese commercial banks have US$150 billion in exposures to Asian countries.
"Japan has been able to put off adjustment because it has deep pockets, but putting it on the back burner is very costly -- if you don't deal with it just gets worse," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rebounded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, skyrocketing 223.84 points to close at 7,313.4.
The bourse opened at 7,136.24, and experienced a high of 7,315.82 and a low of 7,040.54.
Gainers outnumbered gainers 394 to 63, with nine stocks remaining unchanged. In all, 2.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.15 billion (US$3.91 billion).

Financial stocks surged the most at 6.3 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 3.8 percent, construction issues at 3.7 percent, textile issues at 3.2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.9 percent, plastic and chemical stocks at 2.5 percent, and electrical engineering at 0.7 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers were Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, United Micro Electronics, Macronix International, ACER, A.S.E., Mosel Vitelic Inc., Winbond Electronics, GVC Corporation, Cathay Life Ins., and Inventec Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE HOUSEHOLDS GO HIGH-TECH, UPMARKET

TEXT.P: Singapore households are going upmarket, with more of them owning cellular phones, personal computers, video cameras, laser disc players and other consumer appliances.
One in three households now owns at least one cellular phone, a fivefold increase since 1992.
Households owning PCs, laser disc players and video cameras have doubled, while car ownership has risen only slightly, with one in three households owning cars.
About half of all Singaporean households are now air-conditioned, up from only 35 percent in 1992.
These were the preliminary findings of the seventh Household Expenditure Survey carried out earlier this year by the Singapore Department of Statistics in conjunction with the Ministry of Labor.
The department will conduct a more in-depth survey from next month until next October to re-evaluate the basket of goods in the Consumer Price Index.

Over the next 12 months, the department will conduct personal interviews with some 9,000 selected households to collect detailed information on all sources of income, asset ownership, investments, as well as expenditure on consumer durables, travel and housing. Foreign households in Singapore were excluded.
Selected Singapore households were picked based on sampling rules set by the department to ensure that survey results reflect population and geographical differences.
They will be divided into 26 groups of about 340 households, with each group monitoring its expenditures over a two-week period.

The results from the 1992-93 survey showed that the proportion of household income spent on food had declined by 10 percent as people spent more on increasing transport and housing costs, the department said.
It expects this trend to continue in the next survey.
The change in the pattern of consumption shows a clear change in the lifestyle patterns of Singaporeans and the standard of living here, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA DESCRIBED AS A STUMBLING GIANT IN NEED OF HELP

TEXT.P: The current economic crisis in East Asia is minuscule compared with the mounting debt and widespread corruption problems in mainland China and Jiang Zemin is a weak leader of a nation in deep crisis.

So claims a dispatch from Beijing appearing in Thursday's Sydney Morning Herald. The mass-circulation daily's correspondent David Lague reported that Jiang is expected to exploit the prestige and attention of a presidential summit with US President Bill Clinton in Washington to reinforce the widely held notion that mainland China is poised to recapture its traditional role as a major world power and should be treated with respect and reverence.

Many normally skeptical observers of international affairs have long since concluded that mainland China's rise is inevitable and that the Communist Party under Jiang's leadership is on course for greatness. Even the current financial turmoil that has gripped East and Southeast Asia over the last four months and shattered the "Asian miracle" has not shaken this belief.

For some inexplicable reason, mainland China is widely considered to be immune from this convulsion as some of the region's corrupt, inefficient and greedy business and political cultures are cruelly exposed, the daily reported.

But in reality, the economic and political problems in the world's most populous country "make Thailand look well managed and Jiang should be viewed as the weak leader of a nation in deep crisis," the Herald said.
The daily reported that, while Western leaders, diplomats, academics and tourists have marveled at the Chinese revival, most of them have ignored the huge problems now mainland China is facing.
The daily said they see the high-rise buildings, but rarely ask why many of them are empty.
"They almost never ask, 'why build high-rises at all in the middle of a slum?'" the daily reported.

The daily's dispatch from Beijing also commented that Westerners fail to write about that part of the Chinese economy which the reformers left behind: the huge problems of mainland China's over 300,000 state-owned enterprises, which employ more than 100 million and many of which are facing collapse, with hundreds of thousands of workers already unemployed.
These enterprises are obsolete and inefficient and have relied on Chinese state bank loans to keep turning out shoddy and in many cases unmarketable goods, the daily reported.

"These loans have piled up to the point where even the World Bank, traditionally restrained in its criticism of China, has warned that a major financial system insolvency is approaching unless the authorities contain the mounting debt," the daily reported.

It said the number of unemployed people throughout mainland China varies widely and accurate figures are probably impossible to come by. But many tens of millions of urban mainland Chinese are now unemployed and their ranks are certain to expand dramatically now that the Chinese government has belatedly acknowledged that it must reform the state-owned sector.

The daily quoted analysts as saying that 30 million new jobless will hit the streets. Others, including senior bureaucrats, say the combined urban and rural unemployed will outnumber the population of the United States -- 265 million -- in the near future.

The Beijing leadership is banking on more burgeoning economic growth to provide the jobs to soak up these surplus workers, but just as the authorities begin to get tough with the state sector, the 20-year boom is running into trouble, the Herald reported.

Foreign investment is slowing rapidly, consumer demand is also falling, factory inventories continue to expand, losses from the state sector mount rapidly and real estate markets are collapsing, the daily observed.
Corruption in mainland China flourishes as thousands of party officials routinely abuse their positions, it said.
The daily suggested that US President Bill Clinton raise these problems during his meeting with Jiang in Washington.
Instead of the usual assurances foreign leaders give about engaging rather containing an emerging colossus, Clinton should recognize that Jiang heads a chronically weak and unstable country.
"China doesn't need engagement or containment. China needs help," the dispatch concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULT GURU IS SENTENCED TO 7 YEARS IN PRISON FOR FRAUD

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court on Thursday sentenced a cult guru to seven years in prison for fraud.

Taipei District Judge Tsay Kun-hu sentenced both Sung Chi-li, the spiritual leader of the "Sung Chi-li Association," and his head disciple Chen Cheng-dung to seven year prison terms, declaring that the two should be punished for swindling hundreds of millions of NT dollars from the followers of the association.
