Sung, born Sung Gan-lin, was arrested last October on charges of fraud. According to court documents, Sung conspired with Chen and some other defendants to pretend to be a religious guru with seven supernatural powers in order to swindle money from followers.
Chen, who met Sung while they both were serving sentences in Taipei Prison, pretended to be Sung's disciple to testify to what they would later claim were Sung's supernatural powers.

Another defendant, Lo Cheng-hung, a photographer, doctored photos to make Sung appear to be flying atop golden clouds or encircled by halos. The cult leader used the photos as "proof" of his supernatural powers and to solicit donations from his followers.
For his part in the scam, Lo was sentenced on Thursday to two years in prison.
Another defendant, You Fang-chih, wife of Hsieh Chang-ting, the former Democratic Progressive Party vice presidential candidate, was found not guilty of helping Sung find believers.
You had been prosecuted for compiling a book to promote Sung's alleged magical powers and receiving over NT$3 million (US$100,000) in payment for this.

Hsieh told a news conference in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, that he was not surprised by the "not guilty" verdict, saying that his wife's involvement in the case was wholly masterminded by an "anti-Hsieh" ring and underground forces to reduce his political influence.

Around 100 followers of the Sung Chi-li Association were present at the reading of the verdicts, though Sung himself was not. These local believers expressed their unhappiness with the court's decisions.
When Sung was arrested about a year ago, many of his followers prayed on their knees in front of the association's headquarters in Taipei, refusing to believe their guru was a fraud.
You Yin-fu, Sung's lawyer, announced that he will appeal, calling the sentence "unjust" and saying he believes it was imposed under pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ON CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Thursday that the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin showed that the relations between Washington and Beijing are under a new framework.
Chang said that if the relations between Washington and Beijing progress normally under the new framework, this will put a great deal of pressure on the Republic of China in the long run.

Chang was referring to the joint statement issued by Clinton and Jiang on Wednesday, part of which said regular strategic meetings will be held between the two governments at every level, including annual meetings between the two heads of state.
Jiang's visit was the first by a mainland Chinese leader to the United States in 12 years.

On how to deal with the new situation, Chang, the government's top mainland policy maker, said that Taiwan should on one hand step up security talks with high-level US officials, and on the other hand actively seek to break the impasse of stalled cross-strait relations to establish a mechanism of bilateral exchanges.

Stressing that the ROC's stance is clear, Chang said, "The ROC does not want Washington-Beijing relations to undermine the relations between Washington and Taipei, nor should the United States trade the concessions it gets from mainland China at the expense of Taiwan's interests."

He said Washington-Beijing relations should run parallel to those between Washington and Taipei, and that if the United States improves and upgrades its relationship with mainland China, it should also step up its ties with Taiwan.

With Clinton and Jiang pledging regular "strategic meetings," all issues between the two sides will be worked out within these systemic channels, which in the long run will put great pressure on the ROC, Chang said.
Beijing, for example, could use the new channels to undermine US support for the ROC or to add pressure on the ROC's efforts to seek a greater profile in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHEAST ASIAN POLITICS HAVE NOT KEPT UP

TEXT.P: Amid the currency and stock turmoil in Southeast Asia, one factor has been politely overlooked and underplayed, or simply taken for granted -- the web of patronage, cronyism and corruption that inhabits markets and deters effective government action, a Financial Post article pointed out Wednesday.

Clearly, Southeast Asian countries do not have a monopoly on corruption and patronage. Nor is this exclusively a developing country phenomenon, wrote Marie-Jose Kravis. Nonetheless, in this specific instance, the world cannot ignore the deleterious effects corruption has on economic development, she pointed out.

Truthfully, politics have failed to keep up with economics, she observed. "Consequently, governments have shied away from adjustments required to encourage competition and improve economic efficiency," she added.

Generally, Southeast Asian economies have tried to merge their centralized industrial policy process with market forces. The challenge ahead, however, requires "more determined and widespread espousal of markets, decisions by governments to support markets through efficient investments in physical, legal and institutional infrastructure, and greater integration into the world economy," said the columnist who is also a fellow of the Hudson Institute.

Can this be achieved in the current context of centralized decisionmaking, patronage and cronyism? she asked. How can these countries implement measures to diversify ownership and develop property rights and asset exchanges without tackling political reforms? How can they promise to reduce or eliminate arbitrary barriers to entry and exit in various industries without shaking up the protected business monopolies of favored investors? How can they propose to sign international trade agreements and investment codes if they are not willing to guarantee their implementation?

It is indeed difficult to deny that, until now, the Southeast Asian model of economic development has worked. But it is now ill-suited to a world economy that rewards nimbleness, competition, openness and transparency, she said.

The latest financial crisis has, for example, exposed the deficiencies in the banking systems of almost all these countries. The quality and timeliness of information have borne the brunt of unmitigated criticism. Supervision of financial systems has also been a target of complaint. Reform entails restructuring, privatizing and modernizing state-owned banks and the banking system in general. It also requires independent audits and dissemination of information in a useful and timely fashion.

Inevitably, this should expose sweetheart deals and other irregularities. As sounder business practices spread to other industrial sectors, governments will inevitably be challenged, she predicted. Ideally, corruption will begin to wane.

Inevitably, cronyism and patronage prohibit sound decisionmaking and delay elimination of tariffs and obsolete regulation. Greed prevents open markets and competition. Yet, slowly these countries must modernize their political systems as well as their economic plans and business practices.
"We would be remiss if we failed to insist institutionalized corruption and long-term development are incompatible. The issue needs a place on the front burner," she concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUGS OF WAR ARE SAFE IF RULES ARE FOLLOWED: S'PORE EXPERT

TEXT.P: Tugs of war are safe, as long as players are fit and stick to the rules and regulations of the game, say sports officials and experts in Singapore.
In a bizarre tragedy in Taipei last Saturday, two men taking part in a tug of war match had their arms torn off. Another 43 were hurt.
The event, involving 1,600 people -- 800 on each side -- was to have set the world record for the longest tug of war with 150 meters of rope.
The tragedy might have been prevented if the organizers had taken adequate safety precautions, said sports officials here.
"Tug of war is basically not a dangerous sport, but it is extremely strenuous," said S. Govindaraju, chairman of tug of war at the Singapore Amateur Athletic Association (SAAA).
"Most important, players have to be healthy, fit and trained in the game," he said.
The game is popular in Singapore, where universities and many companies organize tug of war games. No serious injuries have been reported over the past two years.
The SAAA, which helped organize a tug of war for the Singapore police force in July, is thinking of setting up training programs this year for other matches.
Training would include endurance-building on the track and in the gym, as well as rope-handling techniques.
Asthmatics, diabetics and people with weak hearts or lungs are also advised to get medical advice before taking part.
Sticking to the rules of the game -- an international competitive sport -- is also important, said Govindaraju.
The International Tug of War Federation has rules governing the number of players, their combined weight and even the way the rope is held, for example.
"For example, there shouldn't be any mass participation, or the situation might get out of control and result in a stampede," he said.

Finally, use common-sense safety precautions, he said. To prevent abrasion, for example, players should don thick, long-sleeved clothing; outdoor participants should wear boots, and indoor participants should wear sports shoes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN NOT MENTIONED IN CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: BERGER
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin did bring up Taiwan in his summit meeting with US President Bill Clinton on Wednesday, but the issue of arms sales to the island did not arise then, said Samuel Berger, White House National Security Advisor.

Referring to the matter of Taiwan, Clinton indicated that the United States will adhere to its "one China" policy and urged dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, and Jiang responded by saying that he is willing to do so, Berger noted in a White House news briefing.
When asked whether the issue of arms sales to Taiwan was mentioned during the summit, Berger said no.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SINGLE STOP' SERVICE POISED TO BOLSTER INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A "single stop" investment service mechanism, proposed by Premier Vincent Siew some two months ago, is slated to begin operations Nov. 3 at the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).

Siew, upon his inauguration as premier on Sept. 1, told the Ministry of Economic Affairs to establish a one stop service system aimed at simplifying investment procedures and spurring investment willingness.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang estimated on Thursday that the number of major investment projects -- those worth over NT$200 million (US$6.6 million) apiece -- will grow 30 percent after the single stop service system, which will help remove investment barriers, is activated.
The investment service center will be divided into five sections, with officials from six Cabinet-level agencies and 33 Taiwan provincial offices as the backbone of the team.

The five sections will be responsible for services related to composite businesses, land acquisition and management, transportation, wildlife conservation, and public utilities, respectively, according to IDB officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG URGES ADHERENCE TO THREE JOINT COMMUNIQUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Edward Han & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: At a ceremony on the White House lawn Wednesday, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin urged the US government to adhere to the three joint communiques signed between Washington and Beijing.

As long as the United States properly handles the Taiwan issue in strict compliance with the principles set forth in the three joint communiques, a sound and stable growth of bilateral relations will surely ensue, Jiang said.
According to observers, the hidden purpose of Jiang's statement is to suffocate Taipei's political maneuverability in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIA OPENS FALCON HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: The first hospital in Saudi Arabia dedicated exclusively to the treatment of falcons has been established in Jeddah.
The hospital has been built as an extension of the Jeddah Veterinary Clinic. It has facilities for more than 50 falcons and has been designed to meet the growing demand from falconers in the country.
Falconry is very popular in the Gulf region, and there are thousands of falcons in various parts of Saudi Arabia.
Before the establishment of this facility, falconers here had to turn to veterinary hospitals and clinics in Dubai and Abu Dhabi.

Dr. Maurice Nicholson, chief veterinary surgeon, said as falcons are caught in the wild, they face problems of stress and nutrition. The longer the birds are kept in captivity, the greater the possibility of sickness, he said.
Nicholson said the majority of falcon diseases are easily preventable or at the least controllable and therefore urged the birds' owners to get them examined routinely.

He said the National Falcon Hospital is not just a place for the treatment of illnesses but also a center for research and development. It will offer assistance, advice and up-to-date information to falconers, the doctor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG OFFERS NO APOLOGY FOR TIANANMEN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin offered no regrets for the Tiananmen Square massacre during his White House visit Wednesday while President Bill Clinton bluntly lectured his guest on human rights during a lively public debate, Canadian media reported.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) said that Jiang clashed with Clinton over human rights and the Tiananmen Square massacre at a news conference in Washington on Wednesday.
Clinton urged "full room for debate, dissent and freedom to worship" in mainland China.

Jiang, however, in response to a reporter's question about the June 1989 incident at Tiananmen Square where an estimated 1,000 people died, said mainland China was facing a political disturbance that disrupted social stability.
Clinton replied that he believes Beijing was on the wrong side of history, CBC TV said.

The Canadian Press (CP) noted the polite but pointed exchange was remarkable for its directness. "It also exposed the kind of divisions the two leaders tried to bridge during a day-long White House meeting," it added.

Human rights is the primary fault line in US-mainland Chinese relations, the CP report said. Jiang tied the issue to Beijing's sovereignty. Clinton warned his counterpart that Beijing's human rights stance puts it on "the wrong side of history."
The Communist leadership's refusal to tolerate political dissent has been a drag on mainland China's influence around the world, the CP quoted Clinton as saying.
"Over the long-run, the societies of the 21st century that will do best will be those that are drawing their stability from their differences," he said as Jiang looked on, according to the CP.

Beijing won a reiteration of Washington's "One China" policy, which calls for a peaceful reconciliation between mainland China and Taiwan. Beijing regards Taiwan as a renegade province, and although Jiang said he favors a negotiated solution, he added that mainland China reserves the right to use force if the island attempts to declare independence, the CP reported.

Although the United States and mainland China share important interests, "we also have fundamental differences, especially concerning human rights and religious freedom," Clinton said, adding that the best way to address them is "directly and personally."
Jiang said he is enjoying his brush with democracy but that "sometimes noises came into my ears."

He was likely alluding to a noisy protest in favor of a free Tibet being held outside the White House. It was led by actor Richard Gere, who told the crowd that six million Tibetans are still living in slavery, the CP noted.
"This is not a cuddly new China we're talking about," he said. "It's the same China we've known for the past 50 years."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR SURGES TO TEN-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The US dollar rallied to a ten-year high against the New Taiwan dollar in the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, finishing at NT$30.944, up NT$0.109 from Wednesday's close.
The greenback had a high of NT$30.99 and a low of NT$30.825 after opening at NT$30.87. Interbank transactions expanded to US$448 million.
Foreign exchange dealers predicted that the US dollar is expected to continue appreciating against the local currency because of heavy selling pressure of the New Taiwan dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS STAGE PROTEST TO JIANG
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A dozen pro-Taiwan independence groups staged a mass protest here Wednesday, the first day of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's state visit to the US capital.

The more than 1,000 protesters, all wearing white T-shirts and chanting slogans such as "Recognize Taiwan's sovereignty, Oppose China's aggression," began their rally at the Washington Monument and then paraded around the White House.

Several key figures of the rally, including representatives of Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party, the Taiwan Independence Party and some US sympathizers, gave speeches to the public, stressing that they wanted to declare the importance of Taiwan independence to the international community on the occasion of Jiang's meeting with US President Bill Clinton.

They later issued a three-point public declaration stating that Taiwan's future should be decided by the Taiwan people and that Beijing should not interfere. They also asked Washington to forswear its "one China policy," and recognize the right of the Taiwan people to build an independent nation.
The protest, which was orderly and peaceful, began in the morning and lasted till the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100 FALL ILL DAILY IN INDONESIA DUE TO HAZE

TEXT.P: An estimated 100 residents of Palangkaraya in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia -- one of the worst affected areas by the country's forest fires and haze -- fall ill with respiratory infections every day.

Tukik Toeman, the head of the provincial health office, was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying Wednesday that a total of 23,303 sufferers of respiratory problems had sought medical attention at local clinics and hospitals between July and September.
He said 11 people had died of the problems in local hospitals during the same period.
The official also called on area residents to reduce their time outdoors. They should also close their doors and windows, and drink more liquids in order to avoid lung irritation caused by the smoke.
The warning is especially aimed at children and elderly people.
"The concentration of dust particles in this region's air has far exceeded the level considered safe for humans," Tukik said.
On Oct. 24, for instance, dust particles reached 2,910 milligrams per cubic meter, or 11 times the safe level of 260 mg/m3.
The Indonesian Ministry of Health recently reported that in each of the 12 provinces it studied, approximately 20,000 people had fallen ill of respiratory problems because of the haze.
The brush and forest fires that have raged for months and choked the region with smoke have brought Indonesia international criticism.
Meanwhile, the Environmental Impact and Management Agency described in its report Wednesday that the forest fire situation has not yet improved.
Satellite monitoring on Tuesday showed that thick, choking smoke still blanketed much of Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADER WORRIED ABOUT EROSION OF U.S. SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 30 (CNA): Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, said Thursday that the United States and mainland China may begin to strengthen their cooperative relations, and that Taiwan should carefully see whether the new relationship may erode U.S. support for Taiwan.
Hsu made the remarks when asked to comment on the summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin Wednesday at the White House.

He said that, judging from the joint statement issued after the meeting, he believes U.S. support for Taiwan remains unchanged. The U.S. government did not mention anything about Taiwan independence, although Beijing has repeatedly urged Washington to oppose Taiwan independence publicly, he pointed out.

The leader of Taiwan's major opposition party said Taiwan people should carefully see whether U.S. support for Taiwan will erode when Washington and Beijing step up their cooperation in international affairs. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CALL FOR EARLY RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS WELCOMED

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang Thursday welcomed President Bill Clinton's call for an early resumption of talks between Taiwan and mainland China.

President Clinton said Wednesday after he talked with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in a summit meeting at the White House that cross-strait issues shall be resolved by the Chinese people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait by peaceful means, and that the United States would like to see an early resumption of talks between the two sides.

Wang welcomed President Clinton's call, and said it is Beijing's refusal to abandon the use of military force against Taiwan that hinders the improvement of cross-strait relations. Jiang said Wednesday that as the Taiwan issue is connected with the sovereignty of mainland China, "we can not promise to abandon force."
Wang said Beijing's early decision to end its hostile posture toward Taiwan and resume cross-strait talks is essential to the promotion of cross-strait economic and trade relations. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA OFFICIAL SEES NOTHING NEW IN JIANG'S REMARKS ABOUT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Minister Lin Yih-fu said Thursday that he sees nothing new in the statement made by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin Wednesday in Washington about Taiwan, and that Taiwan's economic and trade relations with the mainland will continue as usual.

Lin also said Taiwan's economic and trade policy toward the mainland will remain unchanged. Taiwan's trade surplus with the mainland totaled US$10.8 billion in the first eight months of this year. Exports to the mainland grew 6.3 percent over the same period of last year, he added.

He said the government will continue to implement the policy aimed at encouarging Taiwan investors to "make no haste, and be patient" when they consider making major investments on the Chinese mainland. (by Ed Hsieh)

DOC.HEADLINE: CULT GURU RECEIVES SEVEN-YEAR PRISON TERM

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court on Thursday sentenced mystic cult guru Sung Chi-li to a seven-year prison term for fraud, after a court case which began in December last year.

Sung's head disciple, Chen Cheng-dung, also received seven years, while Lo Cheng-hung, a photographer, was sentenced to two years. Fifteen other defendants, all of whom were Sung's devoted followers, were acquitted.

Court documents said that Sung conspired with the other defendants to masquerade as a religious guru with seven supernatural powers. The cult used photographs, doctored by Lo, showing Sung floating in the sky with an aureole around his head, to swindle millions of Taiwan dollars from the cult members.

Chen and Sung first met in Taipei Prison, where the two were serving jail terms for other convictions. They decided to create a mystic cult around Sung, who would claim to have supernatural powers, including the ability to duplicate himself. Chen's job was to testify to the authenticity of Sung's magical powers.

The court said that the other 15 defendants, who were charged with either helping Sung recruit believers or writing articles and books testifying to Sung's unusual powers, were found not guilty due to insufficient evidence.

Among the acquitted co-defendants was You Fang-chih, wife of opposition Democratic Progress Party heavyweight Hsieh Chang-ting. You was accused of compiling a book to promote Sung's alleged powers for which she received some NT$3,530,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REVIEWS RESTRUCTURED ARMY BRIGADES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday reviewed two newly restructured army units in northern Taiwan -- the armored infantry brigade and the airborne cavalry brigade.
The formation of the two brigades is part of the Republic of China's military modernization plan aimed at streamlining the country's military and establishing an elite deterrent force.

Lee first reviewed the armored infantry brigade, which has integrated elements of the original armored and infantry brigades, at the Hukou army base in Hsinchu County, some 75 km south of the capital, Taipei. Later in the day, he reviewed the airborne cavalry brigade at the Lungtan military base in northern Taoyuan County.
The formation of the new combined brigades marks the first time in decades that the ROC military has restructured its fundamental strategic units.
More than 4,300 military servicemen and hundreds of armored vehicles, tanks and artillery pieces, as well as various types of helicopter, took part in the review.
In a speech to the armored infantry brigade, the president said that the military restructuring plan is critical to upgrading Taiwan's defense capabilities.

"The organization of the two combined army brigades, albeit still at an experimental stage, marks a big step forward in our second-generation military build-up program," Lee said, stressing that Taiwan should heighten its vigilance against the potential threat posed by Beijing and accelerate the implementation of the military streamlining plan to ensure national security.
Military spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding told assembled press covering the events that the formation of the new combined brigades marks a distinct change in Taiwan's defense strategy and tactics.

The combined brigades will replace the division as the fundamental strategic unit, Kung said, adding that they will be more responsive to emergency situations. He elaborated further, saying the new brigades will be faster, more mechanized and equipped with night-time combat capabilities.

Military experts said the most dramatic change to Taiwan's defense strategy will come with the inauguration of the airborne attack brigade, comprising a scout helicopter battalion, an attack helicopter battalion, a special operations helicopter battalion, a support battalion and an aircraft repair and maintenance workshop. The brigade is equipped with AH-1W gunships, OH-58D Super Cobra scout/attack helicopters, B-234 transport helicopters and OH-1H helicopters.

The army plans to integrate the existing aviation groups and airborne brigades into three airborne cavalry brigades. In addition to the brigade at Lungtan, the army will deploy similar brigades in central and southern Taiwan.

In preparation for the formation of these additional airborne cavalry brigades, the army has struck deals with the United States for the purchase of 21 AH-1W gunships and OH-58D Super Cobra helicopters, and 12 B-234 transport helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TO MARK FIFTIETH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Renato Ruggiero, Director General of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), announced on Thursday that his office will hold a high-profile celebration on May 20, 1998 to mark the 50th anniversary of the signing of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

"Today marks the 50th anniversary of the birth of the multilateral trading system. The creation of this system surely ranks among the greatest economic achievements of the post-war era. For the first time, the principle of non-discrimination in trade relations was applied on a multilateral basis. Through this principle, the same rights of market access were extended to all 23 of the original signing nations, developed and developing alike. Today, the World Trade Organization, the offspring of the GATT, has 132 members, all of which have adopted the principle of non-discrimination. It is difficult to overstate the contribution of this basic principle to growth and development on a world scale and to the establishment of closer relations among nations," Ruggiero said.

He went on: "On May 20, 1998, we will hold a high-profile celebration to mark the occasion of these 50 years and highlight for the citizens of the world the contribution this system has made to global peace and prosperity."

On October 30, 1947, the GATT was signed by 23 nations -- 12 developed and 11 developing economies -- at the Palais des Nations in Geneva. The agreement contained tariff concessions agreed to during the first multilateral trade negotiations and a set of rules designed to prevent these concessions from being frustrated by restrictive trade measures.

On January 1, 1948, GATT came into force. The 23 founding members were: Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Burma, Canada, Ceylon, Chile, China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, France, India, Lebanon, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan, Rhodesia, Syria, South Africa, the United Kingdom and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAUDS US FOR STANCE ON TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Friday expressed admiration for the consistent stance of the United States on the Taiwan issue during the meetings in Washington on Oct. 29-30 between President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

A statement issued by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs immediately after the Clinton-Jiang summit said the United States has not departed from its long-standing stance on the Taiwan issue and its commitment to the ROC.

Washington has repeatedly assured the ROC of its policy of not allowing US dealings with Beijing to affect the interests of the ROC and this policy remains unchanged, the statement said. The statement also praised Clinton for his firm stance on democracy, freedom and human rights issues in his talks with Jiang.
During his meetings with Jiang, Clinton said the Taiwan issue should be resolved by the Chinese themselves through peaceful means, although Washington continues to stick to its one-China policy.

The ROC government welcomes high-level contacts between Washington and Beijing if such engagements can contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and help promote further reform, openness and human rights development on the Chinese mainland, the statement continued.

However, the ROC government will continue to monitor closely the development of relations between mainland China and the United States, in order to guard against plots by Beijing to undermine the interests of the ROC under the cover of improving ties with the United States, the statement said.

"We must stress that efforts made by the United States to improve its ties with mainland China should not affect the freedom, democracy and human rights of the Republic of China or any other regions in the world," it said.

The statement also said that the ROC will strengthen its mutually beneficial relations with the United States, while pushing for pragmatic diplomacy and an increase in reciprocal cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges to ensure the peace and prosperity of the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL'S MAINLAND OFFICE SEEKS COOPERATION WITH MAINLAND COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: An official from China Airlines (CAL) said on Thursday that the purpose of a representative office set up by the company in mainland China in June is to seek business cooperation with mainland China airline companies.

Yuang Chen, CAL's public relations director, denied that the establishment of a mainland office was to pave the way for direct cross-strait air transport links, which are still banned by the government.

The mainland office belongs to an affiliate of CAL which is registered in the Virgin Islands and has its headquarters in Hong Kong, although its director, Tseng Wei-yuan, is an ROC national, Yuang said.

Yuang said that following the setting up of the office, CAL has reached business cooperation agreements with the mainland's Air China, China Eastern Airline and China Northern Airline to facilitate trips to the mainland by passengers from Taiwan.
In addition, he noted, several mainland aviation officials from Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou visited Taiwan at CAL's invitation in July to talk about business cooperation.
Despite CAL's desire to see the opening of direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Yuang said that the government is the final decision-maker of such a politically sensitive issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S ITA MEMBERSHIP MAY HAVE IMPACT ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The impact on Taiwan of mainland China's membership of the Information Technology Agreement (ITA) under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) remains to be seen, Taiwan's economic minister said on Thursday.

Wang Chih-kang said that once the mainland becomes a signatory to the ITA, it will influence the Taiwan information industry's willingness to invest in the mainland, but on the other hand, it will benefit Taiwan's exports of information products to the mainland due to low or even zero tariffs on such products.

Wang said that Taiwan has reached agreement with the signatories of the ITA, including the US and Japan, on the gradual elimination of tariffs on information products. Except for eight special items on which tariffs will not be eliminated until 2002, tariffs on the other 201 information items are to be reduced to zero in four stages by Jan. 1, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PRESS COMMENT ON STOCK MARKET TURMOIL

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from an editorial carried in Thursday's edition of local English-language daily the China News, entitled "Patience needed, not courage."

"No government official has any right to tell investors not to sell their stocks or their currency. If Taiwan's mom 'n pop stock punters believe the Taiex is too high, then it is too high. If the government wants to use its own money to buy their stocks, that's fine, but it had better know what it is doing. Because if the market continues to fall, as it did yesterday (Wednesday), then the public has every right to complain that its hard-earned taxes are being wasted in an attempt to interfere with market forces...

"In fact, a quick look at the turmoil which has gripped regional stock and currency markets, and subsequently spread to the rest of the world, would suggest... what is being experienced is not a meltdown, but a big and dramatic correction.

"Taiwan has more to be optimistic about than all its neighbors... Just as it was the Asia-Pacific's best-performing market before the recent turbulence, so it will likely be at the forefront of a region-wide recovery.

"Various spokesmen have been at pains to point out that average price-earnings ratios are down to about 25... On a historical basis, this is high compared to mature economies, but reasonable for Taiwan.

"To gain a broader understanding of why Taiwan ought to be feeling more comfortable about its economic future than it is at present, a closer look at its economic make-up is needed. Unlike Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia, Taiwan has not been borrowing beyond its means and is not dependent on massive capital infusions to spur growth. Basically, it is more mature than the Southeast Asian tigers... Most important is that Taiwan's markets are not ruled by institutional investors, as much of the region is. Foreign funds make up less than four percent of trading here.

"If the government is prepared to lead by example, with a sincere and realistic approach to instilling confidence in its markets, then there is cause to believe Taiwan will resume its successful ways in the months to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC HIGHLIGHTS 'PROFOUND DIFFERENCE' BETWEEN US, M'LAND CHINA ON HUMAN

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcaster highlighted the "profound and public disagreement" over human rights between the presidents of the United States and mainland China at the end of their summit Wednesday.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. headlined the story in its major news program, "The World at Six." It noted that Jiang Zemin's visit to the White House marked the first US-China summit since the Tiananmen Square massacre eight years ago.

Bill Clinton, despite scattered protests from left- and right-wing groups, is pursuing his policy of "cooperation, not confrontation" with mainland China, the CBC pointed out. But he dropped his diplomatic language when he sharply criticized mainland China's activities in the Tiananmen Square, and Jiang was "just as sharp in his responses," it said.

Jiang, speaking through an interpreter, repeated the Chinese line that the army had to act to prevent anarchy in Tiananmen Square: "If a country with over 1.2 billion population does not enjoy social and political stability, it cannot possibly have the situation of reform and opening up that we're having today."
Bill Clinton, gripping the lectern in impatience, shot back: "We have a very different view of the meaning of the events in Tiananmen Square," according to a CBC report from Washington, DC.

And so at the edgy and surprisingly lengthy debate between the two leaders, it was not, as you might expect, a debate either man wants, the report said. "We have profound disagreements," Clinton was quoted as saying. "But that does not mean this visit should not have occurred or that we don't have a big interest in continuing to work together."

The summit did result in a promise from mainland China to limit exports of dangerous nucleus technology, and an agreement to meet every year, the report pointed out. Next year, Clinton will go to mainland China.

It was not a lot to show for the meeting, but then not a lot was expected, said the report. Both mainland Chinese and US officials stressed the importance of the symbolism that the summit occurred at all, given the testiness of the past relations, it noted.
It pointed to the scenes across the street from the summit site, where demonstrators chanted slogans all day on mainland China's records on everything from Tibet to religious freedom.

However intransigent Jiang sounded about Tiananmen Square, mainland China has agreed to allow religious leaders to visit. And it has agreed, at least, to ongoing talks about human rights, "something Jiang will hear more about tomorrow, when he meets with members of Congress," the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMPTION OF TEXTILE INCREASING

TEXT.P: According to a report presented at the Plenary Meeting of the International Cotton Advisory Committee convening in Asuncion, the world textile consumption of end-use products increased 3.1 percent in 1996, more than double the rate of growth in 1995.
The increased consumption was attributed to faster global economic growth last year.

Current projections for income, population and price suggest that the world textile consumption will increase 2.6% in 1997 and 1998, and 2.4% in 1999. Long-term projections suggest that the world textile consumption could increase at an average annual rate of 2.3% through 2005, the report indicated.

The report also said that after seven years of stagnation at about 18.5 million tons, world cotton consumption at the end-use level increased 1.9% to reach a new record high of 19 million tons in 1996.

Consumption of cotton is expected to increase at an average annual rate of 1.9% during the next three years to reach 20 million in 1999. But due to the fact that consumption of non-cotton fibers continued to expand faster than the consumption of cotton, the market share of cotton declined for the sixth consecutive year to reach a 44.7% share last year. Current projections suggest that cotton will continue to lose its share of the world textile market, dipping to 43.7% in 2000 and 42.8% in 2005.

World production of cotton and chemical fiber yarn increased 2.9% in 1996, reflecting the rapid increase in end-use consumption of textiles. By 1998, world production of cotton yarn is expected to reach 18.5 million tons, with the chemical yarn reaching 24 million tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYSTS DISCUSS CLINTON'S "ONE CHINA" PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's statement following his meeting on Wednesday with mainland China's President Jiang Zemin that the US will continue to stick to its "one China" policy has sparked heated discussion among local scholars, experts and politicians.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the Forward Looking Policy Center on the impact of Wednesday's Clinton-Jiang meeting, Chiu Chao-lin, a researcher at Taiwan's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, said the meeting did not totally go against Taiwan's interest. She said Washington's cautious handling of the Taiwan issue and its emergent strategic partnership with mainland China will also help maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait.

However, she pointed out that the government should work out new strategies to deal with its relations with mainland China and other countries, as Clinton has linked his "one China" principle to Taiwan's democratization and prosperity.

Chang Lin-cheng, a professor of political science at National Taiwan University, said Taiwan will become the loser in the Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangle if it seeks to distance itself from the "one China" framework.

Lee Ying-yuan, a legislator of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), disagreed with Chang, saying Taiwan should continue maintaining its sovereignty and should seek better relations with the US, Japan and the countries of Southeast Asia because Taiwan's location is of vital importance to the security of those countries.

New Party Legislator Kao Hui-yu said Taiwan will face new challenges in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang meeting amid the increasingly cordial ties between the West and the mainland. She urged the government to thoroughly review its policy toward mainland China and adopt a more pragmatic approach to dealing with Beijing.

Commenting on remarks by mainland China's Vice Premier Qian Qichen to the media following the Clinton-Jiang meeting that Clinton had made it clear to Jiang that the US will not support Taiwan independence, will not support Taiwan's membership in the United Nations and will not recognize "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," both DPP and New Party officials in charge of their parties' mainland policy said they were not surprised by Qian's statement.

Yen Wan-chin, head of the DPP's Mainland Affairs Department, said Taiwan should pay attention to the potential impact of the meeting on US arms sales to Taiwan and on the exchange of ranking officials between Taiwan and the US, since Washington is actively seeking Beijing's participation in the Asia-Pacific security framework advocated by Washington and Tokyo.

Lee Ching-hua, convener of the New Party's Cross-Strait Affairs Committee, pointed out that Clinton's statement is an indication that Taiwan's hope that Washington can develop parallel relationships with Taipei and Beijing is unrealistic. In fact, he said, the relationship between Taipei, Washington, and Beijing is triangular.

Lee further said that time is not on Taiwan's side and that the government should try to reopen cross-strait talks, the sooner the better, as Beijing has taken an increasingly tough stand on issues of mutual concern such as the "three links" and Taiwan's presence in the international community.

However, Yang Kai-huang, political science professor at Soochow University, said the Clinton-Jiang talks have not extended beyond the terms of the three communiques signed by Washington and Beijing. He said Clinton's "three no's" will have no substantial impact on Taiwan-US relations, putting forward the opinion that the purpose of Clinton's statement was aimed at forestalling instability in the Taiwan Strait in order to protect US interests in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: `TAIWAN ISSUE' IS ONE OF DEMOCRACY, FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui was quoted as saying on Thursday that the so-called "Taiwan issue" is simply one of democracy, freedom and human rights.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who briefed the president early on Thursday on the just-concluded summit between mainland China's Jiang Zemin and US President Bill Clinton, told a group of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators afterward that Lee, taking note of Jiang's annoyance at Clinton's insistence on mentioning democracy, freedom and human rights at the talks, said that it is very clear that the Taiwan issue is simply the issue of democracy, freedom and human rights.

Describing the three principles as the founding principles of both the Republic of China and the United States, Hu told the lawmakers that Clinton's emphasis on them serves both the interest of Washington and Taipei.
The KMT Legislature caucus invited Hu to analyze the outcome of the talks which took place early Thursday morning, Taiwan time.
Despite pressure from Jiang, Clinton's stance on Taiwan remains unchanged, said Hu.

"There is no doubt that Jiang's summit with Clinton is a plus for Washington-Beijing ties," the former ROC envoy to Washington said, "but Washington has obviously taken heed of Taipei's appeal not to mend fences with Beijing at Taipei's expense."

Meanwhile Premier Vincent Siew issued a directive at a regular cabinet meeting after Hu's briefing, saying that while the government welcomes the improvement in ties between Beijing and Washington in the context of helping stabilize the region, Taiwan should still guard against a new campaign by Beijing to isolate the island in the international community after the easing of tension with Washington.

While heaving a sigh of relief at America's adherence to its current policy toward Taiwan, the premier vowed to keep a close watch on the developments in Beijing-Washington ties and to remain prepared for any eventuality.
He urged Washington to help Taipei balance the Beijing-Washington-Taipei relations by improving Taipei-Washington ties as well as supporting the island's bids to join various international groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RANKS 3RD IN GLOBAL ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks second in Asia and third worldwide in an Economic Fundamental Health Rating compiled by the Royal Bank of Canada.
The bank rated the fundamentals of 30 major economies around the world on a scale of zero to 10 points. Singapore received the highest ranking, with 10 points.
Among Asian economies, Taiwan followed with 9.1 points, higher than Japan's 8.8 points, South Korea's 8.4 and Hong Kong's 7.7.
Compared with European economies, Taiwan trailed only Norway, which received a rating of 9.5 points.
The ratings of other European economies, including Belgium, Switzerland, Denmark, Germany and the Netherlands, ranged between 7.9 and 7.3 points. Britain tallied a mere 3.4 points.

South Africa, the only African country included in the study conducted by Canada's largest bank, received a poor bill of health for economic fundamentals, garnering a one-point rating. Mexico was the second worst, with a rating of 2.1 points. Canada boasted a rating of six points, compared to the United States' 3.8 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIT CHAIRMAN ARRIVING SATURDAY FOR 9-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Saturday for a nine-day visit.
This will be Bush's first trip to Taiwan since he assumed office in early September.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said Bush is expected to brief Republic of China officials on the content of summit talks between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in the White House on Oct. 29.
In addition to meeting with senior ROC officials and local celebrities, Bush will also inspect AIT operations in Taiwan and meet with the local press during his stay here.
The AIT was established by American authorities in 1979 to handle relations with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Bush, who has a good command of Mandarin Chinese, was a Chinese affairs expert with the Central Intelligence Agency before assuming his current post. With a doctorate in Chinese studies from Colombia University in New York, Bush also once served with the Asia-Pacific affairs sub-committee at the US Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH ALSACE WOOING TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Alsace region in eastern France is wooing Taiwan investors with open arms, the Latest News of Alsace reported on Thursday.

Taipei Representative in France Kuo Wei-fan, the ROC's de facto ambassador to that European country, led a delegation of government officials and Taiwan business leaders to Alsace on Thursday for a fact-finding tour of the pivotal French industrial area.

Kuo and the dozen-member delegation received a warm greeting when they arrived in Strasbourg. Among those on hand to meet them were the Alsace governor, speaker of the Alsace legislature and local government officials.

The region of Alsace, Lorraine and Saar, which borders Germany, has been a "golden triangle" of heavy industry in Western Europe. Formerly a steel industry hub due to its coal production, the triangle is nowadays a center of precision and high-technology industries.

Human talent and capital have steadily flowed into the region in recent years, attracted by its high-caliber manufacturing capacity, commendable social conditions, sound infrastructure development, and quality financial, telecommunications and transport service systems.
The latest joint-venture between Germany's Daimler-Mercedes and Swiss timepiece maker Swatch to make the environmentally friendly "Smart" compact car is located in Lorraine.

In an interview with the paper, Kuo said Taiwan is currently the seventh largest capital source in the world. Until recently, a great majority of Taiwan investments in Europe have centered in the Netherlands, England and Ireland, mainly because there are fewer language barriers existing in those countries, Kuo noted.

That investment pattern could be reversed if more Taiwan businesses opt to relocate their operations to Alsace, which is highly promising as a gateway for Taiwan manufacturers and traders to other major markets in France, Belgium, Holland and Switzerland, he added.
So far there is only one Taiwan company, a liquid crystal display manufacturer, operating in the Alsace region.
Kuo and his mission will also visit other industrial cities in the region, including Colnar and Mulhouse, to measure the investment climate there.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATION MARKS BIRTH ANNIVERSARY OF GENERALISSIMO

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui presided over a ceremony at the Presidential Office on Friday to mark the 111th birth anniversary of the late President and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who passed away in 1975.

More than 500 people, including Vice President Lien Chan, senior central and local government officials, elected representatives and overseas Chinese community representatives, attended the memorial gathering.
Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh delivered a speech at the ceremony, recounting the late president's outstanding achievements during his lifetime.

Hsu said Chiang had devoted his lifetime to eradicating any hurdles to the implementation of the ROC national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and to building the ROC into a prosperous constitutional democracy.
"Chiang's courage and spirit in overcoming difficulties has been a major source of strength and inspiration for our country," Hsu noted.

With the concerted efforts of the government and people, Hsu said, the ROC has managed to create the first-stage "Taiwan experience," which is acknowledged around the world and has enabled local people to lead materially affluent lives.

However, Hsu said, Taiwan's development in the areas of culture and the arts has failed to parallel its successes in economic progress. "As a result, our society has suffered from moral decline and social disorder in recent years."

In commemorating the late president, Hsu said, local people should faithfully support the spiritual revitalization campaign initiated by President Lee and promote a second-stage "Taiwan experience," which will be characterized by a balance between spiritual and material development.

After the ceremony, Vice Premier John Chang visited Generalissimo Chiang's temporary mausoleum in Tzuhu, Taoyuan County, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei, to pay his tributes to the late national leader. Chang is an illegitimate son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, who was the generalissimo's eldest son.
Many elderly retired soldiers and civilians also visited Tzuhu to pay tribute to the late leader.
Meanwhile, hundreds of overseas Chinese representatives gathered at the National Concert Hall in the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei to mark the anniversary.
Speaking on the occasion, James Chu, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said the late president had strived to develop Taiwan as a bastion for building a free and democratic China.

Despite Beijing's incessant efforts to block Taiwan's presence in the international community, Chu said, the ROC government has firmly implemented liberal economic policies and promoted democratic reforms.
"I earnestly hope that all overseas Chinese compatriots will continue to support the ROC's consistent policy and its efforts to expand its international breathing space," Chu urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO DEVISE STRATEGY FOR POST-SUMMIT ERA

TEXT.P: A group of local scholars on Friday urged the government to formulate strategies to cope with new developments in the wake of a high-profile summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in the White House on Oct. 29.
The academics made the call at a seminar on relations across the Taiwan Strait in the post-summit era.
Professor Chang Lin-cheng of National Taiwan University said the United States and mainland China have decided to work toward a long-term strategic partnership following the Clinton-Jiang summit.

"The decision was made after prudent consideration," Chang said, adding that a constructive partnership with Washington is expected to increase Beijing's leverage in dealing with Taiwan-related issues.

Echoing Chang's views, National Chengchi University professor Shaw Chung-hai said although Taipei claims that the Washington-Beijing strategic partnership is more symbolic than substantive, it signals that the two sides will work more closely in the international arena in the future.
As a result, Shwa warned, Beijing will have a louder voice in the global community, while Taiwan's international status will be further weakened.

Professor Pan Hsi-tang of Tamkang University said the strategic partnership implies an alliance in which the United States and mainland China cooperate with one another despite holding divergent views on certain issues.

In the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit, Pan said, the ROC government should take the initiative to prevent Taiwan from being sidelined in the critical triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relationship. "If that fails, Taiwan's presence in the international community will be further constricted," he asserted.

Touching on cross-strait affairs, Pan said whether Taiwan can convince Washington to maintain a balance between relations with Beijing and Taipei in the post-summit era will hinge on its ability to reduce cross-strait tensions and resume regular dialogue with the mainland in the shortest time possible.

Wei Yun, a professor at National Chiaotung University, said the government has been too sensitive in its handling cross-strait affairs. He urged the government to make an overall review of the country's development policy and to prevent its pragmatic diplomacy initiatives from hindering cross-strait rapprochement.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUME CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE 'THE SOONER, THE BETTER': HU

TEXT.P: Commenting on a call for resumption of talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait which was issued upon conclusion of this week's Clinton-Jiang summit, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu expressed hope on Friday that the dialogue will be resumed "the sooner, the better."

The two sides should "restart from where the talks broke up," without setting any preconditions, Hu said. Beijing unilaterally suspended dialogue with Taipei in protest at ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995.

Hu's remarks were made in downtown Taichung, central Taiwan, where he was attending a luncheon hosted by retired servicemen on the occasion of the 111th birth anniversary of the late President and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Although hoping that the cross-strait dialogue will be resumed at an early date, Hu said the actual timeframe will be determined by the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

On speculation that next spring will be the most likely juncture for the resumption of talks, Hu asked the Taiwan public to adopt a "wait and see" attitude, adding that a number of objective and subjective factors still must be considered.
In addition to urging an early resumption of the cross-strait dialogue, Hu also called for an upgrading of bilateral relations between Taiwan and the United States.

Hu suggested that more frequent and regular meetings as well as increased channels of communication between high-level officials from the United States and the ROC would be useful in allowing Americans to better understand Taiwan's situation and its needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 4TH LARGEST FDI SUPPLIER AMONG DEVELOPING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the fourth largest "foreign direct investment" (FDI) supplier among developing countries in 1996, according to a report released by the United Nations recently.
Taiwan trailed Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea, but ranked ahead of mainland China, which placed fifth.

The UN report said global "foreign direct investment" amounted to US$34.7 billion in 1996, up 2 percent from the 1995 level, while global inbound foreign investment rose 10 percent to US$34.9 billion.
Among developed economies, the top three FDI recipients were the United States, Britain and France in that order. Belgium and Luxembourg tied at fourth place, while Canada ranked fifth.
The top five developed FDI suppliers were the United States, Britain, Germany, France and Japan in descending order.
Among developing economies, the top five FDI recipients were mainland China, Brazil, Singapore, Indonesia and Mexico.

Between 1995 and 1996, the United States and mainland China absorbed one-third of the global FDI capital, while the FDI capital flowing out of the United States and Britain accounted for 40 percent of the total.
The report said developing countries in Asia will be the most attractive investment destinations for multinational business groups over the next five years.

Economics Ministry officials said Asian countries attracted 85 percent of total overseas investments by Taiwan companies as of June this year. "This indicates that local businesspeople's investment activities are consistent with the general world trend," an official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG GETS LECTURED BY AMERICAN POLITICIANS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin came face to face with some of his harshest critics Thursday as he met with members of the US Congress, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported.
The confrontation came a day after Jiang and US President Bill Clinton sparred over human rights.
Jiang said that since mainland China opened to the world in the 1970s, "the Chinese people have enjoyed a much better life, and it has intensified efforts to improve democracy and the legal system."
US House Speaker Newt Gingrich called the frank encounter an "encouraging dialogue" that will create a "framework for a peaceful evolution" of relations between the United States and mainland China.

He said Jiang invited him to visit Tibet. "I reminded our Chinese guests that you cannot have economic freedom without political freedom, and you cannot have political freedom without religious freedom," Gingrich was quoted as saying.

Jiang was not met by protesters on the Capitol Hill, according to the CBC. On Wednesday, more than 1,000 shouted anti-mainland China, pro-Tibet and pro-Taiwan slogans across from the White House, it noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESS DELIVERS CANDID MESSAGE TO JIANG

TEXT.P: US House Speaker Newt Gingrich (R-Ga.) said Thursday he believes that after a meeting with members of the US Congress in the Capitol, President Jiang Zemin of mainland China now has a clear understanding of the US position that Beijing should not use force against Taiwan.

Briefing the press at a stakeout in a hallway of the Capitol building about a breakfast meeting between Jiang and some 50 members of Congress, Gingrich said, "I do think they understand clearly our commitment to Taiwan not being coerced militarily."

Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.), who hosted the breakfast, termed the one-hour meeting with Jiang as "excellent." He said he had never attended a meeting with the leader of another country where members of Congress were "more candid and more succinct" in their comments and questions.
"We touched on every important issue that has been raised before," he said.

More than 10 Republicans and Democrats from both the Senate and the House of Representatives asked questions about mainland China's human rights violations, religious persecution, coercive abortion policy, nuclear proliferation and repression in Tibet. Jiang gave his answers en bloc.

Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), a critic of Beijing's human rights abuses since the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, said Jiang's responses to the questions were "evasive." For example, on the issue of forced abortion, Jiang said his country is so large that there may be a case or two, but he does know about it.

Jiang also denied there is religious persecution in mainland China and Tibet. He talked about how he goes to religious festivals and meets with religious leaders to prove there is religious freedom in his country.

Pelosi said she was "most disappointed" at Jiang's response to the proliferation issue. He referred the question to his Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, who said that Beijing has never been engaged in the proliferation of nuclear technology.
Senate Minority leader Tom Daschle (D-S.D.) had the impression that some of Jiang's answers were candid, some were "less complete and evasive clearly."
Daschle pointed out that those members of Congress -- both Democrats and Republicans -- who attended the breakfast were united and spoke with one voice to Jiang.

"I think it's clear he left here with a clear understanding of the importance, the consequence and the significance that we put to these issues. He got it from the president, and now he got it from the Congress."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SATISFIED WITH US HANDLING OF CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) here said Thursday that it is satisfied with US President Bill Clinton's pledge to maintain friendly, open relations with Taiwan following his summit with mainland Chinese Presdient Jiang Zemin.
TECRO noted in a statement that Clinton also emphasized the importance of the triangular relationships, between Washington and Beijing, Washington and Taipei, and Taipei and Beijing.
It said it is pleased that President Clinton and his administration stood firm and handled US policy towards both sides of the Taiwan Strait in a balanced manner at the summit.

A traditional friend of America which shares its values of respect for freedom, human rights, democracy and the rule of law, the TECRO went on, Taipei will continue to work with the US government and people to strengthen the bilateral relationship parallel with that between Washington and Beijing within the policy framework enunciated by Clinton, in order to contribute to the stability of the Taiwan Straits and the peace of the region.

While Washington's decision to expand its high-level exchanges with Beijing is aimed to promote regional peace and stability and democratic development on the China mainland, the TECRO said, it must remain vigilant about possible attempts by Beijing to sabotage Taipei's ties with Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTH HONORS SIX ASSURANCES MADE TO TAIPEI IN 1982

TEXT.P: The assistant secretary of state for East Asia and the Pacific has reaffirmed that he will remain committed in his current capacity to assurances given by the Reagan administration that the United States will not pressure Taipei to negotiate with Beijing.

Stanley Roth made the commitment to Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who submitted written questions during Roth's confirmation hearing in July as to whether the nominee would reaffirm his commitment to these assurances, whether he had ever acted contrary to these assurances by, for example, exerting pressure on Taipei to enter negotiations with Beijing?

In a written reply made available here recently, Roth said: "Yes, I would like to reaffirm my personal commitment to all six of these reassurances. It is my understanding that this is the Administration's policy as well. During my service in the executive branch, I have respected all of these assurances. If confirmed as assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, I will remain committed to the assurances as well as to the requirements of the Taiwan Relations Act."

During the process of discussions on the 1982 joint communique between Washington and Beijing on US arms sales to Taiwan, the United States kept Taipei informed of the developments, and Taipei expressed to Washington its consistent position of firmly opposing the issuance of the document.
On July 14, 1982, the Reagan administration, through appropriate channels, made it known to Taipei that the US government:
--had not agreed to set a date for ending arms sales to Taipei;
--had not agreed to hold prior consultations with Beijing on arms sales to Taipei;
--would not play any mediation role between Taipei and Beijing;
--had not agreed to revise the Taiwan Relations Act;
--had not altered its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan; and
--would not exert pressure on Taipei to enter negotiations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS TRANSCEND CULTURAL DIFFERENCES: MP

TEXT.P: A Canadian member of parliament said Thursday that human rights transcend cultural differences and that the regime in Beijing has to understand that human rights and commerce are "the two halves of the same quote."

Keith Martin (B.C.-Reform) noted that "without good human rights, you don't maximize your commerce and without commerce, you don't have adequate human rights." In order to have an environment in which commerce can take place effectively, you need good human rights, he said.

Commenting on mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's intransigence on the human rights question at a White House press conference Wednesday, Martin said he suspects the Chinese leadership feels that to yield on that issue "might be a threat to their power base."
He proposed that Canada should work cooperatively with mainland China and other countries in order to improve the human rights situation around the world.

On Jiang's statement that Beijing wants to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully but reserves the right to use force in the event the island opts for independence, Martin commented: "You can't have it both ways."

The Chinese position that Taiwan is purely a domestic issue, "belies a fear factor" that the rest of the world might be against their instincts to save face and to issue threats, he pointed out. So they take a very aggressive stance, he added.

"We have to break down that fear factor," whether in dealing with North Korea or China, because nothing is going to the table to be negotiated and nothing is going to be resolved if they keep using threats or forceful language, said the MP.

He said the Canadian government should "get involved" in the Taiwan-China dispute more actively. Ottawa voiced its concerns when the missile crisis was escalating in the run up to Taiwan's first presidential election in the spring of 1996.
Martin said he will present a private member's bill to the parliament in about two weeks urging the government to take a "preventive" measure on the foreign policy front.
In regard to the future of Taiwan, he is for a democratic process in which the people there can freely and openly express their views and make their own choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFERENCES REMAIN BETWEEN US, CHINA ON KEY ISSUES

TEXT.P: Despite a significant agreement on nuclear nonproliferation between US President Bill Clinton and his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, following their summit in Washington, huge differences remain between Washington and Beijing on Taiwan, Tibet and human rights issues.

In an editorial headlined "China Flexes Muscles on World Stage," mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday said Jiang Zemin has been received in Washington with all the panoply of official homage he demanded as a world leader meeting one of his counterparts.

"But the pomp and circumstances surrounding the visit cannot disguise two fundamentals: It is ultimate irrelevant to China's president what his people think of the visit and that for US President Bill Clinton, his newfound interest in a constructive engagement with China in the US," the editorial says.

The editorial says Clinton's warning to Jiang not to minimize the big differences that remain between the two countries concerning human rights was directed at the US Congress and not the Chinese people.

"(US) Republicans are opposed to closer links with China until they perceive some action from the Chinese authorities to accept an American view on Taiwan, Tibet and Tiananmen Square. They will get no joy from Mr. Jiang who maintains all these issues are internal matters which China will handle in its own way and in its own good time," the editorial says.
Despite such huge differences on these issues, the editorial says Jiang's visit to the United States should not "be downplayed."

"The commitment of the two leaders to hold regular summits as part of the progress towards a 'strategic partnership' cannot be anything other than a major plus for world peace. Particularly when the major flashpoint in our region is the Korean Peninsula, it is important for the US and China should have some framework in which each other's position can be discussed and it is to be hoped, understood. It is in no country's interest -- least of all a trading partner such as Australia -- that a Korean conflict develop."

The editorial says the agreement on "nuclear issues -- specifically after China pledged to impose tighter export controls on nuclear weapons technology -- is probably the most significant outcome of the lengthy US-China discussions which led to the Clinton-Jiang meeting."

The editorial says: "Any improvement in US-China relations can only benefit Australia in the long term, even if they put under question the need for such established links as the ANZUS agreement, China is confident it will be a major world influence. It would be better if it were to do so in cooperation with the US, not in conflict."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO PUSH FOR FASTER FREE TRADE AMONG APEC COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Australia will play a leading role in pushing for a faster freeing-up of regional trade in food, energy and metal products at the November meeting of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leaders in Vancouver, Australian Trade Minister Tim Fischer said.

Fischer said the focus has shifted to the prospects for early liberalization in key sectors which show some promise for exporters and away from the progress of individual countries toward APEC's broader free trade goals.
In 1994, APEC leaders agreed that less developed countries would eliminate trade barriers by the year 2020 and the developed members by 2010.
But APEC is being seen as a regional platform for developing sector-by-sector free trade agreements which could then be broadened into global agreements through the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Fischer said the new focus on energy, food and metal products is the result of the APEC decision to support the US-sponsored proposal for a free trade agreement on information technology, which was subsequently taken up by the WTO.
APEC has 18 members, including the United States, Canada, Mexico, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and other countries in Southeast Asia.

Fischer said Australia's priorities at the Vancouver meeting would be food, energy and non-ferrous metals, but it would also actively support other countries' proposals relating to chemicals, environment services and fish.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE BOURSE TAKES A BEATING ON WALL STREET PLUNGE

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market took a beating Friday morning after a plunge on Wall Street Thursday and analysts predicted the market will remain jittery with nervous investors sidelined.
The All Ordinaries Index dropped 34 points in the first hour of morning trading to 2402. The index fell 6.9 points to close at 2436.1 Thursday.
Analysts attributed the fall in Australian share prices to the plunge of 125 points on Wall Street, which closed at 7831 Thursday.
But the Australian dollar edged up to 69.95 US cents in Friday morning's trading from Thursday's closing level of 69.86 US cents.
Analysts said major Asian share markets plunged due to sell-offs by investors, causing tensions on the Australian share market Thursday.

They said the strong rebound on Wall Street and Hong Kong on Thursday was short-lived because the "demons have not been exorcised," meaning the financial crisis remains serious in Thailand and other Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING GAINS SYMBOLIC TRIUMPH AT SUMMIT -- AT A PRICE

TEXT.P: The joint statement that resulted from the summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin confirmed the impression of many observers that Beijing got more symbolism than substance from the summit, while Washington, by granting symbolism, derived more substance in return, The Straits Times reported Friday in a dispatch from Washington.
The symbolism of a state visit -- 21-gun salute, red-carpet welcome, state banquet in the White House and National Symphony Orchestra concert on the White House lawn -- was important to Beijing.
US reluctance to provide such pomp and circumstance is what held back this summit for two years, the report said.
With this symbolism accorded, Beijing was willing to reciprocate US courtesy by accepting most of the demands of the Clinton administration, the daily said.
In almost every aspect of bilateral relations, there are important objectives that Beijing failed to achieve, the report pointed out.

On the Taiwan issue, which is central to US-mainland Chinese relations, both parties merely reiterated their long-standing differences without making any headway. Beijing's wish for a fourth joint communique fell through, the report said.
Even the minimal request for the cessation of US sales, transfers and leases of advanced weapons to Taiwan was met with a resounding "no", it noted.

The other hope of Beijing to persuade Washington to turn its deep involvement in the Taiwan issue into a "positive factor" by getting Taipei to enter reunification talks with mainland China also failed to materialize, the report pointed out.
On security issues, Beijing has been seeking greater transparency in the US-Japan defense guidelines. Again, it failed to extract any American reassurances on the matter.

Mainland China is also seeking an agreement of "no first use" of nuclear weapons between it and the United States. It has already signed such an agreement with Russia. Considering the compromises Beijing already made by joining the Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Zangger Commission, its failure to obtain an American assurance is startling, the report said.

On trade and economic issues, a number of US sanctions imposed on mainland China following the 1989 Tiananmen incident have been lifted. But a few, such as those covering banking and finance, are still in place.
Similarly, the report pointed out, mainland China made no headway on its preference for a once-and-for-all most-favored-nation trading status, rather than the current annual review.
On mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization, the joint statement merely stated US interest in seeing Beijing become a member.
On the US government's pet topic of human rights, Jiang failed to convince Clinton to respect the mainland Chinese way of doing things, the report said.

Conversely, Washington had it pretty good with an impressive list of achievements, including agreement on military contacts, Beijing's cooperation in solving the Korean problem, environmental protection and control of weapons of mass destruction.
While symbolism is important, Beijing should ask whether it achieved that at too high a cost, the report concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD WEATHER HITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A cold front rolling over Taiwan is bringing down temperatures islandwide.
The Central Weather Bureau indicated on Friday that the cold front will be at its strongest Friday night and Saturday morning.

The bureau predicted temperatures in northern Taiwan will drop to 16-17 degrees Celsius, while central Taiwan will encounter a temperature of about 18 C, and the southern part of the island will be 20 C.
The cold weather will continue till Sunday, a weather forecaster said, adding another cold front may come to chill the island on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENDCAST FOR CEP-1

TEXT.P: An educational forum under the sponsorship of the regional economic body, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, is to be held in Taipei from Nov. 2-4.

The forum, aimed at teaching methods and courses related to occupational education, will bring together some 150 representative from 14 out of the 18 APEC member states to discuss how to improve vocational training and upgrade human resources.
The three-day meeting, to be co-sponsored by the Ministry of Education and several local universities, will include lectures, presentations, exhibitions and visits to educational facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION SHOULD TURN TO ASIA'S 'REAL ECONOMY': GOH

TEXT.P: The Asian currency and stock crisis is nothing to be alarmed about, but attention should turn instead to the real economy, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in Copenhagen, Denmark on Wednesday.

Stating that the recent turmoil was ruled by market sentiment and so had given rise to some uncertainty, he said, "But if we look at the real economy -- hardworking population, savings rate, political stability, investments -- we will be doing all right."

Goh was giving his assessment of the situation at a press conference with Danish and Singapore media on the last day of his official visit in Denmark, The Straits Times reported Friday in a dispatch from Copenhagen.

On the currency readjustment, he pointed out that it was in fact the growing strength of the US dollar that had led to a drop in value of up to 40 percent for currencies in Southeast Asia and up to 15 percent in Europe.
"There's a lot of vigor in the US economy, so in that sense, those who have analyzed this quite calmly are not too alarmed," he said.
