Similar crises had happened in recent years in Sweden, Mexico and Britain, he noted, adding that the region would just have to ride out this present turmoil.

Stressing that the Asian currency shock is coming to an end, he said: "When you drop a stone into the middle of a pool, you're going to see strong ripples. The ripples are now reaching the periphery and they are weakening.
"I would say, give it a few weeks, maybe a few months, and the currency will stabilize and we'll see a clearer picture."
Asian currencies would settle at a lower level than before. "But life goes on. The real economy is the most important factor," he said.
"Growth will be slightly slower, but nothing to be alarmed about," he said.
He said Singapore's exports would still remain competitive against its neighbors because the country was not competing in the same areas but in those with higher value added.
Thailand might grow a little slower but Indonesia and Malaysia would grow more robustly, he commented.
Asked to give his view of how the crisis started, Goh said his theory was that Thailand ran into trouble because it borrowed too much offshore to invest at home.
There was also an interest spread of 6 to 8 percent between its borrowings in Thai baht and US dollars, which gave the market a chance to test whether the baht was over-valued.
Asked if he blamed international financier George Soros for the crisis, Goh said he saw Soros as part of the market.

In the present crisis, the market had over-corrected, he said. "Once it swings one way, the herd instinct follows and it tends to go too far. But after a while, the pendulum will come to a standstill."

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS MEMBERS URGE JIANG TO RELEASE PRISONERS OF CONSCIENCE

TEXT.P: Several members of the US Congress urged mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin at a breakfast meeting Thursday to release prisoners of conscience and allow political and religious freedom in mainland China.

At the breakfast meeting in the Capitol attended by more than 50 members of Congress, House Majority Leader Dick Armey presented Jiang with a letter calling for the release of 30 people he said mainland China is persecuting for their religious beliefs. He also gave Jiang a list of the prisoners.

"When you deny your citizens the most basic right of religious liberty, that becomes the legitimate and urgent concern of free people everywhere. Your policy of religious persecution is the central obstacle to better relations with the United States and the democratic world," Armey said in the letter.

In remarks to Jiang at the breakfast, House Speaker Newt Gingrich told the mainland Chinese leader, "You cannot have economic freedom without political freedom, and you cannot have political freedom without religious freedom."

Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) urged Beijing to release Wei Jingsheng, Wang Dan and other prisoners of conscience on a list she presented to Jiang. She also relayed to Jiang a letter from Cardinal Kung Pin-mei, the exiled bishop of Shanghai now living in Connecticut, calling for the release of four bishops being detained in labor camps and prisons in mainland China.
Pelosi later told the press that Jiang denied that there is any repression of the religious and human rights of his people. Jiang also denied there is any repression in Tibet.
"But despite his evasiveness and the duplicity of his government, I believe the American people know the truth. They can see through the barrage of lies," she said.

A day earlier, Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II (D-Mass.) also delivered to Jiang a letter cosigned by more than 60 members of the House of Representatives, urging him to release Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan, who are serving long jail sentences for peaceful expressions of their political views.

"An improvement in US-China relations certainly is important for a variety of mutually beneficial economic and security reasons. But if China continues to refuse to make progress on human rights, such an improvement in relations will not occur," Kennedy said in the letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10TH ANNIVERSARY OF CROSS-STRAIT PRIVATE EXCHANGES MARKED

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Saturday presided over a ceremony kicking off an exhibition of documents and photographs to mark the 10th anniversary of Taiwan's opening of private exchanges with mainland China.

Addressing the ceremony, Chang, the Republic of China's top official in charge of formulating the government's policies on mainland China, said Taipei has always kept the doors open to cross-strait consultations, hoping Beijing authorities will return to the negotiating table as soon as possible without setting any preconditions.

Reviewing the government's efforts in enhancing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait during the last decade, Chang said Taipei will continue to follow the course in a "steadying the steps so as to walk a long ways" manner.

According to MAC tallies, since Nov. 2, 1987, when the government here began to allow private individuals to travel to mainland China to visit relatives, Taiwan residents have made more than 10 million visits there.
Meanwhile, mainland people made some 220,000 visits to Taiwan for cultural and academic activities or to settle here.

In 10 years, two-way trade across the strait has amounted to nearly US$120 billion, and the Chinese mainland has become Taiwan's third largest trading partner in the world, trailing only the United States and Japan.

The two sides exchanged over 140 million letters and 360 million phone calls during the last decade, which have undeniably helped to diminish hostility and better understanding across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said.

To facilitate private exchanges with mainland China, the government devised the Mainland Affairs Task Force under the Executive Yuan in 1988 following the formal opening of private visits to mainland China in November 1987.

The task force was upgraded into the Mainland Affairs Council on Oct. 18, 1990. One month later on Nov. 21 the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was established as an intermediary organization to handle technical problems arising from increased private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
The SEF has also since taken over some of the cross-strait functions the ROC Red Cross Society began performing in 1987.
Not longer after, Beijing set up the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) as a counterpart to Taipei's SEF.

Under joint SEF-ARATS efforts, the "Koo-Wang talks" were held in Singapore in April 1993, marking the first and so far only high-level cross-strait talks since the communists took control of the Chinese mainland in 1949.
The talks are so named because they were conducted by SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

The top negotiators from both sides were originally scheduled to meet again for a second-round of talks in the second half of 1995. But Beijing unilaterally suspended the rendezvous after President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June that year. Beijing also consequently closed other dialogue channels formulated in the first Koo-Wang meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE OFFICIALS WELCOME CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Philippine Foreign Affairs officials welcomed the summit between the heads of the United States and mainland China, saying any improvement in Washington-Beijing relations would be beneficial to the Philippines and the entire region as well.

"Any improvement on US-China relations is good for the Philippines because it makes for regional security," Foreign Affairs Undersecretary Rodolfo Severino told reporters when asked to comment on the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
"Certainly, you don't want those giants fighting," Severino added.

Clinton and Jiang met in Washington on Thursday for the first formal US-mainland Chinese summit since 1989, when then President George Bush went to mainland China -- only months before the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square put a freeze on their relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIAN WOMEN HAVE HIGH FERTILITY RATE

TEXT.P: On average, a Saudi Arabian woman has 7.2 children, according to a study conducted by the King Faisal University.
The survey found that the average in the country's Eastern province is even higher, at 7.4 children.
According to Dr. Abu Sufian, the latest survey shows that Saudi Arabian women have one of the highest fertility rates in the world.
It showed that only 0.08 percent of Saudi Arabian women are childless.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUPS TO PROTEST IN LOS ANGELES AGAINST JIANG
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Members of overseas Taiwan communities based in southern California will stage protests against mainland China's President Jiang Zemin this weekend over Beijing's hegemony, in a gesture to show the world the Taiwan people's determination to defend their nation's sovereignty.

One of the organizers, Huang Chien-san, said the protests are a follow-up to Wednesday's protest in Washington against Jiang's meeting with US President Bill Clinton, adding that one protest will be held on Saturday evening in front of the hotel where Jiang is scheduled to stay and another one where Jiang is to have lunch on Sunday. More supporters from northern California will also gather in Los Angeles on Sunday to take part in the protests, he added.

In addition to the Taiwan issue, Huang said Taiwan communities in California will protest to Jiang over Beijing's human rights abuses, lack of religious freedom, prison labor, and its repressive control of Tibet and the far western Xinjiang province, as well as other issues such as military threats to neighboring countries and arms proliferation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PRESS REPORTS YELTSIN'S UPCOMING VISIT

TEXT.P: Russian President Boris Yeltsin's upcoming visit to mainland China shared the spotlight in Beijing Friday with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's summit meeting in Washington.

News about Jiang's summit meeting with President Bill Clinton Wednesday at the White House dominated the front pages of all newspapers in Beijing Friday. Russian President Boris Yeltsin's visit on Nov. 9-11 was also prominently reported on the front pages of the People's Daily and the Economic News. The latter is the organ newspaper of the State Council.

The reporting of the Russian leader's state visit in the two most important mouthpieces of the communist Chinese government indicates that Beijing has attached equal importance to Yeltsin's visit and Beijing's newly-found relationship with Washington, an analyst said.

Yeltsin's visit in Beijing, in the wake of Jiang's forging "strategic partnership" in Washington, will certainly be the focus of attention of all political observers in the world, the analyst added. (by Chang Lung)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST REGULAR INTERNET USERS ARE MALE, YOUNG AND HIGHLY EDUCATED

TEXT.P: There are some 940,000 regular Internet users in Taiwan, the majority of whom are young, highly educated males, according to the results of a survey made public in the latest version of the Commonwealth monthly magazine.

The results show that 5.7 percent of some 1,336 survey respondents aged over 15 were listed as regular Internet users, who used the Internet for at least two hours every week for the past three months. Based on this figure, regular Internet users in Taiwan are estimated to be around 940,000, the magazine said.
Seventy percent of these users are male and 80 percent of them are below the age of 40, educated at least to bachelor degree-level.
Personal interest was cited by 82 percent of the respondents as being the leading reason for using the Internet, followed by entertainment (44 percent) and work (25 percent).

Thirty-seven percent of the regular users said that the Internet has become an indispensable part of their lives, while 49 percent feel that Internet is a little important to their lives. Only 14 percent said they did not care whether or not there is Internet.

Sixty-five percent of the regular Internet users said that they have the habit of reading advertisements on the Internet. The survey also found that regular users have active social lives and also like to learn new things.
The telephone poll, which was conducted on Oct. 4-5, interviewed 1,336 people aged over 15 years around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELSANG TAKLA NAMED TO HEAD TIBET FOUNDATION HERE

TEXT.P: Elsang Takla, the London representative of the Dalai Lama, has been appointed by the Tibetan spiritual leader to head a planned Tibetan cultural foundation in Taiwan, the China Time Express reported on Friday.

An organizer in charge of the establishment of the "Dalai Lama Tibetan Religious and Cultural Foundation" in Taipei said the Dalai Lama has designated four representatives based in Dharmsala, northern India, to make preparations and arrangements for the setting up of the foundation here, according to the report.
The four men are expected to be allowed to come to Taiwan in early November, while Elsang Takla, a female lama, will head the foundation, it said.

The purpose of the establishment of the foundation, which was approved by the Republic of China government in March, is to facilitate cultural, educational and religious exchanges between Taiwan and the Tibetan government-in-exile, the report said, adding that National Sun Yat-Sen University has promised to offer two scholarships for Tibetan students living in exile in India and Nepal.

Tashi Tsering, vice cultural and education minister of the Tibetan government-in-exile, who is currently in Taiwan to attend a Buddhist seminar slated to be held on Sunday, was quoted by the report as saying that the Dalai Lama has very high expectations of the foundation, the purpose of which will be to focus only on bilateral civilian exchanges.
He stressed that the foundation will not get involved in any political issues in order not to escalate tensions between Taiwan and mainland China, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: DNA TEST CONFIRMS KIDNAP SUSPECT INVOLVED IN TRIPLE SLAYING

TEXT.P: A DNA test has confirmed that a suspect wanted for the kidnap and murder of the daughter of a local TV actress was also involved in last week's slaying of a surgeon, his wife and a nurse at the surgeon's plastic surgery clinic in Taipei, according to the police.

Comparing blood samples taken from the suspect's son with semen found in the body of nurse Cheng Wen-yu, forensic scientists are almost certain that the semen belongs to Chen Chin-hsing, the notorious fugitive wanted for kidnapping and killing Pai Hsiao-yen in April.

Cheng, noted plastic surgeon Fang Pao-fang and his wife were found dead on Oct. 23 by a cleaner at Fang's clinic. All three had been killed with a single bullet to the head, while semen found in Cheng's body suggested that she had also been raped or molested before being killed.

Although no motive has yet been established and no suspect has been apprehended in the case thus far, police are of the opinion that it was the work of Chen and his accomplice in the Pai kidnapping, Kao Tien-ming.

One theory postulates that the two fugitives, under pressure from their months in hiding, forced Dr. Fang to alter their appearances by surgery to escape the police dragnet, killing Fang and the other two in the clinic immediately afterwards.

Although police were able to collect a number of blood samples from the crime scene, they were unable to ascertain which, if any, belonged to either of the two suspects. Police therefore also took blood samples from Chen's three-year-old son which they obtained from a hospital which treated the child in August.

Although the test results support the investigators' suspicions that Chen was involved in the triple murder, a senior police official leading the investigation said that without samples from Chen himself, the DNA test results are no more than circumstantial evidence which only suggests an avenue for investigation.

Although a third accomplice in the Pai kidnapping, Lin Chun-sheng, committed suicide on Aug. 19 after being cornered by police in a chance encounter, Chen and Kao have eluded an intensive police manhunt, escaping by the skin of their teeth on several occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG HAS SHOWN UP MAINLAND CHINA'S WEAKNESSES

TEXT.P: As Asia's financial markets and currencies have unraveled over the past few months, mainland China has stood apart from the turmoil, seemingly immune to the contagion that has gripped the region, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

It may show some of the symptoms of its beleaguered neighbors -- an oversupplied property market, an indebted banking sector, manufacturing industry squeezed by overcapacity and rising fixed costs and an economy generally hampered by corruption and cronyism, the WTO report said.

But, in other respects, the WTO pointed out, mainland China is different. The foreign capital inflows into the country are mostly for long-term fixed investments, rather than short-term lending -- the "hot money" that destabilized countries such as Thailand.
Foreign portfolio investment in mainland China is equivalent to less than 0.5 percent of GDP and even the fledging foreign currency stock markets are driven by local investors.

Foreign commercial lending has grown, but with external debt of around US$130 billion at the end of last year, mainland China's debt-to-GNP ratio is 20 percent, among the lowest in Asia, the WTO report said.
Mainland China's currency is not yet convertible on the capital account. The exchange rate remains strictly government-controlled and defended by over US$130 billion in foreign exchange reserves.

And in mainland China, where exports are soaring, sentiment suggests the currency is, if anything, undervalued: "If they freed the renminbi, it would appreciate," Brewer Stone, head of Prudential Securities in Shanghai, was quoted as saying.
In short, foreign investors are hard put to mount an assault on either mainland China's currency or its stock markets.

However, the upheaval in Hong Kong last week has offered a reminder of the weaknesses of the mainland Chinese economy and how turbulence in Hong Kong, which is intimately involved in the reform on the mainland, has implications for mainland China, according to the WTO report.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTHLY PENSION FOR ELDERLY IN TAIPEI COUNTY IF KMT WINS COUNTY CHIEF ELECTION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday offered to provide old people in Taipei County with a monthly pension, as part of efforts to help his ruling Kuomintang (KMT) candidate win the election for county chief on Nov. 29.

Lee, in his capacity as KMT chairman, said during campaign activities that people aged over 65 in Taipei County will receive a NT$5,000 monthly pension if his party's candidate -- Hsieh Shen-shan -- is elected magistrate of the county, which is currently under the control of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"I promise that old people in Taipei County will receive a NT$5,000 pension every month," Lee said, adding that the pension will be issued monthly, unlike the current situation in the county whereby the elderly receive the pension "only three or four months" out of each year.

Pensions for the elderly was one of the DPP's major campaign slogans in the last local elections, but after honoring their campaign promises for a short time, most of the DPP-controlled cities and counties halted the pension programs. However, Taipei County, governed by You Chin, who is in his second term, is still carrying out the program, at least for a few months of each year.
Lee's remarks are being seen as a turnabout in the KMT's campaign policy, as the party's cultural affairs department has recently criticized the DPP's policy of promoting the pension system.

If Hsieh wins the election and honors Lee's promise, it will cost the Taipei County government an estimated NT$7 billion a year to pay the monthly pensions to the approximately 115,000 elderly residents of the county.
